They didn't care and woman/man (couldn't tell) working there admitted they missed the order completely. Blew it off like it's no big deal, not even an apology.  Won't be eating here again, mistakes happen but good customer service is how you handle the situation. Take some accountability for your restaurant and apologize...
author: Kat C.

description: Exquisite service and very good pizza - not used to the cornmeal crust pizza so it looked a bit impressive to me, first time, with its high, deep crust and toppings. When you start having it can be addictive, though - enjoyed the experience!
author: VIORICA C.

description:
I'd say their pizza is just meh. I've never been a fan of deep dish, but my hubby wanted to come here yesterday so I figured I'd try their thin crust instead. I've had their deep dish before and didn't care for it at all. Too runny, saucy, oily and doughy for my taste. I had their thin crust classic combo and again, just meh. I've definitely had better. It was nothing out of the ordinary- just your regular, run of the mill, combo pizzas. We also ordered their roasted broccolini and I actually preferred that over the pizza!

As for their service, we had the gal with the short, black hair and bangs and heavy eyeliner. She looked annoyed taking our order and given the music is practically blasting in the restaurant, I could barely hear her. She didn't bother bringing out water until we asked for it and even that was a bit of a wait. She also didn't bother to check on us if we needed anything despite the several times she passed by our table. We had to ask other servers walking by if we needed anything.

So again, just an overall meh experience.
author: Lainey C.

description: Best gluten free pizza in SF, hands down. It's can get pretty busy and the staff is always able to handle it, but the food more then makes up for it.
author: Joshua P.

description: Hands Down! This place serves one of the best baked chicken wings in the whole of SF!  Their Spicy baked wings was so tender, juicy and perfectly cooked. Pizza on the other hand was delicious and full of flavors. We customized our deep dish pizza with half all star and half vegetarian selection. Even though we had to wait 10 minutes more than our actual reservation time, it was totally worth it!
author: Anusha K.

description: Little Star Pizza pizza is delicious! We tasted at least half the pizza's on their menu and can honestly say we loved them all.  And the manager is so sweet. They donated 13 pizza's to our hardworking teachers.  I heard several teachers say Little Star Pizza is their favorite! Thank you LSP, we love you!!!
author: Hawks H.

description:
Deep dish pizza in one of my favorite parts in the city? Fuck yea!
I started with a pear cider and the liquid came looking like 7up. But delicious alcoholic 7up
Then we had the wings and their garlic bread for the appetizer portion. The wings were super spicy for me (I can barely gave hot Cheetos!) but they were so good. One downside is that they weren't crunchy... That would've made all the difference! 
The garlic bread came in just a loaf, a side of butter and 2 cloves of garlic. To quote my friend, "if this garlic bread was a girl I would fuck it" but I personally thought the garlic bread could've been put together before showing up for the party. But I can't deny the fact that the bread was exceptionally crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside and after rubbing the cloves of garlic and slapping on some butter on it was like a match made in heaven.

Now for the grand finale, we had the original deep dish pizza. There was a barricade of a crunchy and flaky crust around the entire pizza capturing a thick layer of dough, tomatoes, mushrooms, and sausages. It was to DIE FOR. I can't compare it to deep dish pizza I've had in Chicago but it's by far the best I've had in San Francisco!
author: Linda K.

description: Pizza took over 2 and 1/2 hours to deliver. Completely ruined our experience.  They've done this before along with mixing up my order and delivering the wrong type of pizza.
author: anthony k.

description: I found it underwhelming, and the staff not so friendly! I had asked for no pork on my pizza, and My half was covered, so my boyfriend got a whole pizza to his self. I get it things happen, but when I ordered it I asked three times for them to make sure my half didnt have pork.
author: Mariah L.

description: Good atmosphere, attentive service...just okay pizza. I love Chicago style pizza, and this one is all right. It's not the best or the worst of it. I wish I had more advice to offer...but I'm coming up short. I wouldn't exactly call this restaurant "child friendly" - as it's a tad more upscale than your traditional pizza joint. However, my 2 year old did just fine here. Probably best for small groups plus one, maybe two children, tops.
author: Amber L.

description:
Little Star Pizza, where have you been all my life? The corn meal crust was addicting! I came on a Sunday with the family right after running the Nike Women's Half Marathon and I was HUNGRY. We arrive before the restaurant opened and ended up calling in our order as we waited for them to open. We ordered a large Little Star deep dish pizza, which consisted of  spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic for $25. This was a perfect size for 3 to share. 

Once the restaurant opened and we were seated, we didn't have to wait too much longer for our pizza to be ready. Overall, the pizza and service was great and I will definitely be back the next time I'm craving some deep dish pizza.
author: Steph F.

description:
Been loving this pizza for a while and I hate to give a bad review but it's gone down hill and they've raised their prices.

I get their small thin crust veggie for $21. I've always thought it was kind of little. Most small pizzas are at least a reasonable size. Theirs, not so much. But it's usually delicious so there's that.  I go in the other day and they've raised the price to $25. Seriously. I pick up and get back with my pizza, only a block away and the crust is nice and crunchy but the center is soggy and undercooked. For $25. I was on my lunch break so I couldn't take it back and i ate around the center. It was disgusting and not enough food for my long work day. Not ok.
author: Ty M.

description: Craving for some pizza and stopped by sidewalk juice in the mission so decided to check this place out and so glad we did,  the pizza is delicious. The employees are really nice as well. I'd highly recommend checking this place out for the deep dish, I was just in Chicago and the pizza here is very similar.
author: Cheryl P.

description: We found this place on our way to Bart after the parade. Great little place. Wife and I started with the sourdough and roasted garlic. Excellent stuff. Then we had the All Star deep dish. Very,very good pizza. Plenty of meat, sauce and melted cheese goodness with a crust that's even better. Next time we are in the Mission, we'll definitely stop by.
author: Mark D.

description:
I've only dined in at the one on Divis but I consistently order takeout from here thanks to Caviar. The deep dish really hits the spot for me and I almost always go with the Classic. It's called the Classic for a reason--you simply cannot go wrong with it!

I'm not a fan of bell peppers so I usually get those replaced with spinach, which goes perfectly with their sausage, mushrooms, and onions. The tomatoes are never overly acidic, the crust always stays nice and crunchy (even though it probably takes 30 minutes for them to deliver since I'm out in the Aves), and there's a thoughtful layer of cheese holding everything under the tomatoes together. 

Hot, cold, morning, night--the deep dish always tastes great! Even though I think Caviar is totally overpriced, I'm glad Little Star does business with them because the food is so good it's the only restaurant we use it for!
author: Tiffany H.

description: LOVE the Little Star (vegetarian) pizza. I visit here every time I'm in the city. I love the crust of the pizza because it's not doughy but reminds me of corn bread texture more. Wish they had one in LA! :(
author: Rebekah P.

description:
Little Star Pizza is one of the best pizza joints in the Mission! I've tried deep dish, thin, and a ton of appetizers. The food is awesome every time!

My favorite thing to order is the white pie pizza. The white pie dies not have traditional marinara sauce but instead is topped with cheese and ricotta, zucchini, and delicious tomatoes. I absolutely love this pizza! Some delish appetizers to try are the buffalo wings and the caprese salad. The buffalo wings taste fresh and crisp- love dippin' em in ranch. The caprese salad also has fantastic flavors- fresh mozzarella, juicy tomatoes, olives, balsamic vinegar, and olive oil. A perfect, classic caprese!

Love the service, love the location, love the pizza!
author: Nicole W.

description:
This would have been a 5-star review had it not been for our really horrendous waiter/host. My bf and I arrived, asking for a table of 8 and were told that we can't be seated until the rest of party arrives. That was understandable so we waited for our friends. 30 mins later, we have 7 of our party and gave the host an update. He tells us that they need all members of our party in order to seat us. Mind you, as we're waiting, all the tables are being seated. NONE SAVED FOR OUR PARTY OF 8, WHEN WE WERE WAITING FOR JUST ONE MORE PERSON. Was I infuriated? YES! Finally our last member arrived and our host had the audacity to ask us to wait for another table to clear up so he can combine two small tables.. or get crammed together at a different table. He lost a star right then and there. 

Venting aside, the food is amazing. I'm not a fan of deep dish pizza (thin crust lover for life), but I'd go back here for the deep dish pizza! Both deep dish and thin crust are definitely worth the visit. I hope next time we have a better host or at least someone with common sense. 

Oh btw, there is only one bathroom. ONE BATHROOM.
author: Sue T.

description: They have the best deep dish pizza - the little star pizza is my favorite and a must have! They also have some very unique toppings - the California for example has balsamic! My first with balsamic on a pizza and I loved that! I've come here a few times and food has never disappointed. The only -ve is that the folks working there seem to rush you into finishing your food which we didn't like :(
author: Neha K.

description:
I've been here twice, and I think they make solid deep dish pizza. My partner raves about the Little Star Pizza, which I guess is a good choice if you are a vegetarian. I thought the Classic was quite tasty, and 2 large deep dish pizzas was just the right amount for 4 people. 

In the past, I felt the server was a bit inattentive and rude, but the last time I went, we had a very personable and friendly server. If I had to choose between Zachary's and Little Star, I think I would pick the former maybe because the ambience is more low-key and reminds me of a relaxed, chill place where you can hang with a few buddies eating pizza and drinking beer. Little Star feels like a place for a more grown-up/chic experience, but the pizza is great no matter what your ambience-preference :)
author: Keith H.

description:
Pizza and wings. What more do you really need in life? Luckily, Little Star has both...AND WINE! Perfetto. 

Since giving up the glutens, I'm always on a quest to find a legit gluten-free pizza. This place is spot on. They had a special pie topped with chorizo (actual sausage pieces...not like the ground beef crumble it is sometimes), basil, and jalapeños. I threw some extra shredded motz because that's how I do. Fantastic. Although the jalaps were a little too spicy for me. My boyfriend got the same pizza but with extra glutens and was complaining that they weren't hot at all for him (the jalaps, not the glutens). So either I got lucky with the spicy peppers on mine, or his taste buds don't really work anymore due to the insane level of fire he likes with his spicy foods. 

There's a place in Chicago that makes my most favoritest wings ever. This is the first place I've found that comes really close. They are smoky, not slimy, and have a fantastic rub. Not super saucy either. 

It was packed on a Saturday night. We only had to wait a few minutes for our table and got a drink at the front bar in the meantime. The staff was SO nice. All of them, from the hostess to the bartender to our waiter. So much so, we wondered what we did to deserve such politeness. Or maybe my boyfriend got confused and thought he was tipping $2 but gave them a $20 for our drinks...
author: Carol M.

description:
Ever since having deep dish pizza for the first time at Zachary's, I was looking forward to dining at Little Star Pizza. They're pretty busy, so expect a wait! But don't worry, they have a bar in the front, so you can drink while you wait. They use a lot of wood furniture, and the lighting of this place is pretty dark. 

Happy Hour from Monday-Friday (3pm-6pm)
$1 off all draft beers
$4 red or white house wines
All small sized appetizers $5

- Garlic Bread ($5): comes with bread, butter, and a bulb of roasted garlic, so you have to squeeze out the garlic yourself! DIY garlic bread - pretty cool!
- Caprese Salad: fresh mozzarella, tomatoes, and basil. This dish was pretty refreshing!
- Vegetarian Pizza (Small: $18, Large: $25): mushrooms, olives, onions, garlic, and zucchini. Because it was a vegetarian pizza, it felt like a light pizza.

Their appetizers and pizza were both delicious, so I definitely wouldn't mind coming back for more!
author: Christine S.

description:
Best Deep Dish Pizza I've had in a while. I've tried Patxi which appears to have been opening a bunch of different locations within California and Little Star is definitely ahead of them. 

We got the Class Little Star Pizza with added pepperonis and garlic and I will say that their ingredients are high quality and their crust was delicious. 

Great spot for a small group or a date.
author: Warren K.

description:
Group of 5 on Sunday around 7pm. Got a large Classic and a large Little Star (both deep dish). They told us the pizza would take 30 min but I'm pretty sure it came within 15 min. I'm not a deep dish lover, but was pretty blown away by the Little Star  -- the spinach + the tomato sauce really blended well and melted in my mouth! The classic was OK, just tasted like normal pizza. Two larges were too much for us though. Don't underestimate the portion size of deep dish!

The service was great and we had a good time. I'd come back here again to have the Little Star and maybe to try their thin crust (which I'm more a fan of).
author: Elisa L.

description:
OK, so maybe I should've taken the chance and tried the deep dish pizza here like many other Yelpers raved about... but instead, the boyfriend and I opted for the thin crust pizza.  We ordered the Italian combo and added gorgonzola and started off with a large size of the mixed salad.  The salad was good and definitely could've fed 4 -- hey, I like my salads! -- and they weren't stingy on the toppings for the pizza -- but the pizza was just OK.  The vegetables overpowered the meat and there was nothing about it that really "wow'd" me.

However, the service was excellent throughout our entire meal!  They didn't mind our substitutions, our plates were picked up, the food came out in a decent time, our drinks were consistently refilled, and the server himself was very friendly.  The restaurant itself has dark, mood style lighting.  Once my eyes adjusted to it, it wasn't a big problem for me.

Next time I visit the Bay, I'll have to try their deep dish pizza and hopefully my rating will be bumped up!
author: Annie P.

description:
Damn, yo.

Little Star's pizza crust is the foundation of all things good that happen in their magical kitchen. Their secret? Cornmeal! You can taste it in every bite, whether you get thin crust or deep dish. It's like no other pizza crust you've ever tasted. 

My fave pizza there is the Little Star, and thin crust cheese, pesto and fresh tomatoes or sun-dried tomatoes. I just had the latter, and my taste buds exploded. I'm. In. Heaven.
author: Gabriela W.

description: One of the best vegetarian pizza in the city. It breaks my heart to read some people's comments complaining about having to call to the waiter for more water because it was a busy night. Really!
author: Frances G.

description:
Pizza is delicious assuming you can get one. Really unreliable with orders and staff is the worst. Spend more time posing than actually working.  Ordered pizza told it will be 30 min , one hour later I'm told it's on it's way. Complain to the manager where I'm told they lost the order and had to reorder, so there was never a time it was on its way. 
So this stuff happens completely understandable but this was the 2nd time in a few weeks this has happened and they were not busy.
It's just bad staff who don't know what they are doing, totally fixable.
author: Peter R.

description:
I came here in early October and was pleased to find the place decked out with spider webs across the bar and adorning the ceiling. There was a tombstone over the (out of order?) ATM along with other fun decorations around. 

I ordered a split large deep-dish pizza, half Little Star and half Mediterranean. Although both types were delicious, I had a hard time distinguishing the flavor between the two because they were so similar, with the exception of the flavorful olives in the Mediterranean. It wasn't a bad thing, but they both taste very similar. 

The food was great, but the service was a bit slow. I can understand that they're busy on a Friday night, but I had to desperately flag down a waiter when I wanted more water and the check. It shouldn't be that difficult to satisfy my parched mouth, especially at a restaurant! 

Overall, I loved the decorations and the taste of the pizza, but the service was mediocre. I don't think I'll be back.
author: Erika S.

description:
Wanted to grab something juicy for our weekend dinner out! Deep dish pizzas were on our minds so I suggested trying this place out. I had always passed by it before and I've head good things about the pizza.

We decided to get the Little Star deep dish pizza as a large with added salami. The waitress told us it would be a 30 minute wait but it took maybe a little over ten minutes. We ordered beers in the meantime (Belgian Ale and a Lagunitas) so it was fine. 

I was really wary about getting the large because I thought it would be too much for two, but we handled it just fine. The size wasn't as alarming as I thought and to be frank we both thought it would be a deeper dish pizza. I thought I would only be able to eat one slice but I was able to eat 2 and a half and we left with about one slice each for left overs. 

Flavor-wise, I thought it was pretty good. The spinach, feta, mushroom, garlic is such a great combo. The salami was a good idea for an addition because it adds some more saltiness to the mixture. The crust was really good, I truly enjoyed the cornmeal crust here. 

Overall good experience. I would be interested to try out their thin pizzas!
author: Sofia R.

description:
There's something about Little Star that offers a genuinely authentic SF vibe. It could be the bar area, where you can grab a beer, a personal pizza, and gab with the people working behind the bar while watching the game/Star Trek. It could be the jukebox, which plays a steady stream of old hits, or it could be the staff, who are warm and accommodating.

The food definitely helps too!!! 

Because mozzarella is a bit too much for my stomach, I typically order A) The California thin crust w/ vegan cheese (they use Daiya here) or B) A "Build Your Own" Deep Dish with a pesto base. While the pesto contains parmesan, it does not bother my digestion at all. The chicken wings are also hellllla good (especially if you get them "extra crispy" with a side of ranch ;)). Mixed salad and goddess salad are my fav appetizer.

I typically order for takeout from here but every dine-in experience has been stellar.

Oh, and try the deep dish crust with honey. It's a really nice way to finish off a pie.
author: Megan D.

description: service is not ok but food is good. seasonal appetizer of cauliflower must try :)
author: Freya-Loki O.

description:
Came here after HH since we were still hungry and Little Star was just around the corner.

We had a group of 6, which was about a 1.5 hr wait. I was surprised because there were only two other names in front of us on the list and there was no one else waiting.

Initially, we decided to wait, but after 15 mins, we decided to just order a pizza to go and eat it at our friend's place a block away. They apologized for the long wait, but we understood it's not their fault. We ordered a large, half classic and half special. Yes, make sure you check the special pizza of the day. The pizza takes 30 mins to make.

Since we had time to kill, we sat by the bar and ordered a few beers. The bartender noticed once of our friends wasn't drinking and offered her some wine tastings. Very nice and thoughtful of her. We ended up getting 3 tastings, all reds and all delicious. I would have definitely ordered a glass if our pizza didn't come out. 5 stars to her and the wonderful staff that's helpful and welcoming.

Once our pizza came out, we paid for it and left. 5 mins later, we all dug in and enjoyed ourselves a nice hearty grainy crunchy cornmeal crust pizza that isn't too doughy with loads of toppings. When you pick up the slice, you'll be surprised how heavy it is and how the crust doesn't bend and keeps those toppings in place. All the toppings blend together so well making a great combination. The special had jalapenos too, definitely won me over (they were actually spicy!) I haven't gone to chicago yet, but the pizza from Little Star is just fabulous, flavorful, and definitely filling. I couldn't eat more than one slice no matter how badly I wanted another slice.

My goal is still to dine here one night.
author: Stephanie L.

description: I just went here the other day and got my FIRST deep dish pizza. SUPER EXCITED. I think I went with the classic large. I'll probably go with a smaller quanity next time. I could barely finish one piece before I felt stuffed. I don't know if this is the BEST deep dish in the city, since it's literally the only deep dish I have ever tried. But I'm into it. I'll definitely be coming back.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
Everyone has told me over and over again that little star was an amazing place to get pizza. So I rolled the dice and ordered from
Door dash .... The crust was good but it's definitely not one of my top places... Spent 45$ for a pizza and wings ... Seems like they just took a ladle of tomato sauce and dumped it on top...., probably won't order again
author: Liliana L.

description:
Stopped here for lunch on a Saturday afternoon and five of us each got a personal pizza and traded slices so we could all try something different. I'm a fan.

- great crust
- affordable
- even the veggie pizza was good
- barbecue chicken? YES PLEASE!
- service isn't super perky but they split up five checks without complaining or looking annoyed about it so in my book that's a thumbs up. 

I will definitely come back for the deep dish pizza!
author: Aivy C.

description:
My boyfriend and I are on vacation from Hawaii and wanted to try Little Star Pizza since their reviews and ratings are awesome. We ordered The City deep dish pizza with pesto online and went to pick it up. Upon entering the restaurant, no one acknowledged my boyfriend and I, so we just sat and waited for our pizza since according to the online tracking, it wasn't ready yet. They called our name at the estimated time it would be ready, which was great since I called for a Lyft at the same time. We got back to our hotel and realized they didn't even get our order right. We ended up with a thin crust cheese pizza with pesto instead. BORING! So disappointing! To top it off, I tried calling the restaurant at the number that is listed on yelp (415-551-7827) and the number on the receipt (510-332-3912). The number on yelp said the restaurant was already closed. They're supposed to close at 10pm and it was only around 9:30pm when I called. I called the number on the receipt which isn't even the number for Little Star Pizza. It was some lady's business. Try calling it, I dare you. I looked at the online tracking and it said you can call, email, or chat with a live person 24 hours a day for your order issues. Such crap! There is no number online that is listed to speak to a live person. Really hoping we'll compensated somehow for our horrible first and probably last experience ordering from Little Star Pizza. 

**Addendum 12/3/16**
Dj, one of the restaurant managers responded to my complaint very quickly. He was very apologetic for our experience and reimbursed our whole bill. Thank you Dj!
author: Ashley N.

description:
For all the pizza lovers... come here. As the famous quotes of Yelp " Yay! I'm a fan." This place was suggested to me by one of my coworkers and I was in the area and so we decided to try this place out.  Deep dish heaven. Like Paxti's? This place is slightly better because of the crust. 

Try for yourself and you will not be disappointed.
author: Mariethonnie M.

description: My SO's boss told him about this spot and we finally were able to come last week after picking up our eldest from school. Came here with our family of four one kid, one toddler, and two adults. We ordered garlic bread which is to die for it came with freshly warm bread, 2 heads of roasted garlic, and a nice creamy butter which when put together tasted like heaven. We also got a pepperoni and mushroom deep dish. It was delicious!! Asides from my kids spilling water left and right the waiter and host were very friendly and hospitable. They understood and gave us lots of napkins. Poor waiter had just clocked in and was in a hurry with getting us our food and he ended up dropping our pizza and because we had to wait longer he gave us 50% off our total bill. SWEET!! Will definitely be coming back and as well as recommending this spot too.
author: Tina L.

description: I love this place-- eating here and via Caviar has always been great. We would try different dishes every now and again and everything always had a certain level of quality. Until we decided to order a wedge salad through Caviar tonight. I mean, so bad. It was chunks of iceberg with tiny specks of bacon. No tomato, no bleu cheese. Nothing that would make this salad a "wedge salad"
author: Mika S.

description:
Little Star Pizza was absolutely delicious! Although I have bookmarked many San Francisco places to eat, this one was not on my bookmarks list! Luckily, my friend heard great things about Little Star Pizza by word-of-mouth and convinced me to try this hyped up pizza place out for myself.

We walked in on a rainy day and the tiny pizza restaurant was semi-packed around 4:00PM on a Saturday. The restaurant definitely filled up as dinner time came closer. My friend and I were seated almost immediately. Since it was happy hour (much to our surprise), we took advantage of the Happy Hour Spicy Chicken Wings price as well as ordered a Deep Dish Pizza. Another surprise - we didn't know that we could pick two flavors on our deep dish pizza so we ended up ordering half Little Star and half Classic. While I loved the Classic more and my friend enjoyed Little Star more, both of these different toppings were amazing. What really caught the attention of my taste buds was the delicious deep dish pizza's crust. It tastes similar to one of those delicious breadsticks that a lot of Italian restaurants provide their customers for free, but ten times better. Crisp on the outside, chewy on the inside - yum! Also, our waiter was very funny and friendly as he helped us decide what pizza toppings to order. Price-wise, it definitely is your pricier pizza place but hey, you're paying for quality pizza!

Even when I took a few slices home to heat up as leftovers, the pizza still tasted great! Little Star Pizza, you definitely live up to your hype.
author: Michelle S.

description: If your server is unavailable, no one else is willing to serve and act like deers in headlights. Especially the hipster with the mustache and top hat. He's a real winner...
author: Brittany R.

description: Unfortunately they do not deliver, so we ordered it through door dash. The deep dish was pretty good and like $10 cheaper than another place we were going to order from. I feel like the crust needed a little more salt or something, but I would still recommend to try it :)
author: Audrey M.

description:
Absolutely delicious. 

This place is really small, but we were lucky to be seated at a table immediately because we were a party of two.

Because it was our first time eating here, we needed help with the menu options and just weren't sure where to start because there are so many good looking options and there was a "special" pizza also available for order. 

Our waitress was kind, patient and very helpful in making suggestions and explaining the menu options.

We ordered: 

Spicy chicken wings- tender, well seasoned, crispy and delicious. 

Deep dish 1/2 little star, 1/2 bacon special pizza- delicious, hot, perfectly cooked and fresh!
author: Andreea M.

description: I wish the description on Caviar mentioned the cornmeal crust for deep dish. Was not a far, only ate a slice and the aftertaste wasn't good. Cheese and tomato sauce were tasty though. Not that this is little stars fault but they do mention the prefer customers to use caviar for delivery. That experience was not good. I'm 1.8 miles from the location. The Caviar driver took 50 minutes to get to me. At 30 minutes I mapped it and it said with traffic it would take 10 minutes to get to my location. I watched the driver on the app and she took the craziest course, going so out of the way that I don't think she's ever delivered to this city before. Overall experience was not positive.
author: J A.

description:
Pizza was really good. I've had Blue Line Pizza in Westlake in Daly City, and the deep dish marinara here at Little star tastes better, in my opinion.

Service was good, though the place was crowded on a Tuesday night. Very simple place, but made it feel comfortable. Drawbacks? Not too spacious for a large crowd. But it's ok, you can accommodate yourself and your group. Will return.
author: Audis V.

description: I ate the signature "Little Star" deep dish and it was really good.  Fresh tomato pizza sauce, mushrooms, onions, and roasted garlic - so good.  I'm not a huge fan of corn meal in the crust, but that's their thing.  Great value and good draft beer selection.
author: Les J.

description:
I love Little Star - if anyone ever asks for food recommendations in SF this is ALWAYS my #1 suggestion. I don't know why this place is rated lower than the Divisadero location. Personally, I prefer this location over Divisidero because I feel as though it's easier to park around here. It looks way less ghetto than the other one in SF.

MILES above blue line pizza.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Unfortunately, Little Star Pizza doesn't deliver. Thankfully, we live 6 blocks away - a bit of a walk, but worth it for a random deep dish crave.

My boyfriend special ordered a deep dish pizza with a bunch of stuff, most of which I don't remember, but I DO remember the chicken. I remember it because I have pretty much never liked chicken I've had on any pizza (it always comes out dry & overcooked) so pretty much avoid adding it as a topping. But Little Star's chicken was crazy tender! 

So just another tidbit when it comes to ordering here.. their chicken topping on their deep dish pizzas is great.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I'm not really a pizza person but when I do eat it, I prefer a thin crispy crust all rustic looking with tons of veggies. 

And then there's Little Star. I had heard of the wait and it deterred me for so long. 

Along comes a Saturday when I decided to throw away my 2 1/2 hours of exercise by consuming pizza. No wait during lunch on a weekend, awesome. Restaurant was practically empty. 
They offer personal sized pizzas during lunch, sweet! Having this option made it easier to order. I didn't want to risk ordering a full sized deep dish pizza and hating it. I'm not a big fan of deep dish pizza but I heard that Little Star could change my mind and that it did!

Went with the signature Little Star (personal sized) which is spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic. I hate soggy pizza but even as a deep dish, Little Star's cornmeal crust kept everything crunchy. DELISH.

I need more pizza in my life. More specifically, more Little Star
author: Susy C.

description:
Great Pizza and great service.
Deep dish is that way to go! All the time!
author: Bobby G.

description:
Twinkle, twinkle Little Star, how I wonder what you are. 

After a Monday night dinner, I wonder no more: 

The hostess and the bar tender were courteous but our waitress was a bit off-putting. She never checked on us and just wasn't very friendly. Even when she took our menus away, I almost felt like she was snatching them. We ordered - 

*Garlic Bread: Before tearing away each slice of sourdough bread, our table did it right and buttered and garlic-ed each side of the slices to let the entire loaf absorb the butter and the roasted garlic. This is garlic bread in its most simplest and purest form and I just loved it.  

*Mixed Salad: A preferable salad option if you don't want greens that are topped with a creamy dressing but a vinaigrette instead. I really enjoyed the addition of walnuts but there was too much red onion that just over powered the salad.  We asked for no gorgonzola cheese based on the dietary needs at our table so I'm not sure if this would have changed the salad flavor. 

*Spicy Chicken Wings: The blue cheese dressing dipping sauce wasn't unpleasantly feet-y and went well with the wings. The thinly sliced baby carrots honestly looked a bit sad on the plate. The wings, a bit meager in size and in the serving, were definitely spicy but were very simple, something I felt like I could have made at home. 

*Classic Deep Dish Pizza: Just like the garlic bread, I loved it. Everyone at our table agreed that although the large pizza was smaller than expected, you could distinguish each ingredient and the toppings didn't get lost in the sauce. I particularly liked the cheese, and the crust was extra crusty with the added cornmeal.
author: Maya S.

description:
They had me cornbread deep dish, and they deliver!

I will be back for my cornbread deep dish pizza from this heavenly little star.
author: Erik V.

description:
STARS.

Shining brightly in front of paparazzi flash bulbs.   They are found far and wide in the vast mecca known as Hollywood, on the big or little screen.  In any case, stars are abundant far and wide, high and low.

And certainly the "stars" at Little Star Pizza are very far from "little."  Surely they made an impression on me during this, my first visit.....and hopefully not the last.

PLOT:  Dinner with my brother while visiting San Francisco.

SETTING:  A restaurant in the Mission.

CO-"STAR"RING:  
1)  Classic Deep Dish Pizza:  Flavorful and very good! 
2)  Chicken Pesto Thin Crust Pizza:  Heavenly.  Scrumptious.  

Both of the pizzas we ordered were just delicious.  For me my favorite was the deep dish, while my brother favored the thin crust.  Overall, I think we made a smart decision in choosing to share 2 small pizzas, since this allowed me (the visitor) to try multiple menu items.  To sum things up:  I enjoyed our meal very much and left a FULL and satisfied customer.

CAMEO:  For drinks, my brother had a Racer 5, while I chose a Pinot Noir.

SUPPORTING CAST:  Service was terrific!  The staff was friendly, polite, helpful, and very attentive throughout our entire meal.  Many thanks to one particular male staff member who repeatedly provided us with new napkins after we (somehow) constantly kept dropping our napkins on the floor.  In any case, besides the food, the service is also a "star" at this restaurant.

END CREDITS:  Good food.  Great Service.  Certainly there will be a sequel (future visit) in the works.
author: Michael C.

description: Awesomme.... delicious...Pizza. Loved it! One of the best pizza i have had in months!! Must go place people. Try it. I have tried deep dish pizza, thin crust pizza and garlic bread. They have a very peculiar way of serving Garlic bread...it was great!. Good place for vegetarians!
author: Namisha G.

description:
The food is great
Their piZza is worth every penny 
I have tried their deep dish and thin crust, both are delicious

Some time the staff isn't as nice, but I guess you are always stressed when the place is
Crowded
author: Jad A.

description:
Ordered over the phone to go. Whoever answered the phone seemed slightly perturbed that I didn't know the ins and outs of the menu. (I totally feel the pain of answering phones, though.)
When I arrived with my boyfriend they weren't super busy so we asked if we could eat here. Nope. Can we eat at the bar? Nope, because that's up to the bartender and he's not here yet. They went on to explain how they also don't do pre-orders and things like that. We went to eat at one of the parklettes kitty corner. The amount of added pepperoni was also underwhelming.
They missed out on an alcohol tab. And they lost 2 customers.
We'll try the other location. That pizza's good!
author: Brituhknee S.

description: The manager was extremely rude. parking in the area was very challenging during dinner time, I called ahead of time twice to make sure the order was ready, double parked and ran in to pick up quickly- somehow the manager (the really big wide guy) was at the counter and could not find the order. I explained that I called ahead of time and someone told me it was ready and knew where my order was; he said "stop yelling at me"... i had to shut up and keep waiting. I asked for some napkins, he said "Jesus..." in such impatience, literally threw the napkins on my face... ok, I know little Star Is popular, so that they can treat their customers like this?
author: J W.

description:
It's the best pizza. It's just the best. As a former New Yorker and Chicagoan I suppose I have some pedigree in pizza eating if thats a thing? But wherever you're from or have eaten, this is the best pizza. 

I'm a thin crust guy so please take that into account. But seriously, this is the best pizza.
author: Joel W.

description: Pizza is my game so I think I can call it like I see it. Pretty sure this is a deep dish place, though I tried both. The corn meal style crust is lends itself to deep dish and a more Chicago style pie. Ingredients for the most part are top drawer. Cheese awesome as were toppings and tomatoes. A bit sheepish on the portions but all good. Parm on the table was low quality but many places go cheap there. Nice beverage and service. A solid choice thin or thick.
author: Rob B.

description:
Excellent deep dish pizza with a great alcohol selection to pair with.

Little Star Pizza has excellent customer service and tasty food.

Usually start myself off with some Speakeasy Prohibition amber ale and a glass of wine to start. I do recommend the spicy chicken wings - although they are not something to die for - they are definitely solid. Not too spicy as well! Choice of either ranch or blue cheese sauce - whatever floats your boat.

I am definitely a fan of the Brass Monkey Deep Dish Pizza - got the large with 2 of my friends and we were stuffed. 

Little Star Pizza is a great place to catch up with friends; grab a bite with family... perfect for most occasions with a small group of people.

This place does get crowded - in the heart of the mission district. 15th and Valencia - right on the corner!
author: Sam K.

description: Pizza here is so good! Deep dish is where it's at. Cornbread-like crust and dab it up with a little honey and BOOM you got dessert at the end of every slice. Howboutdah!? There's also a server there named Sean that is the coolest leather rockin band playin motorcycle riding G! Super nice guy to chop it up with at the bar whenever you're grabbing a beer and some za. Stop by and dig into some of that deep stuff.
author: Lachlan D.

description: This pizza was BOMB. My friend and I split the broccolini as an appetizer and then the Valencia pizza as an entrée. The ricotta was incredible. 10/10 would stop in there again :)
author: Cheyenne B.

description:
SF staple that has stood the test of time.  They have amazing deep dish pizzas, wings and salads.  We went here a few weekends ago with my girlfriend's baby cousins.  Typically you are only able to get the kids size pizzas at the bar if it is dinner time but our server was extremely help and wanted to make sure we had a good experience so he had the kitchen make us the kids size pizzas even though it was after hours and we weren't sitting at the bar.

The service here is great and attentive.  My only gripe is that it is too packed and busy!  But that's what happens when you have a great product.
author: Landon Y.

description:
How good is this pizza? 

Wheat really aggravates my asthma. Lame, I know. I avoid it 99% of the time. But this pizza, man. This pizza is AMAZING. 

I have only had two thin crusts so far, the Classic (sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bell peppers) and just tonight, the California (pesto, arugula, red onions, sun-dried tomatoes, balsamic reduction, plus I added chevre cheese). 

The first pizza, the Classic, was so good! 

The second, the California, wow. The pesto! The crispy crust! The incredible sun-dried tomatoes! I ate it all.

I will probably have to use my inhaler tomorrow before going to the gym. I am only a little sorry. I should be smart and get the gluten-free next time, which is available on the small thin crusts. No gluttonous gluten-free eaters I guess. 

Little Star is too modest. I think their name should be GIANT BLINDING STAR GUIDING YOU TO THE BEST PIZZA IN SAN FRANCISCO. That is a lot to print on a box though.
author: Sarah J.

description:
Don't order; they will lose it and leave you hungry! 

They use this online company called Caviar to handle their orders. I submitted my order... waited 40 minutes... and found out they lost my order. The guy at Little Star Pizza told me I could order through Caviar again (yet the website wouldn't let me), or he could make a pizza and have me come pick it up. Well I don't have a car, so now I don't have a pizza. I wasted 50 minutes waiting for dinner and now have nothing.

Little Star Pizza says it's the fault of Caviar, yet they as a company use it as their delivery service. I won't order pizza from this company ever again, as now I know they don't have a reliable process of getting food to their customers.

Try Escape from New York Pizza because they never have issues getting pizza delivered.
author: Scott K.

description: Good pizza, but service at this location is lacking.  Each time I come for takeout it is a disorganized mess.  Some people want a table, some people want takeout, and the delivery vendors are mad they have to wait in line since they are on a schedule.  Total mess.    No one knows where to wait in line, and worst of all no staff communicate with the customers.  I have to step in and assert myself which is fine but the staff should be asking us and not the other way around.  I was given the wrong change tonight.  The server seemed spaced out. But, we got in and got out.  When we got home, they had botched our order and gave us the wrong pizza.  There is no organization whatsoever at this location.  I won't frequent this location any longer, but will continue to patron the Divisadero location, which has great customer service.
author: Paul W.

description:
First time here. The Little Star deep dish pizza slice will melt in your mouth as the cheese dribbles down in a plethora of strings to the mother pizza. Seriously, we had a 5 minute moment of silence, nodding in agreement, eyebrows furrowed, that we had tasted a damn good deep dish pizza.

Tips:
- Prepare to drop some dough ($19 sml pizza / $26 large) to eat some dough.
- A small deep dish is enough for a couple.
- The Spicy Wings are average.
- Close your eyes during your first few bites into the pizza.
- The crust, eat it. Eat it all. Eat your friend's crust too.
author: John F.

description:
Generally speaking, I'm a low-carb-er.  But I was in SF with my son who loves Chicago-style pizza.  A friend told us about Little Star and we can't thank him enough.  This pizza is A-MAAAA-ZING!!!. The crust - yes, I said "crust" - is the best part. The cornmeal adds a nice crunch though the crust still stays nice and airy. And..... if you add a little honey to the edge of the crust, you'll blow your diet forever.  

Now, I can't leave without mentioning their fabulous sauce.  It's tangy and fresh; far from canned.  Simply great flavor.  Their salad is spot-on as well.  Not overly dressed. Just right.  

My only complaint would be a request for Little Star to add a couple more proteins to the topping list.  Otherwise, don't change a thing.

Little Star definitely has it goin' on.
author: Rhonda M.

description:
I had a hankering for pizza and Little Star had been bookmarked for a while, so I knew it was the perfect opportunity to try it!

Our party of 3 was seated immediately on a Sunday night, so I was happy we didn't have to wait. We started with the chicken wings as an appetizer. I thought they were decent, but nothing extraordinary. The 2 boys, on the other hand, thought they were deliciousss, so I guess it's just personal preference.

We got a large chicken Mediterranean with sausage on half of the pie (since I don't eat it). The pizza takes a bit to come out, but understandable because it's not like NY pies. 

The pizza came out and was piping hot. It was cut into 6 slices, but I could barely finish 1 slice! Even the boys (who have huge appetites) had troubling finish the rest of it.  I liked the cornmeal crust, and the pizza was good. Loved the sauce. Though, I felt like there wasn't as much ingredients in it as there could have been.

Note: If you're drinking soda, there isn't fountain drinks. The guys drank 2 cokes each and it was $14!

Overall, it was a decent (filling) meal, but not sure if I'd go out of my way to come here again.
author: Noelle H.

description: Not the greatest for the price. The deep dish is better than the thing crust, and the crust is pretty tasty on it, but overall my girlfriend I felt like it didn't have much in terms of taste. Thin crust is a hard pass.
author: Daniel B.

description:
To all my recently added lovely friends and beautiful admirers (males and females), I am NOT a pizza-person. I may do a slice once every six months or so. But pizza is definitely not my choice of meals. Besides, I am the "boss" and decide what I want to eat and other decision-making. 

Now many of you, are scared and terrified to go out with me on a date. I guess I know why I got divorced and friends including colleagues and yelpers simply would not go out with me. I am very selective in my all my decisions. Whether you may think so or not, "YOU CAN LUMP IT, THEN!"

And if I have a choice of pizza, most definitely I would select a hearty deep-dish. Both Little Star Pizza locations in San Francisco and the new Burlingame location are one of my many target restaurants to check out. But first, I was on the Valencia Street location for lunch. 

I do like the dark and sleek ambiance of the corner restaurant. And with Halloween approaching, the scary decorations blend really well in the venue. 

From the menu, I ordered the small Deep-dish Mediterranean Chicken. For $19.00, I get sliced chicken breast, artichoke hearts, bell peppers, onions and feta cheese. For an additional $2.00, I also wanted pesto in my whole pie. The deep-dish takes 20-25 minutes to bake. 

As I was waiting for my pizza, I was sipping on a $2.50 can of PBR and watching the recent vice presidential debate on my mobile device. "That was a bunch of MALARKEY...haha!"

After the lengthy wait, I finally got my pie. I have noticed the pizza was noticeably pre-made with the pesto sauce swirled last on top like me receiving a "You're Funny" compliment from my yelpers. The pizza tasted fine. But I was hoping for the pesto sauce to be mixed in deeply with the other ingredients. My pizza: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/little-star-pizza-san-francisco-2#Gadm4H6r_6g1swqlrnDkOw

However, the other two locations have slightly higher ratings than the Valencia Street location. I do like to check those locations out one day. 

"Don't PM me or ask me for a date to check out those locations, please!"
author: Matt G.

description:
Little Star has been on my to-try pizza list for a few years now. I've been putting it off because whenever I crave pizza, I usually go for thin crust rather than deep dish, but that changed last night. The wait at this tiny restaurant was ridiculously long. We waited nearly an hour for a table to clear. People seem to really enjoy just sitting around and taking their time at this restaurant, despite eating just pizza. Deep dish pizza takes 30 minutes to cook. To avoid ordering appetizers to hold us over, we placed our order before we were seated to cut down on the wait time.

The two deep dish pizzas to try here are the classic and the Little Star. The classic has your standard sausage, mushroom, green bell peppers, and onion toppings, which makes for a solid pick. The Little Star is a nice vegetarian option with spinach, ricotta, feta, mushrooms, onions, and garlic. Both are great in their own way. The crust was done beautifully and reminiscent of the buttermilk crust that Lou Malnati's does in Chicago.  

We did try the pesto chicken on a thin crust, which was probably everyone's least favorite. The chicken was dry and the thin crust just wasn't as good. Since we were so hungry by the time we got our food, we were pretty ravenous and ate in silence. Overall, Little Star is the place to go if you want deep dish in the city, but I would call in an order for pick-up rather than endure the wait.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
When I moved here I imagined myself frequenting this charming pizza place, the staff knowing me by name and being totally cool with making a custom heart shaped pizza for me (ok not that last part but everything before).

My fave is their mediterranean deep dish. Circle shape. 

Bon appetit!
author: Dejana B.

description:
delicious deep dish

definitely check it out if you're in san francisco; it comes close to the real thing in chicago!!
author: Hemesh P.

description:
Not what it. Hit or miss now. Undercooked thin crust-soft dough too often.  I wouldn't mind the "This job is beneath me" staff if the pizza was consistent like it used to be.
Update: 3/5/17, Thinnest shallowest lowest weight "deep dish" I've ever had in over a decade of Little Star- and I frequent all 4 locations. So unimpressed with The Valencia location in recent months. :(
author: Chris R.

description: I cannot recall how many times I've bee to Little Star...    The tall woman with the piercings in each cheek should not have any interactions with customers.  She was rude on the phone and even ruder in person. There was a problem with the payment system that caused a 20 minute ++ delay with my order that was ready and waiting when I arrived.  Not only did she not apologize once for the inconvenience but after politely inquiring twice into how long I might need to wait I was told I should "sit down an wait until they were ready". I'd like to say she needs some intensive customer service training but really she lacks the most basic of customer service skills.  Please find another position for her that does not have any interaction with customers.  If I have to deal with her again, I won't come back.
author: Kevin M.

description:
I've never dined in at Little Star Pizza, but my friends and I ordered the pizza for take-out on a low-key Sunday evening. I didn't deal with the ordering or picking up, so this will be a short, pizza-only review.

We ordered two large pizzas for five people, and this was the right amount of food, with just a few slices left over. We got the classic deep dish and a thin crust with spinach and pepperoni. The deep dish is what Little Star is known for, so the five stars are for the classic pie alone. This was an excellent, excellent pizza, with a marvel of a crust--substantial, crispy, anchored with cornmeal. I've never had another crust quite like it, and would seek Little Star out just to have it again. It was a perfect base for the deep dish filling, a straight-up casserole of sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers, onions, and cheese. I don't tend to love deep dish pizzas, but Little Star's was delicious--I suspect it's the deep dish pizza for people who can't quite go all-in on deep dish pizza. The filling was not as heavy as the Chicago-style deep dish, and I thought it was much more balanced and enjoyable as a result. The acidic sauce kept it compulsively edible, and the crust held its own beneath a serious pile of toppings. I was less impressed with the thin crust. It tasted okay, but the cheese got rubbery pretty fast. I wouldn't bother with the thin crust again.

At some point I'll have to actually eat at Little Star and sample more of the deep dish pies. It seems to be San Francisco's primary (only?) claim to pizza fame, and judging from the classic deep dish alone, I'd say its reputation is well deserved.
author: Steph C.

description:
Unless you know it's on the corner, it's really hard to find due to small signage and dark windows. Once inside, the space is warm and open. As with all restaurants, it does get loud but we went for lunch to try and avoid that. 

Our waiter was attentive and friendly. No problem with the service.

The cornmeal crust on the deep dish pizza is so good and the wait for the pizza really isn't that long. We got the classic without green bell peppers. It was flavorful, the cheese was gooey and it tasted so good! We ordered the large so we would have leftover. Basically, we ordered two pizzas since we will each have two slices for dinner tonight. Great bargain!

Since we were back near the kitchen and the restaurant wasn't very full, we could hear both the kitchen staff's music as well as the music for the restaurant. They didn't mix well and I didn't really like the music the restaurant was playing but it wouldn't keep me from going back.
author: Tera K.

description: Pretty good pizza, great happy hour deals. Everyone is pretty nice and you always get great service! Only downside is the tables are very close together making it hard to get up from the table.
author: Mandy B.

description: Really great deep dish pizza, every time. I just wish they took reservations because they're usually very busy (since they're so good).
author: Nick R.

description:
Little Star for sure earns 5 little stars in my books. I have nothing but overt praises!

I took a dear friend here for a her bday dinner and the two of us collectively demolished an Italian combo large thin crust pizza. Now you might ask, why oh why would I go to a place that is notorious for its deep dish pizza and order a thin crust? I judge pizza spots based on consistency across the menu, not just their signature item! If they killed it with the thin crust, I for sure know that the deep dish has got to be even better. 

In any case, the pizza was so perfect in every way - filled with a plethora of high quality toppings immersed among a bed of perfectly melted cheese... my oh my were we tantalized. The dichotomous blend of both the veggie toppings and the hardcore meat was overwhelmingly flavorful. 

They also have an extensive gourmet draft beer menu which paired exquisitely with the pizza. 

The ambiance is rustic-classic-casual and a tad hipster given the location in hipsterville (Mission) and the service is great! It's perfect to head to with friends, the family or even a cute date night. 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description:
Little Star's been on the to-eat place for quite awhile, and the right opportunity finally presented itself. I had visitors looking for a casual but SF-y meal in the MIssion, perfect! Parking is a little crazy as usual, but our perseverance paid off and we got a spot just across the street.

Pop in and put your name down, it'll probably be 30 minutes. Maybe grab drinks at the bar, but you should just take a walk down Valencia and check out the hood.

We got the brass monkey (little star + sausage) deep dish and chicken pesto thin crust. This isn't like the crazy Chicago deep dish that represents midwestern obesity. It's much lighter, with a better balance of cheese-to-topping ratio. The chicken pesto was even tastier, with a huuge amount of pesto goodness. Chicken was pretty dry though (just the way my weirdo cousin likes it). The 3 of us way over-ordered with the 2 smalls -- 1 would have been reasonable. Oh well, just means plenty of leftovers!

Staff was really nice, and they do a good job for such a small busy place. They only have the one restroom though, and there is an endless wait when all you want is to get back to your delicious pizza.
author: Vivian H.

description:
I'm not usually a fan of pizza, but anywhere with deep dish pizza and chicken wings can win me over any time. Little Star can get pretty busy, so you may or may not have to wait awhile to get a table. I love that they have a bar area so you can always get a drink while you're waiting. 

The Spicy Chicken Wings ($13) are so good. They are not messy like other places. Perfectly fried. The Greek Salad was delicious too. Good way to feel healthy (or just less guilty) with all these other fried foods in your table. It was tough for the four of us to decide how much pizza to order, so we order the following flavors. Oh by the way, you can request half your pizza to be one flavor and another flavor for the other half. Great way to experiment with many different flavors!

----------

* Little Star (Deep Dish) - Spinach with ricotta, feta, mushrooms, onions, and garlic. You really can't go wrong with any pizza named after the restaurant. This is probably my favorite one!

* Classic (Deep Dish) - Sausage, mushrooms, onions, and green bell peppers. Exactly what it sounds like. Classic... Nothing special but still good.

* Pesto Chicken (Thin Crust) - Pesto sauce, chicken, mushrooms, and onions. All my friends really enjoyed this, though I found the chicken to be a little dry. 

* White Pie (Thin Crust) - Garlic olive oil base, mozzarella, zucchini, tomatoes, and feta. Probably my second favorite next to the Little Star. Great if you're not a fan of tomato based pizzas.

----------

The pizzas are so fresh and CHEESY. The crust is good enough to eat, which I suppose is saying something. Cool vibe here! Great for groups (as shown by their cakeage and corkage fees) and parties, and there are also personal sized pizzas if you just want to treat yourself. OR you can just take the pizzas (and wings, of course) to go!
author: Stefanie C.

description: great pizza, great service, especially  from the two servers  Ray and  Raven They are the Bomb!!!!!!
author: Lori J.

description: Really pleased with this business. I had a small (but annoying) customer service issue - and when I called the next day to report what happened, the manager Benny was totally sweet and sorted me out super quick.  Stellar service fix. My pizza tasted great (despite the issue) and my wife who had a gluten free crust and vegan cheese pizza was also really pleased. We are looking forward to supporting Little Star again soon! :)
author: Dulce V.

description: Never had Chicago style pizza before . Hands down! Delicious . The gentleman names Benni was a true definition of customer service! The staff all were attentive and personable! I am definitely returning here when I come on my vacation  next year! They need to make another one like this , but In Los Angeles where I reside ! When people visit San Francisco they need to stop here for: pizza, wine and a salad. I wish I can take this place a ten star for there impeccable customer service,  their delicious menu and their palatable selection of wine.
author: Andres R.

description:
Good Chicago deep dish and it ain't cheap either! Maybe I grew up in a hood world of Little Caesar's and Pizza hut, but man it was good, but I don't remember losing two Jackson's on a pie! Granted it was a bit taller and deeper than most, but if you want the bomb deep dish you've been craving this is it. 

My tip: order the pizza with your selected accouterments for pick up. Grab it, take it home, keep it warm in the oven and then start your traditional SF smoking. I don't speak from experience, but that would probably be the move if my second hand knowledge serves me correct.
author: Joseph L.

description: We got the City pizza... dry and I think one of the worst pizzas I ever eaten. It barely qualifies as deep dish! I have pizza here before and it was ok but it's definitely dropped in quality.
author: Maria D.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE. There is no going wrong with Little Star Pizza. 
I used to go to their sister Blue Line in Burlingame when I lived in the penninsula and have never gone wrong. We usually get the little star pizza + sausage (roomie needs to have some meat in there), and it's amazing every time. The wings (or so I hear) are pretty good, a little spicy for me so we get the garlic bread app that has huge chunks of garlic to dig out and add yourself - pretty cool display points! They also make their own ranch, which is AMAZING. I think it's $2 for a side but it is totally worth it!
author: Leina K.

description: Picked up my friend from the airport and came here around 10p on Friday to find plenty of tables.  The pizza took around 20 minutes and we had the Little Star pizza with chicken.  So delicious.  I had a glass of the cab but it was not that good.  I'd order another wine next time but the same pizza.  Service was not as attentive but it's probably because they were closing soon.  I love this pizza.
author: Chris L.

description: Takeout takes forever and they are very disinterested in serving you.  Pizza is overpriced in my opinion and not worth it.
author: alec m.

description:
"Pizza is like sex....even when it's bad it's still pretty good." - Bumper sticker wisdom.

Thank the pizza gods that there are places like Little Star - where pizza is just good. Next time you are in the area, do yourself a solid and order the Little Star deep dish. It's so amazing and it's like a party in your mouth (Ricotta, Feta, Spinach, Mushrooms, Onions, Garlic). Om nom nom. Also, if you aren't into waiting to be seated, waiting for your pizza and then being rushed out afterward, I wouldn't eat in. Instead, I'd get your pizza to go so that you can savor all the flavor without being pushed out the door.
author: Tara H.

description: I thought this pizza was good but not outstanding. If you love deep dish then this is the place for you. We ordered the pollo deep dish and it was good but not great. The crust is tasty and it has tons of cheese. I was satisfied with the food but not enough to bring me back. There are to many unbelievable restaurants in SF and unfortunately little star wasn't unbelievable.
author: Nicholas C.

description:
This best deep dish pizza in California!! 
This is a must go place when my husband and I come SF for a visit!! We always orders a large classic! We love the fresh stretchy mozzarella cheese and sweet and juicy tomato! It's just a perfect deep dish!!!
author: Shannon T.

description: Excellent spot!  Ronnie was very knowledgable about the area. Good music, good pizza!  One love from ATL!
author: Will W.

description:
Great thin crust pizza.

They don't deliver, but you can order thorough Doordash or Postmates.   So far the best thin crust pizza (excluding the Italian style pizza's like Delfina).

My personal favorite is a cheese with yellow onions.
author: J B.

description:
Little Star: Chicago style pizza in the heart of the Mission. The cornmeal crust is what makes this pizza special; it's a little bit pastry-like in it's light and flaky nature, but that cornmeal grounds it in being a savory treat. 

The deep dish is where it's at, in my opinion. Order a can of PBR or two,  half half Little Star and Mediterranean (the one with feta) and you've got yourself a chilled out neighborhood dinner.

The special pizza is usually pretty good (often seems more appropriate as a thin crust pizza). Last couple of times I've gone they've featured toppings like prosciutto/heirloom tomatoes and broccoli raab. 

Additional tip, courtesy of an observant (and cash-less) friend - ATM fee here is only $0.25!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Best deep-dish pizza I have had yet, I think a lot of it is because of the cornmeal crust which I found to be a refreshing change for pizza.  The sauce was extremely fresh. The Goddess salad was also very good.  

The atmosphere and location are great--big open windows at a busy corner location in the Mission district contrast nicely with a dark, relaxed interior.  If you get there around six you can beat the dinner rush, we walked right in (on a weeknight) with a large party and were seated immediately.
author: Brian B.

description:
SF is definitely no Chicago. So it was no surprise that when I tried Little Star pizza for their deep dish I was a bit disappointed. It's ok. Though, as the 2 star review suggests Iv'e had better. Massa in my humble opinion in LA is a lot tastier than Little Star pizza. 

Enjoyed the company that I was with and thank you Little Star pizza for providing me a memorable evening with my friends. Though, chances are I won't be back eating deep dish the next time I'm in SF! Big ups on the Corn meal Crust. 

JY
author: Justin Y.

description:
Totally fed up with my neighborhood Patxi's inability to execute basic pizza delivery, and having wanted to try Little Star for SO LONG, I ordered delivery through Caviar.

Little Star Deep Dish Pizza + Added Mozzarella, Pepperoni: 4 stars. The cornmeal crust lived up to the reviews! It was surprisingly light, which was welcome in a deep dish. The spinach, garlic, ricotta, and feta were cooked in perfectly. The tomatoes tasted fresh. I chopped some basil and sprinkled on top, and it was heaven. Looking forward to seeing if the leftovers hold up.

A little expensive for the service/delivery fees, but at this point I'm willing to pay for a consistent pizza, cooked correctly, delivered within the window quoted, no hassle. Deep dish pizza delivered in 30 min.! Awesome. Will be back to try other deep dish combos, for sure. Maybe I'll find my 5 star? Definitely one of the better pizzas I've had in the city.
author: Jordan Q.

description:
For a few early years living in SF, there were a handful of things I missed from the east coast: deli sandwiches, bagels, and... pizza.  Little Star fixed that.

Yes, there were a few good pizza places in SF like Tony's but who the fuck wants to trek to North Beach for a slice?  Once the Divis' location opened for Little Star, I was sold.  And when they opened up their Valencia spot a block up the street from me, I felt like they might as well have just planted the gates of heaven there.

Little Star makes really, really good pizza.  Both their deep dish and thin-crust are exemplary and will satisfy even the harshest of critics (like me).  The secret of the deep dish is their cornmeal crust which serves as the base for all types of gooey cheesy goodness and hearty, chunky tomato sauce filling.  The thin crust is just the right level of crisp, and while it won't make you think you're taking a bite on the streets of Brooklyn, it's an excellent slice.

Favorites:
* The Little Star (deep dish) - spinach blended with ricotta & feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic -it's perfect and you won't care if you're not vegetarian once you've taken a bite
* The Classic (deep dish or thin crust) - Sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells  - simple but simply perfect combo of flavors
* Pepperoni & Mushroom (custom thin crust) - my favorite thin crust, just love the balance of flavor and texture of this old school classic

Pro Tip: Ask about their specials!
author: Saminda W.

description:
Little Star Pizza on Valencia has given new hope to pizza lovers!!  They are proud to have non-GMO ingredients which are always FRESH and yummy.

The deep dish pizza comes with the tomato "sauce" on the top.  It is absolutely DIVINE. The tomatoes are so sweet and rich. The spices and seasonings are delicious. The crust is amazing and the amount of cheese is generous and perfect.

LSP doesn't take reservations and your whole party has to be there to be seated.  It is worth the wait.

Benni is the handsomest person in the world.  Oh, and he's good at his job too! The service was lovely and attentive. 

The jukebox is RAD.

Personal Notes:

-$1 off draft beers for happy hour. A steal as they are cheap as hell to begin with.

We ordered the:

DEEP DISH LARGE PIZZA
Half and half toppings (yes! they do that!!!)
Half "Little Star"
Half "Classic"

*My boyfriend was eating off my plate while he still had a full slice on his. It was that good.*
author: Sky S.

description:
Oh Little Star.. What a little restaurant you are.  Let us start off with the cons since Yelp readers deserve to know what they are getting themselves into.  There are a few things that I did not like about the restaurant itself.  For one, this place has got to violate some type of law regarding maximum occupancy and a pose a fire hazard.  The waiting area is just too small, and combined with the bar area, that is just chaos.  The dining area is small as well, not to mention cramped.  You literally sit next to someone five inches next to you and overhear their conversations.  The last thing that is quite bothersome is the restroom.  There is just one restroom to satisfy hundreds of customers.  Be prepared to wait in long lines before you can use it.  

As for the food, the garlic bread is quite laughable.  By this I mean we were both expecting some bread with garlic smear or simply garlic bread that was ready to pop in our mouths.  Instead we find "do it yourself" garlic bread.  They just give us some bread, garlic cloves, and butter.  I guess we should have expected this when we saw it was only $5.  Haha. The joke was definitely on us.  

The pesto chicken pizza was quite good.  There was excellent pesto-toppings-dough ratio at work here.  It was a party in my mouth.  Good thing we got this pizza because at first I initially wanted the deep dish.  Then we saw a couple next to us order it and the whole thing was tomato sauce.  

Overall, okay place.  They need to move to a larger facility if  they want to adequately provide enough seats for their patrons.
author: Victor L.

description:
Am I in Chicago?

I been to Little Star and have ordered take out and can vouch 100% for their consistency in quality. The Mediterranean is my favorite.

Your pizza prayers have been answered!
author: Shana B.

description:
I called in to ask the wait time and the person who answered was a little rude saying we don't give times Over the phone but I guess 30 mins . So off to a bad start but we decided to go anyway . 

The service: 
Upon arriving we were seated immediately by a very polite waitress not the same person who answered the phone . But in his defense there was a large kids basketball team taking a lot of their time . With that said we were still served quickly and politely . 

The food : 
Garlic bread : roasted garlic with butter both on the side and you spread it on yourself . Good but not really worth the $5 
Classic deep dish : wow ! Loved it ! Flavorful and seasoned just right 
Pesto chicken thin crust : good , chicken was a little dry . But maybe because I'm comparing to the classic

I only took the star off because of the initial impression over the phone . But this place is 5 star once you enter !
author: S R.

description: You can not go wrong with a deep dish authentic Chicago style pie from Little Star I'm sure the thin crust is great too but the magic is in the deep dish pizzas at Little Star. Solid crust, mozzarella, toppings, sauce, and heaven in wedge slices will have you telling everyone about this place. We found out from Dr. Chocolate at UCSF, he likes sweets, about Little Star today 7/7 that was one good call. Go try a pizza between 12 to 30 dollars and you will also be in the know. Take a friend support your neighboring restaurants your economy will thank you.
author: Joaquin G.

description:
Delicious cornmeal pizza! I'm a huge fan of thin crust pizza and this place has one of the best that I've tried. My table ordered a large thin crust and did half & half: a white pizza and the meaty one. I also tried a piece of the deep dish cornmeal pizza (the vegetarian one) and that was good as well. 

Good drinks, nice ambience (however it got a little too dark once they dimmed the lights around 9), and good food. It gets pretty busy, and you have to make sure everyone in your party is there to get seated.
author: Kirby P.

description:
Fantastic Deep Dish Pizzas. My favorite is definitely the Sausage Deep Dish. 
Location is great, very clean and cozy interior. Definitely a pizza spot worth checking out if you're in the area.
author: Charlene S.

description:
Bottom line at the top: usually not a fan of deep dish but this is amazing. 
--
Came here and split a personal little star deep dish and a personal thin crust special of the day (mozzarella, cherry tomatoes, balsamic). Both were amazing but we both loved the deep dish and wished we had gotten both pizzas as deep dish. 

Yum!!
author: Dahlia S.

description:
Being a Chicago native, I was thrilled to find a place near where I live that serves deep dish pizza. It's not super authentic in that you can tell it's been adapted to fit "California-tastes", but overall was still a delicious and filling meal.

I ordered a goddess salad to start which wasn't anything particularly special, but even the smaller portion was quite large and I had no complaints.

For pizza, I ordered a personal classic and a personal vegetarian. Both solid, and the personal portion is perfect I think for most people (I tend to eat a little more than most). The part that I really loved though was their crust. I think a lot of deep dishes places don't really pay a lot of attention to their crust (the filling is after all what deep dish is known for), but their's was PERFECT. It was just the right amount of crispy on the edge but still soft on the bottom where all the sauce is. It also had a slight hint of butter which made it extra tasty.
author: Whitney L.

description: As an east coaster living in San Francisco I quite often deride SF for the pizza situation. Let's face it, it's not very good. This place isn't anything like the pizza we have back east but it's sooooo delicious. I like the Mediterranean Pizza Thick crust. They have a rotating special pizza that's usually pretty good. The beer selection is good. If you want lunch you can get a little personal thick crust from like 12-3 that is a really good deal and very satisfying.
author: Geoff G.

description:
I totally love it! Every time I am in town I come here. The location is on Valencia, which doesn't have the easiest street parking. Their deep-dish seem to be more popular, but the thin crust is also excellent and comes out sooner than the deep-dish. My husband and I ended up ordering a small deep dish, which is the perfect size for two hungry people. The deep dish crust is unbelievably light and crisp at the same time, with a hint of sweetness from the cornmeal crust. I can easily order one of these and keep it to myself.

Eat in or take out... Thin crust or deep dish... Little Star is the way to go!
author: Perla L.

description:
My sister-in-law brought us here last night and as someone who doesn't really go for deep dish pizza on account of the soggy/messy experiences I've had in the past, I was pleasantly surprised and satisfied with what we had at Little Star.

We ordered the goddess salad and a large deep dish Little Star pizza. The salad was light and very refreshing and came out almost immediately after the server took our order to the back. After an entire day of horribly slow service at other restaurants and what felt like the longest BART delay ever in Daly City, their quick service was very much appreciated. 

We were seated in the back next to the kitchen entrance so we kept seeing the servers walking out with everyone's pizzas and each time they passed our table our mouths were watering. Once we received the pizza, we were not at all disappointed. The crust was crisp enough to hold all of the ingredients on it without being hard, all of the ingredients tasted fresh, none of the components overpowered the rest. Overall, the food was very well-made and we would definitely come back if we are ever in town.

Minus 1 star for the poor ventilation in the dining area.
author: Richard M.

description:
Best pizza!!! is always satisfying and never leaves you feeling like a fatty if you eat a whole pizza on your own.
Service is good
Ambience is ok, i like the one in divisadero better.
author: Natalia E.

description:
My quest for the perfect pizza led me to the Mission, specifically to Little Star.  Little Star offers both thin crust and deep dish style pizzas. Whenever I am in the mood for deep dish pizza its always a toss up between Patxi's and Little Star.  

Now what makes Little Star different from Patxi's is the crust. You can taste the difference while both are good  Little Star adds corn meal  to the crust making it crunchier and flakier.  

I always get the deep dish pepperoni and garlic.  I love that they give extra tomato sauce on the side since their sauce is amazingly good. The tomato sauce is made with sweet fresh roma tomatoes which gives the sauce the extra oomph!!! Each bite comes heavy with fresh, layered ingredients over the simple tomato and basil sauce and cornmeal crust.  I savor each bite of this slice.  I can eat two whole slices before my pants start to get tight and I know I need to 1.) slow down or 2.) Stop eating and take the rest home. It never really tastes the same when you take the pie home so me and my friends try to finish the whole thing.

I like the dark wood interiors of the restaurant, the mid-century modern light fixtures and the funky urban atmosphere that lures deep-dish fans to Little Star at the Mission.  I admit I haven't had the friendliest of servers every time I eat here.  Yes I get the fact that you guys are really busy, but it wouldn't hurt to be nice and attentive to people that come to your restaurant.  

Overall I like this place...very cozy and hip but relaxed pizza place in the Mission.
author: Maria M.

description:
Let me tell you what I think about the cornmeal crust people keep raving about: meh. Yeah...I said it. 1200 circlejerks about how amazing this place is, specifically citing their deep dish cornmeal crust as the arc de triomphe, and I just don't get it.

My only visit was around 5pm on a Monday - hardly anyone was in there. I'd heard horror stories, and I'm just too damn old to wait like that. Husband ordered what he calls "The Caleb Special."
