Unfortunately, it doesn't really work well with their deep dish style. The tomatoes should be diced instead of sliced, but regardless I just didn't really like the deep dish. The crust is made for eating, but when I have pizza I throw them away - ingredients ARE the pizza, man! I can have bread any day of the week! Plus, the crust really just fills you up unnecessarily.

We had a salad to preface, and it was okay. For dessert, the secret breakfast ice cream (bourbon and cornflakes in vanilla, fuck yeah). That was probably the only good thing about the meal worth talking about.

I'll probably get flamed for this, but whatever. Maybe I'll go back and try another pizza - the husband did, and said "I tried one off their menu thinking it would be better...it wasn't." Sorry Little Star, looks like you'll have a couple other customers who have less of a wait in the future due to us not being there.
author: Jaime L.

description: Great pizzas and great staff, very satisfied, pizza wasn't greasy like other chain pizza places. If you're in town definitely try this place!!!
author: Malinda R.

description:
Cool place to grab a drink while waiting for your pizza to go :)
Portions are pretty big, so you can share with your buddy. 
Next time I will definitely stay in and try some deep dish pizza.
author: Ellie J.

description:
So, I never end up eating at the Little Star on Divisidero because it's always crowded and parking in the area is difficult.  We always end up calling about a half hour ahead of time to pick it up.  I've been craving deep dish and it was around lunch time on a Sunday so we were happy to hear that Little Star on Valencia is open at 12 for lunch.  

We came right when they opened and were seated.  I just felt a bad vibe when I was seated and I saw my glass had like dried tomato sauce stuck on it.  I saw the extra plates, glasses, and utensils to the side so being the proactive kind of girl I am, I replaced it myself.  When I went to the bathroom and saw there was no toilet paper!  I told one of the hostesses this then she went to go find some and put the humongous roll on top of the toilet.  Did my business then I saw there was no soap!  So, I told the other hostess of this and she apologized, and said "I'm sorry, I guess they didn't do their job."  Finally a guy replaced the soap in the bathroom.  I know this has probably happened to other people at other dining establishments but I just can't stand when stuff like this happens because missing bathroom items just gross me out because it's so unsanitary!  

Anyways, I don't know if it's just me, but I thought my beloved Brass Monkey tasted better in previous occasions when we get it to go from the other location.  3 stars for the good Brass Monkey & $1 off his beer for HH.  Minus two for the bathroom...yuck!
author: Cat C.

description: Awesome pizza... thin crust is my favorite.  I like the Italian Combo and Little Star ones the most!
author: Labonee M.

description:
Little Star Pizza is definitely some of the best deep dish pizza in San Francisco.  Overall, as many others have pointed out, the crust and sauce are out of this world.  The cornmeal dusting is awesome, and the fresh sliced tomato sauce is amazing.  A friend and I came and ordered the small 9" Little Star deep dish pizza but without mushrooms.  I would definitely recommend this.  But since there were so many things in the pizza, we didn't get very much cheese.  :(

The service here was good.  We only had an hour, and our waitress had us in and out with no problems.  I do prefer Patxi's, but it depends on your personal taste.
author: Amanda J.

description:
I don't like pizza.  Yes, blasphemy.  But growing up on school lunches, college munchies, and tipsy shenanigans, regular ol' pizza has been ruined for me.  Gimme something special like deep dish or exotic toppings.

Luckily, Little Star has just the specialty with their cornmeal crust.  I'm a crust guy, and I eat all of the crusts.  I couldn't stop eating and eyed the leftover crusts of my unsuspecting buddies.  The difference between the Classic with sausage and Little Star with spinach was subtle, and the pizzas were dominated by the tomato and cheese of the deep dishes.  $19 for a small and $25 for a large were very reasonable, and as always, I regretted finishing that third slice.  :X

Now if only I could wish on a star that Little Star delivered.
author: Kevin W.

description: More flavor in the sauce but crust is not up to par with Zacharys. I'm a crust person. Would I come here again? Yes, if I'm close but otherwise I'm sticking to my old faithful.
author: Tomi R.

description:
I can't even remember how many times I've actually walked past this place on my way to grab coffee at Four Barrel... 

On my recent trip back home to San Fran, I got a chance to make a suggestions to my buds to try this place out for dinner. Quite possibly, the best choice I could've that night! 

We started off the night in this particular order:

1. the Garlic Bread - a warm sourdough loaf served with whole roasted cloves of garlic and a side of butter. This is the real definition of garlic bread!! The garlic was raging profusely with aroma and the butter was warm and spreads...well, as smooth as butter. Definitely an awesome way to start the meal. 

2. the Spicy Chicken Wings - it's rather rare for me to order wings from places that usually don't specialize in them (ie: Alondra's, Wingstop, etc.), but there are places that surprise me, like Boiling Crab. Who would've known their wings were awesome?? But I digress... This place definitely has some memorable wings on the menu. I didn't really touch the blue cheese dressing because the flavor was right on. Semi kick of spicy and a whole lot of flavor... borderline almost Cajun like. Recommended? Yes. 

3. the Little Star Pizza - as my first time here, come on... I had to. Well, I have to give the credit to my bud Heather for putting this on the table for me. She also added sausage into the mix, which made it the wonder that it was. Along side of that was spinach, mushroom, garlic, and onion all drowning in their savory tomato sauce that was covered in ricotta and feta cheese. I'm not a huge fan of deep dish pizza, but I'm a fan of this one. 

All in all, the experience was pretty nice. A dimly lit ambiance to set the mood if you're on a date or just a nice spot to hang out with couple buddies. Either way, you'll see me here again. 

WORD OF ADVICE: Get the rootbeer!!! It's the bees-knees!
author: Mike D.

description:
I wasn't blown away by my meal at Little Star -- again, it's hard not to compare it to NYC/Chicago pizza when that's what I'm used to. The Bay area just doesn't do pizza very well, and Little Star is no exception.

I didn't order the deep dish, so I may have to come back for that... we ordered the regular/thin slice and it was just okay. I don't like my pizza crispy, and that's how it was served. The greek salad was alright -- tasted/looked fresh.

In terms of ambiance, it has kind of a cozy diner feel to it. Not a bad place to unwind if you're looking for something really casual or chill. Also, they won't seat you until everyone at your party has arrived, although they do take kitchen orders while you're waiting to be seated. 

Other notes: Service was good/friendly. Parking may be an issue, so allot some time for that.
author: Diana K.

description: There was a mix up with our pizza and they gave us free drinks on the house while we waited and it literally only took 10 minutes, i appreciate the gesture and the food was amazing thank you!
author: Mark L.

description:
We got there at around 3pm, and there were only two other tables there. The sign said to wait to be seated, but the waiter just glanced at us and continued his conversation with one of the patrons. We waited a few minutes, but when it seemed like that conversation wasn't going to end any time soon, we decided to just seat ourselves. Waiter dude was still chatting away. We waited a few more minutes, hoping he'd finally get around to us. Nope, still talking. We stood up and got our own menus. You would think he would finally get the hint, but nooo. It took him another five minutes to mosey on over to us and take our orders. Any longer and we would have walked out and gone to Arinell instead.

We got the Brass Monkey, which wasn't on the menu, but we had heard of through 7x7's Big Eat 2013. Basically it's like the Little Star (mushrooms, onions, garlic, spinach, ricotta, feta) plus sausage. We tried the Little Star deep dish before, so this time we wanted to try the thin crust. I really enjoyed the Brass Monkey. The sausage was really good with a strong fennel taste, although it may have overpowered the other ingredients a little bit. The crust wasn't bad either. Not as light and flaky as I would have liked, but otherwise done pretty well. 

I would have given it four stars, but I'm taking one star away for the inattentive service. Oh, did I mention that we had to stand up and get our own condiments too?
author: Racquel N.

description:
Pretty good! 
Its a good pizza. And they are not stingy about their toppings. Loaded up where this thin crust barely held it together.

I love the dough. Service was nice. Nice place. Big window for window watching.
author: Helen L.

description:
how i love you little star
bringing the best of the midwest to SF
deep dish pizza
always delectable
fab for takeout
and dining-in
still licking my chops from the last one
can't wait for the next one
author: Wendell A.

description: The Zachary's vs Little Star debate (sort of the Nintendo vs Sega of Chicago-style pizzas in the bay area) largely comes down to how you feel about the crust.  I personally prefer Zachary's standard flour crust to Little Star's cornmeal crust.  The cornmeal is an interesting idea and I like the concept of innovation, but ultimately, a Zachary's crust blends much better with the tomatoes and spices.  That said, it's about 100 times better than most mass-market pizzas and is frankly better than most of the casseroles-as-pizzas that you get in the actual Chicago.
author: Patrick G.

description:
OMG I have not written a review for this place. The most excellent chicken wings ever. And I mean EVER!.

The pizza is  also great. From the deep dish to their thin crust pizza: pesto chicken.... = YUM.   Damn good not dieters food.

But the most EXCELLENT pizza that was created by my Bestie and me was the Cheese Pizza with Anchovies,  sun dried tomatoes, and peppers. All Anchovies lovers Unit.  Nothing but good anchovy taste.   

I am glad that I found this new Pizza with anchovies. Love Little Star Mission and Albany!
author: Marck N.

description: Delicious deep pan pizzas. The little star was great! I loved the cornmeal crust with loads of delicious stuff packed within. It's an interesting concept that I've never had before but I'll come again to try more. The pizza was more filling than we expected it to be. I'll say 1 small size is good enough for 2 very hungry people.
author: Han Teng W.

description:
My review is for the takeout service only:

LSP is my favorite deep dish pizza in the city. Some family members like the classic deep dish pizza, while a few cousins and uncles prefer Zachary's. But since I'm buying I get to choose the place. This Mission area location is usually packed even on rainy days.

It was raining that night, so I suggested ordering pizza for dinner. I got a pesto chicken thin crust pizza, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/little-star-pizza-san-francisco-2?userid=8Ces6YdT6j7BYycnZLrSng#E6-FqCMp-PzBHgR_hcgMpQ one little star deep dish pizza (added sausage), http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/little-star-pizza-san-francisco-2?select=6ZYxocGWj9XxqSp1OmzIOQ#6ZYxocGWj9XxqSp1OmzIOQ plus an order of spicy chicken wings with blue cheese sauce. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/little-star-pizza-san-francisco-2?select=T47NywO4JW-qYVTYoYTTqA#T47NywO4JW-qYVTYoYTTqA The pizzas were hot and delicious. Afterward I was happy to see there were smiles all around.

** Update for 2013:
In January 2013, the 2 owners decided to separate and split LSP. Owner #1 gets the Mission (2006) and Albany (2010) locations, and plans to expand into Oakland under the name of "The Star" (to open June 2013). Owner #2 gets the original Divisadero shop (2004), and is currently expanding in the South Bay, under the name Blue Line Pizza. Same deep dish pizzas, just different restaurant names. No name changes for the SF restaurants, so customers won't see any difference. But now we can all enjoy LSP pizzas when visiting the East Bay or the South Bay.
author: Luis C.

description: Love it. Always good whether you get the deep dish or thin crust. I like to go plain and simply with a pepperoni thin crust and it is consistently good. Good selection of non-alcoholic soft drinks too.
author: Lauren A.

description: My favorite deep dish in America (a slight up compared to Lou Malnati's and Patxis'). The cornmeal crust is what sets Little Star apart from the rest, as is the service and constant great beer selection in house.
author: Harshith A.

description: Got a small deep dish- old classic for the first half and Mediterranean for the other. Really nice atmosphere. No line. It takes a bit of time for them to cook pizza. Really crispy crust and cheesy pizza. Enjoyed it overall.
author: Kilim C.

description: Great place! Great pizza! Stopped by after Blue Angels Fleet Week show. Two deep dish pizzas, salad and drinks for a family of four for under $70!
author: Curtis P.

description: Excellent service and food! The deep dish little star and old school were delicious, will definitely be back soon!
author: E P.

description: Avoid the sassy male waiter with glasses and yellow suspenders. Super rude! He should take a class on restaurant etiquette. What he did to us was a health code violation! But! Don't piss him off, unless you're ready to get a backhanded apology and be embarrassed in front of your fellow patrons. He ruined a lovely evening out, and unfortunately I will not be returning even though the pizza was good. Little star, you need to polish your service shine, if not you may have the unfortunate fate of burning out.
author: Marco K.

description:
Waits can get a little long here, and the space isn't big at all, so make sure to arrive before 7, and be prepared to spend a bit on your food. Other than that, I love everything about this place.

What do you want to eat? Deep dish Little Star. Trust me, you'll thank me later. It takes 30-45 minutes depending on the size, so grab a drink and an appetizer, and have a nice, long conversation with some friends. I'm going to be honest. I am a pizza snob. Brooklyn thin cheese slice is the only way to go, but as much as I wanted to hate a deep dish, I couldn't. The fresh spinach, mushrooms, and tomato sauce danced on my tongue. And the corn meal crust. Dear lord, it's crunchy and savory at the same time, and the texture and flavor just play musical notes on the palate. Love this pizza. The cheese doesn't overwhelm at all. The pizza will though, so get some.
author: Danny C.

description: Delicious pizza and amazing service. We ordered a large cheese pizza and a large pepperoni pizza for our family of four. We had it all and were very satisfied. The crust was our favorite part. Our waitress was super friendly and accommodating .
author: Mayelyn B.

description:
my favorite pizza place in san francisco! (for deep dish that is)

i love this little place, perfect for a date. note: they won't seat you until your entire party is here and they're pretty adamant on it too.

i dont really have much to say only that you can't go wrong with anything on the menu! the sauce, the cheese, everything is soo delicious. and the portions are pretty big, i went with 3 girls and we had 4 slices left over from a large size. 

they're also featured on the 7x7 list for "The Brass Monkey"
author: Andy H.

description:
Best deep dish in the city and they get my order right every time.  Unlike the other deep dish place in the city which gets it wrong and keeps giving me gift cards so they can get it wrong again. 

They just need to keep the recent ham and pineapple special on menu forever.
author: John H.

description: Stopped by here had deep dish veggie and classic they were good and I need come back and try the thin crust.Service was good all were  friendly.
author: CURT A.

description:
The great thing about reviewing pizza is that it's a food nearly everyone has eaten a hundred times, so the criteria are pretty clear for a good one. It's not like I'm reviewing a kefir-concoction from Bar Tartine that I'll only eat once in my life and can only base my opinion on one impression.

We ordered a salami flatbread pizza and the classic Chicago deep dish. I only ate the deep dish pizza and this is what I thought:

* Temperature: even though we waited long enough that you thought the pizza was being made fresh, it came out at room temperature. While I don't want a pizza so hot the cheese turns into lava, I still want it to be hot. This wasn't. They probably let it cool down way too long, even though the place wasn't busy when we ate.

* Sauce: terrible. My friend, who comes here often, said it was tastier than Patxi's sauce, so I can only imagine what that tastes like. He said the sauce here was heartier, with less sweetness. I think it tasted like a room temperature jar of Barilla pasta sauce that was dumped on top. Really disappointing flavors: the tomatoes had that stiff bite that only canned tomatoes seem to have, and the chunkiness gave it a mealy mouthfeel akin to frozen grapes. I've had great pasta sauce, so I know you can definitely develop a deeper, layered flavor with just a simple tomato sauce. This sauce is what turned me off to the entire pizza.

* Crust: disappointing. The crust lacked enough oil, so it was dry. Since there is very little cheese and the sauce is so -- hmmm fresh? -- the crust should have been oiler to help balance the pizza out. Instead, it had the consistency of old graham crackers and the taste of day-old pizza crust. Some people like day-old pizza crust, but I only like it when the pizza is actually a day old. The crust could easily be improved with a little more oil or fat brushed onto it, better kneading to produce a flakier, lighter crust, and being served hot, which always makes crust soft and delicious.

* Cheese: cheese was tasty and really gooey, almost like you could wrap it around the globe without it breaking. That's a great cheese experience.

Service was excellent and the waitress was really warm-hearted. Maybe I caught them at an off-hour for their kitchen, but I probably wouldn't come back here again. The quest for good Chicago deep dish continues...
author: Erol A.

description:
My advice: order take out!

Pesto Chicken (thin crust): pesto, chicken, mushrooms and onions. Delicious! Best of the night!

Classic (deep dish): sausage, mushrooms, onions and bell peppers. My second time having this. Just as good as the first time. Classic indeed!

White Pie (thin crust): mozzarella,  zucchini, tomatoes and feta cheese. Being that it was vegetarian, it was not bad.

Little Star (deep dish): spinach, mushrooms, onions, garlic, feta and ricotta cheese. Our least favorite. It was too tangy and the ingredients were lost in the sauce.

While the pizzas were good, it wasn't worth....

1) waiting 2 hours for a table. Doesn't take reservations + big party = wait wait wait.

2) being split up. Even after waiting for so long, they had to split our party up into 2 tables.

3) dealing with rude hostess. Our smaller table for 4 was set up first, and so some of us sat down to wait. The hostess made a big deal about having 6 people at the table. We told her 2 of us were tired of standing and will move once the other table was ready. Nope, she made our friends go back to the waiting area. 

4) dealing with douchy patrons. The bigger table was ready soon after and we noticed that there was a table open next to it. My BF went over and politely asked if we can switch tables so we can be next to our friends. Not only did those guys said no, they rambled on to each other for 10 minutes that we were trying to give them a crappy table and then went up to the hostess to complain. A**holes!

Being that all those things happened before dining, the pizzas just didn't taste as good. Our experience was soured. 

ORDER TAKE OUT!
author: Marti L.

description: I ordered the spicy wings and Greek salad to go for $30.00. The food was delish especially the salad. I only gave them 4 stars because the server was really rude and they didn't have utensils...hopefully next time will be better.
author: Harriet A.

description: If you're feeling deep dish, Little Star will not disappoint you. If you're not feeling pizza, go somewhere else.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Super misleading sign about happy hour - says red and white wine $4. Turns out that applies only to house wine which is not listed on the menu

Also check your receipts - after we tried to order the house wine they charged us the normal price anyway!
author: Courtney W.

description:
Hands down the best pizza in SF

the way to go for two people is the 9' deep dish with half little star and half classic. The crust is a fucking revelation, the best crust I've ever had ever.

This place is absolute pizza nirvana. When I die bury me at Little Star.
author: Molly S.

description: This is probably the best deep dish i've had since Chicago. We had both a deep dish, thin crust and 2 salads for a group of 6. All was excellent!!! We had to wait 30min for a table  because the place was hopping, but the staff were great and the service was excellent. Definitely a place worth going to to get a pizza fix.
author: Ron B.

description: The one star is for the pizza which is very good. The 4 missing stars is for the service. I have been here three times in past two years. Never has the service been great. Indifferent host, and servers in general but I was always with a good group of folks the last two times so we really didn't give it much thought then. The last time was downright terrible.  Nasty, angry staff, so rude we walked out.
author: Uda W.

description:
I love pizza, but I finally got to try the place everyone's been talking about (Little Star). The place where deep dish pizza is supposedly identical to Chicago. What's my verdict? Well bud, you guys are awesome, but you're no Chicago. 

I've spent a summer in Chicago and go back often to taste the deliciousness of deep dish pizza. The pizza at Little Star was definitely good (we had appetizers, thin crust, and deep crust pizza). Although for some reason the deep dish pizza fell short for me.

I highly recommend the little star house special deep dish since that is the most popular one. Tasty, delicious, but a little too saucy for my taste. I will say though that their crust is on point. I recommend getting to this place ahead of time because seats do fill up fast. 

In terms of the thin slice pizza there are two that are amazing (pesto chicken and the white pizza). Can't go wrong with either. Oh one more thing, don't get the garlic bread. You'll be disappointed. It's fancy, but not really tasty. Get the chicken wings instead.
author: Nathan L.

description:
If you're in San Francisco and looking for really good pizza this is the spot! I have to be honest I wasn't that excited to come here because pizza is pizza... With that said this pizza is unlike any other pizza I've ever had. THE CRUST!!! Holy crap. So sooooo good. You just have to try it yourself I can't exactly describe it.

It's located in the mission, which from what I'm told it's an upcoming cool little neighborhood. The inside is very nice I love the ambience. We came for dinner and got to sit in front of the large windows and it was so lovely to be able to watch the hustle and bustle of the city life.

Prices are decent and service is friendly. Definitely going to be a staple when I'm in town.
author: Lexi C.

description:
Hands down the best pizza place in town, consistently good even when we order delivery. Cornbread deep dish crust is soooo good, toppings are fresh.

I'm from Chicago, I wouldn't call this chicago-style other than the sauce is on the top rather than under the cheese.
author: Loralyn S.

description: Secret Menu- Monkey something with sausages... and deliciousness. It's a deep dish pizza, not on their menu. Extremely filling. :) Little Star is kind of on the pricier side of pizza places, but it's very good. I'd definitely come here to impress a date, friends, or my family.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
What can I say about this place that hasn't already been said? I was recommend this place by my brother about 6 years ago and I haven't missed an opportunity yet to come here and enjoy some delicious pizza (and beer, at least for me). Ever since Pizzeria Uno's has gone out of business (at least in SF) I needed to find a place to satisfy my chicago style deep dish pizza cravings. Look no further, I have found the place. It may be a little pricey ($18+ for a pie) but it is well worth it! The ambience is amazing too, it feels like you're in a secluded little area in a hole in the wall. The lighting is just perfect for those romantics out there and the service is amazing and the staff is very friendly. I have yet to find a problem here and I will be coming here until the day I die (or can no longer afford food). 

Cheers!
author: Carlos K.

description: I'm not a vegetarian but the veggie deep dish from Little Star is a standard in our local restaurant rotation. So good.
author: Arjun K.

description:
I've never had to try so hard to get a waiter's attention. It was not a nice experience. And today was the first day I've ever walked out of a restaurant after ordering.

There were only a couple tables seated when we came in around 1:50 and were promptly seated. Our waitress was nice and took our order for a couple personal pizzas and a small salad. A couple was seated 7-10 mins afterward. 

Fast forward twenty minutes and not only do we not have any food, the couple seated after us has already gotten their salad. To make matters worse for us, a group of 25 adults and small children came to eat. So now the two waiters are busy putting together their tables and getting their orders ready while we waited to be acknowledged.

Our waitress was still around, adding napkins and forks to empty tables while I kept trying to flag her down before she would dash off to the kitchen. I even got up from the table and said 'excuse me' and she either didn't hear because of all the screaming children or didn't care and rushed back of the kitchen. The other waiter saw me try and flag her down but was taking down the order for the large party. In a full 30 minutes, no one ever checked on our table so after once last wave in her direction, we left.
author: Angela R.

description: I love deep dish pizza. I love the extra sauce, the thicker crust and all the toppings and cheese. I was pleasantly surprised by Little Star's unique crust and their delicious sauce. Keep in mind that you'll be waiting 25+ minutes for your pizza though!
author: Amy Y.

description: The deep dish pizza will win your heart. The best description I've heard of it is: "it's like eating lasagnas". I would recommend to share one deep dish and one regular pizza for a table of 4. You will leave the place with a happy belly!
author: Olivia M.

description:
I'd been having a craving for really good Chicago style pizza for a while and kept hearing about Little Star. This is probably one of the most hyped up pizza places I've ever been to. There was about a 45 minute wait on a Sunday night.

My friends and I opted for 2 pies:
1. Little Star (Spinach, ricotta and feta, mushrooms and onions). 
2. Classic (Sausage, mushrooms, onions and green peppers)

Overall they were both pretty good. However, Little Star puts their own unique twist on their recipe, adding in cornmeal into the dough. This gives it a little bit more crunch than traditional deep dish pies but I found at times it was a little too dry for my taste. I'll have to come back and try the thin crust one of these days...
author: Calvin H.

description:
When my friend said he likes deep dish pizza one day, I immediately set a time to come back to Little Star.

Arguably, the best deep dish pizza in SF...though...I don't believe there are many places that do deep dish pizza. That being said...its not the BEST ever, just the best for the area. They use cornmeal in the crust, or on the baking surface, so there's a bit of extra crunch to it. That being said...I'm not sure how much I like the cornmeal texture to my pizza. I kind of want just a GOOD CRUST, you know? No extra stuff to try to make it more crunchy. 

They're well known for their little star, I guess. I keep hearing about it from people. I'm somewhat of a carnivore when it comes to pizza, so their menu staples aren't very enticing. I often add meats to the Little Star or something. 

I haven't come during a busy time (usually around 1), so I've never had to wait in line for it. The waiters I've had are pretty good, and very attentive. They have another location in Burlingame (Blue Line?) and multiple locations in SF, so you can have your pick of locations!
author: Lily W.

description:
Having deep dish pizza, cheesecake, and chicken wings for lunch made me feel a little guilty. It was evil, but evil in a good way, like Darth Vader or Tony Soprano. Despite being evil, you love them or these foods nonetheless.

The great debate of thinner crust compared to deep dish isn't even a comparison for me.  In deep dish the main attraction has got to be the sauce. In the thinner crust the cheese is the main attraction. Both good, but just totally different to me. 

That being said, before the main event I asked to have a slice of the homemade cheesecake. I must say its a nice, soft, creamy goodness. Not at all overwhelmingly rich like some cheesecakes. Just right. One of the best i've ever had.

Next came the wings. Not the traditional buffalo sauce wings that I admit, I love. But a nice change of pace. Savory, spicy, dry rub, favor filled wings. 

25 minutes later my reason for coming to Little Star arrived.  Deep dish pizza can be a thing of beauty. But does it taste as good as it looks? Not having a lot of experience with deep dish pizzas, in my opinion, the sauce was tasty, had good tasting toppings, along with a crust that held the pizza together with a solid cornmeal taste. 

When ordering a diet coke, the waitress told me they served Virgil's cola which is an organic version of coke.  I also noticed the salad is served as organic.  And while I'm very conflicted in my feelings towards things organic. I'm unconflicted in my love for the food at Little Star and my intentions to return for more guilty, evil, awesomeness.
author: Michael L.

description: i'm not too crazy about pizza, but the hubby wanted to try it. All I have to say is WoW.. it's really good! that crust was pretty amazing.
author: Emily K.

description:
Wow.  In the world of (stuffed crust) pizza, I like to think I'm hard to impress... but impress me Little Star did.  (I'm kind of a regular at Patxi's, and wanted to give LS a try since I moved nearby.)  Got the stuffed 9" with pepperoni and black olives on half and mushrooms and sausage on the other half - and each half triggered an endorphin rush that reminded me of my satisfied pizza cravings as a child.  I'm not sure why I enjoyed it so much more than my usual Patxi's dose, but here are my guesses: LS has a "juicier chunkier" tomato sauce, LS's pizza came out hotter, with the cheese more fully melted, LS's cheese might have been saltier (the secret to all good mozzarellas!), and LS used kalamata olives (see previous salt comment).

Despite my expectations that the pepp / olive side would "win," the sausage / shroom side was the winner for me.  Those mushrooms are magical, but I think still legal.

Also got the Boylan's black cherry soda which is a highly recommended adventure in calorie density.
author: Aaron M.

description: Really delicious! We ordered the chicken wings, spicy but solid. Vegetarian deep dish and the deep dish special BBQ chicken. Both were really good! Crust is nice and crisp and the tomato sauce is bot overly sweet like some other places. Pre order if you know what you want while you be wait to be seated :) will be back for sure!
author: Chauanh D.

description:
Pizza lovers, drop what you're doing and go eat at Little Star! 

Every time I eat here, a part of me feels like I'm cheating on my East Bay favorite - Zachary's. However, after spending some time contemplating, I have officially come to the conclusion that Little Star serves the best deep dish pizza in the Bay Area...Yes, even better than Zachary's! 

The restaurant is cozy and cute. It's pretty small, but luckily, we've always managed to get a table without waiting too long. I can imagine it being pretty crazy on the weekends. The pizza is SO good. The crust alone deserves 5 stars.  If you haven't been here yet, I highly recommend that you go!
author: Suki B.

description:
The pizza was all good but had to wait for so much time to get the order on hand. The people are not so responsive and forget about getting a table. You hardly see people responding back to you. 

The best deep dish you can get in SF.
author: Sharan N.

description:
My boyfriend's mom was visiting, and they picked up a pizza pie for take-out and brought it home, so I finally got to try this legendary SF pizza place. 

I loved the crust, which is not usually what I like about pizza, but it was incredible. It's made of cornmeal and it was crunchy, yet soft and buttery. It was absolutely delicious. No one should leave the crust behind on this pizza pie!

The deep dish pie is all about the sauce. It wasn't very cheesy though. We got the "Little Star" which had spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic. It was really good. 

Also, because it's deep dish, it's so filling! 1 slice will fill you up! The 3 of us had this pie for dinner, and then his mom left and we had the pizza for dinner for the next TWO nights. Wow, one pie for 3 meals! Excellent! I think price per serving, it's a great value!

I would totally order from here again.
author: Rebecca G.

description: Consistently delicious. Wine and beer selection solid, but would welcome some new red wines and IPAs. Our fave is the deep dish Classic and having them swap out the green bell peppers for roasted garlic - perfection!
author: Michael L.

description: I'm a pizza aficionado and to have deep dish from anywhere but Chicago may seem like a sin, but Little Star does a great job putting up a fight. Most people will put this place up in ranks against Zachary's, and I will say that both are delightful in their own ways. They emulates the famous cornmeal crust here perfectly and the toppings are on point. We got a half meatball and half spicy sausage pizza (which btw, I highly recommend because the hot peppers are dynamic and you can get any this crust pizza made as a deep dish). The only thing I would say is that per the portion size of the salad it could be a little cheaper (a large will not really feed a family of 4, so good thing we only had 3). A large pizza will feed 4, but is a little pricey at $29. Also the Pinot noir choice in house could have been better. Maybe I'm just spoiled by the price's at Lou Malnati's in Chicago haha. Other than the price point this places serves up quality food
author: Carly H.

description:
Be prepared! You have been warned!!
Have a little extra time and be patient. The place is tiny and the wait is long but no worries, it's all worth it. I have thought about impromptu trips from Vegas to sf just to eat some of the delicious pizza!
You can put your name down and walk to neighboring bars to have a drink while you wait.
Come hungry and get ready to gorge until you can gorge no more!

Nothing little about the flavor a and perfect texture of the crust and savory, fresh ingredients.

I wish I had some now!!
author: Kather M.

description:
Wow! I absolutely love pizza. My friend and I shared a large Mediterranean chicken pizza. It was beyond amazing! The cornmeal crust had a nice crunch and they didn't skimp on the pizza fillings. 

It's also quite cheap. A large costs $24, so if you're with a bunch of friends it can end up being a good deal.
author: Connie M.

description:
Little Star gets a lot of hype. Some people like to hate things that get too much hype. Don't be stupid and hate on Little Star because it is so good and everyone knows it. Unless you own a nearby, much-less-prosperous pizza place. Then I guess you have the right to be a hater. I probably would be too and go into another business, such as dying cats' fur. 

If you are a tourist, a newborn, or an alien and have never heard of Little Star but are Yelping for some good pizza in SF and run into this review, I will tell you this: It is my favorite deep dish pizza that I have ever had. No, I have never been to Chicago, so Chicagoans, please don't plot my death. 

My favorite pizza is the self titled, "Little Star" but I always replace the mushrooms with salami because my BF thinks mushrooms are tiny little Hitlers that will kill him slowly if he eats them.

I like the Mission locations ambiance better than the Divisadero locations for unknown reasons.
author: Liz M.

description: I ordered a large thin with pep, mushrooms, basil, and fresh mozzarella.  The crust was on point, good cheese and sauce...but very light on the mushrooms , and not much basil either...$33 for a large that wasn't that large, unfortunately don't think ill be returning despite the crispy crust
author: N A T E G.

description:
San Francisco is no Chicago or New York when it comes to pizza, but Little Star does a decent job tackling both the deep dish and thin crust arenas. 

I came with a friend on a Tuesday around 6PM and there was no wait (mostly empty). The tables are set very close to each other against the wall so there might be a bit of a struggle to get out after stuffing yourself with pizza. They dimmed the lights around 6:30PM because everyone knows gourmet pizza is the most romantic meal of this American lifetime.

- Mediterranean Chicken (deep dish): There was not that much chicken (not sure I could identify this as Mediterranean-inspired either), but the artichokes and onions added texture to the saucy concoction that is deep dish pizza. The cornmeal in the crust is also very noticeable and a unique touch (grainy texture, but not in a bad way).

- White Pie (thin crust): Our waiter sent back our first pie because he said "Something about it didn't look right. We have very high standards for our pizza!" Thanks, kind waiter with a mustache! The vegetable (zucchini & tomatoes) and cheese combination is just the right amount of flavor, but I wish the crust was slightly thinner.

Two small pizzas (~$18-20 each) between the two of us were more than enough; we finished the deep dish and took home 2/3 of the thin crust. If you want tasty and not-overtly-pretentious pizza, Little Star is a fine choice!
author: Jessica F.

description: First time here.  Came with a party of 6 on 12/27/14 and the food here was outstanding.  Ordered garlic bread, spicy chicken wings,  pepperoni deep dish pizza and the thin crust pesto pizza.  Great stuff.  Juke box was a nice treat.
author: Lilly C.

description: Born and raised in Chicago and spent my first 42 years there. Moved last year to San Diego and thought I'd never have good pizza in California. Over the last year I visited many of the "Chicago" style pizza places littered across California. I just relocated again burg this time up north in the City. All I have to say is that Little Star is definitely the best I've had so far! Very authentic and tastes great! If you're getting it for take out, ask them not to cut the pie. It's a little Chicago trick that allows the crust to stay crispy until you get it home. Great job Little Star! I'll be back probably weekly!
author: Bobby B.

description:
Tried Little Star last weekend and thought it was good.  Ordered a few items such as the chicken wings for appetizer.  They weren't bad.

I ordered The Classic pizza.  It didn't take too long to make.  Deep dish pizza's usually take a little longer to make due to the amount of ingredients that are on it.  Pizza tasted ok.  I wish there was a bit more sauce on it though.  The winner here clearly was the crust.  They do crust correctly here.  It's got that corn meal type of crust that's pretty legit.  I've tried Lou Malnati's in Chicago and this one has that same great taste.  For Chicago pizza, I'd definitely recommend this one in SF.
author: Christian M.

description: This place is delicious!  This is the first place I tried this style of deep dish with the cornmeal crust and sauce on top, and man is it good.  It's my boyfriend's favorite pizza place ever, so we go here literally every time we are in SF.  Yum yum yum..  the Little Star, which is vegetarian is really good, and the Classic is also delicious.  I assume they are all pretty awesome though bc the crust is really what makes it!
author: Sonia S.

description: We came here on a sunday night for dinner! It's a busier part of town but we were hungry. We ordered the original deep dish with the goddess salad. The pizza was so good. The crush isn't your average doughy deep dish crust it's made from cornmeal? It had more crunch and the pizza itself wasn't super greasy but just right. I really enjoyed it... so much that I had 3 slices! I also got to try out some of their beers on tap and since they were local breweries the prices was unbeatable! Nothing like beer and pizza while enjoying the All Star game on the TV there! I really liked this place, it was homey and the staff here were so hospitable and nice! Definitely try this place out if you're having a pizza craving!
author: Jen T.

description:
Hello world of Yelp!  I have been gone for so long!  It's almost one month... that's a long time to be gone....

What better way to come back than to write about one of the best deep dish joints in San Francisco.  

Little Star pizza with sausage.  YUM!  Oh I just love how the cheese gets so stringy and the flavors just blend so perfectly in my mouth.  AND, I totally love the cornmeal crust.  Little Star, you know what you're doing.

But this little slice of heaven will cost you about an hour to an hour and a half wait time.  Fortunately, both of the Little Star restaurants that I've been to also have a bar, which totally helps with the long wait time.

In addition to waiting an hour or so for your seat, it takes about another 30 minutes for them to bake the pie.  Uhg, at this point, I'm pretty much starving.  So we ordered the spicy hot wings.  Alright, some of you may know this about me.. but I'm not a fan of saucy wings.  I know, call me a weirdo.  I like my sauce on the side for some reason.  However, these bad boys are the only saucy wings I'll eat.  That has to say something right?  They are delicious!  A pang of flavor.  A nice hit of spice.  Mm!  It's pretty much perfection right there.

At the end of our meal, I pretty much feel like I have a 7 month old food baby growing inside me.  It is not a pleasant feeling.  Load up on the Tums... you'll probably need it.  But trust, it's well worth it.


Happy eating!
author: Cecilia S.

description:
LOVE. I might be a little biased since it's my first deep dish pizza but regardless, it's 1000% awesome compared to all the pizza I've had.
I split a small (9") veg pizza with a friend. Although my stomach told me I was at capacity by two slices, I ended up eating half the pie - it was too good to stop! And pizza is so delicious when it's fresh.

The crust is amazing with the cornmeal and tender texture. The cheese is plentiful and stringy, but not overly greasy (this is coming from a regular pizza blotter). The balance of vegetables was nice, though the tomatoes stood out.

Overall the atmosphere fit in really well with the neighborhood - the bathroom decor even included some graffiti! (some intentional and others.. I'm not sure)
author: Lydia N.

description: My review is from the service. The pizza is delicious. But I've ordered pizza from these guys dozens of times and it's always cold and crappy. They should just stop offering delivery from third party apps because clearly they can do their food justice. Do yourself a favor and just go. I ordered a pizza tonight and got the wrong pizza delivered. I got something that was inedible. I couldn't contact the delivery company(Postmates) and the person answering the phones put me on hold for ten minutes after telling me they didn't have my order and that it was divisedero that had it, I called them and they said they didn't have my order, only to call back to Valencia  and them to say, they maybe had my order but it was under a different name(not sure how that works, but whatever.) and that they are two totally separate companies etc. I just wanted my pizza! What the hell happened to companies that took responsibility for their mistakes. Even dominos had a crappy commercial about how their pizza sucked, they tried to make it better. The guys, didn't. I'd say it left a bad taste in my mouth but that's pretty obvious. I've given this company the benefit of the doubt multiple multiple times and they have always failed. And they'll give you some crap about how it's this companies fault or it's out of our hands, have you tried contacting them. At the end, they hire these companies and it's their product that's represented. So find a company that does a better job. Anyways I'm really pissed off about my pizza. I just wanted dinner and now they've lost a customer.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Earlier this year, I was craving some pizza and it just so happened that Little Star Pizza was close by.

I called in an order for a thin crust pepperoni pizza and within minutes, it was ready for pickup.

The crust is thin and crunchy, which I love, but the pizza in general was okay. I'd be willing to come back to try their deep dish.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Small little place but good atmosphere.  Thankfully we didn't have to stay in line, but usually there is a line. We had a party of 4 and ordered just one pizza, the classic.  We also had a small bowl of anchovies.  It was salty anchovies, goes very well with the pizza but it's not for everyone. 

There's literally a pizza joint at every corner in this area, but I would visit this place again.
author: Teresa N.

description:
As a Chicago-style enthusiast, the options in San Francisco are very limiting given the city's pizza style-agnostic backdrop.  I will say that Little Star is up there with the best of them in San Francisco in the Chicago-style class.

The sauce is sweet, the cornmeal crust is cooked with exceptional precision and the sausage is tasty.  The small deep dish is a perfect meal for 2 (or meal for 1 with leftovers tomorrow).

I've never eaten in - only carry out, but several times.  The service has always been fast and friendly.

Strongly recommend trying it.
author: Jason F.

description: Love this place. For my money, it's the best deep dish pizza that's west of Chicago. A lot of Bay Area natives will claim Paxti's is better, but Paxti's can't beat Little Star's amazing corn meal crust.
author: Billy G.

description:
Quality pizza! This is my neighborhood pizza place and I feel spoiled to say so. I have never been disappointed with the quality of food. The crust is done right every time and that's a hard task to feat. Never soggy and always has a little crunch. Oh, by the way, I order the thin crust. The deep dish is great too but thin crust is my style. It amazing when I go back with different friends and try their favorite pizzas how much I like their selections. That makes it exciting when you can order anything and be pretty certain it will be delicious. 


I live just a couple blocks away so when I have people over sometimes I'll order in and call ahead before picking up. A few weeks back I ordered in advance by phone and when I got there it wasn't ready. They were super accommodating and gave me and my friends free beers while we waited. Just when I thought customer service was dead, Little Star surprised me.
author: Kelly C.

description: I ordered a deep dish pizza and a small one not personal but small and they did it 1/2 and 1/2 , I think it was the best pizza I have ever had and I have had a lot . You will pay a little more but soo worth it. I will be back
author: Daniel M.

description:
What's not to love about Little star pizza? Deep dish pizza ooohh, the individual slices are huge and fulfilling. NO complaints here. My friend Joy A. below me introduced me to this place and I love it! Not just ordinary pizza like round table, pizza hut or domino's but Chicago style!!! good salad too!!

I haven't been here in a couple of months but want to stop by soon!! Second to this place, I like Zachary's pizza.
author: Kathy V.

description:
After searching around for a nice late night dinner spot, a friend and I settled on this deep dish pizza joint.

First off, the atmosphere of the place is great. The decor fits well with the space and it was definitely a happening spot this particular evening.

We started out with a drink from the bar as we waited for our table. Upon being seated, we decided to go with a deep dish pizza with pepperoni, sausage, and sun dried tomatoes.

The pizza was good, though I thought that it could have been a tad bit flakier for the crust. The pizza was big enough for the both of us as we ended up bringing about half of it home.

Overall, the pizza wasn't the best deep dish I've had, but it was pretty tasty nonetheless. And the service and atmosphere added to a positive dining experience.
author: Ryan R.

description:
I've been eyeing Little Star for quite some time, but am usually deterred by a combination of hanger and egregiously long lines. No sir or ma'am, I do not have a deep, impassioned interest in waiting in a long-ass line for pizza. Because that is such an annoyingly San Franciscan thing to do. Are people waiting in line for pizza in New York or Chicago? No! Actually, I have no idea if they are. But if people in SF are willing to wait 2 hours in the RAIN for day-old New York bagels as we've recently had the misfortune to witness, you better be damn sure they're camping out for allegedly delicious deep dish. 

Anyway, sometimes the stars align and you start shouting at a couple of your friends that we should go to Little Star RIGHT NOW because TIME IS RUNNING OUT to get there before the line starts casually snaking around the city blocks, collecting people like dead cats on an episode of Hoarders because that's how lines in this city work. 

We only had to wait 15 minutes, which was chill. 

My motley party of three consisted of one wily fellow detailing his disdain for deep dish in excruciating detail, something about "if I wanted shitty soggy bread in tomato sauce I'd make it myself" but I quickly tuned him out in favor of the other kinder gentleman in our group who had 1. been to Little Star and 2. loved it. 

The service was really swell and the caprese salad was delicious in it's simple perfection. We ordered the Classic deep dish and I honestly don't remember what was in it but you should stop whatever you're doing, go there now, and shamelessly stuff it in your face because it was that good. 

Long story short, we had a truly magical time and even The Grinch Who Hated Deep Dish went home happy and content. It was pretty much a fairy tale. 

Until next time, Little Star. The end. :)
author: Meredith C.

description:
Little Star is the answer to my deep dish prayers. The Combo deep dish is heavenly. Between the freshness of the ingredients and the amazingly, perfectly baked crust (do I taste cornbread??) you cannot beat it.

I can't recommend the garlic bread enough, either. It's so much more than your average garlic bread. It's warm bread complemented by FRESH ROASTED GARLIC and warm butter. Like, excuse me as I wipe the drool off my keyboard.

Also you better have Boylan's Dark Cherry bottled soda because it's fantastic.
author: Mariah O.

description:
Great food. Incredibly disappointing experience.

Called in an order for a couple of pizzas, wings and a salad for take-out. While walking the few blocks to pick it up, my friends and I realized we were too hungry and tired to bring the food home so we decided to ask the restaurant if we could just eat there. Figured if there was room for them to accommodate us, we'd be able to do that. But no. While the restaurant was half-empty on this Sunday night, the hostess with the big attitude said there was some rule about not being able to eat there once the food was ordered to go. We asked why. No real answer... something about it being a policy of theirs. I went up to the bar where we were told to pay for the meal and asked the person manning the bar if there was any way an exception could be made. He said that if there was room at the bar, we could eat there. There was no room at the bar and no sign of space opening up for our party of four, so I asked to pay right away so that we could take the food out as soon as it was ready. We waited. And waited. And waited. Over a half hour later (an hour and a half after placing the order) and hungrier and more tired, I approached the bar again. After waiting a good 5 minutes for someone to arrive behind the bar, the same guy came back. 

"Where is our food, please?" 
"Oh, I thought you were waiting for a space at the bar to open up. The food has been ready for a while." 
"WHAT? I never said that! And could you have verified that when you put the food away to keep warm. We were sitting right there in front of the bar this whole time."
"Oh, it was a miscommunication."

It was bad service. Terrible customer experience. Ridiculous policy, or at least a complete lack of explanation for it. Total attitude and disinterest. 

We called an Uber so that we could get home quickly and finally eat. Yes, it was delicious. But it was a painful experience. #fail
author: Maria Elena R.

description:
Having been back several times now, I maintain my stance that Little Star is far tastier than Zachary's over in East Bay. But, I will admit that the cornmeal crusts are a love-it-or-hate-it kind of thing. I find them reminiscent of croutons: airy, crunchy, and almost cookie-like in texture. Personally, I like this more than I do regular crusts (which I'll often toss away), but I know a fair number of people who dislike it, and/or consider it too "healthy".

Not that they don't suffer from a slight saltiness problem though. While the flavor is great, and the first slice is usually fine, the salt starts creeping up on you by the time you hit your second or third piece. Fortunately, I'm usually comfortably full after a single slice, so this becomes a somewhat moot issue for me.

Waits can be a bit long around dinner time, with my longest having been almost 45 minutes. Pro tip: order in line about 30 minutes before you're to be seated. That way, your deep dish pizza will be there to greet you by the time you sit down at your table!

If you'd rather wait, or manage to be seated quickly, and want an appetizer, the garlic bread is a popular, and interesting, choice: a loaf of sourdough is served alongside butter, and an entire glove of roasted garlic, resulting in a DIY garlic bread of sorts.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Did the deep dish thing. My friend and I agreed it was a solid B/B+, using Zachary's as the gold standard for deep dish pizza in these parts. Perhaps this is unfair, but it was a tough Monday at work and we felt vindictive and deserving of pizza at the same time. Also, we once dressed up as ninja turtles and fought in the Valentine's Day pillow fight together, so one must trust the judgment of their hero-on-a-half-shell comrade-at-arms. 

The tomato sauce had more of a chunky stewed tomato thing/less of a rich sauce texture than I prefer, and the crust was on the lighter/drier side. Toppings were tasty and fresh - we had the classic and added whole garlic- never a bad idea. Overall, pretty satisfying if you can't make the trip up to Rockridge. Put it this way - I wouldn't wait an hour in line for this pizza, but I'd probably crawl through mud and sit in a puddle for 46 minutes for Zachary's.

Service was quick and friendly, and it didn't take long for our food to arrive.
author: Selina K.

description:
Came here today, on a sunday, at noon and  were sat right away.  It never got crowded.

We ordered the large thin crust pizza with garlic and basil.  For $24 it is super pricey but it's very good.

We then walked to Rainbow Grocery.
author: Foodlover B.

description: Food good. Staff pleasant. Manager responsive to complaints (I still have his email). When they say "20 minutes," it's more like 45 mins (in my experience) but it's worth the wait.
author: R. O.

description: a journey to find parking...circling and circling....reverse and circling...mission parking literally a mission...called in advance and table ready....group pizza and beer dinner...two deep and two standard thin...vegetarian deep dish quite tomato sauce and vegetable delight...softened garden in red sauce in deep crust a favorite...standard meat deep dish a sausage feast...cornmeal crust always great and crowd favorite...still can't understand the little star thin crust pizza...not great and wonder why order thin crust at little star?
author: Hen A.

description:
Surprisingly first time I've eaten pizza in SF, despite living here all my life and my lifelong love of pizza! Costco doesn't count haha!

Atmosphere of Little star is cozy and relaxed. You could have a casual date here, especially if you love pizza (if you took me on a pizza date, I'd probably be the happiest girl in the world). 

Pizza itself was super good! I don't know if it was the fact that the only thing I had eaten in the previous 6 hours were multiple cups of ice cream, but damn this pizza was good. We got a large deep-dish style pizza, half Little Star, and half something with chicken. Both were really good, and the crust held up really well. The sauce itself was nice and flavorful; my friend who hates tomatoes actually really likes this sauce because it tasted like more than just...tomato.

Would come again!
author: Denise C.

description:
Best of both worlds, thin crust and deep dish. Little Star makes 'em so good I can't help but to order both!

I'm a red pepper flake girl, on my pasta and on my pizza... anytime and anywhere. The zesty sauce that tops the sausage and veggies in the Classic is one of the best I've ever tried. I completely forget about the red pepper flakes! The deep dish crust is unbelievably light and crisp at the same time, with a hint of sweetness from the cornmeal crust. I can easily order one of these and keep it to myself. Easy.

The thin crust is just as amazing, and if dining in, order this first and eat it as you wait for your deep dish. The pesto in the Pesto Chicken has a nice thickness to it, and is swirled around your thin crust pizza topped with chicken, onions and mushrooms. Not too filling, but delish! Leftovers stay crisp.

I've eaten in and also have ordered for pick up. I've heard such great things about the garlic bread, so I ordered it for pick up. Big mistake. The concept of assembling your own garlic bread just loses it's appeal as you unpack the warm bread out of the foil, take the container of melted butter out and look at your roasted garlic thinking... now what? It's also not as enjoyable when you already have your pizzas there in front of you! Skip this if it's to go! 

Eat in or take out... Thin crust or deep dish... Little Star is the way to go!
author: S Y.

description:
If you're a deep dish, thick crust loving girl like me, then Little Star is totally for you

If you're a thin crust loving individual, Little Star is still totally for you

Ordered a bunch of take out for movie night at a sick friend's place b/c pizza allows us to each get our ideal combo - as we're all picky, persnickety, so-n-sos - & this sets us up for maximum movie enjoyment

Thin Crust - pepperoni & mushroom for the diseased one.....she really liked how the crust wasn't too thin to be floppy but not thick for too much bread ( I don't know what the heck this last comment means since there's no such thing as too much crust )

Veggie Deep Dish w/ Pepperoccini & Sundried Tomatoes added - the bf said this was nice & spicy

I chose the Deep Dish w/ Mushrooms, Olives & Gorgonzola - wow was this thing flavorful.  Tomato sauce was very tomatoie yet didn't take away from the other toppings like I've found w/ places who don't really have deep dish but rather offer stuffed pizzas (cough, Zachery's)

We both also thought the cornmealy texture to the crust made it outstanding & provided just a bit of extra crunch & it was thick enough to be the perfect ratio of bread to toppings

it was all super yummy & stood the refrigerator test b/c it was likewise just as scrumptious the next couple days

Future movie nights will totally see us back here at Little Star!
author: Adrienne G.

description: WOW. I am appalled at the terrible service. My boyfriend and I tried to eat here this evening and were turned away. We arrived at 9:30pm (because the sign on the front door says open until 10 as well as the listed Yelp time) and were told, "sorry, we are closed". Huhhh??? Closed? There were at least 15 people eating in the dining room. This was once one of our favorite local pizza spots....guess we will be frequenting other Mission pizza spots that offer better service. Don't waste your time going here.
author: Ashley A.

description:
1/2 of the Dream Team had their 24th birthday yesterday, and picked up pizza to go. She got the Little Star, and they included a slice of cheesecake.  

I really loved the thick cheese, acidic tomato sauce, and punchy garlic. But the crust reminded me of Chuck E Cheese. Straight up. (It tastes NOTHING like Chuck E Cheese pizza, I swear, it just reminded me of eating pizza at Chuck E Cheese. Probably because we were eating it for a birthday celebration and there was a gigantic cake and my roommate was singing.)

And their cheesecake.... oh... my.... that was some of the best I've had in SF. Well done, Little Star.
author: Emily D.

description: The go-to place in SF for deep dish.  Of course my Chicago friends say it isn't quite "Chicago Deep Dish"...but they LOVE IT just the same!!!
author: Felipe A.

description:
Ok I've heard about this place for a while, finally went to lunch with some coworkers. We ordered the salad with almonds and pesto sauce, very yummy and fresh.
Pizzas: Thin italian combo and classic, honestly should have gone with the deep dish pizza but thin was still good. Crust was actually perfect and I am not a crust fan but I ate it all.
You would think it was closed from the outside, we got there around 12 which was a perfect time, it fills up during the lunch hour.  One coworker claimed it was cold in there, the server heard her and turned up the heat. I though that gave a star on it's own for wonderful service. 
Great food, great service, will come back for deep dish pizza!
author: Lana K.

description:
Little star is always good. It will always be good. 

The deep dish crust is one of a kind, crunchy and delicious. If you dont like tomatoes, you will not like Little Star. I almost always get the Little Star Deep Dish pizza, its covered in tomatoes and has spinach and onions and ermergerd soooo gooood!! 

I tried the garlic bread because i was starving and i knew the pizza would take quite a bit, and it was amazing as well! You get to spread the garlic, as much as you like, on your nice toasty fluffy bread, along with butter if you so choose.

If you are a fan, and a fan of deep dish pizza, you need to try this!

Also, the service was wonderful. Our waitress, i dont remember her name, she had a russian accent i think? She was very timely, friendly, and sweet. Thank you!
author: Courtney T.

description:
stretchy cheese?  I've been to little star twice and have tried their salads, thin, and deep dish pizzas.  I love their classic deep dish for the amazing cheese and the white thin crust pizza!  

Ordered their "garlic bread" which was slices of bread, and cloves of baked garlic.  Interesting concept but I would prefer that you pre-assemble my food!
author: Christine K.

description: Prompt, couteous and super friendly staff. The deep-dish crust is perfect. Great wine selection. I will definitely be back.
author: lisa l.

description:
My Rating: 4.0 ($15 - $25/person)
Favorites: Mediterranean, Vegetarian Pizza

Pizza is usually high on my list when I have food cravings. So, it should come as no surprise that I was willing to endure a trek to the city, a 30-minute parking hunt and an additional 30-minute baking time to taste a recreation of the famed Chicago deep dish "throw that Brooklyn cardboard away" pizza. 

The restaurant itself delivers a dimly lit, but pleasant ambiance within a small space. The menu is quite straightforward with a small selection of appetizers (salads/breads) with a decent enough drinks' list to pair well with your choice of pie. However, due to the long cook time, I was slightly miffed they didn't have a more appropriate selection of appetizers. If I am about to delve into a gargantuan monstrosity of cheese, bread and sauce, I do not want to whet my appetite with MORE bread (looking at you garlic cheesy bread).

Onto the pizza itself, it is covered in a thin layer of their tomato sauce under which lay oodles of nice mozzarella cheese and toppings ranging from vegetables to different meats. As with other deep dish pizzas, after the initial tasting, you start to hit only one note of flavor. In this case, that note was a good one, easily taking care of my craving and leaving me relatively full. 

However, now we arrive at my disappointment, the crust! It tastes like cornbread. Not only that, the amount of cornmeal used has probably rendered it a bit too flaky allowing it crumble from the weight of a slice.

Is it possible to be unhappy with a four-star place? No, but with Little Star's famed pizza came a little disappointment (pun intended). Yet, Little Star Pizza will satisfy the pizza junkie, but may leave a more adventurous patron thinking about what really is the best pizza place this side of the Golden Gate?
author: Sri P.

description: Omg I have died and gone to pizza heaven !  You must go to little star, great food... If you like crust you have come to the right spot!
author: laura D.

description: Visited this place for the first time recently. The service was a bit scattered, but the pizza was really, really good. We had one of the night's specials, which was a deep dish with meatballs and a whole mess of other stuff -- and totally yummy and lots of food. We started by splitting a goddess salad, which was also quite good. The dessert menu is limited, but what we had -- a hot, fresh cookie with ice cream -- was terrific. One complaint: That great dessert cried out for some coffee to go with it, but they don't serve coffee! WTF? In my book that's a serious demerit, much as I enjoyed the food.
author: Bruce M.

description:
Can't believe that I haven't yet written a review for Little Star, one of the first pizza places I tried when moving to the Bay Area...

Little Star has a great reputation around these parts - everyone I know recommends it. So of course I had to stop by and see for myself what all the fuss was about. As soon as I walked inside, a familiar smell greeted me at the door. What was it? OMG! It was Pi, one of my favorite pizza places back in St. Louis. And then it dawned on me - this IS the same pizza as Pi, just a different name.

The owner/founder of Little Star sold his delicious cornmeal crust recipe to the owner of Pi in St. Louis a few years ago. They have some sort of agreement in regards to who can make the pizza in which state. Little Star obviously has dibs on California and Pi in St. Louis. I think Pi also has a location in Washington, D.C., but don't quote me on that one...

Anyhoo, I was elated to taste something delicious and familiar on that fated evening back in February. And whenever I'm given the opportunity, I eat Little Star. Both the locations on Mission and Divisadero are fun places to dine-in, but if you don't feel like waiting, order the pizza ahead of time and take it home. 

P.S. This is NOT Chicago-style pizza, so don't let anyone tell you otherwise. It's its own thing, a deep dish, cornmeal crust that you'll never forget.
author: Abby S.

description: I went in today and ordered an old fashion deep dish with pepperoni, olives, and red onion. I was immediately welcome by both servers. The pizza came out it was hot, gooey, and had a good Marinara base. The staff was friendly and helpful and prompt without being too involved. The restaurant was clean and the bathrooms were clean which to me is always very important. I thought the food was good and about the same price as any other deep dish joint in the area.
author: Travis R.

description:
I love deep dish Chicago style pizza! It is difficult to find a place that makes it and makes it well. Little Star is that place!

I shared the Classic deep dish pizza. It was so delicious and filing, I was full after a couple of slices. 

If you like Chicago style or even thin crust pizza, Little Star is your place.
author: Y K.

description:
Okay bitches... listen up! 

This is the end-all, be-all of deep dish pizza. You know what, they even have a side salad that will knock you off your feet. The veggies are so fresh and crunchy with the blue cheese, the nuts..oh and that dressing, you want to bathe in it.

Wait, I'm supposed to be talking about the pizza. 

Okay so the pizza. Here's what you do. Get the veggie pizza and add pepperoni. DONE!  Nope, not another word. This will take your love for pizza to new heights. The crust is so crispy and golden. The cheesy is gooey. The sauce so zesty, the veggies [again] the freshest of the fresh and cloves....CLOVES of garlic.

The wine is cheap and will treat you right. 

I like this location a dash better than the one on Divis.
author: Natalie F.

description: We had take out pizzas here almost once a month if not more. We love Italian thin crest. It never disappoints us. We ordered the spicy chicken one last time. It's way too spicy and less flavorful. Guess we will switch back to Italian again.
author: Tracy D.

description:
I don't like deep dish pizzas normally because I am a huge huge fan of cheese. However, the Little Star was one of the best, most-addicting pizzas I have ever had. Something about the spices/herbs they use maybe? 

Even though my friend and I came right around the dinner rush hour on a Friday, we were able to find seats at the bar and get service quickly. Waitress was super friendly. AND, they even serve ginger beer!
author: Melody L.

description: A-OK but a bit under whelming. If you have ever had real Chicago style pizza or Zachary's Pizza in the East Bay, this place doesn't stand up. The service was friendly and the we will most likely give them a second try but we'll first explore other options. The pizza was good but came out warm not hot?  Who wants a warm pizza on a freezing cold day, in a freezing cold restaurant? Not me! Usually when you get a deep dish the tomato sauce is bubbling and you can see the steam when you pull the piece of pie out. So it was sad to say the least. We should have sent it back to be heated more that was our fault. Also the small size pizza is so small the two of us ate the whole thing and were still hungry! I am usually stuffed by one piece of deep dish. Oh well. Oh Zachary's I love SF but wish you were in SF. Last, I'm starting to question Yelp there are a lot of great reviews for a lot of average joints in this city. That is all.
author: Susan S.

description:
Pizza with a "go-soak-yourself-attitude" - not a winning formula for success in a competitive food category (seriously, it's pizza) in a neighborhood that has lots of other restaurants.
 
No manager on a Sunday and poor customer service from the staff. Called the restaurant before it opened, as we were coming with kids - and he neglected to tell us that the restroom was out of order (it had broken down the previous day) which was a real problem with kids. In the middle of the REALLY LONG WAIT for a pizza (40 mins for two deep dish pies when there was only 2 other tables full, the rest of the restaurant was empty), I had to take my daughter out of the restaurant, cross two streets, and to a coffee shop and wait in line for 10 mins to get in the bathroom - a 15-minute inconvenience which could have been avoided if they had closed the restaurant as it is ILLEGAL TO SERVE FOOD WITHOUT AN OPERATIONAL RESTROOM (wonder about the hygiene of the place). 

Both the two waitresses had no customer/people skills - were not able to turn around a bad situation, were unsympathetic, didn't provide anything more than perfunctory service (caught my eye and I asked the other waitress, not ours, for the check, she didn't tell our waitress who was seated next to her at the bar area), then we had to walk the credit card over to them to pay as they were both seated with their backs to the entire restaurant. This, mind you, at the end of a meal that they knew hadn't gone well - clear sign that they are not interested in turning a bad experience around, but only deal with it to the level their inexperienced customer service training allows.

The deep-dish pizza was ok and so felt that the $25 base price for a 12" spinach pizza and $19 for a small cheese pizza wasn't worth it - though, honestly, the service and experience was so bad that I lost my appetite for the food. Oh, I should have mentioned, there was no manager there to help lessen our pain (the waitress, dealing with my wife, said "I'm not a plumber (shrug)". 

There are (way) better places. 

P.S. The owner has a chance to comment and tell me what he's going to do to improve the experience of the place (hopefully, he/she has better customer service skills than whom he hires).
author: Vik C.

description: The service was great, the pizza was interesting - in a good way. I think the sauce could use more flavor and potentially contain more meat, however, the crust is definitely a must try!
author: Auni A.

description: Just incredible. The deep dish pizza is as good as anything in chicago. Good stuff. Suggest it to impress anyone from out of town. You can't go wrong. The small is plenty for 2 people. Prices are reasonable for one of the best pizzas you'll have in your life! We spent $60 for 2 people, including beers.
author: Marcos A.

description:
I now retract my statement about BJs being better than Little Star.


But WHY WHY WHYYYYY did nobody inform me about the Pizza Special of the day with Bacon, Arugala, Roasted Garlic, and Bell Peppers. minus one star for that. I had to hear it when they were telling the table next to us and then kick myself for days.  :*(
author: Em F.

description:
Little Star has been on my family's must try list for a very long time...and it really did not disappoint. 

For our appetizer, we had the mixed salad. It was super light with a very fresh mix of arugula and other leafy greens. The walnuts added an excellent, but subtle nutty flavor and when paired with the gorgonzola...seriously, amazing. We ordered a family size to ensure that everyone got their fair serving of veggies for the day, but we easily cleared the plate without resistance.

For the pizzas, we were a little torn. Most of the reviews on here pointed to the deep dish pizza as the favorite, but my family definitely loves the thin crust just a little more. We settled on two pizzas: the small (9") classic deep dish and the large (12") white pie.

The classic deep dish was good. The cornmeal crust added the perfect texture to the substantial filling of sausage, mushrooms, onions, and bell peppers. My brother felt that the tomato topping was overbearing on the other flavors though. He also remarked that it tasted better as a leftover the next day.

The white pie was excellent. The fresh zucchini and tomato slice topping added a burst of flavor to every bite...and the feta cheese added an extra little twist to each bite that had it. The crust was light and again meshed well with the flavors of the pie. The only complaint we have about this one was that it was definitely on the oily side. 

We washed down our pizza by trying a ginger beer. It's not housemade, but it was still interesting to try. There is a heavy, but not overbearing, ginger flavor and it made for a good palate cleanser between the two pies such that we could really distinguish the flavors. We were excited to find out that we could buy it at our local BevMo too.

The ambiance in the restaurant is very cool. A bunch of small tables are lined up on one side against one long bench. There is also a neat little jukebox to one side. It's intimate yet still good for families. I can definitely see myself coming here again and soon.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
On a search to find the best deep dish pizza. 

So far, 1. Blue Line/Little Star 2. Zacharys 3. Patxi 4. Lou Malnatis of Chicago [havent tried genos]
Ordered a deep dish, customized with chicken, italian sausage and artichoke.
I got into deep dish pizza with Unos [R.I.P.] and since they have left the area, I had to search for the next best place. Blue Line/Little Star have perfected the cornmeal crust. The sauce has huge chunks of tomato. Not too heavy on the cheese.

I think I found it.
author: Brandon N.

description:
We sat down at the bar. It was a lovely warm Friday night in the mission. We ordered wings. They were delicious, hot and spicy.

I asked the pretty server behind the bar "what's in these, they are great." Her answer " umm, I dun know." 

"Oh okay" I responded and giggled a bit withTom who was sitting next to me.

Then a few minutes later she gives me a sweet hipster smile and a distance glaze. Oh wait then, she pipes in. (I was thinking maybe she would find out, ask the chef or do something.) She then says "I think it has some cayenne pepper in it."  Insert more giggling from me here.

My view of dining out includes delicious food and a certain knowledge & enthusiasm from the staff. Hospitality is an experience don't you think?
author: Laney S.

description: Came here to try out one of SF's pizza place and it's kind of up there with Chicago's fampus deep dish pizza. Waitress was very chill. Ordered a few beers and later offered me a free beer due to a mistake on their end on another customers order, can't let it go to waste! Overall, the environment is low key and enjoyed my stay here. Would come back again!
author: Dane L.

description: Cute little place on Mission in SF area.  You wouldn't expect the decor to be nice on the inside from the outside.  From the outside it looks like a normal pizza dive place but this place has a feel of an up and coming cool place to be.  The pizza & salad are def worth your visit.  Not necessary 100% Chicago style but pretty damn close.  Def worth a trip back with family.  Awesome beers on tap and the pinot is pretty good too.
author: Kim H.

description:
Four stars for the pizza.  I just got back from Chicago and was eager to see how this stacked up.  Decent for the Chicago standards, I must say.  We got a "Little Star" and added chicken.
