Good amount of toppings, but I'm not too huge a fan of the cornmeal crust and there was just a tad more tomato than I'd like (but nowhere near the overpowering tomato flavor of Zachary's).  Not a bad place when you need your deep dish fix and I'm looking forward to coming back so I can try some of their thin crust varieties.

I'm docking one star for the garlic bread and service.  The garlic bread was warmed bread with roasted garlic and butter that you need to spread yourself.  Booo.  We're paying, please do it for us.  Service was slow and while I can understand a deep dish taking a long time (around 45 min in Chicago), there is no reason why it should take 15 minutes for the garlic bread to come out, especially if we have to do all the work on the garlic bread...
author: Jeff C.

description:
The "little star" deep dish pizza is by far top 5 pizza I have ever tried. The crust wasnt overly puffy filling the pizza and letting little room for the toppings! And it is made out CORNMEAL!!! Yes, cornmeal. And it is o so o m g fantastic! 

The toppings were great. Fresh and soo soo flavorful! 

Gooey ooey awesomeness! 

One down fall was the garlic bread everyone raves about. The garlic clove was as big as a babies fist. Meh on the size meter...better than WTF but not as good as OMG WTF this is amazing. 

And the bread that came with it was a tad stale. 

But the true star was the pizza. Cannot get better. One of the best in the city for deep dish for sure :)
author: Michelle I.

description:
Being a native New Yorker, I am always apprehensive whenever it comes to any pizza joints.  I walked in here based on a friend's recommendation.  Although my friend has never failed me on her recommendations, she did lose some of her credibility when it comes to pizza.

I was excited at the way the place looked.  Great ambiance for a Pizza place but that is the only thing it has going for them.  Their Pizza is hands down one of the worst I have ever had.  I did both their Pan Pizza and the thin crust.  The Pan pizza was just a bunch of ingredients that tasted like it came out of a can and poured onto some pie crust.  It was totally tasteless!!  Their thin crust pizza had the weirdest texture and was overly dry and bland.

Never again.
author: Gardell T.

description: I've been here twice and have had great experiences both time. My most recent visit was yesterday and  Grabbed a table for myself after an afternoon of running errands. My server (Ramon?) was great. He checked up on me just enough and was very friendly. I had the chicken wings, which I really love. They are "spicy", but I find them more so flavorful, I like hot things and it only had a bit of a kick. I had a deep dish pepperoni & sausage pizza, which was good. Not sure if it is just the leftovers, but I found my leftovers a little on the salty side. I was drinking a beer so might not have realized it fresh. I will definitely return.
author: Candace R.

description:
Little star's western addition has a 4.5 star average while this little star in the mission has a 4 star average. What gives?! i heard western addition's better but mission's little star seems perfectly fine too. How different could they possibly be? Anyway, I'll have to venture to the western addition chain with skeptical eyes at some point to see what the fuss is all about.

Onto the FOOD. Go to little star if you're craving fanciful deep dish pizza. with only 5 different options for deep dish pizza, and a handful of options for thin crust pizza their small menu boasts delicious eats. I appreciate small menus though so perhaps it's just me. Expect to pay $23-26/deep dish. $4-10 for beer or wine.

We went on a saturday night around 845pm. We expected to wait a good 45 minutes (after hearing about the horrendous lines) but got seated immediately (be jealous). I wish they had better beer and drink options and think they should add a special homespun drink to the menu like basil lemonade or something! But overall the experience and meal was good for the price/quality. 

I really enjoyed our table in the small, intimate restaurant setting and super trendy servers and bartender. Deep dish takes 30 minutes to serve (it's a pie after all) so be wary. We were interested in trying the goddess pesto salad but at $7....how special could it be. We ordered half classic/half brass monkey. It came out. I was wary about having too much feta in the pie. It. was. delicious! And it really hit the spot. I appreciated the crust for its yeasty-taste and simplicity (with cornmeal yum) since it really complemented the "innards." And yes they taste entirely different--class vs. brass so I highly recommend trying half of each.

Will I go again? Probably not. Lines/no reservations/too trendy for a second try.
author: Sarah W.

description:
Let me start this by saying that after having Giordano's deep dish in Chicago, I have extremely high expectations for how a pie should taste. 

Ordered the Little Star pie, adding in artichoke hearts, as well as the mixed salad.  It didn't disappoint!  The crust was buttery and amazing (sometimes the crust can be hard and cooked a bit too long).  I do with the deep dish pie was a bit deeper, but living on the West Coast, I've learned to lower my expectations. 

It was enjoyable, as well as the beer and wine selections!  It's perfect for a catch up dinner date with my girlfriend, where we were able to laugh and be boisterous without bothering other patrons.

The staff was attentive and very helpful, adding to slightly intimate environment there. It was fun and I'll definitely go back again!
author: Liz A.

description: The deep dish Little Star is my all-time favorite pizza, and the weird part is I'm not even a vegetarian. It's that good.
author: Cory D.

description:
YUMMMMM!  I'm a pizza advocate and this place takes the pie for being the best deep dish I've had so far (in Cali).  Came here on a date and was very impressed!

Ambiance:
From the outside, the place actually looks closed!  They're front doors are covered and the lighting inside is fairly dim so it's hard to tell from a distance.  Upon entering, there's a small little bar with a TV and a friendly bartender.  In the dining area, the lighting is mild, and the noise level is medium.  

Service:
Everyone was very friendly.  The hostess greeted us, the bartender greeted us, and the server was prompt and nice.  She refilled out water pretty frequently also!

Food:
Like I said, BEST deep dish I've had so far.  The crust is not too dense or doughy and it had a nice crisp to it.  We had ordered a large half little star, half classic.  Both were great.  Little star had feta cheese with works and the Italian sausage on the classic was perfect.  I cannot wait to come back! (wink wink)

Overall, I will be back when I'm in the area, craving for deep dish pizza!
author: Mike L.

description: We've given up on New York style pizza in the Bay Area, but this is as good as any deep-dish pizza we've had anywhere. This is our go-to take-out spot. I knocked a star off cause it's not the best value and pick-ups can sometimes be a shit show. Otherwise highly recommend.
author: Josh L.

description:
I tried this place for the first time the other day and was positively impressed. I'd never had cornmeal crust before and while it was good, I'd say on balance I prefer traditional pizza dough. That's my taste, though, not a reflection on the restaurant. Given that they do cornmeal crusts, I thought their execution of them was pretty good. I had a veggie pizza and overall, liked it. 

The salad was pretty good as well: a real salad, with fresh-tasting ingredients. 

Service was good, too. 

Overall, the pizza wasn't in the top 10% I've had in the Bay area, but it was very solid and certainly well within the top 40%, so definitely above average.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
Little Star exists to destroy new years resolutions. I went here last weekend for a friends 22nd birthday dinner. We endured the irresistable smell of deep dish wafting through the doors for 2 whole hours while we waited outside for our party of 10 to be seated.

Needless to say, I was very hungry by the time I sat down and my resolve to stick to just one slice of pizza crumbled along with my new years resolutions by the time I had my third slice. 

Oh well, resolutions were made to be broken. This place is no joke--the crust is so good and who knew, the thin crust pizza is dare I say it--even better?

Come here with a good appetite and lots of patience.
author: Patricia Q.

description:
I was told that Little Star Pizza channels the best deep dish pizza found in Chicago. Hearing that, I knew that as a pizza fanatic, I must try it out! 

We spotted the restaurant immediately as there was quite a crowd outside. We were told the wait would be about an hour. Hungry and helpless, we looked around for a spot to hang out and wait in the crowded waiting room. Lucky for us, we found a teeny little spot by the bar. Here's my question Lucky Star, if the hour wait is frequent, why not condense the waiting area and expand the dining room? There's no point having a waiting room as big as the dining room!

Being close to starvation when we finally got seated, we ordered 4 pizzas between the 4 of us-- the Little Star Special, Classic, Mediterranean and the thin crusted Chicken Pesto. At first bite, I can instantly taste the freshness of the tomatoes. Yum! Without a doubt, the Classic was my favorite but the Chicken Pesto came in a close second.

Our waitress was not particular friendly or welcoming-- perhaps she was tired. We felt like we were rushed out of there even though we cut our sit down time in half by pre-ordering. I'm sorry you guys are packed but I did my time in the waiting room so I deserve to sit at our table for at least 45 minutes before you can rush me out!

I probably won't be back on another Saturday night but definitely on a less crowded day!
author: Tiffany U.

description: I had dinner here last night and the food is amazing!! The crust of the deep dish pizza is absolutely delicious! We were a large party of 8 and our food was delivered promptly.  The beer was fantastic!  I will be heading back there when I am in San Francisco again.  Try to get there after 6, parking is a challenge.
author: Lisa B.

description:
Ok, so after going to Paxti's and here, I'm giving both 5 stars, because they are both DELICIOUS pizzas and each has their high point.

What I'm going to say about these delicious pizzas at Little Star is that they have flavorful chunks of tomatoes which I prefer over the smooth sauce of Patxi's. Also, the crust at Little Star is flaky and I prefer the flavor to Patxi's.

That being said, I prefer the cheese of Patxi's. 

Both are GREAT and I would definitely prefer one over the other depending on what I was in the mood for that day.

Definitely go here. You won't be sorry.
author: Emily D.

description: Get the Little Star pizza! So good, so flavorful. Yeah it's a bit pricy but it's really filling and tasty. Not typically a fan of deep dish but the flavors with the cornmeal crust are a total treat.
author: San D.

description:
A friend and I were wandering around Hayes Valley, completely famished, trying to find somewhere to eat. Walked by this place, smelled the pizza, saw the deep dish, and went in to give it a try.

We ordered the pizza with sausage, mushrooms, and onions. The sausage kind of overwhelmed the pizza, and I wish they either diced the onions or sliced it thinly. The onion on this pizza was thick and in big pieces so it was unpleasant biting into those pieces. 

The service was really good. The food was really good too, but I cant really say its better than Zachary's in Berkeley, because they both pretty much tasted like deep dish pizzas. 

3.5 stars!
author: Isabella L.

description:
Awesome awesome deep dish pizzas. However, the customer services was off the top horrendous. I don't care how busy the waiters or the restaurant gets, but I sure as hell didn't appreciate the check thrown at my table and had my credit card glided through greasy spots and spilled beers. All he simply had to do was to take an extra step to give us the check. Seriously...how hard is that? Rude rude rude. 

4 stars for food and 10% tip for my waiter! :)
author: Janny W.

description:
I'm from Chicago. I have high standards when it comes to deep dish. I was told going in to Little Star that they don't label themselves as Chicago-style, so I expected more of a pan pizza style.

But surprisingly, they ended up being more like what I'm accustomed to. It was a very nice surprise. While there was no 'disk of sausage', the toppings were tasty, and the cheese was perfectly moist and left strings of it whenever you tried to cut into it. But for me, it all comes down to the crust with deep dish. The crust had that dense, yet crumbly cornmeal texture. Plus, the service was great, and the prices reasonable.

In short, it was a taste of home.
author: Amanda S.

description: Not generally a deep-dish fan, but this is fantastic pizza. Great crust.
author: Ben A.

description:
Hard to not have to wait at least 30 minutes to get in, but it's well worth the wait. Deep dish pizza is the way to go! And the roasted garlic bread. For two, you can easily share a small depending on your appetite or get a large and take some home. The cheesecake is nom nomy.

I'm always happy and satisfied after leaving Little Star - you really can't go wrong.
author: Erin C.

description: So. Freaking. Good. Cornmeal crust scared me a little before our order came, but I was wrong for thinking that it could be weird. It was delicious, and the chunky tomato sauce was the best part of it all. Great service, nice crowd - the star docking only comes from the fact I went to school near Chicago and ate Giordano's and Pequod's regularly; but if this place were in the same neighborhood as those greats, I still think it would succeed. Awesome spot.
author: Sarah B.

description:
I'm a huge fan of deep dish pizza, so this review may be biased. 

I ordered their special of the day the meatball deep dish pizza and was not disappointed. 

First off it came out in a reasonable amount of time, can't tell you how many times I've gone to deep dish places and waited forever. The toppings were fresh and went well together. The crust was crunchy with a light cornmeal taste. The marinara sauce was a bit sour for my taste, but the cheese and the meat were able to offset it. 

Would definitely come back again to try some of their other deep dish pizzas. They also have a cool little bar in the front and great happy hour specials.
author: Maggie Y.

description: Deep dish pizza here is sooo good!  Ordered the classic.  The sausage is incredibly flavorful as is the sauce.  Got the greek salad which was huge and the dressing was delicious.  The wings were too hot in my opinion and average in size.  The thin crust California pizza was delicious as well.  Would definitely order all of these items again, except the wings.  Actually wish I was eating some of the deep dish right now.
author: Kara M.

description:
People are always appalled when they hear that I prefer Little Star over the over-hyped Zachary's. That's right!!! Little Star is the best followed by Patxi's and then Zachary's. My comparison is not just the crust but the taste and the texture.  Don't argue with me Zach fans.  That was my experience and this is my review, not to mention great service at LSP too  ;-)

Let me put this out there: I'm not a fan of deep dish pizzas because there isn't room in my waistline for extra carbs but I love the deep dish at LSP.  My favorite is the signature deep dish "Little Star" (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OoyK7MyuPtKOQAXmEmyM5g?select=9HMyOflMsp1bUXoMLEdjUw) It came with spinach, onions, mushroom, garlic, feta and ricotta cheese, and I usually add pepperoni.  The crust was made with cornmeal so it's not heavy and doughy but always crispy and never greasy.  The tomato paste had a balanced tang to it, not sour nor sweet.  And OMGosh the combination of cheeses were the perfect blend, gooey and stringy even if the pizza cooled down.  I had it the next day and it was still gooey and tasty.  

Why I don't like Zachary's:  cardboard crust made with flour, undercooked fillings that was heavy on the tomato sauce so it was sour and runny which made the center soggy, and the cheese became hard when we didn't eat the pizzas fast enough.  

I also want to add a few words to those who say the best deep dish is found in Chicago.  Let me break this to you....this is the Bay Area.  Unless you plan to fly to Chicago each time you crave for a deep dish, I suggest you choose the best that the Bay Area can offer.  And the best is Little Star Pizza.  

FYI: East Bayers who don't want to come to SF for LSP, well you lucked out because there's one down the street from Zachary's.
author: Hannah C.

description:
(Updated on this review after receiving the credit card statement)

This is another establishment that took advantage of customers when we trusted them by using our credit cards. For a takeout, instead of putting the tip and total amounts I wrote on the bill, they added themselves for a 30%+ tip. Yes, 6 bucks for a $20.16 bill.

Do NOT go there if you don't want to get ripped off. For many people who don't do reconciliation, it's probably better to pay by cash.

=====================

(See pics)

It's like a dressed up sister of the other Little Star. This place looks classier and almost did not match The Mission style. It's spacious, clean, bright and with nice decoration and furniture. Service was a bit less neighborhood style and more like a pizza date joint.

The thin crysted Italian Combo pizza I had was really delicious. It smelled so good and tasted like how it smelled.

They have a comfy sofa while you wait and is generally quiet weekday afternoons.
author: T L.

description:
Atmosphere: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Food ordered: Mixed Salad, Mediterranean Chicken, Little Star 

Little Star Pizza was a cute little pizzeria with slightly dimmed light and a chillaxing atmosphere. My friend and I were seated by the window and it was entertaining to people-watch as they pass by the restaurant. Our waitress for the night was very friendly and tended our table frequently with excellent service. 

We started our meal with a small Mixed Salad (my personal favorite part of the meal) which was perfect for two people to share. The well dressed vegetables were fresh and the crushed nuts sprinkled on top added the perfect texture to the salad to make it lively. The Mediterranean Chicken deep dish was decent and was filled with bell peppers and onions. However, the tomato sauce over powers the veggies and the feta cheese and it took away the "mediterranean" vibe from the name. The Little Star deep dish was average. Not much surprise to it at all. It tasted exactly like what was expected from the description on the menu. 

Overall, the experience was decent and the food were slightly above average. If you're in the neighborhood and you have a undeniable craving for pizza, then sure go for it. But personally, I wouldn't drive all the way here just for their food. Especially since PARKING SUCKS!
author: Tracy W.

description:
Great Chicago style Pizza. 

Complaint...when it is getting to the point where a side of salad for lunch at a pizza joint is $9+tax+tip, you know things are getting out of control.  Extortionate.

Line out the door for dinner, but no wait at all for lunch.   Very slow, which helps if you are hoping to be in and out and back to work within an hour.

This pizza is excellent.  Best deep dish I have tasted this side of the Mississippi.  The crunchy crust is PERFECTION.
author: Joe S.

description:
The deep-dish is where it's at.

The normal pie ... not so much. But the deep-dish, yes yes.

The salads were thoughtfully arranged and presented, service was attentive, and the atmosphere was casual, yet a little elegant. Very accessible, with a cozy, warm vibe.
author: Jackson B.

description:
Best pizza I have ever had hands down! 
Order the pesto, it was to die for. 

I was unimpressed with the garlic bread appetizer. 
Overall, a bit pricey.
author: Christa J.

description:
Yup, this place definitely lives up to the hype.  Tip: coming in the middle of a weekend afternoon is a score -- Joe and I came in around 3 or 3:30 pm on a Sunday afternoon, and there was no wait, and just a few other tables worth of patrons.  (I tried coming here on Friday w/some buddies, the wait was about an hour).  

We ordered the Classic thin crust pizza, and it was delicious: the sauce had the right amount of sweetness (definitely prefer my pizza a bit on the sweeter side), the crust was unbelievably good without being too doughy, and the toppings were fresh and crisp.  Yum.  

Definitely a contender for some of the best SF pizza I've had to date!
author: Mel G.

description:
I'm originally from Chicago, deep dish capital, and this place does not deserve the praise.
The deep dish spinach pizza was not that deep.
The sauce was okay.
The crust was not remarkable.
Patxi's is the closest.  I would say it betters Pizzeria Uno and even Giordanos.
What a relief to finally find great deep dish pizzain California!
author: David F.

description:
Hands down the best deep dish pizza I have ever had...including infamous Chicago pizzas.  (Blasphemous!  But true).  The Brass Monkey (which is the Little Star with sausage) is life changing.

The proportion and flavors of the spinach, ricotta, feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic, and sausage is PERFECT.  I'm usually more a thin crust fan because I find deep dish too tomato-y and soupy, but Little Star is the exception.  The crust is perfectly buttery and crispy, and the decadent toppings are nothing short of fantastic.

We are also partial to the Valencia location because the garlic bread here is bulbs of roasted garlic over warm sourdough as opposed to the garlic cheesy bread at the Divisidero location I've been to.  

Overall, the BEST deep dish pizza in SF and beyond!
author: Carrie C.

description: We ordered the classic deep dishes pizza and added pepperoni on it. It was so delicious and the sauce was just perfect. The crust was so good. We also order the cheese bread for appetizer. I will definitely go back to this place. Best to go on weekdays cause it is not that busy.
author: Sokha P.

description:
Such a loud, hipster place.  Good place for good pizza & drinks.

I like the Little Star deep dish better than the Classic deep dish.  Both have spinach, onions & mushrooms but the Little Star has ricotta & feta cheese that takes it up another level flavor-wise.  The crust is a typical deep dish crust - can definitely taste the cornmeal, but not as buttery as I normally like.  Nonetheless, Little Star is one of the better deep dish places outside of Chicago.
author: Rose A.

description:
OMG... Food not worth the wait! I'm usually down to wait in long lines for good food but this isn't the place..

Venue: The place looks nice. A Medium to Small size restaurant. Wait is SUPER LOONG... We originally had a bigger party with 10 people but we split up and we still needed to wait 45min-1hr....

Service: Mediocre.

Food:
- Deep Dish (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OoyK7MyuPtKOQAXmEmyM5g?select=laNBdvLKoudmD-3lC3bb9g) $24 - Half Mediterranean Chicken & Half Little Star. Tasted like loads of tomato sauce on bread. Didn't really taste anything else in it...

- Deep Dish $24 - Half Vegetarian & Half Classic. Tasted just the other deep dish...  loads of tomato sauce on bread.

- Thin Crust (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OoyK7MyuPtKOQAXmEmyM5g?select=CLzoQWa3DEnqG1mx5JSa-w) $22 - Half Pesto Chicken & White Pie. i like my thin crust thinner... these were just alright...

Price: TOO expensive for something that doesn't taste anything special... Well its basically $24 bucks for tomato sauce on bread..

Overall: Waste of time and money and calories! Everything tasted the same! Wait was TOO long!
author: Jannifer H.

description:
Words cannot express how much I love their classic deep dish! It is my absolute favorite!  
To me there is no better pizza then a good deep dish and theirs is great. The dough is just thick enough to hold up and still be a bit crispy. The ingredients are top notch quality and you can taste eveything from the mushrooms,  onions, bell peppers and sausage. The ingredients themselves you can taste individually but as soon as you get the beautiful sauce and cheese it just comes together in an explosion of deep dish perfection that can only be tamed with a cold beer and another piece!

I highly recommend this place to anyone who likes pizza!
author: Trevor D.

description: I really hate to give such a poor rating because the food is awesome ... but their customer service is horrific. First of all, we ordered over the phone for pickup. Four of us walk down because we decided we would eat in. When we got their they said "sorry, if you order pickup you can't sit down and eat it" WHAT? Whomever made this rule up should take 101 Customer Service over again. They had plenty of seats so that wasn't an issue. So, we sat down and waited for our order. And waited. And waited. One from our group walked up to the counter and talked to the bartender and explained we were waiting for our food, etc. We waited and waited. Finally we were about to walk out and went up to the bar AGAIN! Mind you, this about after 35 to 40 minutes of sitting in the restaurant in plain view -- not to mention the 20 minutes from the time we place our order. We walk up to the counter and he says "oh, your food has been here for awhile, I thought you were eating in so I was holding it for your" Seriously. Clearly we won't be back -- but their food was great.
author: LaVon C.

description: The classic deep dish pizza is very good (4 stars) and I personally thought the little star was just ok.  The crust is the big standout.  Minus 1 star for service.  I was told 20 minutes for my pizza and it took 40 minutes.  I was in a rush that day so it irritated me.  When I inquired about my to go order the hostess had an attitude.  There were 2 people who arrived after me and they received their pizza before me and another girl who was also waiting.  Otherwise great pizza.  In the future I will try their Divisadero location.
author: Angelique B.

description:
Darn you Little Star! You made me fall in love with your pizza goodness and your so far away! Why can't I live in SF?!

Came in for a late lunch today, it was busy but luckily my husband and I were seated right away. A quick glance at the menu and we were set on a mixed salad and Mediterranean chicken deep dish pizza. The menu is simple, I hate feeling overwhelmed with too many options.  The salad was fresh, light and delishious. Then about 30 minutes later it appeared....my new love.... the PIE! 

OMG we couldn't wait to dig in. I didn't think anything could even come close nor compare to Zachary's deep dish. I now stand corrected. Sorry Zachary's you are no longer my #1. The difference is that Zachary's pizza crust can be soaggy, the corn meal crush on LS's is crunchy and taste great. Also, it seems that Zachary's loads their tomato sauce and it over powers the taste of the toppings. This place doesn't do that. The sauce is just the right amount and you can taste all of the toppings in each bite. 

The service is attentive and quick. The dining room and the bathrooms are clean, there is some interesting art to view and good tunes to listen to. Another huge plus it is so close to Bart so you can just "roll"  your fat belly back on like we did.
author: Amber S.

description: Mediocre pizza and salad. Also a server was wearing her flannel pijama pants. Meh...
author: Marina G.

description:
Used to love this place until we ordered through their delivery service. No where that I saw did it mention their delivery prices were higher than their in house prices although it did say the price per pizza. Well, I didn't know their regular price. It said delivery was $4.95---reasonable. Our total bill was $81.12 for two pizzas that would have cost a total of $57 before taxes had we picked them up ourselves. That is a lot of extra money. The breakdown was $64 for the pizzas, $5.60 for tax, service $11.62, delivery--free. Go figure that out. There ought to be a law. 
In the meantime, I am not even going to Little Star to pick up on my own. I really feel ripped off, rightly or wrongly.
author: Patricia B.

description:
I feel like a Ninja Turtle when I come to this place! Nommm nommm nommm nommmm.

https://www.google.com/url?sa=i&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=images&cd=&cad=rja&docid=IUsMLzm_3g3L1M&tbnid=KBMSId9eHj76UM:&ved=0CAUQjRw&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.geekcraze.com%2Ftv-movies%2Fteenage-mutant-ninja-turtles-pizza-clock%2F&ei=rgayUa-oC8GsiALr7YGwCQ&bvm=bv.47534661,d.cGE&psig=AFQjCNHE1Y1DaKR_QfgQc_SIzhHiMwrP_g&ust=1370707961080677
author: Fredo L.

description:
A friend was visiting from out of town and was looking to enjoy a meal at an sf eatery. We had to bring her here to enjoy the little star and classic pizza. Not to mention the garlic bread!! She loved the corn meal crust. She ate 1 and a half slices and was full. 

My meal was not complete without a bottle of Cock and Bull ginger beer. The crisp and spicy kick of the ginger beer was just the right finishing touch to my meal. 

Till my next visit...
author: Kristina S.

description: Really great pizza place! I love their cornmeal crust. If you're a chicago deep dish pizza lover, then this is the place for you.
author: Renu A.

description:
I've eaten Chicago style deep dish pizza in Chicago, IL and yet I haven't had a pizza quite like Little Star does it.  the flavors are so aromatic and the corn meal crust is to die for.  This place can do no wrong in my book.

Make sure to have your entire party available before putting your name in because they wont hold seats unless all are present.  I love the pear cider with my meal and the pizza is good both deep dish and thin crust.  Start off with a Caresse Salad and end with the Cheesecake.  Amazing.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Three weeks ago, my friend and I were supposed to go to Pizzeria Delfina. We ended up not being able to, so he promised me we'd go on January 2. Yesterday, he found out that he had to go back to University on January 2, so we changed it to New Years.

Well, Delfina was closed on New Years, so we decided to hit this joint instead!

When we got here, the place was jam-packed! No seats, loud chattering, drunk men singing-- you get the picture. We went to check-in, and were told we'd have to wait 25 minutes. My friend and I kept standing up to peek at empty tables and stared at each other in sadness. A man handed me the menu, so I spent a good amount of time fantasizing about and contemplating each item. We ended up waiting for a little over 40 minutes.

By the time we got to our seats, we knew exactly what it was we wanted. The waiter took a little over forever to reach us, and because we came on a completely empty stomach, every minute felt like an hour and every hour felt like a day.

I sat there as my hunger was slowly mutating to neuroticism. I sat at my table, all shifty eyed and soft mumbles. I may seem small, but do not be fooled: my inner chupacabra was waiting to be unleashed!

We ended up ordering the Garlic Bread, Spicy Chicken Wings, and a deep dish pizza (half Little Star, half Mediterranean Chicken).

I was impressed by the garlic bread. Not by the taste, but by the innovation. They give you steamed(?) garlic that you get to spread onto your bread, along with a huge cup of butter-soft butter. The garlic didn't have an overpowering taste, which was nice. However, that might have been because I drowned each slice of bread with 4 tablespoons of butter.. Ohhhh, butter! The bread was rather difficult to cut/slice, so we ended up having to rip it off. That made me question the freshness a bit.

The spicy chicken wings were great! No match for Wingstop, but definitely better than any other chicken I've had! It's hot, but not hot to the point where I'm crying my eyes out and drinking water out of the vase. I didn't really try the bleu cheese dressing, because God knows I hate bleu cheese.

The pizza was the best deep dish pizza I've ever had! Better than Zachary's, better than Patxi's!! By the time we got the pizza, I was already stuffed. I ate most of the the chicken wings, and he ate most of the garlic bread. I liked how they didn't go overkill on the sauce like some other places (often when I picked up a slice of pizza from Zachary's, the sauce would fall off). A balance of toppings and tomato sauce allowed me to taste the ingredients. The crust was "WOW, PARTY IN MY MOUTH"! Soft, buttery, cornmeal crust.... WOW! If I could just come here to order crust, I would!

We ended up preferring each other person's pizza choice, which was funny. I thought the Little Star's garlic taste was a bit too strong. We cleaned off everything so that we wouldn't have to carry anything home. My stomach felt like it was going to explode, so I had to burp a couple of times to finish my pizza. Good stuff! (:

I really, really wish I could have given Little Star Pizza 5 stars. The waiting almost killed me. I can understand, though. Little Star Pizza seems to get tons of customers (there were still people waiting for tables at 9pm!). So I guess, 4.55 stars?

I will probably wake up 10lbs heavier tomorrow, but that's the least of my worries!
author: Elaine N.

description:
This place is amazing!  After countless recommendations from friends, I eventually had a chance to make it out here for dinner.

I took my girlfriend and daughter and we all loved it.  We had a chance to try out a large thin crust cheese pizza with half of it covered in sausage.  A small mixed green salad and an order of garlic bread.

The pizza was of course top notch.  At first taste you can tell that all the toppings were great quality. The small, well made salad was a generous portion with a great balance of dressing to greens.  

The garlic bread was my daughter's favorite.  It came with a bulb of roasted garlic and creamy butter both on the side to accompany the fresh piece of sourdough.  She was stoked she got to put it all together herself.

The service was exceptional and they had plenty of seating so we weren't stuck waiting for a table during the dinner time rush.  Big plus is that they have different varieties of Humphry Slocombe ice cream on their dessert menu.  We'll definitely be back.
author: Lonnie P.

description:
We had the classic and little star deep dish pizzas and even though they were delicious in their own unique way, I don't think it's fair to compare these pies to Zachary's. If I happen to be in the neighborhood i will probably try it again but I would prob opt for Zachary's if I had to choose a deep dish pizza spot. 

Oh yeah, their chicken wings were pretty tasty but could have been better if they offered ranch instead of blue cheese.
author: Lisandra M.

description:
Is it sacrilege to actually prefer their thin crust over the deep dish? That's not to say the deep dish is bad (I love it actually), but the thin crust varieties are baked to crispy perfection.

The vibe here is fun: your typical hipster friendly place on Valencia that comes with a jukebox - one night I came here, an employee kept rockin a ton of classic Hall & Oates songs which was AWESOME!

Oh yeah, the pizzas.  The corn meal deep dish has a nice crumbly texture that is delish. Toppings are copious and it's impossible not to leave full. Thin crust is crunchy and satisfying.  If I'm in a larger group we usually get one deep dish and one thin crust so we get the best of both worlds.  Make sure to try Little Star if you get the chance.
author: Alan W.

description:
I had the original sausage stuffed pizza recently when visiting a friend to help with some home improvements.  It was perfect cold weather take out and held up well on the journey home.  We paired it with a simple but perfectly fresh salad with a great creamy balsamic dressing.  Would go back for sure.

By comparison with Zachary's, I would call this style similar but a bit less rich.  There is a single layer of crust and topping which made it hearty but not out of control gluttonous.
author: Patrick S.

description:
I'll start out by saying that I was always a huge fan of Little Star pizza and recommended it to everyone. 

So naturally when my family was in town I wanted to take them there. So the 6 of us, including a 5-year-old child decided to head to the Divisidero location for dinner on Sunday night (Dec. 30). When we got there, there was a 1 hour 30 min wait, which is hard to do at night with a small child. 

So I called this location (Valencia) to inquire about the wait and the guy on the phone said 10-20 min for our party.  We then went all the way to the mission, only to enter the door and have the host tell us there is a 1 hour wait. We told them what the guy on the phone had told us and the host said, "Sorry, I don't know who told you that because we aren't supposed to give quote times over the phone". It was very frustrating to hear this after going all the way from nopa area to the mission and with a tired/hungry 5-year-old. 

I am not giving it one star because it had a long wait. But 1 star because the host staff obviously does not know what they are doing. I work in a restaurant myself and I know that the staff should have handled this in a different manner and whoever gave us that "10-20 minute" quote for a table should learn that giving the totally wrong quote time is not going to make any customers happy.  

Sorry Little Star, you are starting to lose your edge and it is hard for me to recommend you when the staff is so unorganized.
author: Juliana K.

description: Best deep dish pizza I've had outside of Chicago. Zachary's doesn't hold a candle to Little Star. I get the deep dish wit cheese and sausage, sometimes I add pepperoni but it's always amazing. Buttery cornmeal crust, perfectly seasoned chunky tomato sauce and just enough melty cheese. It's making me hungry just to talk about it. This is not your average gooey, messy, ingredients all sliding out on the first bite deep dish - it's quite simply perfection! The mixed salad is a nice compliment to the pizza and keeps me from eating so much I feel sick! Highly recommend the online ordering/pick up but the ambiance is great and they offer a reasonable corkage fee which I love.
author: Kelly C.

description: Bad customer  service , host desk gave me hard work when picked up  my food ,she asked my info i did than told me didnt recieved  order but the food was ready for to go  , she is not helpful cause were  nervous  and upset she refused to help me , 20  mns when my order was late i got it  with messed items,  after she tryed to explain  wht happened with stupid  story ,
author: Abderrocs R.

description:
Monday
6:00pm - Only a few tables seated. Many tables open.
6:30pm - More crowded. Still a few tables open.
7:00pm - Waitlist starts.
7:30pm - Crowded. Wait at the little bar/waiting area

Caprese salad always starts off a meal right. Fresh tomato slices, mozzarella, some basil, and some balsamic vinegar is so clean and still leaves room in your stomach for the big pie coming up.

I appreciated their crispy cornmeal crust on their deep dish. You could taste all the toppings and the cheese tasted fresh. We had their secret menu item, The Brass Monkey. It's their listed Little Star pizza with the addition of sausage. There's lots of spinach and the ricotta makes it creamy.

The restaurant is trendy and feels cozy with plenty of people and close quarters.
author: Samantha L.

description:
I ate here after SF marathon. I like both thin and thick. Prefer thin.
Yum.
author: Kaori M.

description:
I have had thin crust in New York City, deep dish in Chicago, and this is still my favorite pizza in the United States.

I have a thing for food with texture, and the cornmeal crust on Little Star's pizza is like a dancing party in my mouth.  I much prefer the deep dish there, because that means more crust.

I only go during off times, because on Friday and Saturday nights, the line is too much for me.
author: Christopher Y.

description:
I've had pizza in Chicago, and pizza in New York. Little Star ranks higher than the pizza I tried in New York, and pretty dang close to Lou Malnati's in Chicago. 

We ordered the Little Star deep dish pizza to go and took it back to the East Bay, and it was even mouth-watering, orgasmic then. I can only imagine what it would be like if fresh out of the oven in the restaurant! Note to self: must dine in sometime.
author: Mina K.

description:
Saturday night. 6:30PM. ONE HOUR wait. Being on an empty stomach and having a lack of patience, I was thinking this place better be good or I'm going to have a throw down! 

Agreeing with many of the reviews, the ingredients were fresh and the crust was deliciously crispy, but the taste wasn't there.  We ordered the Little Star, Mediterranean, and Classic. Not only did they all look the same but they tasted almost the same. Maybe it was the excessive amount of tomato sauce that overpowered the toppings. Maybe it was the lack of meat (Little Star) or lack of flavor of the meat (Mediterranean). Or maybe I was just too hungry to tell the difference. All I know is that it wasn't worth the hour wait. 

The server was just a tad bit rude. She asked if we were done eating while my friend was still working on hers. I understand it was packed and a list of people are waiting, but they'll need to wait just like we did. 

I give it 3.5 stars for its fresh ingredients and crispy crust. Would I come back? Sure. And wait an excruciating hour? Surely not!
author: Denise W.

description: I applaud the quality of food, the customer service, not so much. The waitress was probably having a bad day, however her attitude and demeanor was unacceptable. The woman made our party feel as if we were an inconvenience. All nine of us were in agreement that...we will probably not be returning.
author: Michael A.

description: The best deep dish pizza I've ever had. I don't remember exactly what kind we got, probably some type of veggie or margherita. 3 of us got one pizza and a garlic bread and it was more than enough. Great atmosphere inside! The restaurant is on the smaller side.
author: Taylor V.

description:
In previous reviews I've talked about the battle between Thin Crust and Deep Dish. I'll forgo the analogies and skip right to it: Little Star does both extremely well!

We ordered one of each; a Classic Deep Dish and a White Pie Thin Crust. 

The Deep Dish, even though it was large, was smaller than other places I've been. That just means that I wish there was more of it! It didn't have too much sauce, which sometimes can cause it to be soupy. And the crust was yum!

The White Pie was delicious and crispy, with the garlic permeating every bite.

Heck, even the Vegetarian Deep Dish my friend ordered was good! The olives kicked it to a different level!

Yes, the wait can be arduous, but you can't go wrong with the pizza here. And that goes for Deep Dish or Thin Crust. Win win!
author: Greg S.

description:
I'll let you in on a secret.  The pizza here is better than the location at Divisadero, because the kitchens are run independently.  The pesto chicken pizza here has become a stable #2 to the little star (no sausage, please, the veggies shine far brighter alone unhindered by the meaty flavor).  However, I picked up a pesto chicken pizza from the Divisadero location, and it was simply not as tasty.  The cheese they used was a different variety that was more melty in consistency and less sharp in flavor.  The pesto was not as punchy and garlicky, and they dared to put red bell peppers on our pizza. WHY?!

They messed with something that wasn't broke.  Which is why I'm only going to come to this location in the Mission from here on out. Who knows that else they're going to tinker with at the Divisadero branch?? They might even go so far as to... GASP change the Little Star deep dish pizza. I don't want to witness that day.  I'm sticking with what I know: the servers are friendly at the Mission location, the pizzas are consistent in flavor and recipe, the wine list is reliable and I never regret how much we end up paying when we bring our not-local friends and family here.
author: Hannah C.

description: Super disappointing.  Moving from Chicago, I've been dying for pizza, this was my last hope.  In one word:FAIL.  I can't believe they sell this substandard knock off cardboard to the public. The crust is a terrible version of Lou's, with way too much corn dust, toppings are good but ehhhh, sauce SUCKS!! Your pizzas are like $25 is there a sauce shortage?  Heard of seasoning?  Yuck!  Ok people go to Chicago's Pizza or Giordano's online and have a REAL pizza delivered to you for LESS MONEY.  Mayor Daley would close this place down if it was in Chicago.  Little Star is worse than Dominos.  Then end.  http://www.asliceofchicago.com/
author: curtis s.

description: Hands down one of the best, if not the best deep dish pizza I have ever had! I highly recommend getting their brass monkey pizza, you will not be disappointed. The brass monkey is their classic little star pizza, but with sausage added. It was a huge hit when I took my coworkers here. Friendly staff. Im guilty of eating here twice in one week.
author: Alexandra B.

description: How have I not had little star until now!  The Brass Monkey (little star with sausage) is pretty amazing with it's cornmeal crust, definitely worthy of it's 7x7 list must eats title.  I'm usually more of a fan of thin crust, as deep dish is a bit too heavy for me.  However Little Star is just too good to resist.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
All you need to know about Little Star Pizza is explained brilliantly by Nish N. in Check Please:
http://blogs.kqed.org/food/2006/11/16/check-please-bay-area-season-2-episode-8-208/
You can stream the entire episode for free.
author: トモ T.

description:
One of the few, precious benefits of leaving New York is the absence of Pizza Pretension. Thinking outside the super-thin-Brooklyn-tap-crust is a rewarding exercise - you get, for instance, Chicago-and-New-York-style collusion cafes like Little Star. My blood approves. 

SF's microbrew snobbery, though. . . that's another story.
author: Liz C.

description:
Seventh time is the charm.

The first time I tried Little Star's deep dish, I liked it but didn't love it.  I was all about Chicago deep dish and Little Star didn't come close enough.  But Chicago is across the country and Little Star is down the street.  After about six more visits, I realized that I loves me some Little Star. 

My favorite is the "Little Star" deep dish with spinach, mushrooms, onions, and garlic blended with loads of cheese like ricotta and feta.  BF likes the "Classic" with sausage, mushrooms, onions, and green bell peppers.  The ingredients are quality and even better with a chunky tomato sauce, cheese, and encircled by a buttery, cornmeal-y crust. 

It's not Chicago deep dish but why should it be?  California deep dish is just as good and sometimes the best things are in your own backyard. 

But I'll be going back a few more times, just to make sure.  ;)

------------------
Update 2/2013:

http://whilstinsf.tumblr.com/post/41877278665/telling-friends-about-little-star
author: Amy C.

description:
Just had a bad experience at Little Star Pizza Valencia. When we went in we waited at least five minutes to be seated and I had to say "Hello" before someone came out. When a server did come out instead of apologizing for our wait she chastised me and went on and on about how they hate when someone does that. My girlfriend wanted to leave but I was dying for some good deep dish. We were seated and the rest of the meal was OK but we left after eating one slice each. :(

-3 Stars for RUDENESS
author: Jason S.

description:
If Little Star was a person, he/she would definitely be a hipster. My vegetarian friend was very into this place and boasted about their high quality and healthy ingredients. This is great but this will definitely be reflected on the bill.

There also seems to be some sort of health tax on the final bill. I've never seen this at another restaurant but maybe someone should warn management of this clearly health conscious establishment that taxes are a disincentive.

There are only 5 pizza's per crust type to choose from. One of them is cheese and another vegetarian so if you're someone that wants meat on your pizza, there're not a lot of preset options. You can add whatever topping to a cheese pizza but personally I prefer people more knowledgeable about food tell me what should be in it. I'm only good for the eating part.
author: Jason C.

description:
Very quality deep dish pizza.  The Little Star deep dish tasted very fresh, especially if you ask for tomatoes.  Really one of the most satisfying vegetarian pizzas I've had, and doubly so if you like garlic.  The pizza came out pretty quickly as well, I'd estimate around 15 minutes?  

Not much else to say, really.  Just a really solid deep dish pizza that I'd be happy to return to anytime.
author: Norman S.

description:
My friend: "Lets grab lunch"
Me:  "Okay, but I feel fat. Can we eat healthy?"
My friend: "Oh me too, yes, I'll pick somewhere healthy"

she pulls up in an alley way.. I don't know where I am.. we close the doors and walk around to the corner...

Me: "PIZZA?!"
My friend: "oh... is it not healthy?"
Me: "oh well. I've wanted to come to little star sometime anyway...."

So she proceeds to order buffalo wings and A deep dish pizza:

Buffalo wings:  The fact that I could stop after 3 doesn't mean I have self control, it means the flavor was lacking.  I like heat, drenched in sauce, and what is up with not having the mini drumstick part?! Maybe it was just us.. but I like the mini drumstick part rather than the wing since 1) I don't like to rip apart the cartilage, and 2) I don't particularly enjoy sticking my tongue to get the meat out of the middle area between the two tiny bones...

Pizza:  I have liked deep dish pizza (zachary's) so I know it's not that.  The cornmeal crusted hunk-a tomatoe and cheese did nothing for me.  It was fine to eat, and I still enjoyed myself but there was nothing about the pizza that made me want to come back.  I want more flavor!!
author: Hannah W.

description:
This is our favorite pizza place in town.  They're more known for deep-dish pizza, but the thin crust is also excellent if you'd like to eat faster.  The goddess salad is a good starter, and they have affordable bottles of wine.  They don't take reservations, so there can be a substantial wait during prime time.  Also, the restaurant tends to be pretty loud, so it may not be for everyone.

Little Star has another location on Divisadero, which is smaller but also excellent.
author: Dan W.

description: Cornmeal crust pizzas!!!  Happy hour till 6pm, not much on beer but good discount on appetizers!
author: Yen F.

description:
Deep dish. Get ANYTHING with roasted garlic (extra if you love it like I do). The Ricotta cheese is a great topping, they put a dollop on top and it is so rich and creamy. Their meatball special is great, so is the classic. 

Their chicken wings is another must have! Delicious with their house made blue cheese. 

I know, Todd, one of the servers. He recommended the cheesecake to us, and its dangerously good. There is a light chocolate drizzle, and normally this isn't something that interests me because I like my cheesecake plain and simple. But it's thin and light, a great addition. 

MMM.. I'm going again tonight. I can't get enough!
author: Julie T.

description:
I'm in love with Little Star Pizza. 

Here's why:
1. After leaving the restaurant, I dreamed of my next visit. 
2. Although I had to wait over an hour to eat here, it was worth it. 
3. I ate my share of pizza so fast, my friends thought I only ate one piece. 

That's how good it was. 

Food devoured:
* Spicy Chicken Wings with blue cheese dressing
* Large (12-inch) Classic deep dish pizza with sausage, mushrooms, onions and green bell peppers.
* Large Mediterranean Chicken deep dish pizza with chicken breast, artichoke hearts, red bells, green olives, onions and feta cheese.

The chicken wings had a nice spicy kick. Yum. I ate at least three of these wings. Then there was the pizza. I loved the cornmeal crust. This single ingredient brought me to love deep dish pizza. (I'm usually a New York-style pizza kind of gal.) The pizza crust had a grainy texture with a slightly sweet, cornbread-like taste and a beautiful golden, caramel brown color. A chewy, meaty bite with a crunch at the end. Both pizzas were good, however I liked the Classic pizza over the Mediterranean Chicken. Sausage and veggie toppings may sound pretty normal and boring, but it was a delicious combo.

5 stars. I was STUFFED.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
My goodness.  The deep dish pizza here is supreme.  Stacked so high with such plump, flavorful veggies, and delectable meats. And the cheese, so much cheese!  But my favorite part could be the cornmeal crust.  I save it for the end, like dessert.  

The garlic bread (that comes with an actual roasted garlic clove) is also stupendous.  I have only ever ordered to-go, and the people working at the counter always seem cordial.  

I'm going to be dreaming of deep dish for the rest of the day.
author: Pernicious J.

description:
Holy cheezus bejeezus, this place is so so good. I didn't think I was a fan of deep dish. I really was disenchanted with the whole idea. I might be ruffling some feathers when I say this, but I had tried Patxi's a while back and wasn't too impressed. Sure, it was cheesy and hit the spot, but I thought it was too doughy, too...much. But WOW Little Star brought me back from deep dish downer land straight into pizza nirvana. The crust is perfect! Crisp and hearty but not overwhelming, a perfect vehicle for the deliciously fresh ingredients nestled in its golden embrace. 

My favorite was the Little Star. Flavorful, packed with spinach and mushrooms, delightfully garlicky. Even all the carnivorous boys at our table voted this as their favorite despite the lack of meat-y toppings. Of course you could always get the Brass Monkey, basically the sausagey twin of the Little Star but why fix it if it ain't broke?

The thin crust here is also amazing. I had my heart set on the Chicken Pesto and it did not disappoint at all. In fact, I fought tooth and nail for the last slice and fought back tears when I scraped the last of the cheesy pesto-y remains off the pizza pan. SIGH. 

The wait here can be intimidating (we had the maximum party of 10 so we had to bunker down by the bar for a while) but it was worth it. Just get some drinks, hang out, and prepare for a beautiful death by pizza.
author: Carol C.

description:
Gosh, I used to love this place so much.  My family and I would get a pie from this place at least twice a month.  Very delicious deep dish pizza.

Then one night we got a pie with a large pigeon feather baked into it.  One of the most revolting restaurant experiences I've had in the developed world.  I don't know how such a large feather could not have been noticed, but there it was baked deep into our pie.

I will never eat here again.
author: Bill G.

description:
Walked in and were seated immediately in a cramped table between two other cramped tables on an unusually hot, Indian summer day.

No worries, though, I'm as happy as a clam in this weather.

I order up a Blue Star wheat (served with a lemon wedge); the stuff hit the spot like you wouldn't believe. With Elliott Smith blaring through the speakers, I knew this was my kinda pizza joint. 

We opted for a small half-and-half of the Little Star (spinach, ricotta, feta, mushrooms, onions, and chunks of garlic) and the Classic (sausage, mushrooms, onions, and green bell pepper) pizzas. My man loved the Classic (he's a meat-n-potatoes boy), while I inhaled the Little Star (I do loves me some garlic). The pizzas have a great balance of sauce, cheese, and bread; it's not overwhelming any which way. A small deep-dish for two (six slices) was perfectly satiating.

Friendly, attentive servers and fair prices. I'm really pleased with this place.
author: Adena B.

description:
Little Star has redeemed their worth to me.

They have an awesome jukebox selection and the fact that they got my friends and me a table quickly makes up for the fact that I will never order their garlic bread again. (See other review.)

Our server was also a total sweetheart and super understanding about why my party was running late. They were having some motorcycle problems. Oh boys and their toys...when will they learn?
author: Amy J.

description:
On a recent Tuesday afternoon for lunch, I made an enormous discovery (thanks HC).  
It's not that there was practically nobody else dining in, or anything wrong with their service. 
....It was their amazing deep dish!

I'm usually not a deep dish kind of person, but LSP converted me into one.  The last time I had something this great was in Chicago many years ago.  

With their crispy cornmeal crust, feta and ricotta, fresh mushrooms and spinach, the Little Star will always be my favorite deep dish in the Bay Area!
author: Bobby L.

description: besides Zachary's this is probably one of the best deep dish pizzas in the bay.  Try the Brass Monkey.  Tony's in N. Beach is excellent, too, with dozens of ovens and types of pizzas.
author: John V.

description:
Deep dish Little Star pizza, hands-down the tastiest deep dish pizza I've had in SF. Trumps Paxi's. And I want to go swimming the in Goddess salad. Rub its goodness all over my skin.

I've been eating here regularly for 2+ years. Prefer the Valencia location over Divis, the lighting is sexier.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Best pizza? I don't think so. 

B -- S
-- Found parking during the day! woohoo
-- Felt like servers don't look where they're walking, I had to avoid them twice because they were not paying attention
-- Nice to have the ability to fill up our own water, I guess lol
-- Garlic bread was disappointing =/
-- Deep dish was just ok *read below why*
-- Table next to us had thin crust & it looked delicious!
-- No ranch?! Thank God for the liquor store across the street
-- Didn't cost an arm & a leg!

I bookmarked this place because it's so highly rated. The GF & I came here on a Saturday afternoon. We found parking on 15th & it wasn't super packed or anything. About the servers not paying attention: I just don't really think they were "all there." I'm not trying to be a jerk but when you're not paying attention to where you're going & I have the walking right of way, you should stop. Instead I stopped to be nice but two times, really?

We knew the deep dish was going to take time so we got their garlic bread. I did say garlic bread, I read garlic bread and ordered "Garlic Bread." What did we get? We did get warm, delicious bread with a side of butter and some roasted garlic. If I just wanted butter & bread, this would have been awesome. The roasted garlic was mediocre. I ate a whole crap load of it and it wasn't even that "garlic-y" and was just disappointing.

We ended up ordering a L deep dish with chicken, spinach and garlic. I'm really glad we got regular garlic even though our server almost got it wrong when she repeated it back to us. The pie itself was pretty good. The cornmeal crust was decent. The sauce was a bit tangy and really, really a bit too much "tomato-y" for me. I NEEDED SOME RANCH badly to battle the tomato overload. I was very disappointed that they didn't have ranch. Luckily the liquor store kitty corner to Little Star did! The ranch saved the pizza and the meal for me. I will say that the quality of the chicken was top notch on my pizza.

When I compare Little Star to Zachary's, it's very similar minus the fact that Zachary's has delicious ranch & they don't use cornmeal. Their sauces are very similar, both have chinky tomatoes. My recent favorite deep dish winner, however, is Patxi's! They have a much more chewy & flaky crust that also has cornmeal. I can't say that Little Star lives up to Patxi's but is similar to Zachary's. I would like to try their thin crust and might be seeing that in my future soon.
author: Daniel D.

description:
My oh my the crust was in its own definition a sensation! I dont know how they make it but sure is damn good. Best deep dish pizza I have ever tasted so far here in San Fran! The ambiance is hella cute too. The decoration is modern yet simple. love it!! You should come around 3 pm for a late brunch since it will be pretty empty and you can have all the place for yourself.  I ordered the Mediterranean Chicken Deep Dish pizza which cost $18.50(for a 9 inch) Id say its pretty sweet deal. Anyways also I ordered the garlic bread(4.00)...its good:D and also the Mixed Salad! I LOVE the salad($7.00)!! Hell its really tasty, i dont mind eating it everyday! I only paid $(32) with tax and its pretty sweet....Came out of this place with great satisfaction. 

The only reason why Im giving it a 4 cause I had to wait for my food for sometime....Other than that come and try this place!:D
author: Cavin T.

description: Had postmates deliver...good pizza but found a long gray hair in my salad...eek...that was the end of that.
author: N B.

description: Literally the worst service I've ever received, in the history of going out to eat. Our slip said Raquel. "May we trouble you for some more water please?" "* eye roll*. I love the food, and I generally can't stand when people yelp the service, but my god. Just get a new job that doesn't make you so miserable. I've lived in the mission a long time. You're just getting lazy if you're not even trying.
author: Christina S.

description: I had the classic deep dish. It was perfectly flaky and delicious. The 9" pizza may seem expensive at $19 but it is meant for two people. This fork and knife style pizza is just as delicious as anything to come out of Chicago.
author: Petie P.

description:
Went with my 15 year old daughter during a trip to SF....she is a very picky eater and she loved it. We had:

Caprese Salad
Garlic bread: you have to mix the garlic in the butter....kinda weird but ok
Peperoni deep dish

Beer was nice and cold!
author: Bryan U.

description:
Big caveat: I've only gotten pizza to go, but damn is it a good pizza.

I usually get the classic deep dish.  What a delight!  The perfect combination of sausage, mushroom, onion, and bell pepper.  One or two slices (or three if I'm feeling particularly gluttonous) is plenty to fill me up.  My god, it's such a good pizza.

Okay, time for a confession.   I live alone and every so often I will order a large pizza for myself and end up living off of it for a week.  Yeah... pretty sad, but also pretty delicious.
author: Michael N.

description: Delicious pizza. Went with a large group of 8, and everyone so enjoyed their pizza. The only reason I'm not giving it 5 stars is bc the garlic bread was a farce. Instead if delicious sour dough bread baked and dripping in butter and garlic, we got a loaf of bread with a side of butter and a side of roasted garlic. Not okay.
author: Leah P.

description:
Kathy V. recommended that I try Little Star Pizza after my Arizmendi Pizza review. So away me and my boyfriend went to the Mission District on a Friday night. We took BART from Daly City and was just a 5 minute walk from the 16th Street Bart Station. The place was a bit incognito. The way I figured out I found Little Star was a guy that came out with a pizza box. 

Enter Little Star Pizza. This place was uber busy. I put my name on the wait list and the wait was about 20-25 minutes. No problem, beer will make the wait seem much faster. Finally seated, we ordered the Mixed Green Salad and Classic Deep Dish Pizza. The mixed Salad was pretty good, it wasn't heavily drenched in dressing which was good and the salad tasted very light and airy. Finally, our Classic Deep Dish Pizza. As soon as I took my first bite into the pizza, I was floored. I couldn't believe how good the pizza tasted. I've had Giordano deep dish Pizza in Chicago and of course Zachery's and Little Star just knocked them out of the park for me. Overall, the service is great, pizza was awesome. I can't wait to try their other deep dish pizzas.
author: Jocelyn T.

description:
I'm doing this review on behalf of the person who actually ate the pizza (i didn't, bc i'm a vegan)

the vegetarian deep dish was 'the best he's ever had'
this place was recommended by a local
it was very very yummy and smelled delish!

i had a salad. big and tasty, not wimpy at all.
go!
author: Samantha S.

description:
This dimly-lit pizzeria on a dark corner of Valencia has deep-dish pizza that feeds my deep-rooted carb cravings...it's always lurking around, mostly controlled, but once in a while, it rears it's hungry head & leads me to places like Little Star. 

We had a classic childhood combo--root beer & pizza, but instead of generic fountain soda, Little Star serves Boylan Bottleworks root beer (made with cane sugar.) And their pizza is not that flimsy, greasy chain pizza from my youth; it's thick crust at its finest--buttery crust with that awesome gritty mouthfeel & quality ingredients (we chose 1/2 classic w/ sausage & 1/2 mediterranean chicken.) Wonderful flavors! I do prefer thin crust (it's a guilt thing--girls, you feel me, right?!) so you'll find me at a certain Glen Park pizzeria more often, but when I'm craving thick crust, I'll rush back to Little Star. 

Start with the amazing caprese salad--so fresh & delicious...it'll prep your tastebuds for the yumminess that is their pizza.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Its probably the best place in the city, our go to place for a birthdays ... go for the Mediterranean, chicken pesto or the Italian. you won't regret!!
author: Daniel H.

description:
Little Star is home of the best pizza I've had in San Francisco, by a country mile!  I've only had their deep dish (Chicago style) pizza, which is served "upside down": crust, cheese, toppings, then sauce on top.  It's delish.  

Last night we tried the chicken wings, too.  They were spicy, but also really good.

There can be long lines for a table any night of the week, with first-come, first-served seating in the bar.  I don't go all the time (it's definitely more like a big dinner out than it is like just grabbing a slice of pizza), but when I do go, I'm always glad I did!
author: Erin W.

description:
I don't like pizza, really I don't.  Pizza tends to make me nauseous and sick after 2 slices because it's so greasy.  So thank you to Little Star for not making me sick and instead loving the yummy Chicago style deep dish pizza in your totally original corn meal crust.  The corn meal crust really makes a world of a difference and what made this pizza really stand out with a crispy crunch! 

Little Star is on the 7x7 list of 2010 so it's a must try in my book.  I'm glad we did.  My sweetie wanted the Classic (sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers) and I wanted the Little Star (Spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic).  We were about to order 2 pizzas, one of each but thanks to our waitress, turns out you can do a half/half pizza.  Yay me!  Best of both worlds.  OMG!!! I love love love the Little Star flavor.  The veggies all blended together with amazing flavor and the garlic!  I think all pizzas should have garlic.  The ricotta cheese and the spinach was a great combo with enough sauce so the pizza wasn't dry.  The Classic was good too but the name says it all, it's your good old, trusty, boring toppings.  The tomatoe sauce that was used really complemented the pizza.  It wasn't too sweet or sour.  Perfectly balanced.  

But that's not all folks!  You have to get their Spicy Chicken Wings!  They aren't saucy at all which I liked.  They were seasoned, fried and delicious!  A whole pound too!  Great to share...but I secretly hoped that my sister and fiancee would stop eating them so I could eat it all myself!  

A great meal...and you didn't make me sick.  Little Star-you are a rock star!
author: Amy L.

description:
I last visited Little Star in 2004 and I thought it was good...I finally went back, this time to the Mission location, and it was great - better than I remember.

We had the Mediterranean Chicken and Classic deep dish pizzas.  Both were really good.  The chicken pizza was great since they actually seasoned the chicken, which is something I don't recall them doing when I first went to the restaurant years ago.  The other pizza was a perfect balance of rich and savory flavors from the sausage and seasoned marinara.  Everything tasted very good and fresh.  We also split a salad, which was a perfect way to have fresh vegetables with the meal.  I washed this all down with a Thomas Kemper Black Cherry soda, which was awesome - it was like drinking candy - I loved it!

This place is a great option for a fun evening with a friend or friends.  Little Star is very popular, so be prepared for a wait, and make sure you plan your evening accordingly.
author: Ken G.

description:
Let me first say that THIS girl (points both thumbs toward self) knows a little about deep dish pizza as I currently live in Chicago, i.e. deep dish pizza holy mecca. 

I got takeout from Little Star Pizza on a Thursday afternoon. Called about 15 minutes ahead of time and ordered a vegetarian small deep dish. Weirdly, the doors of Little Star are opaque so I was unsure whether it was even open as I couldn't see inside. Once I opened the door, a pickup counter and bar was to the right and a small waiting area to the left. Main seating area was toward the back. Person by the pickup counter was friendly. The overall restaurant is cute, trendy, with a  modern jukebox where you can select to play the PIxies and other such fine bands.

The small deep dish is supposed to serve 2 or 3 but in my book there is no way it could serve 3 (I very nearly ate the whole pizza all by myself!). The crust is what sets this deep dish apart from the pack - it has a delicious corn meal texture. Really enjoyed it - Little Pizza you are giving Chicago some serious competition in the deep dish pizza department.
author: Polly S.

description: Favorite pizza thought I'd let you know this pizza will not disappoint. All time fav is the spinach mushroom with many cloves of creamy garlic cooked in a deep dish cornmeal mixed crust! As for timing expect longer prep times when you come here.
author: alexia h.

description:
We purposely planned for a long layover in SF on our way back home to LA. We had about 3 hours so we decided to check out the Mission District and Little Star pizza. Checked out yelp of course and this place had lots of great reviews. 

We got there right around noon lunch time and there was only another couple in the restaurant. Simple, clean design with dark tone accents. Pretty little place. The waiter was very nice and informed us of the specials during lunch, which were their personal size pizzas. 

What a big difference from the personal size to a normal size! Normal size small runs about $20 more or less. The personal size was only $9!! Awesome deal! We got both the thin and thick crust so we could try out both options.

Deep Dish - "Little Star" - spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic 

Thin Crust - "Classic" - sauage, mushrooms, onions, green bell peppers 

Both were delicious in its own ways!! Deep dish was surprising not heavy and the sauce was so flavorful and sweet.  I'm not a fan of feta, but this was delicious!! Tasty morsels of spinach and ricotta with a crispy corn meal crust! Yum!!! The thin crust also held up to its standards. Totally did not fall apart with the toppings, which I hate. Super crispy, not soggy, and of course, you can't go wrong with sausage and mushrooms. 

Total came out to like $20 before tip! Love it. Totally coming back next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Leona S.

description:
I'm always rather suspicious of deep dish pizzas.  

Issues concerning:
1) difficulty breathing
2) a need to unbutton 
3) and a perpetual fear that I'll spiral beyond 1 gargantuan slice of caloric ignorance. 

Does one really need that much cheese, and tomato sauce all at once? 

Ah, I am torn. 
I ordered a small 9" pie to share with my date.  Out of the many options, we topped ours with Salami, Artichoke Hearts, and Mushrooms.  I don't like to readily admit this to myself but it was completely satisfying.. The ingredients were fresh, the crust was perfect, and my experience even warranted a second heaping slice.  Oh, and they have beers on tap. Eek, "Serenity Now!"
author: Ty T.

description:
Fantastic as long as you know what you are ordering. 

You are at Little Star for Deep Dish. Their think crust pizza's are good, but what sets them apart from other pizza spots is the Deep Dish pizza and the FRESH INGREDIENTS. 

Their red sauce on their deep dish is top notch with chunks of savory tomato sitting atop melted cheese. It was simply high quality pizza. 

The ingredients in the Caprese Salad were tasty as well. 

Yes there is a wait, and no it's not a good spot for groups. So call in your order if you are coming with a ton of people and get it to go. 

All in all - Great Great Place to Satisfy your Pizza Cravings. 

And not to start a whole flame war or anything, but Little Star definitely beats out Patxi's. Still need to try Zac's in Berkeley, but if your in SF and want Deep Dish. Heads over to this spot.
author: Alex M.

description:
Just a nice menu. A great place to go when you're out and not sure what to do for dinner, but you don't want something super run of the mill, while still being fed enough, without breaking the bank, and it's gotta be delicious.

The place has a great atmosphere.
author: Stefan M.

description:
I attended for a friend's wine and pizza birthday dinner. We drank at the bar for about 30 minutes before everybody showed up and we could get a table. The wait staff were friendly and accommodating.

The pizza (we ordered both thin crust and chicago deep dish style (with the sauce on top). I found all the pizzas to be very fresh tasting, but not overly tasty. The crust was good and crunchy.

I had a good time and the decor was very good and the place had a homey feel to it, but I doubt I would go out of my way to go back or order from them. It's not that there was anything wrong as much as there was nothing to bring me back.
author: Jordan C.

description:
These are my all time favorites: 

- Classic 
- Mediterranean Chicken
- Little Star 

Their deep dish pizza is soooo amazing!!  I love the corn bread crust and how it's packed with chunks of tomato.  It tastes even better the next day!
author: Alice L.

description:
"Crunchy butter"

Sure, it sounds like something so wrong, but, no, it's so right. The crust. Crunchy. Buttery. Amazingly not greasy. Believe.

That's all that came to mind last time I sunk my teeth in.

A famished crew, post-bouldering sesh at Mission Cliffs, it's past 9:00 on a Friday. No bigs getting a table at this hour - Party of Five. Not quite like the show. (Did I just date myself? because I never actually watched it, FTR)

Can't seat you unless your whole party is there. Fair enough. (Stupidly, our party involves a car and a lack of parking space for the first half hour.)

The "rules": 
Parties not seated til everyone is there, in the flesh.
BUT If you want to order, they will seat you and get that baby cookin'.
BUT If said party can't park in time, No, you cannot take your pizza to go once you've been seated. Why? I have no idea. The explanation baffled us all.

Back to the butter. OMFG. Knife. Fork. Beer. Salad to tide you over. Crust//Cheese//Tomato//Mouth.
Repeat. 
Knife. Fork. Butter. Mouth.
Rinse & Repeat.
Beer.
Beer.
Butter.
Better!

*sigh of relief*

A well-fed crew is a happy crew.

As an aside, leave your date at home. The acoustics in here will only result in you screaming at each other across the table, not that I was suggesting you be whispering sweet nothings over a pie. Unless, of course, that's your thing.
author: Alissa A.

description: Did take out on their deep dish pizza, chicken pesto pizza , chicken wings and salad. The pizzas were good, I'm more impartial to thin crust new york style, which was what the chicken pesto pizza was. Pretty good. But I have to admit that they make excellent buffalo wings. That was my fave. yum yum yum.
author: Kenson K.

description: We tried the thin crust (instead of the popular deep dish). And it was excellent! Maybe they can have more options for pizza configurations (for vegetarians).
author: Raj S.

description:
After hearing such amazing things about Little Star Pizza, I was excited about having my first deep-dish pizza. 

We were seated immediately (it was around lunch time) which was nice, but, I the tables were too close for comfort. I, for one, do not enjoy eating next to other people (that just how I do). 

The one thing I love is the fact that they have Earth Friendly straws made of paper!!!

We ordered a deep dish pepperoni pizza which was pretty good! However, I was not a fan of the crust. I'm more of a doughy crust person. 

The service was average. The man that served us seemed like he wanted to be elsewhere and did the bare minimum of someone who works in customer service.

Personally, I wouldn't be back.
author: Juliette R.

description:
So I was reading about this place in a Fodor's 2010 travel guide and then looked them up on yelp.  After seeing the previous reviews, I knew I had to visit the Mission.  To experience the Mission best, my friend and I took the BART up and basically hiked from the Mission northward to wherever our interests took us.  A tiring but interesting experience nonetheless.  

Little Star is an unsuspecting place on the beautiful Valencia St. of the Mission District. Littered with small trendy eatery's here and there, we had some good choices in mind but decided to go here.  They didn't open up until noon on Saturday and we were the first ones which meant the service had to be good.  Our server was very attentive to everything; she brought a nice pitcher of water out right away and knew precisely when we were ready to order.  

The pizza supposedly takes up to 30 minutes so we got the garlic bread appetizer which was REAL garlic and seemingly fresh artisan bread that was nice and hot. Butter was awesome as well, you have to try it.  We ordered the 9" small classic deep dish pizza which turned out to be a little more than I'd usually eat.  But that's alright, cause it was so damn good.  The end crust is not overly thick and the freshness of the tomato sauce is exceptional.  I understood why it was on top of the pizza after taking my first bite.
author: Kenny P.

description:
Siblings wanted to take HI haole for a good time... Sis suggested to take him here... 

Off we went...

Got here at 7ish and wait wasn't bad. We got seated right away. 

**Corkage was just $10!** WOW!

We ordered the following:
* caprese salad: just enough for all 4 and we devoured it...

* spicy chicken wings: all 3 but me ate this... was afraid of the spicy part =)

* Mediterranean Chicken: good pizza! We shared it and I think we had a couple of slices left. Just enough for all of us.

Overall, service was friendly and of course, conversation and company was lovely.
author: Cath M.

description:
