I love this place! I don't make it to the city very often, so when my husband and I took a staycation last weekend, I immediately quizzed my local friends on their favorite pizza places. Little Star kept coming up. Since it was our first time ordering from Little Star (and because pizza is my favorite food), we decided to order both the deep dish and thin crust pizzas: Small cheese thin crust with roasted garlic + Large thin crust cheese, with extra fresh mozzarella, olives and roasted garlic. So amazing. The two of us finished it all by the end of the night (no joke). 

My only tip, would be to get 1/2 the amount of roasted garlic on your pizza. It was a bit strong on ours (and I love garlic)... I was tasting it for a full day after.

I will definitely be back again soon.
author: Lacey H.

description: I crave this pizza! The sauce has the right amount of sweetness and the crust is baked perfectly. Salads are fresh with lots of flavor - great portions. Will be back again and again. Thanks!
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
Put simply: the best deep dish pizza in the Bay Area (though there are several other very good ones). The classic is my all-time favorite.
A hint: this pizza saves very well. I've eaten it at home for two or three days after bringing one home, and it's still very tasty.

Nice wait staff, too.

Highly recommended!
author: Arthur C.

description: Not sure why pizza always has to be compared to "NY" or "Chicago". This place is great in it's own right. I start missing the deep dish pizza when I haven't had it in a while. I would definitely recommend giving it a try.
author: Erica L.

description:
Love the pizza; would advise caution when getting a bottle of wine.  We were going to go for something when the bartender gave us a knowing look and suggested he give us a "taste" first.  It was godawful.  He then wisely led us to a much better choice.  

Great fun service (I love seeing hipsters working).
author: Tasha D.

description: I love this place. My husband and I have been twice, always good food, good service. And by good food, I mean delicious fucking deep dish pizza
author: Carrie N.

description: This place makes me SO MAD!!!! They said that we would have a 15 minutes wait, then left us for 45 minutes as a continuous amounts of people were allowed to sit down. We ordered a glass of wine for the wait, and even after we had told them that we were going to leave they still charged us for the wine. This has happened two other times, and the pizza was subpar
author: Aurora B.

description:
Ok. 

I was raised on Zachary's Pizza. 

Don't tell my parents but...Little Star Pizza is even better. Best deep dish ever. 

My only problem is that I've fallen so deeply in love with their namesake pizza, that I have to order it every time. It is freakishly delicious, with a great balance of cheese and veggies. Best of all? It reheats well too.

It does take them a little while to make, so don't make the mistake of arriving already starving. Or you could order some garlic bread to and then have even more leftover pizza. 

I need to try the other things they serve, but for first timers, you can't go wrong with the Little Star.
author: Claire G.

description:
My boyfriend and I ordered pickup. The experience was very pleasant. The order was ready five minutes ahead of schedule, and the pickup procedure was great.  Additionally, the food tasted amazing.

My only real criticism was in the description of the dish. We ordered the Mediterranean Chicken pizza, and there was hardly any chicken in the dish at all. There must have been about one chicken breast used in an entire large pizza. The dish would have been an amazing vegetarian pizza if it had been billed that way, but the chicken was so sparse, that I almost forgot it was an ingredient, surprising me each time I got a bite (which was about one bite per slice).  If the title of the dish had not featured chicken, this would have been fine, but since it did, I was let down.  

The pizza was good, but it appears as though they are heavy on the veggie toppings and skimp a little bit on meat toppings. Just something to think about.
author: Evan R.

description: im very disappointed with the customer service from little star , i have to say that the pizza is great has alot of flavor but what it makes it a 1 star is the customer service, so i decided to tryed it out little star because of the great reviews that i have read and i leave close by , but i never expected to actually be treated bad , my waitress was very rude i felt discriminated because im hispanic and the way that she was acting felt like if i was getting the food for free, or if i have done something wrong, she never came around the table didn't take the right order brought the wrong order and the drinks never got them or the appetizer worse experience ever , i just wont recomend the restaurant to my family or close friends its very sad that there could be people with such a poor mind thinking that just because your not white you are not even worth  being there , in my entired life leaving in san francisco i have never been discriminated before !!! But regarding the pizza is has a great flavor and its great.
author: Helen L.

description:
My cousin found this pizza joint on yelp and decided to give this place a shot.  We ordered a Classic deep dish pizza - TOGO and I can totally see why this pizza joint is rated 4stars.  

I normally do not like eating the bread/crust off a pizza and usually eat the toppings right off of it.  However, the crust on this pizza was crispy on the ends and fluffy under the toppings.  Felt like I was eating a butter biscuit, topped with toppings.

Although the crust was good,. the toppings were just blehhh.  It just tasted like an overload of tomatoe sauce and not enough meat and cheese.  I wont be ordering the Classic if I go back,.. 

But if I do come back,. I will be aiming for the thin crust pesto chicken.  :)

I will be back!
author: Chanel L.

description:
All I wanted to eat for my birthday was Pizza, cause nothing beats having a great slice of pie with good friends. We went to this location cause it was by my second stop of the day, Tartines. 
The venue is nice and small. Food was yummy. And the deep dish pizza is so hearty.
author: Theresa D.

description:
I hesitated writing the review for Little Star because my experiences with the restaurant seemed so atypical.

Firstly, I'd never had deep dish pizza before. I'm not sure I'm a fan, but I couldn't deny the deliciousness of Little Star's cornmeal crust. Every thick-crusted pizza should be made with cornmeal dough. My one stipulation was that the base of the crust could have been a little thicker as its toppings were making the middle soggy.

I thought that the ambiance was quite nice -- but I was lucky to go to Little Star during an odd hour past normal Saturday lunch time. This allowed me to avoid the infamous San Francisco dining crowds that tend to ruin all dining experiences. My friend and I got a seat by the window and enjoyed watching the Saturday pass us by. I was also impressed that their Happy Hour discounts for their alcohol started as early as Saturday afternoon.

All in all a very pleasant experience, but I'm not sure if the food would be worth the regular crowds. Also, I find it slightly disconcerting that they only scored a 95 or something on their health inspection card. Where are those other 5 points? A restaurant of this much talk should not settle for anything less than 100!
author: Michelle L.

description: Best pizza ever!!!!!!!! Must get the white pie thin crust and the deep dish little star!!!! Yummmmmm
author: Alana P.

description: Little Star Pizza at Valencia Street. I asked them where they get their cheese. They wouldn't tell me. So, I had to order a pizza without cheese on it. The pizza took a very long time to come. Although I had ordered the pizza to go, I got so hungry that by the time the pizza got there, I ate it at the bar. I was chided by the waitstaff for 'being unprofessional'. I was just trying to have some pizza. I spent 30 dollars for a pizza and a glass of wine, and was scolded for eating it out of the box.
author: Seth S.

description:
Liked the place overall, but found the pizza just a bit too greasy for my taste. 

For those expecting Zachary's or Mangia's (in Austin), this is different - this is probably a more authentic Chicago style.
author: Vivek G.

description: Really fun place - great food, super nice people, and the crowd seems to match the mood of the staff, especially Marisol who was really fun to be around.  This is some of the best pizza I've ever had, and I'm a big pizza fan.  This place is straight awesome.  Last time I went, we had the Mediterranean Chicken (normally a deep-dish option) but we had it on the clearly flawed and far inferior thin crust variety because of my girlfriend's faulty tastes, and it was one of the best pizzas I ever had.
author: david p.

description:
I went here with my clicks at work, pretty much a foodie group. We were craving for pizza Chicago style. Driving around Valencia st and spotted little star pizza. Friends have said this place is pretty good. The server were very helpful and pleasant. 

We ordered the deep dish Classic and chicken pesto thin crush and salads. They were all soooo good.
author: ML A.

description:
'Little star' deep dish pizza was delicious! Best deep dish I've tried in the bay area!

Crunchy crust, layers of cheese, spinach, ricotta cheese and tomato sauce... Um, status YUM!

Plus, good location and friendly staff.

To avoid a long wait, go before 6:30pm. Enjoy!
author: Eunice M.

description:
This is so good!  Omg, this is so good!  This was what my friend and I kept saying all night long as we share the White Pie thin crust pizza.  So full of flavor - I may have found the pizza I can eat over and over and over again.

We also got the garlic bread - which I always do whenever I'm at Little Star.  That bulb of garlic just gets me.

Discovery of the night:  Ginger beer!
author: Pam S.

description:
I live down the street from the Divis Little Star, so there's really no reason for me to ever venture out to the Mission for Little Star.  But when Delfina's Pizzeria--which is apparently different from Delfina, as I was snobbily apprised of by staff members at each "separate" establishment--couldn't hold the big homecoming party of a certain gallerina-turned-second-curator-in-command in a certain Southern state whose state university's mascot is an octopus for some baffling reason, we moseyed on up Valencia because, well, Little Star is a certain kind of it.

I had what I always have at LS, the vegetarian special or whatever.  There were many of us, and I did some stuff I hadn't done in a while.  I didn't follow up on any of it, but I was a gentleman and walked a certain lady to the 16th Street BART station because, well, I'm a gentleman.  And I care about people, even if I don't know them and may never see them again.  And it's 16th Street, after all.

But because we were all being prim and proper and because I was doing less scarfing down than I normally do, there was pizza left over.  And exactly three of us lived in San Francisco, so I got the veggie-pizza take-home box.  So as I rode the 22 home and tried not to think about how badly I had to pee and how long it would take me to walk home from the corner of Fillmore and Oak in the cold and with a remarkably smaller or less able or whatever bladder than I've ever known, I thought about how much I would enjoy this leftover pizza.  And how I always seem to screw things up in the least awful way possible.

So here's to attractive, affable artists and a certain adorable nephew who confuses the words "crime" and "chime," rather habitually.
author: John S.

description: got a cheese deep dish and added pepperoni. was phenomenal. a bit pricey, but worth it.
author: Brian B.

description:
I ate at LSP yesterday for lunch. The deep dish pizza was inundated with tomato chunks and sauce. All I could taste was the tomatoes! The menu listed through the Yelp link is old or not updated apparently, because the lunch menu in the restaurant listed some expensive prices than online! Aren't lunch menus supposed to list cheaper prices than dinners?  Our 12" ddp was $46! A personal 10" ddp was $26!! All of them gross, salty, and tomato'y!!! It took forever to be served but the service was good.  I can buy a 20" combo pizza at North Beach Pizza or some other quality pizza place for only $25!!!! Never going back!!!!!

I really don't recommend this place unless you're simply bored, lack taste buds, have wads of cash to blow, forced or coerced to go, or trying to pick up one of the waiters or waitresses or have some other interest in this place other than food!
author: Marc N.

description: This place is great for friends, family and couples. I would not bring any kids here but the pizza is just divine. My favorite is the Mederterannian Pizza Deep Dish. Amazing flavor and can't forget the cornmeal crust. Delic!! WIll always and forever go back here.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
First off I only get the food to go, and for me the place seems a bit loud to sit and eat.

That said I could take a bath in their red sauce!  Love love love the deep dish corn crust pizzas.  

Favorite is the Mediterranean chicken pizza and really like the spicy chicken wings too.
author: Mark R.

description: Hanging out in the San Francisco area and was walking around in search of good pizza.  2 locals recommended this place so decided to check it out.  Very cool vibe and very good pizza.  Ordered the white pie thin crust, italian thin crust, classic deep dish, and another type deep dish.  They were all very flavorful.  Drinks here, they serve only beer and wine.   The waitress was very friendly as well.  Great food along with great customer service.
author: Yisel F.

description:
Little Star Pizza turned this Thin Crust Lover to a Deep Dish one!

Finally, after a long awaited year and a half, I finally got to see what all the rave was about. And, it was definitely worth the wait.

FOOD:
*Mixed Salad (mixed greens, w/ gorgonzola cheese and chopped walnuts): I heart gorgonzola cheese, so I enjoyed how it added a great punch to the salad. Everything was fresh and well balanced; the vinaigrette had a perfect balance of citrus and oil. I liked how the walnuts were toasted which added a great crunch and nutty flavor.

*Goddess Salad (romaine lettuce w/ pesto vinaigrette and beets): The crisp romaine was gently tossed in the fresh pesto vinaigrette. The basil flavor wasn't too strong and had a faint nutty undertones from the pine nuts.   

Because the deep dish does take longer to prepare 30-40 minute, if you're starving, it would be best to order an app or salad. 

*Little Star (spinach blended with ricotta, feta and mushrooms): I LOVE Spanakopita, so naturally I thought I would enjoy the Little Star; I did and then some. Let's start with the crust...I normally veer away from dish pizzas b/c if not done right, they can be soggy. LSP deep dish's bottom crust was hearty, crunch, and held up very well to the filling. The cornmeal had a slightly grainy texture that a added a bite to the crust. The outer crust was crispy on the outside and pillowly soft in the inside. The filling was FRESH--the spinach was cooked perfectly and maintained a vibrant green. There was a good ratio of ricotta and feta, so the cheese didn't overpower the entire filling. With salad and beer, one slice was pretty filling.

Overall, the food quality is awesome at LSP b/c all the ingredients are FRESH, FRESH, FRESH!

SERVICE: There are no reservations, so it's first come first serve. On a Sunday night for a party at 7, the wait was about 25-30 minutes. Our waiter was friendly and attentive, so no complaints.

AMBIANCE/DÉCOR: LSP is a pretty small restaurant. Upon entering, there is a small bar area that you can eat at. The main dining room probably seats 35-40. Red brick walls surround the place and is decorated by contemporary paintings. Only complaints are the creaking wooden floors and the place and get quite loud. 

Will definitely come back again, but will hit up their Divis location since it's closer to me. Damn it, so much for no carbs until March! But, at least I got to check another place off my list!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
To celebrate my return to the Bay, my lovely high school girl friends and I met up at Little Star Pizza for dinner. It's been a while since I've been back to the Mission... and I have forgotten how hipstery ghetto this area of the city can be... and how much I adore the Mission. Anyway, I'm digressing, but discovering this little deep dish pizza joint in the Mission solidified my love for the Mission. 

So, Little Star Pizza is comparable to Zachary's. Haha.. yes, I said it. And which one is better? Hmm.. I'm thinking Little Star Pizza wins. Why? Because of its cornmeal crust. That extra crunch at the end of your slice of pizza is a nicely added texture. Also, I think Little Star Pizza has just the right amount of sauce and pizza filling, so it's not overwhelming and dripping all over your place (which happens sometimes with Zachary's). 

Anyway, for a party of 4, we ordered two small deep dish pizzas and a salad to start. We ended up with 3 slices of pizza left over, which I took one.. and will bring to lunch and show off to my colleagues. 

I will definitely be back, Little Star. You're quite a pizza rock star.
author: Cassy H.

description:
Deep dish pizza = greatest of all pizzas...so it's always been in my book. Nowadays, in this new year of 2010, it's not easy finding a good deep dish in this city...but one bite of Little Star and I was in L-O-V-E. We tried the Classic deep dish (bell peppers, sausage, mushroom, onion) and the Little Star deep dish (spinach, ricotta, feta, mushroom, onion) + we added sausage.  Both were amazing! If you order the Little Star, be sure to add sausage and you won't regret it. It's only been 3 days since my meal here and I'm still dreaming of indulging in another pizza! 

Large deep dish = 8 slices
Small deep dish = 6 slices
They also do thin crust (but what's the point?). Plan ahead for a wait since the restaurant is small and obviously popular. But here's a *TIP*: pre-order your pizza shortly before you're going to get seated and it will be ready for you not long after your table is.

My only quibble is that I didn't realize how pricey this pizza was until I got home and thought about it. A small deep dish + 1 extra topping is already $21.

At 14 slices of pizza + 3 beers we paid $68 incl. tip. Typical for a meal out, but to me that's semi-pricey for just pizza. Take that as you wish... in any case, my belly can't say no!!
author: Felicia C.

description: Hands down the best deep dish pizza in SF.   Gotta order the wings with blue cheese dipping sauce. Although I wish they would carry ranch cuz I think the wings would be way better with ranch.  A bit pricy but worth it.
author: David S.

description: Good ingredients. They avoid gmo's. Deep dish crust is unique and really good. Pizza itself is pretty average in my opinion. Wings are spicy and of good quality. I've sat down to eat there and picked up for home as well. Ambiance and service inside is good. Pick up is not so good. Boxes are "doggy bag" quality at best so pizza and wings get cold quick so get home fast. Last time I picked up I ordered online. Arrived promptly at confirmed pick up time (30 mins after I placed online order) and had to wait another 20 mins. They hadn't started baking anything prior to my arrival. Would have waited even longer if I hadn't noticed them boxing my order and then one of the girls trying to stick it in the holding area. Service inside tho has already been good.
author: Josh W.

description: Ok, not a bad pie, no doubt about it. But...BUT, to charge $2.50 for a side of dressing? Two-fifty? C'mon guys. Really? Like, for real and seriously? Man, that's criminal right there.  I'm so bent out by that, that I took the time to write this very review. Not impressed.
author: Booky C.

description:
During some late night startup life, we needed a quick to-go dinner. Little Star was a tasty nearby solution. I hadn't ever had their non-Chicago pizza, and I really liked the chewy goodness of the white pie. Generally pizza's not a chewy food, but I enjoyed the unique texture of it; I think it was the cheese that gave it the chew.

I think I slightly prefer the Chicago experience, but if you need something quick, white pie is the way to go.
author: Emily M.

description: Loved the spicy wings and the "Little Star" deep dish pizza.
author: Tishina B.

description:
Still a 4 star!

This time we had a large group of 7. One thing to note is that EVERYONE in your party has to be on time if you have a large group. They won't sit you otherwise. 

2 Mixed green salad - a bit too oily for my taste but was a great balance with the pizza 
1 thin crust special with prosciutto - the crust was a bit dry 
1 deep dish Mediterranean Chicken  - the crust was crunchy and soft, just the way i like it
author: Sophie S.

description:
I've heard so much about this place from friends who hear me rant about how I can't find a decent deep dish 2,000 miles away from home. One of these poor lads finally made it a point to make me meet him for dinner here last night and it did not disappoint. The wait was pretty long (we were quoted 45 minutes but  really waited about an hour for a table for 2.) When the crowd gets crazy in the lobby, the bartender takes out a sample pizza and kind of calms down the crowd so I was fortunate enough to try a slice of their White Pie. 

They have 3 beers on tap, a limited amount of red and white wines but it's their champagne that makes their drink list fun. When we were sat, I immediately ordered a Hey-Koolaid from our fabulously efficient and pleasant server and was tickled pink by the cherries on the bottom soaked in the champagne. 

We had the buffalo wings rubbed in a spicy rub and baby carrots followed by a Classic DEEP DISH pizza. This is not a sad pathetic attempt at Deep Dish, nay, this is actually passable for the pizzas of my fond youth in Chicago so I'd proudly polish these pizzas again and again. We ordered the Classic with roasted garlic to give it a little pizzaz and I was not disappointed! I'm sure their thin crust is awesome too but it's their Deep Dish that's gonna get me coming back regardless of a 45+ minute wait. 

Their cheesecake is homemade and when served with chocolate sauce, it became MAGIC. The only thing I'd want to add to it is maybe a little raspberry sauce but that's just me. The service was so fast and courteous, the food was hot, fast and awesome and the atmosphere, although crowded was intimate for a party of 2. This is most definitely one of my favorites from now on.
author: Jessica K.

description: The pizza here is okay.  I love deep dish so I wanted to try this place out.  Their crust was super hard/crunchy not soft like the type I was used to.
author: Chloe K.

description:
#!/bin/bash

little_star_deep_dish="Mmm"
patxis_deep_dish="Yum"
zacharys_deep_dish="omfg_thisisheaven"

get_ascii() { LC_CTYPE=C printf '%d' "'$1"; }

lilstar=$(get_ascii ${little_star_deep_dish::1})
patxis=$(get_ascii ${patxis_deep_dish::1})
zacharys=$(get_ascii ${zacharys_deep_dish::1})

pizza_comparator()
{
        difference=`expr $1 - $2`

        # Empirically derived, based on cutting-edge pizza science
        superiority_threshold=15

        if [ ${difference#-} -lt $superiority_threshold ];
                then echo -e "\tMeh, pretty much the same."
        elif [ ${difference#-} -gt $(($superiority_threshold * 2)) ];
                then echo -e "\tZachary's is love,"
        elif [ ${difference#-} -gt $superiority_threshold ];
                then echo -e "\tZachary's is life."
        fi
}

echo "Little Star vs. Patxis:"
pizza_comparator $lilstar $patxis

echo "The only truth:"
for competition in $lilstar $patxis
do
        pizza_comparator $zacharys $competition
done
author: Nima E.

description: Garlic bread comes with whole garlic and the pesto deep dish was DEEEEEEP. I got a side of ranch and dipped that doggie right in. I love this place not to mention it's across from my work. Such a great gem and solid pizza place. A+ on variety and price along with exceptional service and good music.
author: Jess C.

description: First time here and honestly not very psyched ... The place is small and you have to listen to other customers conversations (the one on the left even talks louder than me ... And I talk veeery loud)... The servers only really care about bringing the food and that's it (or at least mine looked like it... Not even dessert she cared for) ... Just like a normal pizza place... Just fancier ... Oh!!!.. don't even think on taking your time eating here .. they want you out as fast as possible (even stated on their menu... Aren't they supposed to be a restaurant t rather than pizza-by-the-slice place?)
author: Camila B.

description: Best. Pizza. Ever!
author: Jaylena P.

description: Really liked this place.   Cool atmosphere and both thin and deep dish pizzas.   Garlic bread is awesome,  so is the vegetarian deep dish  (and I'm a carnivore).  They also have a well selected group of inexpensive wine.
author: Cliff R.

description:
After reading so many reviews from dearest Yelpers and learning that Little Star Pizza made it to 7x7's The Big Eat SF, I had high expectations for their deep dish pizza.

Main Course:
I'm disheartened to say that I was not impressed with their Brass Monkey deep dish pizza. The crust was rather crunchy and hard. The overall pizza to me didn't have much of a "WOW!" The toppings (spinach, mushrooms, onions, garlic and sausages) were ok. I ate a second slice to see if I missed something, but I didn't. I was really hoping to get something as good and if not, as close to Chicago's deep dish pizza.

For appetizers I ordered (plenty for 2):
Caprese Salad: The caprese salad was "just ok" to me. The mozzarella slices were nice and thick and the tomatoes were ripe and about bite size slices. The salad was also served with two types of olives. (Note: I don't like olives)

Spicy Chicken Wings:  Hmmm... I was happy to learn that it was baked! The chicken wings were tasteful... yay! It was my first time dipping the chicken wings in blue cheese dressing and I liked it.

Service: The waitress was cool. She checked on my table a few times.

Ambience: Dark, enclosed, scattered but tables are close to each other..

Crowd: Mixed older adults, not too many kids during dinner time, casual dressing.

Wait: About 15-20 mins. around dinner time, but that was for a table for 2.

Cost: Approximately $60 bucks for two appetizers, a small deep dish pizza, and two non alcoholic drinks.

**** ME **** I prefer my crust to be soft, chewy, and thick. Something like Gino's deep dish pizza from Chicago. More than likely, I will not come back for seconds.
author: Kaycie Y.

description:
The formula for success isn't difficult to figure out: focus on the pizza and add a very good selection of beer. Adding other items, like pasta or wings, may be fine for some but is unnecessary for me. 

Typically I enjoy thin crust pizza but at Little Star, the thicker pizzas are more memorable to me. 

Be prepared for a crowd. On the positive side, most of them are repeat customers, so you'll be in good hands!
author: Mike H.

description:
Mmmmm, pizza. Mmmmm, thin crust. Wait, deep dish? No, thin crust. Screw it, BOTH.

Little Star somehow manages to make excellent deep dish AND thin crust, which is fairly unusual. We sampled the Classic (deep dish, sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bell peppers), the White Pie (thin crust, garlic olive oil base, mozzarella, roasted zucchini, fresh tomatoes, feta), and because my family is a bunch of fatties, the chicken wings. The wings came out first and had this amazing crunchy crust - not breaded, thank god, but just seared with spices. I'm not typically a wing person but I was fighting my brother off with every utensil I had to get at those wings. 

When the pizzas came out I got very, very excited. And then I put them in my mouth. The white pie had a perfect crust, crunchy and substantial enough to hold onto the toppings but thin enough not to overwhelm. That pie was GOOD. I was pleased to note the cornmeal crusting the outsides of the deep dish classic, and was doubly pleased when I forked off my first bite. Perfect sauce, good balance of ingredients, substantial and satisfying crust...I honestly can't say which pizza I preferred. They were both outstanding.

Little Star definitely makes it onto my short list of "I'm in the Mission but don't want a burrito or a booze dinner" restaurants. Which, granted, is not a list I have to turn to often - but perhaps now I will consider it more often.
author: Corinna K.

description:
Food was really good we had the deep dish mushroom sausage and bell peppers. The wait was over an hour and finding the place is ridiculous if you're not from here you might think its a closed up corner building. It's also very small on the inside and you're pretty smashed in there. 

Don't order the garlic bread... It's literally bread.. Butter on the side in a small bowl and a roasted garlic chunk.. Made no sense to me and it was $7 ya too much for it not even being real garlic bread. Overall tasty pizza. It's no Giordanos but its good for the area. Also come after 6 cause parking is free.. As you an tell I'm not from the area..
author: Cyn L.

description: The best pizza I have had ever in California.  I grew up in Chicago, and have never enjoyed a pizza as much as Little Star.  Both deep dish and thin crust are equally good.  They blow the other SF pizza places out of the water. Nuff  said.
author: Gene B.

description: Love love love the thin crunchy crust! I rarely eat all my pizza crust, but I couldn't leave one crumb. It was a lazy Saturday afternoon, so we didn't care that the service wasn't swift. Very happy with our anchovy&green olive pie. Mmmmm.
author: Kathryn S.

description:
The thin crust white pie is awesome.  The dry rub chicken wings are incredible.  The Boont Amber was a great beer.  My mouth is watering as I write this. 

I would honestly give this place five stars but, and this is a big but for me, the tables are so close you are practically sitting in other peoples laps.  Your definitely involved in their lives and know a little too much about them by the end of the meal.  Last night I had to experience this couples awkward first date on the right side of me and several other conversations I wish I would have missed on the left.    Seriously, you have to squeeze between the tables.
author: Frank A.

description: Little Star is a little more San Francisco than the deep dish pizzas I've experienced in Chicago. By that I mean they lean stronger on the quality of the ingredients and less on the ridiculousness of the crust. I really enjoy the way they do it here and find it hard to compare it to San Francisco's other Bay area deep dish choice of Paxti's. I think that I'd probably prefer whichever one you put in front of me because both are super tasty. We did pick up a veteran tip from our waiter that for guaranteed deliciousness throw an egg on top of your left overs as you warm them up for breakfast. That is, if you have enough self-control to have anything left over.
author: Stephen S.

description: Second customer on a warm Wednesday afternoon and I must say the wait was well worth it (didn't check the restaurant hours and got there at 11am + been hearing so much good stuff about the place from lots of people). Felt bad when I left because I forgot to ask my server's name - he was extremely nice and helpful when I asked for recommendations as a first timer. Ordered the thin crust personal-sized California pizza and finished it on my own. It was definitely the type of pizza you can't bring home because it's best eaten when hot. 80's music played from a small jukebox too featuring Hall and Oates, Stevie Wonder, etc and it was just the perfect sunny weekday lunch vibe. Definitely going back for deep dish. Kudos!
author: Monica P.

description:
Little stars.

Even though there are quite a few things to like.

Exposed brick interior is just my style. Pie is ready within thirty minutes of calling in an order. Space is buzzing with pretty much the entire neighborhood anxious for a slice. And the cheese, chicken and artichoke pizza was very good.

Perfect.

If they charged $15 for a large two topping pizza. Not $23. At that price I expect to be left needing to grab the nearest sketchy stranger on Muni and profess my love for Little Star. Wasn't inspired to do that. Not even close.

Good. And overpriced.
author: Jason B.

description: This is my, and my boyfriend's favorite place in the world to eat.  Every time one or both of us are in the city, we have to get a pizza.  Yesterday, I was in town for SF Sketchfest, and my boyfriend was stuck at home.  The show got out 20 minutes before closing, and we were across town.  I called and placed a to-go order, and they said it was totally fine.  They let me in 5 minutes after closing to pick up my order and were still super nice.  Bringing my boyfriend's favorite food home made his night.  We always order the deep dish pepperoni pizza on a cornmeal crust.  If you value your happiness, you will go to Little Star and order this beast of a pizza.
author: Jennie W.

description: My favorite deep dish pizza in the city. Tip, you'll have to wait to be seated even if your party has a driver looking for parking. Ps parking sucks, no fault of Little Star Pizza just the neighborhood itself.
author: Josie C.

description:
First off, have to say I was never a big deep dish fan. However, the reviews looked good so decided to give it a shot.

Let me tell you, this place changed my mind about deep dish---makes me wonder, maybe I was eating at all the wrong places before, which gave deep dish a bad name for me.

We ordered the Little Star deep dish with sausage (upon recommendation by the bar tender who was super nice) and was not disappointed.  In fact, I really enjoyed it.  The ingredients were well balanced---tomato wasn't too acidic, cheese was the right amount, and the spinach and sausage went well together. Best part was the crust was crispy at the bottom, and wasn't doughy or soggy like some deep dish pizzas can get.

Would I go back? Yes.  However, next time I'm bringing my own honey (which they didn't have) to go on my cornmeal crust... If u haven't tried it, it's delicious!!!!!
author: Miyuki I.

description:
The deep dish pizza at Little Star is fabulous-- the buttery cornmeal crust is what makes it truly standout in comparison to other pies. 

The ambiance of this location fits the vibe of the Mission quite well-- artsy, dimly lit, and packed with loyal fans. 

My friend and I ended up ordering  a small deep dish, which is the perfect size for two  hungry people. The garlic bread is tasty-- served with a whole head of roasted garlic which you can rub on your bread with butter.
author: Leslie T.

description:
I love pizza.  Being from the east coast, I have an expectation of what is the best pizza. Going to a fancy restaurant to have pizza is not important.  My favorite pizza in New York and Philadelphia are little places where you order pizza slices to go or call in and have it delivered to your home.  Little Star is one of the few sit down pizza restaurants that serves pizza I would recommend out here on the west coast. 
I do not like most of the pizza places I have tried in San Francisco, but Little Star and Arinell's are an exception because their pizzas are similar to east coast pizza in appearance and taste..
author: Georgefromsf G.

description:
Garlic bread = warm bread that you put melted butter on yourself and then smear some roasted garlic on top
Pizza = Ok, but for a deep dish it's not anything fantastic and there is way too much cornmeal on the crust
Service = horrible, we waited for 15 minutes after being seated before anyone even approached us and it took 20 minutes to receive the "garlic bread"
author: Lidia L.

description: I've never had a disappointing meal at Little Star and it always blows me away.  I love that you can order a deep dish pizza with whatever toppings (or in this case inside toppings) and we always do that and are always pleased.  Keep up the great work Little Star.  If you're looking to sit down here, make sure you get there early and with your entire party otherwise they won't sit you and the wait can be long but it's worth it.
author: Blake B.

description: Sorry, not in a million toppings better than Patxi's. (Not enough marinara sauce)
author: Hector M.

description: Cute little pizzeria with dim lights and cozy atmosphere. The deep dish pizzas are great and personal sized. Wings here are amazing too. Full of flavor and just the right amount of spice. I might have enjoyed the wings more than the pizza!
author: Winnie T.

description:
We came here once before and they were closed! This time we came, and was even more eager to try their pizza! From the outside, I wouldn't have known that this place was super packed! Service was nice and prompt.  Pizza was good! We tried the deep dish: Little Star, the Special (Apples, Chicken, BBQ sauce), and the Spinach Pizza.
The Little Star had sausage -- I liked the sausage at Zachary's better, it was more flavorful there.  The Special was interesting, and sweet, which wasn't really my preference for pizza.  The pizza containing spinach was my fav! Yummy!

Chocolate mint gelato, which the waitress kindly offered us ... yumm!

Overall, this place was good! I don't know why, but I do believe Zachary's tastes better (with more cheese and toppings).  The crust is better there also!

If I'm in SF, I def wouldn't mind swinging by here though!
author: Tramy V.

description:
Came here with my girlfriend  and had the "Little Star" deep dish pizza between the two of us.

Taste 4/5:
Pretty good. There's not many deep dish pizza places around the Bay and let alone a decent one. However, I would have to rate this below Zachary's. Trying Patxi's next month and will change my ratings accordingly.

Extras:
While I would have given the taste a 4, but the entire experience was a 2. On our bill, we were charged a fee called "Healthcare Surcharge". We asked our server what that was, 1) he wasn't able to answer it fully to our understanding, he seemed nervous about it 2) from what we could make of it, it seems to be a health charge that  they have to pay their employees mandated by the city. That's fine and dandy but I went to Candy Bar down the street and did not have the same charge. If they only have this mandate for pizza places, I will eat my words and change my ratings.
author: Tony L.

description:
I am tempted to drop their rating from 5 to 4 stars due to their change with the garlic bread but that would be unfair.. But come on Little Star! Bring back the garlic bread with real garlic cloves.. That was a genius appetizer and awesome conversation started for the unique way it is delivered. 

Anyways, the deep dish pizza is spectacular - Little Star is competing against many great pizza spots in San Francisco. I believe they offer the best pizza and deep dish pizza for a sit down restaurant in the city, beating out Goat Hil and Paxti's. When it comes to best overall pizza in San Francisco, well that crown goes to... you decide!
author: Spencer R.

description: The pizza was so good. We had a thin crust Italian pizza and a thick crust veggie. To find both a great thin and thick crust in the same restaurant is a find in itself. Also, the service was very good as was the value. And it was very kid friendly, as we had a tired pre-schooler in our group. :)
author: Karen J.

description:
The restaurant itself is nothing impressive. The bathroom (there's only one) toilet was stopped up when my husband used it and one of the waitresses kept eyeing him as if he stopped it up from peeing in it. There were at least 5 waitresses there; none were very attentive or pleasant.

But on to the good part...our friend had tipped us off to order the Brass Monkey, and told us we wouldn't see it on the menu. Turns out it's the Little Star pizza with sausage added to it, and it was delicious! Worth a taste if you're in the neighborhood.
author: L. M.

description:
I came here on a Thursday night and man, was it crowded! I was with one other person, and when I went to the front, I was greeted by a big smile and I asked how long the wait would be, thinking he would say 45 minutes. He asked how many people I have, and I said 2. They had a table ready for 2 at that moment, score! 

My friend does not eat meat nor garlic/onion. So we ordered the thin crust tomato pizza with fresh mozzarella, and basil (our idea of a Pizza Margherita). It was phenomenal. Super fresh, the tomato sauce was tangy yet not too much so, and they were generous with the basil. The service was 5 stars. We wanted to watch a movie at the Roxie in 40 minutes, so we told the waitress we were going to a movie soon and would like to order asap. She took our order and the pizza was out within 10 minutes. The wine was so-so (I ordered the Malbec). We also asked for bread/olive oil/balsamic vinegar and the bread was super warm! And it seemed like they toasted it, not just warmed it up in the microwave. 

I will be coming back fo sho.
author: Monica A.

description: Don't ever order pick up from them unless you want to wait around 3 hours or they will tell you you never receive your order online
author: Eddie H.

description: Really fantastic pizza - it's super thick and the crust is really good.  It's definitely one of the best pizza places in San Francisco.  If you eat in it can take a while for the pizza to be ready so it's a good idea to call in the order then when you pick it up they can convert it to dine-in.
author: Jason E.

description:
Caveat: I've only dined in here once. I remember the service and ambiance and whatnot as being fine, but to be honest, I don't remember that particular experience very well. Instead, since I have a friend that lives just around the corner, we usually just get take-out.

So: what about the main event--the pizza? Now, I could wax philosophical about pizza for a *long* time; but unfortunately, Yelp imposes a character limit on these dang reviews. So I'll have to keep things pretty succinct.

Suffice it to say that the pizza is great. We usually get the deep dish classic when we come here, which I believe has sausage, mushroom, and peppers. There may be some other stuff in it. It doesn't matter too much. It's sloppy and full of cheese and sauce and is a pleasure to consume.

The crust is maybe the most remarkable part: crunch and crispy but not tough at all. I can't think of another pizza I've had with a crust quite like it. Tasty and distinctive.

Qualitatively, it's not entirely dissimilar to the deep dish I had in Chicago when I was growing up--although it's also not quite the same. But I don't really care whether or not it fits cleanly into one of my conceptual boxes. The only boxes my pizzas need to come in are flat cardboard ones that usually have some kind of map of Italy on the top.

I haven't had the thin crust here, so I can't say anything about it.
author: Greg P.

description: Tried the mixed salad and the vegetarian deep dish. Both were well done. Service was gracious. Tables were really close to each other though.
author: Debbie Chiou S.

description:
#grilledgarlicbread
#loadedpizza
*read the reviews, eat the food, it's worth it*

So after a few drinks around town we ended up at Little Star for dinner. Great attentive service and as soon as our full party was there we were seated. I'm not the biggest deep dish fan, but this was exceptional, and in a good way at that. First things first though, GARLIC BREAD. Served with a warm loaf, an entire grilled garlic bulb, and some of the best better I have ever had. I could've eaten that alone the rest of the night, and my fat ass even dipped the pizza crust in the butter. 

There wings were also great as far as wings go. But the pizza...crispy crust, not too doughy, yeasty, and a heaving of toppings that tasted fresh. A side of anchovies and I don't think I breathed until i downed 2 slices. Great place, friendly atmosphere, and a quick SF favorite already. Affordable as well.
author: Kevin T.

description:
We were a group of 6. We ordered 2 medium sized pizzas (one thin crust and one deep dish), garlic bread, and chicken wings. I ordered Black Cherry Soda which wound be being nice to wash down the deep dish pizza slices with. I enjoy eating the deep dish pizza as the crust had this taste to it like the sweet stuff they put on pretzel (for a lack of a better description). Delicious. 

I wish I could make my rating to 3.5 stars though. 30 minutes to get some of the food out? On a Sunday afternoon and it wasn't busy at all inside. It seemed like the people who came before us got their food faster than us. I guess I can give them 1/2 star back for the excellent choices on the jukebox. An eclectic mixture of funk, indie, punk, underground hip-hop, and everything in between.
author: Gerard Y.

description: I am not usually surprised by restaurants and food but this place was a very pleasant surprise. Their pizzas are quite unique. They come on a thick sour dough base and is topped with a highly reduced tomato sauce and various other toppings of your choice. We had the brass monkey off the secret menu. Sensational, and that's saying something for someone who doesn't really like pizzas.
author: May C.

description: Went for lunch on the Friday before New year's.  Service was quick.   We ordered the classic deep dish and garlic bread.  The garlic bread arrived in DIY style, with several slices of bread, a large amount of butter and two heads of roasted garlic.  Probably the best garlic bread I have had at restaurant.  The cornmeal crust on the pizza was as yummy as i had expected.  The amount of toppings were both overwhelming and amazing.
author: Jennifer L.

description: This is a tomato and vegetable stew.  It isn't pizza but its delicious.
author: Rocco B.

description: First time visiting. Recently moved here from Chicago & a friend recommended. Had the artichoke, ricotta, & garlic thin crust pizza....soooo good!! Service was fast & friendly, good beer on tap although not too big of a selection. Great music too!! Loved it will definitely be back.
author: Suzy S.

description:
Me and my friend were looking for a trendy place to eat and good food.  Walking by Little Star we decided to check it out.
The first time I ate here was really good, the food and service. As well as this time.  I am server too so I know sometimes the place gets crazy busy.  Our server had an attitude and wasn't friendly at all.  She came to our table only once to check on us.  I was drinking a glass of wine and she never came back to ask if I wanted another one. At the end I needed to ask for the desert menu because she didn't seem very interested to bring to us.

After all, we had a good time, good food but not a very nice nor friendly service!
author: Jonas J.

description: I would categorize this pizza as lame. I've had cold pizza from BJ's better than this.
author: Harry V.

description: Delicious signature deep dish pizza!!  With great SF ambiance for this cozy restaurant.
author: Katherine R.

description: I don't really get the fascination with this place. The food was just okay. We ordered the green goddess salad, and that was good. Then we ordered a deep dish pizza with ricotta, sausage and basil. The basil should be whole, not all shredded so you can't even taste it. The dough of the pizza itself tasted good, but it was very hard and overcooked. I won't be back.
author: Faith C.

description:
YUM.

Deep Dish pizza in a classy kind of upscale looking interior. Came here with the boy and one of his friends from college.

They ordered the Spicy Chicken Wings to share (which they got me to try, and were tolerable my little "spicy intolerant" me.). We also ordered the Large Classic Deep Dish which comes with sausage, mushrooms, onions, and green peppers. 

Between the three of us I think we did pretty good (especially with an appetizer!-- and beer for them), but we did end up having to take a slice home. 

Not that we were complaining. The boy and I ate it for lunch the next day and it was just as delicious. 

Our waiter was SUPER nice, and gave us great service! I wish I had remembered his name so i could give him a shoutout here!
author: Jessica Q.

description:
C A R B A L I C I O U S!

With only a 5 minutes wait last night *note Mondays are not busy*  A friend and I split a small (though big) delicious mixed green salad to start  followed by the Mediterranean chicken deep dish.  The thin is good too (especialy the white pie) but the deep corn crust is the only proper way to introduce a newbie to Little Star. AND one must get the pesto dressing to dip in.  But that's only if you can handle garlic.

Damn oh Damn, I just can't understand why some people eliminate carbs from their world.  That would be my definition of hell on earth.
Little star is an absolutely terrible place if you are concerned with calories.  :)  If you are, definitely skip this joint and nosh on your iceberg lettuce diet.

Like it matters but I still like the Divis location better, maybe because I've been there so many more times.

So Oakland has Zach's and yes it's amazing but SF has Little Star and it's pretty fkucing amazing too.

Yum,
ME
author: Athena S.

description:
I've had the deep dish at both locations.  They are pretty good but cornmeal crust is not a Chicago thing as one writer summized.  There is one place that uses it (in Chicago).  My favorite Chicago pizza is Lou Malnati's that offers a regular (flour) or a choice of their (non-cornmeal) buttercrust.  The buttercrust is the best..... anyway, if you haven't already guessed, I'm recommending that Little Star offer an alternative crust choice.  As you can see, my choice would be a flour-based buttercrust. Also it could use just a bit more in toppings for the price$.

Please Little Star; listen to these reviews!!!
author: Jeff W.

description:
CORNMEAL CRUST. YES PLEASE.

I usually HATE crust, I always let my husband eat it...not at Little Star....

SO GOOD.
author: Nikki W.

description: Best deep dish in the city..  everyone complains about the  service???   I say fuck the staff Im there for a deep dish to go .  This Pizza is off the hook .   Loves the wings. This is where i get my deep dish fix .
author: Joe B.

description:
Five stars for one of the best things I've had in my life. I've had Zachary's in Berkeley (awesome), I've had Lou Malnati's in Chicago (awesomer) and now I've had Little Star in SF and it was better than both of those!

We ordered the Little Star pizza, their namesake. This pie is seriously delicious. It was just myself and another friend the night we visited, so we opted for the small Little Star pizza with sausage (as recommended my our fantastic waiter). Unlike Zachary's, there isn't an overabundance in sauce, so you really do get to taste the spinach, the ricotta, and the sausage and all the other amazing toppings in there. Crust is as good as everyone says! (and not soggy the next day like at other places)

We also got the garlic bread appetizer, which is a good holdover if you're starving and waiting the 20 minutes for the pizza, but nothing extraordinary. The melted butter/olive oil mixture that I thought was brie (and thus consumed as if it were cheese and not a vat of fat) is pretty addictive.

Our total was really reasonable, around $32 for the small pizza and garlic bread. I loved the service, loved the vibe, and will definitely come back.
author: Shira C.

description: The BF and I came here for dinner during the Labor Day weekend.  The city seemed exceptionally quiet so we chanced it and drove knowing full well we may not be able to find a parking spot.  But with the pizza gods smiling down on us, we struck parking gold!  We walked two short blocks and BAM!  We were at Little Star.  The restaurant was fairly busy, but we were seated within 5 minutes (and a window table no less) We ordered a bottle of red and each of us started with a salad,  Caprese for me and some type of blue cheese concoction for the mister.  They were very good.  On to the pizza!  We ordered a small pepperoni and spinach deep dish and it was great.  Paxi's and Little Star are pretty much at a tie when it comes to the deep dish thing.  We ended with a salted chocolate chip cookie with ice cream on top (delish)  The service was great and love this place!  I am thinking the experience may have been a little different had it not  been a holiday weekend, but we are glad we went.
author: Denny R.

description:
I would like to have a dinner at Little Star but a lunch at Paxi's so I can get a back to back comparison (*note: this is one of those, sounds good in theory but might get sick ideas). Both places have fabulous Chicago styled deep dish pizzas and pretty awesome & creative salads. Both cost about the same.

I dream of Little Star's Goddess Salad with the creamy pesto dressing, so worthy. Also I must mention the crust at Little Star, oh my the crust is buttery and yet crisp. Let me repeat, the common theme: crispy yet buttery deep dish pizza crust ( swoon ). Parking is better in the Mission location.
author: Shannon Z.

description: Delicious pizza, deep dish and thin crust. They are so friendly when we showed up with 8 hungry people. We put our order in and right when we sat down they brought our pizza. It's pretty inexpensive which is always nice. I would definitely recommend this place
author: Rachel M.

description: First time there with a couple of friends and it was a fantastic place! While waiting to be seated the bartender was super sweet, the host and our waiter were just the best. Everyone there was great along with great service! Not to mention the food was perfection! Great place to go(:
author: Kate O.

description:
How did I forget to review this Little Star? I've been here many times over the years and it continues to be my favorite pizza in the city.

Their deep dish is solid and I do enjoy the hipster scene up in here. As you might expect, their jukebox is as carefully curated as their beer list... have a hankering for a PBR? Scrounge $2.50 and you're all set.

Last night I had their white pizza (thin crust), pretty good but could have used more of those tasty tomato slices. Service is pretty reliable and a while ago they ditched their cash only policy, which is much appreciated. They don't take rezzies so there is always a decent wait, though if you go early in the week it probably won't be more than 30 mins.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
I love Little Star Pizza!!! But...I had a not so pleasant experience there last Saturday. I ordered a pizza for my co workers and stopped in on my way to work. Unfortunately there was a problem with my order and the person who took it via phone forgot to take my number so they had no way to inform me. I wish that was the worst of the experience, but I showed up, gave my name and still wasn't informed. I stood there for a good 20-30 minutes and nothing. Sucks, right? 

They were pretty busy, but I finally had to ask what was up, as I was already late for work. The young lady serving beer and wine checked and upon return it was clear something was wrong. A gentleman I took to be the manager on duty informed me of the breakdown in communication and complied when I requested a refund. But there is an upside to the situation. The young lady I'd previously spoke to came around the counter, took my order again and told me she'd like to hand deliver my order at no charge.

It takes one good person to change a bad experience. Because of her actions I will continue to give my business to Little Star Pizza. With that said, always request fresh mozzarella on top of your deep dish pizza. It enhances the experience.
author: Drew G.

description:
Wonderful atmosphere, not bad for a part of town that I used to be afraid to park my car in and got mugged at 12 years ago, way to usher in this new environment to the hood. We went early at 6pm to beat the rush, folks from the neighborhood were in their with their screaming children, so maybe being there at the rush wouldn't have been such a been such a bad idea. 

Our waitress mentioned a delicious sounding pizza of the day with prosciutto and heirloom tomatoes, but advised it would be better on a thin crust. (Love a waitstaff with an honest opinion) I was dying to try their deep dish so I stuck with my instincts but have to say I will definitely be back to try the thin crust we settled on one of the gorgeous salads paired with the Mediterranean Deep dish pizza, a draft IPA to wash it down and I loved everything. 

A well deserved welcome to the Mission for this place!
author: B H.

description: 1 star because I cannot give any less. This place reeks attitude starting with the host/ess insisting on everyone being present prior to being seated, having the 5 of us squeezing at a table for 4 because they did not want to waste 1 seat (meanwhile plenty of parties of 3 at table for 4), and flippant service all along... I quote our waiter "Welcome to SF" after I mentioned I had more space in coach this afternoon flying from Europe.  The food? I was so disgusted by the overall behavior that I instantly lost my appetite.
author: Ceredic G.

description:
Let me start with admitting that I feel like I owe this place another try because clearly the other reviews are pretty stellar.... but, I just was a bit underwhelmed by this place when I went.  

I live nearby and had tried to come eat in the restaurant 2-3 times and every time there was "an hour to hour and a half" wait.... twice I came on Thursday nights... really? And they don't take reservations? Ugh. 

So finally we decided to just do take out so we could finally experience te hype of Little Star Pizza. They're daily specials are pretty rad and usually worth going for since I think they do put effort into thinking what might be good to feature. We got a medium pizza and it easily fed two (very hungry) 20-somethings. The crust was very good, but pretty crunchy. The toppings were not overdone or too sparse and certainly added a lot of flavor.  

We also got garlic bread to go - it was literally a loaf of bread with a clove of garlic on the side.... um, what? Forgive me if I'm overlooking some impressive preparation that was not immediately obvious, but seriously? Not worth it... The garlic wasn't even roasted enough to spread. Oh well.. we got a loaf of bread out of it. 

Lastly (please no threats).... Delfina is better. Sorry. If you're looking for great *THIN CRUST* pizza, go to Delfina.  The deep dish at Little Star does look awesome so I won't make any sweeping statements about deep dish... but overall, Delfina triumphs in the pizza arena.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
I am giving this 5 stars because I would give Zachary's 4 stars.

Thin crust was super crispy, just the way I like it. I ate all of the crust!

Deep dish crust was also very crispy, we got the smaller size so it probably helped with the sogginess that usually comes with deep dish pizzas. I liked the fact that you were not confined to eating your deep dish pizza on a plate (what I do at Zachary's). We got the classic and added chicken which was PERFECT because there was a good veggies to meat ratio. 

Garlic bread was very unique and a great starter.

Can't wait to go again!!!
author: Anna H.

description:
Tough choices doesn't have to be hard here. Rather you are a fan of New York or Chicago pizza, they got your back here.

Pretty good pizza here, good vegetarian options as well. but you should get some salad here as well, not your usual garden variety. 

Service is good, a few good local beet on tap. 

My biggest complain? Noise! We had to lean in and yell since that's what everyone else are doing. If you have big party, good luck talking to that guy at the other end of the table, it might be easier to text each other.
author: Alice C.

description:
It's good... real good. The masses do not lie. If I were less of a pizza aficionado, I might have given this place a five star rating.

Five of us split two pizzas, one deep dish, one thin crust (more than enough food). I thought both we're delicious. The Classic deep dish wasn't too doughy; it had a nice crisp to it. The thin crust was uber cheesy, but in a good way. All the toppings were combined perfectly. 

Be prepared, we waited about an hour, which was to be expected on a weekend night at prime time. There are a couple bars near by to help with the wait.

This is definitely a place everyone should try, and although Little Star is known for deep dish, be sure to throw a thin crust into your trial mix - you won't regret it.
author: Glenn G.

description:
The quest for the best pizza in SF continues....

Food:    Well, I completely fell in love with Little Star..We got The Classic and The Little Star with Pesto....Seriously unreal.  As you've probably read in other reviews, their cornmeal crust is out of this world. The quality of their cheese and toppings can't be topped. The pesto drizzle (or whatever you want to call it) on top of the pizza is different than what I've experienced elsewhere, but it works very well. Couldn't have asked for a better pizza.

Service:    Everything went smoothly. Hostess said it would be a 45 minute wait...got a few beers, and it ended up being closer to 25 minutes...Waitress was quick and to the point. The "no ranch" was annoying but whatever; I shouldn't even be dipping my pizza in ranch anyways, so it's all good.


Overall: I've had Deep Dish pizza in Chicago, and this competes with it. Also, I finally found a deep dish spot in the city that's up to par with Zach's in Berkeley; it might even be a tiny bit better. Of all the pizza spots I've tried in the City, I only have random dreams of two; Tony's and Little Star. Yes, I dream of pizza at times...don't judge.
author: Farbod D.

description: My first time trying this place. And I LOVE it! The staff is fast and friendly. It's a bit dim inside but I kinda liked that about it. The pizza was amazing. I had a vegetarian thin crust artichoke, with tomatoes and mushrooms. My friend got pepperoni on his half. We ate all of it!
author: Karina R.

description:
I really enjoy Little Star Pizza and I usually go to the Western Addition location since it's closer but I would have to say that I much prefer this Mission location. Not because it's in the Mission (which isn't my favorite neighborhood) but because the wait is usually shorter and their restaurant has windows which really make the place less stuffy and more airy. Also, I like that the place has an actual waiting area instead of having to eat my dinner with peoples butts always bumping into our table from the people all squeezing into the small waiting area in the Western Addition location.

In short, this place has great pizza just like the other location and if it were closer to my house, I'd be slightly happier seeing as that I prefer the actual dining room at the Mission location.
author: Rylan C.

description:
A solid 4 stars for me. 

We went early-ish on a Sunday so there was no wait. Our server, Ian, was fantastic. 

We started with a caprese salad which was done to perfection. The proportion of tomato to basil to mozzerella was just right. 

We then shared a large Little Star pizza. The consistancy of their cornmeal crust is definitely different compared to normal crust, but not in a bad way. 

The only reason I can't give them 5 stars is the deepness of the "deep dish". It's not quite deep enough for my satisfaction.
author: Sara P.

description:
The crust is the worst part about this pizza. It tasted like cardboard.
The wait is horrendous.
The place is dark and cramped.

I was so excited to try another deep dish find, but it did not live up to my palate's expectations.

I think there was way too much sauce and not 'toppings'  to balance it out.

All sauce and crust.

I want some meat people!
author: Jo M.

description:
What can I say?  Have I had better pizza before?  Most certainly, yes.  But this is not about comparing Little Star to other pizzerias in New York or Italy... it's more like giving them the credit they are due!

I totally love it every time I come here.  The location on Valencia is hard to find and that adds to the allure.  It's difficult to park, it's a small place so the wait is always quite long.  But I'd rather wait a bit for a table for some great pizza than be seated right away to enjoy some mediocre fare.  That's just how I am - your mileage may vary!

A little bar area makes the waiting even more effortless and enjoyable though they only serve beer and wine.

I loved their thin crust pizzas, the regular crust pizzas and actually enjoyed the deep dish pizza.  I must clarify.  As an ex New Yorker, I have the obviously natural tendency to hate everything that's not like New York.  Chicago pizza is and will always be an abomination to me.  Oh, I eat it, but usually with annoying derogatory comments about how this could never stack up to a beautiful thin slice of New York's finest that you can fold and eat... ahhhhhhh...  but, I digress.

So, I did enjoy the deep dish at Little Star, but never more than one slice... mostly for the interesting crunchy corn meal encrusted crust.  But the other offerings are simply amazing... creative toppings (gorgonzola cheese - YES!!!!!!), artichokes sometimes, the usual vegetable medley, perhaps some goat cheese and spinach - you name it, they have it.  

Good appetizer selection though I must ask... WHY????  Wait for the pizza ladies and gentlemen, it is worth it.  Do NOT spoil your appetite with chicken wings or other little nibbles.

Again, beer and wine are available should you choose to indulge in an adult beverage.

Prices are quite reasonable considering the obvious popularity of the restaurant.  I wish they took reservations, even if it was only for tables of 4 or smaller.  But then, that would take the fun out of waiting for a table, wouldn't it?  ;)

~ 5 stars overall for good ambiance, a cozy setting, fun staff, decent prices and drinks and absolutely delicious pizza!  I can't wait to be back here :)

# 242
author: Badri N.

description: Best deep dish in the city!! Always love getting the spinach and mushroom and the sausage one. The small is great to share with another person.
author: Penny C.

description: As I write this review I imagine eating a sweet succulent piece of Little Star Pizza's pizza. I had the deep dish Little Star Pizza and I'm pretty sure my life has been changed forever. My pizza standards know no boundaries now as Little Star Pizza sits at the top. I highly recommend this shop to anyone with taste buds. You will not be disappointed and you will probably want this pizza at your wedding if you're not married yet. The customer service was fantastic as well. I cried tears of happiness after a long walk through San Francisco and having my stomach needs fulfilled. Thank you Little Star Pizza.
author: Danielle V.

description:
I've been to Chicago...and damnit...their deep dish is an absolute hit. I've seen the deep dish attempted and rarely duplicated....until....

Who knew deep dish could be done properly SF? The cornmeal dusting on the crust is killer and sets this pie apart. Full and heavy with toppings and flavors-I weanied  out and only had a slice....but had plenty to take home! Don't sleep on their thin crusts, either. They are just as good but if you want my recommendation-go deep dish all the way, baby! 

My friend and I went on a Sunday night. It was pretty packed and we had to squeeze in at the bar and waited about 15 minutes until we were seated. Great selection of beers on tap--great place to grub---loud and the energy in this joint is magnetic. 

Soooo many great places in the city to grab a great slice, from hole in the walls to hipster havens... Little Star should make it on your go to list!
author: Shy A.

description:
Bad service, cramped seating, mediocre pizza, clueless management.

I found this place to be mind-blowingly bad.  I have no idea how it has a 4-star rating on yelp.  The service was bad, the seating arrangement was just plain stupid, the pizza wasn't worth the price, and the wine list sucked.  I guess that sums it up.

My friend and I tried to call ahead and order a pizza which we might then eat at the restaurant.  We were told that we could order takeout, but we absolutely could not eat it there--meaning that if we wanted to eat there, we would have to show up, get a table, order, then wait (even if I paid in advance with a credit card).  I have *never* had a restaurant that offers takeout tell me I couldn't order ahead then eat it there, and I have done this at many, many restaurants (seriously, what are they thinking?).

We theorized that perhaps the place was packed and they wanted to be sure they would have a table for us, but when we arrived the restaurant was mostly empty.  They then proceeded to place us at a table right next to another pair of people dining, even though the table right next to it was empty (the people next to us seemed equally surprised at this ridiculous notion).  We just quietly took it upon ourselves to slide over to the next table over without asking why in the world they would do that in a mostly empty restaurant--have they no consideration for conversational noise and privacy?.  To make it worse, this table was one of many that was up against a wall with a long bench.  They have the tables packed so tightly together that the waiter had to *literally* move the table out of the way so that I could get to the bench seat on the wall side of the table.  He had to do this for everybody else who came in while we were there, and again when we were leaving.  The place was never more than half full, and this was during dinner time, so I don't see why they wouldn't remove one 2-person table from the row of ten so that diners could get in and out of their seat (seriously, again, what are they thinking?).

As for the pizza.... we ordered the deep dish 'classic' with a cornmeal crust.  It was alright, but nowhere as good as Zachary's or Patxi's, and also not as large for the same price.  Oh, and their short wine list had nothing but wines from other countries like Chile and Australia.  Since I live in California, I don't want to buy wine that was shipped thousands of miles to reach my table, so I just passed on getting a glass, even though I wanted one.  Seriously, no California wines?
author: Jason F.

description: Best pizza in the Bay! Pesto chicken is where it's at! Though the deep dish meatball one is also delicious.
author: Kairina P.

description:
Deep dish pizza + football = perfect Sunday.

I ordered half Classic & Little Star large deep dish pizza for dinner. And boy am I sataisfed?! I called in around 5ish and took about 30 minutes for the pizza to be ready. The Valencia location is pretty easy to find -- between 15th and 16th Valencia in the corner. The crust was perfectly made and crunchy. Classic was ok but I prefer the Little Star because the balance of cheese and garlic = yummy.
author: Carol Y.

description: Always great pizza, but they need to Bring back the PABST BLUE RIBBON BEER!!!!!   (or equivalent)
author: O. S.

description:
Wanted Delfina, but Delfina was twenty deep out the door.

How can you screw up pizza?  Cornmeal crust, chicken, artichoke hearts, feta cheese, red bells, tomato sauce...  super tasty.  Food coma inducing.  Delicious as breakfast.

Little gem Goddess Salad was pretty good.  Would have preferred a little more dressing and I'm not sure almonds were the best complement ever, but whatevs, they mostly fell to the bottom of the plate anyways.

They have Racer 5 IPA.  And paper straws.  Good enough for me!
author: Sandy T.

description:
If you love deep-dish pizza, definitely check out this place! 

Came here with two friends on a Friday night at around 6:30 p.m. and was told that it'd be a 30 minute wait. We were down to wait since I've heard such great things about this place. However, two tables before us didn't show and the host was extremely cool and gave us the table! Literally waited 5 minutes-- I knew I would like this place already.

The restaurant has a very warm and cozy vibe-- I'd definitely recommend it with a group of friends or a date night! We started off with the spicy chicken wings. The chicken wings were good but the blue cheese dressing was AMAZING. Never had blue cheese as a dressing-- I've been missing out my whole life!

The Little Star pizza + sausage = Brass Monkey (not on the menu; found out from fellow Yelp reviewers, thanks guys!) Absolutely delicious. The best part? The roasted garlic. If you love garlic as much as I do, you'll definitely appreciate it in the pizza- really makes a difference! 

Little Star vs. Zachary's? Gotta say Little Star, especially since LS has that amazing, light, fluffy crust!
author: Allison S.

description:
Pizza and champagne cocktails.

It would be "low-brow meets high-brow" if the pizza weren't so damn gourmet. As presented, however, it was a great combination. 

This little spot is a total hidden gem. Aside from the small, nondescript sign hanging outside, the corner space in this dirty exterior looks abandoned.  Once inside, you find a cozy, dark, somewhat upscale spot with a hip vibe and some amazing smells. The area is small, but not too cramped. 

The menu offers some salads and a few choices each of some deep dish and thin crust pizzas. They're offered in 2 sizes, 9" and 12". The offerings are pretty gourmet, and they are more than willing to make half-and-halfs if you like some variety. 

The deep dish pizza has a pretty decent crust... surprisingly thin for deep dish, The toppings are pretty generous but not overwhelming, and they put the tomatoes on top of the rest of the toppings. The 'za is impressively tasty, not too greasy, and, well, hard to stop eating. 

The lack of liquor would be a bummer if the champagne cocktails (served unpretentiously in a high-ball glass over ice with a straw) were not so damn good. I sampled one with ginger beer (amazing) and one with pomegranite juice (a little heavy on the pom).  Both would make amazing sun-time drinks poolside, and go down way too easy. 

Met the owner, and he was more than nice. Welcoming and genuine, he was just as unpretentious as his restaurant, the food, and the service. 

All and all, a great pizza, a great champagne cocktail, and great experience.
author: Don B.

description: This is my favorite pizza in San Francisco. I live in Los Angeles but when I visit my friends in San Francisco, 2 or 3 times a year, this place is always in my top 5. Get the Little Star deep dish pizza. The crunchy crust is perfection, the tomatoes are a perfect balance of sweet and acidic and the amount of spinach and mozzarella is perfect as well. The small has 6 hearty slices so that with a large mixed salad is good to feed 2-3 people. The sourdough bread with the blow your mind roasted garlic is also crazy good. Do it!!!
author: Robyn R.

description:
Deep dish pizza? Look no further: we tried the Little Star Deep Dish: spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, garlic and onions. It was expertly made: the crust was crispy yet soft inside and the filling was fresh and tasty, I love the combination of ricotta and feta cheese. 

For our second pizza, we choose a cheese pizza with our own toppings: artichoke hearts, red onions and basil. Yes we had a vegetarian meal and it was mighty delicious! 

Our appetizer was Little Star's garlic bread: Warm sourdough served with a blend of butter & extra virgin olive oil and a bulb of roasted garlic 

Service was warm and friendly, quick and efficient. The pizzas came out pretty fast and were nice and hot! 

Nice decor: I like the bricks on the walls, the artwork and splashes of color and lights. 
Definitely want to return and try more items on the menu!
author: Evangeline W.

description: Holy deep dish! Visiting San Francisco and my friends took me to this place because I'm from Chicago, so deep dish is obviously a favorite. But, this place was tied with my favorite deep dish place in Chicago, which is literally amazing. The little star deep dish was amazingggg! Literally drool worthy.  Definitely don't miss out on this place!
author: Genie B.

description:
This pizza was awesome, rarely do I ever eat three slices of pizza without this over whelming feeling of guilt. This pizza was way too good to feel that way, if anything I was very satisfied.

I had a classic deep dish, it was perfect. I was starting to miss Zachary's in Berkeley, but I found a fair rival here in my home town. 

I've also had the Brass Monkey, which is on the menu as a Little Star Pizza with Sausage. I had to try this as it is one of the items on the "The big eat SF: 100 things to try before you die". http://www.7x7.com/content/eat-drink/big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die

I can't wait to try more pizzas from Little Star.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
Mmmm! I'm drooling! I've never been here, nor had I ever had a deep dish pizza with this amazing crust! It's not like ... uh, what's that place? Oh yeah... Zachary's. I don't like Zachary's so when I went here, I didn't expect much but when I took a lovely bite of cornmeal deep dished Little Star's "Little Star"... 
O
M
G
!
I fell in love. I absolutely HAD to get it again that week! Mmm! I love this pizza. Now, onto other aspects of this location... The service wasn't very good - stuck up servers always in a rush b/c this place is packed, loud, busy. Would I go here again? I'd try not to... luckily, there's one up the street! YAY!
author: Mayana P.

description: I had never really eaten a deep dish pizza (that stuff at Pizza Hut when I was a kid does not count). The crust on Little Star's pizza is to die for. To light and flaky! I thought there was a little too much tomato sauce and I would have liked to have more toppings, but overall it was a nice experience!
author: Jennifer P.

description: You can't be disappointed with this place. Really great deep dish pizzas, the ingredients are always fresh. It is a great way to feed a crowd for not much money
author: Thibaut L.

description:
After reading all of my Yelp friend's review of Little Star I knew I had to come check this place out after our first outing to the Academy of Science.

We opted to come to this location as the weather was a warm high 70's in San Francisco and we were planning to go to Mitchell's Ice Cream after.  We arrive a little after 4pm and were seated immediately.  The wait staff was very friendly and service was on par.  We ordered the spring mixed salad and a large mushroom, spinach and sausage pizza.  Our small salad was more than enough for two adults so we decided to split it and it was just the right amount.  The salad was very refreshing on such a warm day however I thought there was a tad bit too much oil in the dressing and it completely coated my lips every time I took a bite.  

Shortly after, our pizza arrived.  The corn meal crust was a perfect golden brown and our pizza came out piping hot.  We dug in and it was very good.  I loved the fact that the corn meal crust gave the pizza structure where you could actually eat the pizza with your hands vs. using a fork and knife.
