The tomato sauce was not too tart and had a good balance of spinach, mushroom and sausage.

Over great pizza and great service.  Definitely will be back!
author: Henry S.

description:
YAY I am definitely a fan of Little Star Pizza. I usually am not a big fan of deep dish pizza because a lot of other times I've had it its been very soggy on the bottom, but Little Star makes their pizza to perfection! The crust was perfect and not doughy. 

We did a half/half and had a Classic (typical sausage, mushrooms, bell peppers, & onions) and the Little Star (bunch of cheeses and spinach, how can you not get a pizza named after the restaurant). The Little Star is on the 7x7 list and is pretty good but my personal preference is still Classic. I love just regular toppings on pizza usually.

We also had a Mixed Salad (we were trying to be 'healthy') and wings. These two were okay but the pizza is definitely the best thing there!

I would definitely go back to Little Star, their pizza is soo good and made very well. They lose one star though for their beer selection. I LOVE ice cold beer with my pizza but they do not have a lot of the typical selections you would usually see at other places nor do they have pitchers (gotta love pitchers of beer with your pizza!)
author: Annie L.

description:
A little joke I stole from my cousin:

-   "Why did the hipster burn his mouth on the pizza?"
-   "He ate it before it was cool."

So many hipsters in the mission. Gah daaaaaaaaaang.

If I started hating hipsters before it was cool, what does that make me?

ENOUGH ABOUT STINKY HIPSTERS. 

THE PIZZA HERE IS AMAZING. The crust was AMAZING. Power of the cornmeal I guess. Sauce does NOT overpower the ingredients, a common pitfall of the deep dish pizza. So sad. So so sad. Such a sad tale.

Best deep dish since I've been to Chicago.
author: Andrew M.

description:
mmm you can do some good eating here.  the area makes me feel like a piece of garbage because people are asking for money and i'm going out to eat pizza instead of saving money and donating it to charity 

BUT if you can get past that and want to, like, CHOW DOWN then this place is awesome.  not cheap though.  mmm so good.
author: Amy M.

description:
Does this place need any more reviews?? Its good- go eat here!! Really though it is deserving of a little more.. So I usually don't plan meals around pizza but this place was worth the effort. Of all the culinary jems in San Francisco and I pick pizza- a testament to how yummy this place is.

We arrived before all of our friends (like one hour early) and sat at the bar prepared to drink ourselves into a stupor before they arrived. The beers were flowing and the aroma of pizza was pleasantly wafting through the air. 1/2 hour into our drinkfest we noted that the restaurant was much more crowded and the many empty tables we previously saw, were now filled with happy patrons. Hmmm how are we going to seat 8 people?? Thankfully the host was nice enough to inform us of the crowd situation and let us nab a table before our whole group was there- super sweet!

The pizza was delic! We ordered bothe the veggie and classic large deep dish pizzas with a few apps and had just the right amount of food. The sauce was a bit heavy- my only complaint, but the crust managed to stay crispy and delicious and lacking in grease, plus you didn't walk out with severe heartburn. Pizza Hut pan pizza this ain't!!! And I hate to say it but I do think this beats out Zachary's....So good!!!!  btw I'd give it a 4.5.....almost perfect!
author: Ritu K.

description: I cannot say enough good stuff about these guys.  I've been here three times, and their deep dish pizza is, in my opinion, the best pizza I've had in the bay area!  The tomatoes are fresh.  The crust is incredible with a good bit of corn meal to make is hearty.  Everything just tastes incredible.  Now I used to think Patxi's was the place to go for deep dish Chicago-style pizza, but I have to say that even though Patxi's offers a great pizza too these guys are a lot better.
author: Roger H.

description:
I LOVEDDD the cornmeal crust! 

I wasn't expecting much because I was thinking it'll be any ordinary pizza joint, but I have to say, I really liked little star pizza! It's a cute little place! 

I came here on a Sunday night and it was relatively packed. We had a good 20-30 minute wait for a table of two. Not too shabby. It's definitely worth the wait. AND plus you can just sit at the bar and sip on a little something. 

PS. I like the pear cider they have there! It's fruity goodness!
author: Jeanette Y.

description:
little star's cornmeal pizza crust is yummers!...though i wish it was more buttery. it is crunchy, crispy and has the grainy cornmeal texture which makes it really stand out in the pizza. also, there are sporadic areas of saltiness in each slice, which might not be on purpose, but it intrigues my mouth.

the deep dish pizzas are pretty modest - very litttle toppings (and not many topping options), and NOT overflowing with sauce or cheese :( - but at least the tomato sauce is garlicky and tangy, and you won't feel like a wild beast after eating 3 slices of a large.

there's no caesar salad here...which is too bad because i always crave caesar salad with pizza! ended up getting the mixed greens which just did not satisfy me...the walnuts in the salad were raw (i was expecting candied walnuts), and the dressing was like 90% olive oil.
author: Jessica C.

description:
From a Chicago transplant to California, this place is simply amazing! I never thought that I'd find a place that would give Gino's East and its famous cornbread crust a run for their money, but Little Star does just that.

I came to Little Star Pizza with college friends on a recommendation from my cousin. The wait was pretty long given the small size of the restaurant and our group of 6, but the hostess was super-nice and offered to let us pre-order the pizzas to cut down the service time once we got seated. There are several 'suggested' options, or you can make your own deep-dish. I went for the equivalent 9" deep-dish pie that I usually get at Gino's East in Chicago: sausage, tomatoes, spinach, and garlic.

Biting into each slice is like sampling pizza perfection. The base sauce and cheese is spot-on: very flavorful, but not overly rich and heavy. The rest of the toppings were mixed perfectly, with the fresh spinach and very succulent tomatoes being some of the best I've ever tasted. The crust too was perfect: crisp and buttery, with a hint of cornmeal (not as rich as Gino's East's all-cornbread crust, but this means that the pizza is lighter and "healthier"). If there's one thing that they could add to make it better, they could go for a full-pie sausage patty option like Gino's East or Lou Malnati's instead of the sausage crumbs.

Bottom line: Possibly the best pizza I've ever had. And that's borderline heretical coming from a Chicagoan.
author: Peien L.

description: Amazing pizza!!  Its so freaking good!!  I'm a lifer as long as I live in the bay.
author: Dorsey S.

description:
For some reason I always end up getting thin crust pizza at this Little Star location and Deep Dish at the one on Divis. 

Tonight I tried the Pesto Chicken Thin Crust. It can't compare to any deep dish pie, in my opinion, but it's still damn good. The pesto was lightly drizzled on top of the chicken, peppers, mushrooms, and onions, giving it just the right amount of pesto flavoring. Don't get me wrong, I love pesto, but I find that pesto pizzas are often overly drenched in the stuff. This one was perfect. Two of us split a small and were satisfied, but not overly full by the end ($18.75).

On a previous visit, I also tried the White Pie which has a garlic olive oil base with mozzarella, roasted zucchini, fresh tomatoes, and feta on thin crust. Delicious, though I think I will stick to Cheese Board and Arizmendi for non-tomato based pizzas from now on. Little Star has too many other better options.

Overall: $36 after tax and tip for one small thin crust pizza, one soda, and one beer. A little pricy, but not unreasonable.
author: Talia G.

description:
I discovered, to my dismay, that the Divisadero location of Little Star is closed on Monday nights so I tried out this location (Valencia) last night. Upon entering, I was optimistic that the deep dish pizza would be as stellar as the other location but, alas, it wasn't. The lighting was right, the place smelled great and the crowd seemed happy.

The mixed salad was tasty - a nice balance of bleu cheese, nuts and lettuce mix. As I dug in, though, I found myself getting annoyed by the variance in leaf size; it turned out to be a royal pain in the ass to eat. The anticipation of the arrival of the ultimate gastronomic elixir - the half Class / half Brass deep dish pie - kept my welling frustration in check.

Alas, when the pie arrived, I was completely let down. The sauce was considerably more acidic than I'd expected and the crust tasted yeasty and less sweet than the other location's. The toppings were applied inconsistently - I was actually wondering whether or not they put any sausage on the Brass Monkey.

Like the other location, the service was exceptional - our friendly waitress even feigned interest in my at-table foursquare dabbling and congratulated me on knowing that the Brass Monkey is the Little Star deep dish with sausage. 

I think I'll stick with Divisadero from now on.
author: Mike B.

description:
It's like the In & Out of pizza.  Fresh ingredients, interesting crust.  However, I do think they OD'd on the tomato sauce and cut corners on the amount of toppings.  My 2 cents.

The bartender was super friendly, however.  And the fact that they have a mean cab franc doesn't hurt either.
author: Kristen S.

description:
My meal at Little Star was the highlight of my weekend in SF. The pizza was delicious and our friendly and knowledgable waiter recommended some delicious wine to compliment it! 
The atmosphere in the restaurant was awesome. Know that it is a little bit warm and a little loud, and you won't have a ton of elbow room, but if cozy works for you- then you are in for a treat!
author: A C.

description:
I love this San Francisco twist on a Chicago-style pizza. If you are a Chicago-style pizza purest - then do not go here  

The "Little Star Deep Dish" is my favorite.  Corn meal crust and chunky tomato sauce makes this all very tasty.  And now they have lunchtime personal pizzas.
author: Tia B.

description:
Good solid Chicago-style deep dish pizza. I would align this very closely with Gino's Pizza East in Chicago, only not as greasy or cheesy.

We started with the garlic bread, which was kind of a do-it-yourself affair: a hunk of sliced warm sourdough (be still my heart), a bowl of olive oil/butter mixture (sounds gross but it was actually like very soft butter) and an entire roasted garlic bulb. Delish!  

Some chef (either Thomas Keller or maybe Anthony Bourdain) once said to always try whatever dish is named after the establishment, so I was thrilled with my dining partner suggested the Little Star pizza. A mixture of fresh spinach, thinly-sliced onions, feta and ricotta complemented the traditional Chicago-style tomato sauce and mozz. The crust was clearly a nice cornmeal-based dough, which is perfect for this type of pizza, and the rest of the dish was probably closer to a warm lasagna without noodles, or maybe a salad. It was absolutely delicious. I had been worried about the feta and ricotta, but honestly, I didn't really detect either. Just a really balanced spinach pizza with occasional crunches of onion.

I was also impressed with their selection of craft beers and sodas. I highly recommend the Cock and Bull ginger ale as the perfect pairing for the veggie pies. Next time, I'm definitely going to try one of their carnivore offerings.
author: Wendy B.

description: Definitely above average pizza- really enjoyed it. Nothing all that special in terms of the actual restaurant, but the service was good, no wait on a Saturday night at 645 and the pizza was damn good. The sauce on top of our Chicago deep dish was the best part- extremely fresh, thick tomato sauce. I think the crust at Patxi's is better but gotta try Little Star too.
author: Patrick D.

description:
Writing reviews for restaurants like Little Star that already has 713 reviews is so pointless, but I'm still doing it so I can include it on my favorite pizza lists. (Yep, I have more than one pizza list.)

Little Star serves Chicago style pizza (in addition to thin crust but who would get that here?) and it's all about their cornmeal crust. That crust is something else, and it makes Zachary's and Patxi's pale by comparison. The cheese to sauce ratio is dead on, and my husband thinks their sauce is perfect. We always get the plain cheese pizza here. Go ahead, make a face. We selected some veggies to add to it once but we learned you can't play with perfection.

Anyway, the pizza here is so good that the first month we tried it we ate at Little Star 3 out of 4 weekends. (We were away for Christmas one weekend so we couldn't help breaking the streak.) I should mention that we live in San Jose so that's quite a drive just for pizza.

We've been to both Little Star locations and we prefer this one because parking is far less insane.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
I remember going to the Little Star on Divisadero and ordering a deep dish and thinking to myself, this stuff is dry and no bueno! I didn't go back after that. Years later...
Here I am at Little Star again, hesitant to go, but my friend wanted to go so I sucked it up and went...
The wait was long, the Goddess Salad was actually pretty bomb! I would go back for that...
Then here comes the pizza..
I decided to get the thin crust pizza knowing the thick crust was just plain dry. Mushroom, Olives, Sausage, the toppings were good. But common, you know a pizza is based on the crust. It was a dissapointment once again to the whole table! My friends literally had one slice of pizza each because they couldn't choke down another DRY CRACKER CRUST. That's what it tasted like, a cracker, literally. 
Note to self: Really, DON"T GO BACK! I gave it a 2nd go around and still no bueno. I really don't get it, San Francisco has amazing pizza and they enjoy this Dry Crusty stuff? WAKE UP SF!
author: Karen T.

description:
After 1200+ reviews, there's not much else to add...or is there?  Been craving pizza for weeks.  Little Star to the rescue.

Called at 8:30 to check out the wait.  Was told 45 min to an hour.  Decided to chance it anyway.  Arrived at 9, our luck, no wait!  Parking right in front, total bonus.  Ian, our server, amazing!  Couldn't decide between the chicken pizza on the menu vs the chicken BBQ special pizza.  Ian suggested why not 1/2 1/2 it.  We had an amazing pie.  Gotta say the BBQ half was the winner.  Sweet BBQ sauce, granny smith apples, and chicken in that delicious cornmeal crust.  WOW!    Well worth the wait...oh yeah, we didn't have to.
author: Kim A.

description:
I went on a busy eve a few nights ago.  This is the second time I've been there.   The long and short of is that the pizza is great if you're into that kind of deep dish style pizza - I am, and I really enjoyed the vegie, though I'm not a vegetarian.   They gave the option of having half one flavor, and the other something else - which was nice.  

I have to mention the dark beer that i tried, I wish I remembered the name, but it wasnt a stout - real nice. Oh and you have to get the garlic bread appetizer for two reasons: 1) the pizza takes a full 30 minutes to bake, 2) the garlic bread comes with baked whole clove of garlic, still in its natural casing but baked and ready to be scooped out onto your bread, with butter - that was awesome.

On the pizza topic, I can appreciate a variety of types but if given my preference, I'd choose the texture and taste that I get from Blondie's pizza on Telegraph in Berkeley.  So the pizza here at Little Star is a different style, the bread is not as... doughy.  But having said that, there is a lot to be said for the pizza here.

The atmosphere was nice there, it was filled with people happy to be alive with warm air in the mission.  

Pricewise, I thought it was a little on the high side for what I got, but it *is* a unique pizza experience, I suppose.
author: Afshin M.

description:
I thought I wasn't a deep dish fan.  But I guess having good deep dish pizza changes everything.

I feel like I have been writing long reviews lately.  So to change it up, there won't be a lot of paragraphs in this review. And unfortunately no awesome bullet points.

So had a guys night out, and decided to check out the Little Star in the Mission.  After splitting the Caprese Salad, Spicy Chicken Wings, Deep Dish Little Star, Deep Dish Cheese and having a couple of beers to top things off, we left completely satisfied.  

The menu isn't out of control extravagant.  Overall it is pretty simple.  But they know what they are good at and they do it very well. Oh and the Deep Dish crust is crazy delicious. Recommended!
author: John R.

description:
I'm glad we called in our order for takeout because this place was PACKED.  We had a hard time finding the pick up section but its located on the right when you enter the restaurant. 

We got the White Pie, half without Feta. I hate Feta cheese, it tastes like nothing. What a waste of calories. Both of us were dying to just stop and dig in but we decided to wait until we got home. Four blocks later, we arrived home and quickly finished all but two slices between the two of us. Unfortunately it was mostly cold and I'm not the biggest fan of cold pizza.

I loved the crust. I love thin crust pizza and theirs was nice and crunchy. I loved it so much I even ate the crust dipped in salad dressing (I never eat pizza crust) I wasn't a huge fan of their toppings though and thought it lacked flavor.
author: Tiffany V.

description: Good location. Wish they had gf pizza.
author: Jody N.

description:
Maybe the best Chicago style pizza I have ever had. I mean it!
There is something special about the crust that I love. I feel like everything is always very, very tasty here and the service has always been simple and straightforward. 
It is a bummer to have to wait a while for a table, but if you plan on it, it's not so bad. 
I've done takeout here before as well, and it's the way to go if you have a larger group or are in a hurry. 
Also, just know that whatever zesty goodness is in the sauce, it seems like it's better the next day, so save your leftovers and DO NOT leave them in the car like I sometimes do!
author: Kelly B.

description:
I see that Tia B said that if you're a Chicago deep dish fan, you might not like it.

Respectfully, not so Tia. I'm from Chicago and have been going to Uno's, Due's, Gino's East and Gino's on Rush for nigh on 50 years. The reason you think it's not like other Chicago deep dish pizzas that you've had is because outside of Chicago they genrally suck. 

This is the real thing, and I'd put Little Star up against any of 'em in my home town.

On a side note though, the service staff in Albany is pretty bad, but I suffer through them for the pie.
author: Jerry F.

description:
My GF and I, both former Chicagoans, stopped by for dinner to try the pizza and see if it would scratch our itch for Chicago style deep dish pizza.  I'm happy to say it did.  Although it wasn't better than Pequod's or Lou Malnatti's, Little Star's deep dish was good.  The food was definitely 4 star.

So why the 3 star?  This might seem like a petty thing to complain about but the drafts are not 16 oz drafts (i.e., a pint).  Instead, the drafts are about 12 oz.  The draft is served in a glass that resembles a pint glass, but it holds nowhere near 12 oz.  How do I know?  After ordering several "pints," I ordered a PBR and poured it into a glass.  Guess what, it went almost to the top.  I will say that they don't describe the drafts as being pints, but why have glasses that resemble pint glasses unless you want people to believe it is a pint.  

Whatever, the food is good and I'll be back.
author: Larry L.

description:
Went here with a good friend to try their deep dish. The pizza was delicious! I was impressed with the cornmeal pizza crust which gave it a sweet taste. However, if you are a deep dish snob, it won't come close to a Chicago pie. But if you are in need of a fix, this is definitely the spot to go.

The only draw back was the waiting area. The place is understandably packed on a weekend night. So expect to be packed in like sardines until your table is ready. Although they have a bar area, it's extremely uncomfortable to be around. 

The good thing is you can order your deep dish (usually a 40 min cooking time) and have it ready by the time you sit down.

Please don't bring large groups though. This place is most enjoyed in the company of a friend/partner or a couple of other people.
author: Jorge H.

description: The pizza was delicious, but the freezing temperature made the dining experience extremely unpleasant. Because the food is delicious get Take Out in the cold winter months!
author: William H.

description: Usually, this place is great. Unfortunately, I ordered through a delivery service once (Caviar) and the order was wrong. They made good on it with a $5 refund (and the delivery service provided us with credit for free delivery on our next order).
author: Nipul C.

description:
Garlic bread came as a roasted garlic piece, butter, and slices of french bread. The first thought that came to mind was... "What's this...". It took a few minutes to connect the dots and figure out it's half a piece of garlic and butter. First try was trying to spread the butter and garlic individual onto the bread, which was too much work. The next thing that came to mind was why not just place the garlic pieces into the butter and use the bread to dip into it. Genius. It works.

Amazing deep dish pizza. The pizza crust was thin, but nicely golden brown and crispy. The next layer of the pizza was the cheese followed by a mixture of toppings and tomato sauce. The combination was amazing and it was great!

Service was great also. The waitress was attentive and did checkups at regular intervals to refill water and ask if everything was good.
author: Steven B.

description:
Sorry to bring down the hype of this place, but the food and service was terrible.

We just drove up from SoCal and my boyfriend just spent 7 hours driving us here, so I wanted to reward him with a good meal. This place had really high reviews and my bf LOVES deep dish pizza so I figured it would be a good choice.  Boy was I wrong

We started with the garlic bread. When it came out, we were like WTF?! They gave us a make it yourself garlic bread. We were given bread that was not sliced, a small container of melted butter, and a whole garlic clove which you have to pick apart yourself. I get the concept, but it was just weird!

We shared the little star pizza with spinach, ricotta and feta cheese, mushrooms, onions, and garlic. It was good, but it didn't really blow my socks off. At least it was somewhat authentic chicago pizza and had the sauce on top. But I guess I just wasn't that crazy about the flavor of the sauce and crust. 

Service was poor. It was really hard to get the attention of waiters and they rarely came to check on you. The vibe was trendy with the low lighting and loud music. Would have been an enjoyable environment if the food and service were better. I wouldn't come here again.
author: Leanne D.

description:
i was deeply craving deep dish pizza for a few days after watching some PBS show covering pizzas. Little Star gave us a great experience. Everyone that served us had a friendly smile, personable demeanor, and attentive attitude. I liked the atmosphere on the inside. It's fancy yet you still feel like you're in a down to earth pizza house. An easy spot for a very casual romantic dinner or family get away. The light was dim but they still dimmed the lights even more and brought lit candles for each table. When we left we thought it was going to be black as night yet it still looked like mid afternoon. What an illusion.

We had the chicken wings and Mediterranean chicken pizza. Yeah we ordered two chicken dishes but they sounded the best. The chicken wings had a good spice flavor but nothing revelatory. I wish the chicken had more of a crunchy skin and spice coating than it did. Still good.

The pizza is of the course the main star. As usual with deep dish pizzas it takes 30 minutes to cook. It came out on time piping hot. I really like Little Star's pizza because it feels light and not greasy compared to other deep dish pizza places. Whenever I leave any pizza joint I feel heavy and greasy, ready to take a long shower or sleep. But when I leave Little Star I feel full and content. The cornmeal crust is really good too. It almost tastes like eating cornbread with pizza filling. I love the pizza crust ends because that's where you get the most crunch along with a concentration of butter. The crust is soft enough you don't even need a knife.

The only problem was that when I got here the waiter gave me one of the worst tables in the house. The place only had four tables being served so why'd he give me the worst table? I asked for a new table and he obliged.

____

Upscale casual dining. A different take on deep dish but a great detour I'll come back for.

Note: One large pizza for two people is probably too much. After eating chicken wings,  I ate two slices and my brother only ate one. The pizza is still really good microwaved the next day.
author: Michael H.

description:
Briefly, this is an overpriced, over hyped pizza place whose pizzas aren't above average or interesting. 

I came here on a Saturday night and it was packed. An hour long wait. So we put our names down, and spent 45 minutes trying to park. Then waited 15 minutes more. When we finally were seated, we ordered two small pizzas: a Little Star deep dish (spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic) and a Pesto Chicken thin crust. Thin crust came out first, and although it tasted fine, it wasnt anything special. Definitely NOT worth $18 for 6 small slices. Think about it. Thats $3/slice for average tasting pizza. Ridiculous. 

Next came out the deep dish. At first, it was exciting and novel. Corn bread crust. Ooo la la! But then after a few bites it quickly lost its novelty charm, and unfortunately the taste really didn't really make up for the loss. Just an uninteresting tasting mix of cheese and veggies on top of some cornbread. Not really that good, and definitely not worth $20.

I'm guessing its sacrilegious to say this, but I would prefer CPK to Little Star any time. Little Star's pizza's were just not that interesting, and horribly over priced. At least they werent bad, plus the service was decent. But seriously, when you factor in tax and tip, $24 for a small boring pizza is completely silly. Plus think about how much time you waste just waiting for a table! Definitely will not be coming back here.
author: Igor V.

description:
BOMB.COM
Parking is the shits. There can be a long wait. It is noisy. Hipsters.  All of this does not at all bother me in the slightest considering how good the deep dish is. I have never been to Chi town, but damn, Little Star takes the cake for me. My all time favorite waitress Savannah is the cutest and greatest!
author: Desirée S.

description: That crust is out of this world. Along with Zachary's and Patxi's, definitely in my top 3 of deep dish pizza joints.
author: Madhur B.

description: Best pizza in town. Came in today for the happy hour. Great place to chill. Gets crowded at night but I love the pizza...
author: Ed O.

description:
Oh, Little Star... you used to be my #1 and now you have lost the title to Pauline's.  It's just that when I'm with Pauline's its... different.  It's not you... it's me.

I suppose I broke up with Little Star a long time ago already, but we had a secret tryst this past weekend and I have to say.... Pauline's is a better lover.

Don't get me wrong... Little Star is good.  I think maybe I overdosed on it and now it doesn't have the same effect.  This shouldn't discourage you, however, as it is definitely is good -- especially is you're craving some deep dish.

The good:
    - Nice, pseudo-New York ambience (brick and low lighting)
    - Friendly service
    - The garlic bread is actually toasty bread served with butter and roasted garlic
    - Racer 5 on tap

The ugly:
    - The wait can be pretty bad if you're not conscious of your dining hour
    - It's relatively expensive for what you get

Overall, Little Star, we had a good run... and I will probably continue to stray your way once in a while... but the marriage is off.
author: Kevin F.

description:
Finally got to try Little Star after hearing so many great things about this place. It definitely hit the spot for me!!

Ordered the deep dish with sausage and mushroom and Great White thin crust. 

Will def come back again!
author: Connie C.

description:
When we walked in we were greeted by a very rude lady, I couldn't believe how rude she was.. She mumbled something which we didn't understand but we continued to walk towards the table.. She mumbled again and pointed out few tables so we chose one and sat down.. I over heard someone called her name and I think it was Ravi or something like that.. Anyways whomever she was, she could win the rudest person award.. It is horrible to walk into a place and have that kind of experience before you start your meal.. 
We had the caprese salad, chicken wings and garlic bread as appetizers and they were all really good.. We then ordered the most famous little star special pizza which was amazing.. Thankfully she did not serve us but she was wondering around.. We fearfully ate our food.. I wish we didn't have such a horrible experience as the food was really great and I would have recommended this place to everyone but with such a horrible service it is very hard to suggest for anyone to go there.. We will go to their other location and hopefully we get a better service.. Again it is so sad to have someone ruin your entire dinner..  5 stars for the meal especially for the pizza and 4 for appetizers and 0 for the service..
author: Seda M.

description:
This is my third trip to SF, and we always stop here for pizza. The spicy wings are a great appetizer. I wasn't crazy for the glass of Rosé. The staff is great. We had the cheesecake, it was good! I'd
Give it 5 stars, but they got rid of "great white" beer :-(
author: Juan Cheerio A.

description: We were told the wait would be 15 - 20 minutes. When we came back we were told it would be another 20 minutes. After an hour wait, and a glass of wine at the bar from a not so friendly bar staff, we sta down. Our waitress seemed like she could care less about us being there. Not warm and friendly at al. Pizza was another 30 minute wait. The pizza was on par with Patxis. Very overhyped place.
author: Mark S.

description: The food was on point. It was loud and I didn't have much room but I had such a good time. Will definitely come back again.
author: Christopher S.

description:
Oh, yum! And I don't even like deep-dish.

But the wine is bad. All of it.
author: Allison S.

description:
My friends and I came here on a rainy day and were so excited that it was nice and empty! YAY!  Maybe like 3 small tables occupied the place so how is it that the service was so slow that we weren't seated until a good 20 minutes later.  I'm not used to the pace of this service and was pretty close to just grabbing the menus and sitting down. 

We strategically ordered the food while the server was giving us our water to prevent any more of our lunch delay.  

Garlic bread- was possibly the best I've had. The bread was soft and toasty, but it came with a roasted garlic so you had to pick it out of the clove to spread that garlic goodness all over bread.  The roasted garlic was so good that my friend just started eating the garlic when the bread was finished

Half little star/half classic deep dish pizza- the pizza had this cornbread, gritty, crispy crust with heavy tomato sauce mixed with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, spinach, onions and garlic.  The other half was with sausage, onion and muchrooms. The crust of Little Star is much better than that at Zachary's, but the sauce at Zachary's is much more tastier.

In summary, order garlic bread & little star deep dish pizza upon seating because they're hella good.
author: Nancy H.

description:
are you serious? what is this fabulous cornmeal dusting on the crust? does deep dish get any better than this??? yum.
The brass monkey with meat is any deep dish meat lover's paradise. Nice ambiance, fun appetizers, and rustic decor make for a fun atmosphere ...if you can keep your eyes off the pizza!! :) 
Both times i've been here, we've gone a little bit at odd times, so there was no wait!
author: Tuwie N.

description: Little Star is deep dish perfection. Nothing else in the Bay Area comes close for deep dish.
author: Michael S.

description:
Have been wanting to try this place and finally did when the boy came to visit me on a Wednesday night. Around 7, it was kinda empty, but by the time we left at 8ish, it was packed. 

We went for the Vegetarian deep dish, which was just all right for me. I did enjoy the cornmeal crust, but I guess I'm just not a big fan of tons of tomato sauce on my pizza (I've grown accustomed to Cheeseboard's pizza). I'd like to try more of the thin ones, maybe I'd like those better.  My cousin raves about anything with garlic in it.
author: Katrina L.

description:
Little Star pizza is the only pizza that I've ever dreamed about.

I'm talking scandalous stuff here.  

Little Star isn't  the best pizza out there; but if there were some SF pizza tabloid,,  Little Star could easily be  front cover pie material. Its tomato chunks have that 'something.'

I grew up in New Jersey. Thin, almost soggy like crust , beneath a smooth layer of tomato sauce, and heavy cheese on top is what I knew as pizza. And I adored it.

....

So I couldn't help, but feel guilty, when I went deep dish and liked it. 

Alot.

Little Star was my first.

And 

it 

 was

 aaaaaaaaawesome (insert Chris Farley's (RIP) Tommy Boy voice)

Now I know that most people dog on Little Star for not being authentic. Something to do with the tomato sauce and cornmeal crust. But I've tried the real "Chicago" stuff  and (Superbowl pizza pies flown in from Chicago) it just doesn't taste as good. Authentic or not -Little Star is what makes me wake up the next morning and....crave PIZZA.

That being said, there have been moments where I've yearned to play cupid with Little Star and Paxti's. And rear some Little Paxti's: cute pies with Little Star's top half and Paxti's bottom(their crust is incredible). Little Star and Paxti's would definitely make some beautiful pies together. (sigh)

With such a deep love for Little Star, I was ecstatic to learn that they'd opened up a new location in the Mission.  It has the same charm as the Western Addition location: loud conversations, a jukebox, a bar, uncomfortable waiting furniture and, dark lighting (almost too dark)  They've also added some new touches --- such as Ferris Plock wall art. It's so refreshing, when a restaurant expands and manages to retain its essence, yet still be creative and original. 

The catch of Little Star is that it is a hot number. And with all things that we crave and love --- there's a wait. A loooooooong wait. To be seated. To get your pizza. To get your bill. 

On a busy night, your stomach will probably be knawing on itself - it can be such a painful wait...and your head, if you're prone to migraines, may be throbbing from the loud booming voices around you......

But....

... don't stress it....

Because it's still worth it. Especially if you order the mozzarella appetizer, the cheese deep dish pizza with your own carefully selected toppings, and the cheescake.

....AND...

Even when you have to loosen you belt, and have trouble dancing with nearly a pound of tomato sauce in your stomach. And are popping a big packet of TUMS like tic-tacs... 

---it's still worth it.
author: Jessica T.

description: I discovered this place YEARS ago with my matey from Australia and it's such a hidden gem. On the corner of 15th and Valencia, with a tiny little sign hanging from above the front door, and that's it. It looks like it could be an abandoned warehouse or something... but when you open up, it's your perfect pizza restaurant. Brick walls, cute tables, warm lighting, a perfect setting for the perfect city!! Oh... and the pizza is RIDIC!!! ;-)
author: Courtney M.

description:
Date & Time:  Friday June 6, 2008 @ 9pm
Company:  Michael
Crowd:  Neighborhood Hipsters & Trendy Marina Peeps
Vibe:  Cool & Chill
Decor:  Comtemporary yet Rustic.  Blue Sofa in the Waiting Area.  Cool Bar.  Tightly packed Wooden Benches w/ Dark Wooden Tables, Brick Wall w/ Cool Paintings, Tables for Groups & Twosomes, Light Blue Wall w/ Huge Wooden Mirror.  Tres Chic yet Comfortable!
Service:  Very Attractive Waitstaff in Fitted Tee's or Tanks and Trendy Belts & Jeans.  Very Cool and Personable!
Imbibe:  Pacifico Beer & Henry Weinhardt's Sodas in Bottles
Devour:  Thick Crust Classic & Little Star
Notes:  We had a thin crust on top of the serving tray with the deep dish below it.  Definitly go for the Deep Dish- it is divine!
Total:  $42 something w/o Tip
Love it!!!
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Heard about this place from a guy that works at the bowling alley we frequent with friends of ours.  
This is the 1st time I've ever had deep dish pizza and it was AMAZING!!! We ordered the BrassMonkey and everything about it was absolutely DELISH!!!  The filling was so fresh tasting at the buttery crust was to DIE FOR!!!  
The service was just so-so which is why I knocked off a star but everything else was just fabulous.  
Its a small quaint place that gets packed really quick so plan your visit accordingly.
author: Sarah N.

description: A little disappointed. The pizza is OK but not amazing. The ingredients are fresh, but there just wasn't much flavor. Nothing distinctive. And maybe it's just me but I didn't really enjoy the corn meal crust.
author: Casey D.

description:
We on a Sunday afternoon and we were sitting right away. We order half Classic & Little Star large deep dish pizza for lunch. The pizza was really good, crust was perfectly made and crunchy. The wait for the pizza was well worth it. The Valencia location is pretty easy to find -- between 15th and 16th Valencia in the corner. 

Love this place and will definitely go back!
author: Anthony V.

description:
Yes. It is good. Lighter, more refined than Zachary's, which doesn't necessarily make it better. In fact the young gentleman I sat next too was dissecting his pie looking for mushrooms, but they were sliced so thin he was having a hard time finding them. I assumed he was on a mushroom hunt so that he could move them to the side but NO....this kidlet LOVES mushrooms and was disappointed that he couldn't find bigger chunks. 

You take the Little Star crust, add the more robust Zach's filling....that would make the perfect pie. For me anyway. And the kid.

Big love for the staff, who to a one is kind. Nice people do not suck!!!


!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!CASH ONLY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Little Star, please invest in a sign ! Newbies like me will NOT be able to find you otherwise ! They have tinted windows, NO SIGN and as for as I can remember, no actual lights or anything indicating that this place isn`t actually vacant. 

That said, this place is good ! It`s definitely a "fancy" pizza place--nothing like Papa John`s [which, don`t get me wrong, I LOVE]. The setting is a bit intimate and the wait can be pretty lengthy. But.. their pizzas are really, really good ! Thin crust + deep dish + not too oily = :D :D

My two girlfriends and I ordered the Mixed Salad and the Little Star [spinach, ricotta and feta cheese, mushrooms, onions, garlic]. We almost got talked into ordering a large, but two of the three of us had been snacking like little monsters beforehand, so we settled on a small. The salad was surprisingly tasty ! I was left wanting more [always a good sign]. Then came the pizza. At 9" and a good 2" deep, it was enough for three small appetites. I was a tiny bit hesitant about the mushrooms [yuck], but you can`t even taste them. Instead what you taste is just.. deliciousness. The ingredients meshed well with each other and no individual item was overpowered by another. Despite being a deep-dish, it wasn`t overwhelmingly heavy either. 

My *only* complaint is that prices could be just a liittlee bit cheaper. But that`s just me. Certainly won`t prevent me from coming back !
author: Dominique Y.

description: The pizza is really, really good - a big pricey, but it's a treat. Interesting combos, delicious toppings (sauce = yum).
author: judah m.

description: So on the advice of friends we decided we would finally check out Little Star Pizza.  The atmosphere was a little dull with Leonard Cohen depressingly singing 'Sisters of Mercy', bored servers and tables that were so close together I felt i was sitting on my neighbors lap partaking in their conversation.  The Pizza was nice but not the best I've ever tasted.  The crunch came when it came to paying our bill.  The $6 glass of wine from the menu became $7 on the bill.  I paid my bill and added the customary tip.  I then checked the menu and confirmed we had been overcharged.  I went back to our server who said "I'll give you $4.  I pointe3d out that the principle was really not good and she blamed the computer system.  I said that really is not good enough and I got the hand in the face accompanied by the "whatever".  i asked to see the manager who offered to give us a drinks voucher for next time we eat there.  Why would we ever return to a restaurant who's computer system rips customers off to the tune of $1 for every glass of wine and when point it out get the 'whatever' hand.  NEVER AGAIN.  Certainly not worth the wait or the aggravation
author: Michael D.

description: Zachary's is SO MUCH better. We had the Little Star w/ sausage, Italian Combo, and Mediterranean Chicken. It was good but soooo not as good as Zachary's!
author: Diana F.

description:
I had the Little Star deep dish pizza and it was so tasty! The crust is really what makes it stand out from any other pizza restaurant. The corn meal tastes just like a nice southern corn bread but crunchier. 

One thing I didn't like about the restaurant is that it is very small and I had to squeeze to get in and out of my table. The service is somewhat inattentive and only came by twice to get our order and ask if we needed a box.
author: T L.

description:
This was an excellent choice for pizza on a Tuesday night. We had perhaps a 15 minute wait as some tables were seated just as we walked in; but we did a quick walk around the block to get the appetite going. And I'm glad I did, the large deep dish is a LOT of food!

The atmosphere was nice; tables were a bit close but my friend and I still had a nice conversation without straining to be heard. We ordered a deep dish with spinach, roasted garlic, and sausage. Excellent, spicy sausage; nice tangy Chicago style sauce on top, and stringy, gooey mozzarella. This was actually my first deep dish crust with cornmeal; and it was a great contrast with the sauce. Definitely my new favorite for deep dish in SF.
author: Chad C.

description:
Had a little trip to Frisco.

We tried out this spot. Had the Caprese Salad and a Deep Dish Classic.

The Caprese was very good, pretty fresh.  This was my 1st time having a real Deep Dish pizza.  The crust was very good, lots of sauce and the meat in it was delish.  Overall the food was very good. The service was top notch! Nice upbeat music in the background.
author: Dyryl B.

description: The only other place I've had deep dish pizza is Patxi's. Depending on what type of crust you like, one may like one over the other. I like both crusts so I'll alternate going here and Patxi's :)
author: Timothy L.

description: I recommend if you want to experience Chicago Style Deep Dish Pizza with an SF twist this is the spot to be! I've had the privilege dine here on 4/26/14
author: Tanya G.

description:
Admittedly I have pizza issues. 

Many trusted sources rave about Little Star, but I found it fell short. 

I liked the atmosphere, staff was friendly, nothing wrong with the service.

But the pizza was too heavy to be propper pizza. More like a doughy baked torta topped with tomato sauce and other stuff. But not pizza. You don't eat pizza with a knife and fork.

I have since learnd they have a thin crust menu. I'll likely return to try it, but really, why look for pizza in SF when there's so many better options to be found?
author: Christian A.

description:
If Zachary's in Berkeley didn't exist, Little Star would be the best deep dish in the bay. However, it's kind of a toss up between Zachary's and Little Star... I'd have to have them back to back to determine which one I like more. Both are on par.

As far as pizza goes, I've only tried the Little Star here. May as well go for the tried and true once you find something you like, right? If you go here with four people, you can easily finish a large deep dish pizza and have a drink each for no more than $15 per person... definitely a cheap (and tasty) night out. 

The ambiance and service are also good.... The only reason I'm giving it four stars instead of five is the wait. They don't take reservations so you have to hang at the bar for at least an hour, depending on the time. But, it's still worth it.

Oh.. .and I swear they must put sugar in their crust or something... it is amazing, whatever it is!
author: Kristina C.

description: Atmosphere is nice decor as well. The place is not big but it's roomy as long as they aren't trying to cram in a bunch of table in there. Deep dish pizza is ok but I know better places. Greek salad is too vinegary service is kind of poor they dont smile much
author: Erkan Ç.

description:
This restaurant was hard to spot. The windows are all blacked out and the only sign they have is the small one they have by the door. Anyway, I didn't know a pizza joint could ever get so hip. There's definitely more of a trendy (and by trendy I mean hip and/or gay) crowd here vs the kind you'd see at a regular pizza joint. I wouldn't even consider this a joint - it's more like a gourmet restaurant.

Whatever you order, just make sure you stick with the pizza - deep dish since that's what they're known for. The appetizers might get you full like it did me. Plus, they weren't even that great, or at least the chicken wings and the garlic bread weren't. If you do order appetizer, I suggest sticking with a salad. You probably would want to order a salad since it takes them half an hour to bake that pizza.

The pizza crust was crispy and didn't leave oil stains on my plate - that's a definite plus. It was really good, one of the best I've had, but I believe pizza is meant to be eaten on an anytime basis. With this place, you'd likely have to wait for a table during peak hours, then wait for them to bake your pizza to perfection. That's why I won't be coming here too often, but I'd still recommend it to anyone who hasn't tried it yet.

Lastly, with this type of restaurant, why cash only? Oh well! Good thing for once I had enough cash with me.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Hamburglar brought over a half Classic, half Little Star so I got the best of both meat and non-meat worlds.  The Little Star was my favorite of the two since I generally like pizza without any kind of sausage.

I think I prefer Zachary's but I would need to do a side by side comparison to be sure, along with Paxti's.  Unfortunately, I can't eat that much pizza so this may never come to be.
author: Seong P.

description: Little Star Pizza makes an excellent deep dish. The crust, tomato sauce, and interior "toppings" were all delicious. The service was good. I highly recommend this place.
author: R. J.

description:
BEST deep dish pizza you will ever have! I've been here a few times in the late afternoons and never had to experience any of the so-called waits. I tried BOTH the CLASSIC & Little Star Deep Dish Pizzas and they were FANTASTIC!

Pros:
-One 9" pizza will stuff at least 4 girls cause after the first piece with some soda you are pretty stuffed! Plus there were left overs to bring home and devour the next day(;
(FOR THE GUYS- I think the 9" will be good for 3 and the 12" for 4)

-The cornmeal crust was so crunchy and yummy; it wasn't even soggy after 45mins of working on what was on your plates!

Con:

-when you're very hungry, be prepared to wait 20mins or so cause they make everything FRESH! UNLESS you get an appetizer.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Better than Zacharys in Oakland, better than Paxtis in SF/Palo Alto/Lafayette - this place rocks.  We get the half classic (sausage pizza), half little star (ricotta, spinach, veggies) -- it's a perfect combination.  

Above all, what makes this better than any other Bay Area deep dish pizza is their cornmeal crust.  It cannot be beat and it's what continues to bring me back!
author: Kimya P.

description:
Preface: This pizza is fine for the West Coast... obviously compared to East Coast pizza it would be sub-par

Little Star is fine for group dinners and usually a good deal. The food here is unimpressive-- the salads, insalata caprese are all plates that can easily be recreated at home and aren't really heightened that much (particularly compared to Beretta, where even their simplest appetizers are incredibly fresh and use innovative ingredients). The pizza is fine: while the crust is great, the sauce needs more garlic, is a bit too sweet, and need some oomph.

Cons: I was very unimpressed by the douchey host and waitstaff. We came here for a birthday dinner; we had all arrived on time but were waiting for 1 person. Of course the restaurant wouldn't seat us (even though we were sharing everything because it's friggin' pizza), and also said if our last person didn't arrive soon they couldn't guarantee that they would seat us at all... mind you, we were all there, had arrived early, and had been waiting a half hour. And the birthday girl was very excited to be there, so it was disappointing that they couldn't have cared less.

The douchey, rude host finally relented and seated us. I dunno, I feel like Little Star tries to give off a posh vibe, but fails because it's a factory in there. They definitely want to get you in there and out. When we ordered, they told us we to make sure we had enough food because they don't take additional orders for more deep dish pizza after the first order.  It just doesn't feel very welcoming when they're itching for you to finish up so they can get in more diners. 

Overall: Poor service, douchey wait-staff, and pretentious vibe don't make me want to come back here. Definitely not worth the hype.
author: Jessica L.

description: My favorite pizza in the city. Thick or thin you just can't beat their crust, service, and specials. If the special pizza of the night is Brass Monkey, order it!
author: Cat M.

description: I ate here twice and the food was very good but it lack parking in which it was me and a few formally co-workers used to be Cala Food / Bell Markets in few other's location went here (the first time) and The 2nd time was family friend took us here and later went to see Music Show in SF CA!
author: EdwardF A.

description: its really good pizza with fresh ingredients and nice crust
author: Shuting Z.

description:
So last night's dinner (and this morning's breakfast) was a deep dish pepperoni (9in) with extra of their wonderfully fresh tangy tomato sauce as well as an extra pound or so of mozzarella (hey if I'm gonna cheat on my diet I may as well go all out!) cheese piled on top. Don't forget the garlic bread with real garlic and no skimping on the butter! Ahh you haven't tasted heaven until you've had a slice of pizza from Little Star Pizza! The crust almost oozes buttery yumminess (I sometimes switch to baby talk when I'm this happy) so even if you're a thin crust fan you'll love every last bite.

The pizza is obviously a 5 star experience, but they lose a star in the overall experience because of the long wait (usually 45min to an hour from sit down till your pie arrives). When you're hungry the wonderful aroma of garlic and baking pizza will almost kill you. My reccomendation is to order the garlic bread if you're dining in. Not only is iot a sensory delight but it will help pass the time till your pizza is served. 

Or do what we did last night- order it to go! They're fairly accurate with pick up times and the pizza and garlic bread were still perfect (and more than hot enough) 45 minutes later when we reached home in Oakland.
author: Lisa H.

description: I have been here twice now.  I think it was excellent both times.  I ordered the Chicken pesto thin crust pizza, delicious.  Crunchy crust, thinly sliced sweet onions, yummy pesto sauce with chicken, just YUMM!  We had a salad and some garlic bread both were very good.  I dont love the location mostly due to NO PARKING.  But I really do enjoy that pizza. It would have gotten 5 stars but its pricey and the decor is very simple.
author: Suzy L.

description:
I've never had corn meal crust but it was good and different than the usual flour based crust I'm used too. 

We ordered the chicken wings, garlic bread, and a 1/2 and 1/2 pie to split.

Wings - 4 stars, they were very tasty plain or with the light blue cheese dip that comes with it.

Garlic bread -  4 stars, it's a mini french loaf sliced and served with a side of softened butter with 2 whole bulbs of roasted garlic (YUMMM). I've never seen garlic bread served this way and thoroughly enjoyed it. I'm a big fan of roasted garlic so of course I spread the entire bulb on the bread and my pizza.

Pie - 3.5 stars - 1/2 Veggie with Italian sausage and 1/2 pepperoni with bell peppers.  The cornmeal pie crust was good, it had a rustic earthy taste to it. My half of the pie was overall good. I love the veggies except olives. With all the toppings, it did make for a heavy pie so we were only able to eat 1-2 pieces each with leftovers for lunch the next day.

Ambiance - 4 stars, it was the first time i'd been to a pizza joint where it was contemporary and felt a little upscale compared to the hole in the wall places throughout the city. 

sitting area - there's plenty of tables even though they've maximized the use of the small space they have. My only gripe is that the tables against the wall are too close to each other. Thankfully we were there early enough that there wasn't a crowd nor anyone using the table next to us but there is very little space between the chairs and tables. You literally have to pull out the table if you're sitting against the wall regardless of your size.

Parking was a little challenging even though we were there before 6. Valencia is a busy street especially in the evening hours so you might have to drive around the block a few times to find a space nearby.
author: Faaae L.

description:
This has got to be the best pizza I have ever had in my life.  The pizza is deep dish, with lots of tomato sauce, tomatoes and extra cheesy with a crispy garlic crust.  IT IS FINGER LICKING GOOD.  I wish we had one down here in southern ca.  Their hot wings are delicious as well.  It's flavorful and spicy.  Their garlic bread is good too, but I'm not a fan of crispy bread so I left it for the bf since he loves it.  

The restaurant is small and intimate and they also have a bar.  If you happen to go later at night, expect a wait time of about 30 mins to an hour depending on how crowded it is.  The bar is a first come, first serve so you could sit there and order your food as well.  

I love this place.
author: Shong H.

description: 1 hour wait ended up being 2 h30. Service sucks soo much! Definitely not worth the wait!
author: Cedric M.

description:
Despite the hubub and hipsterishness of this place we decided to eat here on a Friday.  6:30 must be magic hour because we were seated immediately and had frosty beverages in our hands 'tres rapidement'.  There was a major crowd by the time we left. 

 We sorta had to order an appetizer because the deep dish pies can take a while.  The hot wings were very tasty and not dry at all considering the 'spicy' came from a rub and not a thick sauce - scoring points for easy clean up.  The Mediterranean pizza was delish and a small was ample for 2.  Uh yeah they score over Zachary's big time!  Service was great including our server's aside that leftovers are perfect for 2am munchies.  Charming and very SF.  

My only recommendations to improve are - 1) serve draft beer and 2)more carrots with the hot wings - 3 measly baby carrots all sliced thinly is chintzy
author: Julienne G.

description:
I would describe this dining experience like a Joe Montana (49er) led drive. Joe Montana would take the niners the whole length of the field in small chunks, 5 yards on a screen To Roger Craig there, another 12 yards to Jerry on a slant there, etc. The aggregate moves culminating in a touchdown. And a touchdown is what Little Star's is, an all around awesome dining experience from the roasted garlic bread, the chicken wings, the nicely frosted glasses of beer, to their signature pizza. This is just for the food too, the atmosphere, look, service, and feel of the spot definitely make it a 5 star.  

Little Star does not disappoint and is a definite hall of famer in my book.
author: Earl G.

description:
Me: Wow, this looks good. (bites Pie)
Pie: Was that flavor exploding in your mouth, or are you just glad to eat me?  

Little Star brings the heat.  My first visit to either location...all kindness, from the front desk on.  No wait on a post-Zeitgeist, summery Thursday?  Yesssssss.  My hot date was glad that she had recommended tha joint when the cute, hunky waiter turned out to be as saucy as the tomato paste.  

See, it's all good when you serve the brotha a perfect crust.  Dude, crust and sauce are 90% of what any pizza can ever be, no matter what you put on it.  And this is 110% pizza.  Throw in some delish wine for me and a ginger cocktail that adds some fizz to her sparkle?  Gawd Dahhhhhm!

S'all I'm sayin iz...food + scene = a pie palace with it all in place.  Great tunes, 60's/80's/00's mix...completely tasteful and rockin'.  There's just this chill comfort-frequency dialed in here that has more than a touch of the vibe you get at the original (as in where they made the sheet up) pizza parlors in New Haven.  How to explain the essence of it?  At Little Star they "get" pizza. 

"POW BIFF BANG CRUNK"
Oh, that sound?  That's just the bodies flying as I make my way to the front of the mf'n bandwagon.  Get out of the damn way, I gotta get my 'za on at Little Star again - and soon
author: Ted R.

description: Since my boyfriend and I first tried Little Star, we really can't bring ourselves to try any other pizza joints in SF.  We also can't seem to get past the Little Star (specialty) pizza!  YUM!  We always visit late afternoon/early evening (btwn 3 - 6pm) and have always been seated immediately.  Service has always been prompt and friendly.
author: Annie P.

description: My fav deep dish pizza place West of Chicago. It's well worth the wait, especially if you hit up a bar nearby. I highly recommend the garlic bread to start -- they serve a whole bulb of garlic that they roast. Garlicy, yet delicious.
author: David M.

description:
Don't mess with my Little Star. The off-menu brass monkey (a Little star with sausage) is probably my favorite pizza on planet earth. Their mixed salad is also excellent and great to split. 

Can't go wrong here and always very friendly staff.
author: Matthew H.

description:
After reading for many years varying reviews of little star I decided to check it out. The New little star on valencia is nicely done...great layout...nice artwork yata yata yata. The pizza is very good but it is not awesome. The classic little star pizza is nice crust, nice fresh chunky tomatoe sauce, nice toppings....It is perhaps one of the best in San francisco....but it does not compare to chicago deep dish.

The staff there is really great...nice friendly and on top of their game. I would defintly go out and eat there again.... keeping in mind that it aint cheap....19 bucks for a small deep dish...6 pretty small slices.
author: David G.

description:
the best pizza i have ever had and i can safely say that it puts up a good fight versus chicago deep dish. The place is soooo good that they only have to be open for dinner time. I remember the first time coming here i thought the spot closed down because theres no crazy lights or signs or anything outside; but when you go in its totally a different kind of pizza place; very modern and homely in an artsy fartsy kind of way.  

We ordered both the original deep dish and the italian thin crust with beers and vanilla creme soda. The wings were nothing special but thats not why you come here. The traditional deep dish is a must; fresh tomatoes, fresh meats, cheese and veggies. The thin crust was good but it really wasnt anything like the deep dish. I would recommed this place whole heartedly to anyone who is craving real deep dish pizza.
author: Brian U.

description: Yes, the pizzas are phenomenal (better than Delfina, in my opinion), but the salads are the icing on the (very healthy) cake. They are huge, with fresh ingredients and bursting with flavor, for less than $10. Back to the pizzas, I usually prefer thin crust, but Little Star's personal sized deep dish can make me forget all about it. You can customize your ingredients and make it as crazy or simple as you prefer. It's more of a take out spot, as the interior dining is oddly dark and quiet, but service is good and the location on Valencia near Four Barrel is great.
author: Marie F.

description:
I think YES! Loved it. I'm a HUGE Zachary's fan, and this was right up there with them. Cute, dim, small restaurant with cool music and a scene crowd. They serve beer, wine, appetizers, dessert and of course deep dish and thin crust pizzas.

We ordered a large deep dish classic pie and their do-it-yourself garlic bread. I say do-it-yourself because you're given a sliced loaf, runny butter and a toasted bulb of garlic. The garlic is entirely soft and spreadable and the butter liquefies when slathered on a slice, which made it super tasty!

The pizza: deep dish with chunky peppered sausage, thinly sliced onions and mushrooms, with no bell peppers but with an add-on of perfectly firm plump artichoke hearts. The outer crust was really good because it was almost pastry like. It was buttery and flaky and even tasty when microwaved the next day for lunch. It was definitely different from Zachary's in that there's a whole layer of tomatoes ABOVE the toppings (really they shouldn't be called toppings since they're underneath the top) but the deep dish at Little Star didn't have such a distinct layer, which is not a bad thing, but I LOVE tomatoes.

Only a small pizza made it to our table although we ordered a large, just a small mistake of the waitress, but no biggie since we weren't charged for a large pizza. We weren't rushed through the meal nor pressure the kitchen was closing, even though we were some of the last people in the restaurant. Service was so attentive and genuine, I still give them five stars. I will definitely be back!
author: Chelsea P.

description: Best pizza in the city.  Great small selection of micro brews.
author: Eric L.

description:
When a food-forward friend gushed over the pizza at Little Star and insisted we forgo at-home cooking to go there, I was so optimistic I would've gone after Moby Dick in a rowboat and brought the tartar sauce with me. 

I asked for a glass of champagne and it came served in a goblet. If this was their version of flute, it was more of a trombone. 

Their ATM surcharge was .25 cents. Yes, you're reading that correctly.

They let us pre-order our pizza while we waited for a table at the bar... so by the time we sat, it arrived within minutes. 

Oh and the deep dish pizza, damn good. For you thin crust pansies, just order the deep dish and pipe down already.
author: Monica S.

description: One of two places in town that I would say have the best pizza in town.  Thick crust is their forte, but even thin crust is wonderful.
author: Mike D.

description:
Pizza was OK.  I eat pizza maybe twice or three times a year.  Believe it or not, I actually craved for pizza for the first time this year and Little Star Pizza was what I have bookmarked for over a year.

Service was excellent

Pizza was a little too tangy for me personally.  I like a more cheesey type pizza.  Plus maybe I'm just a thin slice kinda guy.  I used to love Uno's and Zachary's pizzas.

The place feels like a renovated dive bar that is kinda hip.  They have a bar which is cool but for some reason when we were there, there weren't anybody sitting there.  I think I can answer that on my next review.
author: jason g.

description: I used to be a devoted Patxi's follower, but I've been converted: Little Star is where I now go when I am in need of some spiritual-food-healing. The crust and toppings here are a bit lighter than what you'd find on a standard heavy-duty Chicago style pie, but as a result the toppings mix into one glorious union of flavors, rather than staying divided in distinct layers. Also, the cornmeal crust here is amazing (dear Little Star, please don't ever post your nutritional info!)
author: Jean L.

description: The pizza was /very/ good though not my favorite kind of pizza. I feel like if it were this place would definitely be a 5. I do highly recommend the garlic bread appetizer because they give you a full head of roasted garlic, which if you don't know, is sweet and creamy and delicious. As far as toppings go we got sausage and pepperoni, the pepperoni was really good but i found the sausage slightly over caraway-y.
author: Sara G.

description: I'm a pizza guy. What? I can't help it! Offer me a deep dish, thin crust, New York style, California style (what?), etc....and usually I'd say yes, I'll try it. I'll also try to save you a slice (maybe). We chose to eat in Mission at a dimly light, tightly tabled, and otherwise intimate spot. We settled on the Deep Dish Classic and Thin Crust White Pie to share across the table. The Classic included a salty sausage with mushrooms, onions, and green peppers thumb-deep in a hearty marinara. It was true to a pizza pie - the deep dish crust held up well, with an emphasis on the filling. I'm ok with this. The White Pizza has been done countless times with mild variation. Here, it's served with garlic olive oil, mozzarella, feta, zucchini, and tomatoes and piping hot: gooey and so cheesy that the ribbons seemed endless from the pizza serving plate. At the end of our meal, I found myself counting among the table and nibbling on the unclaimed remaining slices until all were gone (others followed suit until it became a fork battle for the last few pieces). Orders take some time, so bring good company you can sit with for a half hour before the pizza feasting begins!
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Hands down, the best pizza that I have ever had the privilege of feasting upon. And though this pizza fiend has done quite a bit of traveling (sampling pizza as I go, of course) including Italy (Milan) and NYC, I have yet to dine on the legendary pies Chicago has to offer (but this will change come my visit planned for august, and i will update this review then, opining whether Little Star's deep dish is still king). 

Their deep dish pizza dough/crust recipe is legendary and most likely protected by a team of attorneys ready to sue anyone who pilfers it, but goddamn Ive given serious thought to infiltrating them through a cooking position simply to gain access to the recipe for my own selfish gaping deep dish needs. One bite, and one can see the layers of flakey, beautiful, almost dense pastry-like goodness, that does a good job of staying firm even after a day or two in the fridge after being warmed up in my toaster oven (whereas Zachary's deep dish pizza in Berkeley had somewhat bland tasting, flimsy crust that quickly became soggy, even after i heated up the left over pieces in same toaster oven). The sauce has just the right amount of fresh tomato chunks. The cheese is just right (whereas I felt Zachary's was a bit too cheesy, to the point where I needed more sauce where there was none). It's simply, and utterly fantastic. 

I also prefer Little Star's admittedly overly hip/low lit atmosphere over Zachary's bright, childish (in the literal sense of the word) decorations. 

Though Little Star could take a tip from Zachary's efficient reception, specifically the fact that one is able put in their pizza order while waiting for a table. 

Delivery option would also be nice, though I live super close, so pickup isn't a problem for me. 

Their garlic bread is splendid in its simplicity. 

It's an expensive pie (Zachary's is pretty equivalent in price), but worth every penny.
author: Safiya B.

description:
I've gotten Little Star a number of times as take out, but last night I sat down and ate for the first time. The wait was a little over an hour, which is long, but we had a big group and it's a small space so all was forgiven. We got the garlic bread which was stinky awesome. They serve the bread with a whole roasted garlic bulb. The top is chopped off the bulb so you can just get a clove out with your knife and spread it right on a piece of bread. Smelly and devine.

We ordered a deep dish classic and a thin crust pesto chicken. We meant to order a build-your-own deep dish with pesto and chicken, but we didn't realize there was a thin crust one on the menu and ordered it on accident. The best mistake I have ever made. The thin crust pesto chicken was crispy and amazing. I've had the classic a couple of times and it is always a winner. I've also had the white thin crust and it might be my favorite pizza of all time, but it always seems like I have to lobby to get my friends to order any pizza without meat on it. Anyway, this place is my current #1 pizza place in the city.
author: Jeremy J.

description:
I lucked out when I came here.
we had a pretty big group of friends, as if getting in wasn't hard enough.  They did the hard work, like bringing booze, getting a table, and ordering.

The hardest thing for me was to park my car. Which is pretty damn hard.

The food was delicious and they counted our box of wine as 1 bottle.
Yea, I get the hype.  If you want awesome deep dish pizza in the city, head over to little star, you won't be disappointed.
author: Van W.

description: I'm not a deep dish pizza fan, but I will gladly chow down on a slice of the cheese deep dish from Little Star.  I will warn you that it is best piping hot at the restaurant and not as take out.  We have it catered at work every other Friday and by the time I get through the lunch line, the cheese is congealed and the crust is soggy, which doesn't make for an appetizing bite.
author: Vanessa L.

description: I wish they had one of these in San Jose. I make it a point to pop in whenever I'm in the city. Hands down best deep dish pizza!!!
author: Khody A.

description:
A 3 star rating on the pizza snob scale is actually pretty good, though I am not sure if it would be as high if this place was actually in Chicago.  I think the Bay Area spots try to bribe me for better ratings.  Hear me out here.  For the most part, if I know nothing about a pizza place, my go to topping staples are spinach and mushrooms (yeah I am vegetarian).  Now if a place has something that they are known for [Burt's bell pepper medley] then I will of course add to this list.  Both Little Star and Zachary's both have a spinach mushroom special on their menu.  Little Star also managed to get their version on the 7x7 list.  It was calling me and I surely answered.  

We got take out, which obviously takes away from the experience a bit, but it was still good.  The crust is similar to Pizano's (in Chicago) and the ingredients were fresh.  This was rather pricey for even deep dish and it was really strange that their large deep dish pizza is the same as some Chicago spots small.  I could probably eat an entire large when hungry and in beast mode.  I guess that is why Chicago is on the fattest cities list.
author: Jason P.

description: So, this place is a crowded. Like a little times ten. I stood behind the door like a dunce for awhile until I got tired of that. There was literally nowhere to even stand in the lobby/bar, forget about walking. It's like the after-work N-train, where you have to play Twister to get out at your stop. I've never met up with a mean staff person though. They have a professional warmness that makes me think that they really love their jobs. They call me "dear." It means a lot in my book. And the pizza. I would brave any crowd for that pizza.
author: Heidi H.

description: I was raving about Blue Line Pizza in Burlingame and found out its the same company as Little Star. My bf and I frequent the Mission so I was excited to eat here. Identical menu to Blue Line. Love their deep dish crust. It's to die for. Garlic bread is also awesome. Can't beat the roasted garlicky goodness. Definitely come early or eat at the bar. Very popular place because the food is Awesome!
author: Rochelle I.

description:
ODE TO LITTLE STAR SWELLNESS

Twinkle, twinkle, Little Star,
How I've traveled near and far
Up above the world so high
Down below Little Cesar's pie.
Little Star you rise above,
But not just quite enough for love.

Your veggie deep dish is my fav
Your salads just so-so to my nave
Make-your-own garlic bread, what the f___?
What, has your kitchen just gone amok?
Little Star, still all the same,
Your beer selection sure has game.

Little Star you taste just fine,
Cornmeal deep dish is your sign.
Crispy, light, and rich in taste
Still Zack's n' Paxis', rule home base.
Little Star your wait is long
Sometimes more painful than this song.

THE END
author: Paolo M.

description: We brought our 4 year old daughter there on her actual Birthday. We ate on a Saturday night at around 7-8PM and we probably only waited 20-25 minutes. Great service! Ian was our waiter and was nice enough to bring out a slice of cheese cake for our daughter's Birthday! We didn't even mention that it was her Birthday, but he noticed that she was opening up gifts and he surprised us. The sausage/mushroom pizza was awesome. Very fresh tomato sauce.
author: Stephen M.

description:
Don't believe the hype, really.

Zachary's is good. Little Star is good too but neither place is ah-mazing. 

What is notable about Little Star:

The pizza is very tasty, especially the White Out and the Little Star.

It is very affordable. $10 - $15 per person w/o drinks.

You will be full. 

Cool decor. 

Chill bar area.

Good service.

It's a good place to check out but don't break your neck trying to go there.
author: Kiristen R.

description:
We order from Little Star frequently, and it really is great pizza, both deep dish and thin crust. The salads are really good well portioned. The pizzas are really good, with fantastic ingredients. The pizzas are a little on the small size, so if you order a large deep dish for example, you'll be a little surprised at the size. A large is 12", which is a medium just about anywhere else.  Like a lot of places in the Mission, the customer service is hit or miss. Some days it's stellar and friendly, other days are like the time they almost dropped my take-out order on the floor, smashing everything to one end of the box and then with an afterthought, "oh... is this crumpled pizza ok still? And that'll be $40 please."

As much as I like it here, if I had to compare Little Star to Patxis, I'd have to give the W to Patxis since their pizzas are a little larger, less salty and nicer staff. If you have kids, Patxis is also a bit friendlier on that front as well, and have kids menu options.
author: D S.

description:
Went on Tuesday. Got there early (at around 6:30PM) before the rush. Had no trouble getting seat. The pizza was great! We had the small Veggie deep dish. One half all veggie for me and one half veggie with salami as well for my boy. In addition we ordered the Caprese salad--also great. Big, delicious juicy tomato slices with fat portions of good mozzarella di bufala, fragrant strips of basil nicely dressed in balsamic vinegarette and olive oil. 

We paired the pizza with the Tempranillo by the glass on the menu. Wonderful pairing. The smokiness of the Tempranillo really complemented the subtle, smoky, richness of the salami.  My boyfriend also had the Blue Paddle Pilsner and said it was one of the best beers he's ever had in his life! It was served perfectly ice cold.

Our server was great, attentive but not overly or underly so even as it got busier and the music choices from the juke box were excellent! I noticed one of the employees putting change into and selecting music the whole time we were there and she did an awesome job! Death Cab, Wilco, Tom Petty.... 

I gave it four stars only because I prefer the crust at Paxi's more. I find it's a little less buttery.  

Overall, I love it and I'll be excited to go back.
author: Dee I.

description: People will tell you that this is deep dish; it's really pan crust for a Chicagoan. Nice tasting pizza with its cornmeal, but nothing too memorable. We had the classic and little star (preferred this one). The goddess salad is pretty good.
author: Chrystina Z.

description:
One of the closest things to Chicago Deep Dish Pizza (yeah, I'm gonna capitalize it cuz it's BOSS) outside of Chicago. Also comes with the associated wait-time. Get the pie to go.

"Hipster" is listed as an ambience choice? I am totally checking it.
author: dj z.

description:
I love these ebullient Yelp reviews that are overly enthusiastic about a particular place and try to justify their point by name dropping a few other places that have a similar product.  This is kind of one of those except I won't name any other places.

Little Star has the best pizza in town, hands down.  The deep dish pizzas are amazing creations.  I sat at the bar and had a great dining experience.  I was having a decent amount of trouble deciding on what to get and the bartender, Kristin, made some great recommendations in addition to providing outstanding service.  I had a half classic and half of some of the special pie of the night (Gorgonzola, garlic, onions) and it was delicious.  The ingredients taste fresh and the crust is amazing.  I washed it down with a Mateveza or two and while it's no Piny the Elder, it was a great beer and one I was glad to try (again at Kristin's recommendation).

After living in Chicago for a year and trying the best of what they have to offer in terms of deep dish, I'm proud to report that Little Star can hang with the best of them.   After I ate here I was supposed to go study but instead fell into a pizza coma and ended up staring aimlessly at a coffee shop, thinking about how full my stomach was.  Will definitely be back to throwdown on pizza.
author: Steven R.
