description: Aaaaaaamazing deep dish pizzas!! Make sure to add the roasted garlic to your deep dish!!
author: Chi P.

description: The best deep dish pizza in San Francisco.
author: Richard C.

description: Delicious deep dish with great selection of toppings. Cool atmosphere, decent prices, and wonderful service. Even the jukebox is awesome!
author: Samantha D.

description:
We stumbled in here from the pouring rain on Friday night. I had been wanting to try this place for some time, and when it was suggested as a possible date spot, I made no hesitation in the decision. Nothing really affects me quite like a great pizza. I saw a couple of the tables around us devouring their pizzas and I was tempted to reach over and try some of theirs due to my impatience, but since I was on a date, I had to pretend to have manners. 

Smelling the pizzas and watching them being consumed all around us, I knew that it was necessary to order an appetizer so I wouldn't gnaw my arm off. We shared a caprese salad which definitely was a good way to curb my hunger for the meantime. We ordered the Brass Monkey, which is basically the Little Star with sausage and some other stuff. Look, I didn't really pay that much attention to all the ingredients, because all that really mattered was that it tasted FANTASTIC when it went down the hatch. The crust was made using cornmeal and added great texture and made the pizza less doughey- something I have experienced on a couple occasions at other inferior Chicago-style pizza joints. 

If you are in San Francisco, come eat here. You won't regret it.
author: Katie B.

description: As a recent Chicago transplant who worked at Lou Malnati's in high school, I had my doubts about any restaurant in SF attempting to perfect Chicago-style deep dish pizza. But Little Star nailed it! I loved the amount of cheese and the wonderful tomato sauce, but the real star was the cornmeal crust. I've never had cornmeal crust on a Chicago-style pizza before, so this was a fun twist that makes Little Star unique. The ambiance was fun and casual, just how it should be.
author: Julia B.

description: I love Little Star Pizza.  Ate here about a week ago with some out of town guests.  We split a salad and a small deep dish pizza (3 people).  Everything was delicious.  Our server was friendly.  I tried one of the draft beers & loved it.  If I hadn't been driving I would have had more than one. :)
author: Christy L.

description: We ordered two pizzas, a deep dish and a thin crust, to go.  It still took over 30 minutes and cost over $50.  Eeeks!  Is this pizza truly worth it?  Our pizza was a little cold once we reached our friend's house, but it wasn't even close to the best pizza I've ever had.  The deep dish one was definitely better, with fresh sauce, basil, nice seasonings.  The crust was okay, but not spectacular, and we liked how it wasn't dripping in grease.  The thin crust was like "a cracker with cheese", as described by a member of our group.  I agreed.  I liked the fresh tomatoes, but it wasn't good enough to warrant eating another slice.  We has a lot of that pizza left.  I'm sure it would be much better hot, but I'm not impressed, especially at those prices.
author: Kari C.

description: Best deep dish pizza in the Bay Area with its cornmeal crust! Highly recommend the little star deep dish classic.
author: Sarah L.

description:
I love hipster pizza. Came on a really busy night and the host told us we might be better off coming back another time since they had just seated a huge group that was taking up much of the restaurant, but we told him we were content to wait and had beers. He then seemed to talk a bunch of other people into leaving, moving us up. It got to be about 50 minutes into it and he felt bad...so he brought us a complimentary garlic bread appetizer!
Overall...
The pizza was yum, a small salad is a large and it's really loud.
author: Nikki M.

description:
Best combination ever ....

Half Pesto Chicken w/o the Chicken and half White Pie, thin crust.  Who needs deep dish after this?

The Mission location is open for lunch!
author: Michael M.

description:
How did I miss a review on this place??  Here's my haiku to get in the upcoming Yelp Elite event at Patxi's:

"Little star deep dish, was orgasmically the best...Ooo food coma here I CUM ;)"

I would have to say that Little Star is my first experience of deep dish pizza.  It was orgasmic....pizza orgasmica does not even come close, im so so soooooo sorry!  This place is the TRUE pizza orgasmica *gasp*  I really don't like meat on my pizza but since I was in the company of other people it was a must to get a meaty deep dish.  So we did..."nommmmmy" (said num-me).  The only thing I would change on my next visit would that I ask for extra cheese and put it on top!  Oh and we also had the chicken, holy crap....so good, sooo sooo sooo good! finger licking good that is.  You can smell the aroma of bbq'd chicken--it was very very flavorful that I could've just ate it by myself.  Too bad I had to share.

I tried to go here another time and there was no parking....I was soooo mad that I had to settle for another pizza place.  Why can't good food places in San Francisco have parking lots?
author: Mary-Anne C.

description: Delish! Came here after a 9 hour birthday party picnic extravaganza in Dolores Park and there was only a 15 min wait around 8:30 pm on a Sat night. We were able to order in advance as well so def do that to cut down on wait time. We got the classic deep dish Little Star, which has spinach, ricotta and feta cheese, mushrooms, onions, and cloves of garlic. We got a large to split among 3 people and we had one slice left over. The pie was delicious, with just the right amount of melty cheese, mushrooms, and spinach to crust ratio. My mouth is watering just thinking about it again. The pizza is still delicious a day later as leftovers too! Would definitely come back!
author: Joyce H.

description:
I wish there was a half star option because I like Little Star but I wasn't floored. 

I have to admit that I am a Zachary's fan, so there was already some stiff competition.

Little Star is NOT Zachary's, so if you are going there expecting it, then you will be disappointed. There are similarities, yes, but it has a totally different taste (which is a good thing, presumably).

I liked the cornmeal on the crust, I thought it set the pizza apart from others. My boyfriend didn't like it too much.

It's not the cheapest place to get a pie, but it was decent for the price. We went on a Sunday afternoon, so there was no one there and no wait for a table. The only way to do it.

Previously we ordered a flat pizza to go. The flat pizza is a no-no. Don't even bother.
author: Inga B.

description:
Not sure why you're still bothering with breathing?
Need a good reason to justify future exercise?
Cornmeal crust?

Covered.
author: Kimberley D.

description:
LOVE LOVE the little star!  

Order before you even get a table...the wait is long but the pizza is worth it.  

A party of 3 on a Thursday night at 7...we ended up waiting for 1.5 hours...at 745 we ordered our pizza...at 830 we got seated and at 9 we got our pizza.  So glad we stopped by the corner store for a snack before we had dinner...because I would have been ready to eat my arm. 

Lesson learned...the wait is redonkulus...so now we just order to go and it hasn't failed us!
author: nancy b.

description:
FINALLY. After much waiting---literally in the restaurant and also in my lifetime--- I have eaten at Little Star Pizza. Was is worth it? YES.

AMBIANCE: Walking in, the first thing I see is a bar serving beer and wine to the mass of customers waiting for a table. The place is pretty loud and happening. It's a bit small but not uncomfortable. I like.

FOOD: There were two of us and we wanted variety so we got two small pizzas:

1. Brass Monkey: Little Star + Sausage + Deep Dish = Slice of Heaven. The crust is what makes this dish more special. It's so crunchy and baked perfectly. All the ingredients are fresh. Honestly, I don't eat much deep dish so I have little to compare to. Nevertheless, this is one of the best deep dish pizzas I've had.

2. Pesto Chicken: Crust!! Again, the same quality crust as the Brass Monkey. The pizza is topped with chicken, mushrooms, and onions and drizzled with pesto sauce. Very appealing to both the eye and the stomach.

PRICE: Normally, you'd probably spend about $10-15 a person. We spent a bit more, since we got two pizzas for two people. Even though a whole pizza may look small, it's definitely enough to fill your belly. 

SERVICE: The wait for a table can be brutal. We had a 45 minute wait on a Friday night, so we walked around the Mission to kill time. The waiters are super friendly here. You definitely feel welcomed into the establishment.

THE BOTTOM LINE: Best pizza in town? It comes close. I am debating between Gaspare's and Little Star Pizza. But then again, why argue when you can have both. =D
author: Jonathan L.

description:
i don't usually eat pizza.. like ever, because the taste of most is never worth the calories. but i will gladly make an exception with little star. the pizza here is the BEST I'VE EVER HAD. Deep dish absolutely blows my mind. i love everything about the pizzas, but nothing as much as the CRUST. the crust is so divine. i could eat the crust... by itself. i have no idea what they put in it, but it has the perfect taste and texture. buttery, flakey, and all kinds of other delicious descriptors. 

the only downfall is probably the fact that this place is teeny tiny and doesn't accept reservations. BUT.... honestly i dont care. the wait is not egregious as it is at say... sf's hottest brunch spots, so i can manage. plus if you come on a weekday, the wait is virtually nonexistent. ORRRR my favorite solution. TAKEOUT. Come with a friend so that you drop em off, circle the block, then pick them up with your yummy pizza and head home to devour that ish. 

okay. this is probably one of my more long posts... but as you can see, i'm very passionate about the pizza that i do eat. SOOOO glad i live close to this place. see you soon LSP!!!! xo
author: Jennifer O.

description:
One of my favorite places for pizza in the city. The pizza is oh-so-good and great beer/wine options. The only downside is the wait. We got there around 8pm and didn't get seated until almost 9pm, but it's definitely worth the wait!

Food:
- Mixed Salad: just a salad, vinaigrette dressing is good and light
- Spicy Chicken Wings: hella good & spicy! Not a fan of the blue cheese dip though
- Special Pizza of the Day: mozza, tomatoes, and other veggies, thin crust, lots of toppings (didn't get to eat a slice but it looked good)
- Pesto Chicken thin crust: simple, good ratio of toppings to crust, but the crust is my favorite! nice and crispy, not too thin or thick, nice texture
- Mediterranean Chicken & Classic deep dish: good corn meal crust, lots of sauce & cheese. not that big of a fan of deep dish, i prefer thin crust.

Beers:
- Great White: perfect beer for me! light, hint of sweetness, smooth
- Stout dark beer:chocolately
- Cider: absolutely clear, looks like water, light and sweet but not too sweet, very fruity

Our server was great! The food was good. No complaints besides the wait. Until next time Little Star!
author: Linda C.

description: Great deep dish pizza!!! I love their cornmeal crust. Should come here and give it a shot at least once ;)
author: Catherine T.

description:
Why is this place the best pizza in SF?  

becuz cornmeal crust!!!!

It's tough to make deep dish that doesn't feel like cement in your belly, but this place acheives that and more.
author: BringMy C.

description: God, it's good. I rarely even eat pizza, but the crust on the deep dish is so delicious. A bit crowded at times, but I like the rustic feel as well. From the outside it probably doesn't look open but that's just their thing I guess.
author: Roxy B.

description:
Ducked in the other day to escape the rain and ended up having some of the most fantastic pizza this side of the U.S.  Coincidentally, I was in the company of some pretty large pizza snobs from the east coast. 

However, after they sampled a slice of the Pesto Chicken thin crust pizza they were left speechless without any snide remarks to make about how you can't truly have a pizza on the west coast due to the alkaline water.'

I was completely shocked at how empty the joint was. You would think that pizza this good would have people clamoring to be let in. Oh well, guess that just means I won't have to wait as long the next time I swing by:]
author: Kevin T.

description:
Let's get the negatives out of the way.  Parking sucks.  The wait staff was inattentive.  The beer selection is limited.  The wings are OK and have good spice.  The pizza? it's not as good as Zachary's.  Shut up, it's not and you know it.  Still, it is good pizza, so I'm still awarding three stars, just for the pizza.

The positives?  If you live in the Mission or nearby, you don't have to travel all the way to Oakland for good deep-dish.  Plus, you look oh-so-cool waiting in line with all your hipster friends, right?
author: dan s.

description:
It was good. Only disappointment is it was really small for a large and barely any cheese. Also, it was hella hard to find it's location. It look like it was cracking in there when I went to pick up the pizza. 
Overall it was okay.
author: Matthew C.

description:
Twinkle twinkle, baby.  Twinkle, twinkle. 

Friday night, feeling like some pizza and beer.  Our friends suggested Little Star.  Never been, but heard so much about the place.  After our 1 hour wait, we were itching for some delicious pizza pie.

We ordered:
- Caprese Salad - One order is enough for 4 ppl.  The mozzarella and tomatoes were SO good and refreshing.  There was something about the balsamic vinegar and EVOO, made me want to lick the bowl clean.

- Classic Deep Dish (large) - Good thing we ordered the large, b/c we each had pizza babies in our tummies that night.  The sausage was incredible.  I don't know what they do with that bread, but it was the best crust I have ever had - fluffy and crunchy, so good!

Better than Zachery's - there, I said it.

- Thin Crust White Pie (small) - Mr. O loved this one.   It was great, but I personally like red sauce pizzas.  The tomatoes and zucchini kicked butt on this one. 

The others washed it down with a few glasses of Boont Amber Ale at $4 a glass, and I had a pear cider (yeah yeah...I like pretty, sparkly drinks).  The entire bill, including tax and tip came out to $75.

I'll be back, Little Star.  I'll be back.
author: Stella K.

description:
My first time here was ok but second was great. I ll explain later


We ordered a large half/half
 half little star and half classic the little star which has feta cheese and spinach was excellent . The classic had green peppers and sausage it was ok.

So I think this experience was better than my first because our first time  we had a custom deep dish with sausage pepporoni and mushrooms.  I think that veggie toppings on a deep dish is somehow better...

 Something about meat on the deep dish didn't make little star impressionable. Maybe it's cuz it's too heavy by itself . I can't put my finger on it ...

Be prepared to wait 30 min for the deep dish

Service was cool and friendly.

I'll be back maybe for
Thin crust
author: DOM d.

description: Only been here for take out but was really impressed.  We ordered a thin crust pesto chicken and the crust was crispy but chewy, and the pizza had a ton of ingredients.  The chicken wasn't overcooked, and there was just the right amount of pesto.  Thoroughly enjoyed it.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Yum! At 8 pm on Sunday, we were seated as soon as our entire party arrived (no waiting). The mixed green salad had gorgonzola and walnuts.  The "Classic"pizza was composed of a crisp buttery crust, chunks of fresh tomatoes, cheese, sausage, and bell peppers. One pie is enough for four people. Plus a good selection of fizzy drinks: limonata, aranciata, henry weinhard's root beer.  Unfortunately they were out of the cheese cake, but perhaps by that point, we'd had enough of cheese!

Hipster retro dim interior.  Aromatherapy candle in the bathroom.  Really friendly service.

When you're standing woefully outside Pauline's when it's closed Sunday night, go down the block for outstanding deep dish.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
It's really closer to a four star rating.

Someone brought some deep dish pizzas from this place, and it was INCREDIBLE.  Not only because it was free, but it's been a long while since I've had a tasty deep dish.  But just to make sure, I had to try it out for myself.  I was partially right.  It wasn't the same pizza from the party, but I should've known that since the guy who brought it probably got the hook up.

That's not to say the pizza wasn't good:  PIZZA GOOD.

The place itself is not in the best of neighborhoods but not the worst either.  It doesn't matter.  Once you get inside (and please don't sit by the window since people will stare at you from outside), it's quiet a pleasant atmosphere.  It's gets loud but in a comfortable way, as in everyone is having a good time way, and you don't have to scream to be heard.  The staff is friendly and attentive.

The funny thing is I've never had pizza that tasted so good the day after.
author: Dan B.

description:
My vocabulary isn't  advanced enough to describe how much I love Little Star Pizza.

That's all.
author: Matthew P.

description:
Little Star is the Holy Grail of pizzas. The crust is amazing- I dream about that cornmeal crust. The classic is my favorite, and the little star is not too far behind. I'm no vegetarian, but I enjoy the vegetarian pizza quite a bit too. The sauce is fantastic and the toppings are all great- the sausage in the classic is really what seals the deal for me. A lot of people I know spend a lot of time debating whether Little Star is better or Zachary's in Berkeley. If you've been to Zachary's, then you'll know that this is quite a bold statement. I personally can't choose which one is better. The crust at Little Star is better I think, but it's pretty tough to beat the deep dish chicken pizza at Zach's. You decide for yourself.

I like the Valencia location a little better than the Divisadero restaurant because of the size. Valencia seems a little bigger and so the wait is usually a lot shorter. It's also better lit, so you don't feel like you're walking around in the dark. The pizza is pretty standard-priced for chicago-style pizza.
author: Tyler C.

description: I really love the sauce at Little Star. It has a rich tomato flavor with that slight hint of sweetness I love. They make a really wonderful crust that's super crisp on the outside and soft and chewy on the inside. Best of all, the sauce to topping to crust ratio on the deep dish pizza is perfect. Good service and a nice ambience add to the experience. Highly recommended.
author: Nicole M.

description:
My party of 3  waited about 40 minutes (on a Monday night!)  for a table but the food was worth the wait.

We were with a vegetarian / non-sauce eater, so naturally I was worried about our options. We ordered a delicious white pizza with roasted zucchini and feta. Perfectly seasoned and cheesy, definitelyt not too buttery or salty as white pizzas can so often be. We also ordered the SF sourdough garlic bread (with a whole bulb of roasted garlic - it was fun to pop out the little cloves). 

Will definitely be back to try the meat / deep sish options!
author: caitlin m.

description:
Quick Review:  Really Good food...just okay on service.

Detailed: I came here with my cousins and we loved the pizza. We were trying to figure out what the crust tasted like.  "A little sweet...cornbread?" No that's not right.  "Hushpuppies?"  I can see where you get that, but no..."I got it!" says my cousin. "It tastes like the last little piece of bread on a corn dog...you know, the piece that stays on the stick"  PERFECT description.

So our pizza was a Chicago style pie that had spinach, onions, garlic, and sausage.  The spinach was perfect...not soggy at all, and definitely fresh.  The sausage was sooo good, as well.  Put together, this pie was excellent.  We were definitely happy with the food (also the wheat beer they had on tap here was excellent.)

The service...ahh, not so much.  Our waitress seemed like she was just going through the motions and had no personality whatsoever.  She seemed like she did not want to be there.  One thing that struck us as a little inconsiderate was that when they delivered our appetizer salad they only had two pieces of bread with that.  There was three of us...why would you only give us two pieces of bread?

Overall, I would come back, because the food was really good, but I really hope they pay closer attention to service next time.
author: David C.

description:
After 27 years of living in the Bay Area, I finally got my first taste of the infamous deep-dish Little Star Pizza tonight.  Long overdue, right?

My friend and I arrived around 6:30 after a brief walk from the 16th and Mission Bart station, and fortunately, we were able to get a table before the big dinner rush came at 7.  We were greeted promptly with menus and waters as we deliberated what kind of pizza we wanted.  When our waitress informed us that the pizza takes about half an hour to make, we opted for the garlic bread to keep us occupied.

I suppose you can call Little Star's version of garlic bread as "deconstructed."  A loaf of pre-sliced bread is in the middle, and then a whole bulb of roasted garlic and butter are on the side.  It was a bit of an adventure to extract the cloves out of the garlic and spread it along the bread slice, but I've never seen that presentation anywhere else.

Let's not kid ourselves here: the star of the show is the pizza, and the headliner, as many Yelpers have commented, is the crust.  Normally, the crust is the worst part of the pizza whose purpose is to just hold the toppings together, but Little Star's crust is much more than that.  It actually has taste and crunch, thanks to the cornmeal that they blend in there.  I bet that if they served the crust by itself as an appetizer--just the crust--people would go bonkers over it.  It's that good, folks.

We went for the large, which is eight slices, and both of us managed to chow down three each.  The waitress gave us each a box to go, handed us our check, and back home we went.

Thank you, Little Star, for waking me out of my Yelp review hibernation with your version of an awesome deep-dish pizza.  Now I need to make a trip to Chicago to compare!
author: Marlon E.

description:
Hey vegans,  looking for  a pie of non-dairy goodness?

Little Star is your answer for a no holds barred thin crust with just the right amount  of sauce and the freshest toppings.  

After bike riding meltdown #8 the dr. and i found ourselves parking our bikes outside of Little Star with the intention of checking out Pica Pica across the street.  (We'll definitely be visiting Pica Pica soon) The  doors of Little Star called though.  Actually, beer was callling.  My nerves were shot as cars whizzed by me on Market St. 

Being a new biker who fears an untimely death really sucks.

Even though the restaurant was wide open we sat at the bar and one beer turned into several (lost count!) turned into ordering a large pie and finishing it.  How could we not?  Roasted whole cloves of garlic, artichoke hearts, zucchini, mushrooms, all sorts of heaven.

We chatted with the staff and they were friendly as all get out (don't understand the 1-star reviews about the attitude here, we didn't experience any at all!).  

Beer and Pizza definitely made riding home a lot less stressful.

Thanks for making an awesome vegan pie and the friendly service!  I'd live in your oven if you'd let me.
author: Jen I.

description:
Twinkle, twinkle Little Star, how I wonder what amazing-yummy pizza you are. 

That said and out of the way, this is as good as it will ever get for deep-dish pizza outside of Chicago (which I've yet to try, oh but it's coming soon). Not only are the ingredients fresh, but you can taste each individually with any pizza you order. Oh, and the sauce, oh dear God, THE SAUCE. As far as Little Star Pizza goes, its namesake (The little star deep dish) speaks more loudly than the people sitting across from you, and bursts with more flavor than Skittles coming out of a freakin' rainbow. 

This location being the site of a very special second date with a very special someone, also has a place in my heart as truly outstanding. It's loud, it's busy, it's fun. 

Thin crust pizza was also delicious. 

I give up, just GO, what are you waiting for?
author: Ben G.

description:
Great place to come and have some beer and pizza!

Little Star doesn't have your 'pizza joint' feel.  It leans more sit down/classy pub, but still feels like a place you can come hang out and relax.  They are known for their deep dish pizza, so we got a couple of those along with some chicken wings.  It was good, but the best deep dish pizza I've ever had is still Zachary's Pizza in Berkeley!

Don't get me wrong, everything at Little Star was good.  I have no real complaints.  It wasn't my favorite.  Both the wings and the pizza were just off the mark and short of a 'wow.'  The food was a 3.5, but the beer selection and experience gave it a 4.
author: Nadiyah S.

description: Usually this place is great but little did i know about their delivery service.  I ordered 2 pizzas and ended up paying over $60. Wtf? $20 delivery fee? ? And i waited over an hour plus when it finally arrived,  it was fuck8ng cold! ! Horrible delivery service. Guess it was my own fault for  being lazy and not going in to pick it up. Now i know! !
author: Graham K.

description:
Had the Classic deep dish and the pesto chicken thin crust pizza 2 days ago and I cannot stop thinking about it!!

It's that good! 

Try to dine in. Pizza tastes much better. The wait is worth it!
author: Molly T.

description: The pizza was advertised as Chicago style pizza and was very delicious. I love the hip vibe of the place and the staff was extremely friendly! I only gave it four stars because I felt the wings were pitched to be better than what they were. Don't get me wrong, they were good, but not the "Best wings you'll eat."
author: Bradley V.

description:
We've had take-out many times and finally went in person with family from out of town. The service was really great. They were out of the cocktail I ordered so the bartender came right over and apologized to me for being out of that cocktail and offered to make me anything custom that I would like. As always the pizza was divine. We had the Little Star deep-dish and the Classic thin crust. Delish.

If I could do anything to improve upon the ambiance to match the perfection of the pizza I would say find a way to make the bar area less crowded and chaotic for putting your name on the table list and do something about the grayish-blue tint to the lighting. I'm a big fan of warm glowy light and the lighting in the restaurant could use a little more yellow and orange and gold to the glow.
author: Kelly S.

description:
I liked their Chicago style deep dish pizza more than the deep dish I ate in Chicago!!

My favorite pizza place!!! Always jammed pack but you can order and pick up instead for home. Get the "little star" deep dish pizza... Although no meat in this option for a meat lover like me, I think it's the best effin pizza ever!! 

Always need to order the spicy chicken wings w blue cheese dressing too to nibble on while waiting for my slice of heaven.

Sister restaurant called Blueline w similar menu in Burlingame and Campbell for those in the Peninsula and South Bay.
author: A. Z.

description: If it wasn't for our server Ian I would have given this place negative stars. The kitchen was running behind or forgot our order who knows but Ian was on top of things. He comped our appetizer for the delay and was prompt with our drinks. He was checking in our table making sure we were are ok an hour later our pizza was at out table I would have normally cancelled my order after waiting so long, but Ian literally saves the day ;)
author: Leslie C.

description:
I don't get it? This place was mediocre at best. The pizza was heavy and covered in cornmeal (used to release from oven but this much? Come on!), yuck! The toppings were alright but lacked the heft they should have had by lack of quantity. 

It pains me to say this but Pizzeria Uno is so much better and its a chain, yuck! 

However, salad was very good.. service was even better!
author: Alexander C.

description: I have tried authentic chicago style pizza from chicago, and let me tell you, this is as close as its gonna get. I have had Zachary's from berkeley, and Little star pretty much takes the cake...or the pie/pizza pie. lame. anyways, the 7x7 SF list says brass monkey is what you gotta try, and that is the poo, and I'll gladly take a big whiff. The sauce is smothered all over that pizza like bbq on a big ol booty. the ingredients, uber delicious. the crust is the piece de resistance. so delicious that its ridiculous. I love this place, and the only thing I don't like is that I don't go there enough. San Francisco Staple for sure
author: Alvin P.

description: Excellent pizza. It was crowded, but we only had to wait about 15 mins for our table on a Saturday night and we were able to grab some wine at the bar while we waited. The vegetarian pizza was fresh, hot, and tasty. It wasn't overstuffed- definitely had the right amount of vegetables, sauce, crust, everything. Will definitely be back :D
author: Vinitha R.

description: I know this place is known for their pizza, and it was good, but it didn't knock my socks off.  The sauce could have been a bit more zesty, and the thick crust had that grainy texture yuppies like (am I dating myself?).  I've had better pizza in New York, Chicago (deep dish), and frankly, even LA and Orange County.  But it was still good, but slightly pricey.  The caprese salad was solid.
author: Gregory N.

description:
I'm craving Little Star as I write this. Came here on a Friday night around 745 pm with a 45 min wait. Not too bad, for a place where reservations cannot be made. Definitely worth the wait. 

We got a large half classic, half little star. Classic won hands down for me. The slices were huge and filling, and smothered with sauce. And the crust... The crust was the piece de resistance. So delicious and I'm not usually a fan of pizza crusts. 

I can't wait to come back again!
author: Kimberly F.

description:
I've only had take-out from here and I'm a fan. Pizza is always so perfect and fresh either eaten immediately or hours after. Salad is good here too, simple mixed green salad with balsamic vinaigrette. Cheesecake from here is just plain amazing. Deep dish pizza is delicious with a cornmeal crust being the perfect foundation for the plethora of toppings. 

Every time I have a meal from here, I slip into a happy food coma.
author: Tracy N.

description:
Everytime I hear the words "Little", "Star" and "Pizza" in the same sentence my eyes grow deer-wide and I start to drool. 

This is what this place has done to me. If you don't want to fall in love and develop a relationship with this restaurant, then never come here. RUN!!

haha Classical Deep Dish pizza and Spicy chicken wings, this is what Ive always ordered so far.

There is usually a little wait, time enough to have a beer or a glass of wine.
author: Gerardo C.

description: Food may be good but service is one of the worst.  Ignored when we walked in.  Waiters were very unattentive and not friendly despite a relatively empty place.
author: Greg S.

description:
This place deserves five stars IF you were eating their pizza at the comfort of your home.

I have been to Little Star on several occasions and it seems that each time I go the service gets slower, the staff get worse, and the music gets louder.  The servers all act like they do not want to be there and it shows with their attitude.  The music is way to loud, and it is extremely hard to talk without shouting. The whole environment sucks.

On a positive note, the pizza is delicious whether its deep or thin crust it's full of flavor.  The crust is unique and extremely taste, it perfects the pizza in my opinion.  They use cornmeal in it which gives it the extra kick. 

But in the end the overall package is not worth it, I would rather go to Zachary's in Oakland or Pizzeria Delfina on 18th.
author: Hanna A.

description:
I love love love this pizza.
It truly has changed my whole pizza world, which kinda sux b/c its hard to find a pizza to compare.
The Little Star pizza is the bomb. As is the pesto chicken, I also love their garden salad and garlic bread..Yumm!
author: Laura B.

description:
Deep dish deliciousness. Dim lighting, cool music to listen to as you wait (there seems to be a following, hence lines) couches and chair waiting area by the window. Takeout section at the end of the bar and the bartender was friendly and prompt. 

Now for pizza talk: Ordered the tin crust white pizza, and the deep dish little star. Holy moly mother of pizza goodness. (repeat loudly) Something about the crusty/flaky/cornmeal parts combines with wholesome, fresh, ingredients that just did for me. Also got a pesto salad, a simple, salad with romaine, pesto dressing, and almonds. 
Utterly refreshing and if you know me, I love occasional champagne, but golly gee, this made me rethink the word occasional.
author: Stephanie H.

description: The only place in SF where a former Chicagoan can get a really good deep dish pizza. Love the cheese & spinach combination!
author: Juls M.

description:
This place has delicious pizza! I was weary upon coming here because it was pizza; I could have gone to Pizza Orgasmica for good pizza. However, after trying their deep dish pizza, I became a fan. The crust was so crispy and after having 2 and a half huge slices of mouth orgasms, I didn't even feel heavy or bloated. Overall a great experience. 

P.S. this place is very small, so be prepared to feel like sardines.
author: Kevin D.

description:
Whenever pizza is the topic, I like to start by saying I'm a stark, raving conservative about one thing in this wacky world and that's pizza.  Crust, sauce, cheese... I'm of the mind that these elements are not merely vehicles for toppings so when I ordered both a 12" thin crust and a 12" deep dish I wanted to taste what everyone was so excited about.

Turns out, not many kind things can I say about it.

The deep dish crust was perfectly flat up the sides and that made it far too crispy.  Cause I love you all, I'm going to set that aside as maybe just a flaw suffered only by 12" pizzas at Little Star and move on to talk about the crust in general.   The cornmeal imparted it's usual gritty texture - which sucks, in case you were wondering :).  I understand how cornmeal can help slide a pizza out of an oven or pan and I don't care, it's unpleasant and adds no discernible flavor, so 86 that.  The crust taste was okay but nothing in particular stood out, save for a hint of butter.  The texture was meh, especially of the thin crust, I can't imagine anyone NOT pushing the crusts of their thin pizza slice to shame-side of the plate.

Little Star's pizza sauce needs some more zing.  It could benefit from more garlic and a bit of a sweet under-taste to go along with the tangy tomato (like basil, or sweeter tomatoes).  It could also use a savory spice.  Little Star does sprinkle with oregano and a healthy, welcomed amount of powdered cheese of some kind, but that aint making me wanna lick it off my plate.  The thin crust had only a whisper of sauce beneath the cheese which quickly dried into red paint.  While the deep dish had the perfect amount of sauce, it failed on having enough cheese.

Zachary's and Patxi's have much better tasting crust and sauce.  Yes, both places are known for their stuffed pizzas - you don''t gotta get up all in my face to remind me of the differences.  Flavor, texture. You feelin' me?  If the basic elements aren't strong, it don't matter what you stuff it with or throw on top.  

The restaurant itself is pretty cool.  I personally dig the brick wall and dark furniture, the ambiance is unlike most any other pizza place.  Hipster crowds?  Well, yeah... welcome to the Valencia corridor!  And I suspect your money is as green as theirs. 

TL;DR version for the ADD crowd:  if what lies beneath a pizza is really important to your oral pizza pleasure, then I can't recommend Little Star.
author: Ben S.

description:
I've been to Little Star twice; once after a concert at the Independent (around 10pm) and again the day of Bay to Breakers (around 3:30pm).  I say this because this review doesn't consider the experience during "peak" times.  I haven't yet seen the line around the corner.

Another disclaimer:  I have Lou Malnati's delivered to my door (Lou's is widely considered the ultimate Chicago Deep Dish pizza).  So, I'd consider my palate trained as to how a Chicago pizza should taste.

Cut to the chase - Little Star is NOT a replacement for a Chicago Style pizza.  It just doesn't have enough of what's bad for you in it (aka grease).  That being said, it's still delicious - you get the stuffed pizza experience minus a little of the guilt that comes with eating cups-worth of grease that usually accompanies a Chicago pizza.

Service:  The first time, service was just right - and there were just two of us so we quickly got seated at a high top.  The second time, we had a party of four.  There really aren't many tables and the pies take 30 minutes to make, so we avoided the quoted wait time by sitting at the bar.  It took us 15 minutes to put in our drink order - we had to jump up and down to put in a second drink order mid-meal and our order was wrong.  

All said and done, we'll go back to Little Star if we are looking for a long wait time - otherwise we'll order take out, have Malnati's delivered, or head down to Windy City in San Mateo to get our Chicago-pie fix.
author: Heather L.

description:
When I have a (rare) craving for deep dish pizza, Little Steezy is it.  Love that cornmeal-dusted crust and juicy sausage filling. Wings are yummy too.
In the great deep dish pizza rivalry between Zachary's and Little Star, I go with the upstart.
author: teray g.

description:
Can i just say deep dish heaven??? Definitely one of my fave pizza's around SF! I go here cause its closer to where i live but the first time you'll drive by here you might not even notice it cause its at the corner in between this buildings that wont look like there's place to eat so kinda got lost for a moment. The place is good perfect for small talks and cathing up with friends since its not loud and love the workers! very friendly!
Little star pizza is def a try i added meat into it so good with a perfect pair of cabernet!
author: Nikka L.

description:
Excellent atmosphere, excellent authentic Chicago style deep dish pizza.

Plan to arrive early or wait, prices are very reasonable.

Best pizza in SF!
author: Daniel M.

description:
We ordered a large thin crust WHITE PIE, a large deep dish CLASSIC, and a small deep dish VEGETARIAN.  There were 4 guys and 1 girl, and we could have ordered more.  We should have ordered a large vegetarian.  The pizzas were smaller than what we expected.  The slices are definitely not as big as Patxis, but I recommend it over Patxis.  Just know that you're going to need to order more to fill you up.  
The best pizza of the night was the vegetarian.  We all agreed it was, hands down, way more flavorful than the classic pizza with meat.  It was less saucy and more cheesy.  You could actually taste the ingredients, like garlic and olives.  I would definitely go back and order the vegetarian, even though I'm a meat-eater.
author: rose h.

description: This place upset me tonight. I came in and put my name down. My friends and I waited patiently at the bar. A random friend that I invited earlier (who never RSVPed with me) showed up after we waited for about 45 minutes, increasing our party size by one. I approached the hostess and let her know our party grew. She was very rude. She said "that's not how we do things. I am just going to put you on the list as if you hadn't waited, and it will now be at least an hour." She talked to me like I was a bad little boy who needed to be put in a corner with a duncecap. Honestly, different places have different policies, but the bottom line is you don't have to be rude. I have always sang Little Star's praises. Unfortunately, I have to change my tune.
author: Andrew K.

description:
From the outside, this restaurant looked closed. The windows were black and it looked dark inside. Just push the door to go in and it's quite loud and lively in there! Their bar is right at the front!

Our 40 min wait for a table for 2 turned out to be 15 mins! It was indeed very crowded in this small restaurant. A lot of people did take out. We ordered the garlic bread and white pie. I was expecting the garlic bread to already have garlic and butter on it. But when the appetizer came out, I was very surprised and confused to see a cup of butter, a whole roasted garlic with the top cut off and a small loaf of pre-sliced bread. They should rename it to a loaf of bread and garlic. I really liked the white pie! It was a very crunchy thin crust 12-inch pizza with thin slices of zucchini and tomatoes with cheese!! All this was very filling for 2 people. We also got some beer because they were having a Mission Holiday Block Party special. I really enjoyed the Great White Lager. It reminds me a lot of pale ale. Their IPA was ok, but it almost tasted like a chinese sauce... hoesin sauce.

The atmosphere was extremely loud. It was very difficult to hear and talk to the person across the table. I felt I was yelling the whole time and asking, "What did you say?" But good quick service and friendly staff! I really want to try the pesto chicken next time! :)
author: CeCe C.

description: Hands down my favorite pizza in SF!  The cornmeal crust makes Little Star deep dish better than both Patxi's and Zachary's.  I have called in orders for pick-up several times and they almost always have the order ready on time.  But beware - because each slice of deep dish pizza is so delicious and looks small, you may find yourself wolfing down more than your stomach can handle and passing out from food coma afterwards!
author: Beatrice W.

description:
I love perspective.  

I especially love perspective when I get to use it to my advantage.  

Example?

In SF, I am a slightly pudgy (i prefer "lovable chunky") dude yet in Chicago, compared to all the fat bastards walking around, I am a svelte piece of tanned California beef.

Even the pigeons are overweight.  

They look like NFL footballs with wings.  

So it makes perfect sense that Chicago would invent a pizza that, even in a small size, weighs more than my head.  

Little Star makes a mean deep dish but take that with a grain of salt.

I have no idea what makes a good deep dish pizza since I don't eat them that often.

You know, because while in Chicago I might be Jon Favreau, in SF, I am a more of a John Goodman.  

It's worth a trip down there but do what I do, get it to go and bring it home - the wait is sometimes insane.

Mass.
author: Archie R.

description:
I love this place. 

Pizza the way pizza is supposed to be made.

If you're looking for an authentic quality pizza place that doesn't try to be something its not, look no further than Little Star Pizza. I try to visit every time I'm in San Francisco.

In addition to Pizza, their Mozzarella and Tomato salad is wonderful.
author: Joshua G.

description: The deep dish pizza here is amazing! When I order deep dish pizza at other places I usually have to wait 30-45 mins... But no here we got our pizza in about 20. How awesome!
author: Carlos G.

description: A very solid version of Chicago-style pizza.  Great crust and sauce, and it smells wonderful as soon as you walk in!  As good as I've found outside Chicago.
author: jeremy d.

description:
If I had to have one food every day for the rest of my life, the brass monkey at little star would be it for me. The Brass Monkey pizza is not on the menu, but it is the little star + meat (a friend filled me in on this gem). The feta cheese is really what sets this pizza apart from their other deep dish options. 

Their deep dish pizza's are not the only item on the menu that is delish, If you are going for a regular, thin crust pizza, go for their white pie. YUM! It is a salt aficionado's dream food. Perfect saltiness to tingle the taste buds. I wish I had some riight now! Oh, and their wings are also pretty tasty.
author: Erin A.

description: This is hands down the best deep dish pizza I have had and the ambience is great.
author: Brooke H.

description:
When I moved to SF I was astonished by this city's lack of anything resembling good pizza. Everyone kept telling me GO TO LITTLE STAR. So finally I went, with the promise of real Chicago style deep dish. No dice Little Star, no dice.

The servers were friendly enough, and I suppose for a pizza place they have what would qualify as "ambiance" (being seated close enough to your neighbors to hear their mundane conversation, and having to squint to see your pizza in the candlelight.) But $20 for the small pizza is absurd. This thing is maybe an inch bigger than a Pizza Hut personal pan pizza.

The flavor was okay, although there were mushrooms on the pizza we ordered which was not indicated by the menu and I'm not a mushroom fan so I wasn't thrilled. This wasn't a bad pizza by any means, but it wasn't worth $20 and it didn't resemble anything close to Chicago style. They are using some kind of corn meal to give the crust a firmness, when really it should be more like pastry. I enjoyed the root beer more than this pizza. Our server was far more interested in asking my dining companion about her tattoos than bringing us our check. Hint: if all parties seated at a table are checking their text messages, they are done. 

All in all this wasn't a bad pizza, but it's not authentic Chicago style and isn't worth the price.
author: Beth D.

description:
Veggie pizza w/ sausage on 1 side and pepperoni on the other: 5/5
Wait staff: 5/5
Atmosphere: 5/5

Yummmmmmm! A small deep dish between 2 people is the perfect amount of food... Though their salads did look delicious...
author: Jodie B.

description:
The best deep dish pizza I've ever had, bar none.

The crush is buttery, crunchy, and has a delicious cornmeal dust to it.  Absolutely the best deep dish crust I've ever had. 

We ordered three deep dish pizzas: a classic, a little star, and a mediterranean.  They were all awesome, but I think the little star was my favorite.  The combination of ricotta and feta was just amazing.  

They have a decent selection of beer and wine on tap, the service is great, the atmosphere is great, blah blah blah.  The five stars is for the pizza.  It's seriously that good.
author: Jace P.

description:
Super awesome!!  A girl took me their for our second date, and it was a great choice.  Excellent pizza & salads ... and a great vibe.

"Intimate" is an understatement - you're literally packed-in their like sardines.  And that's why it's fun.  If you're sitting along the wall, they actually have to scoot you're neighbors table over about 1 foot, just so that you can squeeze in .... and then the move the table back.

Unfortunately, this place is probably bad for large groups ... it's so packed I doubt if they'd even wait for 8 neighboring seats to open-up to seat your 8-person party.  On the flip side, it's great for a 2-person date.
author: Michael B.

description: My first time here and I'm here for lunch.  They weren't too crowded so they were able to make  a deep-dish pizza in 20 minutes.  And it was so delicious.  The waitress was nice and very attentive too!
author: Joe C.

description:
I'm no pizza aficionado, especially when it comes to deep dish; I just know what tastes good, and Little Star blew my palate away. Every list I checked of San Francisco musts included Little Star, so I wasn't surprised to wait 20 or so minutes for a table. However, the mellow, pleasant vibes our waiter exuded made that time worth it. 

My companion and I split a small mixed salad, comprising greens, cherry tomatoes, red bell peppers, Gorgonzola cheese crumbles, walnuts and a light house dressing. Because it was so tasty and full of textural interest, I've already tried to recreate this salad at home. 

Our waiter misunderstood our order, as he brought us a large classic deep dish as opposed to the small we requested. While we would've loved to leave with leftovers, my travel partner and I were hitting up a show after dinner and didn't want to have to hold a container in the middle of a hipster music mob. The pizza's toppings included sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers and onions, along with a delicious tomato sauce piled heavily on top. Like I said, I'm no pizza guru, but I found the delivery of sauce on top of all the other strata interesting. The thin crust reminded me of an apple pie Pillsbury crust but left substantial room for layer upon layer of cheese, toppings and the incredible sauce I wish I could slather on my face again. 

A small pie would've been perfect for us, as our salad and two slices apiece left us satisfied but not stuffed. Our waiter suggested we offer our remainders to a homeless person, as innumerable people live on San Francisco's streets. Ironically, a man pushing a grocery cart stood just outside Little Star's entrance when we left, so I sadly gave him our deep dish delicacy. Hopefully he ate the leftovers I would've loved to devour myself.
author: Bobbin W.

description:
Admitting that I'm not all that partial to deep dish pizza,* I still enjoyed my meal at Little Star.  

We started with the BBQ wings, which had  decent amount of meat to them as well as a bit of a kick.  This was probably the best item of the meal.  

We then proceed to the Little Star and the Mediterranean Chicken pizzas.  The cornmeal crust on both was interesting, from both a texture and flavor standpoint.  The Mediterranean was very underwhelming, the flavors barely distinguishing themselves either individually or in concert with their counterparts.  The Little Star was much better; the mixture of feta and ricotta added a pleasantly creamy contrast to the crunch of the crust.

Service was decent and the prices fair.  

Overall, very good pizza but nothing I would be especially eager to get at again.

* I once visited the original Pizzeria Uno in Chicago and my friends were aghast when I could only muster the enthusiasm to sample a single bite and no more.
author: Christopher R.

description: I LOVE Little Star. Get the deep dish "little star" pizza. This is my favorite pizza in the Bay Area. I like it better than Zachary's. I know pizza style is a very personal thing, but if you like deep dish cornmeal crust pizza you will probably love Little Star too. (Don't be suckered in by the shorter wait for the thin crust pizza ...if you want good thin crust pizza go to Delfina)
author: A R.

description:
My brother has become a yelper and doesn't even have an account. He was "yelping" for deep dish pizza places in the city and Little Star came up. After reading the reviews, he was convinced that we needed to try the place.

We didn't dine in though, picked up, as we had a house full of people awaiting some pizza goodness.

Parking is a pain the butt, busy busy busy area. So I drove and circled as he went in. We were hoping to call in the order at 4:30 so that we could pick up at 5, when they opened. They answered the phone at 4, but still said the pizzas wouldn't go in until 5 when they opened. Pfft. But they were ready when they said they would be ready, 5:30.

We ordered a large deep dish classic. Which was just okay to me. Seemed a bit undercooked to me. The cheese at the bottom wasn't even melted. And albeit we travelled a bit, the sauce on the top was cold and overpowering. 

We also ordered a large pesto chicken! Grubbin! Love the presentation. Will have to post photos of it later. Loved that the pesto was "contained" and not spread out all over the crust. My kind of pizza! But then again I've always loved pesto on my pizzas. The corn meal crust was yummy, loved the crunch of it all.

It is pricey, my brother said it looked yuppy inside. But he's convinced he wants to try again! As long as he's footing the bill I'm there.
author: Dina V.

description:
I am OBSESSED with Chicago style pizza. It all started when I lived in Berkeley and had Zachary's and it was the most amazing thing ever. Well, then I moved to the South Bay and found Paxti's and was amazed again. Little did I know that I would be swept off my feet!! Little Star is actually pretty different than both Zachary's and Paxti's. At the other two places, I always would get the whole wheat crust, so when I ordered from Little Star I asked for the same, but they advised that their crust is cornmeal so we couldn't get whole wheat. BOY am I happy! The cornmeal crust was to DIE for. I mean I really can't explain how delicious this pizza is, you really just have to try it on your own! 

Two things: 
1. The place is on the corner and the windows are completely blacked out and you would never in your life know that it was a pizza joint unless you were looking for it. 

2. NEVER, and I really mean NEVER order the small. There were only 2 of us so naturally we figured we should order the small. Well I don't eat that much but my dining mate was a guy and I was able to eat the entire half of the small and my dining mate was still hungry for more!!! Which honestly, I don't think we would have eaten much more if we got the large, but the price difference between the small and large is only $4 so it is totally worth it to get the large and have some leftovers.
author: Raheleh K.

description:
Sorry happy that this place is open for lunch and that the salads have improved. I still wish that they had more vegetarian specials.

I went here recently when in SF for business and had to visit all my old haunts. I had never eaten here solo before.  I should have been asked to be moved when they sat me next to one of the only occupied tables on the bench along the wall. Even with my engrossing novel, it was impossible not to feel like I was part of the first date occurring beside me. I didn't ask to move because I figured any moment swarms of people would enter and big parties would need the tables. Needless to say, I was surprised that the place remained quite empty for Saturday lunch.
author: Jess O.

description:
I'm a Chicago native and, as such, kind of a pizza snob. I've spent a lot of time in St. Louis, where a Little Start spin-off (Pi) gave me a little hint of what I'd be expecting. 

Along with the fabulous Nichole P., I ordered take out on a Sunday night. We chose a large Brass Monkey (off the menu), and it was ready in 30 minutes. 

As I can't really vouch for the actual restaurant, I'll keep this review strictly in terms of taste. The pizza itself was good, but the large is certainly not the "large" that I'm used to, even for deep dish. The highlight of this pizza is really the crust; it's simply the best part of the pizza, and it compliments the tomato sauce quite well. 

The downside to me of Little Star deep dish is the price...a large pizza was $30. While it will certainly provide leftovers for quite some time, that's usually a bit more than I like to spend on pizza. 

Give it a shot, but I'm still looking for a better slice here in SF.
author: Tom A.

description: The wings are abundant. The wheat beer is legitimate. The deep dish pizza is choice.
author: Stanley J.

description:
I'm craving pizza and only Little Star came to mind.  Excellent Pizza and great deep dish.  This place is most comparable to Zacharys in Berkeley, but with nicer decor and more hipsters.  Wine selection is pretty good for a pizza place.  They also make an awesome roasted garlic with sour dough bread.  If I didnt consume 2000 calories everytime I came here, I'd come more often.  

I haven't been here in a year, but the wait used to be 30-45 min.  They do not take reservations and is a cash only establishment.  ATM is on premises.
author: dion c.

description:
--Date: Sunday, 3/11/12
--Time: Indeterminable, roughly 4PM (a little tipsy off Zeitgeist Bloody Mary's)
--Crowd: Families, not too busy, got seated right away
--Group: Party of 6 tipsy 20-somethings
--Service: Fast and efficient
--Food: Garlic bread (Oh-M-Gee fresh squeezable ooey gooey garlic),Small mixed salad of mixed greens, cherry tomatoes, red bells, red onions, gorgonzola cheese and chopped walnuts and a large Little Star Deep Dish pizza with spinach blended, ricotta, feta, mushrooms, onions and garlic
--Portion: We would've liked more bread to eat the garlic with, the salad was enough for everyone to have a decent portion, the pizza allowed for everyone to have 1 full huge piece, then a half (we were happily full)
--Price: $5, $7, $24=$36 divided by 6, plus tax and tip, only about $8 each
--Overall: Chill atmosphere (I think we busted out in a tipsy rendition of Fiona Apple's "Criminal," and no one batted an eyelash), the food was outstanding and the service was quick and friendly
author: Shira O.

description:
Yum yum yum!!! 4 Yelp stars for Little Star Pizza! :)

My friend and I had initially wanted to go to the Little Star on Divisadero, but they don't open until 3 pm(!), so the guy told us to go to the Mission one. Guess that was my fault for not reading the restaurant times :T

Anyway, it was easy to find this location on Valencia and 15th. I immediately liked the atmosphere and I was happy to see it wasn't too crowded! I'd heard some people say they've waited an hour or so! 
Me and my friend shared a Caprese salad (ALWAYS good...can't ever go wrong with mozzarella and tomatoes!) and the Little Star deep dish pizza (spinach with ricotta, feta, mushrooms, onions, and garlic!). We got the 9 inch pizza and thank goodness too! We couldn't finish the whole thing...the bigger one would've been too much.
Hmmm the Little Star was DELICIOUS! I especially liked the cornmeal crust! SO. GOOD. I don't know if I'll be able to eat normal pizza crust again haha
I don't know how they make the filling, but it was the perfect combo of flavors! Not too much cheese either! In the words of Goldilocks, just right! I wish there had been more spinach thrown in there, but that's probably just me cause I love vegetables.

The bathroom is really clean too! I went twice!

The only reason I gave 4 instead of 5 stars was because it was my first time and I want to try all the other pizzas first to see if they're just as good! I'm sure they are, but just in case...
author: Kei H.

description:
wow.  the pizza here is amazing.  i could NOT stop eating the crust!! two large deep dish pizzas -- three big guys and me.  it was a great time and great food.  

we were all berkeley natives so we were debating about the little star vs. zachary's .. and i think it was a close tie.  omg.  it's sooo good.  we got one little star and one meat combo (forgot the name but it has sausage in it).  YUM. YUM YUM YUM.  

i am a huge fan of their crust.  cornmeal and crunchy.  everything cooked well and cheesey.  we also had the garlic bread which was so yum.  hot roasted garlic, smooth creamy butter with hot bread.. definitely needs more servings of garlic to truly enjoy this.. but it was really good.

service was great and the beers were also flowing.

definitely would go out of my way to hit this place up.
i also love how they have natural sodas and good, fresh ingredients.

i have to say that norcal chicago style pizza ain't got anything on chicago.. craving it right now!!

thumbs up to little star.
i hope i see you sooner than expected!
author: Kimmy C.

description:
The place in the Bay to get deep dish pizza with cornmeal crust

Been here a couple times, but reviewing only most recent visit.

ORDER:
Their special - Hawaiian with ham, pineapple, asiago cheese
We added pepperoni per my boyfriend's request
$? (I didn't pay)
Great crispy crust, not overly dry. Could have had more toppings. Absolutely love the stringiness of the cheese and the amount of tomato/sauce.

AMBIANCE: Dark modern space

SERVICE: The waiter didn't write down our order and ended up forgetting the first half of it. We had ordered half of the large deep dish pizza to be Little Star and the other half as their special + pepperoni, but instead got a whole pie of the latter half. Oh well. The resulting pizza was still good, so no complaints or redoing of the order.

VISIT DETAILS: Dinner with boyfriend and his family. 7:30 pm dinner on a Saturday night managed to get us a table right away. When we left an hourish later, the wait time was 1.5 hours!
author: C L.

description:
Walked in the door around 6pm on a Saturday night...and what do you know NO WAIT!  

So one of my friends has been wanting to come here for a while so I made the trip out here...ironically without the said friend.  I really did want to make the comparison between zachary's and little star.  And here's the verdict MY preference is Zachary's.

Don't get me wrong, little star pizza was and excellent pizza that was pretty close to perfect in my book, but it really did come down to the crust.  I'm a HUGE fan of Zachary's flaky-crispy crust, albeit there really is little to no flavor to it.  On the opposite end, the crust at Little star is a very flavorful cornmeal (so i've heard) crust.  Texture wise it was denser and it had a lot more substance, it was tasty but I wanted that crunch texture.

I will give Little star the slight advantage on toppings and how well they blended everything into one solid pie.  The ingredients just seem to have more presence in the little star pizza but I can't say it was like a whole step above zachary's toppings, probably like a 1/2 step.

I also order a house salad, I'm not usually a salad guy and the salad was extremely oily for me, maybe it's supposed to be like that.  

I will be back again to Little star, but like i've said I do prefer Zachary's.  But go here and be happy with the awesome food!
author: Joey L.

description:
I have never had Chicago style pizza before.  I am a New Yorker and well in true New York style believe that no pizza is to be placed before ours.  O.K. other than pizza in Naples.  I know we are conceited about pizza, but it is our thing.

The cornmeal crust kept the pizza crispy, even though it was jam packed with flavor.   I am a cheese fiend so the lack of cheese on top through me off, but it was truly yummy.  I would try this again.

You also have to love the fact when one slice was left and no one wanted it the waitress convinced us to take it and give it to a homeless person.  Never would have thought of that.
author: Megan P.

description:
Pizza Pie, emphasis on Pie. It's evident in the crust--all the attention that you expect a pie crust to receive, these firm yet flaky pizza crusts do as well. 

And this is a layered pizza. The problem with thin crusts is that they are 2 dimensional. Their toppings are not stackable, but with deep dish you embark on the culinary equivalent of a geological dig. 

The garlic bread was also amazing. It's DIY; they hand you sourdough bread and butter and roasted garlic, the rest is up to you.

In conclusion, I actually wanted to come back here for dinner the next day as well, thanks for the tasty memories.
author: Alan F.

description: Flavorful filling, but I prefer my deep dish pizzas with more of a corn-mealy taste, which their pizza did not.  Even though I've rated Paxti's with the same number of stars, I would say Paxti's tops Little Star.
author: Christina L.

description:
Their thin crust Pizzas are amazzzzzzziiiiiiinnnnnnggggg!  You can def. taste the freshness of their ingredients. I love their sauce that they use on their pizza and their crust is just perfect! It's not too thin or too think. When I ordered their garlic bread, I can admit that I was alittle confused. Unlike the typical garlic bread, where it's buttered and it has garlic flakes on it, Little Star Pizza's garlic bread is quite..... interesting... They pretty much give you a loaf of bread, a side of butter, and a whole cooked garlic. 
Their tables are kind of close to each other but I think for a pizza joint, I love their decor ( a little intimate and dark ). This is the place to go for college kids, group hangout,  late bite, and dates...
author: Jenny L.

description:
Two words: TAKE OUT.

Yes, this place has tasty pizza.  No, it is not worth a two-hour wait, especially when you're a block away from a zillion amazing restaurants.  

I don't care if you've flown here from Pittsburgh specifically for a particular blend of red and green peppers that can only be combined in this perfect little package.  There's got to be a comfy couch somewhere, where it'd be just as pleasant to enjoy this pizza out of a box.  

If you do end up waiting for a table here, bless your heart, you have time to drink away your sorrows at one or all of the fine establishments on the block.  And I'll share my secret - swing by Pakwan for an order of naan to keep the stomach pains at bay.
author: Amy H.

description: Little Star has quickly become one of my all-time favorite pizza places! Love the deep dish Little Star and vegetarian. There's usually a good crowd, and the waiters are very accommodating/helpful. There can be a bit of a wait on the weekends, but not too bad (especially considering the area).
author: Buster B.

description:
Deep dish - 4 stars.  Not excellent (i.e., this is not Zachary's), but very good and flavorful.

Thin crust - 2 stars.  Bad flavor, average quality pizza.

Overall, 3*
author: Josh B.

description: the pizza here is good. I was a little dissapointed though with the deep dish pizza we ordered, the Mediterranean Chicken pizza. The crust and bread part was very delicious but there was too much tomato sauce on it and i felt it over powered everything. i couldnt really taste the cheese cause there was so much tomato sauce, which is bad for me because i love cheese on my pizza. 4 of us came out to eat and we ordered the deep dish and a thin crust cause we were scared one pizza wouldnt be enough, real talk though..we are fatties... Any who, the thin crust pizza (lg) is big enough to share with four people and the deep dish (lg) is probably big enough to split between 3 people so it kind of worked out that we ordered two pizzas but we still had leftovers. overall cool place to hang out and have pizza!
author: Dana J.

description:
Note: there are two Little Star Pizza locations -- this one offers a bigger space, but otherwise I've found my experience to be very similar at both.  Please read on...

Best deep dish pizza.  Ever.  In my opinion.  Yes, there is Z's across the bridge and the original deep dishes may hail from Chi-town, but I'm a huge fan of the corn meal crust!  Also, LSP's deep dishes aren't as heavy while offering the full deep dish experience.

The inevitable wait (30 min is considered super short!) is the major drawback.  

On my most recent visit, our group of 3 arrived ~9PM on Sat night and by the time we were seated, was ready to devour our 1 large pizza (1/2 Little Star and 1/2 Mediterranean Chicken) and chicken wings (pretty good with a spicy kick).  With a drink each, the tab came out to ~$20/person.

Take-Away: 5 stars for the corn-meal deep dish pizza, but knocked down for the wait.  Highly worth considering as a take-out; then can enjoy the great pizza without enduring the long wait!
author: Carol K.

description:
Little Star Pizza is definitely one of the more notable, "destination" pizzeria's in San Francisco, and rightly so.  The pizza is ... just bomb.  Unfortunately, this also means that competition for tables can be tough, so try and come on a slower night or outside of prime dinner hours.

I'm actually writing this review to replace a more negative one I had, but I had such a nice experience the most recent time I went to Little Star.  The previous time I came, there was a bit of confusion that led to a much longer wait than had been expected, but this Sunday, Little Star was great.

My group enjoyed the garlic bread appetizer, which comes with piping hot bread, a whole head of roasted garlic cloves that you take out of the head of garlic yourself, and soft butter.  This do-it-yourself garlic bread is a nice new take on a standard appetizer.

The chicken wings were spicy and DELICIOUS.  I've never had them here before, and wouldn't have thought they'd be such a ... little star ;) but they really were.  I will actually get them every time I come back.

And lastly, the vegetarian pizza.  There are a lot of pizzas to choose from here, and the ingredients will always be fresh and delicious, so just choose whatever sounds best to you.  Any pizza (go deep dish, of course) should be great here, because Little Star's strongest point is their *pizza crust*.  Like everyone else has said, it is awesome, with corn meal on the outside that adds just the right amount of texture and a little bit of crunch.

Among deep dish pizzas, Little Star is my favorite for the crust (and Zachary's in the East Bay is my favorite for pizza sauce.)

Definitely try Little Star, just try to avoid the biggest crowds.
author: David W.

description: Great experience.  The staff is attentive and friendly, the place is clean and stylish, and the food is delicious.  Both the salad and the pizza had fresh ingredients and were very tasty.  Even the small salad and deep dish pizza were enough for two with leftovers.  The Little Star deep dish pizza was not too cheesy, even with both ricotta and feta, and the crust was amazing--light, crispy and buttery.  Yumm.
author: Augie R.

description:
All I have to say is YUM YUM!!

Good Pizza.. Deep Dish is fresh and not too oily!

It gets crowded and no reservations so don't arrive on a hungry stomach. 

The home made wings were delish!!

Ambiance is cool.. small and nice people.
author: Christina M.

description: A really good friend of mine introduced me to this 'lil spot just over a year ago.  Their classic sausage deep dish pizza is awesome!  The pizza is hearty and delicious, and there's something special about that cornmeal crust.  I normally don't crave pizza... but when I do, I go straight to Little Star.  I have also tried the wings... pretty good, but on the spicy side.  Although the restaurant is really cute and trendy, it can get really crowded.  I find it easier to just call-in the order and pick it up.
author: Joy A.

description:
Really really good pizza. As with any other famous and delicious restaurants in SF, the wait requirement is about an hour... but absolutely worth the wait. 

I love the wait staff here. The wait was about an hour long and my party was getting restless. We saw some empty tables but since the restaurant was so busy with just 1 waitress and 1 busboy, we weren't seated right away. Also, a bigger party who came after us was seated before us because a bigger table had become available first. Not knowing this, I protested, and the waitress kindly and patiently offered me an explanation.

Even though it wasn't her fault, the waitress felt bad that we waited a wee bit longer than other parties. So she gave a complimentary glass of beer to each of us. Even though we went during their happy hour where the beers are $1 off from their already low priced beer selections and we wouldn't have minded paying for them, I still thought her gesture was very kind. I would definitely go back just for their customer service. But lucky for me, even the food was amazing. 

Per every yelper's recommendation, we ordered the spicy chicken wings. They were delicious indeed. Even if you're not a fan of appetizers (although not likely) because you don't like having entree leftovers, chicken wings are worth a try. 

As for the pizza, we ordered the vegetarian deep dish. It was my first deep dish pizza ever and I'm so glad it was at the Little Star's. It was the best vegetarian pizza I've ever had. Everything about the pizza was so scrumptious - from its non-greasy yet savory crust to fresh vegetable ingredients to marinara sauce (that tasted homemade).

Despite the fact that this place is located in a somewhat less desirable part of SF (compared to Marina/Cow Hollow which I'm partial to) with some questionable characters (i.e., many homeless people talking to themselves or hitting on random people walking about the neighborhood) and that it's a bit more pricey than what I'm used to paying for for pizza, I am definitely going back. And to this particular location because they're open at noon, as opposed to the downtown location where they open for dinner only. 

If you are in SF and you love pizza, it's a must try.
author: Lina S.

description:
Little Star is officially one of my new fav pizza places in the city!  I came here Sunday afternoon for lunch in the midst of a massive pizza craving.  We were in the Mission and briefly considered going to Delfna, but I wasn't too impressed last time I went there and had recently heard good things about Little Star.

We cruised in minutes after it opened, and were surprisingly the only people in the restaurant for the duration of our meal.  I'm going to chalk that down to the fact that Little Star is pretty dimly-lit and it was a beautiful day so people were probably looking to take advantage of the sunshine.  Glad we were not!

We started with the Caprese salad and after much deliberation and a recommendation from the waiter, decided on the on the White Pizza, a thin crust number with feta cheese, roasted zucchini, tomatoes, and garlic galore.

Both were DELICIOUS.  That pizza hit the spot and we almost finished the ENTIRE pizza.  That's an accomplishment even for me!  We started off seasoning our pizza with Parmesan and crushed red pepper, but learned with slice 2 that, though still delicious, the extra seasoning threw off the masterfully-concocted flavor.  The interaction of the feta with the garlic and other cheese created a delightfully tart flavor that was a party in my mouth!  Seriously, some of the best thin crust pizza I've had.  

I can't wait to go back and try the other pizzas at Little Star!  Though I'm a fan of thin crust, they also boast delicious deep dishes that I am excited to try.  

*proceeds to wipe drool off desk...
author: Julie S.

description:
It's Zachary's and Little Star in the ring, folks. A very special night as our 25-year East Bay reigning champion takes on a new school San Francisco favorite. This is going to be quite a show, the crowds are amped. And there it is, the first bell!

At first glance, they look about even. Thick-crust, similar stockiness and weight, enough to take any other contender down, but they've met their match tonight. Zachary's takes the first swing, coming into full contact with LS's rib cage: "That's for stealing our two signature topping combinations and calling 'em by your own name."  

Little Star shakes it off, and continues dancing around the ring, then *pow* connects with the left side of Zachary's jaw. "Your stuff's tired, old man. We got the new shit. Cornmeal crust is where it's at. Your sauce is too tinny, your cheese is too heavy. Ricotta is the stuff of the future. No one cares about your pies anymore but families with little kids can put up with your cheesy music. The lights are too bright, man. Might as well be Pizza Hut."

Things are heating up, folks. Zachary's had enough and sidejabs his knee into LS's thigh, "Well, at least I don't have lame hipster boys with pants so tight their balls are suffocating. And my staff actually treats people like human beings."

LS attempts to pin Zachary's arm back and footstomp, "Whatever. The hipsters are making us money, they like to be mistreated. And it's a good reason to carry real beer. Plus the way you make your servers scrape the cheese when they dish out the first slice is weak."

Zachary's isn't having it. He stands up taller, and pulls back, preparing to headbutt LS's chest and heave him over his head, "Have respect young man, we're an institution!" But too late! Little Star has secured his footing, swung a surprised Zachary's around, and gotten him into a guillotine choke. His opponent slumps to the floor.

Little Star rolls Zachary's onto his back, and stands on his chest. The whole world goes into slow motion as rose petals fall from the sky onto their sweating, panting bodies, Little Stars arms above in a V for victorious.

History has been made. Bay Area deep dish will never be the same.
author: Ligaya T.

description:
I was wr... 
I was wrrrrrr... 
I was wrrrong. 

I used to think that Zachary's was the best pizzas in the world. But I was wrong. Little Star has the best pizza. That I've had anyway. And I've tried the "Best" of Chicago. And New York. Nope. It's Little Star. 

They skimp on the pepperoni, so order extra. And you won't be sorry. Great salads too. 

Order up!
author: Scott W.

description:
I don't really consider Little Star *real* deep dish.  But it's still pretty good. The ingredients taste fresh. The decor is nice. And it's conveniently tucked away in the heart of the Mission. 

Patxi's is still my favorite, but it's nice that they have appetizers like garlic bread etc here and not just salads.
author: Richa A.

description:
Is it just me?  Little Star used to blow me away, but I was there last night, and... I think the spark is gone.  

The problem (sigh) was the deep dish.  The sauce:topping:cheese ratio was off and the crust was noticeably less cornmealy and--it pains me to write this--soggy.  There.  The deep dish was soggy.  

Not that it was bad.  The servers were friendly and funny.  The music has finally found a sweet spot between rockin' and conversational.  The salads still wow--their caprese is a study in how that salad should be made--the cheesecake was worthy (tho freezing cold), and you can hardly go wrong with beer in frosty glasses and oil-drenched roasted garlic smeared on warm sourdough.  

But the deep dish, the heart and soul of this place, just wasn't pulling its weight.  

All and all we had a great time, but I'm over waiting for a table on a Wednesday.  Four stars for everything but the deep dish, but alas, three stars overall.
author: Dana S.

description:
Wow- this pizza couldn't be yummier!  Deep dish, flaky crust- very tasty.  The salad we had was good as well- lots of crumbly blue cheese and walnuts!  The garlic bread was cool, because they gave a clove of roasted garlic so that you could put your own garlic on..mmmm

Definitely agree with other reviewers that it ties with Zachary's Pizza.  I will definitely be going back here!!!

The guy that served us was very nice as well..and it was not too loud in there.


Delicious!
author: Lisa M.

description:
Good food.  I absolutely LOVE their caprese, which I know is easy to make, but they have it just right!  Everything is so fresh!  I could eat 2 plates of this!!

Three of us shared two 9" deep dish pizzas - the vegetarian and the Mediterranean chicken.  They are excellent - but I felt like these 2 pizzas tasted the same!  The only difference was a handful of small chunks of chicken on the mediterranean chicken pizza.  It was not memorable.
