The veggie pizza on the other hand was really good...probably because there was a lot of garlic and onions!!   The crust was excellent though.

This place is on the pricer side.  2 small pizzas, 1 caprese, no drinks = $60 with tip.  Will come back only if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Jannie Q.

description:
The best deep dish pizza EVER.

It all starts when you try to serve it.  When you slice into it, it keeps it shape. Unlike other places where the toppings all ooze out.  Wow.  How do they do this you wonder?  It's because they don't use tomato sauce but use whole(ish) tomatoes so you get that flavor but the pizza doesn't turn into some deep dish stew.  Brillaint I tell you!  And of course there's the crunchy tasty cornmeal crust.

It's so good that it's inspired us to make our version at home.
author: Jean K.

description:
This review is more about their continued lack of customer service skills at the take out counter than their pizza. Seriously get some customer service skills you hipster tattoted chica that works the phones!! The pizza here aint worth all the tude they throw your way. I mean seriously Paxti's and Gialina don't give as much tude as this joint!! Obviously their attitude is an ongoing problem as I have reviewed it before!!

Husband ordered a classic and upon trying to confirm with the person on the phone taking the order he said "umm the classic that's the one with the sausage right"...she goes "sausage?" he then repeats "yeah the classic sausage right?" she goes "ummm please don't order a sausage pizza because next time you will only get sausage on your pizza it's a CLASSIC!!!!!!" He said "well maybe you did not hear me I said classic."

Well you self-righteous pizza ordering bitch he ordered the right thing next time be polite I know all those tatts "stars and flowers and shit"...inability to find a man in this city and that old tired face of yours can make life tough but get over yourself....a polite demeanor tends to make work a little more pleasant give it a try.

On a side note the Pizza was aiiiiggghhhttt...wings were pigeon small but tasty and salad was yums!! For $60 i expect to at least be treated with some decency!! BITCHES!!
author: T H.

description:
Delicious deep dish pizza! Don't attempt to eat the whole thing in one go; you WILL suffer the consequences. Sharing a large one will leave plenty of leftovers for the next day. 

PS: gorgonzola on pizza might be better in theory than in practice :(
author: Tizia B.

description:
This has to be the best pizza I've ever had. 
Had never had deep dish till I got to America, and have tried the 3 main places in the Bay Area, and this is the best by far.
The cornmeal crust is killer and the filling is great, with the right amount of flavor. Couldn't tell you how many of their pizzas I've eaten by now, but it's quite a few.
Only downside is that you have to wait if you want a table, but they have a bar you can have a beer at, so no problem.
Prefer this location over Divisadero as you can get parking and it takes credit cards, so added bonus.
author: James J.

description: Best deep dish pizza I've ever hard! Only bad part was the wait and that it gets a little crowded. The wait was about 45mins, but I guess you can say it was worth the wait! The veggie deep dish is a must.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
:in Kelly's voice:

"Oh."

Yeah, ermm, hmmmm. So Zachary's is WAAAYYYYY better than this place.

(There's no comparison if you ask me).

First off, LS's deep dish is pretty good, though the crust is distinctly similar to Pizza Hut's. Uh, I didn't go there for Pizza Hut pizza... I went there for something special.

Second off, can we say P-R-E-T-E-N-T-I-O-U-S?

... The snob factor was [nearly] off the chart on our visit. Especially the annoying "salt & pepper" haired bar tenderer guy. You can tell he thinks he's the shht (and he obviously wasn't).

As for the interior, it was trying to be classy/hit/chic, so OK, I didn't *hate* it...

Oh, get this: They're MORE expensive than Zachary's in that for the same money you can get a larger/BETTER pizza at Z's. And the service is nicer/not annoying... yeaahhhh..

"Meh, I've experienced better [in the East Bay]."
author: Kai S.

description:
This Little Star Pizza is excellent! I'm not quite sure if this one is as good as the Little Star Pizza on Divisadero, but it's still awesome. 

They are definitely better than Zachary's! (Zachary's pizzas are not authentic Chicago-style) Overall, Little Star Pizza makes the 2nd best pizzas in the SF bay area. Check my reviews for the best...
author: Shannon L.

description:
Still my favorite pizza in the city. 

I used to live right down the street, and Little Star was my local pickup treat, since getting delivery pizza was the norm in my apartment.

I'm such a big fan of the thick crispy-on-bottom-but-soft-on-top cornmeal crust. The "Little Star" style pizza is just so incredible, the spinach mixed with feta and ricotta, mushrooms, sauteed onions and plenty of garlic all mixed with that bomb crust.. I dunno, it just seems right, just seems.. meant to be.

I actually haven't tried that many other items besides the other deep dish specials, which are also excellent. Oh, and the house-made cheesecake, which is one of the best I've had in a while.

Expensive pies, but the ingredients, preparation, taste and service all makes it oh so worth it. Five big stars for Little Star!
author: Chris G.

description:
Came here with three friends, and had to wait a long time for a table. Fine. For that, I expect very good food (aka worth the wait).

I love deep dish. That is, when the sauce is abundant, the cheese is melty gooey, and crust is soft and plump while being crunchy, and the toppings add flavor. oh, and when its actually DEEP-- do people not know what deep is ? that means your pizza depth is bigger than 1/4 inch.... It wasn't bad. It just wasn't deep dish. Oh, and service sucked.

Here's an ode: 

Twinkle, twinkle, Little Star 
I am shocked at how popular you are
Lack of sauce and not much cheese,
Toppings needed to de-freeze,
Twinkle, twinkle, Little Star
How disappointing your pizzas are!
author: Roxane W.

description:
Man, I've been eating a lot of pizza lately.  Little Star did not disappoint.  Crust was yummy - the vegetarian options here are delish.  I recommend the white pie (thin crust), and the Little Star - the spinach was fab.

No to the garlic bread, which is just bread + bulb of garlic.  Not really worth it.  I think the wait here is less than the other location, and the place seems slightly bigger and less crowded.
author: Liz L.

description:
LOVED the white pie! Ordered it once when sharing with colleagues and went back the following week for an individual portion. The Greek salad was good too, but oh man, that white pizza is something else. Try it! 
I wish they'd give a salad on the side to balance out all those carbs, but that's a minor gripe. It's not cheap--but it's worth it. :)
author: D B.

description:
Dear Pizza from Little Star, 

You are good. I like the classic deep dish. Please move to Houston

Sincerely, 

Amit K

ps - you are a tiny place though.....but that's part of the charm
author: Amit K.

description: While I would love to give this place more stars, the service is the worst I've ever encountered. We were quoted an hour wait for 6 people. 90 minutes later, we gave up and ordered take out as we saw multiple parties of 2 walk in and get seated immediately. I understand it's a small space; it is, however, not small enough that pushing two tables together is impossible.
author: N M.

description: OVERRATED!  Pushy wait staff, over crowded loud environment. All for very average pizza.
author: aaron t.

description: Really, really good deep dish pizza, nice place, staff was fast, food came quickly. Deep dish really isn't my thing, but they do it well.
author: Meghan S.

description: Amazing! My boyfriend and I found this place due to my fellow yelpers and you guys did not disappoint. Both locations in the city are great. There are a lot of great deep dish places in the area but there is something about this crust which pushes it to #1. We always order the classic deep dish. My boyfriend and I can polish off a full large pie but then again we both have pretty big appetites!
author: Kathy G.

description:
4 stars with a disclaimer:

Have never even had the thin crust so know that this review only applies to the Deep Dish. Go with the Little Star (7x7 thinks so too). It's quite good. HEAVY. Don't eat too fast or you'll feel sick.

But for the biggest con:
The wait is obscene. Random weeknight. 3 people. Waited like 1.5 hours. Know though that while waiting you can put in your pizza order at the bar. They won't cook it until you are seated, but since you'll probably be ravenous by the time you're seated, you'll appreciate how ever many minutes have been eliminated between the time you're FINALLY seated and the time you are stuffing your mouth with pizza.

So I am going to make a controversial statement: Though frequently identified as such, Little Star is not the best deep dish in SF. My heart lies with Patxi's after sampling both multiple times (I just think Patxi's is a little more flavorful and I love love love their whole wheat crusts). 

However, you'll have to make that decision for yourself, and you can't consider your San Francisco pizza experience complete until you've had Little Star.
author: Rachel L.

description:
have great memories here...that cornmeal does wonders, far better than the comp (patxis, zacharys) imo

caprese salad, classic pie and pbr on repeat
author: Clark G.

description:
Great pizza.  Good food.  Absolutely unforgivable eating experience.  The management allowed someone to enter the restaurant ON A SEGWAY.  Said douchebag then proceeded to ask me to get up from my meal so that he could navigate the restaurant ON A SEGWAY.  I've seen the owners of a restaurant in Italy tell a German tourist that the man who boxed in his car would move his car when he was finished with his meal.  Now I'm not asking for these aforementioned tactics, but for fuck's sake, who the fuck lets some gyroscopic piece of shit wheel around a restaurant and make people get up from their meal. 

PS. the segtard was not handicapped.
author: Gianpaolo P.

description:
Pizza here has been consistently AWESOME!  it just never fails.  We ordered the deep dish vegetarian and it was delicious!!  

Service though was a bit lacking.  Our waitress spoke to say hello and curtly answered our questions.  She was going thru the motions with an attitude that she was doing us a favor by taking our order.  Kinda soured the experience.  

Four starts for amazing pizza but robotic service.
author: FoodJunkie S.

description: I love their pizza. I won't get it to go again though as I found the to go service to be a bit rude and inconvenient. You must get a deep dish and a thin crust pie. Both are divine.
author: Nicole O.

description:
It's now open for lunch! yay! 

All I have to say is: YUMMY!!! 

A group of us were really hungry and since we heard the wait can be awhile, we called in while in the car heading to LIttle Star and ordered the pizza over the phone... so once we got there, we quickly got our deep dish pizzas. YES!

I would totally come back here again! and again and again!

My favorite pizza was the Italian which is a little spicy but if you like spicy- you'll like the Italian :)
author: Eileen Z.

description: Ive been here only once but my experience was pretty good overall.  I would have given this place 5 stars had the waitress been a little more friendly, she wasnt blatantly rude, but just seemed like she maybe was having a bad day or didnt want to be there.  As for the pizza I loved it!  Im by no means an expert on the deep dish pizza but I thought that this place's Classic (Sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells sm $19,lg  $23) was delicious!  The girlfriend and I tried to split a large pizza and was left with enough food to last us for days...The garlic bread was also very good.   They roast a hole bulb of garlic and serve it too you on the side with butter, again delicious.  The price isnt super cheap, but it seems to be worth it for the quality and taste.  I will definitely be back.
author: daniel p.

description:
If you love Deep Dish Pizza, there's only two contenders near San Francisco, with just one in the actual City itself. 

I love Zachary's Pizza. Years ago, it would be tempting to leave the City to eat at Zach's, or get a half-baked if I were in the East Bay at any point in my day for eating at home. I once drove a large Zach's 400 miles to share it with a friend. 

Enter Little Star, and I no longer feel compulsion to leave the City to get an excellent pizza. 

What, then, if Zachary's and Little Star were equally convenient?

They are simply different pizzas. 

Zach's: thick, homey and robust. 
 
Little Star: artful, a bit crunchy and delicate.
    
Both: absolutely delicious. So mutter-flippin' good that it makes regular pizza seem like junk food.  

You can't go wrong at either place.  My favorite at Little Star is the Classic. 

I can't comment on the dining experience: I've only picked up pizzas there (take out) - at least a dozen times.
author: Brent D.

description:
Ever since Vicolo closed I've been in search of a great corn meal crust pizza.  My search is over.  Little Star is a slice of heaven. The classic sausage is perfection - sweet not bitter tomato, right ratio of cheese and excellent sausage.  Salads are fresh and delicious.  Red wine - which is an artery clearing must with this pizza is good.  Did I mention juke box...
I've always had great service and they manage the crowds well.  They are spot on their timing to table and keep everyone informed and happy.  

My only complaint - which does not keep me away - is the noise.  Don't expect to have an intimate conversation - but you'll be shouting, "This pizza is great".
author: Gail D.

description: I've only had deep dish pizza once before (at the famous Zachary's) and didn't like it. I decided to give it another try and had the Little Star at, well, the Little Star. I have to say that I LOVED it!! The crust was crunchy and wonderful (love the cornmeal blend), the sauce very fresh tasting and the cheese/spinach/mushrooms/onions perfect compliments. I would definitely order it again. Will try out their thin crusts next time too.
author: Alice W.

description:
Here is my "Little Star Pizza" rant:  For the first few weeks of a breakup, you try to avoid your ex in order for you to break old habits.  It's almost like a dog pissing on a fire hydrant as a means to claim its territory.  I can literally pull out a map of the city and draw out places that I avoided because knowing my dumb-luck I'd bump into him during his lunch break or what not.  One of the places that I tried to avoid during the state of "healing" was certain parts of the mission.  With that being said, stumbling across "enemy lines" due to your friends dragging you out for "semi-pity-yet-celebratory-your-single-now" happy hour leads to a stupid drunk text/call that one regrets the following day.  I've seen it happen countless times with my girlfriends as well as, I admit I've shamefully done it in the past; the last time I've done this very deed was at Little Star Pizza.   So now whenever I walk by Little Star Pizza a part of me cringes because I'm always reminded about the humiliating angry drunk text that I've once committed here in the past.

Although I much prefer Patxi's, Little Star in the Mission is the PERFECT spot to go to right after having happy hour at Blondie's or at some other dive bar around the area.  Besides bacon wrapped hotdog, pizza is one of my favorite foods to eat while trying to sober up.  I say, stick to deep dish when you're here.  A small deep dish is actually really heavy and perfect for 2-3 people.  I normally order the classic (Sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells) whenever I go here.  The Little Star is also very delicious (Spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic).  It's normally a long wait if you order a deep dish pizza, but it's totally worth it.  I say order a salad while you wait.  They actually make pretty yummy salads here.  I've tried both the Caprese Salad (Fresh mozzarella served with sliced tomatoes, basil, and drizzled with extra virgin olive oil and balsamic vinegar) and the Goddess Salad (Baby gems with a creamy pesto dressing, topped with chives and toasted almonds).  I much prefer the Caprese Salad, only because it doesn't fill me up as much as a small goddess salad so I have enough room for the pizza.  

+3.5, the highlight of Little Star is the crust.  Everything else, I feel that Patxi's does a much better job.  Although I am normally reminded of my embarrassing message whenever go here, it's still doesn't stop me from going because it really is one of the best post-happy hour places to go to in the mission.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
When I was in Chicago early last year, I met Giordanos. He certainly set the bar high for the other guys. Oh, how I miss Giordanos dearly...

Currently, I'm dating Little Star in SF. I was in love with Zachary's for four years while I was at CAL, but when I moved out to SF and met Little Star's, I was forced to leave Zach (sorry, but I like the light Ricotta cheese Little Star offers me and the dim lighting to set the mood). I couldn't help it - my love for Little Stars grew deeper and deeper...deep like a deep dish pizza.
author: Angellica Y.

description:
Best thin crust I've had outside of Italy. 
The deep crust is just okay. Lots of people love it and, if you crave a lot of toppings and a huge portion, the deep dish is your best choice. 
I love the snappy, crispy texture differentiation that happens with thin crust and they do it RIGHT!
Good salads, appetizers and wine choices as well. 

You WILL wait if you come at prime dinner-time, but they have massively extended their hours to account for the demand. 

It IS very loud, but still worth the din of happy diners.
author: Melody M.

description:
Mmmm... this pizza is so good! I'm not usually a fan of Chicago-style deep dish but this place rocks! The cheese is gooey and unctuous, the fillings are all high quality and well thought out. And the chicken wings! THE CHICKEN WINGS!

My thoughts are that this pizza edges out Zachary's by a small margin due to the acidity of their tomato sauce being lower. Because of all the tomatoes, too much acidity fatigues my palate but they have it just right at Little Star! Just enough to keep the flavors bright and popping but not so much that it burns your tongue. Yes!

Conclusion: Little Star is a huge star!
author: Daniel K.

description:
I don't own skinny jeans and I rarely visit the Mission.  And sure, I have bangs, but they don't perfectly fall into my eyes so as to shield me from the uncool plebes. 

Little Star, however, is enough to make me venture into the Land of Making Jennie Feel Really Old (did I mention I'm not old?  I'm just uncool) and Lame.  Which says a lot for their pizza.  It is deep dish, full of flavor, with plenty of varieties and options, and perfectly paired with their hefeweizen.  

On a weekend night with a group of 6 without a reservation (do they even take reservations?), you probably will have to wait a long time in a tiny space, which is best accompanied by beer and a hell of a lot of patience for feeling like you're in the way.   As tiny as the place is, it has a nice, casual-but-upscale atmosphere, and the service is pretty good.

The staff is happy to accommodate semi-complicated orders: a vegetarian who doesn't like mushrooms but meat eaters who do, meat eater who hates bell pepper but loves mushrooms still wanting to eat the half of the pizza that the mushroom lovers are eating... wait, this is too much like math, and if I wanted to do math I would have gone to medical school.

The pizza is fairly pricey but it is delicious - making Little Star a special treat.  And by special treat, I mean that I'm still working up the nerve to go back and face the preternaturally tiny people ensconced in tight denim and ironic tees.  No one ever accused me of being brave, but everyone knows I love my food.
author: Jennie K.

description:
if i had ordered nachos then it would make sense why i was eating a dry crunchy corn chip with cheese on top. instead i distinctly remember ordering a pizza. anyone who serves pizza crust so dry that it cracks like a chip is obviously unaware of the need to squeeze the ends of a crust and have it curl to support the weight of cheese on a supple crust. this pizza was so dry and overcooked it was stale by the time we had finished the first slice. it was like a giant single nacho chip that you could use to pound nails. 

i felt bad for the russian couple next to us who desperately tried to saw their way through with fork and knife. the woman was practically sweating from the workout of trying to cut a piece off to eat. 

service was non-existent. a woman busied herself with little errands like raising the shades, lowering the shades, lighting candles, arranging napkins, wiping down the bar, but was too afraid or unable to ask the basics like "can i get you anything" or "how is your meal". several times she walked by looking away and we eventually had to send an emissary from our table to negotiate for some of her obviously scarce attention and to get another round of drinks to wash down the disgusting cardboard our pizza had turned into.
author: Mulberry S.

description: Damn good chi-town pizza! Love the classic deep dish with garlic added.
author: Anayo A.

description: I've always ordered to go and loved their pizzas. This a the first time I've dined in and really enjoyed it! Sure it was a little crazy busy, but the glass of wine made the wait not so bad. Overall, I'd do it again and it's a nice alternative to a quick pick up and go.
author: Gregg M.

description:
Came here for the _th time and it is only NOW that I am writing a review. You gotta be here at least an hour ahead, because it gets packed and you sometimes have to wait for a table...but, no worries, there's the bar right across the waiting area and you can start pre-drinking (which is important to me haha). 

The deep dish pizza (all flavors) is my favorite. I will suggest to always order "half-half" flavor -- the medium is enough for 2 people or even 3.
author: Emil J.

description:
The windows are covered and there is a lot of construction in front of the restaurant.  At first we thought they had closed and started looking for something else to eat, but then we realized that we saw some lights through the blackened windows and we smelled pizza coming from the restaurant.  We went back and poked at the door and discovered a very crowded, very operational pizza shop.

For appetizers we also got their mixed salad and garlic bread.  The salad was good, with everything you would expect from a good salad, though it was not especially memorable.

The garlic bread appetizer was very good.  It was toasted sourdough bread with a nice texture and taste.  I love sourdough, so anything that starts with a thick slice of it is off to a good start.  On the side, they had butter and a whole head of baked garlic which you could spread on the bread.  Mmmmm.

I don't usually like deep dish pizza, but we got the deep dish "Little Star" pizza and it was pretty good.  I liked the crust, especially the cornmeal flavor and its crispiness.  It managed to stay crispy even under a pile of deep dish toppings.  The ricotta cheese inside went great with the crust.
author: Michael C.

description:
Maybe I am just being nostalgic but Zachary's in Berkeley is much better. I want my deep dish pizza to be so heavy that after two slices, I have be to carried home. 

This was more like deepish pizza than deep dish. Yeah the corn meal crust was a nice touch but I got bored with it rather quickly. Toppings were ok--we had the garlic, sun dried tomatoes, fresh basil. But I could barely taste the garlic and the basil was barely noticeable. 

We also had the wings (pass on those) and the salad, which I thought was really amazing. 

Service was great and parking on a Sun was easier than I thought.

A good meal but it does not knock Zachary's off its throne.
author: George J.

description: So, I read a lot about this place and decided to check it out while i was at SF.  i didn't have that much time so I went for a take out. The staff were so nose-in-the-air and not friendly at all. The pizza was terribly salty! I stopped eating after the first slice! Besides, the pizza was ok. nothing special. I've had much better than this in Domino's or Pizza hut!!
author: Hamid C.

description:
A few friends and I decided to come here after church for lunch because one of them had a coupon for 30% off. I couldn't even tell we had arrived at the place because there were no obvious signs around the building... just black framing and dark windows. There was just one unassuming sign, "Little Star Pizza" with a cute logo hanging in front of the door.

We walked in and it was very cute... a nice, muted blue paint on the walls with quirky artwork. We got helped by a nice waitress and we ordered immediately.

The food was pretty good. Deep dish pizza is just so different than it is in Texas... I'm not used to the tomato sauce on top. But this crust is definitely amazing... better than Zachary's. I would definitely go again!
author: Becky K.

description:
I already knew I liked this place because I've eaten take-out from here at a nearby friends' house several times over the years. Delicious thin crust pizza. 

I hadn't eaten pizza from Little Star for a couple years but listen to this recent experience:  After ordering take-out pizza on the phone I drove (about 15 minutes away) to pick up the pies. Nearby street parking is non-existent, folks. After half an hour of  circling I gave up and parked illegally many blocks away, ran in, gave my name and was informed that my pizzas were already picked up! By someone with my same first name.  Wha? It was a crazy mix up but they were so cool about it; they immediately put my order back in at the head of the line. And they comped me 100% for the trouble. The guy would not let me pay a penny for two big pizzas! That's some great service and a happy ending.
author: Randall J.

description:
Initially I wanted to give Little Star and Little Star.  Some friends and I head there on a Friday night expecting a little bit of a wait.  After 45 minutes of waiting, we asked how much longer the wait was, we were told that we were next.  This happened for about another hour.  After of almost 2 hours of waiting we were finally seated.  Because of this wait I wanted to give LSP 2 stars, but the service was prompt helping save them. 

I am not the biggest fan of deep dish pizza, so we ordered 1 deep dish and 1 thin crust.  It is hard for me to give a non-biased review on the deep dish, since I only had 1 bite.  But it reminded me of Zachary's, in the East Bay.  It was nothing special.  Definitely not worth waiting 2 hours.  But the thin crust was great.  Definitely helped save them.  I really enjoyed the crunchy crust.  The toppings (we got the combo) were well distributed and were plentiful.  I would definitely recommend the thin crust.  

Also, what I'm not to excited about is that they are cash only.  A place with multiple locations should be able to take card.  They are not running a hole in the wall place, they need to step that up.  

Overall a great place for a good thin crust, if you don't wait 2 hours.
author: Jeremiah K.

description: I used to love this place. Hadn't been in a while, and my memory of the Mediterranean chicken deep dish pizza was that it was loaded with veggies and olives, but this one was mostly straight tomato sauce of the corn flour crust. Maybe an olive nugget per slice. I'll have to go back one more time to see if that was just a bad night.
author: Kate G.

description:
this place used to be one of my fave pizza spots. however after yesterday's experience, i don't know if i will return again.

i am huge on customer service. if you're friendly, it automatically makes the food taste better. our server was so whatever and i felt like she thought we were getting in her way. she didn't come back once to ask how the food was or to refill our water. i was pretty annoyed so i wanted to get out of there as fast as possible so we asked for the check. when i asked her to box up our leftovers, she gave me an irritated look. i can't believe it!

the food is delicious so maybe i'll check out the other locations. i think restaurants definitely need to teach employees the importance of good customer service.
author: Jenny T.

description:
The pizza is pretty good but don't go in thinking its as good as Zachary's.  The crust is excellent but I didn't think it really wowed with the flavors.  

I will say the atmosphere at the Mission one is pleasant... the Divisadero one, not so much.

Little Star, I know Zachary's and you're no Zachary's!
author: Mo P.

description:
I have heard of Little Star for ages and always wondered what all the hype was about... I went the other day with a friend from outta town and let me tell you, hands down, YUMMY! We ordered a half White Pie and half Classic thin crust. I wish it was larger so I would have had more to talk home. I was secretly excited when my friend said, you want to take those home? My one slice of each we had... YES! 

We went on a Thursday after work right before 6pm, there was no one there yet. I had heard it gets packed and figured we were safe at this time. And we so were! So we are greeted by the staff and seated by the window (the tiny table). I had wondered how we got that tiny table since it was completely empty... but 30 minutes later... people were waiting and looking like they were about to mob. There is a no reservation policy, so plan ahead if you really want to eat here and are starving. Be nice to staff, after all, they are the ones that will be seating you and are the ones that control the flow of things if need be, with bad attitudes, I wouldn't expect anyone to work hard to seat me (this is a side comment about a group of people that were there as I was leaving and their ring leader was giving them attitude). 

To start, we had the Caprese Salad - Fresh mozzarella served with sliced tomatoes, basil, and drizzled with extra virgin olive oil and balsamic vinegar $10. It was really tasty, fresh. As much as you may think you can't mess this up, yes you can. It is all about the selection of the tomatoes and cheese and they were both perfect. 

The White - Garlic olive oil base, mozzarella, roasted zucchini, fresh tomatoes, feta Sm 12" $17/ Lg 16" $21 

Classic - Sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells Sm 12" $18/ Lg 16" $22 

They have a nice selection of wine and brews... but best of all, they have my favorite on draft, Pear Cider. 

I did not check out their ladies room... I goofed on that. But that just means I need to go back!

Food - 5
Ambiance - 4.5
Service - 4.5 
Value - 4
Overall Experience  - 4.5

For an average of 4.5 Stars that Yelp! doesn't allow, but if we were rounding up... it's a 5. ;)
author: Amelia M.

description:
Excellent deconstructed version of garlic bread.

The pizza had excellent toppings (if you like chunks of tomatoes) on top of a very flavorful sauce, but the crust was kind of like dry bread.

Limited beer selection.

Parking in this neighborhood is tedious.
author: S M.

description:
I love Little Star on Valencia, the location is bigger and the wait is shorter than the one on Divis. The Little Star pie (deep dish of course) is my favorite, I love the cornmeal crust! My friends tell me it's even better when you add sausage to the Little Star pie but I haven't tried it yet. 

Sidenote: I brought my friend from Japan who is not a fan of deep dish when he visited in April and he said it's the best pizza he's ever had ever. When he visited SF again in  September his only meal request was to eat Little Star. That's how good it is!
author: Jess H.

description:
OMG I can't believe I have been hanging out in the Mission for six years and never tried this place. The cornmeal crust is amazing.

I don't want to overhype it, but I think the chicken pizza I had might have been the best deep dish I've ever had (and I've been to Chicago numerous times). I enjoyed the sausage and mushroom pizza too....the right balance of delicious crust, cheesiness, and toppings....and unlike most deep dish pizzas, you could eat it with your hands.
author: Drew K.

description:
Nice, chill spot to bring a date.

Excellent deep dish, Chicago style, pizza. Crispy crust and rich sauce with nice, hearty chunks of tomatoes.

Definitely can't go wrong with this spot!
author: Alex F.

description:
What can I say that everyone else hasn't said yet? Yes it's a damn good deep dish pizza.  We had the Classic with sausage, onions, and mushrooms.  If you've had Zachery's pizza across the bay, their pizza is similar.  

Does it tastes as good as Zachery's?  Not in my opinion but Little Star's is good in it's own right.  Loved the layer of sausages, onions and mushrooms underneath the layer of tomatoes.  As I bit into the cornmeal crust I couldn't help but taste of hint of butter.  Hmmm...can't go wrong with butter can we?

It's nice to know when I crave deep dish pizza I don't have to cross the bridge...just head to one of the two locations in town.
author: Cris H.

description: Delicious pizza! No matter what you order, thin or thick crust it is always oh so good
author: Sasha Z.

description: I am from the east bay so I hate to say its better than Zachary's BUT the truth is its better than Zachary's. In fact it may even be the best pizza I have ever had. It's easily the best in the bay area in my opinion. If you have not been there before then make it a point to try it. Just be prepared to spend a little more $$ than a usual pizza and there is a little wait too.
author: Brandon M.

description:
delicious!
best deep dish i've ever had
the one on valencia particularly has great service.
author: Jill F.

description:
I was really excited to try this pizza. The hubs and I have been wanting to try this place for quite some time given the really hefty + many good reviews read about it. 

We arrived to the little corner restaurant at 6:00 p.m. The restaurant only opened 30 minutes ago and dam, it was already hot + crowded. We put our names down, but couldn't be immediately seated since our entire party wasn't there. Boo. So, off we sat in the bar area and enjoyed some drinks. They offer various types of beer in which one of them got me thinking if it was a generic version of Blue Moon as it was named, Blue Star. 

We got to order one of their appetizer which was the hot chicken wings. Really good as it wasn't saucy. Looked like they just put a spicy rub on it and fried it to perfection. Served it with blue cheese and a few slices of baby carrots. 

Our pizza's arrived within a well timely manner when we finally got seated. We decided to order a small thin crust Classic pizza and a large deep dish Little Star pizza. According to the employee at the bar, the Classic + the Little Star is the most popular. 

The thin crust pizza tasted good, but it wasn't anything spectacular. I really enjoyed the crispiness of the crust though. However, the deep dish Little Star was great! It was very fresh tasting and the ricotta just hit the spot. Made the pizza taste fabulous! Reminded me of lasagna. 

The crust  resembled the buttery crust that you get at Pizza Hut. 

We also ordered the housemade cheesecake. It was a hunk of a piece that was drizzled with chocolate sauce on top. Very, very good + creamy tasting. 

Would return here but only will get the deep dish pizza's.
author: stacy k.

description:
The classic conversation is comparing this place to Zachary's over in the east bay and there couldn't really be a higher compliment for bay area deep dish pizza. I'm going to agree with a few other hundred comments here that their deep dish is divine even if there is a small contingent of people who think that the cornmeal in the crust is some sort or religious blasphemy. 

The one thing that drives me crazy about this place is how bad the layout of the space is. I've started wearing safety padding whenever I go there because inevitably some body opens the door real quick which smacks somebody and then everybody goes over like dominoes. Why they couldn't make the door open outward or move the bar back a few feet to make room for the crowd or so something, anything to make it feel less claustrophobic and like you can barely get into the place. I just want to pick up some pizza after a long day not take a spin in the Lollapalooza. You'd think that after years of shopping at birite I could handle a crowd but their is something particularly ridiculous at this location that always sours my mood. I've started making my brother pick up the pizza as I just can't take it anymore.
author: Charlie S.

description:
deep dish anything. cornmeal crust.

chicken wings.

long wait but worth it.

that is all.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
4.0 Stars

I must say that I'm feeling the vibe and decor of this pizza joint. It looks like an art gallery with the paintings on the walls and the brick backdrop. It never hurts to have a good ambiance and it makes the pizza dining experience that much more exquisite.

The place itself isn't very big so I definitely would not recommend coming in a big group. A small group of 2-4 people will be perfect to get seated in a timely manner. I came with a large group for a friend's birthday so we ended up waiting around an hour for a table to fit everyone.

If you end up having to wait, there's a bar conveniently located in the front! Bottoms up!

Our group ended up sharing the following pizza pies:

Classic (Deep Dish)
*Sausage, mushrooms, onions, and green bell peppers
*If you're having trouble deciding between the other choices, this one is hard to pass up. It's your standard combination pizza with all the right toppings.

Little Star (Deep Dish)
*Spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, and garlic

Pesto Chicken (Thin Crust)
*Pesto base, roasted chicken, mushrooms, and onions
*This was my favorite pizza and I found it cool how the pesto sauce is swirled on top.
*I loved the combination of all the flavors with the pesto complementing the chicken. 

White Pie (Thin Crust)
*Garlic olive oil base, mozzarella, roasted zucchini, fresh tomatoes, and feta
*I was able to really taste the fresh flavors come out in this pizza. It was relatively light and refreshing.

I had a great experience with Little Star Pizza. The ingredients in all the pizzas were fresh and I could taste it. I'm generally a fan of thin crust pizza, but the cornmeal crust in the deep dish pizzas were an added twist. It gave the deep dish pizzas a good texture and didn't leave me feeling really bloated.

== A MUST TRY! ==
author: Jason H.

description:
This place had a great cab and thin crust pizza.  My BF, doesn't eat tomatoes... He had them here on my pizza.  Seemed like ingredients were good quality... I didn't feel gross after 3 slices :o haha!    I think they use real tomatoes in their pizza sauce, yummy!

I give it 4 stars now, because it needs to prove its consistency for a 5 star :) ... EAT HERE! :_)
author: Belina G.

description:
Authentic Chicago style pizza in San Francisco? (Hwhat?)

This place brings out my inner Lil' Jon (YAYUH!) The deep dish pizza is just right. Great flaky crust, not too much cheese and chunks of delicious sweet tomatoes adorn the top of this pizza. (I'm usually not a fan of the latter, and used to scrape a lot of them off because they got in the way, but it works so well here! Everything comes together to form a symphony of goodness. I'm only knocking off a star because it's somewhat pricey...but it's worth it!
author: Jole S.

description:
Obama's favorite pizza place in San Francisco... or something to that extent. 

Two overworked, tired and hungry people in need of something delicious... and although this satisfied the hunger part, I'm not sure it was truly satisfying at the end of the night. Daniel N. and I left work around 8 after a full 12+ hour day... and we were on an adventure. After I got us lost - as in driving out to T.I. instead of towards the Mission, we found our way and ended up at Little Star Pizza in the Mission. The wait wasn't too bad, maybe 5 minutes... and the atmosphere is completely opposite than the Little Star on Divisadero. 

Our eyes were bigger than our stomachs, and I've noticed I have this effect with people I dine with.  We of course ordered the Little Star to satisfy an item on the 7x7 100 things to try before you die list, we had the caprese salad, a glass of wine and a beer. 

The pizza was a little soggier than I expected... what am I comparing this to? The deep dish pizza I had in Chicago. My true test is how does the pizza taste either old or the next day. It did not taste we good as I had hoped or wanted. Not bad, but again, I am comparing it to deep dish in Chicago and not Zachary's or Paxti's. 

And the atmosphere... when the noise level dies down, it is such the romantical spot - candle light, mood lighting, the works. Until then, it can be quite chaotic.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Ok my friends were asking us for the longest time to check this place out and I was thinking "OMG it has the word 'star' in the name, it's going to be cardboard pizza I know it!"
WRONG!
This is the BEST pizza I have ever had in the Bay Area.  Whether you are getting deep dish or thin crust this pizza rocks!  The crust is what makes this pizza so great.  They use a cornmeal crust which makes it light and delicious and never tough.
The one thing about the deep dish though is the filling.  I like the filler at Zachary's better but even so the crust make this pizza as a whole must more delectible than Zachary's.
We usually end up getting a large White Pie (no meat but you'd never know it because it is so savory!) and a small classic (deep dish deliciousness!).
You can't go wrong.  
AND soon they will be opening a store in Albany, I can't wait!
author: Josh C.

description: If i had to choose how to die, Little Star wouldn't be a bad way to go. So fatty and unhealthy, and So worth it! until remorse kicks in. I had the Deep Dish Pesto Chicken (they were willing to make it a deep dish pizza for me). Loved it. Very heavy. I had the Little Star pizza previously. Although a meat lover, I was completely satisfied with it as well. Amazing! Service was excellent as well.
author: Newton L.

description:
Does Little Star need another review? No, but I'm gonna do it anyway. 

This place has really good pizza. 'nuff said. Fresh, good ingredients, right flavoring, crispy crust, good combos.

Salads also good. 

It's all still good even if you get it to go and bring it back to your apartment in SOMA when your parents are in town...
author: Kristen L.

description:
I use to live in Berkeley.  And as anyone who lives in Berkeley knows, we live and die by our Zachary's Pizza.  If you need a deep-dish craving, theres no other alternative, not even in SF...so I thought.

My friends convinced me to come here and to put it simply--I was impressed.  The ambience is great.  Very different from the usual suspects crowding Zachary's, Little Star is more intimate and quite.  Way less noisy.  A great place to take a casual date and have a great time.  I sat down, ordered a Stella and it was a great place to enjoy others company.  We ordered the vege and the mediterranean  pizza which was more than enough.  

The crusts on the pizza are the bread-winners (har har har).  It had a great crumbly texture when you ate it.  And the contents were just as good, maybe a little heavy on the marinara sauce.  Although I enjoyed the pizza there that 1 star that is missing is perhaps undeserving, and only a petty reviewers biased toward my local favorite, Zachary's--whos ambience and food quality is unsurpassed.  

BUT, if you are looking for a great alternative on the other side of the bay, look no further than Little Star.
author: Paran Y.

description: I've heard Little Star compared to Lou Malnati's and so I finally had to give it a shot.  Although quite good, it really doesn't stand up to the Chicago champ.  Their house deep dish is one of the best meatless deep dish pizzas I've had here in The City, but that's not saying a whole lot.  If you want deep dish, go to Chicago.  You might also find nicer servers as well.  Maybe it was an off night for them, but everyone seemed as if they were being imposed upon.  Can't blame 'em I guess, it's gotta be a tough job.  I'll be coming back, though, since Lou Malnati's is a bit too far of a trek.
author: William T.

description: I don't know about Little Star anymore.... I used to like it.  But what I got tonight was basically corn bread with cheese and sauce. I don't know if I would describe it as pizza.
author: Dan K.

description:
I've heard and read horror stories of the wait to get a table, but we walked in and were seated immediately. Just luck I guess. 

We ordered a small mixed salad to start. It was really good with a lite vinaigrette and gorgonzola crumbled on top. For a small it was really big and split easily between the two of us with plenty remaining.

Next came the Little Star deep dish pizza with spinach, mushrooms, garlic and some other good stuff. The crust is really light and airy. 

I would definitely go back to try something new.
author: Kelly N.

description: An affair well worth waiting for. Literally, you'll never just  roll into Little Star or call in an order without a 45 minute wait. But damn, their pizzas are just ridiculously good. And it doesn't matter weather it's deep or thin crust (although I am strongly biased towards the thick crust). I've had both all meat and some veggie combos, but my brother created this abomination of a pizza that is "The Situation"- their homemade sausage, artichoke hearts and ricotta cheese. Oh yes, it's well worth paying for the make-your-own style that would probably bring any Jersey Shore wanna-be Italian to their knees. I said it. It's that damn good.
author: Alita M.

description:
4.5 stars
Mmmm pizza!
I was skeptical about how good pizza could be from such a fancy-looking place. On top of that, we came in for lunch and there was only 1 other table there.
But I changed my mind once our deep dish Brass Monkey (Little Star with Sausage) came to our table.
There is something about that crust. It must have crack or butter in it.. it's flaky and crispy.. soooo good. The toppings also complemented it well... it had a lot of marinara sauce. I just wish that it was cheesier. 
I was just a little disappointed with the price to portion ratio. We paid $19 (pre-tip, pre-tax) for a small pizza (6 slices) for 2 people, which is pretty pricey for a "simple" lunch.
Regardless, it's good enough that I'll probably be back; I've been salivating ever since I started writing this review.
author: Jen T.

description:
like i originally wrote for my divisadero review... LOVE THE CORN MEAL CRUST!

i usually do NOT like deep dish but the ones at little star are marrrvelous! this location however... was not as good as the divisadero one. i don't know if it was the beers i had before eating or not but something was a little off!  still pretty darn good though!
author: amelia g.

description: I dont know what the hype is about little star. I ate here two years ago and it was really average lots of tomato sauce and virtually no ingredients on the pie. I remember leaving, feeling underwhelmed and kinda ripped off. Lol
author: Ali A.

description: Don't understand all the fuss about this place. After seeing so many rave reviews decided to try it out and ordered the classic deep dish (sausage, mushroom, peppers, onions, and we added pepperoni). Save your money and just order plain cheese because you can't taste the toppings anyway. I'm not sure how the sauce can completely overwhelm all other flavors yet simultaneously be so bland. We did takeout, and thankfully I had red pepper flakes and Parmesan at home to add some taste. Also avoid the garlic bread. Basically warm sourdough loaf served with side of rock hard cold butter you have to spread on yourself. Although the online ordering system was a little clunky, on the plus side I will say the pickup process on a very busy night was seamless and food was ready when promised.
author: Anna M.

description:
Delicious.

The small salads are large enough for two.  Thin crust and thick crust pizzas are both very tasty.  Good quality ingredients, from what I can tell.  Clean.  Have always had good service.  Pizza in this town is a little pricey, so comparatively, it's around as good as you're going to get, unless you are ok with crappy pizza.
author: jen h.

description:
Nice decor to look at & fun juke box to keep you busy while you endure a long A$$ wait.  

Pizza was just ok - that took a long time too.  My boyfriend's pizza made with Trader Joe's store bought pizza dough would've won that quickfire challenge.

Would come back on a week night dinner date with quickfire-challenge winner boyfriend.
author: Tina T.

description:
I LOVE PIZZA!  This one by far is my absolute favorite.  Honestly, it's a love/hate kind of thing.  And I only hate it because even when I'll full, I want to continue stuffing my stomach with this delicious, saucy, tasty, flaky crusted deep dish pizza. 

I prefer the deep dish to the thin crust. (Not that the thin crust is bad, its actually quite good!)  The "Classic" and "Little Star" are the ones I tend to order because the combination of toppings with the sauce on top, are just perfection!  

The waiters are always super attentive and friendly.  Once, the waiter forgot to bring us plates but luckily, another waiter noticed and gave us our plates so that we could dive into the hot pizza.
author: Lesliegh H.

description:
After an hour plus wait, we finally made it to our table. We started with garlic bread and spicy chicken wings. Both decent, bread was tough and the wings were on the smaller side, must have been free range chicken, too much exercise. (gimme the plump injected wings, yeah!) it was good though. Then we ordered the Classic deep dish and the Italian Combo thin crust. I've had Zachary's deep dish and to be honest, Little Star does not even compare! I was expecting their pizza to ooze with cheese and a perfect flaky crust, but I forget I wasn't at Zachary's. The crust of both pizza's were too crispy and the thin crust pizza was way too salty. It may have been the salami or pepperoni, but wow!    

Overall: Service was great, didn't have any problems like other reviews mentioned. Pizza was decent, definitely not worth the wait..head to Zachary's you'll have a much better time.
author: Tina P.

description:
Little Star now takes plastic.

My life is complete. :)
author: Angela B.

description: great deep dish selection with excellent crust.  worth the wait for a table.
author: MJ A.

description:
I was very excited about placing an order for the Little Star tonight. I have not had deep dish in a LONG time, AND its another item to check off the 7 x 7 Big Eats list. Well, the pizza was delicious! The name of the pizza should be changed to the Little Lasagna with all the toppings on there, (Spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic). Add a little ground beef and you are putting together the best of both worlds! Either way, I was very happy with the pizza. 
i also had the spicy chicken wings. They were not very spicy, but were very flavorful. I also like the idea of a pound of wings, vs a dozen. 
The service was speedy and the food was delicious. If you are having deep dish with friends, you are going to need a few pies...
author: Miguel V.

description:
Little Star secret, only helpful over the next few days: if you don't want to wait for a table, go during a World Series game.  There are no TVs here.

I took my roomie here for her birthday dinner upon her request, since we'd been meaning to try the Star for awhile.  We had no wait for a table; the place was relatively quiet and nobody was sitting at the bar.  I ordered a draught beer, she ordered some champagne cocktail called "the Kool-Aid" (or something along those lines), and we settled in to chat and wait the 30 minutes for our 1/2-classic, 1/2-little star deep dish.  She seemed to like the cocktail; I am not a fan of sweet drinks and this was no exception.

As the Giants' runs mounted (we were checking in on her iPhone), our deep dish baked.  And then it arrived.  We knew immediately we should have ordered the small instead of the large, and that we'd be taking home leftovers.  We liked both halves, though found the little star to be a bit too overwhelmingly cheesy at the end.  Like other Yelpers, we appreciated the cornmeal crust.  I was full after 1.5 pieces; she ate 2.5 and felt stuffed.

I couldn't believe how heavy the take-home box was (4 pieces)!  A nice arm-toning walk home followed dinner, and we made it home to see the last 2 outs.

In the end, I think she and I are New York-style, thin-crust pizza gals.  But as far as deep dish goes, this place is pretty darn good.
author: Pam M.

description:
Little Star makes some DAMN good pizza. That's the short version. If you have an itch for the deep dish and you're in the city, you should not pass up this place. 

This is one of those reviews that you write and as you're writing it, your mouth is starting to water. They do the cornmeal crusts on the pizzas that are soooo good. Lots of different variety in terms of toppings and preparation styles. 

It's a very bright, nice space inside. One thing to keep in mind is that it's a small space so you'll want to make a reservation if you're coming in with a group, otherwise you might be waiting for a while. 

For pizza, it can be a little more than you'd expect to spend but you definitely are getting what you pay for and I can't imagine that you'd be disappointed. Especially if you're a deep dish fan. 

Great place to meet up for dinner with friends before going out (Zeitgeist is right nearby...) or to bring folks visiting for some awesome fancy pizza.
author: Andy A.

description: Definitely one of the best deep dish pizzas I've ever had. We ordered a half classic half Mediterranean combo. The crust is awesome.
author: Gobori U.

description: Unassuming from the front but a bloody jewel of a pizza shop! My bf and I got the green goddess salad and Italian thin crust pizza. Everything was surprisingly delicious! You can taste the olive oil in the crust... The quality of ingredients was impeccable. the Salad was perfectly dressed and very gracious serving wise (we split a small salad and personal pizza). The decor is modern paintings and brick walls. Very chic. I'd recommend this to anyone in the mission. Wait staff was great too! Overall super pleased.:)
author: Molly T.

description:
It takes a lot for me to go to the mission these days. After my best friend has been jumped, our cars vandalized, no parking, and the infamous hipster crowd taking over, I attempt to be caught in that part of the city as little as possible.

We were invited to my friends birthday dinner party here the other night, and I bitched and moaned while driving to the mission about my woes and foes there. Whats new? I'm a shit talker by nature, but hey, I embrace my darker half with love. 

Almost hidden in on the corner of Valencia and 15th, right by Monroe Motors (a great Ducati wrenching spot by the way) is Little Star pizza, boasting some of the best deep dish in the city.

Now I've had great pizza, in the old school heart of NYC, where I've been spoiled by the crust which was cooked in the same oven for over fifty years. 

There were many of us, so we ordered tons of appetizers, and four pizzas. The appetizers were, well, lacking to say the least. The blue cheese for the buffalo wings tastes like the cheap one from KFC from back in the day, the gorgonzola was flavorless in the salad and the onions were overpowering. The garlic bread wasn't on great bread, the butter was mild, but the garlic bulb itself which you spreaded was delicious, but a bit oily. 

But then came the pizza, especially the "little star" deep dish. It was incredible, the cheese and homemade sauce nestled beautifully into it's amazing cornmeal crust. The crust itself was to die for. Flavorful, and not too dry. The white pizza was unlike other white pizzas. It was moist, and complex, flavorful and left you wanting more. The other pizzas weren't as memorable as those two, but still pretty amazing. The crust made everything. It was perfection.

These pizzas upon themselves made up for the boring and less desirable appetizers, and even the boring and flat cheesecake we had for dessert which was smothered in what seemed Hershey's chocolate sauce. (not a fan, but that seems obvious)

Struggling for parking and fighting to get in may not be worth it at this location in my mind, but I am definitely willing to eat at their sister location on Divisadero which in my opinion is a much easier location to weather. 

For a moment, even if it was only one, while consuming this delicious pizza, I forgot about the horn rimmed faces of hipsters seemingly glaring at me from throughout the restaurant, the drug addicts leaning against the wheels of my car, and the torn dirty pajama pants under shorts it seemed like everyone was wearing. 

But I was shocked when I saw on a nice eatery's menu, PBR in a can....yep, it's official now. We're in the mission, and my city (born and raised bitches) is being taken over by hipsters....

SIGH..........
author: Danielle S.

description:
This deep dish pizza is good but not great.  I had both the classic and the little star.  My biggest issue was that it had too much breading/crust.  It looked and smelled great so I was really excited to bite into this sucker.

After my first bite, I was disappointed.  Each bite was 50% crust (with cornmeal at the bottom).  I prefer a thicker toppings level, maybe like a 80/20 toppings to crust ratio, not 50/50.

In the end, I enjoyed the pizza, but this place doesn't belong in the same sentence as Zachary's.  Put another way, if there were a Zachary's right next door, I would go there 10/10 times for a deep dish.
author: David S.

description:
There are over 800 reviews for this place, so I'm pretty sure mine will be insignificant so I won't delve into details.

Considering I just came back from Chicago and ate at Gino's East, I have to say, I like Little Star's deep dish more.  All you people from the midwest, I'm sorry, I know... it's blasphemy.

That's how good this place is.
author: Jessie H.

description:
Though it tastes alright,
I wasn't wow-ed and amazed
It's over-rated
____________

I was a bit disappointed by Little Star, but in retrospect, I think I went in with unrealistically high expectations, so I'm going to try and give them a break.  It is undoubtedly the only place in the immediate vicinity that serves deep dish pizza, and it does taste good--but it's not 5 star, yelpgasmic, and cumtastic.  The corn meal crust tasted like the pizzas I sometimes make at home, and I'm no professional chef by any means.

I got here at 5pm, and the crowd was reasonable, but when I left an hour later, the smell of cumulative body odor was over-powering the pizza aroma, and several somebodies touched my butt without my permission on the way out.

Consider Patxi's for a deep dish alternative.
author: Jin D.

description: Amazing spot.  Went here with a group of friends and we all loved the pizza.  I've never been a fan of deep dish pizza, but the crust here makes all the difference, it is made with corn and tastes amazing...changes the whole taste of pizza.  Also they have a decent beer selection.
author: Michael S.

description:
REALLY good pizza!  We had the deep dish Little Star pizza - the cornmeal crust was the best ever.  It was perfectly crispy but did not seem oily at all.  Even the bottom of the pizza crust stayed crisp.  The filling was really good, tomato, spinach, two kinds of cheeses.  I think I might like it better than Zachary's, but that is a hard call to make.  The mixed green salad was very nice too (way better than I expected from a pizza place).

Be aware that the restaurant sort of looks closed from the outside (windows completely darkened, major construction going on on the sidewalk outside).  We almost left disappointed, but as we were walking away we smelled the pizza ("mmm.. what is that amazing smell??  they must be open!  let's go back and see") and happily discovered that they were indeed open.  We came really early (around 5:15 on a Saturday) so we didn't wait at all for a table, but when we were leaving we noticed there was a huge line of people out the door waiting.  Showing up early seems like a good idea.
author: Cassie H.

description: Having been a regular of Zachary's for a while, I have to say that Little Star now has taken the crown for best Deep Dish in the Bay Area. The Classic wasn't overstuffed and was filled with great, high quality sausage. The crust, however, is what separates Little Star from Zachary's - coated in cornmeal with a great crunch, it's a far cry from the typical butter-laden, quick pastry-like dough commonly found on a typical deep dish.
author: Kevin N.

description:
It had been well over a year since I last went to Little Star and I'm happy to say the place was just as good as ever.

I'm by no means a vegetarian and they have meat on the menu, but the "Little Star Pizza" (pie) with the tomato sauce, feta, ricotta, mushrooms and that crust, is really nice - crisy/crumbly with those toppings and sauce.  It kept this usual carnivore happy.  The mixed salad was good, but not on the same level as the pizza.  The cheesecake was very nice too, not too heavy and you can get it drizzled with chocolate sauce.

All the small portions and desert are perfect for sharing for two.

The wine and beer are also reasonably priced.  The selection is good.

Went in on a whim and again was happy to see the place is still good.
author: eugene c.

description:
If you have never been to Chicago and aren't picky about your pizza then Little Star is for you. I'm born and raised in Chicago and know how to a true deep dish pie should taste. Little Star is over-rated, with rude, too cool for school staff, pizza that looks great but tastes like nothing, a noisy restaurant, and long waits for tables in a not fantastic neighborhood.

Corn Meal crust may be trendy and sound cool, but in reality it bakes up bland and boring. They say they use fresh and local ingredients, however the sauce tasted straight out of a can and the veggies were limp and tasteless.

Skip Little Star and either go to Patxi's were the pizza crust is buttery, crispy, and delish or fly to Chicago for the real deal.
author: Abra A.

description:
This review is long overdue.

I have been a loyal fan of Little Star Pizza since they opened the original place on Divisadero.  Now it's come to my side of the City.

My top two favorite pizzas are the deep dish veggie and deep dish classic.

The crust is delicious and has a great corn meal base.  The sauce, cheese, and toppings are always fresh.  I also enjoy the house salad with a cherry soda on the side.

I would definitely recommend this spot if you are in the mood for deep dish pizza.
author: Jesson d.

description:
While I love Zachary's in the East Bay. This place has the best dish pizza on this side of the Bay Bridge. Located on the uber trendy Valencia Street. 

The Chicken Mediterranean pizza is great. Little Star Pizza with spinach is close second. Terrific hot wings with silly little carrots wrapped in tin foil.

Seems like a noisy dining room most nights. Allow 30 minutes for takeout orders.

Take a cab, walk, bike or prepare to using your ninja parking skills in this area! Divisidero location may be easier but I doubt it.
author: Russ C.

description:
I heard a lot of hype for this place and finally decided to try it on a Friday night.  We knew it would be crowded and didn't feel like waiting so we called there for take out.  We thought we'd have a huge wait for that since they already say on their site that it takes 25 minutes to bake a deep dish pie, but they only gave us a 30 minute ETA so we were grateful for that.

When we finally dug into the pie at home, I would say that it was definitely good but not as good as Zachary's in terms of deep dish.  My husband liked it way more, and I'm not saying the pizza is bad by any stretch of the imagination, but it just didn't live up to the hype and wasn't one of the best deep dish pizzas I've ever had.
author: B. Y.

description:
Another one to check off the 7x7 100 Things to Try Before You Die. A lot of the items I can argue DON'T belong on the list, but this pizza is WORTHY of the honor and praise!

The Brass Monkey is what was featured on the list, and it is a "secret" item on the menu, which consists of the regular "Little Star:" Spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic; except that it comes with sausage too! The pizza was temperature hot, perfect for a cold, rainy, foggy SF day. Every bite was bursting with flavor, and the deep dish crust was so crispy, and tasty (not just doughy). Definitely my go-to for my fix for deep dish pizza. 

I've been to Little Star twice, and each time at a different location. 4 outstanding stars for consistency and a solid performance.
author: Margaret Y.

description: I freakin' love this LITTLE STAR PIZZA. I rarely visit here so, when I do, this is a treat for me. The pizza slices are huge, and the price for it is cheap. My stomach is fully satisfied with one piece. Not to mention, if you are a pepperoni lover like myself, they load it on!
author: Anonymous T.

description: Little star hardly needs another 5 star especially from little ol' me but I'm on my donuts and pizza run and just had to throw my 5 stars in the ring. Hands down my favorite in the city and YES I've tried them all. I think what separates LS for me is the crust. I'm usually a crust leaver especially on NY style or bready deep dish. This crust is miraculous and buttery.  I usually get  the classic but have had a variety. Never have taken the plunge with the NY style, I always want to, but  I just haven't had enough trips to say OH I'm sick of the deep dish. Can't actually imagine that happening! Service is always friendly, have never had a bad experience. Sometimes I hit it just right and no wait. It's hard to wait when you see all of that yumminess coming out of the kitchen!
author: Ann K.

description: 4.5 stars rounded up. We kicked off our SF vacation with a night of deep dish pizza at Little Star. Note: we ended our vacation with Little Star, too, but at the Divisadero location. Flavor wise, Divisadero Little Star seemed to be more pronounced and bold. Perhaps their sauce had a bit more seasoning? But! The Mission location's service was quicker and friendlier. We'll definitely come to this location for more yummy pizza. My gf and I agreed that Little Star's pizza is one of the best we've had. We'll miss you, deep dish goodness!
author: Fede O.

description:
I am a fan of Pizza and I have had pizza in every place from NY to Chicago. 

Little Star Pizza is best of both worlds!!!!! 
It was extremely busy when I and 4 friends arrived, but really only a 30 minute wait. Grabbed a beer at the bar and hung out till we were called. 

Super friendly staff, and AMAZING PIZZA!!!! We had a large deep dish and small thin crust. 
NOTE... BRING YOUR OWN BOTTLE OF WINE... $10 corking fee!!!
author: Zac G.

description: I believe this place is better known for their deep dish pizzas and I definitely see why! The cornmeal crust was perfectly crispy yet flavorful and buttery, even with the heapful of sauce and toppings.  I tried both the Mediterranean (chicken, artichoke hearts, olives, onions) and Classic (sausage, green peppers, onions) Both were delicious, but I would probably just stick with Classic next time.
author: Nancy H.

description:
To be honest, I don't have that much experience with deep dish, but if Little Star has taught me anything, it's that a baked pie stuffed with meat, cheese, veggies, and sauce is damn good for the soul. Maybe not the arteries though, but hey, you only live once right?

Little Star is a prime SF locale for a fun b-day dinner or a meal out with friends (be forewarned though - it gets busy busy busy). The restaurant is small, with a hip and cozy atmosphere - good music, art on the walls, trendy-looking staff, etc. The tiny bar/waiting area gets really crowded, but you can still easily get a drink, which is nice. They have a good wine and beer selection, and even $2.50 PBRs for those trying to imbibe on a dime. My favorite item on the menu is the Little Star Pizza: spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic. To add some freshness to your meal, the Mixed Salad is great to share, and the Gorgonzola in it has a nice punch. Also, their garlic bread is warm sourdough served with butter and a roasted clove of garlic on the side that you spread on. My breath is still kickin'!

Cash only, but if you find yourself unprepared *shazam* they've got an ATM on site that only has a 25 cent charge. Cha ching!
author: Stephanie P.

description: Pizza Chicago Style, also called Deep Dish Pizza. Definitely is a polarizing thing to eat. When I heard about it and asked some friends and colleagues I heard either something very enthusiastic or something coming with a funny face. Of course I had to try this! A friend I trust in when it comes to food chose the place. I was so focused on the pizza, I cannot tell a lot about the place. Pleasant light, friendly staff. We ordered three different ones: The "Little Star" with spinach, ricotta, feta, mushrooms and garlic, the "Classic" with sausage, mushrooms, onions and the third one was from the menu of the day, with meat balls. - Don't call it pizza. Call it pie or invent a name, but this is no pizza ... Nevertheless, I liked it! I hope the ones with the funny faces will still know me when they see me in the street. Europeans, watch out, don't order one "pizza" just for yourself, you won't make it, remember, it is a pie. ;-)
author: Sandra R.

description:
The pizza was good, but the service was really awkward.
Once I was seated, one of the servers kept squeezing in between the table next to us and our table.  What made this awkward was that her bottom was pretty much six inches on our table every time she squeezed by.  She spilled my beer a few times by doing bumping in to it. I understood the place was crowded, but an excuse me or a fore warning would have been nice. I was also concerned for sanitary reasons, because she was wearing really short shorts.  
Her necklace said Blake, I'm assuming that was her name?  On top of that, she gave overall bad service.  I'd be willing to go back again for the pizza under the condition there is a different server working.
author: Mike P.

description:
mmm deep dish is the way to go!
personal favourite is still the little star, but I'm a spinach fan. My buddy said, it taste kinda healthy (in a GREAT way). As healthy as pizza gets. This is what I'm ordering when I'm on a diet... ya right.....

anyways, great place, great vibe, LONG WAIT (30mins on a thurs night). but nonetheless, great pizza in the city. two locations! equally tasty. 

the manager, brett is super friendly, super nice. say hi. :)

oh parking... not so good... and champagne cocktails... not so good.... 
but who cares? the pizza is great!!!
author: Scarlet S.

description:
The Garlic Bread is out of this world.
There Deep Dish Pizza is just wonderful.  Be ready for a wait so order the Garlic Bread and a nice glass of wine!
Really nice place for a Friday night with someone special.
author: Ramona L.

description: Service here was great. We had a fabulous and friendly waiter. We tried the Classic, Mediterranean Chicken, Vegetable, and Little Star deep dish pizzas. The Little Star was the best followed by the Classic. The pizza was good but I honestly preferred the BBQ Chicken deep dish pizza I had at Patxi's in Hayes Valley. However the atmosphere and service at Little Star's was much better. Also the ice cream from the local creamery in the Mission (I wish we had heard which one it was) was delicious.
author: Katherine T.

description: The difference between this restaurant and other pizza places is that this place IS actually a real restaurant with nice wooden chairs and tables without the greasy formica tables that are so common in pizza joints. It was a bit smaller than I expected but on a Sunday night it wasn't hard to get a table for 5. We ordered two different pizzas, one veggie and the other some kind of chicken, but when they arrived they both looked the same because they slathered so much of that delicious chunky tomato sauce on top that you can't even tell which is which. Surprisingly I enjoyed the veggie pizza better than I did the chicken. The cornmeal crust was okay, though I still prefer the regular doughy crusts. Since everyone else seems to be doing it, if I had to compare it to Zachary's I think I would still choose Zachary's but Little Star is definitely up there.
author: Queena T.

description: love love love,  it takes time to cook so give yourself a little time and put your order in when you order your appetizer. Service is good price is more on the $$$ side and remember you will probably eat no more then three slices. The crust is very good and even after the main part is eaten. Ask your service about the size and for two a small is good enough with an appetizer and drink. So Good and for dinner or weekends expect to wait if you don't reserve.
author: RICHARD J.

description:
I have long wanted deep dish pizza from Little Star, however with busy friends like mine, my friend and I were only able to meet up during lunch. The Divisadero St only serves dinner so it was off to the mission we go for some pizza for lunch!

I have heard their pizza was good and I was scared my expectations were going to be too high. However, Little Star still managed to amaze me. I had the Little Star (deep dish) with garlic, spinach, mushrooms, and onions. The sauce and the rest of the ingredients were very fresh. It all tasted so delicious, probably because of the garlic. I do love garlic. The pizza didn't feel too heavy like most deep dish, there wasn't an overkill of cheese. I usually feel so bloated from deep dish pizza. I must also say that I liked their crust more than the crust of other deep dish pizza I have had in the past. I have been to Zachery's in the East Bay and I like Little Star better.
author: Angela T.

description:
We ordered a large thin crust classic to go. When we got home, we realized we got a large deep dish classic instead. 

Not a big deal, except we weren't in the mood for heavy pizza. Disappointing.
author: An B.

description:
Came here with some friends for dinner. Had to wait a bit for a table. The place was pretty poppin' on Friday evening. Loved the old school couch in the front...a bit low though.

Ordered:
-Classic, deep dish: lots of tomatoes
-Little star, deep dish: my fave from the night. After leaving, we realized we should have ordered it with sausage which would have then been called a "Brass Monkey"
-Pepperoni and green peppers, thin crust: only got this since one of our group members doesn't like deep dish. It was good, though.

I thought the dough for the pies were great. Didn't seem to be as heavy as Patxi's dough and maybe that's why I could eat about 3 pieces last night! It was light and fluffy and not dense at all. The ingredients tasted so fresh and the pies come to your table piping hot. Service was good. i felt price for the deep dish was average (~$23) but I felt the thin crust price was pretty high (~$16 + $2.50 for each additional topping). We got 3 pies for 5 people which was more than enough (even with 2 big eaters).

Will have to come back to try the Brass Monkey.
author: Janel Y.

description:
I've heard some people say that this location is the the tastier location.  I don't know.  I love both. 
 I usually get the deep dish veggie pizza and add pepperoni and sausage but when I came here with a friend he insisted on the Mediterranean Chicken-which I loved.  I recently tasted the thin crust Italian combo which was unsurprisingly delicious.  I would still stick with my deep dish veggie combo.  
The side by side tables are way too close to one another (my not that big butt pushed the next table's cups when I got out) and it does have a long waits -so don't come starving! 
The last time I was there the hostess had a bit of unnecessary tude.  I reacted with rolling my eyes and taking it.  
 I however am willing to push the negative aside to bite into the tasty deliciousness which is Little Star Pizza!
author: Carmen S.

description: All stars die in direct proportion to their mass, I was told this by a upward gazing derelict on my street. I guess that Little Star is not a misnomer, the smaller the star the quicker it dies. Having been around for only so long Little Star is fading. Last night I ordered a pickup pie, that once had delivered interstellar pizza orgasms, sadly Little star failed to shine. In no astrologist terms it sucked. It took way too long to make  (2hrs for pickup) and dealt with rude staff. I am at amiss for astrological euphemisms for incompetent employees. The pizza tasted not as good as past memories. Hopefully they will not be sucked into a blackhole of mediocrity (The new red baron pizzas) and perhaps they should reconsider their employees. No gold stars here!
author: Mark K.

description:
I prefer a thin-crust neopolitan style pizza but damn, the deep dish at little star was pretty amazing. the portions aren't as big as the ones i've had in chicago but hey, we're in figure-friendly san francisco. 

I had the classic deep-dish with sausage and tomatoes and the italian thin-crust. both were yummy but I'd come back for the deep dish.
author: Jane C.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday night and the place was packed!  Me and my man had to wait 20 minutes for a table and it was well worth it. 

We started off with their spicy chicken wings.  It's not as spicy as I expected, but it carried a good kick.  Next, we ordered a large deep dish; half of the Classic and half of the Mediterranean.  Both of them were extremely good =).  Everything tasted fresh and had a good amount of everything.  The only con about the Mediterranean were the green olives cuz they were hella salty.  But other than that, the pizzas were perfectly cooked.  Since they were deep dish pizzas, I expected my dinner to be a bit messy, but my plate was clear of any loose food.  
And after lookin at some fellow yelpers reviews of the cheesecake, we had to try it.  They give a big slice of cheesecake with chocolate sauce on top (if requested).  And dayum was it good.  It's really different from your ordinary cheesecake.  The texture, the creamyness (if that's even a word) made a big difference.  

Overall, if you love pizza, you should definitely come here.  They not only serve deep dish (which is what they're known for) but they serve thin crust as well.  ENJOY!
author: Tes ..

description:
A bite of their pesto chicken w/no chicken, and all is right in the world.
