They have always been the fall back to any failed expectations from new and/or much anticipated restaurants in the Mission.  Little Star never disappoints, providing excellent service and even better food.  When I set foot, I smile a lil inside, because I know I'm leaving happy.  

But only at their Valencia location.  I don't like the one on Divisadero.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Yes, I prefer it to all the pizzas in Chicago. Even Giordano's. And Zachary's can't even hold a candle. 

I prefer take-out bc it's too crowded in the dining room. 

If calling in an order, don't forget to ask what their special of the day is - they always have an inventive new pie that's delicious. 

Go Little Star!
author: andy o.

description:
What can I say about this awesome place. I've been coming here faithfully for about 3 years. Never had a bad experience, besides the wait and if you come with a party of 6 or larger be prepared to wait a while. 

Chicken wings are to die for though they can be a tad spicy the blue cheese sauce cools you back down. 
All the salads are also great for those who choose to go that route. 
Caprese haven!!!!! What!!!!!!! Best fresh mozz and tomato so simple. 

Deep dish pizzas really good make sure you come hungry they really nailed the dough so crunchy even in the middle. 

Thin crust cmon!!!!! You can't go wrong. The white pie is outta control. 
Make sure you ask your waiter for the special pizza of the day, that's were the kitchen gets creative!!!!!
author: Javier L.

description:
We were told it would be a 20 to 60 minute wait for a table but I guess we got lucky.  At noon on Sunday, we just walked straight in and got a table for two without a problem.  The place was pretty much empty, so I would suggest you go there around noon.

Recommend the deep dish and garlic bread for starters.  It's at least a 20 minute wait for the Pizza, so the garlic bread is the way to go.

Love this place and will definitely go back!
author: Maggi T.

description: I wish this place weren't so popular, but then again, I understand why. We ordered a pizza with pesto sauce, chicken, garlic and olives and it was one of those "holy crap- this is good" moments.
author: Amanda C.

description: Best Chicago style (deep dish) In the city. Nuff said. Call ahead and do take out cause there is always a super long wait.
author: Michael S.

description:
I really enjoyed my time here with my friends.

The lighting was a bit on the dim end and it really had a good sense of night time atmosphere. The service was remarkable as well; the waiter was observant, friendly, funny, and polite. 

The deepdish pizza was outright one of the best I've had! The pizza was cheesy to the point where I can describe it as  lasunga on pizza. 

The only setback and reason for my mark deduction was that it was a tad bit high on the sodium or there was inclusion of MSG. After I've gone home, I found myself very parched and having to chug a glass of water every so often. Other than that, I have no other complaints.
author: Ken N.

description:
I went back and this time the host was extremely good at setting expectations.  The wait was still about 45 min,  but he set expectations well and told me to check in again at 30 min.  He also gave us the option if we wanted to take a smaller table or wait for a larger one to open up.  Very considerate in my opinion.  

Still a long wait, but I guess that's the price you pay for corn meal crust.
author: Elsa H.

description:
So I went to this place on a Sunday evening, the wait was about 45 mins, but totally worth it! I sat at the bar and had some local beer which was pretty awesome.
 This place is super cozy and no matter how tired u get of waiting for your table, the amazing aromas that are in the air just won't let you leave.
 By the time you sit down and order you know you are in for something great!  As an appetizer we had the spicy chicken wings which had a great seasoning to them , but they just didnt seem crispy enough to me (I guess cause I'm from Texas).
For main course we had the Ny style thin italian combo pizza, it has Salami, pepperoni, olives and pepperoncini! F--ing fantastic!

 SO all I can say is Come hungry and The wait is worth it!
author: L V.

description:
Before coming here I heard nothing but good things and needless to say it lived up to its hype!

I got the deep dish Mediterranean Pizza which I wasn't too crazy about getting in the first place but my friend really wanted it so I was down. It seemed really hard to get a seat in the place so we took it home which was fine. It was a reasonable wait to get a delicious pizza.

The cornmeal crust is out of this world. Loaded with toppings as you could get in a deep dish pizza. You pay a pretty penny at this place for a small but it is well worth it. 2 slices is enough to fill you up.

I won't finalize this statement until i get back to Chicago but it was possibly better than any real Chicago style pizza I've ever had. But hey, what can you expect if you compete with San Francisco in food??

Highly recommended!
author: Nick E.

description:
Little Star's unassuming facade was almost so unassuming I almost walked right. past it-- I'm really glad I didn't.

My eating partner and I eventually determined the dark building on the corner was THE deep dish place we had heard all the rage about. So we walked into the bustling pizzeria, our expressions silently saying "I don't want to wait an hour for a table", but we went ahead nonetheless and talked to the hostess. "Two? Right this way," she said to our happy surprise.

After ordering beers and our pizza, we hungrily waited for its arrival at our table. It was simply delicious, but it would have been better with the sausage that we ordered on it. When our waitress came around we told her this, and she presented us with two options: free pizza or free pizza (and pay for a new one with sausage). We opted to order another entire pizza (a two-fer deal!) and meals for days. Yum.
author: Kristen K.

description:
Their deep dish pizza is really not that good.  I'm definitely not a fan of corn meal, so maybe its just the crust that's my real issue.  But their sauce, what should be the centerpiece of a good deep-dish pie, also seems like a shadow of the tomato-y goodness that you get from Zachary's.

Even so, their wings are really good, and the thin crust pizza is actually one of the best I have had in the city.  So, I begrudgingly give Little Star 4-stars, even though I know the corn meal lovers of the world will force feed me that dry, grainy crust whenever I agree to go there.
author: Lenza M.

description:
Good pizza; bad attitude.

That about sums it up. Their deep dish is totally solid and fairly reasonable in price but the air superiority that bleeds from the staff and clientele is not reasonable. 

The pizza is not so good that it entitles the unkempt misanthrope at the host station to treat customers like lowly plebs unworthy to seek an audience with their glorious deep dish.

In a very mild defense of the staff, I can only assume that their superior attitude is due, in part, to the multitude of know-it-all hipsters that dominate the lobby's landscape. One can only be talked down to so long before they start talking down to others as if that is the norm. (And the cycle of pretension continues.)

On a whole the atmosphere in Little Star is just a bit off. Just enough to make the experience less than comfortable.

Try it once for sure. If it makes special things happen in your pants then, by all means, come again. For me, the overall experience is just aight.
author: Peter F.

description: The pizza here is delicious and the service is wonderful. My favorite salad is their mixed green salad. The ingredients always taste so fresh. While they are "known" for their deep dish pizza, the thin crust pizza is yummy as well. You can't go wrong eating here!
author: Michelle M.

description: So good!  So mofucking good.  My coworker took us to this little gem one evening and it was perfect.  Small place that is intimate but busy.  Attentive waitress.  The beer was perfect temperature... almost icy, but not quite.  Perfectly complimented the piping hot pizza.  I'm typically not a fan of Chicago style pizza, but my world was turned upside down with this pizza.  The sauce and tomatoes were so flavorful.  The crust was crunchy and chewy and just amazing.  I typically leave the crust, but I ate every last crumb off my plate.  No shame, I also snagged the last slice.
author: Trey W.

description:
Little Star you are so modest.

Your name does not do you justice.
Please go to court and change your name to Big Star.
This will put you inline with the taste that comes with consuming your deep dish pizza.
If you need an advocate feel free to reach out to me.
I'll gladly take payment in crispy butter crust, flavorful red sauce, cheese that melts the soul, and toppings that make your taste buds dance.

Little "Big" Star... you're the one.
Making dinner time lots of fun.
author: Po L.

description: This place is a great place for Deep Dish Pizza hands down...if you want some good Chicago style deep dish pizza and you haven't gone here before then you need to go because you are missing out big time.  The one I go to most is the one on Valencia which also has a cool artsy/soul type environment but they also have a few other locations so check it out!
author: Nick R.

description:
I'm in love with Little Star! I crave it in my sleep! Both times that I've been here I came early so I didn't have to wait. Try the mediterranean deep dish. It's heaven! The sauce has fresh diced tomatoes, and it is the best pizza sauce I've tasted.

The wings are also really good. They're spicy and have a kick to them. Way better than wingstop chicken wings if you ask me...

For dessert, I shared the cheesecake with a friend because it's huge, but definitely a good ending to a yummy dinner.
author: Lily Z.

description:
I'm not a big fan of deep dish pizzas, but I wanted to give Little Star a chance since it's got a lot of hype. Deep dish pizzas were always too heavy for me. The crust is thick and there are way too many toppings. I'm more into the Neapolitan style pizzas with thin crusts and fresh ingredients. Nonetheless, Little Star does serve great deep dish pizzas.

The scene:

We took it to go, so I didn't get a chance to fully absorb the atmosphere. I was expecting an old looking pizza parlor with a fat guy from Chicago handing us a pizza, but boy was I wrong. Who knew this is where the hipsters hung out in the Mission? It was a trendy restaurant with candles and cloth napkins. The cashier even had tattoos up her neck.

The food:

K has been wanting to try an anchovie pizza, so we ordered the "Little Star" with anchovies on top.

Little Star pizza - Spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic. I have to admit, it was a dang good pizza. Although not as great as Tony's Pizza Napoletana, I give it props for being a good deep dish pizza. The crust was crispy and firm, much like a pie crust made from corn meal rather than pizza dough. If you're a loyal follower of TheCultureBite, you'll know I don't eat tomatoes. The tomato sauce on this pie was literally 3 inches of semi-crushed whole tomatoes. I just picked it off and passed it over to K. The bottom half of the pizza was very good, however. The ingredients are undoubtedly fresh and it was loaded with garlic. All pluses in my book.

I'm down to try Little Star Pizza again and actually eat in the restaurant. It'll never be better than Tony's by personal opinion, but it's still good.
author: Sam L.

description:
I'm going to keep this short since this place has been reviewed to death

Hanging on the refrigerator door
Pizza is all around outstanding. Crust, sauce and toppings are spot on.
Drink Specials -  I like cheaper drinks.
Service is really friendly and attentive.

Better Luck Next time
Pretty cramped. Surprise Surprise for San Francisco. You are pretty much eating on top of each other.
Chicken wings were just OK.
author: Jeff P.

description: I was so happy when I woke up this morning and remembered that I had leftovers from last night's dinner.  We ordered two pizzas - the Brass Monkey, which is actually the Little Star Pizza with sausage - and the Pesto with chicken which had come highly recommended.  The Pesto came out first - thin crust which I prefer.  It was amazing.  The pesto was just right, and the entire thing was a balance of chicken, and cheese, and pesto.  I could have eaten the entire thing, but I knew we had a second pie coming.  The Brass Monkey was worth the wait. It's deep dish - which is not exactly my favorite.  But it wasn't super doughy.  Instead, it was loaded with sauce, and basil, and cheese, and of course, the delicious sausage.  The crust on both was crispy and light (even on the deep dish pie).  Again, it took some restraint not to finish the entire thing.  I couldn't wait - I made the leftovers of the Brass Monkey into breakfast this morning.  I only wish there was more of it.  It was totally worth the wait (we put our names on the list when we got there and it was going to be an hour wait - we grabbed a drink nearby).  The server was so friendly - as was everyone there.  It just added to what was already a phenomenal meal.
author: Lilly N.

description:
Truthfully, I'd give this place 4.5 stars if I could.

I like the fact that they have both deep dish and thin-crust pizza options. Even though I'm usually a thin-crust fan, I highly recommend the Brass Monkey (deep-dish). You can't find it on the menu, but it's a Little Star (spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic) with sausage added. It is quite amazing!

I just wish there was more seating in this place. If you go when it's busy, expect to wait at least 30 minutes.
author: John C.

description:
Pabst, salad and pizza all very good....bunch of douche bag hipsters here all bad...hahhaa

for some reason it just feels like a copy of zachary's.....still very good though.
author: Hen A.

description:
I love the deep dish pizza here! I usually go out to Zachary's out in Berkeley for deep dish, but I am SO HAPPY to have found a good deep dish place here in the city. The cornmeal crust they use is amazing and definitely adds a wonderful twist to the already awesome pizza.

 If you decide to go, i highly recommend the " Little Star" which consist of Spinach, Ricotta, feta, garlic, mushrooms, and onions. 

But bear in mind that this place usually gets fairly packed so be prepared for the wait!
author: Jenny L.

description:
#60 on the Big Eat SF


Brass Monkey - glorious... but note - it's not on the menu! but it exists if you ask! =)
author: S V.

description:
This is my FAVORITE pizza place! 

The reason for the missing 5th star is the cash only policy (eventhough they checked that they accept cc cards in their profile here), and they don't have my favorite pizza toppings, canadian bacon and pineapple.
author: lex m.

description:
YUM YUM!  I'm from Chicago and this rivals any deep dish pizza I've had there.  Full of flavor and a great rich crust.  

Fun space and lively energy.  Only downside is the long wait, but at least the beer is ice cold to keep you occupied until your table is ready!
author: Philip D.

description:
Ate for the second time last night and the food was awesome again!
The deep dish pizza we had, Mediterranean chicken, was done just right, filling but not too heavy.  We had the garlic bread appetizer which was great, although I would avoid ordering it at all costs on a first date.  It will leave you very pungent.
The only drawbacks were that they don't take reservations so it took like 45 to get a table and the bar/waiting area is pretty small.
author: Norman M.

description: Today was my first "A-OK" meal at Little Star. We deviated from our norm - the delicious thin white pizza and the deep dish with sausage and pepperoni - and instead had the Little Star Deep Dish (a wonderful spinach pizza) and a thin crust pepperoni and sausage - a bit too meaty and spicy for me. We were a four-top, and the noise was so loud that we couldn't easily converse. Waitress seemed rushed and not super nice (albeit efficient). Since we went to socialize as well as eat, feel that we made a bad choice this time. Would also be nice if they had something for kids to drink other than water or soda.
author: Scott B.

description: There's just something about the delicious crust with this pizza.  It's buttery, substantial, and chews with the best texture.  If you're looking for some great pizza, this is what you want to try.  After that, might as well hang in the Mission for the night.  Awesome date night!!
author: Andy S.

description:
The Little Star deep dish takes pizza to the next level. I ask for light cheese because something magical happens with the tomato and the garlic when less cheese is present. 

Ambiance is amazing and the moping cool of the Mission wait staff adds an element of exclusivity. You may feel a bit of tattoo deficit while there.. but it's OK. Don't feel compelled to go get sleeved before a visit. :)
author: Dan B.

description:
all I want to say is when it comes to deep dish pizzas around the east bay and SF, there are a few places that do it well, but what makes Little Star my favorite is their cornmeal crust and that perfect amount of tomato sauce that allows me to taste the other toppings in the pizza.

ahhhhhh.....
author: Joyce L.

description:
Our friends took us here on a weeknight and we fell in love on first bite! WOW -- this is great pizza from the pointy end to the crust. 

Between the four of us, we ordered one thin crust and one deep dish. Both were delicious and we each had leftovers... which tasted great the next day. There is something about that crust that just makes it all work...

I ordered two champagne drinks they had on the menu (hey, it was a rough day and I ordered one-at-a-time), both were delicious but dangerous. One was ginger inspired and the other was more on the fruit punch side. I could have easily ordered more.

Great music on the speakers, great service... nice mix of an after work crowd sprinkled with families (with well-behaved tots, thank goodness!) and date nighters.
author: L. S.

description:
Dinner with a friend on a Wednesday evening around 6:30pm and there was not a wait - we were seated immediately.  I have heard from multiple folks that this is the place for pizza - the part I missed is that the deep dish is the one to order.

The pizza we ordered was a thin crust Italian Combo - Pepperoni, salami, onions, (minus the green bells) black olives, pepperoncini.  The pizza was delicious - wonderful crust and tasty toppings.  It just wasn't anything to write home about.  However, I will say that it was a delicious dinner and I was completely satisfied with both service and meal.  I just don't think it lived up to the hype.

I will have to try it again, and this time order the deep dish.  I do want to note for those out there looking for some amazing pizza (I mean really amazing) -  so far the best pizza I have had in San Francisco by far, is from a place called Giovanni's Pizza At Club Deluxe located at 511 Haight Street.  You will not be disappointed.
author: Kavita M.

description: Okay, while I'm still searching for a SF pizza worthy of deeming "Chicago style," Little Star pizza shoots to the top of my pizza joints list.  The deep dish is the best I've had in the city...so far.  It doesn't compare to my Home Sweet Home Lou Malnati's, but it's got a tasty crust and lots of cheese!!!  The restaurant was small and packed on a Friday night and service was friendly but a little slow.
author: Maggie G.

description:
I've never really been a fan of deep dish pizza, but ended up here with some friends. I'm more of a thin crust girl and planned on ordering one here, but was conviced by those in my dining party and fellow yelpers to go with the deep dish. I split a small deep dish pepperoni with one other and oh my goodness, I was in heaven. It was enough to put me in a food coma and have me coming back for more.  

A small deep dish cheese is about $13 + $1.75 (per topping) before tax.  This was enough for 2 people to each have 3 slices.  

I went with a party of 4 around 7:15 and the wait time was 30 minutes to get a table and another 30 for the pies to be done. There is a small bar at the front to keep you entertained while you wait.

Ambiance: cozy, fairly noisy.
author: Jaime L.

description:
This is my favorite pizza place of all time- I LOVE the classic deep dish. The crust is amazing and the tomatoes add so much flavor. It is always mega packed whenever we head there but is well worth the wait. Grab a glass of wine or beer at the bar and the time flies!

Only thing I don't totally love is the dessert.. nothing too special about it. Otherwise, everything is awesome!
author: Seema M.

description:
I love it. The pizza is consistently outstanding, the staff is always friendly and there's always a bit of a wait, unless you time it just right. 

What to order?

1. Beer. 

2. The Classic Deep Dish (Sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells.) is my personal favorite and always arrives fresh tasting and hot.

3. Mixed Salad. (Mixed greens, cherry tomatoes, red bells, red onions, Gorgonzola cheese and chopped walnuts, tossed with a housemade vinaigrette dressing.) The combo of fresh greens and Gorgonzola and walnuts is perfect.

4. Order up a round of Spicy Chicken Wings (Pound of wings served with baby carrots and blue cheese dressing) and just so you know -- they are addicting!

I've always found the staff to be really cool and accommodating. One of the times we were there, they forgot the chicken wings and dropped our pizza. Wasn't a big deal though, because the way they handled it was really amazing. No complaints and I'm not an easy customer to please.

5. Finish with a scoop of Ciao Bella Gelato. 

Tip: Don't have time to sit around? Take-out is quick and easy!
author: thrasher b.

description:
Little Star - definitely not BIG Star. 

Went here on a first date the other day. I enjoyed the date; the restaurant not so much. 

Half star for the service. Waitress was definitely friendly, but quickly glancing to see if the pizza is done as she zips by doesn't count as checking on how a customer's meal is going. We weren't asked if we wanted another glass of wine (we would have said yes). Wine glasses were simply snatched off the table without a smile even before the last drop was swallowed. It seemed like they were simply trying to herd customer's in and out (order what you want up front because you won't get another chance to get something else later!). 

A solid star for the delicious cornmeal pizza crust. A "not bad at all" star for the cheese and toppings. The delicious glass of Sangiovese gets a star, as does the friendliness of hostess when I walked in.

Reminded me of Best Buy though - nice to you as you enter, difficult to deal with once they know they have your patronage. 4th best tasting pizza I've had in the Bay Area behind Cheeseboard, Zachary's, and Giora.

Not the best restaurant for a date. I would get the pizza again to go though.
author: Gerald W.

description:
Awesome Pizza.  

I love the cornmeal crust, face melting good.

Best pizza in San Francisco.  There, I said it.
author: Niels v.

description: The deep dish pizza was not what we expected. The crust tasted like bisquick. The place was extremely noisy. The only thing that saved them was the green salad. It was mixed with fresh and simple ingredient.
author: Rose O.

description: Yum! The best pizza I've had in SF. I've only had take-out, so I don't know how the restaurant is inside.
author: Olivia P.

description: Very quality artisan pizza. I love pizza, and it's good when it's also as meal-like and nutritious as at Little Star. The takeout is exceptional and stays hot and fresh no matter where in SF you live.
author: L. E.

description:
I shared the titular "Little Star" deep dish pizza with my girlfriend. The quality of the ingredients themselves were great. I loved biting into the chunks of tomatoes and garlic cloves. The crust was also very tasty in a flaky way.

There's nothing more they could have done to make it better. Flawless pizza.
author: adrian b.

description:
A friend of mine and his girlfriend were visiting me from Hawaii and their other friend came up from Santa Cruz to hang out. We hit up Maker Faire and after a long day of walking around, we decided to get dinner. I suggested we go to Little Star, but not the one in Western Addition, the newer Mission one was in my sights. 

It took us forever to find parking, as always on a saturday night in the mission. After a good 20 minutes of searching, we got a parking space not too far, walked to Little Star, and  waited to be seated. Andrew and I had a few beers at the bar while the girls chatted about this and that. It took a while to be seated, which is normal. 

We ordered a large pizza to share and Andrew ordered a plate of wings. The wings weren't all that spicy, though I'm biased because I love the Utah's wings. The pizza took just as long to come to our table as it does at the other location, so nothing surprising there. The atmosphere was  a lot better, having brighter lighting, which was one of my main concerns with the Western Addition LS. 

Overall, I enjoyed this Little Star just as much as the other location, if not more. Skip the mediocre appetizers, have a brew, and dive straight into the deep dish!
author: Aaron M.

description: So unbelievably good all the time every time. You really cant go wrong with ordering any of the deep dish pizzas, and this is coming from a guy who typically dislikes deep dish. Being their specialty, I ordered it the first time there, that was sufficient to make me a believer! Have never gotten around to trying the thin crust, but I'm sure its totally worth trying out at some point. I keep telling myself that but once I'm in there I somehow never even consider it. You can bring in your own bottle of wine for a nominal corkage fee. The things to remember are that they only accept cash and are closed on Mondays. Kind of sad, cos there have been many a Monday when I craved little star. You cannot go wrong with this place, so if you have not been yet...GO!
author: Vivek N.

description: I can't say I've ever been to Chicago, but real thing is half as good as Little Star... buy me a ticket to O'Hare.  We went her for the first time last night and it was delicious.  The salads was great too.
author: Olivia B.

description:
There are two Little Star Pizza locations, one in the Mission and the other in the Western Addition, but this is the way hipper joint of the two (although in a slightly sketchy neighborhood).  Of all the bargain bite places I've been to, this is one that I'd bring my cool friends to (if I had any, oh snap!).

Food:  5 stars.  Although this place is known for it's deep dish pizza, I'm in love with the White Pie, a thin crust pizza topped with feta, mozzarella, tomatoes and zucchini.  It is that good.  The classic deep dish pizza (sausage, mushroom, onions, green bell pepper), is also delicious and not as heavy as most deep dish pizzas (and the crust is fantastic).

Service:  5 stars.  The servers are friendly and the level of service is definitely at a higher quality than most of the Bargain Bite places I've been to.

Atmosphere:  5 stars.  The atmosphere is very lively but a bit noisy.  The crowd skews younger and hip.

Hits:   White Pie, Classic deep dish pizza.

Misses:  Don't park a nice car in the neighborhood.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Pauline's Pizza, Delfina Pizzeria, Pizzaiolo.
author: Keith C.

description:
Yummm I love pizza with lots of tomato sauce. Crust is delicious too and not soggy at all. It's even good the next day if you eat it cold.

They actually accept credit now? I remember coming here before and it was cash only.
author: Leily P.

description:
I think the quality of the food at LIttle Star as gone down a little.  All this talk about Obama being served LIttle Star-inspired pizza made me want to go back again, but has all the success gotten to their heads?  This review was based on my recent visit to their Valencia branch.   

Take the case of....

MIXED GREEN SALAD.  
OLD DAYS:  Little Star green salad was one my favorite salads in the city--basic mixed mesclun, perfectly dressed, with sweet cherry tomatoes and piquant gorgonzola.  
NOW:  The mesclun was really tough, bitter.  The gorgonzola didn't have the fresh, creamy sharpness that it had before.  It tasted like they got it already crumbled out of a container from the De Lano deli case.  The tomatoes weren't as sweet either...  Doesn't have the WOW factor any more.

CLASSIC DEEP DISH PIZZA
OLD DAYS:  Sweet, juicy bits of sausage embedded in layers of cheese, tomatoes strewn over cornmeal crust.
NOW:  Mealy, "sausage" that resembled ground beef more than sausage.  Can someone say "Mama Celeste"???  

Hmm.... that bohemian pizza competitor next door with chef named "Pauline" is sounding more attractive after my last visit to Little Star.  I'm disappointed that one of my favorite pizza places is now cutting corners.  

If you are a LIttle Star old-timer, drop me an e-mail to let me know if you agree that LIttle Star is cutting corners or let me know if I'm smoking crack.
author: Tom K.

description:
Yum yum in my tum tum! Delicious Chicago deep dish style pizza with the crispiest crust I have ever tasted. Equivalent to Zachary's in the East Bay. We usually get take out, but I think the Mission location would make a good happy hour place while the Divisadero location would make a good date place.

Make sure you come with cash!
author: Angela L.

description:
We love this place!!  Order the caprese salad as an appetizer & the deep dish Mediterranean Chicken pizza.  SO YUMMY!!!  Get there early, the dinner crowd gets nutzo.  We got there around 6pm or 6:30 and beat the crowd on a regular weekday (a Thursday, I think?).  We tried "The Little Star" deep dish--we liked it, but it paled in comparison to the Mediterranean Chicken deep dish.  

Even though it's just two of us, we always order the large pizza & take home half, as the deep dish pizza gets better over time :-)
author: Sara W.

description:
I'm still not sure whether I like Little Star or Zachary's better.  Definitely like the cornmeal crust here, and Little Star tends to be a little more sophisticated than Zachary's, so maybe it depends on my mood.  

One thing I do hate is that you won't be seated until your whole party arrives.  I know that a lot of places do this, but I'll always think of Little Star when I think of this policy because we tried to get a large group together for a birthday dinner here, and ended up racing with another large group that was also waiting for the rest of their party to arrive...we ended up losing due to parking issues and had to wait something like 45 minutes to an hour to be seated :(
author: Mousputin S.

description:
We wandered into Little Star on our first night in San Francisco, and were too hungry to endure the two-hour wait. We tried again late on a Monday evening, and were seated at a cozy table with plush booth seats in ten minutes. A bit of wine, a bit of conversation, and a bit of flirting with our hip waitress mitigated the hungered edge of our anticipation, and the hilariously tipsy patrons a few tables away called to both laughter and relaxation to blanket us. 

Soon, a steaming cast iron skillet domed in tomato sauce released from its orbit and descended upon our table, where I eagerly nestled a spatula into layers of fresh tomatoes, clinging mozzarella cheese, tender basil-infused pesto chicken, and golden roasted garlic, drawing out a generous slice with a thick, gleaming, lightly browned crust. The pizza was perfectly baked, but I detected a hint more of the pan's oily residue in the crust's flavor than I would like. Still, I would not hesitate to return to Little Star. The sassy atmosphere and solid preparations keep me full of desire.
author: Brianne C.

description:
Which is better, Zachary's or Little Star?  It's the question on every San Franciscan's lips, right?

I truthfully can't answer.  They are both aiming for different things.  Zachary's is much more American style- they have all the standard toppings I like (the combination of pepperoni and pineapple is amazing, btw!)

Little star is going for something completely different.  Not one mention of pineapple on the menu here- traditional Italian is what they are after.  Their crust was pretty good, about on par with Zachary's.  Their sauce and toppings were awesome!  They have fresh (organic I believe) toppings such as sun-dried tomato.  

Don't waste your time, order the deep dish.  If you want to fit in, put on your best hipster gear and order an organic cola (that's right, no Coke here).  Or if you're like me, just wear your sevens with Uggs and go out to eat in the Marina next time if you don't want funny looks.
author: Cersei T.

description:
Very tasty! I like how the cheese isn't overpowering, even when in leftover pizza.  But most of all, I love the awesomely-textured crunchy substantial cornmeal crust, that's complete with just a hint of sourdough / bitterness.

And yeah, the pizzas are a bit pricey.  But if you actually calculated the price per ounce, you'd likely be amused and surprised; these pies are not only delicious, but DENSE!  Two large slices may well do you for dinner.
author: Adam L.

description:
My second Little Star Pizza review, but this time to rave about the Valencia location. This is hands down the best pizza in the Bay Area. I keep hearing about how Arizmendi tops the list, but I've gone there twice and it's nothing compared to Little Star. 

Last night we chomped down on their mixed green salad (blue cheese, walnuts, tomatoes, red onions on a bed of greens with balsamic vinaigrette) and the thin crust Italian Combo (salami, pepperoni, pepperonicini, green peppers and onions). The ingredients are so fresh it's ridiculous! Their chicken wings are also insanely delicious and you get a huge portion of it to enjoy while you wait for your pizza to come out of the oven.

This place does get really crowded, especially during the weekends, but I've found that Mon-Thurs around 5:30 is a good time to go. Ordering for pick up is also an option and big thumbs up for this location accepting credit cards.
author: Joy L.

description:
Want to know a really quick way to piss me off?  Treat me and my friends like we're an inconvenience when we dine at your restaurant.

Look, I understand that it's tough being the popular kid.  Everyone wants your attention.  Everyone wants a piece of your time (or your pizza).  You have to deal with this every day. The pressure is intense.  I get it.

HOWEVER, that does not give you the privilege to enact selfish rules at the expense of the customer.  I can understand the "Entire Party Must Be Present Before Seating" rule.  You don't want empty seats while others are waiting.  That's cool.  Your "Cash Only" rule is annoying and anachronistic, but tolerable. 

You were even cool when we (very apologetically) broke one of your rules and had an unexpected guest arrive late.  I thought maybe you weren't so bad. 

Then you dropped the bombshell.  

See, our friend is a vegetarian, and we wanted to order another pizza without meat.  But you said no.  That's not allowed.  There was a rule you forgot to post: the "All deep dish pizzas must be ordered at the same time" rule.   Wait.  WHAT? We're not allowed to order more food? That's insane!

Okay, fine.   When I think about it, I get that rule too.  Deep dish pizzas take 20 minutes to cook.  You wanted to turn the table over. Get some more people in the restaurant.

Oh, wait a second.  Forget that.  My friends and I spend money when we go out.  We would have occupied that table and continued to order drinks... you know, those alcoholic beverages with the insanely high profit margins?  Yeah, we would have continued to make money for your restaurant. 

But that's cool.  I get it.  You're just looking to maximize your profits in a mechanical kind of way.  Service isn't your bag.

I won't be back, Little Star.  Your pizza is great, but I want service when I dine out.  There are too many other options in this town.
author: Christopher K.

description:
Little Star has one star on their company graphic, and it would appear that the management of this location are shooting (pun absolutely intended) for a one star review to stick with that one star theme. 

Being as I do not want to reward them for bad behavior, I tacked on a second star for the following reasons; the pizza is tasty enough that I can say with confidence it is better than Zachary's (I don't care if you disagree, so there!), the pizza blow Patxis out of the water (if you disagree with that then you clearly have no taste), and it's a whole lot cheaper than actually flying to Chicago to get my pizza fix.

HOWEVER, the customer service we received makes me happy there is the Divisadero location, because I will not be back to the Mission location anytime, well....ever! 

We had a large group (large group = large bill, assholes!) come in for dinner. We ordered 3 pizzas and various other goodies initially and had another 3 stragglers join our group very shortly after we ordered (and when I say very shortly, it was by no means a long time at all). One of those three does not eat meat, and all of our pizzas were ordered with meat. As anyone knows deep dish pizza is pretty much impossible to "de-meat" (not that I would ever dream of it, those vegetarians are a little cray-cray), so our late bleeding heart, animal rights, kooky but super funny, useful and cool friend asked to order another pizza, sans meat. 

The response? No, we were not allowed to order any more pizza because we were taking up too much room and they wanted us to leave. Enter the obligatory "What the fuck? I want to talk to management" conversation, which ended it management basically reiterating this message. Not to mention they didn't even allow us to order dessert (which might have fed our one hungry companion) for I guess the same reason...they do not want our business (though they were happy to take the mandatory 18 percent gratuity they tack on to large parties). 

Little Star, you are not so important that turning away business because you have a wait suddenly becomes acceptable. I don't care how good your food is. I will not be back. 

P.S. if you are going to serve your beer in overly iced glasses (ie. chunks of ice frozen to the surface), absorbency coasters would be a good investment....perhaps some of that unearned gratuity could go towards those.
author: Drue C.

description:
Little Star only gets one from me. After my good Friend Carla comes to enjoy their above average pizza, she is told that for large parties, we are limited to the number of deep dish pizzas that we can order; that we can only order them at the bigging of the meal. 

WTF?!?!

They said that this is due to the amount of baking time that it takes for them to bake a deep dish and so that the large party can get rushed off the table and more people can be seated. This makes no sense on so many levels: 

1. We still had pizza on the table so we definitely weren't going to leave any time soon anyway.
2. They couldn't even consider the fact that people's diets are different. (or they didn't care) 
3. That's just horrible customer service....any way you cut it. 
4. I don't remember them asking if we wanted desert. (not that I would have patronized them any more, but still..thats just rude)

I just don't get how paying customers are told that they can't order again when the food runs out? Bad form Little Star. As a Filipino I guess I'm especially disappointed that they left a customer leave the table hungry..... 

Get over yourselves....and treat every customer like they are valued. Pizza Orgasmica Here I come.
author: Angelo F.

description:
*update 3/2/2008* 

Little Star's eh, star is starting to fade. No, the pizza is still fantastic. But the holier than thou attitude is getting to be a bit much. 

We were with a large group and arrived soon after opening to assure a spot. A couple of late comers showed up as our pizzas started to arrive and we decided to order one additional pie. And we were told no. Wait, a restaurant that won't let you order MORE food? It's not like we didn't have food in front of us that was still going to take a while to finish. And it's not as though we weren't going to continue ordering more drinks while eating and waiting for an additional pie. 

My original five star review is now three...and I even deleted my original review and all those U-F-C votes to get the word out.
Booo, Little Star.

*original review*  Craving Little Star pizza but don't feel like waiting an hour for a table?  Get yee to the new location on Valencia Street!  

We arrived around 7pm on a Thursday night and there were only two other tables occupied.  From the street the place looked closed-they actually had to post a sign on the door saying that they were open!  By the time we left at 8:30 or so it was starting to fill up but was by no means as crowded as I've seen Divisidero get.

Overall it's a little bigger than the original location and a little fancier-not so much as to seem out of place in the 'hood, though.  They are also cash only (hmph) but with pizza this good (I still say better than Zachary's) it's definitely worth a trip to the ATM.

*update 11/4/2006*  I returned to Little Star in the Mission with a group of friends and we were seated within 10 minutes around 8:15pm on a Friday evening.  I guess the word is still not out on the new location-lucky for me!
author: phil h.

description:
Twinkle Twinkle Little Star
Your deep dish is best by far
On a base of corn meal crust
Sweet tomatoes fuel my lust
Twinkle Twinkle Little Star
Your deep dish is best by far

It's a little cramped inside
A simple menu is your guide
With PBR instead of Schlitz
Jukebox plays some 80s hits
Pies baked fresh and it smells great
Order salad while you wait

Years I thought Zach's was the best
But after yours I can attest
You're the Bay's Chicago king
It's so good you'll want to sing
Twinkle Twinkle Little Star
Your deep dish is best by far
author: Arnold G.

description:
When you have 15/20 Yelpers in your restaurant you are in trouble.
First things first, our waiter was AWESOME! He handled a large group not just professionally but with style. On a busy Friday night most places would have acted like "Eat up and leave". But no, they were totally cool.
They have Racer 5 IPA on tap!
I have to ding 1 1/2 star for the food. I could tell the ingredients were first rate and the crust was west coast perfect. The sauce was good but damn they put 3x as much as needed on the pie. The sauce is suppose to compliment the ingredients not cover them up.
This review is based on one visit, but my friend lives around the corner so you my loyal subjects shall remain informed as details emerge.
author: Lance G.

description:
Something needs to be said when I'm sated after two slices of pizza. It happens so rarely. I am the Kobayashi* of sending pizza slices into a vortex of me, never to be seen again. I live to eat them and eat them to live. So imagine the giant question mark over my head when I had two slices of Little Star's vegetarian pie and was overcome with the fat, happy, satisfied, "that was so good if I eat another I may get sick" blissful feeling.

The pizza bitch in me usually manifests when pie is soggily leaden with too many toppings. Usually three is my max. So again I'm surprised because there's maybe fifteen vegetables on my pizza, 2 or 3 kinds of cheese somewhere in the center, sauce on top. Has the world gone President Newsom**? And moreover, am I okay with it?

Didn't eat in the joint, it was take-out on Oscar night. Bored, bored, bored watching interpretive dance. When I'm bored, pizza is fearful, as well it should be. Pizza is wise to fear me when boring teevee is on. With the help of the American Express commercial by the Rushmore guy*** I surprised myself and left two slices in the box.

So I enjoyed Little Star pizza. And it helped me finally become master of several key personal weaknesses: 

1) My inability to stop eating pizza. 
2) My inability to stop eating free food. 
3) My inability to stop eating when bored stiff by the boring Oscars.
4) Some other inability. I forget. Probably the inability to turn down a hit of weed when I'm already half blind from the drink.

Fancy buff jobs on what are basically peasant eats are a San Francisco trendy dining staple. But I still must admit that this is some kind of Super Pizza made from the parts of Lesser Pizzas.  
 
* Kobayashi is that Japanese guy with the mutant belly that allows him to only ever eat hot dogs on the day of the Nathan's hot dog eating contest and still beat every fat, gross American in sweatpants who dares challenge him.

** President Newsom is my new unit of measure for crazy. In the car of Newsom's stalker, the night he tried to get in The Mayor's building, they found a composite photo of The Stalker, Stalker's Dad and the Gav, purple latex gloves, a bunch of other creepy stuff and a mixtape labeled President Newsom.

*** http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=spCknVcaSHg
author: Jeremy W.

description:
I wish I may, 
I wish I might, 
On this Little Star, 
I wish tonight.
Tonight I wish for a good deep dish pizza in San Francisco. Oh.. and I guess for World Peace also. But definitely a good deep dish. 

*poof*

My wish has been granted.  Actually let's keep this brief and go through the laundry list of what's what:
1. Great deep dish
2. Great thin crust.
3. Good selection of beers.
4. Amazing juke box. One of the best in the city.
5. Cool staff.

The only negative: Cash only. But they have an ATM on property that only charges 25 cents for the transaction. 25 cents!! And the barkeep who had just served me an ice-cold Racer 5 IPA apologized for charging that much saying, "We have to charge something." Awesomeness. What are you still doing here??? Quit reading and go get some good beer and pizza at Little Star.
author: Bucky K.

description:
My Little Star experience came when back in SF visiting a friend.  How strange that I lived in the city for a decade and never came here!  It wasn't even on my radar.

Anyway, we got take out (a smart choice, I guess, since it's always packed!).  Ordered up some spicy chicken wings, a mixed salad, and two small pizzas:  Mediterranean Chicken and Brass Monkey (the latter I learned of reading Yelp reviews, so thanks!).  It was an expensive undertaking - I'm not used to spending $70 on pizza take out!

The wings were great - nice and tender, and great flavor.  The salad was a small portion but flavorful.  On to the pizza!  I was completely skeptical of the Mediterranean Chicken.  I'm not a fan of chicken on pizzas for some reason, but this was out of this world!  I really enjoyed it.  Tons of flavor.  The Brass Monkey was ok, but I felt that the flavors were muted, especially as compared to the Chicken.

In both cases, the crust was great.  I'd definitely get this again if I got a deep dish craving and wasn't able to get to Zachary's!
author: Lynn L.

description:
I grew up in the suburbs of Chicago and yes, I love pizza.  I lean towards a certain kind, mostly deep dish.  However, I love me a good thin crust pizza and I won't frown upon the thought of sinking my teeth into one.  

Having a great pizza place is important in a city.  Its close to having that reliable mexican burrito joint that you can visit and know what you are getting.  Since moving here, it was important for me to find great pizza I could eat as well as take any guests to  that I could guarantee a great night with.  

I had heard of this place, only because this was the pizza Barack Obama wanted when he first got into office.  Yes,  I Illinois senator, living in Chicago, choosing a deep dish pizza from San Francisco.  

The roots of Little Star (I believe cause I'm trying to remember from a story about two years ago) come from some place in central Illinois.  I think someone moved from there to SF but brought their style of pizza with.  The key difference with this pizza, more than any other deep dish  is that they use corn meal and there is a fair amount of it in the crust and drizzled on the top of the deep dish.  

The addition of corn meal is an excellent addition.  I can't complain.  Of all the deep dish I've had, this is the only one that has had corn meal in it.  Of all the deep dish crusts I've had, this is one of the few that I loved eating.  It was a welcome addition and one I can't complain with.  

So where does the deep dish fit compared to all the Chicago standards?  I think its unique with the addition of corn meal.  We ordered the Little Star.  Actually, we ordered the Brass Monkey, which is the Little Star with sausage added on.  The 7x7 menu had Brass Monkey on it but that was last year and they no longer have it on the menu.  But, you can add it to the Little Star.  

Its not as cheesy as Giordano's.  Not as marinara-saucy like the original Pizzeria Unos.  Not as buttery as Lou Malnatis.  Its very good deep dish pizza though.  

Surprisingly, I thought the thin crust was excellent.  Once of the best and the corn meal crust really showed its strength here.  We had the chicken pesto and it was excellent.  Great thin crust pizza.

We had the garlic bread to start as well as the spicy chicken wings.  Both were very good.  The garlic bread is a spreadable garlic and butter at your table.  A slightly different twist on the normal and I liked it.  The wings were tasty too.  Not too spicy but not overwhelming and tabasco based as well.  Its served with a nice crumbled blue cheese dressing.  

I had high expectations for Little Star and they didn't disappoint.  I can easily recommend this place.  

I now feel at home.
author: Mark K.

description: Love the deep dish pizza --- delicious crust. I dont live near Little Star so I don't come here as often. It's definitely better than Patxi's though!
author: Shivani S.

description:
Dear Stephanie, 
(Manager of Little Star)

Thank you for being so accomodating!!!!!

You never know with large groups! It's like herding cats! Phew! I'm so glad everyone came and had a great pizza feast in honor of our friend Cootz!!! 

Everyone had a great time and enjoyed themselves. Super low key.

 I hope we ate enough pizza and beer! 
I have never eaten at Little Star before and I'd have to say that you guys give Zachary's a run for their money!

 Well, now I've found my pizza shop. The Divis one is close to my house, so you guys win. I've lived and worked in SF for ten years and have not had the OMG reaction with my first bite of SF pizza-that is-until now.

 Our server was awesome-so we tipped him extra and he was really cool with helping with the beer selections. He chose one for me that was dark and 7% alchyhall! Burp!

I was so afraid our table would be whisked away making Joyita very =(
So thanks to Darin for being on time-i will paraphrase since I had beer ear muffs on, "I'm Japanese, I show the fuck up!"
and Kia for being a stand-in Joyita to talk to you. 

I'm still full. 

And it's 8 am the next day!

I think.

 If I'm good.



 I deserve pizza tomorrow. 




I'll be coming with bells on.
author: J A.

description:
Wow. I died and thank God ended up at Little Star Pizza. Best. Pizza. Ever. Never have I munched on perfectly thin, cripified pizza with just the right amount of toppings.  I really despise pizzas that have too little or way too much toppings - and worst of all, a soggy thin crust. But Little Star Pizza has perfected the art of creating a masterpiece pizza. I will be back here again and again...and again. The only other place that's comparable to Little Star Pizza is a place called Krunchy Pizza - BUT that's all the way in New York. And I'm not about to hop on a flight anytime soon.

As for the garlic bread, which I was totally craving, was good because, well, I made it.  They bring out a toasted loaf of bread, a whole clove of oven roasted garlic, and some soft butter. It's a do-it-yourself garlic bread, and I didn't really want to do it myself, but I did. Yes, some people may like the idea because they can choose how much garlic and butter goes on the garlic bread, but not I. Maybe I'm just lazy, but I want my food to be fully prepared when I eat out at a restaurant. 

Anyhoo, nevertheless, this is some of the best pizza I have ever tasted in my present life, and well, just maybe, my past life too.



***This is a CASH ONLY establishment. :*( I hate cash.
author: Aim E.

description: No wait on a Sunday afternoon. Sweet. Pom-pagne (champagne, pomegranate juice and sugar cubes) with a deep dish classic pizza and anti-pasta. Good food. Great company. What more can you ask for?
author: Anne T.

description:
I have to say, I'm a little disappointed.  Oh not with the food, it's very yummy (if food were the only element under consideration I'd give this place five stars),  not with the service, not with the prices (ended up at less than $20 per person including drinks) but with the management.  Allow me to explain...

We were a pretty big group, 13 by the time all was said and done, this is, perhaps, mildly difficult for a space as small as Little Star, however, we arrived early, well before the dinner rush, so it really should not have been  a big deal.  Our waitress was very nice, she recommended the special of the day, an asparagus, asiago, white wine and red onion concoction that sounded delicious (and it was!), so we ordered that, a classic, a pizza to appease the picky among us and some wings.  

There we were, eating, drinking and making merry, plowing through everything we ordered, it was decided that we didn't have quite enough, so we called our waitress over to order more.  We were informed that we could not order another deep dish pizza for some reason that made no sense.  Apparently they have some rule about large parties having to order everything they want all at one time.  WTF, are you kidding?

Sadly, they were not kidding, and unfortunately that really soured the experience.  Allow me to make it clear, we were not being loud, rowdy or otherwise obnoxious, we had not been monopolizing the table for an inordinately long period of time, it was early, there was not a huge crowd waiting to be seated, there was no reasonable reason for such an arbitrary rule.  Shortly after the whole 'no more pizza for you' exchange our waitress dropped off the check, before we asked for it, before we were ready for it.  The "get the f*** out" message could not have been more clear.

Ok, I hear you Little Star, you don't have to ask me twice.  There are plenty of other places to spend my money.
author: Renae H.

description:
3.5   After my first amazing experience at Little Star on Divis. a few days ago, I had to have it again.  Now.  So, since we were in the neighborhood, we stopped by this Little Star.

Not as good as the one on Divisadero.  First of all, it is loud as a mofo in there.  Normally I dont even notice when it's loud in a joint, but this was ridiculous.  Secondly, the pizza just wasnt as good as Divis.  It was too saucy.  And lastly, the order of wings was "meh".  Really oily.  

I'll be at Little Star on Divisadero.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
This place can do no wrong, and now with a larger second location. . . . .ta da!

The Valencia Little Star location is wonderful.  It relieves the anxiety that would occur before heading to the Divis location knowing full well if you don't show up before they open, you'll wait, and wait, and wait. 

This new location is larger with a bar area to chill out, wait for your table, and chat with your people.  

My brother Daniel and I went to dinner last night before a concert.  We arrived on the earlier side of Saturday night din din but the place began to fill quickly.  We were not rushed at all and had plenty of time for my brother to fill me in on his love life.  He's currently seeing a nurse who needs a lot of reasurance.  He then told me about this awesome gal he met through his pal at work.  Everything about her seems great; she's beautiful, smart, independent, witty, confident, friendly. . .sounds good eh?  

Little Star is good like that.  Good food, good people, good ambiance to have a fabulous dinner relaxing and catching up with the people you care about. . .ah, isn't that just sweet?

So after dinner we decided to walk off our food coma with a stroll down Valencia street right before we took off for our concert at the Warfield. . .
author: James M.

description: ok, major improvements since the last time i ate here. theyre yummy again. yayyyyyy
author: Richard L.

description: I love the Divis location, and believe I will stick to that one exclusively. I came here with a friend, we ordered a pizza with half pesto, half not. When it arrived it turns out they had squirted the pesto on top. Weird. I don't know if this is something typical, cause I've never had that occur anywhere else.
author: gabby m.

description:
Once you have Little star pizza you cannot go back to any other pizza...Last night my roommate and I shared  a deep dish veggie pizza.  This pizza was so wonderful that even after I gorged myself eating half of a deep dish, I caught myself eying my neighbors pizza!  
The crust is perfectly crunchy and tastes like butter and the toppings taste fresh and tangy and delicious.  They also have fantastic salads to start your dinner with and excellent wine selection...
Little Star is super delicious and does not cost any more then any other pizza place!  16/20 per pizza and worth every cent.  

Also, They are now open for lunch on the weekends AND they started taking reservations for dinner this week..........sshhhhhhhhhhhhhh.

Can't wait to go back------I love you Little Star Pizza..
author: Michele K.

description:
I don't even care that it doesn't accept credit cards. OK, I kind of do, that's a bit strange considering the average bill of this joint. But I'm usually six vinos in and three slices deep before I even think about the cost which, ultimately, isn't bad at all. But cost, schmost.

Flavor? Lots of it.  Eat-the-cornmeal-crust good. Lick-the-plate-if-I-wasn't-in-public good.

A large salad (even if you don't like pizza, you'll be blown away by the gorgonzola/walnuts/spring mix/feta creation), works as an appetizer for four. If I'm feeling healthy, I split this sucker with one other person and chow down on only 1 or 2 slices of thin crust. Red wine to wash down all that delicious, red-sauced delight. Deep dish (classic) AND thin crust (Italian combo) to keep everyone happy. Great jukebox that'll keep you busy if you have to wait for a table or the bathroom.

It gets crazy crowded in here (and, admittedly, can get unpleasant) after 7 p.m., but if you can get here even at 6:30, you'll find more open tables and room at the bar.
author: Tara R.

description:
Notes:

1) I'm dumb and I had the review listed under "original review" posted for the Western Addition store for the past 3.5 months. I hate when I do that

2) The food is very good.

3) The management is not so much. Big parties are forced to order all their food at the same time. No late orders. No matter that they are paying, that they are drinking, that they are being considerate. No matter, sorry, no more food for you.  They lose a full 1.5 stars here

4) I am ROUNDING UP to 3 stars. It is two and fractional.

original review:


I have a new favorite pizza place in the bay area! At least I think so; it's been two years since I've made it to Zachary's, so I will have to try that again to be sure. Regardless, Little Star is quite good.

There is much to like about their pizza. The sauce is filled with large pieces of tomatoes, and well spiced (but more of the sauce later). They use a proper amount of cheese. And the bottom crust was crispy and tasty (but more of the crust later). They also have a decent beverage selection.

Now for the inevitable criticisms:

1) The sauce is good, but there is too much of it. My plate was a sea of red bits when I was done eating, since I knocked about 33% of it off.

2) The crust, while good, is not great. If they brushed the edges with butter like Lou's, it would kick the crust into the "I will eat this even though it is filling me up and making me skip out on the inside part that I really want" territory. As it is, I'll eat some of the crust, but not all.

3) The service - a little spacey. It wasn't that busy while I was here, but I kind of wonder what it's like when it is packed.

4) Cash only - I understand they're slackers, but still, in this modern day and age, cash only is pretty lame for a place like this.
11/18/2007
author: neil c.

description:
I'm about to review the shit out of this place!!!  Why?  Because I love Little Star like nobody's business.

Their signature "Little Star" pizza - ricotta, feta, spinach, onions, mushrooms and garlic - is unbelievable (I suggest adding sausage).  The Caprese salad is unbelievable.  The White Pie is unbelievable.  

So what else do you need?

Exposed brick wall?  Done.  Good selection of nice wines and bottled beers?  Done.  Awesome jukebox blasting some jams?  Done.  

The only difficulty I have is deciding between this location and the Divisadero location.  Divisadero is smaller, has slightly longer waits, but I feel less crowded than I do at this location.  Truth is that either loaction has pizza that you'll have dreams about:  Wet.  Dreams.
author: Matthew H.

description:
I'm going to have to add my voice to the recent outcry against the service at Little Star in the Mission. Which is a shame, because in my book, Little Star's deep dish pizza is better than Zachary's, it's closest competition in the mouths of the outspoken public. Having a little east bay pride, that's no small statement. It's a shame that I won't be treating myself to such a pizza again, or at least not at this location.

I was at the opposite end of the table, so I didn't hear the goings on. But I have absolute faith in the previous reviewers. I know that the offended customer did show up late, but while there was still plenty of food on the table, and more beer was served after she arrived. I never saw her eat a bite. Having seen her earlier in the day, I know that she was looking forward to some pizza with her friends. It sucks to be left out. As has been said, that's no way to treat your customers.

Perhaps Yelp should have a "People hate us on Yelp" sticker to affix over the one that's currently in their front window. Because loved they're not.
author: Paul B.

description: Fantastic crust, but that's about all it has going for it. Also, check your bill for potential shenanigans with their "we're going to be a jerk because San Francisco makes us treat our workers like human beings" surcharge.
author: Brian W.

description:
I never crave non-Asian food. But the other day I realized how much I love this place because I was actually craving a Little Star deep dish pizza!  This place is awesome - their salads are delicious and the Little Star deep dish pizza is heavenly.  We take our family and friends to Little Star when they come visit us and every person has absolutely loved the deep dish pizza here.  

The only down side is that the last time we went we called ahead and the guy said there was no wait at all and that we did not have to put our name on the wait list. When we got there 5 minutes later, there was a 25-30 minute wait!  I thought it should have been handled better. We ended up waiting for 25 minutes and I must admit, I was a bit miffed. But as soon as I bit into the Little Star deep dish, all was well again. 

They now take credit card at this location.
author: Connie W.

description:
Little Star has sort of become the epicenter of my little Mission world.  You can find my peeps here when we're not at drinking margaritas at Puerto.

The jukebox alone earns it 5 stars.  Where else can you find the Pixies, Jawbreaker, the Shins and Joanna Newsom all in one place?

After coercing your friends to pick some songs, grab a nice glass of red wine from the bar to warm you up while you wait.  Once seated, order the deep dish AND the thin crust. 

By the time you get your pizza, your jukebox selections will have kicked in, and  you'll be singing out loud, reveling in the fact that you were able to take over a pizza joint.
author: Nicole G.

description:
YUM!  Little Star kicks some major ass.  I've been here a few times and it's great every time.   We ordered a mixed salad which was enormous and delicious.  I would definitely recommend getting this to  share.  

Last time I went, I wanted to try two of the deep dish pizzas...so we ordered the Little Star and the Classic.  The Little Star was amazing.  It makes me want to go now just thinking about it!   Next time I go, I'll get the Little Star and try a thin crust pizza too.  

Little Star uses a fantastic cornmeal crust that is so incredibly tasty.  The ingredients are really fresh as well.  Zachary's still holds a special place in my heart since I lived in Berkeley for a while.  I would have to say that both are my top picks for deep dish pizza.  If you can't make it that far north,  Paxti's in Palo Alto isn't a bad backup plan.

*Cash only- but they have an ATM*
author: Vivian W.

description:
what i ordered... classic deep dish (w/ sausage, mushroom, onion and green bell peppers)

overall pizza pie was just ok, the crust was made of cornmeal, tasted like sliced cornbread toasted too hard on one side so it crumbles on a bite. sauce on top was good just like zachary's, mushroom was so good and so much of it, cheese was the most minimal i've eaten and/or seen in a deep dish, clump's of sausage were nowhere to be found but i did tasted some pellet sized one's the size of tic tac's.

ambiance... good(warm, dim lit atmosphere with clean restroom)
service... good(nice and smiley but reserved)
cost... $$+(typical)
author: Gors P.

description:
Chicago Style pizza = Comfort Food...

We've been ordering the deep dish Vegetarian, with anchovies......and it's incredible. Have that with a big bottle of old-vine Zinfandel, and it's the perfect meal!! 

MA
author: Mickey A.

description:
Let me begin by saying,

This is my favorite Pizza Place in the City!

They have the "Best Thin Crust Pizza" in the City!

I have tried all the flavors, and I must say the best combinations are a Half/Half  Pesto Chicken and The Classic.

The Italian seems good with all the toppings, but when it comes to the taste "The Classic" is named that for a reason.

This restaurant has a strong word of mouth, so if you don't get their before 6:30 Expect to be waiting up to 20-30 mins even for a table of 2.  This place gets busy!  The prices are very reasonable for what you are getting, better quality and cheaper then Delfina.  The ambiance is just as nice, the cool brick walls makes you feel like your in New York's Meat packing district!

I'm not a big fan of their Deep dishes, but I must say again that the Thin Crust Pizza is the best in the city,  It's so crispy that I left some leftovers in the backseat of my car, and when I had it the next morning it was still crispy...simply amazing!

I eat here at least once a month, so if you see a tall, Asian dude stuffing his face...please buy me a beer, a Pacifico please, non of that PBR (hipster's drink of choice.) Sh*t.
author: J Y.

description:
As Snoop Dogg would say...

"ooo-WE!"

I am tempted to end my review there just to make a point, but that would be lame. Let's just say that Zachary's deep dish pizza ain't worth the drive anymore. Not when  Little Star is just down the street. And (GASP!) it's better!

mmm-hmm...

The corn meal crust (I think that's what it is) is awesome. I swear I almost ate a whole small pizza by myself, quite the accomplishment I might add. Never mind the fact that I went back one week later to get another fix of deep dish delight. What can I say? I love me some Little Star!
author: Stephanie I.

description: May have been the best pizza I've ever had.  The salads aren't bad either.  Will make it a point to go back.
author: Chonlana J.

description:
What the world doesn't need now . . . is another Little Star Review.  But hear me out, since I trekked all the way from Oaktown to meet some friends for this joint.  The next paragraph is for Oakies:

It's Zachary's, but better.  Yeah, I said it.  Better food.  Less douchey.  No college crowd to contend with, but I think our table was the only one wearing black - hipster element, check.

Amazing pizza, (we had the Little Star) good wine list (tempranillo, santa ynez cab, and dry creek valley ZIn) with a happy hour that we took advantage of.  Cute sign in the bathroom warning would-be graffitos that they would rather have you give the finger on the way out than deface their walls.  That's cool.  Friendly staff, refreshingly free of the mission hipster self-righteousness that's so easy to run afoul of when you're here.  And when I lived here in the late '90s, I was just as guilty as anyone else . . .

did I mention how incredibly cold and windy it was last night?  at least we weren't near the door when the portal to Hoth opened . . . and I think my choice of blue shirt and blue jeans wasn't so smart, I probably looked like a sureno, not exactly the wisest thing in the mission . . . made it home safely to Oakland unscathed, though. ;-)
author: Joe B.

description:
Size DOES matter...  Little Star Pizza isnt so little :-)

My friend and i (the greedy bastards that we are) ordered large deep dish each.  thinking if we can finish it we can take it home.  We've been eating leftover pizza for the last 3 days.  our waiter was shocked when we placed the order since everyone else seem to order the std 9 inch and share.  we ordered the 12" (or 13 i think) EACH.

as you can imagine we're OD'd on pizza.  once recovered, we'll try their thin crust.  looks equally delicious.

the couple next to us was roe-sham-boing on who will pay the bill.  what a DOUCHE!!  HE should pay...  if youre on a date and youre RSB-ing on the bill, drop the looser.
author: Marcia B.

description:
Before you fling poo at me. This is my rationale:

1) My patient side convinced me to wait **1.5 hours** for a table here on a Saturday night just so I can get it over with and see what the hoopla is about.Thank god for their interesting list of beers and good company, So: 2 stars

2) Their White Pie is just ok. Sorry, I am just not too impressed with their thin crust. It's like too thick to be thin or something, So: 3 stars 

3) Classic Deep Dish is where my money's at. Their tomato sauce rocks and is fresh as hell. The crust is slightly sweet and it tastes like it's made out of something divine like corn meal?? And I love corn, So: 5 stars

Finally: (2+3+5)
               ----------   = 3.333333333
                    3
author: Faffy L.

description: Awesome chicago style pizza. I have been to Zachary's and Patxi's numerous times but this is my first time at Little Star. I'd say all three pizza's are quite similar with the big difference being in their crusts. Little Star has the most semolina/corn flour which many think is authentic to how it's done in Chicago. Zachary's on the other hand doesn't use any semolina and it's just a flour crust, and I'd say Patxi's in right in the middle. I like all 3 versions, but it's awesome the Bay Area has so many great Chicago style pizza places to choose from!
author: John G.

description:
Dear Zachary's,

We've had some great times over the last 10 years or so...some cheesy, some not so cheesy, and others more garlicky than cheesy (huh?).

If everything's so great then why am I writing, you ask? Well, I have a confession to make. You see, I've been cheating on you over the last few years...first, it was a couple of brief flings with Patxi's, and more recently I've been sneaking out to see Little Star...it's this recent development that has caused me to rethink some things.

When I saw Patxi's it was like spending time with a slightly less attractive (yet attractive nonetheless) version of you, and you were always number one in my heart...however, When I first started seeing Little Star I feared that this would develop into something different, and it has. I now find myself thinking of Little Star more than you, and it hurts me to say that it has replaced you as my number one...

There, there, don't cry...you have many eligible suitors walking through your doors every day, and it's not like I won't see you again...I'll just be seeing less of you.

Be strong, and good luck...

Love,
Art

Whew, now that that's over...

So, I went to Little Star in the Mission for the first time a short while ago, and it was fantastic! The pie we had (the classic) was a perfect blend of crust, sauce, cheese and toppings. As I mentioned in my review of their other location, the thing I like most about them is that they don't use as much cheese as other stuffed pizza joints do, which definitely reduces the 'brick in the gut' post-meal feeling...

They also have great salads (love the mixed salad) and drink options (this time around we tried a wine, but all I can remember about it was that it was a red and was really good). They also have one of the best (if not the best) jukeboxes around...while we were there I remember hearing New Order, the Smiths, Depeche Mode and Interpol, among others...

The service was great, and I like the dark, cozy decor (you're pretty much forced to get cozy because it gets loud in here!) as well as the location (compared to the one on Divisadero)...just remember to bring your cash (or an ATM card), because that's all they take!

As mentioned above, I'll definitely be coming back here, but may cheat on them with Zachary's and Patxi's from time to time...
author: Art D.

description:
Well, I had really high hopes for this place.  I'd read the rave reviews of the Divisadero location, and was happy to see a hand-written sign on the new Valencia window saying that they were now open.  We pulled the car over ... screeeech!

We walked in, and the place looked great.  The staff was perky and eager to serve, and Kenny Rogers was playing on the jukebox, later followed by the Violent Femmes, Donna Summer, and Pat Benetar.  The wine/beer/soda list was eclectic as well.  We were ready to be blown away.

Granted, the waitress told us the specialty here was deep-dish, but we are thin-crust folks at heart, and that is the standard by which we judge our pizza.  This is where the "meh" comes into my review.

The sun-dried tomatoes were fantastic.  The crust was bland and a little thick for a thin-crust.  The sauce was pleasant, albeit unremarkable. There was too much cheese.  We were underwhelmed.  (OK, I was rawly disappointed.)  

I would come back for drinks (they have happy HOURS from 5-6:30pm and 10-11:30pm nightly), but would rather hit up Delfina or somewhere else for my next pizza.  I hate to be the bearer of bad news, but you'd rather hear it from me, no?
author: Andi T.

description:
I'm not sure if its because I'm asian.

1) ordered buffalo wings.
2) waited 20 or so minutes for them, didn't get them so we got our waitress to come over to our table, she said she forgot and she'll get it out right away.
3) waited +20 minutes, still no wings, but pizza came.
4) finished pizza, no wings, got the manager, obviously apologized like any other dignified manager, offer us free dessert and would pack our buffalo wings in a box.
5) check came, still no wings.
6) me: what the fck?
7) no tip.

Last but not least, this place is so small, if you sit next to other people, it would seem like you're sitting together.
author: Csndra L.

description:
One of the few places that have earned my coveted 5 star rating. hahaha

Um, it's good. I mean, pizza is always good, but it's especially good here. 

crust is always just the way I like it. I love meat, but when i go with my veggie friend the Veggie pizza makes me forget about the delicious tastiness that is meat. 

Salads are kinda ...meh, but that's not what I'm here for anyway. Beers are decently priced and so is the pizza for the quality. ;) 

OH, and I always avoid the lines by going in right before 7. Eating earlier is healthier anyway. Oh, and the best part about this place, they finally take credit card!!!

TASTYYYYY!
author: Eugenia Y.

description:
I think I had a food orgasm at the table.  People were sort of staring, but in that "we understand" way.

Context: it was after a hike, and then a few drinks, with some great company. 

But mostly, it was the pizza.  Perfectly crispy-soft cornmeal crust, fresh ingredients, gorgeous cheese, but what really did it for me was the sauce.  Where can I get that sauce?

Love the ambience, service was quick and friendly, could have done without the line for the bathroom.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Are you reading this before heading over to Little Star?
If so let me know because I will join you.
After eating here last night it's all I can think about.

Great cornmeal crust and chunky, tangy past sauce on top. Not crazy cheesy like my bad memories of wannabe deep dish, all the elements are in balance. 

Had to wait 45 minutes but walked to a nearby bar in the meantime.
author: Sari G.

description:
I loved this pizza. It was a San Francisco take on deep dish. I expected it to be heavy, but to my surprise it was light and fresh. My boyfriend and I got a small to split with a salad, but we'd do a large and take some home next time. We almost needed one extra bite for the perfect amount.

The wait on a Wednesday evening was over 90 minutes, so be prepared or you can carry out!

Can't wait to go back to try the thin crust too and maybe with friends for a few beers. Seems like that kind of place.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Love the new local. 
When the peeps are hungry at an impromptu gathering where we find ourselves with no reservation. Little Star in the mission has been accomodating. The service is fast and friendly. Right now I am all about their deep dish. The wine list is still Kermit Lynch imports. Five stars because you can order the Bandol by the glass. But why would you just want one glass of Bandol.. Well, I just cannot have one glass of Bandol.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I am by no means a pizza aficionado, but I know what  I like...and Little Star is it!

It was a busy Saturday night, but we still only waited about 10 minutes for a table. A big delicious beer (Flight of the Conchords,anyone?) from the bar filled up the time nicely.

We ordered the garlic bread as an appetizer. It is warm bread, a bowl of butter and whole garlic...basically, build your own garlic bread! It is *so* good and the buttah is...buttah. So good.

We had the Little Star, and it was freakin' delicious. Plenty of leftovers for munchies later!
author: S F.

description:
I hate crust.  I usually eat up to the crust and leave a pile of crust scalps on my plate.  But that's apparently because I've never had Little Star's crust, until tonight.  Now I understand what pizza crust can be.  This is the platonic form.  Even the deep dish left me wanting more.  Zach's crust has nothing on this.

It's a disappointing, then, that the rest of the pizza wasn't so good.  All the pies were topped with the same pile of somewhat inert tomato sauce.
