The Mediterranean pizza, which has chicken, was the same texture as the little star, which is all spinach.  How is that?  Other than the crust, the pizza was a touch monotonous.  If only I could transplant this crust onto a Zach's pie.

Still, 4 stars because of the astounding chicken wings.  The salad wasn't too bad, either.
author: Ben A.

description:
Other than the countless hours that I have spent at O'Hare International Airport during various layovers while criss crossing the country, I have never set foot in Chicago proper.  That means I have never actually had *Authentic Chicago Pizza* and wouldn't know what it is if it came up and stepped on my peener.  I think arguments about *authentic* this and *authentic* that are a bit silly anyway.

That being said Little Star served up a couple of really good deep dish pizzas when I came here for a proper send off of our pharmaceutically slanted friend Texture not too long ago.  Of course he left for New York so having deep dish pizza was propably not very fitting.

The Classic and the Little Star were both very good options.  Chunka chunka tomatoes in every bite, flavorful ingredients, and probably the most tasty cornmeal crust that I have had all gave me a very good first impression.  I would have loved more cheese, but I can never get enough cheese.  Besides the pizza the mixed green salad was very good and the caprese salad was great.

I want to go back and try the thin crust but it's going to be hard to not order the Classic.
author: Luis M.

description: Seriously the best deep-dish in town.  MmMmMmMmMm.  Same vibe as the original.  MmMmMm.
author: Melanie C.

description:
Dear Little Star Mission,

You are very good for Chicago style Little Star. Your cornmeal crust is scrumptious and buttery, your sauce is hearty featuring big chunks of Tomato. Your wait staff always gives me all the salt and garlic that I need without ever fucking anything up.

You serve some great ales. Thanks to you I now drink Abbey, and yes it tastes even better with little star pizza.

But I can't help but miss my regular trips to the divis location. I guess I was going on dates back then, shucks, where as now I'm sitting in a less intimate corner of your dining room with a friend having shameless foodgasms in the spot light. Yeah life's tough.

I also don't feel like the pizza is as good at your location, but I can deal. There are also less hot male serves, why is that? The place is also too loud to hear the amazing jukebox, at least in the same way as at the Divis location.

But oh well, I love you anyway.
author: Alexandra M.

description: great pizza spot! the hostess and our waitress were really sweet and very informative when we had questions about their wine selection. The ambiance and aesthetics were great, loved the brick wall. We ordered garlic bread, half classic and half Mediterranean deep dish, and a bottle of wine. Everything was great and the service was excellent. We were one of the last parties there that night and they did not rush us to finish even when all the other servers were by the bar waiting to close. The entire staff was great and very relaxed.
author: Ruby R.

description:
BEST PIZZA EVER!!
their deepdish is to die for, Zachary has nothing on them. This guys are the best
author: Salvador O.

description:
After months of hearing how much better Little Star was compared to Zachary's, I finally tasted for myself. And my conclusion... Zachary's, by a VERY SLIM MARGIN. Sorry, it really just came down to the crust. 

If you prefer a more doughy, bread-like crust, then go to Zachary's.
if you prefer a more corn meal, crunchy (almost fried cookie-like) crust, the Little Star will make you happy.

But as for deep-dishyness, it ranks right up there with their use of quality ingredients. The sauces are just the right amount of tang and the cheese could be referred to as "creamy goodness."

The garlic bread was also quite delicious. It's more of DIY garlic bread as you have to spread the butter and the roasted garlic cloves on the slices yourself. But since you've ordered a notoriously time consuming to make deep dish pizza, you might as well take your time with appetizers. Order some wine too. (I enjoyed the Rhone.)

Complaints? Only in comparison to the way Zachary's does it, the wait seems a lot longer as you can't pre-order your pizza before being seated. Plus if the waiting area is packed with rain soaked annoyingly loud Marina/Mission-hipsters who sit with their dirty feet on the couch, then the wait is barely tolerable.

But when all is said and done, it IS damn good pizza. So Little Star gets a full 5 even though I'd personally give it a 4.5 due to my doughy-Zachary crust preference. The extra half boost is because my BF (the pizza expert) was converted and has declared Little Star better than Zachary's. Which means if you are on this side of Bay, then Little Star is definitely the place to go for deep dish.
author: Viv C.

description: I always love the pizzas I get here.  They take 30 minutes to bake so I call in ahead of time and pick it up.  The to-go employees have all been very nice, but last night Kenny was exceptionally helpful and pleasant.
author: Ryann L.

description:
Deep dish was great, not amazing, but solid.  I'll admit to not being the biggest deep dish fan, but I found a way to enjoy it.  I loved how the pizza was comprised of an overflowing amount of tomato sauce.  It's one way to my heart, and I'd go back just for that.

The server we had was great.  I liked her daisy earrings, and she contributed to a great meal and experience.  Didn't catch her name, but thank you _____ for being patient and helpful with explaining the rules around toppings.  You were great! :)
author: Daniels L.

description: A-ma-zing. Delicious salads & pizza & wine list. WIll be going back for more soon. Yum!
author: Lynn m.

description: What can I add to this... I definitely prefer it over Zachary's deep dish that's for sure. It's cheesier with the right balance of ingredients and not overwhelmed with too much sauce. The crust throughout the whole pizza is crisp and tastes great especially if you love that cornmeal/corn bread flavor. Even a day or two later the crust is still crispy when reheated in the oven and tastes just as good as it was the day it was made. Also, besides the garlic bread the spicy chicken wings are a great starter. I must admit that they weren't that spicy or spicy at all; to me at least. They did have great flavor and were moist all the way through. Service is great and always attentive in this joint.
author: Steven T.

description:
It is rare for me to wait an hour and a half...for pizza.  Not to mention the time it took for you to bake your signature deep dish pizzas.  Little Star, you amaze me, especially with your cornmeal crust.  I can just eat your deep dish crust covered in their sauce.  

P.S. Your name conjures up happy memories of the cute-pink and blue-haired twin-Hello Kitty characters from the 80's, so I like you even more.
author: Courtney B.

description:
two words: FOOD POISONING.

let's just say it was horrible and consisted of four hours of nonstop vomiting.  i'm too scared to come back here.
author: Lili K.

description:
I know people from out of town who regard going to Little Star when they're in San Francisco as an essential part of the experience. Me, I still daydream about the deep dish pizza I had in Chicago. Little Star is almost as good. It's a tiny place that gets a bit noisy, but the decor is cool and the pizza is great. A friend of mine used to work at the restaurant the owner had in Berkeley  (Little Italy, I believe it was called), and I thought the pizza here is a little too heavy on the cornmeal in the crust in comparison, but that's really a small thing to complain about. 

The last time I was there, they didn't take credit cards, but they have an ATM in the restaurant that charges only a $0.50 fee. I guess it's not too bad, but it kind of annoyed me.
author: Jennifer d.

description:
Went there with some co-workers,  had a good time.  Nothing special.  overpriced.

Whoever thinks this is the best pizza ever, definelty is a retard that hasn't traveled much in this country, or abroad. 
And between us, we ordered 3 pizzas, so I had the chance to try two meats, and one vegie. 

It is medium-good pizza, for a hefty price. Good ambiance, and beer selection/bar, so it is good spot for a date.

But, they have that "Party has to be complete before you seat" rule crap.  Even when the place is half empty.  We just wanted to start wtih two pizzas, and when a couple of other buddies came over, order another one.   But no, you can't do that in here.  Any place that has that, get's a minus star from me.

This place really deserves three-stars and a quarter, but I am rounding it down to three stars.  

Nothing special.

P.s They seem to use electric furnaces, and not woden ones.  No pizza can be great tasting coming from a electric oven.  Wood fire is, and always be the best method to get pizza done.
author: Ardit B.

description:
I'm going with Little Star in the epic Little Star vs. Patxi's debate. The crust is great and just the right thickness to keep it light and balanced. 

Sure, it's not Chicago style deep dish but who said all deep dish has to be Chicago style deep dish anyway.  

If you're from Chicago and need a fix, go be disappointed at Patxi's otherwise, go to Little Star.  

Little Star vs. Zachary's is still up for debate.
author: Calvin N.

description:
Better than Zachary's for 2 reasons:

1. Crust
2. Tomato Sauce

The crust is much crispier than Zachary's doughy pie, due to the cornmeal crust and a proper baking time & temperature. Little Star's tomato sauce is definitely less tangy than Zachary's, and more of a savory roasted tomato flavor.

We had some of their garlic bread during the "30 minute" cooking time, and it's served with a roasted head of garlic and butter. The bread is good quality, but I think the garlic could have roasted a bit more, aiding its spreadability.

They also have a good selection of wine for a pizza joint, I had a nice Cab with our Classic deep dish. But 4 stars because I still like thin crust, in general, better.

Note they take credit cards now.
author: Derrick V.

description:
Oh wow, ppl love this place. Almost everyone's giving them 5 stars! And I agree with the majority - the pizza here is quite delicious. We got 2 deep dishes, a thin crust, and the garlic bread. The deep dishes were reminiscent of Zachary's...and to be perfectly honest, I can't decide which one is better. Recency effect is making me choose Little Star...

What I really really love about this place, however, is the garlic bread. They actually bring out a bulb of roasted garlic and a little tub of melty butter for your bread! ingenious! I had a glass of Zin too - very nice.
oh oh. Bday boy got a piece of their cheesecake. omg. the cheesecake was really good. The crust was perfection, and the cheese part of the cheesecake was smooth and creamy. Yum. Everything I ate at this place was solid - down to the cornmeal pizza crust! 

Two things though - your entire party must be there for them to seat you, and the place is DARK. I was a little disturbed about the lack of lighting...
author: Carol L.

description:
Went here tonight for the first time.

Why anyone would choose to have pizza here and not Pauline's one block down the street is beyond me. Yes, they have deep-dish pizza here and it's good. But Pauline's is the best pizza in the City: there is more of a selection, the place is bigger (so the wait is shorter), and the pizza combinations are just more interesting and delicious.

If you like Chicago-style pizza then I guess you will like this place. But if you're in this neighborhood for pizza, you are missing out if you don't choose Pauline's.
author: Steven C.

description:
This place can get very crowded so long waits are to be expected.  We waited around 45 minutes or so and then it's usually another 30-45 minutes for deep dish pizza from the time you order.  Our group of 8 ordered two large deep dish and one large thin crust pizza and it was the perfect amount.  We had the thin crust classic which was totally delicious.  Their claim to fame is their cornmeal crust which is present in both their thin and deep dish pizzas.  Loved how crispy the crust was, even in the center.  For deep dish, we got the Little Star and the Mediterranean Chicken.  Both were good - their sauce is spiced without being spicy, toppings are fresh, and there is that fantastically buttery crust!  

Good pizza but the wait times make it almost a better place to get take-out.
author: Carrie L.

description:
So, I finally got to eat at Little Star Pizza after hearing about it for several weeks running.

First thing to note: don't go looking without knowing the address, as the glass is tinted white so that you can't see inside and you might mistake the place as a house of sin or some such.

Second: the staff, both at the bar and waiter, were excellent hipsters of the best type...laid back but also attentive.  I don't know where they find them.

Third: garlic bread is not what I thought it would be.  It was better.  Bread with soft butter and roasted garlic.  You assemble together.

The Pizza: we got the Chicago style Original with lots of sausage and tomato sauce.  As the Chicago boy at the table said, can't order pizza without sausage.  Pretty damn tasty and awfully filling.  

So, why not 5 stars?  Because I am a NY pizza gal at heart.  But for all you Chicago pizza folks...this is the place.
author: Sooj O.

description:
Recommended toppings:

At least two friends to accompany you down that sketchy block between 16th and 15th Street.  You need to meet (or preferably exceed) the number of crackheads with shopping carts or else your pizza is going to get taken from you on the way back home.

The patience to wait for a table OR

The courage to walk past the crackheads for the third time to go dodge hipsters at Blondie's or Casanova's while you wait for your pizza to be done.

Damn, we should have called in advance.

But it was good.
author: Alissa K.

description:
It was a last minute decision to come here last night, and despite the wait, I really enjoyed the pizza here. The place isn't that big, but there are plenty of tables for parties of 2. So two of my buddies and I arrived here around 9:45 for a late dinner, and the wait would last around 45 minutes. Since we already made the trek out here from the East Bay, we might as well wait. In the mean time, we tried some of their blue summer wheat on draft, and that was pretty delicious. The only problem was it increased my appetite haha. 

After finally getting seated, we tried to order right away since we looked at the menu while waiting. I have to take the experience down to 4 stars since it took awhile for us to be served. We eventually ordered a large classic and some garlic bread to start. The garlic bread was pretty bomb even though my friends and I didn't know how to eat it at first. Its practically a loaf of sourdough with butter on the side and a roasted piece of garlic. Apparently you have to take the roasted cloves out and then put it on your bread. Hey, the roasted garlic actually tasted really good with the bread. Good start.

The classic pizza came out right on time after we killed the bread, and I'm not gonna lie the pizza tasted great. Normally I always eat the crust first on my pizza slices because I'd rather enjoy the main contents of the pizza. The cornmeal crust was amazing! One of the better crusts I've enjoyed, and I didn't even need to eat it with ranch! Each successive bite of the pizza had a taste of freshness to it, and two slices from the large was filling enough between 3 hungry guys. 

I'd heavily recommend this place for a casual date or for small groups. Pizza is a little on the pricey side for its size, but the quality and taste justify the cost. A solid 4.5 stars from me (except there's no 4.5 star rating given on Yelp).
author: Loren John B.

description: I am addicted to this place. I never ate pizza with a corn meal crust until I came to this place. The deep dish pizzas are amazing. I've had several pizza's but my favorite was a specialty pizza they had and it had chicken, bbq sauce, with sliced apple in it. I wish they would bring that pizza back. I've never had a bad pizza from them.
author: Justin T.

description:
We fell in love 2 years ago when I took my first bite in the Divis location.  It was love at first bite.  How stoked was I when I found out they opened a location in the Mission?

I was craving some Little Star lovin' a few weeks ago and I wasn't disappointed.  I called ahead, arrived a bit early, chatted it up with the bartender, and ran out the door.  

I just couldn't help myself.  It didn't matter that people were looking.  We were locked in the car, just me and my pizza, and we were fogging up the windows.  omigod!  Omigod!!  OMIGOD!!!  Yes, call me shameless.  I.  Could.  Not.  Help.  Myself.  I had to have the Little Star right there and then.  Who needed to be civilized when I had to satisfy my craving?

When all was said and done, I had a big smile on my face.  So what if it got all over the place?  I heard someone say, "If it doesn't get all over the place, it doesn't belong in your face."
author: Annalynn C.

description:
Sunday night.
Hanging at the Thieves Tavern with some friends. Friends was holding a event there. It was great fun.
Friend suggested in getting a pizza. "OK!"
He gets pizza.
We eat.
"HOLEEE-CRAP!!!!" chompchompchomp.......
"This is" chompchompchomp "FUCKING" chompchompchomp "delicious" chompchompchomp.......
[ note* I eat pizza about 2x a week. I've had a BAGILLION combinations of GAGILLION ingerediants, and I've never felt like killing for pizza.
......This was one of those rare moments.]
"WHAT THE FUCK?! THIS IS WAY TOO GOOD!!!" chompchomp....
We had a 1/2 and 1/2 deep dish combo.
One part was a traditional Peperoni, black olives mix.
The other, was chicken and artichokes.
"OH-MY-GOD!" chompchompchomp.......
 
We also had an order of spicy chicken wings. 
"Ay!" chompchompchomp "This is fracking good too!" chompchomp...
We got more beers and all was happy.

I want more Little Star.
The End.
author: Kione E.

description:
i reaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaally like two things about this place:
1. that this place looks so unassuming from the outside (hard to find is more like it) and once you walk in... it's just a mission hipster pizza heaven. Tricky tricky!

2. the deep dish is better than zachary's.

THERE! I said it! I thought i would never cheat on zachary's... but i have.. and i LOVE IT!
author: Angelinaaah h.

description:
Went there 12/22 for the first time. I shared a mozzarella salad, garlic bread, and the barbecue chicken with apple deep dish pizza with 2 others. The mozzarella was delicious & the deep dish cornmeal crust was superb - especially with some butter on it. There was too much sauce on the pizza, however, and the apples were cooked so much you couldn't even taste them. 

Also, the wait staff is rude. Don't know about the rest of you, but I don't like it when people randomly come up behind me and just grab my empty glass or bottle without asking - which (in the case of the bottle) isn't always empty.
author: Red Tail H.

description:
Food: five stars
Service: five stars
Ambiance: four stars

I'm a Zachary's guy. I've long considered that venerable Rockridge pizzeria the gold standard of Chicago-style pizza in the Bay Area, and I can only name a handful of pizzerias in the country that do it as well or better--among them, Zelda's in Sacramento and Lou Malnati's in Chicago. The only problem for me: Zachary's is often too far via BART. Fortunately for me--and you--Little Star here in San Francisco belongs on the short list of great deep-dish pizzerias.

We had prepared to down some brews during a very long wait, but luckily for us we hadn't even finished our first beers (they have an amazing wine and beer selection in their hipster bar/waiting area) before we were escorted to a great table in the happily noisy, warmly decorated dining area. 

Confession time: my ten-year quixotic quest for real Chicago-style pizza in SF proper ended not by design, but by a happy accident. I didn't realize until last night Little Star served deep dish. I was psyched. My stomach began to growl and my heart quickened. I couldn't wait to finish up my second and third Racer 5 IPA--which we referred to as our "appetizers"--and dusted off my "It was good, but not as good as Zachary's" schpiel for later use.

But then it happened. A perfect deep-dish pizza landed on our table. It had the right look, the right consistency, the right flavor. It was Chicago-worthy. The sauce was fresh, chunky and well seasoned. The cheese underneath was clean and in proportion. The sausage had substance--a great texture and the right amount of flavor to stand out from the other ingredients, but not too much. The green peppers and properly-diced onions brought the zest. And the crust--oh, the crust--hearty, dusted with (I suspect) cornmeal, neither oily nor too dry. The crust sealed the deal. We damn near inhaled the whole thing.

Fortunately, there was one slice of pie left for each of us, and I enjoyed mine for breakfast. The crust held up overnight, and the sauce only got better. Little Star may very well be the new gold standard for Chicago-style pizza in the Bay Area. I'll need to conduct more research, of course...
author: Raoul U.

description:
i really liked this place, my girlfriend and I got the deep dish mediterranean pizza and she got a coke, but not really a coke but a coke tasting soda made out of allegedly all natural ingredients because the owner is sexy like that and can have those beverage options for the hipsters that frequent the restaurant. 

my one complaint is that there isnt much room between tables and youre pretty much sitting next to the couple next to you, and listening to their conversation, knowing damn well they are on a first date. that and you dont want to go use the bathroom because youre going to inconvenience the 8 eaters around you.
author: JD B.

description:
Dined in recently. Service was great and the Pesto Chicken Thin Crust Pizza is on point!!!

Can only speak on their take out...

It was fast and efficient. They keep your pizza in their warmer until you pick it up. And there's a handicap parking spot out front so you can park real quick to grab your pie...shhhh don't tell DPT that =oP
author: Rana A.

description:
A pretty darn good little deep dish pizza. They use fresh toppings but it is really about the superior crust at Little Star. I am a make-at-home pizza lover, but when I order it out this is where I like it to be from.

I always get the same, the Classic pizza, TO GO because the place is always packed, is small to begin with, and lacks ambiance otherwise.
author: Alona G.

description:
I had high-hopes for this place and I guess I had an OK time.
The pizza sauce was good and tomtaaato-y, the crust was tasty (if a little over-cooked), and the cheese was certainly cheesy enough. 

They had an excellent selection of ales and I enjoyed the eclectic music and urban decor.

But it was only OK. I will probably come back to give this place another chance, but they better do better by me next time!

So, what's the problem? Insufficient vegetarian options and insufficient vegetables, THATS WHAT! 

Sure, you can always build your own, but it would be nice to see some creative suggestions on the menu. I don't know why people always assume that people want meat on their pie - but, if you have ever had pizza catered in your office, you will know that the vegetarian slices are ALWAYS the ones first to go.

I also said "insufficient vegetables" - and I was right, dammit! Six half--olives and six cloves of roasted garlic on a eight-piece pie? For an additional $3? WTF!

I guess at this point I just sound like a whining vegetarian, but if you had just six half-salami-slices on your eight-piece pie, I'll bet there would someone whining too, Meat!
author: Kingpin X.

description:
little star means 5 stars...
Cornmeal crust pizza, so fresh
nice ambience, great, great salad 
and even better house dressing. 
I love the Vanilla soda, served in a super
cold frost beer glass. We had to wait for 20 minutes
or so to be seated, was a perfect time for a drink.
I eat at little star every 2 months because I LOVE IT !
author: Alex M.

description:
If you aren't going to get meat in your pizza, really why bother?

Oh yeah, you're a mission hipster.  I'll take it to go then.
author: Steve S.

description:
One of the best thin pizzas in SF can be had here. Great salads, decent wine selection, friendly staff, and reasonable prices round out a really great dining experience.

My only complaint (and before you lay in, I ain't no bridge-n-101 lad) is lack of space. It's either that or abundance of popularity, but wow does this place get packed fast. Go early, and if the rest of your party can't make it till later, enjoy drinks in the waiting/bar area.

This Little Star location gives me hope that, someday, Valencia between 16th and Market will be hopping and will give Valencia between 16-24 a run for its money.
author: Jeff H.

description:
My only other little star experience was at the Divis location, deep dish style.....this time around, on Valencia,  had the thin crust.
First off, this new location is great, much roomier and not as stuffy.  Got a table right away, which is always a wonderful thing when you're ready to get grubbing.
Our server was quite lighthearted, accommodating and engaging.
The wine, the mixed salad and the pizza were all so tasty.  Special request to make it a bit more crispy, they got it perfectly.  The crust was perfect, not soggy at all, the topping and cheese blended in nicely.  
The deep dish is good, but the thin is better. Divis is good, but Valencia is better.  Either location has great after dinner activities, so you can't go wrong if that's on the agenda too.
author: ERICA E.

description:
Yum!
I mean... YUM!!!!

After spending 10 weeks traveling in SE Asia, every meal I've had the last week since my return  has been a tasteless, bland let down....  UNTIL TODAY!!

It's not like I haven't had pizza from Little Star a thousand times before, but after spending ten weeks in a culture that doesn't understand the concept of cheese I have a new found appreciation for this place.

Two Words: DEEP DISH ~ one slice is enough for a meal.  Two slices and you're done for the night. (Not recommended before a Saturday night out on the town)

great sauce, 
awesome crust
perfect cheese.

It's best when hot but they don't do delivery only order for pickup.  Lucky my friend lives 3 blocks away.

Yum!
author: Shayna N.

description: While most Chicagoans will insist that Lou Malnati's, Gino's East, or the Home Run Inn back home serve better thick crust pizza, you're not going to Chicago. Little Star Pizza serves a specatcular approximation of the Lou Malnati's pie - a thick crust topped with tomato chunks and thick slices of mozzarella - just avoid the wings.  They have locations in the Western Addition (fairly inconvenient due to transit cruddiness) and the Mission (convenient - transit is less annoying in this area).
author: Matthew L.

description:
I love pizza, and I will look for any excuse to come here.

Their signature Little Star pizza has a perfectly crisp cornbread crust, rich, zesty tomato sauce, and delicious spinach with layers of cheese (but not greasy cheese).  I'd really like to try the vegetarian pizza sometime, but I love the Little Star so much that I can't pull away from my staple.

They have also have a nice selection of beers, wine, and cocktails, and you can even BYOB.

The Mission Little Star is small and usually crowded, but you can't beat the location if you ride BART, because it's just a block away from the 16th & Mission station.  I've also had no complaints with service and have never waited long for a table, despite it being crowded.  Their pizzas are also completely affordable; better than more expensive pizzas I've tried, and more filling.  

If you love deep dish pizza (or haven't tried it before) and don't want to make a trek over to East Bay for Zachary's, this is a absolute-must for you to try.
author: Alison M.

description:
Yowza! How do these guys manage to make a deep dish pizza that tastes so...fresh? I mean, almost like salad fresh? Speaking of which, our mixed salad was pretty high on the fresh-o-meter too. 
But not like this pizza! The combination of spinach, ricotta, feta, mushrooms, onions, and marinara all came together on a cornmeal crust and still didn't feel heavy. And you're speaking to a person who lived years in Chicago, so has seen some "original" deep dish. She pretty much hated all of it. Apparently, she needed to travel cross country for quality. And freshness. 
Little Star is no secret. The place was buzzing on Wednesday night.
author: Purnima M.

description:
You should see my keyboard right now. it's missihg the 4.

(Mom, what's Pantone 201 + 424?) 

The atmosphere here is welcoming. I arrive with a group of my closest biz-natches and we are seated promptly. 

Pabst in a can, fuck yeah. 

We share the sourdough bread with a bulb of roasted garlic. 

Shit, garlic. Whatever. 

We enjoy a deep dish and Iaugh...

Any real east coast girl will tell you it's all about the dough. 

Our server is attentive and funny.

Your cheesecake is no way to seduce 3 vulnerable women. Is it?

After leaving the restaurant we managed to form a line with our arms linked around each others shoulders..

"One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight. Schlemeel, schlemazel, hasenfeffer incorporated!"
author: Bean T.

description:
hm i dont know about the business model of this place.  long wait for a tiny table that's way too close to the table next to it, 30+ minute wait for a deep dish pizza and almost $40 for a pizza+1 beer in a seedy neighborhood.  

i ordered the famous "brass monkey" and was really impressed with how fresh the ingredients were...delicious!  ive never had cornmeal in a pizza crust and found the texture a little bit too grainy.

i also wish there were more selection in sizes of the pizza:  just two sizes and from what i remember, the individual/small size wasnt that much cheaper than a large size (which is enough to serve 3-4 people).

not the best pizza ever and i probably could have died without eating this (looking at you 7x7!) but at least i got to cross this off my list.
author: Erin C.

description: This pizza place has the best deep dish pizza in the city.  Get the classic deep dish, if you are very hungry I recommend the large.  The thin crust pizza is excellent also!
author: Jerry H.

description:
This is the most delicious pizza my family and I have ever had. We order the deep dish pizza each time we go and regardless of the toppings we choose, it has always been a treat for us. 
I'd highly recommend it!
author: Joyce S.

description:
Unexpectedly found myself here with a friend. We were wandering along Valencia looking for a place to have dinner. When we got to the corner that houses the entrance to Little Star Pizza, I did a double-take and almost squealed with delight. Now, I've never been to Little Star Pizza before, but I've had it recommended to me by very many friends. So Little Star Pizza was to be the place where I dined that night.

My companion and I shared the small (9"inch) Mediterranean deep-dish pizza. Ohhhhhhh *DROOLZ*

It was sooo good! So good that I almost don't even remember what was in the pizza because I practically inhaled it.

I dimly remember the thick, crispy crust (which I like) that wasn't all floury and doughy (which I don't like), and the ingredients of the pizza all melded together so well. No wonder Little Star came so highly recommended. A new favorite of mine for sure!

This could've been a five star review, but the service was a little underwhelming. The host was quick and attentive, but our server was either stoned or just having a very apathetic day. Meh.
author: Judy F.

description: Not bad, but I'd take Patxi's any day over this place.
author: Alfredo A.

description:
Would you be willing to wait 1 hour for a Zachary's Wannabe?  We did.  It was crowded and loud, and a cold breeze kept blasting the tiny waiting area from the street each time the door opened.  Nevertheless, I am a sucker for Chicago-style pizza.  The waitstaff was nice and the Za was very good.  The crust is cornmeal-laden and somewhat dry and crunchy.  I prefer either doughy or flaky like the real deal at Zachary's, but to each his own.  The sauce was thick and pungent and the 'roni was savory.  The cheese was fairly flavorless.  Zachary's sauce and cheese are even more flavorful and savory in my opinion.

This place is still terrific and I'll be back.  All my friends affirmed.

Little Star is a respectable contender, but Zachary's is still the Za-bomb for the Bay Area; the reigning champion.   

However, Little Star is miles above the other generic pizza in the city.  In fact, that would be a good 'Mile-high Club' to join: the Pizza Mile High Club.  Little Star is a member and you can join by waiting an hour at their bar.

Let's hope there is no Celebrity Pizza Death Match or the sauce will be everywhere and we know which East Bay pizza joint will remain unbeaten.
author: Neuro G.

description:
Wow a 40 minute wait for a table of seven on a Thursday night? I though this was SF, not NYC. Fortunately my friends are always 40 minutes late so it worked out well (for them... I got there on time like a douchebag).

I am usually of the opinion that pizza is a commodity, but this stuff was very very good. I recommend the White Pie (thin crust) for all my veggies out there.

The hostess and waitress were extremely friendly, beers were cheap ($4 for a pint, and $2 for PBR cans... PBR cans!).

Only complaint (um, besides the wait) was that the music was rocking a bit too loud for easy cross-table conversation. It was good music, thankfully.

PBR CANS!!!
author: Trey F.

description:
4.5 stars

Love it!!

This is definately now one of my favorite places to go to for some delicious deep dish pizzas. Is it better than Zachary's? No b/c I think they're both equally great. You get good quality pizza here.

We arrived around 5 pm on a Friday evening and were the first patrons at the restaurant. The outside looks like a nightclub, but once you enter the establishment, it's cozy and set up quite nice - a bit dark w/candles lit on each table. 

I loved that the waiter brought over our water immediately without us having to ask for it. He greeted us and was very friendly. 

From the menu we ordered -

Appetizer: hot wings w/blue cheese (you get about 12 pieces of chicken...they come out very hot, crisp on the outside w/the perfect seasoning of spiciness and juicy on the inside)

Deep dish pizzas: small classic and large little star for 5 people, which was more than enough (both were wonderful w/a generous amount of toppings...the chunks of tomatoes were huge and flavorful, along w/the rest of the toppings...especially loved the large pieces of sausage we added separately) I never eat the crust of my pizza, but tonight, I ate every bit of it. Loved it. Best crust i've had. Leftovers the next day were just as great. Fyi, the pizzas didn't come out as hot as I wanted them, almost room temp, so you may want to make a special request if you want them right out of the oven hot.

Overall: This is one of the best pizza places around esp for deep dish pizzas. The service is one of the best as well...very friendly and prompt staff.
author: Veronica H.

description: This place is AMAZING!! I'm from SoCal was in town to visit my hubby and decided to come here to grab a bite to eat. Staff isn't very friendly but their Chicken pesto thin crust is AMAZING!! I'm still craving it and haven't found a place by where I live that makes this amazing pesto pizza!
author: Liz I.

description:
Great pizza. I love the spinach, mushroom, feta, etc. The wait for a table can be pretty long some nights but it is well worth it.  Great jukebox too.

Zachary's hurts my tummy after one slice. That's never happened here. 

I used to go at at least once every other week but my Little Star partner in crime moved out of town. I need a new one.
author: Sam S.

description:
Gastronomic love is a hard thing to quantify, and even harder for me to put into words. I don't quite have the words for Little Star. I brought my Dad here last night. We had the White Pie with Salami and Deep Dish Cheese with Sausage. He was really impressed, I don't even know if he has ever had a deep dish pizza. The food was amazing as usual. The server brought us a slice of their homemade cheesecake. I generally never have room for dessert here and never would have known what I was missing. Its drizzled in dark caramel. Word.

I just wish they would install some sound baffles in the ceiling or something. The noise level in here is so bad I can't hear people across my own table. Minus one star for that.
author: Zac H.

description:
Indescribable! Exceptional! Delicious! Fulfilling! Satisfying! 

Such an incredible deep dish pizza!

This was our first visit to this location, and second time ever to Little Star

We couldn't wait to get to this place, and the 15+ mins we spent trying to find a parking spot, worked up a good appetite.

Went for the Garlic Bread and Vegetarian Pizza.

As expected, chunky sauce, moderate amount of cheese, good thick crunchy crust. 

I hope they open in the South Bay!
author: Manish P.

description: Hands down the best deep dish pizza I have ever had. It's gotta be the cornbread crust and to-die-for suace. I seriously have dreams about this pizza. Be warned though, there is usually a long wait.
author: Karie S.

description:
We finally sampled the wares at this southern outpost from Little Star. I like this location and interior better than the Divisadero branch, but could that pizza be ever-so-slightly more savory? Or was it just the night? 

We got a deep-dish Little Star Special (spinach, mushrooms, onions, ricotta, etc.) and -- at the seasoned direction of one of my favorite Yelpers -- the thin-crust Chicken Pesto (minus the chicken, sub spinach). It was my first time having Little Star's thin crust pizza. 

As with my impression of the Divisadero branch, these are very good pizzas. Little Star is uber-generous with toppings, particularly for a specialty pizza shop, which generally seem to subscribe to the minimalist philosophy. As with my initial assessment at the other store, they could use a bit more spice and zip to take their pizza to the next level. 

I've had enough experience now to comfortably report that I prefer Zachary's. Its crust, its sauce, its seasoning are more to my liking. That said, Little Star blows Zachary's out of the water in terms of generosity and amount of toppings. Sometimes at Zachary's, I have to search for items I've order to ensure they weren't forgotten (they always are in there, but in sometimes minuscule amounts). Still, I'd likely take a minimalist Zachary's pizza over a generous Little Star. I just like it better.  Plus, Zachary's takes credit cards.

That said, Little Star is a quality establishment with fine pizza which I am happy to patronize when in town and/or with friends. 

Note: CASH ONLY.
author: SalsaBoy S.

description: This place is same as Patxi's to me.  The pizza is good but not as good as Zachary's in Berkeley.  Great place to bring co-workers, kind of loud for dates.  Skip the appetizers as they're overpriced, esp the tomatoes with white cheese dish.  A small pie with a couple beers should run you about $20.
author: Win C.

description:
It took me a little while to hop on the Little Star bandwagon, since I was under the impression that they just served deep dish, for the longest time. I am pretty much a straight-up thin crust person, I have been to the wonder that is Zachery's in Oakland, and while I can appreciate it, it's just not really my thing. Then someone, I forget who, told me that Little Star wasn't exclusively a deep dish place, so then I was like, okay, I could hang with that...

I have now tried three of their pizzas (all thin crust), the "White Pie" being my favorite, as well as their garlic bread, caprese salad, and champagne cocktails (the one with the orange cream flavor...OMG!) Their garlic bread is just bread and butter served with a big bulb of roasted garlic! Cool concept, although not what I was initially expecting (they explain this on the menu, I just didn't bother to read it the first time around so I was surprised). 

Tonight I tried the "Little Star" and they kindly converted it to a thin crust style for me, even though it is only listed on the menu as a deep dish. I called in and got it to go, which you can do, although it's a big destination place, typically with lots of hipsterly peeps hanging inside. Good thing they didn't snub me when I walked in looking all middle-of-the-road and bundled up with my north face and uggs!!
author: Shannon R.

description:
I can't say a bad thing about Little Star. I'm so lucky that it's only a few blocks away! And even if it wasn't, it's worth the trip.

There have been stretches when I've frequented this place once a week, and loved it every time. It's comfortable yet sleek. Casual yet very high quality. 

You can always count on fresh salad and amazing pizza, whether its their famous deep dish or thin crust. My favorite is the classic deep dish. It's like our waiter said, would you go to a quality steak house and order salmon? No! You have to go with the house speciality, DEEEEEEP dish. And then you have some left overs to look forward to the next day.

Their wine selection is always yummy too, never had a slection I didn't like. The house Zin is my fav.

I guess my only gripe is that you can't stroll in on a Fri. or Sat. night, the wait is way too long.
author: Kim M.

description: I had the little star pizza with sausage.  This place reminds me of Zachary's.  I think this place might be better, same Chicago style deep dish pizza with a crunchier crust.
author: Matthew P.

description:
After writing my review for Zacharys deep dish in rockridge i was pointed towards Little star pizza by Mary A, and Bird B. 

It lived up to the hype, I was a little hesitant because i walked over and it is on the corner of 15th and valencia which looks like a crackpipe alley type street and you couldnt see inside as you walked up...

But none the less when you get in the place is down right swanky.. they have a nice bar right up front, they seem to have a nice selection of beer and wines (i was just picking up an order so i didnt get to dabble into all that goodness) 
Anyways the staff was super friendly, i had to wait about 5 minutes for the pizza and got asked if i had been helped by about 4 different folk which is a nice change from some of these places that seem to snub the customers...
so go the order and headed home.. on the walk i had to resist opening the box and taking it all in because the smells that were leaking out of that box were telling me i was about to dive into deliciousness... 
Finally get home and dig in.. it was worth the wait.. the pizza was phenomenal.. 

I am looking forward to going back here, getting a table and dining in with some pizza and beers. 

worth every penny... thanks for the heads up on this place! ! ! !
author: jamie z.

description:
I love tomatoes, and I love deep dish pizza. Until now, the only place I could go to for solid deep dish in the bay area was one of the three Zachary's locations in the east bay. But I decided to check out Little Star on a tip from a friend.

So how did it compare? Pretty well. I'd say the pizza here has a little less depth than Zachary's (in terms on actual height of the pizza) and they don't try to overwhelm you as much with tomatoes (not that I mind). The tomato sauce also has a lot more going on, with more herbs giving it a much fuller taste than the tomatoes at Zachary's. 

We ordered the "Mother Clucker" - the special name for the "Little Star" (mushrooms, spinach, feta, ricotta and garlic) with chicken added on for some protein. It was quite good and the pie had a good balance of ingredients so that you could taste all of the individual flavors. Also of note - the crust. You could tell it had cornmeal mixed into it. My friend really dug the texture that it gave, but I'm not that into cornmeal in my pizza crust. I guess it's personal preference but I'd say it didn't detract from overall taste in any way.

We also got a half mixed salad to start and it was really good (gorgonzola + walnuts!) minus the red bell peppers that I could've done without.

The space is a little tight (like all things in the Mission) but we were still able to get a table for 2 on a Friday night around 10pm within 10 mins. There's cool bar you can get a glass of wine at while you're waiting for your table. They have a second location in the WestAdd I might have to check out next time, and there WILL be a next time.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
The BEST deep dish pizza I ever had!!!! and I adore their salad too.
We go there often, and every time we are pleased from the service and food.
author: Amal M.

description:
It took me a while to get used to deep dish pizza.  On my opinion, it has too much sauce and not enough cheese.  Plus I didn't like a deep dish pizza restaurant in San Jose (too greasy).  But after accepting deep dish pizza for what it is, I learned to love it.  Zachary's at Oakland and Berkeley is also excellent, but Little Star Pizza is a little better.  Their crust is a little crispier.  

I go to Little Star Pizza when I want a special treat.  Their pizza is not cheap, and it  fills me up so much that I'm ready to puke when I'm done eating.  :-)

Little Star Pizza's service is very good.  Plus I don't have to go all the way to Oakland or Berkeley.  Some tips: bring cash, since they don't take credit cards.  And come early if you can.  Both locations are very small and you will probably have to wait about half an hour for a table.  That's why I like to go as soon as they open (5 pm).
author: Francisco J. R.

description: My favorite deep dish place EVER!!  I don't eat here very often, but I will be sure to have Little Star Pizza before running a triathlon or half marathon! =)
author: Sonia M.

description: Thomas L. and I came here on Friday night with a couple of our friends hoping to get a table. We showed up after 6:30 pm and the wait was about an hour. When we finally got our table, our server was nice and the deep-dish pizza came out more quickly than I expected. We ordered the garlic bread as well and it really surprised me. It was a small warm loaf along with a whole bulb of roasted garlic and butter in the consistency of mayo. Trust me, it was delicious! The pizza was good, but it was the crust that really blew me away. Their crust is far from soggy and was perfectly crisp. Pizza was tasty, but the wait really hurts. Someone once told me, "There are too many great places to eat in SF to wait around for a table." - Hence the 3 stars. Tip: Their "large" deep-dish pizza (which has 8 slices) will only feed 3 average size people or 4 girls watching their waistline.
author: Lisa R.

description:
With 4.5 stars from 121 reviews, it doesn't really seem necessary that I add another 5 star review.  However, I can't have pizza this good and NOT tell the world.

I really did think that Zachary's pizza was the best--I really did.  But I think Little Star Pizza is better.  Why?  The crust is a little crunchier, and the pizza itself is lighter and less tomato-ey.  Not that I have anything against tomato-ey pizza, but it's just nicer to be able to taste the toppings (well, except they aren't on top).  Also, they use some kind of delicious spices at Little Star that don't compare to anything else I've had.  

Get an extra pizza to go--that's my recommendation.
author: Sara O.

description:
I usually get my Little Star to go.  Me and my boyfriend call in advance, pick it up, and go home for pizza night.  They've always been friendly at the pick up counter, and if we had to wait, we'd sip on some of the great beers they have there.

Only the other night did I actually eat in for the first time.  Their food is always incredible.  I usually get the deep dish, but this time I tried the thin crust and it blew me away.

They forgot to bring me the takeout one I ordered, and the waitress acted like I was supposed to know it was in their "hot box".  I'll let it slide this time because the pizza is the best in the West.
author: Jess R.

description: Best deep-dish in SF, but it's not a very competitive market.
author: Kevin F.

description:
Little Star is good.  The pizza is good, the ambiance is nice if you're eating in, and the staff is friendly and even engaging.  That being said, I don't find the pizza to be spectacular.  Don't get me wrong - it's totally delicious.  It's real pizza.  It's good.  But it isn't, like, phenomenal.  For comparison I visited a friend in Chicago once, and had the best deep dish pizza ever, and Little Star just isn't quite juicy enough to meet that.  

I think maybe it's because Little Star's deep dish pizza is just like normal pizza, but deeper...whereas truly amazing deep dish pizza is like a somewhat different food item altogether in terms of ingredients and consistency.  Regardless, if you want pizza and Little Star is open, it's one of your best options.
author: Oliver N.

description:
Missing the last star because of the inconvenient cash only policy. 

This restaurant is one of those places you only go to because you heard your best friend mention that it's simply amazing but it's not advertised anywhere and easily missed as you drive past. The wine list needs some work but the fresh ingredients and the deep dish pizzas definitely compensate. 

Try the Caprese Salad... I've been all over the world ordering these things and I kid you not this place really did beat out Italy. After you eat that in one uncomfortable, eye popping gulp, dig into your classic deep dish pizza, drowning it with your (home brought since they're kind of losing money by not offering it) Napa grown Cabernet Sauvignon and you too will go into a food coma of delight.
author: Anthony B.

description:
I had the deep dish original pizza.  The crust was fantastic on the pizza.  Very tasty.  The special pizza they had the night I went there looked tasty, but I decided to go with the original for my first time.   I am looking forwrd to returning and trying out one of their other pizzas.

Update:
I just went back last night.  I went with a friend who wanted to try the Original deep dish pizza.  I wanted to sample something new, but the original was so good, we got it again.  It was even better than I remembered.  SO  delicious.  It's all about the crust.

2 gals won't be able to finish a small deep dish pizza, so keep that in mind.  We did also split the small mixed greens salad - the small sized salad is HUGE.

Also, the wait staff is extremely nice, friendly, and always there to refill your wine glass.
author: Angie C.

description:
The best deep dish pizza in the Bay Area.  Better than Zachary's.  The sauce: zesty and delicious. The crust is absolutely perfect -- crispy, buttery, corn meal-y goodness.  I've only tried the Classic -- Sausage, peppers, etc. -- but I'm going to go out on a limb and assume that the other pizzas on the menu are equally as good.

A few other things:  

-a small deep dish is a good size for 2 people.  Ordering a salad to munch on before your pizza is ready will round out the meal nicely.
- the service is solid.  Fast and friendly.
-I haven't yet been to the Divisadero location, but I hear it can get extremely crowded. The Valencia restaurant is not.  We walked in at 8:30 on a weeknight and were seated immediately.

Little Star: believe the hype.  It's that good.
author: Andrew E.

description:
When I bite (slice, devour, lick) into a slice of pizza (with tomato-based sauce) I want to taste tomatoes, olive oil, basil, garlic....  The sauce here is perfect .  The crust is perfect.  This really is deep-dish perfection.

Why it doesn't get 5-stars.... cash only?  Come on now.  For 2 of us, it was almost $40 bucks (small pizza, 2 beers, and i think a starter).  Not that that's expensive, but most taquerias take debit cards!  it's just silly.
author: Jon B.

description:
How are you diff-er-ent from Zachary's?
You're in the city, and you're dimly lit.
Since I still live in the East Bay, it seems,
Chicago-style at Zachary's I'll git.

I think the crust at Zachary's is best?
Or maybe it's the sauce that I prefer?
Or maybe 'cause I knew Zachary's first,
I set my standards by that famed parlour.

I think the pizza may merit four stars, but I'm deducting one for the uninspired poetry.   Must be Little Star's fault.
author: April D.

description:
I went to Little Star yesterday for my job's monthly volunteer night.  It's about half a block from the office, and yet I had never tried it.  They seated us without the whole group being there, which was nice of them, and I got there before 6:30, so that meant that I could chug as many cans of $1 Pabst's as I cared to (and I cared to chug about four, plus the one that I stole from my co-worker).

I've never had pizza like it.  ONE SLICE filled me up.  ONE.  And I'm the girl who consistently comes back from lunch with guacamole, or curry sauce on my neck and caked into my eyebrows because I decided to bathe in it.  I eat a lot.  I bet I could win a contest like that little Japanese guy who ate something crazy like 56 hotdogs in five minutes or something.  I dont think I would want to join a contest like that, though.  If I lost, I'd be too full to shame-eat.  And I don't live in Texas, or whatever god awful place those things happen in.

Anyway, the sauce was good, but it overpowered every other ingredient on the slice.  They do this thing with the deep dishes where it's "backwards pizza" or something.  It goes: crust, toppings, cheese, sauce.  So the sauce, which is big juicy chunks of tomato is falling everywhere, all over my neck and hairs (see guacamole/curry example above).  And it's really good.  Again, though, the sauce overpowers everything else.  But it's really good sauce, so it's actually a very confusing situation.  Quite the quagmire, I should say.

The jukebox is totally bitchin, and the servers are entertaining and attentive.  There was even a three legged dog!!  It belonged to one of the other customers, so you may never see it there, but I shit you not, I saw it.  And it was really cute, especially after five (ok, seven) beers.
author: danielle p.

description:
As a friend recently said:  I give little star a solid "meh." My girlfriend recently took me there, claiming it to be the "best" pizza in SF. (Mind you I am from Chicago, where pizza is no joke.) 

We got there and had to wait for a about 30 minutes to be seated. Upon my first bite of "Deep Dish" pizza I thought to myself: "Was it worth the wait?" Not really. The pizza is definetely a "meh." Too much hype and not enough flavor. The crust was not crispy enough, the sauce was too sour, the cheese not  perfectely melted.

I don't mean to be snob here but if you think this is great pizza, then you probably have never been to Chicago or New York. If you are looking for good pizza on Valencia St there are far better choices within a block's distance. If you are looking for cheap go to Arnells on 16th and if you are looking to sit down and have a superb pizza dinner for the same price go to Pauline's, it's waaaaayy yummier.
author: Javier B.

description:
How do you bridge the divide of a year spent apart when your Honduran Pabuloso is in town for a weekend of debauchery? Stumble/walk/crawl to Little Star, get tanked on the $2 PBRs and pound the delightfully saucy deep dish pizza.  This place puts the commercial/sterile atmosphere of Patxi's to shame. 

I hate having to wait for a table, and we did... for about 45 minutes (after watching so many people sat for dinner - it's the most heartbreaking/stomach-growl-inducing thing ever).  Shame shame shame.... But out waitress with long black braids was very cool and the service was great.
author: Stanley E.

description:
This is the first of many, MANY pizza place reviews I intend to write so I hate to do this for my first Pizza place review but holy crap I have no idea why the hell this place is rated so high! The pizza is just plain and simply, AWFUL! Maybe it comes down to preference for types of pizza but I would like to think I am not a pizza snob by any stretch of the imagination and while this place is not the WORST I have ever had I am sad to say its pretty far down the list of decent pizza to enjoy. Disappointing to say the least considering the stellar reviews this place has.

First off I enjoy any kind of pizza be it thin crust, thick crust, deep dish, NY style etc so I don't really prefer one type over another and seeing that Little Star offers both I thought that was a pretty cool thing since I had not had any "real" deep dish since my days visiting Chicago where I had the chance to experience two of the best Lou Malnati's and Gino's East deep dish pizzas. 

Having said that I tend to prefer super thin crust pizza these days having found out that is what "real" pizza is supposed to be and am slowly starting to convert away from my days of super piled on 10 meat-fantastic pies of Round Table, Mountain Mike and the Hut lore. (Not that I will not enjoy a slice of the Round, the Hut or the Mike if its hanging around...any pizza is better then no pizza amerite??? And lets be honest any super hot and fresh pizza is probably going to be pretty damn good anyway no matter where it comes from so I am not talking down to those "fast food" pizza places. Heck even Dominoes is good now sometimes) 

But having that perfect balance of cheese, sauce, spice and crust from an original Margherita pizza made the right way is truly the taste of real pizza that I look for now and Little Star is pretty much the farthest thing away from that for thin crust and Chicago's best for deep dish as they fail miserably in both styles of pizza. 

Where you begin? I went in on  a thursday night around 8pm to meet some family for a going send off dinner and my first impressions when walking in at the Mission/valencia location was that it was small, extremely dark and super noisy. Seriously the noise level is off the chart and only magnified by the fact that they are all open tables and you sit very close to all the other tables. So much for the ambiance but the food is going to be awesome right, so who cares?

Checking the menu we started with some Garlic Bread  and then ordered 1 large deep dish pepperoni and sausage and 1 large thin crust half and half of cheese and white pie. The one good thing was the bread which was pretty good sourdough with olive oil butter and a fresh clove of toasted garlic with bulb intact which was awesome but it all went donwill from there.

After waiting for about 45 mins the pizzas came out looking and smelling pretty good but the problems started when you take a bite.

Thin crust: The main issue with the thin crust was that it was not thin crust at all but rather a fairly standard med depth crust that had no taste or flavor and was somewhat doughy and lacking in any good texture. Did not really serve the purpose of bringing together the flavors of the toppings as it seemed the ratio of toppings to crust was way off in favor off the dull crust. The toppings for the white pie portion were very fresh however and had decent flavor but the cheese size was just flat. No bite of seasoning in the sauce, no gooey consistency of cheese and no hint of anything that would make a cheese slice standout. Just your avg forgettable cheese pizza slice you can get anywhere in the city for a couple of bucks.  

Deep Dish: This is where things really went south. The biggest problem is the crust! It is a crumbly mess of bad texture and zero flavor. It was insanely dry crust that had no layers, no flake no NOTHING. I cant go into how bad the crust was but when i took out a slice it got even worse. SAUCE, SAUCE EVERYWHERE. Why the hell is there 90% sauce and 10% cheese!?!?! There was way too much sauce and it was pretty plain thin sauce to add insult to injury. Huge chucks of tomato and hardly any seasonings to speak of. What little there was of the cheese on this pizza seemed like the best part but with barely any of it there the ratio of sauce to cheese was so far off it ruined the whole thing. The meat toppings were there and had decent flavor but thats about as good as it gets. I seriously think this may be the first slice of pizza that I just picked the toppings off to eat and skipped the rest. And this is from someone who usually finishes everyone else's peices of crust!

All in all a terrible, terrible pizza experience topped off with the too high of price of admission for well below average pizza. Avoid and go to Delfina's....or Tony's....or damn just go to the Round, the Mike or the Hut for pizza way better then the crap here. OVERRATED!
author: Donnie W.

description:
I really LOVE this place in a way which is blasphemous, because I grew up in the city of the One True Crust (thin).  You can tell that someone really put a lot of thought and care into this restaurant, and to them it is not just a way to make money.

The surroundings are that perfect blend of shabby and chic without pretension.  The service is great.  They are attentive without being intrusive, yet they still seem to have personality.  The beers on the menu are fantastic and go really well with the food, and the prices are quite reasonable.  Even the non-pizza food is impressive.  I had the chicken wings and they were wonderful, and I am waiting for the day I show up with enough people to share one of those huge and tasty looking salads I see them bring out.  I even love the jukebox which seems to have nothing but indie-ish CDs in it.  Every ten minutes I find myself saying to whomever I am there with, "I LOVE this song!"

The pizza itself is mind-alteringly good.  My other-half who is a Berkeley graduate and was very faithful to Zachary's admits that this is better.  The cornmeal in the crust gives in a really special texture, and it tastes like it may have been fried a little.  What really makes this pizza special is the tomato sauce.  It is nice and lumpy with tomato pieces, and the tomatoes in it taste so FRESH.

When the two of us go we order a large pizza for $22 and only eat half.  We eat the rest for breakfast and lunch the next day.  $22 for three meals is really good value in my book.

A lot of Yelpers have complained about the wait, but we have found that if you show up between six and six-thirty the wait is non-existent despite the restaurant not being empty.  Even when there are three of us.  I do not eat huge lunches, so by this time I am ravenous and it is not inconvenient for me at all.

I have only recently moved to San Francisco, and the first couple of weeks I was wondering if I had made a mistake in wanting to come here.  This was the perfect combination of EVERYTHING, and it just made me feel so much better.  I cannot recommend it enough.
author: Toy W.

description:
Awesome pizza joint!  As it's located in hipsterville, the pizza definitely has its own pizzaz.  I love deep dish, and I wasn't sure what this place's pizza would taste like, so I had only Uno's and Zachary's to compare.  

We ordered the Little Star specialty pizza (with spinach, cheese and mushrooms), and it was the perfect amount, not greasy at all and light enough to be sufficiently fed, but not overwhelmingly filling to the point of food coma.  We also tried their root beer (I forgot the brand, but it was brewed and foamy), which was delicious.  The pomegranate champagne is also a nice and different accompaniment to the pizza.

Overall, a great and chill place with a diversity of pizza offerings.  Make reservations or be prepared to wait 10-20 minutes for an evening table.
author: Megha S.

description:
I don't even wanna know how many Weight Watcher points I ate last night, but you know what? I don't fuckin care cus mah pizza pie was guud! 
I had the Mediterranean Chicken w/ artichoke, deep dish style and it was so FRESH, so JUICY, so MMMMMMz.  
I had no regrets and to tell you the truth evertime I eat pizza even it's only one slice I feel like shit afterwards. Not here! 

Plus our waitress was so nice and funny, I wish I could remember her name. 
NE Ways, check it foos!
author: Roxane P.

description:
I went there to celebrate some June bdays. The place has Wyder's pear cider! I think this place makes some great pizza, both Chicago style and thin crust. We had the classic deep dish and italian pesto thin crust. both were good. the pizzas had just the right amount of ingredients and flavor. definitely a great place to eat pizza with friends! 
the staff are efficient and nice. the only downside is the size (too small!) of the place.
author: Andrea K.

description: I've been to the one on Divisadero, and for some reason, I think the one on Divisadero is better.  I guess I don't have the right basis for comparison - I had the Classic at the Divis location and the Vegetarian at the Mission location.  I know, what was I doing eating vegetarian food?  (With vegetarian friends...)  Anyway, maybe it's better to just say that you should order non-vegetarian deep-dish pizzas.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Best pizza place in the city?  Yeah, I'd agree with that.  I'm not talking I'll-take-that-to-go pizza, but more of the kind where you want to sit down and have a nice glass of wine to go with your slice.  

If you don't mind a noisy crowd and a bit of a wait (they don't take reservations), then you probably want to give this place a try.  The deep dish pizza with cornmeal crust is crazy good.  I couldn't get enough of the stuff.  Which is probably why I left there with a stomach ache.  Oh, and the huge piece of (amazing!) cheesecake probably didn't help either.  

*burp*
author: Ryan L.

description:
Thank you Little Star for opening one that I can get to on BART!

Seems like there is slightly less of a crowd/wait here on weekends but it's still busy busy.

Me love them long time.

(why haven't I reviewed this yet? sacrilege!)
author: Christine K.

description:
A fairy tale about Mr. and Mrs. Pizza:

Mr. & Mrs. Pizza were in a very long dull relationship.  They had been married for 47 years and were simply going through the basic routine in life.  Everyday, roll the dough out ... sauce ... cheese ... tan in the oven.  Mr. Pizza was quite frankly sick to his stomach.  You see his dough wouldn't puff up like it used too.  His confidence was lagging and it was certainly evident in the bedroom.  Mrs. Pizza assured Mr. Pizza that it had nothing to do with him.  She explained that old dough just doesn't rise like the younger stuff.  

Mrs. Pizza did hold back that a certain "zest" was missing from their life.  Mr. Pizza used to be more romantic and inventive back in the day.  A little jalapeno here, a blend of oregano there.   Mrs. Pizza had more variety and a husband who made sure he kept his lover guessing.  Lately, he had just been bogged down and threw no more variety in there.  Everything was so basic ... regular ... boring.  She was hoping Mr. Pizza would turn it around; maybe throw in some goat cheese, pesto, anything other than basic cheese and sauce.

Mr. Pizza asked his friends Mr. Budweiser and Mr. Parmesan for a little help.  Mr. Budweiser appeared quite cold and frosty on the outside but he seemed to come thorough every time you needed him.  Mr. Parmesan didn't smell too good up front but every time he was matched up with somebody it was always too good to be true.  

Mr. Parmesan and Mr. Budweiser gave Mr. Pizza a few recommendations to spice things up and recommended he see the folks at Little Star Pizza.  Mr. Budweiser assured Mr. Pizza these guys do amazing things to dough, sauce and toppings that are bound to make him feel like a new person.  Mr. Budweiser recalled his last visit as something he hadn't experienced in a long long time.  He told Mr. Pizza that Mrs. Budweiser came back to keg multiple times that night!

Mr. Pizza went to Little Star and was amazed at the selection and the delicacies on the menu.  It was like he was getting his own little makeover.  He was bound to surprise Mrs. Pizza.  Mr. Pizza pulled up in his delivery truck and made his way to the bedroom.  When he got in, Mrs. Pizza nearly melted!  Her old plain dough of a man formerly known as Mr. Pizza had now turned thick and was piping hot.  And what have we here?  Olives, real tomato sauce, fresh bell peppers, fresh ground sausage.  Things started to get mighty hot and heavy.  

The next day Mr. Pizza thanked Mr. Budweiser.  He told him that Mrs. Pizza went back for more than one slice that night ... and she hadn't done that in years!  The days old old flat plain dough and cardboard crust were done!  Mr. Pizza knew settling for that was a thing of the past.  Little Star was the answer he had been waiting for.  Mr. Pizza was reluctant to divulge his secret but he knew once everyone knew about Little Star, everyone would want to go.
author: Bill P.

description:
I love Little Star! We were hanging out at a friend's house in the Mistro (Mission/Castro) area and we all suddenly had the same craving for some deep dish pizza. Little Star was a few blocks away and was thus quite convenient. Needless to say, I had little expectations since (a) It was 9pm and I was hungry (b) the margaritas i had on an empty stomach needed a complement...and fast! 

The deep dish pizza was awesome - the tomato-basil sauce was perfectly seasoned, the red onions were fresh and thinly sliced, and the big chunks of italian sausage (not the ground up kind, but actually sliced wedges of  a sausage) made all the difference. it was a pretty heavy meal, and for 4 hungry people a large sufficed. 

Another reason to be completely jealous of our friends' kickass place in the Mistro. It's so close to great restaurants and pizza joints/bar places like Little Star! Ahhhh, I wish they open one up in my neighborhood!! 

Less one star for the crowd! Uhm, I couldn't get in when I first tried. As soon as you open the door, you were immediately faced with people's backs against said door that you just opened....Yeaaah, quite crowded, but that says a lot about the food quality as well!
author: Erika I.

description:
Came for an early dinner and there was still a wait for 45 min. We chilled at the bar and was excited when we got to sit. We ordered the garlic bread for appetizer and i was impressed. Out came an entire garlic soften, baked from the oven that you squeeze out and spread on your bread. It was really delicious, but for the price, I wish they gave us 2 garlics and more bread. 

The pizza is ok. Not really anything to rave about. The crust is good, but it's not really chi-town deep dish. 

I wouldn't come back if there was another 45 min wait. 

***Yes! They now accept credit cards now! and the ATM machine still only charges $0.25 service fee if you want cash.***
author: Gladys C.

description:
We were determined to try out Little Star within its first week of opening.  Apparently, we missed our chance as the server indicated they were in week 2.  You can't tell from driving by, as we've been doing for months.  The space is actually a little smaller than the one in Hayes Valley, but they've taken advantage of the small space by lining the walls with benches.  Otherwise, the location looks very similar to the sister restaurant.  The tables are very tight-the women next to me managed to spill a beer on my shoes-and the acoustics are such that the vibe is not the same.  It struck me as very loud.  I noticed the jukebox was not running at all times the way it is at the other location.

We got the last open table when we walked through the door at 8:15 on a Friday night.  We were in and out within an hour.  The service left a little to be desired-my boyfriend's salad was brought out a good ten minutes before mine.  That said, it's been a year since I ordered salad at Little Star (it's something I generally try and avoid at all costs) but both were exceedingly good-his mixed full of feta, and little pieces of pepper, and they hadn't skimped on the tomatoes.  My caprese featured smaller tomatoes, which I initially turned my nose up at, until I tried them.  The waiter hustled the salad out of my hands because there wasn't room on the table to put the pizza down.  When he placed the pie on the table, we realized it wasn't our pie-it was the pie of the couple next to ours.  It was too late-my salad was gone.

The couple next to us was very annoyed that it was cash only and that there wasn't a sign.  I could understand their animousity.  It seems like a reasonable request, or at least that the server could mention it early on-they had not visited the other location and they have signs up about how they won't seat incomplete parties.  It's likely to draw a new crowd who hasn't tried the previous little star-so I'll be back lots while I can still do the walk in thing.  I think the pizza crust was even crispier, but my mind may be playing tricks on me.

I'm always up for Little Star-either location.  I'm confident the kinks in the service will be worked out shortly-and maybe it was just the large crowd a few tables over that made it deafening.  I'll be back again to check out the situation shortly.
author: Beth V.

description:
I'm not much of a writer nor a critic so this will be simple and to the point.  Cash only but there is an ATM on the inside in the wait area.  Very reasonably priced pizzas and beer.

By far the best pizza I have eaten so far in SF.  Great tomato sauce and excellent selection for toppings and cheeses.  The crusts....both thin and deep dish are delicious.  Beer selection is good but bottled, good wine selection as well.  

The mission district is a pain for parking so I would recommend public transportation. The wait isn't so bad, it can range from prompt seating to approximately 20 minutes.  There is a bar and a seat area for waiting and it can get packed later in the week at around 8ish.

Seating is somewhat cramped but nothing uncomfortable.  The waitstaff is prompt and provides the right amount of attentiveness.  The noise level can be really loud where you begin to have a difficult time hearing the person seated across from you.  High noise levels are on those packed house nights but isn't so bad when its not crowded. Good jukebox selection. Clean bathroom facility, only one unisex bathroom for the place and normally there is no line.  Good to know if you had a few beers.  

I highly recommend this place.
author: Suzanne C.

description:
The pizza was sufficiently enticing that I disregarded my normal discipline and consumed way too many slices of cheese pie and the white star special. And I was totally sober.  

I would not trek far and wide for Little Star.  But you definitely will not go wrong by dining here.
author: Keith R.

description:
There is a three-way tie between pizza, yoga and 'hella' in the contest of Last Thing New Yorkers Will Do When Assimilating. We take our pizza seriously, and yes it's annoying to listen to, but understand that we are trying to help you, not condescend. Californians are good people and deserve better than North Beach Pizza. You call that sauce? Frauds!

Top honors for New York-style pizza go to Arinell's, hands down. For the rest of the field, though, Little Star is right up at or near the top. I was a little skeptical at first -- deep dish, lots of crushed tomatoes on *top* of the cheese? -- but you can't really argue with the flavor. And it doesn't suffer from that bloated dough-to-other-ingredients ratio that's so pervasive in pizzerias around here.

I seem to recall some subpar buffalo wings in a previous visit? But we got a caprese salad with our pizza yesterday and it ruled. No points off.

Racer 5 + deep dish = happy
author: andy d.

description:
In a league of its own... one cannot compare little star to other "pizza" because it's not really pizza.  What it is is a little slice (get it) of heaven.  

I am not interested in the reviews of whiners complaining they waited too long. One must wait for perfection. And thus, I wait. I wait and wait because unfortunately, I cannot eat little star every day... all day. And then, I wait when I get there because the place(s) is cute as are the staff and they have the best juke box... sometimes you can even hear the music.  Extra points for the Divis location for having adorable art.  

We always order the veggie deep dish LARGE so there is some to take home.  

hint: you actually dont have to wait at all if you get there early!
author: shannon m.

description: The best pizza in town. Simple, modern, down to earth.
author: Randy S.

description:
So, I hate thick crust pizza.  Like really hate!  (All those Carbs go straight to my hips/thighs).  That was until I had Lil Star's thick cornmeal crust veggie.....  it's freak'n yummy!  Really Yummy.

:)
author: Pammy S.

description:
Totally agree with Tamara. The service STINKS (unlike the Divis joint) but the pizza is yummy. We, too, had a election shin dig and sadly, Little Star Divis turned us away - couldn't take more orders. Luckily - or not so luckily, the Mission spot took our order. I wish they hadn't. Arriving 1 hour after placing the order (they said 45 min), we waited another hour at least. While the streets were buzzing and people were hooting in hollering, the girl at the cashier just gave us lip galore. I greatly dislike when people in service-oriented industries don't give a sh*t about their customers! I will note that the chick behind the counter did give us extra pizza - but while saying "I gave you more pizza" as if it excused her from her awful customer service and the 1.5 hour delay.

For now, I am turned off from this spot. I think I'll stick to my local Little Star.
author: Deann M.

description:
I've only had take out from here and every time I've been inside to pick it up, the place has been crazy crowded. I can't comment on the wait or the table service, but the pizza itself is outstanding. 

The ingredients are fresh and the toppings plentiful.  I liked the tasty crust and the deep dish alone is worth the trip.  Praise also for the sauce - the weak point of many a pizza. I'm not sure whether they make it fresh on site, but it is flavorful, fresh and made with the perfect amount of spice.

A solid contender in the world of upscale pizza.  Definitely worth the price and the wait.
author: Bryce M.

description:
Yummy deep dish pizzas, fun atmosphere, a little bit pricier but worth the money...

However! Be prepared to wait....especially if it's a weekend.  We were told about an hour, so we decide we'll walk around and see what else is up.  Needless to say hours later and we end up back at Little Star, after some blister-inducing search for food....and finally we are able to get seated, pretty close to closing so it was nice of them to accomodate us.

The staff was friendly, the food was tasty, portions huge...not a bad combination.  I would definitely recommend checking it out, if you're looking for a little more fancy than usual pizza experience.
author: Kristine C.

description:
