Used to live in Chicago, and have to say, this is right there with the best I've had there.  Please no more comments about NY vs. Chicago style.  Both are good.  (but I have a tender place in my heart ...or stomach...for Chicago style).

I liked Little Star.  Would recommend it to anyone.
author: Sam P.

description: Count me among the minority that doesn't think Little Star stacks up well against Zachary's.  It's still a fun restaurant with a great vibe and good service, but I don't get excited for Little Star's dense, over-oiled, cornmeal crust.  Nor do I think they're particularly generous with the toppings the way Zachary's is.  I'm still happy to go in a heartbeat 'cause I love me some pizza, but you won't see me cutting my ties to its East Bay competition anytime soon.
author: Laurence W.

description:
Not a full 4 stars, but if they were called "Little Star Crust," I'd give them the full 5.

The crust is definitely one of the best I've had, but seriously, who goes for pizza just to munch on some crust?

I'm not the biggest fan of Little Star because the deep dish isn't really deep dish pizza IMO.  Calling it a thick crust pizza would be more accurate.  I'm used to deep dish with a thick mess of ooey gooey cheese & toppings.  Little star gives me 2/3 crust with just enough toppings.  They need to do away with the thin crust, because it's borderline cardboard.

On the plus, the pizza prices are just right.  There's a nice vibe in the place.  The wait can drag on sometimes, but the cute bartender chick makes good conversation.  Brownie points for her!
author: Eric W.

description:
Where can you go for a cheap, delicious birthday dinner with fifteen of your closest friends?  That's right.

Not only that, but we made the reservation at the last minute (3pm that day).  

Now, we did have to jump through some hoops (7:00 reservation, as opposed the the 8:00 that we wanted; had to be out by 8:30 so the next reservation could be seated; had to pre-order the pizza).  But all being said, they were very accommodating for such a poppin' place.

Pizza: Delicious.  Holy alcohol sponge.  I believe we got: (probably not the real names)
Thin crust chicken pesto
Thin crust white pizza
Thick crust vegetarian
Thick crust classic
Thick crust chicken and artichoke

All really good.  Also, we thought that the service was great, which I know stands in opposition to some other reviews.  The waitress kept our beers filled and checked on us quite often.  

PS: The birthday ice cream was oh so fine.  I could bathe in that pumpkin ice cream.
author: Zak D.

description:
The same wonderful tastiness as the Divis location, but in a much better space!  It's not the big gray echo chamber the other one is - this one is shaped more like an L, with the short side being the bar & entrance area, and the long side being where the seating is (though it's still pretty small).  Hopefully the shape of the space will help cut down on the awful noise that plagues the original location.
The big wall along the L is all brick, which I find more attractive.  Still a very dark environment like the other.  They don't have any beer on tap, which is too bad, but there's a big bottle selection.
Cash only, as reported.  But it's just as yummy!  And in the Mission!  Which means I can walk there!
author: Don H.

description:
Jesus tap-dancing Christ everyone!  Shut the hell up!  Keep this Little Star Pizza to yourself!  Gah!

Oh well.  Guess I'm too late anyway, see as this place has a crap-load of reviews already.  

So as not to completely rehash everyone else's review, this place is bomb.  End of story.  

GO!...to the one on Divisidero.  I'm eating _here_ tonight so I better not see you! *evil eye*
author: Chris M.

description: Pizza wings and garlic bread were great!!! Pizza was light and filling and I had a Belgium beer to match. Awesome dinner I'll be back.
author: Kiara S.

description:
Trying to find adequate Chicago pizza in San Francisco, is like, well, it's like having a major earthquake in Chicago.... not so likely.  

Given that, I will say that this place definitely satisfied my craving for a Chicago style pizza, though not so much that I have been running back on a weekly basis.  Mostly, I have just given up on having the true Chicago pizza experience.  

Fresh ingredients, good flavors, tasty crust.  What more can you ask for?
author: Naka H.

description:
I am usually not a fan of deep dish style pizza but the deep dish pizza at Little Star is just too good. This is definitely the best deep dish pizza I've ever had. The corn meal dough is my favorite part about their pizza, and so is the perfect ratio of dough to cheese to sauce. And the pizza always tastes exactly as I remember... very consistent.

I usually get it to-go so service hasn't been a factor. The few times that I ate there, service was alright. The wait time to get a table can get too long sometimes, but that's because they're always busy.
author: Adisorn R.

description:
While I like to think eight stanzas of trochaic tetrameter should be enough to sum up any restaurant, it's worth screwing up my whole rhythm to post this update:
I went to LSP last night with some friends and discovered their new special.

Wait for it...

The Little Star with Bacon and Gorgonzola.  

Now, I normally don't like to eat pig (I figure I'm breaking enough Biblical directives in my life as it is), but for this I made an exception.  

I wasn't disappointed.  The gorgonzola wasn't overwhelming and the bacon was, well, perfectly bacony (no Bacos here!).  I cried a little.
author: Richard T.

description:
I have never been to one pizza place more than once in a month in the city.  I actually ended up here two days in a row.  I've heard great things about it from fellow foodies and my date finally brought me out to try out the deep dished goodness!  My first time there, we started off with the caprese salad, which was absolutely delicious, and that was just the start.  We ordered a small deep dish "classic" and the yesss, the name does the pizza justice.  Mind you, this was my first REAL deep dish pizza experience.  (I still need to visit Chicago, btw).  Everything about this pie was on point all the way down to the corn bread crust.  FYI, I'm not big on bread, but I must admit that this was my favorite part.  You know you did pizza right if you can get a non-starch fanatic to chow down on her crusts.  Too good...The next day I had a lunch date with my cousin and I raved about the place, so he insisted we went there for lunch.  This time, we split the Mediterranean Chicken, which was just as good.  I must admit though, the Classic is still on top of my list.  

A couple weeks ago, I met a couple of friends at the Little Star location on Divisadero where we shared the classic deep dish, the Italian Combo thin crust, and some chicken wings.  The Italian Combo was really good too, but after trying their deep dishes for the first time, it was hard to fall in love with it.  This is why I saved my classic deep dish for last.  And about their chicken wings...they're not all that visually appealing but they are delightful lil firecrackers that dance on your tongue.  NOM NOM NOM!

One thing though, I wish they a full bar.  Beer is good, but I like my g&t better :)
author: Kimba V.

description:
This review is long overdue.

As a native Chicagoan, let me be bold and say: I don't think I could find a better quality pizza in Chicago itself. 

I love Little Star, love their Chicago style, love their thin crust. Love dining in, love picking one up - either way, you can't go wrong.

By a server's recommendation, had a glass of their Quivira zin and it was so good, we drove to Sonoma that weekend and bought a few bottles. The next time we went to LS, we took our own bottle of Navarro zin, and shared it with the server - she loved it!

I'm far from being young, skinny, and tattooed, but the service at Little Star has always been very friendly and accommodating!

Update - 10/04/07 -
Their thin crust rocks and I'm addicted to their caprese salad.
Try it...you can't possibly be disappointed.
author: Dora A.

description:
While I've primarily eaten from their Western Addition/Divisadero location, I have to say that the Little Star Pizza on 15th Street and Valencia in the Mission rocks!  While being infinitely better lit inside than the other restaurant, it also has the advantage of being larger and getting seated much quicker (according to my sister).  

I thought their version of Chicago style pizza was superior to everything else I've tried in the Bay Area (even while I was in Illinois---I know, blasphemy!), and THEN I ate it inside the restaurant!  The pie's crust was crispier, the cheese was even more decadent and I devoured three slices before my dinner mates had even finished their first!

Only four stars because parking sucks ass.....
author: Michael W.

description:
Going to Cal, I am not foreign to good Chicago style deep dish pizza (i.e. Zachary's).  So when I heard that Little Star was the Zachary's of SF, my interest was piqued.  There are two locations in SF, one in the Mission, and the other in Western Addition/NoPa.  We went to the former since it was closer to the BART.  Now, I should mention that the mission district is basically the opposite of Union Square: less Chanels and Louis Vuittons and more taco stands and bum fights (yes, we actually saw one) if you catch my drift.  But that is something that I really like about SF, every district is so unique and different from each other that you feel like you are stepping into a different city at every place.

Once we got to Little Star, we were told it was gonna be a 30 minute wait, but after 2 parties didn't respond when their name was called, the cool host swooped us in with barely a 5 minute wait.  The ambiance inside was pretty cool:  brick walls, dim lights, a very urban feel.  My only complaint was that it feels they tried to fit too many tables in an already small space, it was difficult just to get into my seat.  For appetizer, we got their spicy chicken wings with blue cheese dip.

I could really have eaten the whole thing as the main dish! They were really good.  I love spicy food, and these wings really had kick! So much so that one of my dining companions had to get an extra soda to wash they down.  And the cool blue cheese dip really contrast well with these spicy wings.  Then, it was onto our pizza.  For the 3 of us, we got one large pizza called the Brass Monkey (which is a secret menu pizza but not really).  It had spinach, ricotta, feta, mushroom, onion, garlic, and sausage.

Hmmm...nom nom nom, the Brass Monkey isn't popular for nothing.  All the toppings really stood out so that I actually tasted every single ingredient from sausage to spinach.  It wasn't overpowered at all by the tomato sauce.  And the garlic!  You really taste the garlic in this pizza and that is perfectly fine with this garlic lover.  And then there was the flaky and crispy crust (which upon research, I've learned is made from cornmeal).  I actually cut my crust and forked it with my pizza so I would have a piece of it in every bite.  So good.

So how's Little Star compared to Zachary's?  I would give LS the edge for its indulgence in garlic and that awesome crust.
author: Alex T.

description:
This place is okay, I guess.  They have both deep dish and thin crust pizza, and my opinion is, basically, "pick one and try to do it well rather than doing both mediocre."

I ordered the white pie, hold the tomatoes, because tomatoes are such a disgusting weed and that was the only pizza I could get without tomato sauce.  Everyone else in my party split one deep dish and one thin crust.  My pizza was okay.  Their pizzas were okay.  Nothing terrible, but nothing great either.  Little Star basically excels at being okay.

If you want thick crust, go to Zachary's.  If you want thin crust, go to Piccino.
author: Chad H.

description:
Super!  Just like the one on Divis, only in the mission now!  Good prices on great food.  Super nice staff with great suggestions.  Good beer selection too.

Keep up the good work, you've got my business.
author: Daten S.

description:
Kind of wankerish to bombard Yelp with a bad review from every member of your party down there, but anyhoo....

I don't have much to add too all the (mostly) wonderful reviews here, so I'll just say that I'm totally gay for this pizza. Little Star has the best pie in the known universe. Sorry NYC.
author: Christine N.

description:
Wow !!!

Crust = A+++
Cheese = A ++
Salad = A+

Fabulous charming restaurant in a not so fabulous neighborhood.
author: Mihae T.

description:
Another drop in the bucket.

I'm from the Chicago area. I get homesick, so I order a pizza from Little Star. I've always gone for the veggie pizzas and still do. My favorite (and the only one I've tried) is the "Little Star" (no onions). 

Great crust. Authentic taste. Damn good.
author: Kitty H.

description: I love this place. Great homey feel, great pizza, good salads. reasonable prices, good service. The perfect place to take your parents when you don't wanna go somewhere fancy. Great place.
author: Claire b.

description:
BEFORE YOU READ ANY OTHER REVIEWS, READ THIS REVIEW FIRST as I am from Chicago....

This is simply THE BEST deep dish pizza you can find anywhere in the Bay Area. 

You really can't go wrong with this place in terms of what you get for your toppings. What makes their pizzas unique is the tomato sauce and the dough. The tomato sauce is nice and mild, easy on the palette, unlike Zachary's (too tangy....which pales in comparison....I would give them only 2.5-3 stars) 

The crust is corn meal. It provides a nice and mellow sweet taste as your salivary glands slowly begin to break down those starches into sugars providing a nice backdrop to your savory toppings. 

Recommended dishes other than their pizzas: Caprese salad: mild and FRESH mozzarella in with balsamic and virgin olive oil

spicy chicken wings: Fried to perfection, not too crispy, not too soft. If you are not a fan of blue cheese dressing, this will make you a fan as their sauce is again very easy on the palette. 

There are 2 locations, this one and another on Divisadero. I suggest going early as they do not take reservations which can bring the wait to as long as 2 HOURS!!! This location is probably less crowded...and maybe you can figure out why.
author: Michael C.

description:
Been twice and love their deep dish pizzas!  After the first time, I was hooked, even after a 45 min. wait, and I found myself craving their pizza soon afterwards.

Last time, I wasn't paying attn. and didn't realize my husband ordered a small deep dish for the two of us.  While it is was more than enough for the two of us, I wanted to take home leftovers!!!  Oh well.

We showed up at 5:00-ish on a Sunday so we wouldn't have to wait and didn't know they took reservations (shoulda checked out yelp first!).  I saw the list and there were only two reservations, one at 5:30 and one at 7:00 so I don't think it's hard at all to get one and the place filled up by 6:00.

Can't think of any other place in the City where I'd go for pizza!

oh yeah, their dinner salad is really tasty too.
author: TC C.

description:
We have been waiting here at this supposed awesome pizzeria for almost 2 hours. Got here at 7 and we were told that we would be seated in 45 minutes and here we are an hour and 45 minutes later and we are still waiting. I usually am a patient person especially with a dinner rush hour but this experience has been ridiculous.  They could not accommodate our large group of ten people so we had to split up in a group of 4 and a group of 6 which was fine.  We didn't care where our two groups would get seated just at the same time so we would get out of this place at the same time.  They kept seating four tops and six tops that came after us instead of holding two tables for us and after an hour and a half , I don't even care about the food. I have never reviewed a restaurant while I'm waiting to be seated. I don't even want to patron this establishment but it is impossible to find another restaurant at this time. To add insult to injury, she just offered to comp one order of the garlic bread due to our 2 hour wait. Are you kidding me? 5 dollars off for a 2 hr wait? That is a slap in the face.  On top of that, we were told to order while we waited so that our food would be ready when we get seated and guess what , no freaking food for our six tops as they are seating there right now waiting.  They need a better system or just refuse large groups if they cannot accommodate large groups.

They tried to redeem themselves during service and I have to give them an A for the effort they put out.  The food was really good and that was a great redeeming factor to a disastrous evening.  We got the garlic bread and the crust on the deep dish pizza was too die for.  So Even though the night started off rough, the food really made up for it.  Plus, we were so hungry anyway so we ate everything up.  The waitress did apologize for the hostess and said that it was her first night.  I just don't understand how they could start a new employee on a busy saturday night and basically throwing her to the sharks.  The waitress did comp our bills and I thought that was the right thing to do and despite of a crazy start, I would probably come back but with fewer people.
author: Alex N.

description:
Fabulous pizza!  Definitely go deep dish because it's extra saucy.  I wanted to keep eating this pizza until I burst out of my pants!  But I restrained.  The garlic bread looks divine - loaf of bread, butter and whole roast garlic head on the side.  Maybe that and the Gorgonzola salad for dinner sometime?  But why go if you don't get pizza?  And then the cheesecake - We ordered one piece and split it four ways.  I'll never do that again.  Only my grandma makes a better cheesecake!  (Actually, I make a kickin' cheesecake too because I have grandma's recipe!)

Anyway, the waitress (although very nice) kept knocking things over on the table and dropped used utensils in my lap.  So, don't sit at her table - she's very clumsy.  Service could use a touch-up in my opinion.
author: Jackie D.

description:
Pretty good pizza, although I've never tried the thin crust. The beer selection is great and most of the waiters are pretty cute. Not gonna lie, it helps. 

Really, the only reason to walk in the door is the buffalo wings. They're re-fucking-diculous. Kinda deep fried, and wicked spicy, it's almost like the chickens they came from marched straight to the Mission from Mount Olympus. Normally I'm pretty apathetic about buffalo wings - lots of work and mess for little payoff - but these are amazing. We couldn't even dip them in the blue cheese sauce so as not to bastardize the flavor. 

As it's like 3 blocks from my house, I've started coming here biweekly just for beer and wings. It's so KANSAN!
author: Ron A.

description:
Really f"ing good- hits the pizza, craving spot. 

You have to try the "Little Star" deep dish pizza- It's like a pizza lasagna.
author: Paige B.

description:
We went here Sunday and we were starving.  With no reservations, we had a 45 minute wait for a table.  The place is deceptive from the outside, it looks like an office with its blacked out glass doors and no windows, once you get inside it had a groovy sort of warehouse feel.  The ceiling is painted black and it's lively and loud.  
The salad was good, delicate and not overdressed, but I guess I am a pizza snob.  To me a perfect pizza is simple,  the crust   (thick or thin) is the most important part and the toppings should be used sparingly.  We had the Little Star deep dish and the crust was pretty good, but the tomato spinach and feta topping was kinda bland. 
Prices are more than fair, all and all, good, not great .
author: Joanne K.

description:
This is a tough one to rate. Probably the best pizza I've ever had in my life, and coming from me that's a good compliment (insert fat joke here). 
However, the staff here is probably some of the worst I've ever experienced in my life. Numerous times I have been in to eat some pizza with friends, but wind up sitting around for up to 2 hours to place our order and get our food. Not good when you are starving. 

The last time I went, I went with 2 friends. Movie starts in 2 hours, we have time. Little Star it is (gah, i love that pizza!) You guessed it. Our pizza finally came out about 30 minutes before the movie starts (and we still have to hop the BART to get to the metreon). we had to SCARF our pizza down and run out the door to get to the movie - already started. great. 

Literally every time I go, the servers walk around ignoring their tables. I have had to flag them to get their attention many times just so we can place our order. "Oh, are you ready to order?" they ask. Really? We've been sitting here for 25 minutes.. how long do you think it takes to decide on pizza? Give me a break. They act uninterested and half asleep when talking to you. It's kinda weird. Slow to take your order, the pizza takes forever to cook, and it takes forever to get your check. 

Like I said the pizza is worth it sometimes. But, I would safely say to go here when you have hours to spend on dinner. Don't go if you have to be somewhere at a specific time. And know you are going to be devoting the next 2-3 hours on dinner or lunch. Don't go while your stomach is growling, because you might gnaw your hand off in starvation/frustration. 

The 3 stars is generous, and only because of the pizza. Maybe I'll just stick to take out.
author: Michael M.

description:
Maybe I was finally recovering my appetite during the worst ever chest cold I have so far endured in adulthood, my first bite of Little Star Vegetarian (!!) pizza tasted so amazingly yummy that I forgot to cough for the first time in a week.  It was deep dish and contrary to all my previous "deep dish" experiences, this one had texture and flavors.  

We also had some hot wings.  It was a treat to see my long-time Aqua-tarian (seafood and veggies only) friend devouring a chicken wing just to make a very sick girl laugh (believing that it is still the best medicine).  

Little Star shined a silvery spark into my stomach that night.  And smart as we were, we picked up our pie to efficiently avoid all that irritation associated with having to wait for a table.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
Just had Little Star for the first time last night and already wish I could go back!  My boyfriend and I celebrated his birthday with an order of garlic bread, small (9") Classic Deep Dish, and their Blue Star Wheat beer.  Everything was AMAZING!  The butter for the garlic bread was soft & easy to spread and the bulb of roasted garlic on the side was genius.  Our small deep dish was the perfect size for the two of us and everything about it was delicious.  The beer had a nice clean taste to it and kudos for being served in a frosted glass.  I definitely can't wait to go back again.

Got there just before 7pm and there weren't too many people there (didn't have to wait for seats) but the place was packed by the time we ordered and it was a Tuesday night so definitely be prepared to wait or show up really early.
author: Carmel H.

description:
So, I'm a bit of a pizza snob.  After growing up on the east coast and living in places such as Cleveland and Chicago, I've always been disappointed with the lack of New York style pizza options.

Little Star does not serve New York style pizza, but:

It's really damn good.

I'll be heading there a lot more now, even as I continue my quest for the perfect NY style slice.
author: Ryan K.

description:
Pizza and beer -- could there be a better combination?! There are not many places in the Bay that do Chicago-style pizza right (Zac's is the only other place that comes to mind). I never understood why some people call pizza "pie" until I came to Little Star. It truly is more of a pie than a pizza, and that is why it is delicious. The pepperoni, sausage and mushrooms were all cooked inside the pizza, sandwiched around multiple layers of crust. 

I don't think I can handle Chicago-style pizza all the time, but this is the place to go when you have a craving. They also have a great wine list. The only negative is they only take cash.  C'mon Little Star -- at least come into the 20th century.
author: Lupe P.

description:
pizza. deep dish. in SF. YES PLEASE!

It looks like I've found my deep dish pizza spot in the city. My friend and I ordered the small deep dish pizza - half Classic (sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells) & half Little Star (spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic). It was more than enough to feed us both. The Little Star was better than the Classic, but that doesn't mean the Classic was bad. We also had the Mixed Salad (mixed greens, cherry tomatoes, red bells, red onions, gorgonzola cheese and chopped walnuts, tossed with a housemade vinaigrette dressing) and surprisingly, it was way better than I anticipated. Salads usually taste all the same to me, but this one actually made an impression on me and definitely had me remembering it.

Although the food is great, I must say it was very noisy at this Mission location. The restaurant is not that big and so the tables/seats are very close together. You could pretty much hear everyones conversation. I went on a weekday and it was pretty packed, so I'm sure it's even more packed on the weekends.
author: Krystle A.

description: Wow... finally a good deep dish pizza on this side of the Bay.  Nice tasty crust, good sauce, and nice thick ingredients.  Worth a visit, and BART accessible.
author: Dan M.

description:
This place has been reviewed enough and for the most part I agree with them... good pizza. But I am here to add two more things about this place that may have been mentioned somewhere in the 925 reviews, that I am not about to read to find out.  So if someone has already mentioned this I apologize:  

As far as I know Little Star has the least expensive ATM additional charge in the city!.  A whole quarter! I have never seen anything like it.  I got money out and I didn't even need it.  It really is the little things in life. Also a long time ago when the first one opened over on Divis someone told me they had the best jukebox in town.  I never got around to testing that out, but I did like the merriment of music in the this one.  The speakers were horrible however so I could not really understand the songs. Might want to work on that.
author: Thomas C.

description:
I love Little Star so much that I am willing to take out cash just to go here (no credit cards accepted). The menu includes some salads and appetizers, I think, but skip them and go right to the pizza. You'll need all the stomach space you can muster. Though my friends argue back and forth over whether thin crust or deep dish is better (I'm on the deep dish side, myself), you can't really go wrong.

The only downside is that the place is small, dark, and really, really loud. I don't mind small or dark, but it would be nice to have a conversation at normal decibel levels.
author: Renee T.

description: Disappointing. Too acidic from too much tomato sauce, the crust was like stale old biscuits, and bottom was very soggy. I had to eat with a fork because the pizza completely flopped when I tried picking it up. Perhaps if I had the pizzas in-house (I had them picked up) they'd hold better, but they didn't even deliver in flavor. Toppings are meh.
author: Nicole L.

description: Zachary's, eat your heart out.  Chicago has good stuff, this place has good stuff.
author: Shinny L.

description: This place is a really place if you are a fan of deep dish pizza. Highly recommend.
author: Jamal W.

description:
As I have with my Paxti's and Zachary's reviews, I want to preface this review by saying I am a born and raised Chicagoan who has been eating real Chicago pizza since i started teething.  My benchmark is Lou Malnati's, and for those in the know, they know that I am basically setting the bar at Olympic gold and asking for nothing less.

With that said, I have been hankering for a Chicago style deep dish pizza since moving to SF over 6 months ago.  I have tried Paxti's (mediocre, not very good crust, boring sauce) and Zachary's (better crusty, nice garlicy sauce), so Little Star was the next logical step.

I had to keep my mind open after stepping into the place since it doesn't exactly exude Chicago-style pizzeria, which is typical old fashioned Italian restaurant with pies instead of pasta.  Instead, it was very hip and somewhat minimalist.  While waiting, I settled up to the bar and had a very good Belgium beer in a nice frosty glass (nice!).  After getting called to my table, I looked at the menu.

The pizza selection can best be described as Chicago California fusion.  A true Chicago style pizza is not long on toppings.  There is a ton of cheese and some meat.  You might have a few veggies too, but everything is simple.  At little stars, the presence of Chicken, feta, and olives on the pizza was a bit out of whack, but I guess you have to run with the local flavor.  We ordered a 12 inch deep dish with Sausage on half and spinach on the other half.

When the pizza came out, I I was impressed initially by the crust.  As I have mentioned in past reviews, too often the crust is too think and not buttery.  Little Star, on the other hand, nailed it.  Crust was butter soft, but with a hint of crunch in the right places and not too doughy at all.  The topping were ample (the sausage chunks could have been a bit thinker, I guess), and the cheese was excellent.  The sauce was a bit bland at first bite, but a little crushed pepper spiced it right, although it could have used a bit more spice, I imagine.

Over all though, the pizza was excellent, best Chicago style pizza I have had out here, better (dare I say) than Zachary's famed pies.

Service was top notch as well, quick and friendly and perpetually provided with a smile.  The missing star is attributed too the rather high noise level which made conversation a might difficult.  Otherwise, mighty impressed and definitely a place I would frequent again.  I only which they offered a larger pizza size.  While 12" of deep dish is enough to serve three, the best part about deep dish is that it is 95% as good as leftovers as it is fresh!
author: Eric M.

description:
Pizza I need, Pizza I want, Pizza I love... the one place to go is Little Star!  

First off, I want to comment on the logo -- it's simple yet creative, I totally dig it!  Came here for the first time a couple of weeks ago with my roommate.  We were lucky enough to find parking a block away, the wait for two was about twenty-minutes.  We sat at the bar, drank some beer as we waited to be seated.  

I think it's all about the deep dish specialty pizzas.  We shared the Little Star (spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, and garlic).  The small, six slices was $19, perfect for two.  I'm speechless, still can't stop thinking about how good the pizza was, mouth-watering for sure!  The toppings, the crust, oh-my-oh-my...!

Little Star Pizza has a few appetizers (chicken wings, salad), thick as well as think crust pizzas, and cheesecake or gelato for dessert.  This place gets crowded so be prepared to wait, if not, take it to go :-)!

Would definitely be back soon.
author: Celeste M.

description:
We just spent $42 for two people (with tip) at Little Star.

Could've gone to Zachary's.

For cheaper.

And better.

Don't get me wrong: Little Star has its pluses. Fairly easy parking (easy for SF, that is), warm service, good beer selection if light on the porters, which are my favorite.

But the comparisons to Zachary's are apt -- and no, my Zach's takes it. Hands down. 

We got the spinach/feta/mushroom pizza, which was yum but not overwhelming. It seemed to cool rather quickly, too. Maybe it was just the effect of a cold January night.

I would warn against spending $4 for the garlic bread. Nice concept -- butter and garlic your own, using their roasted head -- but ah, nothing special. If you want kickass garlic bread, head to the Sunset and check out Milano Pizza.

But any night that Adam and I get to get buzzed and eat pizza is a good one, so thanks, Little Star. You gave us a good night.
author: Allison L.

description:
I am a deep guy so it is only natural I would also enjoy deep dish pizza. Little Star is perfect for all pizza lovers by serving both deep dish and thin crust to satisfy both New York and Chicago people. They have unique and delicious flavor combinations and great crusts for both types of pizza. Their "big star" is the deep dish with its crisp and relatively light crust although I prefer the pan pizzas with greasy crust drenched in oil.

They take reservations and have remarkably fast service considering the usual baking time. Only downside to this spot is the single unit unisex bathroom, pretty much don't get the runs while you're here.
author: Ed L.

description:
This was the first stop on the pizza crawl.

As a regular of the divis location I like Little Star but previously thought it was overdated.

I no longer think so:
The service was fun and attentive. The crust is crispy ( even on the deep dish), well seasoned, and the cornmeal adds additional texture. The cheese is tasty and appropriately salty - although I would like salt shakers on the table in case for salt is needed. The sauce is also well seasoned. 

For some in the group the crust was too cracker like but as I )and my bestie,  Linda L.) point out  no one should like soggy impitent crust. (again the pizza- sex analogy).
author: Sara K.

description:
Had dinner with Gur E., Amy, and Linda after LFN.  We shared garlic bread and  a large veggie deep dish pizza.  The pizza was good - not as cheese laden and heavy as Zachary's.  The large was the perfect amount for the four of us. The garlic bread was "deconstructed" served with warm butter, warm bread, and roasted garlic on the side - yummy.

It was also a very economical meal - 1/4 pizza, a pint of Racer 5 (yay! Amy likes it, too), and 1/4 garlic bread = $10 + tax and tip...I don't think I've ever eaten with Yelpers for that cheap.  Parking sucks, though
author: Gracie B.

description:
Prefer Mission location over Divis.
Prefer deep dish over their thin crust.
Prefer roasted garlic-their garlic bread is so good, definitely don't forget to order that.
Prefer happy hour-$1 off alcohol until 6:30 (that makes their beer $3 instead of $4)
Prefer paying with a debit card, which they now accept.
Prefer Little Star over any other pizza place in SF.
author: Sarah M.

description:
An hour and a half? Who the hell waits an hour and half to be seated for pizza?

That's what I asked myself when the hostess gave us the wait time on a Sunday night. Ok, that's just ridiculous. And I was still pretty annoyed when we decided to wait 30-45 minutes for our carryout instead. This pizza had better be really good...

OH, AND IT WAS! We got deep dish with pepperoni and thin crust with chicken and mushrooms, and both have been constant fixtures in my dreams in the weeks since.  

I still don't know who waits the length of a Disney cartoon to be seated for pizza, but I do know who will drive all the way across town for takeout: ME.
author: Ben R.

description:
Maybe i have high expectation.

for the price i expect them to give me a deck of pepperoni sausage under the cheese for their signature pizza .....but i didnt get that :( 

the waitress was very nice 

overall it was a ok
author: Amy K.

description: Great Pizza and pretty much my only pizza source for deep dish however this location also has snooty staff. However it is well worth putting up with for a yummy dinner. The pizza is always consistent in flavor and quality.
author: E B.

description:
FYI: Cash only and expect to wait long on a Friday & Saturday night. Parking isn't great either, since its close by all the bars and lounges on Valencia.

The party I was with ordered the little star deep dish, pesto chicken thin crust and the classic deep dish. Since I don't eat meat, I stuck to the little star, which was very good if you like chicago style pizza with lots of marinara sauce. Everyone raved about the pesto chicken. FYI, if you plan on ordering the spicy chicken wings they do not have ranch sauce, try to bring your own, lol. The garlic bread is sooo good, the bread is nice and crusty and the bulb of garlic spreads like butter.
author: Karen F.

description:
I've been a big fan of Little Star for a few years (often recommending it to my friends) but gotta tell ya that I was a bit disappointed during my last two visits.

Food - 4 stars.  Great deep dish crust with fresh toppings and reasonable prices.  But the pizzas have not been coming to the table hot.  What gives?  The chicken wings were piping hot but the pizzas are at best lukewarm.

Service - 2 stars.  The hostess and bartenders are great.  But the servers are downright unfriendly and surly.  Here's a tip--if you don't like people, don't work in the service industry.  You can be cool AND be nice.  This is my biggest gripe.  

If there's just two of you, you'll likely only have a short wait to snag a 2-top.  3 or more should expect a wait of about 35-45 minutes.  Parking sucks but that's nothing new in the Mission.  

Overall, I have to take the average and sadly give Little Star a 3 rating.
author: Marissa D.

description:
This location gets 4 stars cause I didn't have to wait forever like I do at the original location.  Although at the OG location I just put my name down, go across the way, and drink sake at Tsunami ;)

The lighting and music in the jukebox here is much better.  Pizza and salad are just as dee-lish here, as at the OG location.  Also for the first time, I tried one of the 2 desserts they offer.  I was instructed to save room for the homemade cheesecake.  Not bad-taste like an upscale Sara Lee frozen cheesecake.  Remember those?  Plain or the one with the strawberry topping?  Anyhoo, try if you have room.

One more thing:
Upon Brett's (AKA: F*ck Nuts) secret recommendation, order the fab root beer with the vanilla gelato=ROOT BEER FLOAT!!!  Eating/drinking one of these is no ordinary experience....so f'n good!!!
author: Cassie G.

description:
I ate here with a friend of mine after she recommended it. The pizza here is first rate, for sure. I'll get to that in a moment.

Here's what I did not like about Little Star Pizza: 
1. The salad sucked. 
The salad had potential to be awesome.. it had blue cheese, walnuts, that spicy lettuce, olive oil. Supposedly, there was some vinegarette but I didn't taste any at all. No tang. No sweetness. And the large was way too big. The waitress could have told our party of two that the small $5.00 salad was plenty for an appetizer.
2. No free refills. They ensure this by giving you a can every time.
3. The wait staff is distant and cold. We didn't even get a thank you on the way out (even though we gave them not one but two thank yous!). 
4. Cash only. However, their ATM fee is very fair.. 25 cents. That probably covers their cost.

The crowd here seemed pretentious, its true, but that's not a ding on the restaurant -- they have no control over their crowd.

The my onion-pepperoni-pepperoncini pizza was FANTASTIC. The thin crust was likely the best I've had in years and it was just as good toasted in the oven on the second day.  

Even so.. even though it was some of the best pizza I've had in a while, the restaurant atmosphere sucked so bad that I don't want to go back. Thankfully, I found out that they have a second location in Western Addition.. I'm going to give them a try soon.

UPDATE: I forgot..my friend got the sausage on her pizza. If you like PIzza Hut's sausage, then you'll like this. It tastes EXACTLY the same. I wasn't impressed..and I was glad that I stuck to pepperoni.
author: Chrissy Q.

description:
Great pizza in the city.  The thin crust pizza is delicious and the thick crust pizza is great too.  I think you are usually in one camp or the other, but I like both their pizza styles.  We had a group of 8 and got two large salads and three large pizzas and still walked away at $11 per person.  I think that is almost impossible to do anywhere else.  

The real kicker to this place is they offer drinks for the masses.  $2 beers if you don't mind slumming a bit (PBR) and $3 pacificos.  Everything else is $4.  Glasses of wine are reasonable too.  Sodas are $1.50 - that's cheaper than my corner store.
author: Rob U.

description:
Delicious! Chicago style deliciousness without having to trek over to Zachary's in Berkeley.

Cheap wine, but cash only. BOOOO! If you want us to spend money, you've got to spring for that credit card machine.
author: Glory W.

description:
This by far is my favorite place for deep dish pizza.  I'm normally not a fan of deep dish pizza, but after one bite of their Classic deep dish, I was hooked.  I love that they use a cornmeal crust.  

Upon ordering for the first time, I made the mistake of ordering a large to share with one other person.  Whoa...what that too much...and my dining partner and I have HUGE appetites.   A large deep dish is good for 4-5 people.  The small size deep dish is a nice amount for 2-3 people.

Little Star only accepts cash!
author: Michelle N.

description:
This place has some very good deep dish pizza. The only reason I'm giving it 4.5 stars is that I thought the crust wasn't quite as good as some I've had. It seemed to have a little too much corn meal (or something like that) in it which made it a bit gritty. The sauce, however, is some of the best I've had. The appetizers were also very good (try the peppery chicken wings). The service was quick, attentive and friendly.

The atmosphere is standard S.F. pizza place which is fine. It's a good place to take kids if they like deep dish pizza and parking isn't too bad by S.F. standards.
author: Stuart M.

description:
Really good thin crust pizza. 

For those of you who are comparing Little Star to Zachary's pizza in Berkeley, my question is why? Zachary does very good deep dish pizza and as a past east bay dweller I can tell you that I have eaten a lot of pizza there and pretty much left satisfied every time but I wouldn't compare it to Little Star because it's a totally different vibe, in every way.

First of all Little Star is a little place but they manage it pack a lot of people in and every time I've eaten here people look like they're not only enjoying the food but also the atmosphere, good music, cozy setting. Zach's is more family style and casual, good for large party's, kids, and sports watching.

I won't go on and on but this is a really good place for a little atmosphere, a little wine or beer, and a little star pizza with a big taste.

Yum!
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
The deep dish sausage is fantastic.  I get cravings at least once a month.  Boy, is it filling! Even when I'm super hungry, I can only eat 2 slices at the most.  Plus, if there is a line, the wine selection is wonderful and the bartenders have all been fun, interesting, and full of helpful recommendations if we ask them to give us their favorites.  A good place to get tipsy while you wait (often there is a line, so I usually go on a weeknight after 9pm).

Sadly, all the other pizza I've tried there is mediocre. I wouldn't order anything else there, now, except the classic. Going to a place monthly just for one item means their signature sausage deep dish has gotta be good, right?!

QUICK UPDATE: just tried the thin crust pesto, garlic & chicken pie and it was very good. Now I have to go twice a month!
author: Jenny W.

description:
Fast, friendly (to-go) service.

I LOVE gaining weight with Little Star Pizza on Valencia by (on) my side! I call in, wait 30 minutes (preferrably while sitting and maybe eating an appetizer in my apartment), then walk one block and burn 2 calories to pick up my order.

It's amazing!

Oh, and the pizza's damn good, too.
author: Greg Z.

description:
I went here a while ago with a friend. From the outside, it will look closed. They tinted and curtain their windows. So you can't tell unless you walk up to the door.  One thing I will tell you, it gets pretty busy here. If you in groups larger than two, you'll probably be waiting two or three times longer. It is worth the wait. 

Their deep dish pizza was pretty good. It will pretty filling. But what I liked the most was their garlic bread. It was actually roasted garlic!! They pop out pretty easily and you spread them on the bread. It taste sooo good. That itself makes it worth coming here. Interestingly, that is the impression and what I remembered the most here.
author: Jimmy H.

description: Order this - Little Star Deep Dish, White pie thin crust, Mixed Green Salad, Garlic, red wine.  Perfect. Loud and crowded so get there early.
author: Jeni S.

description:
Living in Chicago and knowing so many types of Chicago style pizzas, I'd have to say this place stacks up to some of my best picks in Chicago.  The Classic, Little Star and Veggie were all amazing.  Great crust and sauce, just the right amount of cheese and toppings.

Get there early!  We went out with a group of 6 on Saturday night to the Mission location around 730 and were seated around 8.

Great selection of beer and it's cheap, especially if you want a PBR!

Enjoy!!!
author: Stephen W.

description:
As an east bay native it pains me to say this (I've only recently been able to admit this to even my closest friends and family) but Little Star has supplanted Zachary's as my favorite deep dish pizza. The crust is just too good.

The cash-only, mega-busy aspect of the place is the only thing that keeps it from being 5 stars in my book. (frankly, 5-stars isn't enough to rate the pizza itself).

The garden salad is also amazingly good. Fresh, bountiful, and generally awesome. 

So good. So freaking good.
author: James F.

description:
This is the best deep dish in town! And any place that serves PBR with pizza wins in my book.

Little Star is great for meeting friends or taking a date. Split a caprese salad and a small Little Star (deep dish of course) with a friend and you have a FULL MEAL.

The space is a bit crowded, but comfortable. The noise level can get high, but this is a place known for pizza.  

If you have left-overs, bring them home. The pizza re-heats in the oven very well. I would drive here for take-out over any of the delivery options I have tried.
author: Kemp M.

description:
This place is pretty garbage. The delusional Californians will think that this is good deep dish, and you know what, it's not too bad, though the crust recipe is straight out of the pizza hut playbook.

That thin crust white pie is a fucking disaster. If anyone thinks that carboard crust and oily topping is good, they have no fucking clue about food.

I miss NY.
author: Jon F.

description: My friends were a bit concerned we would not love this place simply because it had been touted as the best pizza- ever. Well it very nearly was and I wish they had eats like this in Atlanta where I live. The food was good, loved the crust, the tomato sauce was slightly bland for my taste but otherwise a very yummy deep dish that I'll be working off for some time to come but TOTALLY worth it.
author: Aisha I.

description: The pizza is hella good, but their wings are also the best in the city. I sometimes just call in an order for these wings!
author: EJ S.

description:
It takes a lot to impress me. Especially when it comes to pizza. Especially when a place has a lot of hype to live up to, which is definitely the case with Little Star. 

The hubby and I braved some serious rain to walk over here. Upon entering, I was very pleased with what the owners have done with the joint. It used to be a Thai place that failed to find a crowd. Subtle changes in layout and decor have served it well.

The thin crust being served at the table next to us looked tasty, but we had to go with the deep dish given that it's what everyone raves about. We topped it off with onions, tomato, garlic, and anchovies, and started out our meal with a salad to share. The salad was just right, the wine was inexpensive and did the trick, and the pizza... perfect distribution of toppings, just the right amount of cheese, and the crust is divine. Kind of crunchy but quite light, just chewy enough, I seriously was not expecting to be this happy at the end of the meal.

My only criticism is that they don't take credit cards. Come on. It's not a hole in the wall, the wine list varies from the mid-twenties on up, the pies are not that cheap - I think Little Star is slightly above the cash-only threshold in terms of people's expectations. HOWEVER, I will concede that by having an ATM on the premises (with only a 25 cent surcharge, believe it or not) they alleviate the potential for confusion and problems. 

So yes, Little Star really is all that. My cynicism has been put in check.
author: Amy K.

description:
Next to the Projects on the Guerrero Valencia Corridor, dark drapes on the windows and small sign: it looked more like a pot club (few blocks up the street, for those interested) than a pizzeria. 

I "stumbled" in it while walking to Delfina one night and it was a very good surprise.  Good the caprese (hold the cheap balsamic vinegar please) and exceptional pizza. Thin crust (what else?), right to the spot. Attentive and courteous service (but the server had to ask the manager before bringing me some bread.. oh well...), cash only at the register but there is a ATM in the entrance with a very low service charge. 

Good  the decor but the place tends to get very loud.
author: Alex P.

description:
Ridiculous!  Ridonkulous!

I'm not going to compare this to Zachary's or Paxti's.  I'm also not going to compare this to authentic Chicago deep dish (even though I did spent 4 chilly years in Chicago).  I don't believe in comparing apples to oranges.  Little Star Pizza is delicious in its own unique right.

Ingredients are fresh.  We normally pick our pie up, but the dine in experience is fun too.  It's normally crowded here; lots of folks on dates (and too dressed up for the place, IMO).  The "Little Star" deep dish is the way to go.  Salads are really good also.  Plan on a large if this is going to be your meal.

Tonight's meal:  3 huge pieces + two extra crusts (the BEST part)=  I'm so disgustingly stuffed.  But you know how I do.
author: Poker B.

description:
Scenario: Dinner with friends on a random weeknight.  Then dinner on a Saturday after the 2008 Red Bull Soapbox Derby.

Price: Holy damn this is good Chicago style deep dish pizza.  For the pizza you're getting I think the price is right on at around $10.  Drinks are a little pricey I think at $5 for a beer (except the PBR if you're down to PBR), but the stout is pretty darn good.  Portions are good in that four people can eat a whole pizza, two slices each, and feel very content to possibly stuffed.  The pizza is made with some kind of cornbread crust I think... like a normal thick crust deep dish pizza but with a hint of cornbread taste.

Service: Service is pretty good.  The servers are generally on top of things and the pizza seems to come out in a reasonable amount of time.  Bartenders are decently attentive as well.  Cute, young servers always helps, except that the cutest one never looks my way :(

Atmosphere: Well, if you come to this place on a normal night it is busy and the wait is around a half hour.  However, they have a small bar in the lounge area, which is perfect for waiting.  The place feels candlelit and intimate, but is low key casual as far as dress and does not feel cramped.  If you luck out and get there when it opens, like 5 on a Saturday, you're right in and rarin' to nom.  Location is good in what feels like a hipster part of Mission near 16th St BART.

Uniquity: People seem to want to compare this place to Zachary's so I will too.  Slightly better than Zachary's in my opinion.  Service is a bit faster, Atmosphere is more intimate and less crowded, and the corn meal dough is something I've never experienced before or since.  Oh, if I remember correctly the plates are served warm too.  And you pretty much have to eat the pizza with a knife and fork.  Finally, the fact of a full bar in the lounge is both awesome and a smart move on their part.
author: Robert R.

description: We found the place and initially thought it was closed because the door was covered.  Then someone opened the door and we realized that it was open.  We ordered a deep dish pizza, a salad, and some beer.  I will have to say that I was really full right after and the food and beer was great.  I would definitely recommend this place to everyone!
author: Shad B.

description:
OVER RATED

The wings are lousy and the restaurant is weird and uncomfortable. The pizza is pretty good, but nothing to write home about. Ironically I'm Yelping it. Other than Zachary's (not in SF) there is no place to get a stuffed pizza. I think that's why people rave about this place.  It's like if you went to school and everyone was ugly, you would try to hook up with the best looking ugly girl. But if you went to a normal school where you had more options, never in a million years would you hook up with that same chick. That's what little star is, it's the best stuffed pizza place in the city that doesn't have another option for stuffed pizza.... at least that i know of.
author: Chris P.

description:
We ordered two pizzas, one thin (half chicken pesto and half chicken some) and one deep dish with sausage, pepperoni, mushroom.  The think crust was just ok, but the deep dish was really good.  

Deep dish is my favorite type of pizza and second is the thin crust (Brooklyn style).  I've been to Uno's and Gina's? in Chicago, and Zachary's in Berkeley.  It's been a while since I've been to each one, so I can't really compare, but I have no complaints and would come back again.   Now, I just need to find a good deep dish pizza place in the San Jose area.
author: J T.

description:
Oh holy for-the-love-of-pizza this place is without a doubt, the best pizza place ever!  I probably shouldn't have made that comment because more of you will now come to Little Star Pizza and I'll never get a table.  LOL!

Friends of mine and I have a standing tradition of choosing a pizza and beer joint for one Friday a month.  We experienced Little Star Pizza as the recent venue and now I'm stuck in a rut, as I can't find a better pizza restaurant.  I guess we'll have to go back to experiencing the dive restaurants for a bit.

Be prepared to stand in line for about an hour if you decide to dine around peak dinner time.  I like to go a little bit earlier, so as assuage my hunger and craving as soon as possible.  The deep dish styled Classic, adding pepperoni, is my favorite.  Their wine list is fine and they have a nice selection of beers on tap, as well.  

Be sure to save room for their heavenly cheese cake.  Yes, the fine chefs at Little Star Pizza have managed to ruin my hopes of ever finding a better cheese cake, as well.  You'll receive a very healthy portion, fit for sharing with a friend.

Congrats to the fine folks at Little Star Pizza on an award worthy recipe and fun dining experience.  Best of luck to you on great successes.
author: Kenny V.

description:
Thankfully, I have a mellow boyfriend. When asked where he wanted to go for his birthday dinner, we contemplated pizza. He mentioned Little Star Pizza. I was a bit worried. Here I was, supposed to treat the guy I like to a nice birthday dinner. And I was going to take him to a pizza place? I envisioned your typical pizzeria, with some teenage girl schlepping pizza-by-the-slice into a oven for reheating, only to shout out, "SUPER VEGGIE!" when its ready. 

I was wrong.

Little Star was bustling and busy and had a waiting list. As if it were meant for us, a table of two was available, and we cozied on in. The place was packed and loud-- not ideal for a romantic dinner, but we were more about each other and the food, anyway.

The two of us settled on a bottle of wine and garlic bread, which is served with a bulb of garlic. We both knew we wanted deep-dish pizza (the menu is split into thin and thick crust pizzas) but eyed a particular pizza on the thin crust list. Our waitress warned us against making a thin crust pizza deep-dish, so we settled on the Little Star pizza, complete with spinach, feta, mushrooms, garlic and onions. The service was surprisingly quick, despite the business. 

The pizza was delicious-- the perfect blend. We ordered the larger size, hoping that we would want to take a chunk home, which we did. While it wasn't a quiet dinner, my boyfriend was happy-- and I won some points.
author: Bryan B.

description: Excellent pizza, lovely relaxing atmosphere and a cute venue.  Adult and kid friendly, although a perfect date place with no pressure.  A brief 15 minute wait was fine as the waiting area is in the bar and has a comfy sofa.  The staff was friendly and prompt.  We had a cabrese salad and garlic bread to start.  Yum!  Garlic bread was fresh sourdough with roasted garlic and butter on the side - Mmm!  Large deep dish pizza with cornmeal crust was fabulous. We split meat and Little Star veggie - both sides were delicious!  Slightly off the beaten path of 16th St "restaurant row" in the Mission, and well worth it!!!
author: Tania S.

description:
This place has the best Chicago-Style (Cornmeal-Crust) pizza I've had west of Chi-city. Wonderful, hulking massive pies worth their weight in something very shiny!

/throws mic on the floor and walks away
author: Wil E.

description:
Hands down, no question, ZACHARY'S WINS!

I really wanted to give them 2 stars but think that in all honesty they deserve 3 because it's ok, but I've also experienced much better.

Tried it because its closer to home, but the entire time I was eating I kept fantasizing about eating at Zachary's instead. Their crust is superior but more importantly their tomato sauce has much more flavor and tastes more like what I had in Chicago.

It was just a bit disappointing, but I can certainly appreciate that some folks prefer this to Zachary's. Isn't that what makes the world go 'round?
author: Abby Z.

description: Normally if my pizza won't fold in half and a pile of grease drips off it, i don't want it. But, Little Star ranks #1 in my book for deep dish deliciousness. Even reheated on day #2 is out of this world! The Little Star classic is my favorite.
author: Danielle D.

description:
I came to this place with a friend one evening for some pizza. I had to try this one out because I went to the Little Star on Divisadero and knew it was awesome. When we first got there it was a Friday night so there was about a 45 minute wait. This 45 minutes turned in an hour and a half.  Strike one. The hostess kept letting people in that had just waited about 15 minutes. She had said that people had called up for reservations but when I called 4 hours earlier she had said they don't take reservations.

Our time finally came and we were shown to our seats where we ordered. My friend and I were into our salad and out the corner of my eye I see something scurrying across the back of the wooden bench my friend was sitting at. I don't know perhaps my eyes were playing tricks on me. After all, it was finals time I was staying up doing projects for school and not eating. I motioned to my friend to have a look and he nearly came out of his seat. It was an insect of some sort. I thought it was a roach. I was a little scared because it kept staring at me. My friend told the waiter in a hushed manner not to alert the rest of the patrons to insight a riot. Our pizza came.  Strike 2. The waiter assured us it was from construction they were doing outside and it stirred up a lot of things. Gotten up and walked out right? What would you have done? Ya we stayed there and took our first bite into the pizza and instantly forgot about the insect we had seen a little bit ago.

It was beautifully done with excellent amounts of cheese, meat, bread. The moment I was finished with 1 slice it was enough for me. Aside from the insect invasion this place is great. Keep your eyes open!
author: ryan n.

description: Noisy and pretty small, so expect to wait about a half hour for a table alongside the small bar at the front of the restaurant.  The atmosphere resembles a chaotic movie infused with alternative music and punctuated by all black scenery.  Service is very slow, but the food is worth the wait.  The salads are very fresh and the pizza (both deep dish and thin crust) are excellent.  The large, thin crust pizza suits two hungry people.  A popular spot in the Mission that would benefit from more table space and less sassy waiters.
author: Lynn S.

description: Heard about this place from a few people and finally went in for some Deep Dish.  I ordered their sausage  deep dish and we also got a Chicken pesto thin crust.. Racer 5 on tap, hell yea.... The tight fit of the place leaves you sitting so close to others you'd think they came in with you and you just forgot who they are.  Sauce on the top was a nice touch, which leaves the crust nice and crispy and not soggy.
author: momo m.

description: Eaten here multiple times and it's always a favorite. Our favorites are the Classic deep dish and spicy wings. Flavors are great and the crust is superb. The wings are delicious; seasoned well and not too greasy. We prefer this place a lot better than Zachary's. :-)
author: MishEddie G.

description: I didn't like the pizza. It could be because I am Italian and used to a completely different style. Also, the place is a little too dark.
author: Luca R.

description:
Bad service, okay pizza.  But if I want crappy service I'll go across the st to Arinell and have some great pizza to show for it.

I will not go back.
author: Nikki S.

description:
Based on the large number of favorable reviews here perhaps I'd have been less disappointed had we ordered the deep dish as opposed to the thin crust, but the latter is always my preference, and it bordered on bad at Little Star.

Considering the crust, it wasn't thin as much as it wasn't deep dish. Its greater fault, though, was that it was tough -- a uniform toughness from one end to the other which made it a textural bore. Chewing on dense crust provides no reward that I can think of. Crust should yield a bit in places to the teeth and any post pizza ingestion mouth trauma should result from a combination of food temperature and hunger-induced impatience, not hard, sharp edges.

It was a bit like pizza on bread that had been frozen for a long time, then partly thawed and toasted. 

As for that equally important flavor, when it came time to divvy up our two leftover slices -- one each of the White Pie (mozzarella, tomatoes, feta, zucchini and olive oil) and the special pizza of the day -- topped with asparagus and carmelized onion -- my friend asked me first which slice I wanted to take home. I thought about it for a second and realized it didn't matter because they tasted nearly identical. Why? Too much cheese and a major over dousing with the dry herbs. Didn't even know there was zucchini on the White Pie 'til I re-read the ingredient list posted on the restaurant's website menu. Nor could I gather that the onions had been carmelized.

So unfortunate when cooking methods are employed and seasonal ingredients are used yet fail to present. I was tempted to make a dash back across the Bay for a slice of Gioia's asparagus, spring onion and ricotta pizza where each ingredient strikes a shining note on your palette. 

Two stars for the pizza.

The generously sized mixed green salad with walnuts, feta, chopped bell pepper and ripe, red tomato wedges was the highlight of our meal. 

The service was attentive from the time we walked in and were greeted at the bar and seated soon afterward, although our waiter had an oddly contrived tableside manner. When I left my fork on the salad plate which he was preparing to whisk away, he had this to SAY, more than ASK :

"Do you want to keep that silverware I think you just might"

I indulged his obvious concern for my dining preparedness and retrieved the fork from the plate and, per my usual preference, proceeded to eat the pizza with my hands.
author: Michelle M.

description: I really like the pizza here. My friends and I dropped by on Sunday, and we shared the deep dish classic pizza. Even though I don't have pizza that often, I don't think this was your regular deep dish pizza in that the crust was not particularly thick. The thickness is primarily caused by the amount of tomatoes that they put into the pizza, which is probably better for you anyways. I think the amount of cheese and meat was reasonable, although other people at our table would have preferred more. The crust was pretty amazing. The large pizza was a little over 20$, and three of us shared it.  Overall a nice place to eat if you are in the area. The service is a little bit slow, but on a weekend, most people aren't in a hurry anyways.
author: Steph G.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Chicken artichoke deep dish= Toppings tasted fresh, the marinara was put on top so it was saucier, the chicken was a little dry


SERVICE:
Pretty nice workers, our server was kinda rushing us to order tho

ATMOSPHERE:
Nice contemporary date atmosphere
author: Angela L.

description: Have loved this place for years. It's worth the wait. Salads are yummy and I even like the deep dish pizzas (am normally a thin crust girl). Parking is a pain but what isn't on that side of town.
author: Jill M.

description: A bit of a wait but totally worth it. We got lucky and sat at the bar. Bartender was helpful with suggestions and awesome. We got the wings and the special for the night which was a deep dish with chicken, BBQ sauce and apple slices. It was a perfect combination. I only wish they had one in LA.
author: Sandra S.

description:
I went here tonight after reading these reviews on the pizza and I have to admit that this pizza is absolutely awesome. The thin crust pizza was quite great. 

Parking in this area is actually a lot easier than it is in other parts of the Mission, so you can usually find someplace to park. It's still pretty crowded in there on Sundays so try to get in before the peak times.
author: Eston B.

description:
I enjoy the ambiance of this place.  Before going into this restaurant, I imagined it to be a hole in the wall.  But it was the exact opposite.  It had a chic feel to it.

We had one pizza for two with the special little star toppings along with the pesto chicken.  Frankly I couldn't taste the difference between the two toppings.  Both were very rich in tomato sauce...maybe too rich.

While we ate there on a Sunday, there was still an immense line from 6-8.  From the time we sat down to the time we finished our pizza, there was still a line waiting to get seated.  Brace yourself.

Overall I'd go visit this pizza place again.

Edit: 3/10/08
I think the pizza here is really good!  But just make sure to skip the appetizers and go straight to the pizza.  Otherwise you may be too full to enjoy the main course.

We made the mistake here (2nd time for me) of ordering garlic bread and a salad before the large pizza.  By the end of the night, we just finished two slices.  But the take-home experience was great!
author: Alan T.

description:
This was the first stop on our Pizza Crawl - Mission edition.  It was also the winner (though not difinitively).

I have only had their deep dish in the past but the thin crust was delicious.  The service was friendly and fun.  The crust, sauce, and cheese were great and in perfect proportion.  Some in our party wished that it had been more than the sum of its parts... but the parts were damn good.
author: Linda L.

description: I only went once and it was with a friend.  We ordered a Large Mediterranean Chicken pizza and it was ok.  I personally dont like artichoke hearts and onions and things like that but I still ate and enjoyed the pizza which is why Ive give it an extra star up to 4.  I'd like to go back and add toppings I like and see if its any better.
author: Sam S.

description:
great pizza!!! but the service is not good. i was there with 3 friends and the waitress just brought the food put theme on table and left.... disgusting... not sorry we even bought expensive bottle of wine that we have to place it on floor.i asked for deep she brought the different pizza. they are really good to treat you like stupids.
ps: they are late night dinner but get ready they will trough you out of there as soon as you blink your eyes.
author: B H.

description:
The best deep dish pizza this side of Chicago.

Yes, this is better than the famed Zachary's in the East Bay.

No, this is not better than Lou Malnati's in Chicago (The best pizza that I've ever laid my lips upon).

Yes, it is worth the wait for a table.

No, they're not open for lunch.

Yes, you have to try their thin crust, which is just as delicious.

No, this is not your typical pizza joint (the lights are dim, the ambience is classy).

Yes, it's that good.

No, I'm not exaggerating.

Yes, I'm giving this place 5 not-so-Little Stars.
author: Raymond R.

description:
I am the only person in Mission who doesn't like Little Star.  The restaurant feels like it was converted from a realtor's office, and they play such cliched hipster music from the 90's that I want to go running out the door - but I can't since this is the place where everyone hosts their birthday party.
 
As for the food, I guess it's great if you like Chicago-style pizza.  But for me, I'm just not impressed.  On a positive note, the wait staff are really nice.
author: ML P.

description:
I've given this place two tries now, and it was not worth the money either time. The plain deep dish pizza has very little cheese on it, so it's mostly tomato and crust. The Little Star, which includes spinach, feta, garlic, onion, etc., was exactly as mediocre as the plain.

I guess this place is great if you don't like any cheese on your pizza. But I've had better at Uno! Way overpriced for an overall unsatisfying pizza.

(This review is for take-out ordering. The establishment itself looks pretty classy. But I still wouldn't order the pizza.)
author: Karl N.

description: too much affectation for a place that prides itself on chicago style pizza. not enough of the key ingredients - warmth, heart, and friendliness. the food is exceptional, but the service is atrocious. order for take out.
author: KC G.

description:
I'm from the Midwest with relatives who live in Chicago, so as a kid, I'd end up in Chicago several times a year. Then, I married a woman whose parents lived in downtown Chicago. This interlude about my life is to demonstrate that I know Chicago-style deep dish pizza.

Little Star does not disappoint. The deep dish pizza we had was solid. Fresh ingredients with just enough tomato and cheese to hold it all together served up on a flaky yet no greasy crust. Service was spot on and friendly. And they get bonus points for letting me wheel in my daughter in her stroller while she was passed out from her nap.

P.S. Some of my born and bred Chicago friends may say this place isn't authentic enough, but c'mon. It's tasty pizza and we're 2,000 miles away. Get over it.
author: Tony H.

description:
Ok, Ok...

So, yes, everyone in a while you come across a pizza joint that you have to tell everyone about, and I think I will tell a lot of people about this place....BUT... I will also have to mention my favorite at the same time, and unfortunately for those of you scared to venture to Berkeley or Oakland, you'll be missing out on Zachary's Chicago Pizza. Yet, I digress; this review shall be about Little Start.

The menu is pretty simple. Appetizers/salads, this crust pizza's, and deep dish pizzas are your choice. My boys, and I were super hungry so we ordered the Little Star (added chicken) and the White Pie. Both were great. The white pie served great as a tasty thin crust warm up pizza to the deep, tomato laden deep dish. The crust on the deep dish was particularly good/interesting. It was like a crispy cornbread crust...and I luuuuuuuuv me some cornbread.

All in all, a good meal. It's just that nothing (for me) compares to Zach's.

Enjoy.
author: Reza A.

description:
Big fan of their thin crust, chicken wings. Young noisy crowd, but a lot of eye candy around. Good beer and wine selection.

FYI, take out is never as good as dining in.
author: Pandora B.

description: best deep dish pizza! I thought Little Star was better than the deep dish pizza I had in Chicago.
author: Jeff Y.

description:
Came here twice...first time was with a vegetarian group, 2nd time with meat-eaters(yay!)...both times there was a wait, about 30minutes, worth the wait though....the place had a fun vibe to it..and it didn't hurt that it smelled good as well...you can actuallly smell it's goodness a block away!! a friendly staff..our server was quite attentive(both times!!)  love both there veg and meat deep-dish pizza....i love deep-dish...sooo gooey filled with cheese and an assortment of meat/veg!!  and their bbq chicken wings were soooo goood...i tempted to order another one...but i'm glad we didn't....we had soo much food for the 6 of us.... along with the chicken we also had the caprese salad and two large deep-dish, the chicken Mediterranean and the Classic...i personally really liked the Classic....the chicken was a tad bit dry though...but the cheese made up for it!!...  

Downside: parking was a whore! we circled and circled...granted it was dinner rush hour and everyone and their mother was trying to find a parking space!!  other than that i was completely content!  ;)
author: Tara B.

description:
nummy nummy nummy!  salad, deep-dish pizza (great dough and not too greasy) & champagne cocktails!!  
Kinda small so not great for huge groups, but they were able to accomodate my party of 8..which turned into 10.  luckily it was a rainy sunday so not a huge deal.  
just mad i didn't stop by sooner.
author: Lorena G.

description:
amazing pizza, dangerously close to my house. The new location has not yet been overwhelmed with crowds so its much better than the divis location. 

my fave is the veggie, minus zuchini (sorry, zuchini has no business on a pizza) add pepperoni. YUM. even better cold the next day.

Take out is my favorite. no wait and i get to eat in my pjs.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Best pizza currently in SF.
The mix of ingredients combined with the fantastic pizza dough make this a must see for pizza lovers.
author: Mike S.

description:
5 stars for dine-in, 1 star for take out= 3 stars

I love this pizza. The deep-dish crust is amazing, the toppings are always fresh, and it has real left-over staying power (not like Delfina, where the pizza quickly starts to fade as soon as it leaves the oven until 15 minutes after it is baked the crust is crewy and bland- yuck).

When we eat in the servers are always super nice (esp. the bigger guy w/the beard last night. Very friendly!). My only real beef with this place is that, in the 5 times we have ordered to go, they have never gotten our order right. Usually this means that I  (the meat eater) get two small pizzas and my girl (the veggie) gets none. After the third time this happened we started opening the boxes at the restaurant before we left, and we still would end up with the wrong pizzas.

Due to the time involved in baking a new one we usually just throw up our hands, take the wrong pizzas and my girl will get a falafel from Truly Med. The last time they screwed up our order the guy behind the counter remembered us, comped our pizzas and gave us another comp to use in the future- so at least they take care of you when something happens. Having said that, I wish it wouldn't happen so often....

So, um, yeah. 5 stars for dine-in, 1 (little) star for take-out.

EDIT: So they have gotten our order right for the last three take-outs, up to four stars. Hooray!
author: Jon M.

description:
My girl and I split a 1/2 special 1/2 veggie combo and it was good. It reminds me of how Zachary's in Bezerkley tasted about 15 years ago. It tastes exactly how you imagine it to taste by looking at it which I find to be impressive. The only thing is the crust tastes kinda like Bisquick(not a big deal) and also you don't get any of the oven's flavor in it. The funny thing is I actually asked if they used Bisquick thinking it would be cool if they did. I did not want to be insulting and knew it took some balls to ask, but I had to know. I was assured this was not the case. 
Some people complain that it goes cold quickly. Thin crust pizza would cool faster,right? Besides, what real pizza eater wants pizza hot out of the oven? You gotta let that shit kick it in its own thang for a minute to get the combined flavor, no?
I'll be back.
author: Boxxxman J.

description:
Best pizza ever. They excell in both thin crust and deep dish...and there is something magical about splitting a bottle of red wine (or two) over a big, spicy pizza.

They serve champagne cocktails at the bar while you wait for a table and the dining room is nice and dark.
author: carrie c.

description: Walked in on a Saturday afternoon and there was definitely no wait. Cute spot, chill ambiance, attentive service. My bf and I ordered a small half Pesto Chicken/half "Little Star" deep dish and it filled us up perfectly. 30-minute bake-time didn't seem too bad as long as you munch on an appetizer while you wait! (We had the Gemstone salad and it was pretty good but nothing special.) Loved the deep dish, along with the cornmeal crust giving it a nice crunch! Although the "Little Star" didn't have any meat, I sure didn't notice with all the savory flavors in my mouth! Will soon return to try their thin crust pizzas and spicy chicken wing app!
author: Jacqueline V.

description: I am going to say it, I was underwhelmed by Little Star.  Maybe it was the crust.  It lacked the thickness, the strong cornmeal flavor or even the proper crunch of real Chicago deep dish.  I compare all deep dish to the glory my mouth witnessed in Chi-town many years ago.  The toppings were decent as was the tomato sauce.  It just lacked.  I was also bothered by the fact that their Tempranillo is allegedly undrinkable.  Our waiter tipped me off to this, which I gave him props for, but why even have it on the menu if customers aren't supposed to have it.  Cute place, good service, but only fair deep dish.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Go for the Classic Deep Dish - Amazing crust, perfect seasoning - and heat the left overs (if you are lucky enough to have any) in a cast iron skillet in a HOT oven to preserve the crunchy texture. 

BUT, take it to go! The place doesn't take reservations, and the staff, well lets just say they have their own lives and really dont care much about the customer.
author: Jerry M.

description:
They say this is the 'other' deep dish place to go besides Zacchari's in Oakland/Berkeley/Albany.  

Yet none of their pizzas really compared.  I consider great deep dish pizza to be one that helps blows my insides out all over the toilet seat, and this didn't do it for me.  Not even a fart.

Be aware though, when you order a pizza that if it doesn't list tomato sauce, then it's going to come without it.  We ordered two or three pizzas, the thin crust being my favorite.

We did have the fortunate experience of sharing a few blue moons at the bar, which was neato.
