author: Alfred Y.

description:
i really want to give this place 5 stars because the deep dish pizza we got was SO TASTY. it was literally the best crust i have EVER had, and the sauce was also delicious. the toppings were all incredibly flavorful. the atmosphere was nice, but a little loud, and we didn't have to wait long at all.

but the four stars is because our waitress seemed a little out of it, and she got 1 of our 3 topping choices wrong (onions instead of olives). this is after getting a DIFFERENT one wrong, and us correcting her when she read it back, but not realizing that there was another wrong one in there (why didn't she read it back again?). also, when we told her about it while eating the pizza, she just said that those were the toppings she read back to us and then mumbled an apology.

anyway, we still thoroughly enjoyed the pizza even though none of us wanted onions. so i'm hoping to go back there, get a good server, and change my review to 5 stars, since clearly the pizza is TERRIFIC.
author: Sarah J.

description: sticking with the 3 stars.  went in and had a sit down lunch with friends and ordered a few other things, and left still ONLY being incredibly impressed with the deep dish classic pizza, but not so much the price of it all.
author: Melody T.

description:
i really should have reviewed this place sooner because i can hardly remember what i had there. that being said, there must not be a lot to remember about this place.

originally, 2 friends and i wanted to go to tartine but they were out of sandwiches and the line was still out the door. so we went to little star and ordered the garlic bread and mediterranean chicken pizza (or something like that). the garlic bread was good .. it came with warm bread and a oven roasted bulb of garlic to spread. the pizza.. im sure it was alright. but i don't remember it well.
author: L M.

description:
This is my favorite chicago-style pizzeria in the bay area.  I prefer Little Star over Patxi's(which is more traditional) and Zachary's(which doesn't have as flaky of a crust).  I took my friend who lived in a chicago, and he says that although he still prefers Lou Malnati's in Chicago, Little Star is very comparable. 

I love the buttery crust, and how the toppings always taste really fresh and juicy.  If it's your first time, I recommend getting the Little Star pizza on the menu, and don't even bother ordering the thin crust pizzas.  And if you don't get there early, be prepared to wait a while just to get seated, and then wait again for your pizza to get cooked.  Fortunately, they have a decent selection of beers and wines to keep you occupied in the meantime.
author: David W.

description:
Hurray for Little 5-Star Pizza!

Everything here, the food, drinks, ambiance raises the star-bar for any other place that's worthy in the city...without breaking your bank. One small deep dish pizza plus salad was enough to feed my party of 3 guys and a girl, which was surprisingly economical for such a quality meal. 

If you like champagne cocktail drinks, they serve them in PINTS, so guys, even if you're feeling a little girly ordering a champagne and chambord special, you can still raise your glass with the beers and not feel ashamed you're enjoying a delicious pink drink.

Little Star Pizza also works in conjunction with any dating scenario:

If you really like your date and hope to get some:  Take them here, followed by a show at the Independent down the street.

If you like your date but are entering the friend zone: Take them here, split the bill, and call your buddies to meet you at the show.

If you like your date only because you think you'll get some: Take them here, skip the pizza and focus on the champagne cocktails. Skip the show.

If you don't like your date but are too nice to say so: Walk by here, mention "maybe next time" and proceed to Jake's Steaks across the street. Tell him/her the show is sold out.

If you want your date to run screaming from you: Don't be seen here. Pick up a few 40s at the local corner store and take a walk through the neighborhood, down Turk.
author: Kelly R.

description: Quality ingredients and plenty of it.  May be rated great in other cities, but in competitive SF, I am giving it A-Ok.
author: Laurence H.

description:
This is not pizza for mere mortals.  
It's a slice of heaven with tomato sauce and cheese on top!
author: Tabatha Y.

description:
HOOOOOLLLYY CCRRAAAP!!!!

ZACHARY'S??? Zachary WHO???  You will NEVER EVER go to that "funk of a crust" pizzaria again!  Little star pizza is amazing!  The crust itself is what keeps me coming back.  Buttery, salty, crunchy goodness is what it is!  The toppings are even better...super fresh and always a good mix with the preset choices.  Salads are just as good.  God just talking about it makes me want to go!  
Only sucky thing is that they dont take reservations and the wait can be long.  They have a small wine bar that literally only sits 5.  who cares....ITS WORTH THE WAIT!
author: Tammy H.

description:
Coming from Illinois, I have very high standards for Chicago style pizza.  Little Star does it quite well, and whenever I get a craving for deep dish, I come here.  I love the cornmeal crust and the sweet tomato sauce! 

Service:   I wish the wait wasn't quite so long for a table (it's a small little restaurant), but I'm perfectly willing to wait if I have to.   My latest experience was at a birthday party with my friends, and I have to say that the servers were especially nice when they had every reason in the world to be annoyed with us.  We showed up with a huge crowd (which is really annoying for a small restaurant), the number of seats we needed kept changing, we couldn't decide what to order, and we were generally annoying.  But, they were awesome and accommodating, and treated us really well.  They are seriously rock stars.
author: Jane A.

description:
I'm only giving it two stars because the pizza itself is amazing.
The service sucked. if you sit at the bar they won't let you take a table. The beer is only sold in bottles and over priced.
Decor needs work. It felt dead.
On the bright side, the deep dish little star (ricotta mozzarella, spinach, onion and garlic) was amazing the lightest deep dish pizza I've ever had.
I'm willing to give it another try on a week night when it's not so busy. 
We'll see how I feel then....
P.S. It cash only. Just another annoyance. I'm so sick of that. I have to stop now because I could rant about that for a long time. stop.
author: Rory V.

description:
Little Star Pizza is the most flavorful deep dish I've had in a while. We had a Classic with no sausages and with garlic (friend's boyfriend's request, not mine) and it was pretty good - very heavy on the tomato flavor. I would mostly taste the chunky tomato flavor (each pizza basically looks like a sea of red) and then the pepperoni, mushrooms, etc. under the tomatoes, as opposed to most deep dish pizza places that will put the toppings above the tomatoes. It makes for a very interesting and fresh flavor nonetheless; I also had the vegetarian and the spinach went very well with the tomato. Overall, pretty good shot.

Orders take a while though - we were smart and went around 6:30 on a Friday night, so we got a table after waiting ten minutes or so, but even then the waitress advised us that our order would take about 25-30 minutes to finish and it did. So bring some people who you like to talk with. Bring loud talkers too - it's very loud in there. Also kind of dark (I'm not as partial to the places that consider a candle at the table sufficient light, as Little Star is). And as we left at 8... you could tell the crowd of people next to the door was going to be there for a while.
author: Justin L.

description:
In the known universe there are three types of pizza. Rudy's in Lawrence Kansas, Little Star, and everything else. Yeah, you read that right, fuck YOU New York.

Little Star's deep dish pizza will reach up to you on it's cornbread crust as you reach down to it. You will take a bite out of it, and it will nibble at your soul. You won't mind, I mean what's a little bit of soul? Right? Five minutes later, a surprisingly not so greasy pan will be starring up at you with contempt, and your fat gut, already slipping under the tight wings of that corset, will jiggle just a little more and ooze out  just a little further. Trust me on this, you won't care.

Come early. My limo driver brings me, but you may want to take public transportation with the other plebes and avoid that wonderful Mission parking. Don't go to the other one, you'll never get into that place without killing a local who got there before you and assuming his/her form.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Yuuuuhahummmm!!
I love this place- juke box and low lights brings back memories of  going to Shakey's Pizza post-soccer game when I was little. 
I love that Little Star's garlic bread comes with a basket of warm, crusty bread, an entire bulb of roasted garlic, and a little tub of butter- make-your-own-fresh garlic bread!
The pizza was amazing, but I can't say too much about it because between my husband and me, it was gone in a flash.  Extra points for super friendly service and frequent water refills.  I'll definitely be back soon.
author: Elena W.

description:
I don't usually eat pizza, but Little Star opened a block away, and is now the closest restaurant to my house. The waitress was helpful in telling us we could get half/half pizzas (I can't eat the moz but my date doesn't want to do without). The salad was big, delicious, and easy to share, the pizza was pretty tasty, and I liked the beer choices.

We did have to wait a bit for our food and this place is LOUD. Hard to hear your companion from across the tiny table loud. Another star off because the table we were given put me directly over a giant gaping crack in the booth seat along the wall, and when we moved over to avoid that, the track lighting was aimed directly into my left pupil. There wasn't any art on the wall behind me, so I guess this is just a special migraine inducing bonus.
author: Gus J.

description:
I FRICKEN love this place.  The Pizza is simply delicious.  The atmosphere is cozy and warm, and is a great place for a first date. Fellas do your self a favor and follow theses steps.

1. Start with some drinks to ease the first date jitters.  
2. Order the mixed Greens salad for starters. 
3. For the main course order the " The Little Star " 

Trust me it works. Follow these 3 step and your guaranteed breakfast in the morning.  I know from experience.  The cute young lady I took there is now my girlfriend.

ENJOY
author: Robert M.

description:
I love how my friend's kept telling me I'm gonna love "Little Star" knowing eating pizza is not my first or second choice.  But, I heard a lot of great reviews from my friends about this place, so I was expecting to be disappointed and get ready to catch grief by posting an "the pizza is just aight" review.

The thing that I want people to remember for my review about the pizza at this place is this: eating the rosemary/garlic crust is like eating an "I can't stop eating this snack" that's topped with goodness!  It's like eating a fried banana and topped with ice cream!
author: Don B.

description:
My best friend took me here last night. It was so good, I couldn't believe it. He definitely didn't undersell the place. 

We had their Italian with pepperoni and salami on half and the pesto chicken on the other. It was insanely good and reasonable too.
author: Tom D.

description:
The two stars are for the noise in the restaurant.  O-M-G!  My husband ran the decibel measuring program on his iPhone (yea, there's an app for that).  

I looked it up....110 Decibels = Regular exposure of more than 1 minute risks permanent hearing loss.  It was a pretty steady 110 decibels in there.  

The pizza was good though.  Had the thin crust with green peppers, olives and mushrooms.  Nice and crispy.  Will order again - but this time for take-out.
author: Bobbi C.

description:
I can't believe I'm going to use this adjective (or re-creation of an adjective!) to describe Little Star, but the only thing I can think of is FABULOSO! 

Yum, yum, and more yum! Seriously, the garlic bread and deep dish pizza they served us, were totally worth the wait and anticipation I've had for months in going to this place. The garlic bread was super fresh, they actually give you a well cooked side of garlic to spread at your discretion. And the pizza, the small vegetarian pizza I split with my friend, was so delicious, filling but not oozing with grease. Since we shared, it only cost me $8.50 and I left full, happy and not broke =)

If you're like me and like deep dish Chicago style pizza, Little Star will not disappoint.
author: Swetha G.

description:
We came here with some friends a week ago for the first time. We thought we would have to wait forever, but we came in and were promptly seated. The atmosphere was nice: dark, loud, and meant for lots of noise making conversation! 

We ordered a large pizza to split between the 5 of us, and so as not to be fair (I'm pregnant), I ordered a salad so I didn't hog the pizza. We ordered the vegetarian. The pizza was fantastic-- rivaling my personal fave: Zachary's. 

They had a good selection of alternative label beers and even sodas. I had the ginger beer and it was crazy delicious-- I'm trying to find some in the stores! 

We will definitely be back to sample some of the different pizzas! I can't wait!
author: Lindsey A.

description:
Decided to hit some of the restaurants on Valencia Street, use to be a SF girl. Wow how it has changed. Came upon Little Star Pizza, was in the mood and decided to give it a go. Boy did I love it. 

Ordered the Mediterranean Deep Dish Pizza. Chicken, Artichoke Hearts, and green olives. It was killer. The perfect combination. The crust is so good. My husband and I ordered the large as there are only two sizes small or large. I have three slices left and yes that will be lunch tomorrow. 

Can't wait to come back and try something else. 

Parking was hard, as it is street parking. But if you don't mind walking, its all good.  Restaurant was loud, but not a problem. I enjoyed the food and ambiance.
author: Cindy M.

description:
Little Star has a deep dish pizza that somehow holds a ridiculous amount of sauce, cheese, and toppings all within a crispy-to-perfection thick crust.

Our server put it best in saying that he actually enjoys serving here--serving at other places is like dropping plates off at tables and running off for fear of whatever bad comments might come your way about the food.

"Little Star is one of those places that makes you feel good about being a server, because the responses are ALWAYS good."

Not a lot of seating so you'll end up with a long wait time, especially if your whole group isn't all there at the same time, but you can relax at the small bar at the front while waiting. No draft beers, but an otherwise fine selection.

Oh yeah--Cash only. BUT. The ATM there only charges you TWENTY FIVE CENTS. I didn't know what to think when I saw that. Was I in some kind of strange, parallel universe, where "getting my own money" didnt require  a couple beers' worth of fees????

If 25 cents is too much in exchange for such killer pizza, you might be in the wrong city.
author: Kyle S.

description:
I'm an ex-pat Chicagoan, and I have one word for Little Star...

Fail.

I've had many-a-pizza in Chicago, and I know my pizza.  For one, LS pizza is about half the thickness of the real thing.  Not nearly enough cheese or sauce.  Then the crust was wrong -- it had more of a consistency of cornbread than wheat bread -- because they actually use cornmeal to make it.  Epic megafail.

My pizza was ready on time when I came to pick it up....that's probably the one nice thing I have to say about Little Star.

Go to Oakland to get Zachary's (http://www.yelp.com/biz/zacharys-chicago-pizza-oakland) for real Chicago pizza.  And if you can't be bothered at least go to Patxi (http://www.yelp.com/biz/patxis-chicago-pizza-san-francisco) -- they do a reasonable approximation without San Franciscanizing the pizza with corn.
author: Eugene F.

description:
Came here after a day in The City tired and hungry. We opted to not wait for a table and just hung out at the bar. My GF ordered a glass of wine, but i passed because i had been drinking beer most of the day and was just tired of feeling slightly buzzed for an entire afternoon. 

We started out with some garlic bread. I dig that it comes with a roasted head of garlic, but trying to get that garlic onto the bread can be a bit messy and a real hassle. Big props for sending it with half melted, easily spreadable butter though.

We then split the deep dish vegetarian pizza, which was awesome. The crust was crispy enough to have some crunch, but was also light and flaky. Naturally, we took half of it home with us to eat later. It made fantastic leftovers. 

Didn't get a chance to try the thin crust, but i guess that just means we'll have to come back. And i'm okay with that.
author: Travis D.

description:
deep. dish. pizza. 

i went in a group of 4 and we ordered:
- garlic bread (a MUST-try)
-  goddess salad (which i LOVED and i'm not even big on salad)
- and for pizza, we ordered "little star" -- simple, meatless, but delicious nonetheless

everything was so fresh and didn't leave you feeling disgustingly full. i definitely plan to go back for another tasting.. especially for that cornmeal crust. 

when compared to zachary's, i'd say the overall quality of the pizza about evens out; what each pizza has, the other lacks-- zachary's tomato chunks/sauce is way more zesty/flavorful, but little star's crust is just so buttery and light. 

4 stars for you, little star. i'm definitely a fan.
author: Muzna N.

description:
UPDATE: October 2007. So I took a bunch of friends visiting from NY and even they were impressed at "California" pizza. And, guess what? They brought in the champagne cocktails to this location! Of course, I had one and it was delish. I look forward to more CC in my future at LS!


Same unbelievable deep dish and (ok it's not NY and it's not Delfina's but it's still quite good) thin crust... BUT no Champagne cocktails??  What gives, man?  Don't deprive the Mission!  I take off a star for that...

Otherwise, all the things that make LS great are still in place:  delicious red sauce, fresh ingredients, sweet deep dish crust with just the right amount of cornmeal crackle balanced with chewy mouthfeel.  I think my only complaint the last time I was there is that I got chicken in my deep dish and I couldn't tell the difference between the vegetarian one-- need some slightly bigger chunks, if you please.  Salads are fresh and refreshing; wings are fatty, fried and succulent.  It's like healthy junk food... or something like that.

Looks like lower Valencia street is gentrifying far cry from the days of me checking in suckers at Gold's Gym across the street from the projects and two doors down from the Lucky Lady Candle Shop.

I have nothing against a little ship-shape in the Mission as long as it piques my palatte, ole skool residents are not pushed out and most importantly, VISITORS take taxis or a bus to our 'hood and not my parking!

Little Star is DIVINE!
author: E L.

description:
My Dearest Pauline's, 

Thank you for the wonderful years we shared together. You were the best. Always there for me with a warm, hearty, doughy hug when I needed it. You totally got along with my friends. They loved you! We sure had some times, didn't we?

Things have changed. I've...I've met someone else. My new favorite. Someone who understands what I need at this point in my life. Sometimes I need thin crust and sometimes I need deep dish. I always need delicious. And the service. Don't even get me started about prompt, friendly, unintrusive service. No, no, your service is great too. I said not to get me started. I knew you would get defensive. See, this is the problem. 

Look, I am in love with Little Star Pizza. I won't apologize for it. I will only say goodbye. You will always have a special place in my heart (and I'll definitely always come eat upstairs when I'm having a big pizza party!). 

Love and pizza, 
David
author: David C.

description:
Last night the weather sucked, and I didn't feel like cooking.  Not unlike many winter nights in San Francisco.  So I managed to "convince" a coworker to trek out to the Mission and grab a deep dish pizza with me.  What's super great about this is that my coworker actually HATES tomatoes but was still totally psyched about getting a large deep dish classic pizza.

Hooray!  I love deep dish pizza.  And while, it's definitely  not like the ones I've had in Chicago, it's still a nice treat.
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
When I last came here with a friend...our seats were so close to another couple that there was actually this weird awkward conversation about how close we were to each other. The guy next to me started trying to compliment us on our pizza and our ability to look like a nice couple (and we're just friends)...
Good thing I'm a people person...didn't bother me much and now my friend and I joke about his comment.

Luckily, the tomatoes were well worth the wait. I love the cornmeal on the crust...the extra texture on the Chicago-Style pizza makes it very San Francisco. Obviously their own spin on an old favorite - but they do it well...every time. 
You can't go wrong with your order there - although...their specialty is deep dish for a reason. Stick with what they are famous for and you'll never be let down.
author: Katy A.

description: Best deep dish pizza and probably my favorite pizza in SF next to Golden Boy. In my opinion I think that little star even has zach's in Berkeley beat. Delicious!
author: Amanda M.

description: I have yet to try the thin crust but the deep dish here is bomb.com  this crust was uber crisp and corn meally and adds a whole new level of excitement to littlestars awesome sauce and variety of fresh toppings... for a person who generally hates deep dish pizzas I was thoroughly impressed and am excited to come back  soon! Very fair prices and takeout is available as well- get there early cuz ain't no reservations round hurrr
author: Bobby P.

description:
Aside from the pizza, this place is just really cool. It almost feels like you're in a trendy lounge/bar, and it's also very inconspicuous from the street.  only a small little sign with a star and the words "little star pizza" in small size font would give it away that this place serves AWESOME pizzas.  I've come here before and had their signature deep-dish pizzas, which is all fine and dandy.  But realizing chicago style saucy pizzas aren't for me, I opted for the thin crust pizzas. Which are equally good as well.  I ordered the buffalo wings (not thattt great - but will do), and they're house salad large - it was enormous.  Could feed about 4 people.  It had gorgonzola, balsamic onions, all in all, very good.  The thin crust pizza we orderd was the classic - bell peppers, sausage. The toppings could use some help, but it's good.  

They also have a pretty good selection of beer.  I got the oatmeal beer - which was tasty.  

Very good - pricey for pizza, but hey. you go for the whole dining experience. if you want cheap, go down the street to Arinell's pizza where there's pizza but no fancy lighting.
author: Kelly H.

description:
The pizza here is pure awesomeness. I love the cornmeal crust, my only gripe is that it's a truly heavy pizza. You want more, but you just can't stomach it! I remember it was also very hard to find parking around here, and the wait was horrible. The ambience was nice though, with its painted windows you feel like you're in the backroom of some fancy establishment. Try it out at least once. For me it's a matter of convenience, it may be a while before I venture out nearby again.

Edit:I like Patxis Chicago style pizza better, it's not as heavy, and slightly better tasting.
author: Marv G.

description:
I enjoyed Little Star Pizza.  I went here based on all the hype.  I had a beer at the bar with my friend, which was pretty good - I had the pear cider. Though I think it lacked a good amount of alcholic content, it tasted pretty good.  Also, it is not their beer, so you can't really blame Little Star for anything but serving it.

The pizza was another story.  We ordered a large deep dish Little Star Pizza.  It was amazing.  Good deep dish quality, great crust.  I was a very happy customer.
author: Joanna S.

description:
OMG, this pizza was delicious. Our server suggested we get two with our garlic bread (for a party of 3). Enough for 5 people. Wagh, cannot move right now from the fullness.  The crust was divine, the pizza was a good and thick Chicago, you get a full head of garlic for your garlic bread. *drools*

The atmosphere was ok, it's a little small so it's better to call ahead for large parties, and it was really loud. Too loud to hold a coherent conversation with my party, but that was ok. We were too busy anyway 

Minus one star for the loudness and also because it's cash only while being a bit pricey. I normally don't carry more than 40$ on me, so after a good night there, I have no cash at all. They DO have an ATM by the door, but if you're like me and don't like to incur all those extra charges from a non-bank ATM, then bring plenty of money. It was also crowded, but it was Saturday night, so it's a bit excuseable there.

But PIZZA.... yummy.
author: Regina L.

description:
Eh. That's what I say. Before Delfina Pizzeria made a pizza-lover out of me, my mantra was Pizza is Pizza and this place reminds me why. Sure, interesting crust; it's corn meal after all. Great toppings, fresh, bright, yummy. But it hits you only the way a pound of bread with a cup of melted cheese, a fist ful of sausage and a bulb of roasted garlic can; like a Mac truck.

If you absolutely love pizza, it's worth checking out but if you're over pizza, don't bother, save yourself for Delfina. If you want to hipster-the-heck out of yourself with your androgynous haircut and moody disposition over beer and pizza, this is your place. Some FINE ASS people here!
author: Mario T.

description: Little Star has the best deep dish pizza I have ever eaten. The corn meal crust is amazing and it doesn't get soggy like other deep dish pizzas I've had. The thin crust is also delicious. The toppings are fresh and the homemade cheese cake is yummy, but I ask for it without the chocolate sauce. I've never dined in because it's always so busy, but I get take out about once a month. If Little Star delivered, I'd give this place 5 stars.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I can't wait to go home and eat my leftovers from last night. Little Star deep dish pizza is sooooooo good! This place always has a wait regardless of what day of the week it is. I got here at 9:30p and didn't get seated until 10, not too bad. In the meantime my friends and I had some of their garlic bread which was not what I was expecting garlic bread to be, it was really really good though! They serve bread with butter seperately, they melt the butter so it's soooo soft and creamy. Then they serve a roasted garlic bulb on the side. So you spread the butter on top of the bread and add pieces from the garlic bulb - Great Idea!

As for the pizza, I definitely recommend the Little Star deep dish pizza, that one was delicious. We also got the Mediterranean Chicken pizza which was not as good, not as tasty as the Little Star. I really like how they pile on tons of tomatoes onto the pizza. The crust is also perfectly crispy without being too oily. This place is awesome! It's a great, low key, mission hang out spot.
author: Susan L.

description:
I RARELY give 1 stars. To be honest, the taste was good as far as the pizza was concerned. The reason 1 star: my fiance and I both got really really sick after we ate there. AND we were charged for drinks we didn't buy, and after getting a new receipt, we were charged again for appetizers we didn't order. What a mess!

We went last night for a friend's party. It was super busy as to be expected, waited about 1 1/2 hours to be seated. The waitress was quite rude- when we weren't ready to order she gave a look of disgust. 

We ordered mixed green salad. It was odd- oily leaves even though the dressing was on the side, not on the salad itself. Having oily leaves made me realize that 1) I should have asked for another, but being me and not wanting to disturb the waitress, my fiance and I ate. Our pizza was good- but then it was downhill from there.

My fiance got so sick, and I as well a few minutes after him. I think a health inspector should come in and make sure the salad's are lacking E.Coli or Salmonella.

By the way, to overcharge your customers twice in a row? Messed up!

Though I liked the pizza, I wouldn't come here again.
author: Rebecca R.

description:
this little star has a different vibe than the divis one.  maybe more hipsters?  not sure.  we come in and the wait is 45 minutes.  omg kill me now.  i hate waiting so long to eat!  so we decided to just do take out.

the take out took 25 minutes as we were told.  we ordered the special which had bacon, pepperroni, sausage, and cheddar.  but it wasnt as good as the host made it sound.  the bacon was really thinly sliced so it was hard to detect.  and unlike the other special i had, it wasnt so well balanced.  this was a salty, meat pizza.  we also had the little star which had spinach, feta, and mushrooms.  this one was pretty good.

we came back here to dine in and the host told us it would be 20 minutes which quickly turned into one hour.  i was almost angry at the wait since you sit there smelling the pizza that people are eating and here i am starving!  you can order ahead of sitting down since the pizzas take a bit of time.  salads and apps you order at the table.  we tried a salad and chicken wings.  the wings were a bit weird since they differed greatly in size.  i would eat a huge wing then a teeny tiny one.

oh and cornmeal crust WIN
author: claudia y.

description:
My friends and I went on a Friday night.  The wait was about 45 minutes.  Unfortunately, they do not take reservations nor cash.  I thought our server and the hostess were both very friendly and efficient.

Between the four of us, we ordered:

Caprese salad
Spicy Chicken Wings
Mixed Salad
Classic Deep Dish
and
we created our own deep dish of - fresh tomatoes, zucchini, mozzarella, and sausage.

Overall, we thought the food was quite tasty and would go again.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
I'd heard firsthand from a couple of friends that Little Star has excellent pizza, but then came here to read the reviews complaining about rude staff, etc., and was really nervous about taking my 3 1/2 year old daughter to eat here.  3 1/2 is an unpredictable age, and I have noticed that although my daughter tends to be pretty well-behaved in restaurants, we tend to get a lot of eye-rolling from even the kid-friendliest restaurant staff as we come through the door...

Enough about that!  We had an excellent meal here.  The waitress who helped us was great (Tuesday night, kind of early evening).  We (two adults) ordered a small salad to share, and a large half white pizza, half classic thin crust pizza.  No, we weren't taking any chances on the fuse of the small child, but I'd love to visit again and get one of the Chicago-style pizzas.  The food came out quick, and was super tasty.  The music was also great, my friend remarked that his "coolness factor" raised four points because he was eating in a restaurant that was unabashedly playing Clap Your Hands Say Yeah and Arcade Fire and I agreed.  

Turned out *I* was the only person who knocked over a cup.  My daughter was much more well-behaved than me. (The waitress didn't roll her eyes at me, but our friend did!)
author: Conchita R.

description:
Great pizza. My favorite is the thin crust chicken pesto. The freshness of their ingredients is key and even though we almost always order take out, the ambiance is nice and laid back. A small personal pizza lasts me several meals so it isn't too bad of a deal. 

Sadly, after eating here I can no longer eat Pizza Hut (But they deliver!). I think the challenge of living in a place like SF is that you come to expect a lot from even the simplest of foods.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
I'll say up front that I have a huge bias for good service - so that's most of why I'm only giving Little Star a 2 star rating.  The folks here are pretty completely detached from the customers - I can only assume that they don't want to get attached because they know you'll leave them sooner or later and this way it won't hurt as bad.  Either that, or they're just disinterested.

I'm not sure why people compare this pizza favorably to Zachary's Pizza, but I have to say that the expectation this created for me was not met.  If I'd never heard some one say "This stuff is better than Zachary's" I would have gone in with a blank slate - but once the comparison is made, it's impossible to ignore.

Don't get me wrong - it's a good pizza, but nothing to write home about, and certainly no better than Zachary's.  I will say that the wait here was much better than Zachary's, and it's a lot closer, but the food itself didn't stack up in my opinion.  I wish it had, though!

With better service, and a slightly better product, this place could be amazing - but as it stands it's just overpriced.
author: Nick T.

description:
I'm an East Coaster who has had a lot of kick ass pizza. Some time spent in the Midwest (Chicago) made me a bit of a pizza snob too. In my opinion, Little Star makes the best and the freshest pizza in the Bay Area. I like my pies thick and yummy. They never disapoint me. In fact, the Little Star is my favorite choice. Yum yum...

The sucky part is that if you don't get there when they open you're screwed. The wait is long and the bar area is tiny. Sometimes I prefer going to the one on Divis but it's crowded too. 

In any case, check this place out!
author: Shara H.

description: YUM! Definitely my favorite Chicago style pizza place in SF. I love the cornmeal crust.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
I'm lovin' this grown up version of Zachary's. Had the brass monkey, which is their signature pizza with sausage. The crust is so good, better than Zachary's by far. I'm one of those people who usually leave the crust on the plate, and at the end of the night I'll have a whole plate full of crusts and you can count how many slices I've had. Not at Little Star though, without the crust, there's no telling how much anyone's had, so we had to rock-paper-scissor for the last slice. 

Oh, and their champagne cocktails are mmmmmmm.
author: Ava C.

description: After all the great reviews was disapointed.  The pesto chicken pizza was very greasy... Dripping.  And the combo was just ok.
author: Juliana R.

description: The cornmeal crust is to die for.  We like the Little 5 Star and the meat one, with sausage.  Consistently good, fair price point for taste and quality.  Quick too.
author: Mr. J.

description: I love this place.  Abbey beer & Little Star Pizza is a perfect way to spend the night.  It's always packed so you'll have to wait....thank god for their bar & Abbey beer.  The pizza is amazing...thick & fresh.  Every time has been very satisfying.  Makes me want to go tonight.
author: Natacha M.

description: So after all the rave reviews, we decided to check this place out. First off, I liked how nice the interior of the restaurant was. It's a good palce to take a date without it being too fancy or too casual. We ordered a large  deep dish little star pizza. The best part of it was the crust.. that cornmeal buttery crunchy goodness was great. But the rest of it.. I don't know. It was good, but not great. I would have liked more sausage on it too.. I kinda feel like they skimped on it. the flavor needed a kick to it.. more tanginess or spiciness or garlic.. not sure but it was just missing something. Nizarios or Golden Boy's beats this hands down.
author: Misty M.

description:
Yes, I am busting out the 5-stars for this place. I have to do it because before eating this pie, I was a Deepdish Naysayer.

Now I say "yes" to the dish that is deep. These people know what they're doing. The tomato sauce is more tomato than sauce. The crust is crunchy with a soupcon of oil, and the filling is delightful. The caprese salad was a fantastic starter, even though I thought that tomatoes with flavor could not be found in early March. 

Go there. It is delicious, and the prices are reasonable. One starter and a small pie was plenty for two AND we had some to take home. That's good eatin.

Let me say that I was prepared to be disappointed, since when we arrived, the bar was jammed full of other hungry folks. However, we didn't reach the predicted wait time of 25 minutes, and the service was snappy and really lovely. I'm a believer!
author: Liza T.

description: The pizzas are great.  Love them.  Our problem has been the ordering for takeout.  The last two times we ordered pizzas got our orders mixed up.  One time it was the wrong size.  The second time we got two pizzas instead of three.  The worst part was that the woman who took the order remembered the details AND argued that she took it correctly.  Very frustrating.
author: Veronica P.

description: Just like being in Chicago - but without the sub-zero winters and the wind. I can't wait to go back! Aside from the pizza being awesome, the wings were very good too: a very sophisticated take on classic bar food! We ordered 2 large deep-dishes: cheese and classic. I can't wait to go back. Bon apetit!
author: Sandeep C.

description:
After seeing the restaurant reviewed on Check Please Bay Area, we decided to check it out and it did not disappoint. My experience with deep dish pizza in Chicago (Gino's, Giordano's) and authentic Chicago pizza in the bay area (Zachary's in Berkeley) has not been great. In all these places, I did like the crust, but the cheese-sauce-topping proportion was not to my liking and it just felt like a gooey mess. I prefer fluffy crust style deep dish pizza in Pizza Chicago (Palo Alto, Sunnyvale) which is much less goo-ier. 

Well, Little Star fell right in the middle of the two. The crust was fairly thin (for a deep dish) and crispy, but the cheese-sauce-toppings proportion was much better balanced. We had a mixed salad to start with. The menu described the salad as having red onions and red bells. However we only found itty-bitty pieces of these two, so it was a little disappointing, (well, maybe not that much for the onions) but the salad was decent overall. The pizza, we got a half-and-half of the Little Star and the Vegetarian with pesto as a topping (yes, just a topping, not as a sauce). The pizza was quite good. The crust is quite distinct and the sauce and toppings were nice too. For imaginative combinations of toppings, I still prefer Pizza Chicago in the south bay though.
author: Manjesh N.

description:
I have to confess, Little Star pizza shines brightly. The ingredients are fresh, the tomatoes and tomato sauce is sweet and flavorful. The crust is flaky and crisp, the flavor of corn augments the flavors of fresh ingredients nicely. 

Overall, the wait staff are very pleasant and professional. 

Price is good and for what you get this is really a good deal. 

I would give it 5 stars - but the noisy dining room can grate on my nerves a bit - If you like the noise and staged excitement that bare masonry walls simulate you will like all the din.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Apparently, I'd spend the last few dollars to my name for a small deep dish cheese pizza here (it's about $12). It's worth it. I've tried to go elsewhere for deep dish but found myself craving Little Star even more! 

Salads are good starters as well if you're trying to lighten up the pizza fare. Decent wine/beer selection. Almost always a wait and while they don't deliver, you can order for pickup.
author: Angela N.

description:
Food:
Excellent pizza, simple, delicious flavors.  I love getting the garlic bread (comes with a whole head of roasted to perfection garlic and a butter-olive oil spread).  Nice beer selection.   The best gourmet pizza I've had in San Francisco.

Service:
Friendly waitstaff - when they mess up an order, they make it right however they can.  Last night my friend and I got seated 20 minutes before closing and everyone was as nice as can be - no rushing us to get out.
author: Kat M.

description: The place to go for deep dish in SF. We had the Classic with sausage, bell peppers and onions. Very good pizza and great crust.
author: Jackson G.

description: I've never had a deep dish pizza before. I was recommended by a friend to try this place out. When we got there, no wait was needed, although that changed really fast. We ordered the deep dish little star with sausage. This was not what i expected a deep dish pizza to taste like. Maybe it was the fact that the crust was made of cornmeal? I imagined it to be more doughy. The toppings were delicious though. I'd be more inclined to come again to try the thin crust pizza instead.
author: Jason Dak W.

description: I've never had REAL deep dish pizza (unless you count BJ's) so I came here to cross that off my list (and to see what all the praise for this place was about).. Stopped by on a weekday for lunch and there was no wait (and a number of empty tables). We started off with the garlic bread. This is NOT the garlic bread you are used to getting. It's do-it-yourself with slices of bread, two roasted garlic bulbs, and butter (which had the consistency of mayo....easy to spread but a little odd). While this is a fresh way to eat garlic bread, it was bland for me. We also had a 12 inch Classic deep dish pizza. Personally, I found the crust to be too hard! I'm not sure if deep dish pizza is supposed to have a really, really crispy crust but it ruined the whole pizza for me, even if the toppings/sauce put up a noble fight to win me over. If I ever do return, it would be to try their thin crust pizza. Sadly, I guess I'm just not a deep dish pizza girl...
author: Caralisa L.

description:
Little Star serves great classic American pizza.  It's like the stuff we grew up eating - Pizza Hut, Dominoes, but waaaaay better.  If you're looking for a fancy, gourmet, true Italian pizza, you will have to go to A21 or Delphina's

We usually get the thin crust, Classico (sausage, onions, peppers) which is out of this world.  We have also tried the White pizza (vegetarian) and the Chicken Pesto.  Both are good, but Classico is our favorite.  

Pizzas run between $16 to $24 depending on the type of crust (thin or deep dish) and the size of the pie, which I believe come in 12" and 16".

You can get deep dish or thin crust  You can even get 2 flavors on a pizza (one side with one flavor and the other half another) if you and your partner have a different "favorite" pizza. 

They have a great selection of beer like Boont, IPA, Sierra Nevada and you can also get a glass of wine to go with your pie if you prefer wine.

The environment is high energy with pop/rock music playing in the background.  The NOPA location is very dark and has a bar/lounge feel.  The Mission location is quieter with exposed bricks and better lit.  If you have kids, the Mission location is more kid-friendly as it's quieter, a bit older clientel wise, and better lit.
author: Paul K.

description: It's not NY pizza nor is it meant to be.  However, their thin crust is still good for a baked, crunchy crust instead of the brick oven/kiln charcoaled crust.  This place is known for its deep dish pizza and gets a solid 4 stars.  Check out their Little Star signature pizza with spinach, ricotta, mushrooms, garlic, and onions.  It 's closer than driving to Eastbay and South Bay for good deep dish pizza.
author: Jenny L.

description: This place was just as I had anticipated, and it was excellent in sooo many ways. Although the wait time can be a bummer, there are plenty of bars in the area to pass the time. We waited for about 40 minutes. We ordered the Mediterranean Chicken deep dish. Excellent amount of toppings although the tomato sauce kinda overwhelmed the whole thing.  Couldnt find my chicken pieces. The best garlic bread Ive EVER had. Fresh garlic, none of this powdered shi&*t. Champagne cocktails rock. Hey Kool Aiddddddddd....
author: Thomas L.

description: I agree there are a lot of hipsters.. but yes the pizza is great. Ordering togo works great for days when you can't handle the crowd. Don't get me wrong, the staff has always been great - its the customers that keep me from going too often - good thing too... I am currently going to the gym to eat more ice cream... I don't need to do double time for pizza as well.
author: Angelito R.

description:
wow! great pizza..wish there was something in hawaii that is this good.

my friend and i ordered a large deep dish with sausage, mushrooms, sun-dried tomatoes, and garlic. the crust is light and buttery and has a nice light crunch to it. i like how the sauce is poured on the top of the rest of the ingredients instead of on the bottom so the crust on the bottom doesnt get soggy. the sauce itself has a nice fresh tomato flavor.

we also split an appetizer of buffalo mozzeralla and tomatoes. this also was very good and was a pretty good portion. in hindsight, this and a small pie wouldve been just right. but i'm not complaining one bit. the leftover pizza tasted great cold the next morning.
author: Mark Y.

description:
Went to Little Star last night, making my second visit in the past month or so.  I've been to Little Star four times in the past year.  I now think it's the best deep dish in the Bay Area.

My go-to pizza is the Little Star, which does not dissapoint.  What makes all the pizzas here better than Zachary's, or Patxi's even, is the cornmeal crust.  It's cornmeal, and, I'm wiling to bet, a little bit of butter.  Dee-licious.

I live about a block away from the Divisadero location, so I also have fond feelings for this business as it played a part in really transforming the Divisadero St. corridor.  They're a good neighbor.
author: Martine D.

description:
Super Bowl Sunday: HDTV, awesome weather, football, moderately entertaining commercials, Springsteen, beer and hot wings and a large brass monkey with pepperoni.

Read the reviews; the pizza here is great. They always have special Super Bowl hours (2-8p). Get the wings: they are surprisingly spicy.
author: Hiten P.

description:
Cool ambiance, nice service, and great deep dish.  It's a little pricey but will definitely leave you full.  I can't remember exactly what I got since I went a few weeks ago, but I remember it was really good.  It had spinach and some onions in it.  

Garlic bread is amazing!  Never seen a place give you actual garlic that just melts in your mouth.  

Good place to get some pizza, but still keep it sort of classy if you're trying to impress someone.
author: Isamarie P.

description:
Now listen here.  I'm from Chicago and was raised on deep dish.  Spinach stuffed and sausage were staples.  Gino's East, Giordano's, Carmen's, Pizzeria Due, etc.

I had this Little Star pizza and was blown away.  It is SO GOOD.

So good.  I think it's so good because all the ingredients are fresh.  The Chi-town spinach was always canned spinach, as I'm sure all the other ingredients were.

The service was fine, but the lighting is bad (direct lighting) and it was too bright.  When a restaurant has only ONE bathroom, it automatically gets a .5 star deduction. 

I will definitely return or get it to go. my mouth is watering right now.  i too, wonder if I will ever be able to eat other pizza in SF ever again.  sigh.
author: Christian H.

description: Awesome deep dish pizza.  The crust is the best.  I'm usually a fan of the thin crust, but if I am in the mood for deep dish, this is where it is.  A must visit Mission spot.
author: Jonathan U.

description:
To be more exact I would say a bit better than just OK but not quite "yay" material, if that makes any sense. Liked the semi-hipster feel of the place and little touches like bottled 'organic' soda (which was interesting but pretty much tasted like a flat coke)...
Ordered:
Spicy Chicken Wings- good stuff.
Garlic Bread- big ++ for the creative touch, sliced sourdough bread served with separate creamed butter and a roasted bulb of garlic, made eating fun, although the taste did not particularly stand out from your regular garlic bread 
Brass Monkey- not on the menu, but pretty much the signature "Little Star" (spinach w/ricotto + feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic) pizza with added sausage (had to satisfy the carnivore in me). ...sounded flavorful, but felt like most the ingredients flavors were drowned out by the chunky tomato sauce...the cornmeal crust, however, was exceptional...
All together a nice eating experience, however the pizza wasn't anything I'd be craving next time I'm in need of a pizza fix.
author: Mahsa K.

description:
Delicious pizza!

We split a large deep dish with artichokes and fresh basil between two, plus the warm garlic bread. It was a TON of food! We each had two slices of the pizza and took the rest home, the pizza was also great reheated (in the oven not microwave).

My only negative was the service, which seemed slow...I know pizza takes a long time to cook but the bread took forever and the girl didn't warn us it would take a while. We got lucky and didn't have a wait, I actually called ahead to make sure we could get a seat-which I would recommend doing

We'll be back!
author: Holly S.

description:
Parking in the Mission can be a pain, and the wait can be long- but I LOVE this place and plan to go back whenever I have a deep dish craving :) 

I've been to this Little Star twice. Both times, I've had to wait at least half an hour. It wasn't too bad though because there is a small bar right at the front of the restaurant and I was with great company.

What I ordered:

On my first visit, I went with my boyfriend. We ordered the spicy chicken wings and a small deep dish with sausage and mushrooms. I am a big fan of spicy wings in general, and the ones at Little Star were pretty good. The pizza was excellent - the corn-meal crust was nice and crunchy + just the right amount of tomatoes and cheese. Not overly greasy, just the way I like it.

On my second visit, I went with three other friends. We ordered one large deep dish classic pizza and one small thin crust white pie. We ordered the right amount of food, and both pizzas were great. I personally liked the deep dish better. The thin crust was good, but I'd go to Tommaso or Delfina if I didn't want deep dish.
author: Arisa A.

description:
I don't know what to say...

Even though you might think you don't like deep dish pizza (not quite Chigago-style, which I'm not a fan of) you will probably love Little Star. They have a cornmeal crust which sounds funny but its freaking delicious. A single slice of the large would classify as a perfect knife & fork meal.

P.S. I'm a total thin-crust NY pizza fan, this is weird for me, but I can't deny it. Ohh yes--a warning: many times the wait sucks and CASH ONLY!
author: kate r.

description: My wife & I had garlic bread (ok, just warm sourdough bread, but butter & roasted garlic) with a small deep dish vegetarian pizza (very nice, better than Zachary's or Patxis as it has great taste but is not as heavy) & Virgil's natural cola (great). Service was fine. Went Sunday at lunch when it was not that busy.
author: Mihir M.

description:
Woot!

Happy me!

Chicago style pizza is the best, and Little Stars was great.  Three of us split the salad and a large little star pie along with a few drinks.  The total was $44 Awesome.

The little Star pizza with spinach, ricotta, mushrooms, and a plethora of other delicious, garlic infused ingredients pleased my palate and filled my tummy.

I will def. head back.
author: Krissy M.

description: This place is absolutely delicious. The Vegetarian Deep Dish pizza is probably my favorite. They have great beers on tap, and the service is tops. The jukebox is damn decent and the garlic bread is some of the best I've ever had. The wait for a table can be a bit long, but it's well worth the wait.  It seems to get better every time i go. Also a great place to take a date. Highly recommended.
author: Joseph N.

description:
Super lucky that I got a table for two with no wait!  How is that possible?  That totally made my night.  With me being vegetarian, my friend and I each ordered a Little Star - he added sausage to his.  I was so hungry that I easily gobbled up half of my pizza even after starting with garlic bread.  Seriously, I was that hungry.  

Ok, so I really like Little Star and its crust.  My friend is a native Chicagoan, so he thought it was too much.  In his words, "there's too much stuff in the sauce."  I'm not quite sure what he meant, but I love the sauce, so maybe it's not authentic to Chicago.
author: Olivia T.

description:
Being a fan of deep dish pizza, I came to this place with high hopes. It did not disappoint at all. The dishes were freshly prepared and arrived in a timely manner. We started off with the garlic bread, hell yes it came with roasted garlic. Sooo good, if this was all I ate at this place, I would've been happy. The dish comes with tasty sourdough bread with butter and roasted garlic on the side so you can choice the amount of each you would like, highly recommended appetizer. For the pizza, we of course ordered the deep dish style and opted to choose our own ingredients to put it which were spinach, italian sausage, pepperoni and of course mushroom. The small size is enough for two people, but the slices seemed small. We still did leave very full and satisfied. The ingredients were very fresh and you were able to tell this right away, the crust was super delicious. It had hints of olive oil and butter in it. 

The staff was very nice and made sure we were taken care of, place was a little small but clean and had nice decor. 

I'll always be a zacharys girl, but this is definitely a comparable and good alternative for deep dish pizza on this side of the bridge, will for sure be returning.
author: Jollieanne J.

description: Go to Little Star for your deep dish fix, Delfina for your thin crust, and you'll never wish you never moved out of NYC. :)
author: Lisa S.

description:
One can't blame a place for being successful, right?

Whether it's Tuesday night or Friday night, this place is always PACKED, so be ready to wait. The bartenders are friendly, and beers are served in ice-cold pint glasses - so cold that if beer dribbles down the outside of the glass, it'll freeze! The pizza is definitely the #1 deep dish place in the Bay (Paxti's, Zachery's, etc). It's deep dish, but the crust is so light, it doesn't feel like you're eating heavy food. Not much in the way of appetizers. At the same time, who goes to a deep dish joint because of the appetizers?
author: Rod M.

description:
Been waiting for this place to open and what a treat to order take-out from Little Star Pizza! We decided to try some classic items recommended by other Yelpers - including the Spicy Chicken Wings with baby carrots and blue cheese dressing. Not fried wings (almost healthy!) but nice and spicey with black pepper. Very good - will order that again.

We ordered the Classic Deep Dish pizza topped with sausage, mushrooms, green peppers and onions. I am an Italian pizza fanatic and usually I will turn my back on the deep dish. Little Star's Classic however is not to be ignored - excellent, moist crust that stands up to the hefty toppings - including the delicious and chunky tomato sauce which crowns the pie.

Impressive - will be back for more!
author: Mariangela S.

description:
Great deepdish pizza, rivaling that of even Zachary's.  

Feels like a trendy/yuppy joint, dark lighting and designer curtains.  

NO ranch sauce available! I ran to the corner store and picked up a bottle of ranch sauce.  

The wait can be pretty long.  

Very noisy inside.
author: Dong T.

description:
This is the best Pizza I have had in San Francisco.  Hands down.  We had the thin crust and it was fabulous. Perfect crust, perfect amount of cheese and toppings, not to mention the great service and the enjoyable ambiance of the restaurant itself.  All this, and it is very reasonably priced. 
If you go early and get a table quickly, this place is perfect.  We got lucky, usually there is a wait, which is why it has taken so long for us to try it out. 
Seriously, this is one place where all the hype is well deserved!
author: Nilu r.

description:
I've decided I'm not a fan of deep dish pizza.  Gimee my thin crust and I'm happy.  I know this may make alot of people upset but it is what it is, I like thin crust.

That said, if I were to become a deep dish lover, this would be my spot.  The menu is full of deep dish options, as well as thin crust options for the haters like my self and on top of all that has a great drink menu with things like the Kool Aide cocktail made with champagne and a few other things.  Both the deep dish and the thin crust pizzas were good on flavor and appeal.  I guess what makes a deep dish good is that it's covered in food: and this definitely was, in our case we had the Little Star deep dish.......The appetizers also were great.  

So good food, good service, and even though it was a Thursday night, and the place was packed, we only had a 1 minute wait, truly amazing!  

Reality is that if I were into deep dish this would be 4 stars but because I'm not I don't feel like I can rave about the place endlessly because I don't have anything to say.
author: Denise B.

description:
I think this place is really good.
Get there early or prepare to wait.
They don't take reservations and the bar/waiting area fills quickly too.

In the menu, they have certain combinations according to crust style.
But I later learned that any combination is available in any style.

Wish they had anchovies, that would bring my vote to 5 stars.

If you decided you can't wait the 45 minutes to be seated...
You can always get it "to go". The pie will be done in about 20.
Sure, can't watch and flirt with the beautiful people that tend to go here, but hey, it's the pizza you come here for right?
author: Geordie E.

description:
4.5 Stars

What can I say that hasn't already been said?

I've never been to the Divisadero Little Star but I was incredibly impressed by the Deep Dish vegetarian pizza I had here. The crust was incredible - I keep dreaming about how I could just go for some Little Star crust. The vegetables (mushrooms, onions, black olives, red bell peppers, garlic, zucchini) all tasted fresh. And the best part was Mr. Stretch-like elasticity of the cheese.

Unfortunately, there is always a wait so make a reservation.
Also, perhaps there could be a better system for the bathroom. When it's busy it's hard to tell how many people are awkwardly surrounding the bathroom door and it can cause tension if people haven't eaten yet and are waiting.

It seemed like our waitress was a little rude when we only ordered a pizza with no appetizers - we wanted to save our stomachs :)!
author: Anthony K.

description:
This review is for two things in particular: the bar and dining with more than 2 people.  The people behind the bar last night (two women) were singularly bitchy.  Our small group arrived at 7:30 and immediately ordered a bottle of wine while we waited for a table.  I thought the wine would be in a carafe (you know, because the WINE LIST SAID IT WOULD), and so I was confused when she brought out a bottle.  She said "we only have one Sangiovese" and rolled her eyes.  Fine.  So I took the bottle back to my crew on the couch and didn't realize I'd forgotten my credit card.  About 45 minutes into our 90 minute wait (more on that in a second), she came over to me and stuck her hand in my face.  My credit card was in her hand.  "Oh my gosh, thanks so much!" I said.  She scowled and walked away.  I thought I was maybe a little sensitive about it, but before I could ask my friends if they saw that, they were talking about "what an angry bartender", "nice bitchface", etc.  So that blew.  Particularly because I was the host of this small party, and I wanted to show them a good time.

The hostess was in NO HURRY to seat us.  Sure, there were a lot of people there, but as we sat and waited, couples would come in, get seated, eat a deep dish (read: slow cook time) pizza, linger over wine, pay the bill, and walk out, full.  Still we sat, with our bottle of wine, playing musical chairs while we waited.  This happened over and over -- couple comes in, gets seated, eats, leaves.  Finally, she says "you know, you can order takeout from the bar".  So we did.  When we finally got a table, an hour-and-a-half after arriving, and after half a dozen couples had come in, eaten, and left, our pizza was ready and all the server had to do was keep the water filled.  But of course, we still had gratuity added to the check.

(Why did we not leave earlier, you ask?  I dunno.  Probably the stupid bottle of wine.)

Long story short, the pizza is decent (Zachary's is better), but the attitude raised so much bile that I could barely taste it.

If you want to "dine in", then bring one friend.  ONE.  And warn the small groups waiting on the couch that they're in for a doozy of a wait, because the hostess apparently hates groups.  But really, with a place like that, takeout is definitely the way to go.  And finally, just do takeout from Zachary's, where the people are happy to have your business and don't treat you like a nuisance.
author: A W.

description:
Ok.... maybe it was just the reisdual high I felt from eating this pizza but I could have SWORN I already wrote a review for Little Star.

Do I even really need to go any further? It's friggin DELICIOUS!

I'l just drop some tips.. 
The champagne cocktails are huge and delicious
After 9 ...till close it's $1.00 off all drinks ... the PBR's are normally $2 .. that makes them only a buck :)
Go here before you see a show at the Independant .. perfect fit

Take it to go on a Sunday night and watch lots of garbage tv on DVR :)
author: Jeremy R.

description: Are you kidding me pesto chicken?  I could literally eat you 3 meals a day for the rest of my life
author: Dana C.

description: Stopped in for a quick bite before catching a flick at the Roxie.  We got there around after 5 on a weekday so it wasnt packed so service was pretty quick.  The restaurant had dim lighting so I had a bit of a hard time reading the menu.  We only got to try the Thin Crust Pizzas sm 12"/lg 16" - Italian Combo - Pepperoni, salami, onions, green bells, black olives, pepperoncini $18 / $22.  I really liked it.  I'd like to come back and try the Pesto Chicken - Pesto base, roasted chicken, mushrooms, onions $18 / $22, White Pie - Garlic olive oil base, mozzarella, roasted zucchini, fresh tomatoes, feta $17 / $21 and Classic - Sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells $18 / $22.
author: she q.

description:
I was hesitant in going to Little Star since I'm not a pizza lover, but I'm glad I did.  I got the thin crusted pizza (Italian combo), and it was delish.  It had the right amount of cheese and the crust was, well, crusty!

I noticed that most other tables had pizza leftover and had it boxed to go.  No exception here.  When the waitress came to clear my dishes, she pretty much assumed I wanted to box my pizza.

The next time I'm back in the neighborhood I will try the deep dish pizza that everyone seems to rave about.
author: Tony L.

description:
Be assured, they are open. Love the incognito-ness!
This lil star is good to Finaz, who in turn is good to us...thanks for the free, we know it's a ploy - "the first one's always free", but is being addicted to pie all that bad?
Love the cornmeal crust and just a plain ol' sausage pie. Staff is super sweet & friendly.
author: Colleen B.

description:
4 stars for their thin crust pizza! I am crazy about thin crust pizza and they delivered... had the cheese with the pepperocini (sp? it's the spicy peppers) and a glass of zin. My day was complete.

My boyfriend had the deep dish (he's a Chicagoan) and his eyes went wide... it was damn good. 

Only thing: It was too dark in there for me (mood lighting for pizza?) and the red light was somewhat blinding... and if only they could get 1 more bathroom (they only have 1 for men/women). All would be swell.
author: Nenette Y.

description:
Shh don't spread the word that the Mission one has opened yet.  I actually think I like this one better than the one on Divs.  The waiting area and bar are right in the front and seems to be roomier.  Grab an Abbey Ale and chill on the couch cause even though it just opened there of course still will be a wait :) 

The pizza has everyone has mentioned is freaking amazing. I am usually not a fan of deep dish pizza but there crust is ridic, it taste like a buttery cornmeal biscuit.  Service was fine, could have been better but it was super busy and on a Friday night.  Once I told our waiter we were in a hurray and off to a Xmas party he got our bill right away so that was cool.

Also like the Divs location they have a pretty good jukebox selection.
author: Katie M.

description:
DAMN, that was good!

I had the "Little Star," which was deep, with sweet and tangy tomato sauce reminiscent of my days in Italy, real mozzarella, and fresh spinach. The brick-exposed interior gives it a warm ambiance, too.
author: David K.

description:
Busy loud, but damn, that thin crust is good. As is the wine list.

Friendly solid service and you haven't disappointed me yet. Little Star, thanks for coming to my neighborhood!

Pauline's has been disappointing me for the last 18 months. Sad, but true.
author: Glen M.

description:
OMG the deep dish pizza crust is to die for. 

everytime i've gone it was with a large group. and if you've been here, you know that means an incredibly long wait. both times we probably waited over an hour. but you know what? it was worth every second. 

yes, that's just how damn good this pizza is. no joke.
author: Jon N.

description:
This place rocks -- I think the nearly 300 reviews that have been posted here thus far more than adequately attest to that. The pizza is fucking great. Thick, hearty, filling, artery-clogging. I love the spicy tomato sauce. Dry yet dense cornmeal crust. You can get a decent salad, too. And the thin-crust pizzas are great, too. What more could you want?

First went to the original Divisadero location, learned about this one, tried it, found it just as good. A bit more polished, even, but working to maintain its hipster cred. You will find a skinny-jean, Converse-clad, cap-wearing, messenger-bag-bearing crowd here.
author: Tara M.

description:
The pizza was great. Chock full of wonderfully fresh vegetables, generous chunks of spicy sausage and awesomely zesty tomato sauce. Obviously they make a wicked deep dish pizza. I haven't been to Zachary's in a while, but I'm fairly sure it's comparable. I would definitely return when craving deep dish.

I am forced to deduct two stars for the following: 1. When we called in our order, we were told half an hour. It was over an hour until our order was ready. Busy on a Saturday is fair, but just tell us an hour, yo. And certainly don't tell us, after 45 minutes that you "have no idea when it'll be ready." 2. No jalapenos and a $50 pricetag for two pies. For shame!
author: Jenni D.

description:
I came here last Thursday with a group of 3 other people. One of the people who used to live in Chicago said this was the place to go if you wanted authentic Chicago style pizza. 

We showed up around 8pm and it was pretty crowded. Our wait was about 30 minutes. The bar was full and the only other option inside to sit down at was a 3 chairs and a couch. I only point that out because I was annoyed by these 2 women who were hogging the couch. My three other friends sat in the chairs but the women were not about to move to let me sit down. I was so ready to tell them to move the f over. But they left after about 15 minutes. (ok - got the venting out of the way) The hostess did come to inform us that she was just waiting for a group of people who were already finished with their meal and were just chillin. I appreciated that she came and updated us.

When we finally sat down we ordered the caprese salad - fresh mozarella, basil, tomatoes drenched in a balsamic vinegar/Olive oil mix. The tomatoes were fresh and the dressing was just right. There was also 2 pieces of garlic bread that came with it that was perfect to dip into the balsamic vinegar. 

We ordered 2 large deep dish pizza: the Classic and the Little Star. As a veggie I was only able to eat the Little Star. It had chucky pieces of tomotaes and a fair amount of cheese. There were pieces of garlic that I would randoming bite into and at times it seemed a little over powering. I never tasted the feta that was suppose to there. I loved the crust. Although, I never tasted it except when I ate the outter portion. It was crunchy and buttery.  I was full after 2 slices.
Overall I was extremely satisfied with my meal. But it was not exceptionally enough to deserve 5 stars.

As the stand alone veggie in the group I didnt have the oppurtunity to try both. But out of my party 2 people prefered the Classic and one other prefered the Little Star. They all like both pizzas though. The only common complaint was the garlic.

***Note: My friend calculated the size difference and price difference and we figured out for about and extra $5 for the large you get just under double the amount of the small pizza. So my suggestion...Upgrade to the large.***
author: Richard C.

description:
The pizza: great deep dish and very good thin crust with good ingredients.

The beer: bottles only, better than average selection, though they chill the hell out of them and the glasses, which is great if you're drinking a lager, but weird if you're drinking a stout.

The salad: nice greens, tomatoes and walnuts, with some gorgonzola for good measure, but they should dry the lettuce before making the salad.  The dressing slid off the leaves and pooled on the plate.

The wings: about as good as one would expect wings to be in at a place service Chicago-ish deep dish pizza.  That is to say, TERRIBLE!

Bring cash!
author: Suo L.

description:
First pizzeria in USA that I would go back and try more items on/off the menu. It's still not nearly close to the pizzeria in Italy, but it's awesome in its own american way.

I hate thick crusts pizza. Hate it. No italians do it that way. When you go to a local pizzeria, the crusts are as thin as paper that the pizza takes 3 minutes to cook. It's so good yet so light that I myself, a girl who's always on a diet, and never finishes her food (when she's on a diet), could eat an entire 12" pizza.

So, why???? Why do I choose to go to a Chicago deep dish pizza place? If it wasn't for the Top Chef challenge, I'd never had tried it. It's something that holds a significant position in the culinary world, and it's something that I've never had before. I knew I might not like it, but just had to try at least once.

Got a deep dish with whole bunch of toppings. I have to say, it's just not my thing, like what I expected. But it's actually very delightful. The crust is thick, but not overly clogged with sauce/toppings, and the crust is crispy on the edge and soft inside. It's so surprisingly light considering how much dough is there. I was very please with the experience. 

Also got the thin special of the day, white pie with pear, gorgonzola, candied walnuts, and sauteed onions. It was sooooooo delicious and sooooo refreshing. The only thing I don't like is that they "cubed" the pears, instead of thin slice them. Sliced pears would not only stay on the pizza better, it'll also be more flavorful.

Overall, wonderful experience, nice cute date spot, but also good for friends' catch-up. Get there early, bring some cash.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Oh how I love thee...my Little Star Pizza!

Let me count the ways!
1. Everything is awesome here (I'm not kidding.  Even the wings are good!)  
2. Salad (perfect amount of dressing and toppings in every bite)
3. Roasted garlic bread (I've nearly died and gone to heaven)
4. Thin crust pizza (even my less favorite, deep dish, is amazing)
5. The drinks are delightful (champagne and ginger beer- HELLO!)

You really can't go wrong.  My only complaint- Why don't you have an East Bay location??!!??
author: Michelle U.

description:
I. Love. Little Star. 

Seriously orgasmic pizza. 

I go for the Classic, deep dish with a cornmeal crust. Fresh tomato sauce, and a perfect mix of classic ingredients that come together into a legendary pizza with the only crust I bother to eat! Two peeps? Go for the small, and save room for the crust!

Apparently there's homemade cheesecake, but I've yet to manage to save room... that's just how good the pizza is... maybe I'll just go for dessert someday? Nah! What am I, crazy?!
author: Angela G.

description: This place gets really busy (for a reason of course) so we had to wait about 45 mins to be seated. However, the wafting smell of our pizza as it was placed at the table made me overlook the wait. That first slice of crispy crust was devine! The filling was good, but I've had a bit better. Despite, their crust tops all other deep dishes I've eaten. I'm not sure if I would come on a weekend to wait for a table. But then again, when I get good food I usually forget about the wait. ;)
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I guess it doesn't matter what goes down at this point with over 700 reviews.  But what they hey....   whether you're in the mission or on divis, this place has the best thin crust pizza this side of the Mississippi.  For the other side, I'm going to have to stretch my memory.  Standard fare is the italian which comes with sausage, pepperoncinis and tomatoes.  The store- brewed beer is great too (wheat ale).
If you have to wait, I usually just take the available bar seats which are just as fun.  
Expect hip, rockin music on weekends!
author: Tony N.

description: You'll get a great deep dish pizza here. Try it! You'll be hooked.
author: Danielle D.

description:
We had a great time at Little Star! Todd was our server and he was so gracious and attentive! We will definitely be back! 

Also, being from Chicago, this is the closest thing to actual Chicago style pizza I have found in the city so far. Delicious!
author: Katie M.

description: Fan-friggin-tastic deep dish pizza - and Racer 5 on tap, and really really good (albeit expensive) wings. its nice!
author: Ben B.

description: Great pizza and great people working there. The place is nice and we had left overs walked outside seen the same bums asking us to buy a news paper as we walked in so i asked them if they wanted our left over pizza and they said "hell yeah!" Ill come back not only for the food but those funny ass bums.
author: Richard T.

description: This is the best Best! Best! BEST! deep dish pizza I have had. Don't think twice..just order. And they have wine on tap, tasty and a good value. I'll be back soon!
author: Hidegrl A.

description: Pretty cramped but that means people like the pizza obviously.Cool spot on Valencia, good but not best deep dish around.
author: Pearson L.

description: My favorite pizza, probably ever. They make Chicago style pizza, so so delicious and wonderful. This place is tiny, so the wait is usually kind of long, but so worth it. The waiters always seem to be cute and funny. Order the Little Star, and if you're not a vegetarian, order it with Italian sausage.
author: Kat M.

description: I love Little Star. What do they put in the crust? It must be crack because it is soooooo good. I think they use a ton of butter in it to give it that delicious flakiness and texture. I went with a group of three last time I ate there. One pizza was plenty for all of us, plus we all had salad. The atmosphere is is fun and busy- very typical SF. I've never been to the NOPA location; I'm more of a Mission gal myself,  but I hear it's just as good. This isn't your typical pizza, but it hits the spot!
author: GHADA Y.

description: This place has fantastic pizza! I especially like the deep dish pizza. YUM!
author: Carol B.

description: I'm extremely disappointed in that they got rid of their original cheesecake.  They used to make it in-house, and it was UH-MAZING.  I guess they changed their ovens and no longer make it, instead they bring it from outside.  It is mediocre.  So sad. The cheesecake was the best part.
author: Cecilia C.

description:
I wish I've had the time to come again...and now that I've reminded myself of how good my experience was the last time, I'll probably stop by in the next week :)

We had the spicy wings, the Little Star and a multitude of drinks during my first visit. We sat at the bar and didn't have to wait at all (lucky for us we stopped in right before the rush). The bartender was friendly but not overly chatty and offered suggestions for pizza and drinks - he convinced the two of us to get the large pizza which we didn't even come close to finishing -- but no complaints there because the thick slices of pizza became lunch for the next few days and launched many coworkers into fits of jealousy.

The only gripe was that  the pizza was only lukewarm in the very middle, leaving the cheese unmelted -- i love my food piping, burn-ya-lips-off HOT and my cheese extra gooey and melty. If it had been hot, the pizza would've been amazing, but despite that, it was still a great a pie.
author: Chelle Y.

description:
Our waiter was pecular. The pizza (cheese deep dish) was satisfactory and the caprese salad was real good. The $10 glass of pinot noir was meh. The ambiance and music were pleasant.

UPDATE:
everyone's complaint - can't find the place. with a sign that small, i guess you need real good vision (which i do have). This time our waiter was way cool. the garlic bread was cool because it was actual roasted garlic that you could spread on the bread. the little star pizza was good but what i really liked was the thin crust pizza. it was soooo crunchy! i want to go there again to try the cheese version, my friends ordered the chicken pesto one and i just picked off the chicken to try it. i liked that one the best though...i'll give this place more stars once i confirm that the cheese pizza is worth something to write home about.

FYI: This place is cash only!
author: Anita C.

description:
Can so much love for a pizza joint be justified?  The heaps of praise posted about Little Star roll on day in and day out, with nary a nay-sayer in sight.

It's all true.  This is great pizza.  Period.  The "Little Star" in particular is transcendent.  Didn't completely make a convert out of my wife, a native New Yorker, and not such a fan of deep dish, but it came as close as anything ever has.  Certainly beats Zachary's.
author: Hugh B.

description:
I reserve five stars for those few super-duper mind blowing unique restaurants. Little Star is essentially a spin on Zachary's. They're doing well to get the four stars, not many make it to such rarefied heights.

Entering the doorway to Little Star on Valencia during dinner hours, you will be greeted by a small line and a 20+ minute wait. Never fear, you can get appetizers and drinks in the entryway.
