Mmmm, their Caprese salad is so fresh and yummy, it rivals the best I've had on a trip to Bologna and beats anything I've had in a San Francisco restaurant. I'm not eating Italian food in SF every night, but I eat Italian about once a week. So, I'm not easily impressed by just any green leaves and cheese. Also available in the entryway: the coldest Thomas Kemper sodas known to humankind, served in a pint glass so cold, air condenses on the glass and forms ice on the rim. Oh, and the glass is filled with ice. There must be no better place to cool off on a hot day with a Black Cherry soda.

I'm on the fence between Zachary's and Little Star. Both their thick crust pizzas are among my favorite treats. I could choose either. Fortunately, they're on opposite sides of the bay. Essentially, LS's crust is flaky and crumbly and Zach's is flour or whole wheat flour. Take your pick. I give the edge to Little Star for fresher tomatoes, and herbs in their pies. You will not be doing yourself a disservice if you order the thin crust pizza. The Margherita is just right. Someone there knows their pizza. I'd put the Margherita up there with Pizzeria Delfina. Yes, solidly in Delfina's class, but no, not better. I recommend coming here with four people unless you want to put some tables together. Plus, it's loud enough the extra two people wouldn't be heard at the far end of the table anyway. Great place to bring someone who doesn't fit into the group so they can be comfortably ignored.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Good, but frankly I preferred Paxti's for when I need to get my Deep-dish fix.

Pros: Excellent sauce, reasonable price.
Cons: Not enough cheese (at least, compared to Paxti's, but I need plenty of cheese), sausage was only so-so, crust could have been better.

Essentially it's a case of damning with faint praise. There was nothing particularly exceptional about Little Star while, IMHO, Paxti's was truly excellent. If not for another option I'd probably come here for deep-dish though. Give them both a try and decide which you like better.
author: Mark S.

description:
On April 25, 2007 a business associate and I decided to eat at Little Star because the place has a 4.5 rating with over 200 votes on Yelp.  That is just downright impressive!

Finding the restaurant was not difficult with our GPS unit, but parking was a challenge.  We finally found a parking garage 2 blocks away which was about $5 for two hours.

From the outside Little Star doesn't look like much, but when you go inside it is quite nice. Much nicer than I expected for a pizza joint.

The pizzas are a good size.  A small is $16 and a large is about $20 but a small will feed 2-3 people.  

The people working there are quite nice and when I whipped out my laptop they noticed that I had yelp open and told me they check it every day.  They were very concerned about making sure we had a nice meal.

Service was friendly but a little slow.  But it seemed to fit the mood of the restaurant.  You don't go here for fast service, but for good food and the ambiance.

Between the two of us, we ordered way, way more food than we could eat, mainly because we wanted to try it all.  We had the garlic bread appetizer (~$4) which I'd say was OK.  I probably wouldn't order it again but it was good.  They serve it with a side of creamy butter which the staff told me is whipped with olive oil to make it spreadable.  And that butter was awesome.

We also ordered the wings, and they were very good.  I'd recommend them to anyone.  They are not "hot" but they are spicy, meaning they have some unusal spiced flavor.

We also got one thin, and one deep crust pizza (~$17 each) - both small.  Somehow we managed to eat 1/2 of each, though we were stuffed.  The pizza was truly excellent.

One drawback to the place is that it is not very intimate.  You will hear everything being discussed at the tables beside you, so I wouldn't recommend it for a business or romantic evening.  But if you want to go get some really high quality food you can't go wrong here.  Personally I'll be returning on future trips to San Francisco.

Please note, this is the first 5 star rating I've given on Yelp.
author: John P.

description:
I'm from Chicago and I used to live in NY, so I am always excited to find some pizza in San Francisco that I like. And Little Star I like. Unlike, Zachary's, it doesn't try as hard to be like Chicago deep dish, Little Star has a crust and style all its own.

We ate: the classic, garlic bread, and wings. Wings were NOT like your spicy type, which I didn't like. Oh, yeah and $2 PBR. yes!
author: Nima K.

description:
As one of my most cogent friends would say, "oh, effin' wowzers".

Tied with Zachary's and Rizzo's in Queens for Best Pizza EVER.
author: Momo R.

description:
Just like the original on Divis, this place rocks.

It's a little pricey, and a little too delicious to eat all the time, but its AWESOME.  

I especially like the deep dish little star special and chicken wings.
Salads and thin crust pizzas are great, too.

Honestly, i don't care about service and decor when food is this good. But service and decor are good.

ok, done.   take out anyone?
author: chad n.

description:
I know a girl who works here, and sometimes she shows up with a pizza. The crust is my favorite part. I should point out that I've never actually set foot inside the establishment to eat, so there's not a whole lot I can actually comment on, but I just want to reiterate that the pizza is so freaking delicious.

Minus 1 star for being just a tad expensive.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Hype. Lots of it.

For deep dish, Little Star pizza isn't nearly as good as Patxi's or Zachary's pizza. They don't cook their pizzas long enough (you have to wait 40 minutes for your pie to finish at Zachary's, 25min+ baking time), and as a result, the flavors don't mesh as well. Moreover, they don't add enough tomatoes. In fact, compared to the other dominate two--they simply don't add enough ingredients all together. I should struggle to bring a slice of pizza from the pan to my plate. Toppings should fall all over the table, and there should be a sufficient amount falling off that I break the five second rule once or twice to in an effort to bring them all back to my mouth. If it doesn't get all over the place, it doesn't belong in my face.

Moreover, the spicy chicken wings were baked (or tasted of it). Blasphemy. I don't believe in baked wings. If they are baked, that needs to be prefaced on the menu. My wings should be crunchy and actually spicy. 

The garlic bread appetizer was good, but could have been improved. LS servers you warm bread accompanied by a bulb of roasted garlic and a ramekin of butter mixed with olive oil. The bread was good, and the garlic was perfectly roasted. While the butter mixed with olive oil is a great marketing pitch, it was actually a bit of an annoyance. Mashing the garlic and the butter-oil medley proved to be a pain in the ass. The garlic was piping hot, and the butter-oil mixed didn't hold when mixed in the garlic--resulting in a slimly, oily mess difficult to spread on the bread. Sure, It tasted good, but it probably would have tasted better if they held the olive oil to maintain consistency. LS should have provided a better means for mixing, or have the server mix it for us--and add a couple of herbs for color.

I've totally knocked Little Star. But you know what, it's still good pizza. But if you want to complete with the big boys, you've got to master the details. If you're in the east bay, got to Zachary's--if you're in the SF, hit up Patxi's. But if you're in the barrio, it's still not a bad option.
author: John M.

description:
awesome.  I like pizza, and this is some of the best pizza in SF.  it's busy, but you can usually get a seat at the bar if you're down.  you can also walk down the street to Fly bar for a drink.
you'll spend a little, but it's well worth it for this kind of pizza.
author: Spencer W.

description:
A game that I play, a parlor game if you will, with family and friends is to answer the question: 'If you were lost on a desert (not dessert) island and could only have one food (you would be able to survive by eating fish/fruit/roots) what would you choose?'

My choice: pizza.

I love me some pizza.  Be it frozen, thick, thin, with meat, without... I just want to eat it.  I have my fave place, Za -rocks!- but decided to try this Little Star that has so many raves.  It's a cute place, and comfortable, although a little crowded.  The salad and appetizer selections are good;  I shared a salad and a garlic bread (warm bread served with butter and a roasted garlic head that you spread yourself) and then ordered a small, deep-dish vegetarian pie.

The flavor is good, and the pizza is prepared so that the crust doesn't get soggy with all the chunky tomato sauce on top. It was all very well put together, and I'd eat it every day on my desert island, though I would prefer Za's pizza, if I could choose.  Perhaps I'm not the biggest fan of the Chicago-style, but I am a fan of Little Star.  I have to say, it was very reasonably priced, too.
author: Karen W.

description:
YYYYYYYUUUUUMMMMMMMMMMMYYY!!!!

After stuffing our faces with deep dish pizza, we ordered the cheesecake to just "take a little bite".  We ended up licking the plate clean!  

Definitely end your meal with the cheesecake - homemade, soft, light, fluffy cheesecake!
author: Victoria F.

description:
OK, so a lot of how we like something is based on our feelings. So, here are my feelings during a recent visit to Little Star Pizza, in reverse order since that's how I remembered it  (hmm, think hard what that means):

Buzzing - full, happy, and content, off into the night; we'll definitely come back and try the thin crust.

Ah ha! - there is an ATM inside here.

Really? - No, traveler's checks? Um, OK, I'll pay with cash (to myself, whew, I had some cash, but, will have to take the Bart and Muni back in the rain instead of a taxi, oh well.)

Shock - OMG, you don't take credit cards (to myself, shit, hope I have some money; well maybe they'll take a traveler's check).

Awesome! - That was a freaking awesome Pizza, and I love the corn meal type crust!

Yum - That deep dish 'chicken with artichokes' pizza looks great.

Buzzzzzzz - wheat beer

Buzzzzzz - Cabernet Sauvignon

Buzz - Zinfandel

Cool - I like this place. It's really dark and non-pretentious. Glad we got here early; there are a lot of tables available and I heard it's usually hard to get a table.

Here it is!

(The beginning)
author: barry s.

description:
This place served the best Chicago Pizza I ever had!  I normally don't like Chicago Style Pizza because it tends to get soggy with so many toppings.  But here - they put cornmeal in the crust so it stays crispy!
My friends and I picked it up and didn't even eat immediately - and it was still crispy and tasty 30 minutes later.  

I did try their thin crust pizzas and it wasn't as great.  I would just come here for the Chicago Pizza - I think that's what they're known for.
author: Bess N.

description:
The food is great and the service is colorful at this pizza joint. You need to get there earlier in the evening, or you'll be waiting 30-90 minutes for a table, but there's a nice wine/chanpagne/beer bar area with VERY reasonable drink prices while you wait. The pizza is definitely worth the wait if you're not dying of hunger. Both thin crust and deep dish pizzas are good, and there are a lot of exciting toppings to choose from. The staff are good at recommending toppings you might like as well.

Happy hour is great because it's everyday - even on weekends! While they have a good selection of beers, you can pop in for $1 PBRs during happy hour to quench your thirst. Overall great place!

** This location recently started accepting credit cards (within the past couple of months) and our waitress was happy to split our check.
author: Matthew S.

description:
After 4 months of hearing about this place I finally had the opportunity to try it out. All I can say is I fell in love...with pizza that is...even though I'm arlready a pizza fanatic. 

I ordered the caprese salad which was delicious compared to other places. Maybe because they lay the cheese on the plate first then the tomatoes on top. Most restaurants do the reverse. Anyways, too the pizza. I ordered the small classic deep dish which is more than enough for you two people. It was soo good I wanted to order another one to go. In my opinion the crust is buttery and toppings were pretty generous. It's hard to find pizza place where you pull a slice that the cheese stretches out. If you don't like to read reviews, here summarized breakdown:
- GREAT pizza!
- Friendly service
- parking sucks
- very small inside so go early
- you gotta try black cherry soda

I definitely recommend this place to everybody. Best pizza I tried so far in SF.
author: David W.

description:
Lemme just throw this out there: don't come here unless you're hungry and in the mood for some delicious pizza. If you fall in the "I am hungry and I like pizza" group -- then damn, this is your stop.

A nice environment full of young people, a bustling selection of drinks, and some tasty pizza with CORNBREAD crust that's actually not greasy at all. Go for the deep dish and you're golden.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
When I went to Chicago, I ate pizza there eeeveryday.  I loved Giordano's and Gino's East.  It was very disappointing to come back to the west coast only to find that almost all deep dish pizza imitations here tasted nothing like the deep dish pizza I had in Chicago.  I was thrilled to hear that Zacharies had pretty good Chicago-style pizza, but was disappointed once I got there.  I didn't mind the long wait as long as the pizza tasted good, but the sauce was just way too salty.  

ANYWAYS, when I found Little Star...I was brought back to the taste of REAL Chicago-style pizza.  I can't say it's on the same level as Giordano's or Gino's East, but it is very close to it.  The only thing that sucks is the layout of the restaurant.  It's very crowded in the waiting area with barely anywhere to sit.  I've waited for as long as an hour and a half here before.  So don't go unless you've got time to spare.
author: Melanie C.

description:
Yum. Deep dish pizza. Really though, how can you complain about oven baked thick cornmeal crust, melted cheese, gooey goodness? 
Cool environment, dark but relaxed and comfortable/casual, great juke box.
author: Jasmine O.

description:
I've been going to Little Star since its first location on Divis. We always order a deep dish pizza with the garlic bread, which I find pretty good. Although I have a slight issue is with the tomato sauce -- it tastes a tad "tinny," and not cooked down enough.

But from my most recent order, I think I found the perfect combination: chicken pesto thin crust with a side of garlic bread. Smear those jewels of sweet, roasted garlic onto the pizza, and dammit... you've got a slice of heaven on your tongue!
author: Antoi C.

description:
3-strikes and it is OUT.

i do not know what it is about the pizza here but it is just okay.
nothing stood out and i have had better at many other places with better service.

all my friends and even gary likes the pizza but this last time, I ended up eating homemade tamales.  the pizza did not look as though it was the one gary ordered.  he questioned upon reentering the vehicle, when we picked it up the other night.

i am an extreme man.  they never fail and and never f*** up an order.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
Got the caprese salad.  For the price, skip it.  Tried both the deep dish and thin crust.  The cornmeal crust on the deep dish pizza was a nice surprise.  The Little Star is good with meat.  It's not on the menu but you can get it.  There is a specific name for it, but I can't for the life of me remember it.

Make sure you are ready to wait.  It gets super crowded on the weekends.   There is a bar right when you walk in.  And it's a good thing we like beer.  Made the wait that much more tolerable.

Worth a try.  Probably won't be back for a while though.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
We found this place by accident on a Saturday evening just walking by.  We noticed they were Zagat rated and thought we would try it..  
We were seated right away in the close quarters but cozy enough space.  Our wait staff was attentive.

I ordered the ginger ale, champagne, ginger candy drink  which was pretty good but I think pitting it in a more better glass would make this drink special.  Who wants to drink champagne out of a typical restaurant water/soda glass? There is just a piece of chewey ginger candy sitting on the bottom of the glass-not that impressive.  I was thinking a crushed ginger candy rimmed glass was on its way but no luck.

We ordered the Caprese Salad of mozzarella, tomatoes, basil "drizzled with extra virgin olive oil and balsamic vinegar."  The truth is the tomatoes did not look or taste fresh and the plate was pretty much a vinager bath.  I didn't see much olive oil.  Pretty much a let down.

Other tables' thin crust pizza looked great.  We ordered a small deep dish "classic" which was pretty good and not too heavy.  We ate the entire pizza and were not hungry nor wanting to take a nap from deep dish exhaustion--if you know what I mean.  And no walking around town w/leftovers.

I would go back for the pizza but not order caprese again.

Oh, and they have a little bar in front if you just want to go and try the ginger drink.

J
author: Jane D.

description:
Love this place. and i don't mind the wait since it's likely that my friends and i would have a beer (or two) in hand to past the time anyway.

When we come here, we usually start off with a salad and the garlic bread. There's nothing special about their salad (but is there anything special about any salad anyway....ever?) but I do love their garlic bread...the soft, spread-able roasted garlic cloves are to die for. And with a decent size party, you'll be able to get the best of both worlds by ordering a deep dish pizza AND a thin crust!  I'm a thin-crust pizza guy...but this is one of the few places where I definitely don't mind having a slice of deep dish.
author: Jeremy F.

description: I've been lucky enough to travel a lot for work, allowing me to try different local cuisines and see if they live up to the hype. BBQ and Tex Mex from Texas is okay. Hawaiian mai tais are mediocre. Out of all the places I've been, it's the pizza debate that I battle with the most. Do I prefer Chicago's deep dish or New York's thin crust? Both are amazing in their own right. The only problem is, you can't get them here in the Bay right? WRONG! Little Star serves up the most authentic deep-dish this side of the Mississippi. The crust is pure awesomeness when served up warm. The sauce? Well, it's saucy. Add the toppings and the cheese and you've got a winner. Not in the mood for deep dish? No problem. They serve up a thin crust that'll hit the spot. Best part is you won't get mugged while eating it. I can definitely say that you can get the best food from around the U.S. right here in the Bay. Aren't we lucky?
author: Axel G.

description: As a figure of speech, I felt like I was on drugs eating this pizza - it was seriously that good!  Each bite I took was heavenly and this is my all time favorite pizza spot in SF!  Its a must try, and be forewarn it looks closed fro the outside but it's open.  Make sure you get extra cheese!
author: Nazli P.

description: Absolutely love the thin crust and deep dish pizzas... im not a fan of crust but they make it so differently with cornmeal that taste so good.
author: Do L.

description: 1/2 classic deep dish & 1/2 little star deep dish! 2 pieces and I was beyond stuffed! We had to wait 30 mins for it. We didn't order anything else, we saved our hunger for the pizza. This is my first time eating deep dish pizza so it's defintely different from my usual thin crust. The pizza itself was stuffed and the classic was yummy! I love my meat! The cornmeal crust is to die for! There are as much tomatoes as shown in the pictures! My bf and I had a good experience and I found out deep dish isn't for me. Little star def has quality ingredients ;)
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Order take out, unless you want to be in the midst of a tiny but packed bar/restaurant.

Defaults: 
Spicy chicken wings (balanced peppery spices with absolutely - you must dip - tasty blue cheese dressing on the side)
deep dish classic sausage, mushroom
Thin crust Itailian combo
author: Miles G.

description:
This place brings me back to Chicago and my fond memories of these thick pizzas with delicious sauce and phenomenal crusts. If Chicago deep dish is what you like, then you gotta get to Little Star. 

Tonight I ordered out and had the spicy wings and the classic deep dish. I must say that eventhough the wings aren't buffalo style, they're great.  Here's the thing; buffalo wings are so damn common and the pursuit of the perfect wing often leads to dissappointment, I think this is why the intelligent folks at LS passed on the idea of the buffalo wing and created something that you'll develop a new craving. 

The pizza was awesome, totally Chicago, but with the classic San Francisco twist; Using (what looked and tasted like) fresh ingredients and chunky pieces of tomato, and mushrooms, this pizza was dare I say... better than Giordanos. 

I'm glad I have a place to remind me of one of my favorite food cities right here in my backyard!
author: Douglas L.

description: I suppose it's a little ridiculous to review the second Little Star location, when they both serve the same delicious deep dish pizza; however, there are distinct differences. Namely, the Valencia location doesn't feel quite so much like a cave, there is natural light coming in, and a reasonable level of ambient noise. It's not quite the assault on the senses that is the other location. I suggest this location over the other easily.
author: Herbert S.

description: the crust is excellent and crunchy. lots of corn meal to keep the crunch. liked the classic more than the little star. the wings had some extreme amount of pepper to them, so wasn't too much a fan of that.
author: M T.

description: there are over 1000 reviews of this place; about the pizza, see below.  As for me, I can say: this place has the BEST SALAD (the mixed greens salad) of any takeout/delivery pizza I've tried.   but instead of the house vinaigrette, I get the blue cheese dressing they give you with the chicken wings ... AMAZING.
author: Jaina S.

description: Cornbread crust?...GENIUS!  also, try their wings.
author: LIVE to E.

description: The pizza is amazing. My favorite is the little star. Yummy. Also, the garlic bread is a must.
author: Johanna W.

description: I'm a huge deep dish guy, but I don't quite understand why everyone raves about this place. The crust is above average, not out-of-this-world. The sauce and toppings are nothing to write home about. And the pizza expensive. Though I have yet to find a great deep dish pizza in SF, I'd take Patxi's over Little Star
author: Tom H.

description:
update:  last time we were there the food was great as usual.  When asked for our food to be wrapped to go, our server dropped our pizza on the floor.  She was very apologetic but it was 3/4 of our meal and we never got a replacement - oh well an off night .  still an awesome place.  

Now that EVERY one of my friends in SF is sick of hearing about desperate longing for Chicago-style deep dish pizza, there was a sigh of relief when I FINALLY made my way to Little Star Pizza.  If its one thing I miss from my hometown, its the pizza.  

Space:  simple, casual, low-key.  (it was unusually cold in the restaurant since they don't have heat and I did notice that no one took their jackets off when eating - my only minor complaint is that a whole room of people shouldn't have to keep their jackets on when in a restaurant especially when it wasn't that cold outside).

Service:  like the space - low-key and casual but very friendly. 

Food:   some of the best deep dish pizza I've ever had.  No one at our table was disappointed (and we are some hard-core pizza critics).  We all deep dish pizza (I'm not sure why you'd even order thin crust here since you can get that anywhere).

Overall, the best pizza I've found in the bay area and I can not wait to return.

(PS the juke box is excellent!)
author: J J.

description:
I have no idea why people rave about this place. We ordered a thin crust pizza, and got a pie that was burned on the edges and soggy in the middle, and had enough cheese to gag Jabba the Hutt. The sauce wasn't even that great, though if there had been more of it, I might have been able to taste it better.

The decor? Dark. Too dark. Not being able to even see my food is NOT HIP, people. Turn up the lights a little bit, please? Before I knock my damn wine over.
author: Shannon R.

description:
I am unable to weigh in on the great debate of the day because not only have I never ventured across the bay to try Zachary's; I have never in my life had a slice of deep dish pizza. I realize this will come as a great shock to many of you and you will most likely ignore my review but come on deep dish virgins have taste buds too!

So we decided to make our first attempt to Little Star on March 17 despite my long held belief that the only people that should be out on the street that night are the Irish and drunken amateurs. It appeared that I would be proven correct when we entered the crowded bar area to a woman slurring "I don't care if they do, I have been kicked out of better places than this" while chugging a glass of wine. We were told the wait would be about thirty minutes and decided to stick it out despite the aforementioned woman and one of dinning/drinking companions loud and drunken conversation about whether or not carrying a child for nine months was any big deal and a debate about the rights of fathers that was so cringe inducing I was happy they were clearly so wasted that they wouldn't remember it in the morning. 

Since we turned out to be the only party of two we got seated within ten minutes and were waited on promptly. Our eyes were much too big for our stomachs as we chose both the large salad, garlic bread, and a large classic deep dish (sausage, mushrooms, green peppers and onions) and a nicely priced bottle of wine from there short but well chosen selection. Everything came out in a timely fashion and the mixed salad was lovely with delicious fresh tomatoes and perfectly dressed, the roasted garlic and warm butter for you to slather on bread to your taste was also a lovely twist. 

The pizza arrived shortly after we finished the salad and was delicious with a firm and tasty crust and huge chunks of sausage. As has been mentioned the place is crowded, small and noisy and this was not helped much when the drunken party from earlier was seated next to us and apparently decided to mend their earlier argument with a drunken sing along of Def Leppard's Love and Affection, so I can't quite to commit to five stars but I will definitely be back due to my new love of deep dish. Maybe I will even venture across the bridge to compare.
author: Tara A.

description:
4.15.2007
8:00PM

My room mate and I came here after a little trip to Zeitgeist.  I've been introduced to their fare before (my room mate brought back their deep dish pie) and it was greasy, grimy, and gross.  

When I walked in, there were no traces of the 3 G's.

We sat at the bar because of the wait and ordered the wings.  I was really turned off and a little irked when they said they only served beer...WTF mange...get it done.  

My slinking around ended promptly after I bit into my first wing:  fucking bomb.

Eating wings while watching the bartender artfully pour beer and punk newb customers = awesome.  

They BAKE their wings after giving it a dry rub.  

How awesome is that.

For pizza?  Delphina me.

For wings...Little Star.
author: William R.

description:
UPDATE:

k... Finally ate INside... awesome.  My favorite is definitely the White Pie i can't stop eating it it is PERFECT (Thin crust whatever  you get is the absolute best ever ever, but even deep dish is awesome, cornmeal almost fluffly dough... mmm....  and the roasted garlic cloves that come with the garlic bread appetizer are  totally amazing and sticky and sweet and gooey and garlicky, but save room for the White Pie, mmm....)

OLDER Review:

thin crust plain cheese.
get pickup
best night at home ever.

(cash required)
author: Today Y.

description:
I'm from Philadelphia and I think this is the best pizza I've ever had. It was crazy good. We got a small deep dish classic and a salad and came nowhere near finishing it. The leftovers were just as good. I live down the street and fully expect to gain a hundred pounds here.

Update.
Ok, after 8+ years of being Little Star Valencia's neighbor, I need to remove a star. :-(

The "I don't care" service was one thing but now I've had a terrible tasting pizza experience. We ordered a thin crust pizza with green peppers, onions and sausage and it was the worst tasting pizza I've ever eaten from this otherwise great pizza place. No sauce and overwhelmed by kinda bad tasting sausage. I'll be back but am less confident in them than ever.

Update 2: The service has lost the attitude. I guess they realized that there is a lot of competition for dining dollars these days. Good for them. Fifth star restored.
author: Raj T.

description:
If you have a party of 4 or more arrive together cause you my friend will wait while those of us without friends will glide on in to the small, but friendly dining room.

The garlic bread was a total surprise it was a make your own affair with a bulb of roasted garlic, butter and hot bread all separate. All i could say was super sweet and breath is much worse for it.

Onto the pizza got the vegetarian without zucchini(cause really who likes zucchini be honest). Sauce on it was sweet and garlicky and just right. The veggies were a little hidden in the pizza and the cornmeal in the crust made the end of the slice not too great for me hence only 4 stars. If I could give decimals this would be like a 4.8
author: Chris G.

description:
Just go!  The best deep-crust Pizza I have ever had in my life.  Atmosphere sucks, but hey - its a pizza place-frickin deal with it.  Oh and drinks are cheap enough.

Note - I think its closed on mondays......that was very upsetting.  San Fran is so anti-capitalism!  G-D COMMUNISTS ALL OF YOU!

Oh - a note - I dont think either LS location is open on Mondays - always the day I seem to be craving.....
author: Aaron D.

description:
I just moved to the city in June, and I think I've finally found a Chicago style pizza joint that I love!  Thank you, Little Star!  The Vegetarian Pizza I had this evening was heaven on earth!!!!  The crust was perfect in all its cornmeal glory, the vegetables were fresh and delicious, and the cheese was so abundant and stringy--such a high quality!

To that end, I was further wowed with the wonderful service! 

Little Star, please open a restaurant in Nob Hill!!!!  There are a million New York style pizza places in my neighborhood, but none that specialize in the deep dish! :(

Bonus: The romantic dim lighting, the contemporary interior design, and the rich art work.
author: Jacqueline T.

description:
Reallly, really prepared not to like this place.  A party of 10 people, the usual 'we're too cool to take reservations, and you should be cool enough to enjoy it' trend (America, when are we going to give up and realize that just isn't cool, it's pretenious, and a sign of bad service?), having to show up early, make sure _everyone_ is there before you can seat us, etc.

So first, the service.  Terrific.  Unpretenious.  Nice.  Some hostesses seemed a little snooty, but not the waitress.

Then the salad.  Wow, where did you get those greens, the back garden? So fresh.  And then you had someone with a fantastic palatte who managed to dress it just enough, not too much.  Wonderful.

Finally, the pizza.   I'm not a deep-dish fan.  Okay, I wasn't a deep-dish fan.  But when it's that good, that buttery, corn-mealy crust (that also reheated well!  Amazing!  Not just that it reheated well, but that we had leftovers!) I'm all yours.

I'm going again.  Maybe even to go, if I can't get seated, but you guys, you're wonderful.  Just keep it up, the salads, the crust, and don't get too pretentious.....
author: Christina R.

description:
Yes, San Francisco, Little Star is good. However, it is not the God of Pizza Joints. It's just food.

Here's what stands out:
1. The cornmeal crust
2. The music

Beyond that, it's stuffed pizza. I like cheese as much as the next girl, but I'm nut sure it's worth waiting 45 minutes to sit, and then 45 minutes for food. Not to pick a fight, but at least at Zachary's they take your pizza order while you wait so that the food arrives shortly after you sit down.

If I reviewed this place the first time I visited, I would have rated it four stars, but last night my pizza wasn't served quite hot enough and the waitress gave us this bored stare when we didn't order within 15 seconds of her arrival at the table. Also, my pint glass was so over-frozen that chunks of ice were sliding off it, leaving puddles around my coaster. I've heard of chilled glasses, but this was excessive.

But the food was tasty, especially the salad. Overall I like this place, but not enough to wait forever.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Gotta love that cornmeal crust. it gives this surprisingly pleasant, grainy texture in your mouth that really complements the warm cheese and sauce.

But i still like Zachary's better. there's something about the doughy wheat crust and their tomato sauce that just makes their pizzas seem...fresher. i guess i'll go review Zachary's now.
author: Amy H.

description:
Yeah - I like it.  I would also like it if they took a reservation.  I get it - you don't want to deal with that... but hello?  I wanted to have my birthday there.  With, like, 20 of my friends!! You're really telling me that I have to cat-herd all 20 of my friends there an two hours before we plan on eating and HOPE you can fit us in?

Give me a fucking break.
author: Dutch G.

description:
Only once, and its good, fresh, and deep flavors.

I had the deep dish, and I was impressed.  The place is a zoo, so I stuck to take out.
author: Ken p.

description:
A friend of mine knows someone who worked at Little Star and she brought a deep dish pizza to a gathering.  It was one of the best pizzas I've ever had!  It was the Little Star special w/ riccotta and feta cheese and veggies.  I recently went back the other day and tried their vegetarian deep dish w/ italian sausage added.  It was so cheesy and yummy.  The crust was made of cornmeal and it was sooo buttery and crispy.  The restaurant was really busy, but the staff was very friendly.  However, be prepared to wait for your pizza.  Our pizza took about 30-40 minutes to make.  But good things come to those that wait!

I've never had deep dish pizza from Chicago before, but if it tastes anything like Little Star, then I definitely need to make a trip to the Windy City!
author: Jolene W.

description:
BEST pizza restaurant in SF.  Sometimes I forget that it's even a pizza restaurant.  Maybe the wait times in excess of 1 hour and the three pints to pass the time compromise the reviewer's state, but more likely, it's the addictive thin crust, the intoxicating salad, the bear hug of a deep dish, the wings, the beer.. everything is perfect.

It's right in the Mission, so get there any way but in your car.
author: Rion S.

description:
Semi-deep dish with a corn meal crust - just damn good. Our buddies Tim & Jay recommended it and they were right on. Kind of a trendy hipster place, not my thing, but we got the pizza's to go and had drinks at their place. It was the corn meal crust that really made this pizza great.

I've eaten lots of pizza over the years and this is now tops on my list. Number 2 is down in Pismo Beach at a pool hall, but we'll get to that later.
author: Michael E.

description:
You MUST try their thin crust pizza! I'm in LOVE with the crunchy, non-soggy crust of their white pizza. Even their deep dish (which I'm normally not a big fan of) was delicious and not super greasy like other places.

If you're in the Mission, like pizza, you have to go at least once!
author: Kitty N.

description: Pretty good...if you're not from Chicago and don't know any better. I can't say it tops Zachary's...by any stretch.
author: OKAY O.

description: The pizza is definitely the best deep-dish pie in town. I wish they delivered but they have a pizza ready for you in 30-minutes if you call in and come and get it. Noisy place to eat but 5 stars b/c of the pizza.
author: Ben L.

description: Pizza is to die for. Loved the cornmeal crust and drinks are not too over priced. The dining area is pretty small - but wait was not too bad.
author: Kara D.

description:
Take this for what it's worth--the food is five stars--something about this knocked me. 

After a long week, on a Friday night, a buddy of mine and I went there for dinner. I decided on wine. I had a glass before dinner, and one with dinner. We sat after that BS-ing around, and I decided I'd like one more. For some, I know red can knock em' out cold (read: My Mom), but a few glasses for me is making for a fantastic Friday night sleep. I ordered, and a manager came over, and told me she wouldn't be serving me any more booze. 

I was shocked. I can drink, and I know what drunk looks like, and what it sounds like, and I was nowhere near it. I asked my friend who was with me if I was rude, my speech was slurred, or something. He used to be a waiter, and doesn't drink, and he was completely shocked. I went home and told my wife, who was also shocked. 

Now--Little Star is a great place, and I don't think this detracts from it's good pizza, usually good wait staff, so don't judge too harshly. It was just that this incident--bumped, ney, jilted me off a little bit--about one star off, to the left.
author: Chad G.

description: This place is not for me. the crust is this cornmeal that tastes way too healthy to be a crust on a pizza. I would say that the toppings and sauce were tasty but I can't really vouch for everyone else that adores this place. I guess since Zachery's in Oakland does it so great that I just feel like the parking, and the gross tasting crust just doesn't do it for me.
author: Nina M.

description: We were in Chicago last month and were able to sample deep dish pizza so now we're looking for good deep dish pizza in the bay area. We're fans of Zachary's and a friend told us that Little Star is even better. I could not fathom a better pizza than Zachary's so I had to try. We went to Little Star last night and got the classic and mediterranean. The crust was perfect and crispy, not doughy at all. The tomato sauce was the best I ever had. I think Zachary's has met its match!
author: Daniel W.

description:
Order the 'Little Star.' 

Excellent cornmeal crust.

If you get there after 6pm you must be prepared to wait.
author: Robert V.

description:
On a weekend night, you'll have to wait a good 30 minutes to get a table. THEY DON'T TAKE RESERVATIONS!
And, YOU MUST PAY CASH! (even with the average bill being over $40. WTF?!?)
author: Mark B.

description:
Pizza is good (4 stars), service was horrible (1 star).     Came on a Tuesday night, 9:30-ish, not crowded, got seated right away.   There appeared to be at least 2 waitresses for maybe 8 tables of people.  Got our orders taken fairly quickly by our watiress, then it all went downhill.     She brought our drinks and Greek salad appetizer after about 10 minutes, but as we split the salad between plates, we noticed it had no olives (um, kind of key to a greek salad, even a simple one....)   Checked the menu, and indeed, olives were in the delicious description.   It took us too long to get her attention, and when we pointed out there were no olives, her answer was 'oh, its new so I guess they don't know how to make it yet'   and she didn't offer to do anything about it.   We had to ask her to fix it.  She took our plates and told us she would get a new salad......great!   Then we waited, and waited and waited.....15-20 minutes, no new salad.     How long can it take to make a greek salad that has only 5-6 ingredients?    

Our pizza was brought to the table (yay!), and about 2 minutes later our salad finally arrived.....although we had originally ordered a small salad they brought a large (maybe as an apology?).   And, it had a few olives now.     Once we tasted the pizza (delicious) we decided we wanted a few pizza condiments (dry peppers, grated cheese etc).   But, the waitress did not return after we got our food.   Ever.    We ended up having to ask the patrons 2 tables over if we could borrow their condiments.     
 
4 stars for the pizza, 2 stars for the salad (even with the olives it was pretty boring) and 1 star for the service.
author: Peggy J.

description: Best Deep Dish pizza I will ever try in my life.  The cornmeal crust was AMAZING.  For every 2 people I would get a 12".  Expect a line.
author: Jamie L.

description: I love Little Star. The deep dish pizza with mushroom was super yummy! If I go back, I will definitely order less. One slice by itself is enough to fill me.
author: Helen L.

description: This review is on service, not the food since we all know Little Star is the best gourmet pizza in the city. I already did a review for the food for the one over in my hood on Divis and McCallister and I have to say the one in the Mission has the edge as far as service and efficiency goes. I came in here with a group of 12 and luckily we were seated right away. Got here before the big dinner rush. The server was excellent. He was friendly and super efficient. He got our drink orders out fast. He got our appetizers out fast. And he got our pizza out fast while still checking on us frequently and clearing our table of dirty dishes. He also hooked us up with free desserts. I wish I could remember his name but with good service like that the food tastes even more better.
author: David C.

description:
Unfortunately, my metabolism let me down before I discovered Little Star. 
I would treat myself twice a week if I could. 

The deep dish pizzas are the best I have ever tasted, short of Pequod's 
(www.pequodspizza.com) in Chicago. 

I have ordered both the Vegetarian and Little Star signature (spinach and feta, mushrooms, onion, garlic) which were both outstanding. 

Never dined in, but the restaurant and bar have been packed both times I ordered take out.
author: Jason N.

description: The pizza here is good. There is nothing bad I can say about the food but the service could stand some improvement.I just don't really like paying for service that I don't get. Here's your pie and your beer, you're welcome. as soon as the pies came so did the check, and I have been known to order more pies when asked "can I get you anything else?". I guess this is not a place to enjoy pizza, I was sorry to bother them for being a restaurant. Good enough for take out but what's the point?
author: William R.

description:
We came here after a long bike ride on a Sunday evening with primed appetites. The pizza took a little while to show up, but made up for the delay. We got one each of the thin and thick crust. they had the freshest sauce and toppings I've had on pizza yet. 
this is definitely one of the places I would return to over and over again !
author: Asheem M.

description:
My out-of-town friends decided they wanted to move here after eating at Little Star. One of them actually used the word "orgasmic" to describe the pizza. 

There will be a wait if you go at dinner, and your whole party has to be there, but once the food comes it's absolutely worth the wait. My only complaint is that they're not open on Sundays!!
author: Dina S.

description:
Not bad service, sometimes fantastic and others just OK... so far never bad though. 

Excellent thin crust pizza! Love love love their white pizza! Nice wine selection ... and the gorgonzola walnut green mix is awesome!
author: Maddy S.

description:
I'm pretty sure I don't need to do this for their business but ...OMG!  This is the gift to the Mission from the Pizza Gods and Goddesses of yummy deliciousness!!!

Way better than Zachary's if you like deep dish Chicago style.  Their thin crust is pretty awesome, too.  And their salads are perfectly dressed and fresh.  The large is huge but two hungry people can easily polish it of with room for their ambrosianic pizza pie.  Yum!
author: Joe O.

description:
Growing up in the NY metro area, I have a very specific notion of what good pizza should be.  Of all the pizza I've had in SF, Little Star thin crust pizza comes closest to true NY style pizza.  I can't speak to the quality of their deep dish.

B+
author: Josh B.

description:
I lived in Chicago for four years, which was enough time to make me into a huge snob about "Chicago-style" pizza.  And this is the ONLY pizza I've ever had outside of Chicago that actually lives up to the name.  I've actually only ever had one kind of pizza here, the deep-dish "Little Star" pizza (their version of the canonical Chicago stuffed spinach pizza), but it's so good, why would I try anything else?  And I have to say, their salads are better than anything I ever had at a pizza place in Chicago.  

I greatly prefer the Mission location over the Divisadero one, which is louder and feels more cramped.
author: Jen W.

description:
Based on the quality of the food alone, Little Star easily gets five stars. It's definitely the best sit-down pizzeria in San Francisco. Also, the jukebox kicks butt!!! The best of the best late 80s and early 90s alternative rock ... you know, before alternative became so mainstream. 

So why 3 stars? I've been twice now and both times the host/hostess has been a total jerk! Since it was not the same person both times, i can only assume that they hire for this position based on the applicant's jerkiness. I know they must take a lot of flack from people who are frustrated to have to wait so long, but we got to the restaurant 45 minutes before the kitchen closed, were told to wait 30 minutes for a table ... so far, nothing to get that upset about. 30 minutes later we were told that we were not going to get a table and should order to-go or go somewhere else. 

If the message was bad ... the attitude was worse. She basically said to us: "well, if you want to go in the dining room and ask another table to leave, then be my guest." WHAT?!? This is horrendous service and just not cool. 

Advice to owner: 1) Keep your darn restaurant open longer and/or 2) don't tolerate employees who rudely turn customers away just because they want to zip home so they can get in a few bong hits before Jay Leno starts.
author: Scott H.

description:
gREAt place for chicago pizza.

Little Star special comes with spinach, ricotta, feta, onions and garlic. A large is enuf to feed 3 ppl and cost $23.  This place is cash only.

This is more of an adult pizza place.  The ambiance modern but its kinda dark inside.  They have a bar.  The crowd is in their 30's.  You won't see stroller moms or kiddies in here.

Parking in the area can be difficult.
author: Serena H.

description:
"You Have to try this place", so many people said.  Get the garlic bread app.  OK, OK, I'll go.  Get off my back will ya!  Showed up there at 7:30 exactly, Wednesday night and was a bit surprised that it wasn't a packed scream fest.  Checked out the menu,.  Yup, pizza, thin or thick crust, some by the bottle beers and soda and a few other things.  

OK, started with a salad cause that is what you are supposed to do, all healthy and stuff.  It was fine.  Very salad like.  The garlic bread showed up about the same time.  A nice warm half loaf with a garlicy butter spread on the side and a head of roasted garlic if you really wanted to get into it.  So far so excellent.  Then the deep dish corn meal crust Classic showed up.  Really fresh ingredients.  You could TASTE it in the mushrooms, sausage, pepperoni, bell peppers, tomatoes and tons of cheese.  Seriously, my mouth is watering right now writing this.  

The waiter was really nice but I saw him too much or maybe it's just that I'm not used to seeing one... ever...  in a restaurant.  The fact that he came back to check 3 or 4 times freaked me out but that is probably just me.  "Let me eat damn you!  MY pizza, get you own"

BTW, the leftover 2 slices were excellent the next day.  I thought the corn meal would get all soggy but seemed fine to me.
author: Mathew N.

description:
Great pizza, there's no doubt. 
It's a small place, and even though there's limited tables, the wait isn't usually more than 20-30 min for a table of four.  They have a cute little 6 person bar, and you can get a beer while you wait (note: no beer on tap at the one on Valencia St.).
One large deep dish is good for 4 people with medium-large appetites, especially if you get a beer - it's enough to have 2 well-portioned, well-topped pieces each)

I had to ding this place a star because it takes a while to get the pizza (~30-40 min after ordered).  And, because if you are really hungry and can't wait that long and order the garlic bread, you have to make it yourself... it comes as half a loaf of bread warmed up, regular semi-melted butter, and roasted garlic.  I'd say if you can't wait, get the salad, which looked really good.
author: Simmi M.

description:
I'm a San Francisco native so my claim that Little Star is the best Chicago-style deep dish pizza can only mean so much... but I've heard on several occasions from natives of Chicago that this place is damn good...

First timers should go for the Classic.  You won't be disappointed by the fresh tomato sauce that's perfectly balanced (not too tart, not too hearty).  But in the end it's all about the crust.  Sometimes I just crave the crust all by itself.  Oh the buttery, crispy goodness.

Be prepared for a long wait if you plan to dine in, but definitely do the pizza justice by eating it fresh on the spot.  It's just not the same after sitting in a box.
author: Brandon C.

description:
Little Star is far and away the best pizza I've had probably anywhere. So good. Deep dish is usually too greasy for me, but this one is not at all.  I dont think you can go wrong with a heavenly slice of the deep dish. The thin crust is good, but average (it hurts to disparage anything little star). The caprese is a great appetizer while you wait for the pizza. Garlic bread -- hot bread and whole roasted garlic cloves is also delicious, but dont spoil your appetite!

Atmosphere is also good -- the one on divis is more intimate and funky but it gets pretty loud. Long waits are worth it.
author: Morty M.

description:
I love deep dish. This place has a fantastic corn meal crust. Points for that. They are definately second string though to Patxis. For real. 

I'm really put off by how much of a hipster social scene this place is though. The only thing lamer would be if tables had Obama stickers and ipod docks or some shit. You can avoid all that nonsense by getting it 'to go' though.

Bully!
author: Lord Mandrake P.

description:
This pizza rocks about as hard as Madonna, and she's been rockin for 20+ years (no joke, right?!).  It's hella good pizza, but shit man, you really chargin' me that much for some dough, cheese, and whatever else i eat?  Can't complain-- i paid it.  Also, waitin to sit for pizza = annoying.  

Facts:  Good pizza, good ingredients, good location (down the street from Zeitgeist).

Opinions: I was drunk, so who really cares what I think?


It's good, it's like zachary's in berkeley.
author: Michael P.

description:
Came here cause I was craving some Chicago style pizza.  For those of you who haven't been to Chicago, there are actually two types of Chicago style pizza: deep dish and stuffed.  Unfortunately for me, Little Star serves deep dish.  The pizza was good, but I'm not a fan of deep dish.  

The happy hour special is pretty good, $1 off bottles.  We had a chance to get a couple, due to their "no seating until the entire party is present" policy.  And their obviously behind the times in that they don't ask if you want to pre-order your pizza while you wait for a table (like Zachary's and Patxi's does).  

Once we did get seated, our waiter never came.  The table next to us, which was seated after we were, had a waiter take their order and bring them water.  We had to ask the host where our waiter was.  Finally he came out of the kitchen area.  So, not only did we have to wait for the table, but also for the waiter.
author: Jory R.

description:
This update is just for the chicken wings and Italian Combo thin crust. Both were pretty good, but I wasn't blown away. The chicken wings aren't the best I've had (they were soft; I like my wings crispy/charred a bit) and they came with blue cheese dressing (I'm not that fond of blue cheese).

The Italian Combo was good, but didn't slap me in the face with goodness like the Classic or Pesto Chicken. It has pepperoni, salami, onions, green bell peppers, olives, and pepperoncini. Although the flavor was different, there just wasn't a good kick to it.

BUT! I still give 5 stars for the Classic and Pesto Chicken. =)

NOTE: THE QUALITY (AKA CRISPINESS) OF THE PIZZA IS INCREDIBLY BETTER WHEN YOU SIT IN. Take out is good, but really does not convey the deliciousness of this place.
author: Angela H.

description: Having experienced the joy that is Little Star on several occasions, I must say, best deep dish around. The day after one particular visit, I decided to head out to East Bay to see how Zachary's compares. Eh. It may have it's followers, but wasn't as good. I'll stick to the Star's crust any day. Killer spicy wings too!
author: Michael A.

description:
Checked this place out over the weekend. I'll start with the good. They picked up the phone and took our order. The pizza was ready when we got there. The service was fast and friendly.

Now the bad. The sign for this place is very tiny and quite easy to miss. We drove by it a few times before we finally found it. The pizza was so-so. The crust was over-cooked and burnt. The toppings were minimal at best. 

If you're looking for a place to eat in a pinch...this will do. 
If you're looking for a good pizza place, I'd recommend that you try another spot.
author: Dominic M.

description: The deep dish pizza here is absolutely delicious! I've gone to multiple locations and found the same quality and taste at every Little Star. The last time I went, the waiter did forget to deliver the salad I ordered and didn't remember until I mentioned it. I would normally knock a place down a star for forgetting my order, but she made up for her mistake with a lovely piece of cheesecake, which works for me. I'll definitely be going back and plan to take my parents too :) One small piece of negative feedback that I have is that their restaurants are small and i did feel a little crammed in my table at the mission location. Their other locations are a bit bigger. It's a small price to pay for their YUMMY food!
author: Katherine B.

description:
I know I'm like, the ONLY person who doesn't think garlic is the greatest thing ever, but too much of it makes me a little sick to my stomach.  Also, I've traveled Italy and found maybe 1/6 the garlic consumption you might expect.  

Anyway, this place is cozy and busy and relatively tasty, but I would've preferred some veggie pizza that maybe tasted a bit more like VEGGIES or CHEESE instead of garlic.  But the deep dish crust was really good, they have PBR, and it's not like there's a better place for high end pizza in the Mission, so I'll never veto it as a meeting place.
author: Tmon B.

description:
I love the thin-crust pizza here - especially the Classic - sausage, mushrooms, thinly sliced peppers and onions.  Yum!

Plus, champagne cocktails??!?  

Tasty :-)
author: Frances S.

description: Ehh, I think it's over-hyped.  I went on a date here once and just as the date was just ok, so was the food.  Caprese salad - decent.  Pesto chicken - ehh..I've had better.  But just to be sure this place wasn't for me, I tried it once more and ordered the little star deep dish to go.  This time.. the date was amazing!  But the pizza was still just ok.  Verdict? Keeping this guy, finding another pizza place...
author: Jessica W.

description: Some guys like 'em thick and stacked. I'm a girl who like her's solidly thin. We're talkin' about pizzas, baby. Little Star hit multiple spots I didn't even know I had.
author: Jen Y.

description: omg, best pizza I've ever had! normally I'm not a fan of deep dish but i was definitely a fan of this. We had a group of six and probably waited about half an hour on a Thursday night for a table. We started with the garlic bread, which they serve with a whole clove of garlic, yum. The table ordered three pizza's to share: the little star deep dish, the Italian thin crust and the white pie thin crust. The little star was delicious with feta and spinach and topped with tomatoes. The Italian was our choice for the table and it was so good too. nothing beats salty meat, but combined with pepperoncini's, even better. I've never had pizza with pepperoncini's, they added great flavor to the pizza. I only had a bite of the bf's white pie, but this was super good too. Now i know why everyone loves little star so much! i cant wait to go back!
author: Carolyn K.

description: Yummy! Garlic bread and a large deep dish with 2 glasses of wine and a friendly waiter. Score. I never realized I even lacked a place like this in my life. Sooo good!
author: Aurora B.

description:
For those of you who hail from the East Bay and love Zachary's, I have finally decided that Little Star has passed them up in my book.

The "Little Star" pizza, seemingly the same as the "Zachary's Special", has an extra added kick of flavor and is a bit less heavy on the cheese than its predecessor.

The crust is scrumptious!  It is a bit more crispy, although a bit more oily (in the good olive oil way), but also more falvorful.

The thin crust pizza is a bit better at Little Star, although who goes to Zachary's to eat thin crust!?  I highly recommend the White Pie.

Plus, one thing i like about Little Star, is that both locations are just somewhat hidden, dark and not clearly advertising, as if they want to stay underground or something.  That being said, it is not as "fun" to go to Little Star as it is to Zachary's, since you don't feel the vibe of a world-class favorite restaurant.
author: Zachary F.

description:
So that is what Chicago style means!!! The sauce and stuff are on TOP on the cheese.  Brilliant!  (Leftovers weren't soggy the next day!) Nice place, good crust, very fun.
*CASH ONLY - Important to remember that ; )*
author: Alicia W.

description:
This place proves again that one does not need to travel to the East Coast to have great pizza.  This is the best deep dish pizza that I've ever had.  

Most deep dishes tend to be greasy, but the crust of the pizzas here come out just perfect.  Don't quote me on this, but it looks like the crust has a good amount of cornmeal, which gives it a very nice, crisp, clean taste.  I also love the variety of toppings and pizzas they offer.  

You can definitely expect a long wait for seats if you don't get there when they open.  From our experience, it takes a while for the pizzas to be made which means that turnover is slow from party to party.  But, if you don't care to eat in-house you can order take out.  

I wish I live closer to LS so I can eat here more often.
author: Star Y.

description:
Amazing crispy pizza crust that starts with a crunch and softens into a buttery dough so amazing you don't know how you didn't hear about this place sooner!

All pizzas come in two sizes and they serve two styles...a thin crust and their famous deep dish with the most amazing marinara soup on top! The staff is fun, polite and engaging but make sure to come with a full wallet they only take cash!

A full fledged cult phenom Little star leaves you with midnight cravings for more!
author: Christopher S.

description:
So I would give Little Star 5 stars, because I love the pizza and its one of the only restaurants I CRAVE sometimes (I even learned to make cornmeal pizza crust at home because of it), but I have had at least 2 occasions where the wait staff weren't the most friendly. And I am, I think, pretty dang easy going when it comes to wait staff.

So... food = wonderful. Wait staff = not always uber sweet.
author: Jen B.

description:
Everyone talks about the fantastic deep-dish pizza. It's really that good. Cornmeal on the crust takes it to that next level--crispy and delicious.

But seriously, the best thing about this place is their CHICKEN WINGS! Rubbed in spices--not dripping in sauce--their chicken wings are the best things there. My ex-girlfriend is a WING-CONNOISSEUR and has requested them for our anniversary, valentines day, and her birthday. They are that good.
author: Marc M.

description:
My mouth is watering just thiking about the "Little Star" signature deep dish with ricotta, feta, mushrooms, onions and garlic . I don't know why people are comparing it to Zachary's...for me they are very different pizzas. The cornmeal crust is what makes this Little Star a stand-out. 

What makes this place even more impressive is that their thin crust pizza is equally delish. I was a doubter, but with friends one night we ordered both and did a side-by-side taste test. We couldn't decide which was better.
author: K L.

description:
This is some good damn pizza.  I prefer the thin crust -- I've never been a deep dish fan.  The caprese salad is solid too.  I like my pizza plain -- straight up with some fresh tomatoes and basil.  I've eaten here a number of times and this place has never disappointed. 

Minus one star because it can get crowded and loud here (and there's limited wait space at the Divis location), and some of the servers can have a bit of attitude.
author: mazzy r.

description:
WHITE PIE! WHITE PIE! WHITE PIE!

(& no im not talking about some white girls pnanny)
im talking bout the best pizza (i think) on their menu.  simply delish.  get the bread w/ the kick-ass roasted garlic on the side, too.

waiting (they swear their buca di beppo w/ this rule) until everyone arrived teabagged, but the the food made up for it.
author: Lady K.

description:
Love Little Star!  

Only eaten at the restaurant a couple of times as I usually get it to go.  

I grew up on a lot of East Coast thin crust pizza and never thought I'd go for deep dish pies.  Little Star has changed my mind.
author: Jayna B.

description:
EDIT-- this place most definitely takes reservations, but ONLY the valencia address takes reservations. You can call between 3-5pm tuesday-sunday to make reservations. 

I agree with Eugene F. above, patxi's is better. 

This place has been so hyped. Went here yesterday, was expecting the best tasting pizza ever. We got two pizzas, one sausage/pepperoni/garlic and one with chicken/sundried tomatoes/gorgonzola. 

They both tasted exactly the same. Couldn't taste the garlic on the one pizza at all. 

One star for taking reservations and seating us the second we walked through the door. 

One star for the cheesecake and the candle they put in for one of our birthday's.

One star for not being hungry after I left. 

Overall -- probably would not go back again. 

Will try Zachary's in Berkeley next!
author: parker p.

description: Our table might have been a bit rowdy. We received some looks from a few of the Saturday night cool kids. Our server was super friendly. An impromptu pizza party with good company, copious amounts of good wine, and The Red Hot Chili Peppers seriously clogging up the jukebox. Not our doing (a certain employee was really grooving out) and it just added to our laughter at one point. Really? loved some peps back in the day...but more? two hours thick. We started with the green goddess and it was a perfect salad. Then the chicken wings. They are roasted and not of the typical buffalo variety. I appreciated this fact but we agreed a tad under seasoned and the blue cheese needed to be thicker. We decided on the classic deep dish and the thin crust white pizza. The deep dish was impressive. Unfortunately, it was a slightly watery and it was mostly crust (insanely good crust) and sauce, not my favorite. The white pizza really let the flavor of the dough shine but I was missing tomato sauce. Hmmm. I'm thinking that the thin crust cheese pie with tomato sauce must rock! I do not need to hear the big star kiedis lisp funk for awhile. Overall, it was a stellar intro to the little star. We'll be back.
author: Staci W.

description:
Three stars for my thin crust "classic: pizza" - sausage, bell pepper, onions, mushrooms, plus I asked for olives as well.  Pretty yummy, but the sausage had unpleasant fatty bits that were not good.  So next time I will not get a sausage pizza.  
Four stars for my companion's veggie deep dish pizza.  It's like lasagna in a pizza.  Awesome tomatoey goodness.
I was there for lunch on a Friday, there were only 2 other parties in the restaurant.  The service was SO ridiculously slow, especially considering there were so few other people in the restaurant.  I understand the pizza is made to order, but what's the waitress' excuse for not checking in, and taking forever to bring the check and pick up the credit card?  Kindof annoying.  She seemed perfectly nice, but boy was she slow!
author: Lisa B.

description:
"That is such good pizza..."  Those five words encapsulate the experience that is Little Star Pizza. 

Let me start by giving my pizza credentials- I love pizza, I love pizza aLOT.  I eat pizza probably three to five times a week.  I have eaten every type of pizza and enjoyed them all, almost...  I can say that there is only one piece of pizza that I remember that was not good.  And, by not good, I mean it was horrible- and the place in Glen Park that I bought that rubbery cheese piece of doughy grossness is long gone, having been replaced by Gialina (another great pizzeria that gets its own review).

Now to Little Star...I grew up on Ken's Pizza in Tahlequah, Oklahoma.  It was thin, thin crust and extra crispy goodness.    That is NOT Little Star.  

Little Star does offer a thin crust, but it is heresy to eat that when you can enjoy the thick crust goodness that makes this place so special.  I have not tried every pizza they have-I am only a pepperoni and/or sausage guy.  And, boy do they make a great deep dish half pepperoni and half sausage pizza.  

When I need to put something a little healthier than dried meats like pepperoni into my system, I have to say that the salads are really hearty and very good.  

While I have eaten in the restaurant a couple of times, pizza is best when it is eaten in front of your own TV in your comfy bunny slippers.  Not that I actually have comfy bunny slippers (anymore) the point is that Little Star travels well.  

While it can get a little uncomfortable having a hot pizza with the name Gerald scribbled in crayon on the box (the kitchen is loud so they though Joe was Gerald...),sitting on your lap for 15 minutes, the discomfort was worth it.  

When we got home and dished up the slices, I wasn't even seated before  Faith (the border collie) was  waiting for her share.  Happily scarfing down a slice of the best deep dish pepperoni around using knife and fork (which are required for this kinda pizza), I stopped at the crust's edge and got a piece for Faith.  My finger almost came off as she took that little slice of heaven with a bit of tomato on it from me...
author: Joseph S.

description:
So I waited for a table for up to an hour, but entertained myself by hanging at the bar and talking about the old days with my b/f.  When we finally got a table, we ordered the garlic bread, Little Star deep dish pizza, and red wine.  The garlic bread was...eh, okay, but the pizza was light and fresh.  Good stuff.  My boyfriend usually refuses to eat bell peppers, but he really enjoyed the pizza.  After eating only 2 slices, I was full and took home leftover pizza.  For the next couple days, I ate the leftovers, and the slices still tasted pretty good.  

So, come here if you are willing to wait for some yummy pizza.
author: Dylan's Aunt E.

description: I've had Zachery's, but little star takes the title for the best of deep dish pizza in the bay area.  They get the award because of service and the cornmeal crust that taste like it been lightly fried and crunchy.  My fav is the classic with roasted garlic(extra), italian sausage, mushrooms and olives... Zachery's is a close second I must say.  LS's thin crust is not that thin but very good as well.  I like eating there at both establishments actually.  There always a little buzz around... The bartenders are generally nice and fun to talk to...
author: Vinh N.

description: Little Star Pizza has the best deep dish pizza I've had in awhile, if ever?  I heart it's perfectly cutable thick crust that you don't have to fight to position the best bite.  It's great!  The scene is very Hipster and cute.  The garlic and bread is a must as well.  I will be back soon!
author: Jessica G.

description: My daughter and I visited during our SFO vacation because I read the Yelp reviews and wanted to introduce her to deep-dish pizza. It was good Perhaps if I had never eaten Chicago deep-dish pizza I would feel differently about it, but this didn't come close to my Chicago experiences. We also both found it a bit off-putting that the toppings refused to stay on the crust. We were also elbow-to-elbow with other patrons, to the point that it was not easy for people to sit down or get up from their tables. I'm not sure if I would return.
author: Charles L.

description:
I must say, I was never a fan of the thick or deep dish pizzas...

HOWEVER, after my sister took me to Little Star, I changed my mind completely. I LOVE, absolutely LOVE their deep dish pizzas. I tried all the vegetable deep dish specialties (my sister is a vegetarian) and I was amazed! The crust is so flaky and is juicy in its buttery goodness and I REALLY RECOMMEND this place for all you pizza lovers as well as hesitant deep dish pizza eaters out there.

lesson learned: DON'T HATE IT UNTIL YOU TRY IT! =)

Note: The cheesecake is delicious too!
author: Hillary M.

description:
Delicious!  Both the thin crust (which was quite crispy, as I love it) and the deep dish (go with the Little Star) were quite tasty.

We got pick-up, and as it should be, pizza was perfectly ready and hot when we arrived to get it - 30 minutes after putting in the phonecall.

Seemed to be a decent wait for dining in, but very cute ambiance (similar to the Divisadero one, but a bit more cozy and updated).

I'd go again.  Soon!
author: Tamra K.

description:
Living in the Mission, I love Little Star, but there are things about it that make it a little painful to eat at:

Positives! Great pizza, both deep dish and thin crust. The deep dish especially comes made with that corn-mealy goodness that makes it crispy on the outside and flaky on the inside. Fabulous. Also if you like extremely saucy pizza which I do, the pizza at Little Star is very saucy. It's also a bit of a "scene" for a pizza place so if you're up for feeling a little hip and trendy while eating your pizza then it's a good place to go.

Boo, Negatives... Man this place is slow. There is always a crowd so be prepared for a wait. I remember on election night that they sold out of pizzas because of all the people. Sometimes it can be 45 minutes to 1 hour+ to get seated, and another 30-45 minutes to get your pizza after you order it. Take out is a good alternative as that "only" takes 30-45 minutes, but that's a long time to wait for pizza if you're hungry. Also it's incredibly loud inside the restaurant so you better want to be part of the "scene" if you are dining in at Little Star.

Definitely if you haven't gone before, go! But know what you're getting into...
author: Michael P.

description: Magical! The pizza is amazing and our server Todd was impecable! This is a definite if your in SF and are craving pizza! Love, love, love everything about it!
author: Victoria J.

description: Delicious deep dish pizza combined with fun Sparkling Wine cocktails equals a great night out with friends! My favorites are the vegetarian pizza (love the zucchini) and the Hey Kool Aid cocktail. Cornmeal crust is crunchy and moist, love it!
author: Kim C.

description:
Can I just say BEST DEEP DISH PIZZA EV-ER!

I don't think I've had a deep dish pizza this good!  I've been here a few times and always get their Classic and LIttle Star deep dish.  It always tastes like heaven =D.  On my most recent trip, my friend and I decided to try something else on the menu and tried their Mediterranean Chicken deep dish and their Italian Combo thin crust pizza.  I think I'll be sticking to my usual of Classic and Little Star deep dish because the Mediterranean Chicken and the Italian Combo were a little bit salty for my taste.  It wasn't the chicken that made it salty but the artichokes on the deep dish.  I don't think they thoroughly rinsed it to be honest.  As for the Italian thin crust, I think they put too much of the pepperoncini that made the pizza very salty = /.  But all in all this place has a great ambiance and mood.  It's a great place to come and hang out and catch up with your friends or even have a date =)

One thing though, this place is a little bit on the small side so expect to wait for a table and it's always packed no matter what day of the week (trust me I've tried coming here on differet days of the week and it still gets packed).  If you get there between 6-7 there usually isn't much of a wait, but after that...be ready to wait.  They won't seat you either until all your entire party has arrived.
author: Bertie Y.

description:
Disclaimer: I am originally a New Yorker, so maybe I just don't get the deep dish thing.

That said, this kind of salty, too-sweet crust with the chunky sauce just doesn't get the job done for me. I like hanging out here, but I'm not feeling the food. Will gladly report back once I've tried the thin crust--maybe that will be more to my New York pizza-snob liking.
author: David K.

description:
This is NOT party pizza. I had eaten here alot but always like with friends or to get some chicken wings - witch are AMAZING - to take home, but a few weeks ago i got this pizza for a party, lets just say 4  pizzas over 100 bucks. I mean it was a party, and i dont mind throwing down for some pie, but the WORST part was i didnt even get any. ok ready for the moral - if your going to get pizza from the best pizza place in SF, MAKE SURE YOU GET SOME!

The few times that i have actualy eaten here have been really nice, they have a jukebox filled with some really great music, and trust me pizza, the postal service and friend is just one of those unbeatable combos.
author: David P.

description:
No need to reiterate other reviewer's comments at much length.  

We ate in and had fabulous plain cheese deep dish pizza and glasses of chianti.  Good table service.  Didn't have to wait long for a table.  

No complaints.  Highly recommended.  Great Chicago style pizza.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Although Little Star does provide the best option for deep dish pizza in San Francisco, over all, it definitely does not live up to the hype.

Food: thin crust pizza is underwhelming - far better choices are Pauline's pizza (just down the street), Delfina Pizzeria, or Gialina in Glen park.  The deep dish is delicious, although not nearly as good as Zachary's in the East Bay. 

Service: Bordering on awful.   In general, I am tired of hipsters posing as waiters.  If you want to wear three shades of black and look mildly disinterested, that's your choice, put don't expect me to tip you 15% for the pleasure of being in your company.  Specifically, the servers  rushed us off our table at the end of our meal.  If I order a salad, two pizzas, beer and wine, and dessert, I (just like any other patron) deserve the privilege of monopolizing a table for at least two hours. 

Added sadness - there is only one bathroom, which means a long line.  Boring!  I may take out from Little Star if I crave deep dish, but I will not return as a guest.  i advise you not too either.
author: Jesse R.

description:
Hands down, the best pizza in the city.
  Deep dish or thin, you cant go wrong!!!  
I buy an extra pizza whenever i go, individually wrap each slice and freeze them for  late night munchies or when i have nothing else to eat in the house.
author: sfc j.

description:
Dull. 

Tedious interior. Narrow topping selections. Fine it's DEEP DISH but that is simply VOLUME. Cash? What planet are these folks from? Cash is for poor folks. No style. Utterly without style.

Pauline's is clearly superior. I simply don't get the pizza fetishism. Salads are just passable. This is a plain pizza joint that has DEEP dishes. It's one dimensional.

As the man said:
In matters of gravest importance style, not sincerity, is the vital thing.
author: C M c.

description: Definitely not nearly as good as the deep dish pizza in Chicago.  Overpriced.
author: AJ B.

description: I was pretty excited to try this place after reading the reviews. Don't waste your time. Go to Pauline's about a block away over this place.  The acoustics in the restaurant make having a normal conversation without screaming almost impossible.  I have a sore throat after eating there last night. We had the mixed green salad. This was fine.  We ordered their signature pizza, the little star deep dish, and it was bland and tasteless.  Even after I salted, put crushed red pepper and parmesan on it, there was still no flavor.  With so many great restaurants, I will not be giving this a second try.
author: Carrie C.

description: Really good deep dish pizza.  We had the vegetarian and it did not disappoint.  Our pizza arrived loaded with yummy mushrooms & peppers & zucchini, it was just the right size for four of us, we all left with full tummies.  Deep dish is a little decadent, but sometimes you just need to go for it.
author: Emily T.

description: i'll let you in on a little secret...you can order from the menu at the bar!!! the bf and i put our name down on the wait list of 45ish mins, went to the bar to grab a drink, found two seats, and was offered the food menu. we had struck gold! this place cannot be more perfect. i eat a mostly vegetarian diet while the bf eats a man diet(meat), so a small half-and-half makes us both really happy. every time we're in the mission, i'm always thinking of an excuse to ditch our dinner plan and come here instead. i.can't.get.enough.of.little.star!
author: Melissa Y.

description: I love Little Star pizza, they have the best crust and the service to back it up. I've never once had any problems with wait or quality, it is always awesome. The day they deliver will be like Christmas to me, but I like going in and seeing all the artwork and atmosphere...so it's a toss up haha.
author: Alicia C.

description: affordable wines, great pizza and a super cool space. they even have a juke box!
author: Ameer N.

description:
