let me just tell you that i grew up in chicago, so i know bit about deep dish pizza, well little star's somwhat california-rized made chicago perfection better!  i didn't even know that was even possible.
i  have some friends who are from chicago in the bay, and we both agree littlestar's pie is better
author: Joseph K.

description:
I went to Little Star in Western Addition a few years ago and enjoyed the meal, so when my colleague and I were looking for a place to eat in the Mission, I thought Little Star would be a great choice. It was a half-block from where we were seeing a play that night and pizza sounded good.

The location in the Mission is very nice. They pack the tables in, yet you feel that you have a enough space to chat and don't feel crowded. We arrived 15 minutes late (damn you lack of parking in the Mission!) but the hostess accommodated us, which seems to be rare based on the other reviews. When seated we were offered a table by the front window or towards the back. Our Hostess asked if we wanted a seat near the window or further back. After we choose back, he said, "Are you ok with sitting near the kitchen?" I really appreciated the fact that he said that. Our waiter was very kind and attentive.

We split an aptly named Little Star pizza that was delicious. It absolutely hit the spot. The flavors mixed well and there was not a dominant ingredient. I greatly enjoyed the entire meal and highly recommend this restaurant. I won't be throwing around five stars too often, but this succeeded.
author: Justin C.

description: SOO good.  We come here almost every time we're in the city.  The  garlic bread is delicious (they give you a whole head of roasted garlic w/ sourdough) and deep dish crust is perfect - crispy but not too heavy.
author: Lanee J.

description: We kept hearing Little Star was the best in SF. They don't deliver though, so it took a long while before we tried it. This past Monday, roomie and I decided to walk down there and try this fabled pizza. Ya, we could have eaten it there, but the whole point of pizza is to sit at home and be lazy and watch tv while you eat it, not to sit in a restaurant. We chose the Little Star special flavor. It's vegetarian with different cheeses. The pizza was cold by the time we walked all the way home. Annoying. We had to warm it in the oven. Once we did though - yum! So many of my favorite things on one pizza! So yummy! The sauce was awesome, the blend of flavors, awesome. I love Chicago deep dish pizza! The crust was very good too, nice and soft. I suppose it was cornbread.  I have to say, it's not as good as Patxi's cornbread crust. Patxi's has deep dish Chicago pizza and is closer to my house. Plus they DELIVER. Little star's sauce was a tad bit better, though I like both. Little Star's pizza combinations, esp on this one, are better.  Patxi's crust and delivery are better, and you get a hot pizza and to be lazy. So, it's a tie. On a lazy day, neither of us will make the trek over to get this, but once in a while, we'll be craving it. It was so good, I was full and lamenting how I couldn't fit another piece. We both had to rest up in order to stuff more in our stomachs. I had 3 pieces in the end, over some hours. SO FILLING. Yum.
author: Merredith L.

description: Garlic bread + little gem salad + Little Star deep dish = perfect meal. And I don't even think it was because I was starving after the expected hour-plus wait. I too am sold on the cornmeal crust.
author: Robyn M.

description: Pizza was decent. Wait was horrendous. Worst part was the hostess, she didn't even give us water or comp any of our apps after having to wait over 1.5 hours for a table of 7 people. We were waiting on another table that was taking their sweet time. When 2 tables opened up, that could easily seat 7, she took a party of 5 and another of 2 versus us and when I asked if we could be seated there she replied with "I am just doing my job". You will never catch me at this joint again.
author: R P.

description:
I drool just thinking about this pizza! It's a cool, trendy atmosphere and the pizza is the best in the city. They also have great salads.

Trust me, try it!

The only downsides-
Usually a long wait to sit down
No delivery option
author: victoria S.

description:
Recipe for a perfect day in SF =

Go to Zeitgeist at about 3pm on any gorgeous, sunny day.  Order one of their hit-the-spot bloody mary's.  Hang on the porch with some pals.  Get some more bloody marys, then maybe some beers. Get hungry and walk over to Little Star at 5 or 6 and chow down.

The pizza's the bomb but the WINGS are A-FREAKIN-MAZING.  

They're not buffalo wings, so no frying involved.  Our server (who admitted to stealing the recipe and making them at home) told us that they coat the wings in a bunch of spices then roast them.  Then they roast them a second time to give them a little bit of crisp on the outside.  SOOOO good, we had two orders between the 4 of us (2 pounds o' wings) and housed them in 5 minutes.

The pizza's also great, but you have to love lots of sauce and garlic galore.  Service is great and beers are cheap!

Go early, tho- place was packed by 6pm.  Oh, and cash only.
author: Camille C.

description:
Yes, the pizza is fantastic (I'm a fan of the thin crust Italian special).  BUT Little Star gets five stars in my book for being the only restaurant in SF with an ATM in the lobby that has a $.25 surcharge. That's right peeps, stop by on your way to the bars! Twenty five cents. God bless Little Star Pizza and their cash only policy. 
PS: I've known Ed since 7th grade and he's rad.
author: Rachel D.

description:
I am a pizza snob. Rarely does anything outside of NY state or Italy ever live up to my standards. I realize you can't really compare deep dish with NY pizza, but i just need to caveat my feelings toward pizza. I avoid going out for pizza when possible simply because I'd rather not be disappointed.

Well anyway, finally went to little star, a place i've heard a lot of good things about. And yes, I actually liked it... as far as liking deep dish pizza goes. I still don't understand the hype with Zachary's pizza in Oakland. But this stuff was good! Also a pretty cool atmosphere inside. Great place for a relaxing night to catch up with old friends.
author: pam k.

description:
Man o Man, Was this place killer.

I took my lady here last night and we would consider ourselves pizza connesiuers and I must say little star has some of the best pizza i have ever tasted.

Make a res, it makes the experience a lot better. I walked in and there was like 30 people waiting for a table. When you make a res and are there on time, You walk right in and sit down, nice.  Great drink selection. My lady got a hooker drink (Champagne cocktail)  and I had a boont amber which was a pretty good brew to wash that pizza down with. 

We ordered a large Mediterranean and took half of it home, It was incredible. I have eaten at Zac's many o times and i would honestly say that Little Star is on the same level.
author: Blake C.

description:
I've never been much of a fan of deep dish pizza, until I tried Little Star. My fiancee and I eat here once, sometimes twice, a month, because they make the best cornmeal dusted crust and the best spicy chicken wings. They also serve Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout, which has to be one of my favorite beers. 

Service is fast and friendly, and pricing is relatively inexpensive. Because it's so good, it tends to get very crowded during dinner time, but if you cruise by for lunch, you won't have to wait.
author: Irene N.

description:
This is the best pizza I have ever tasted.  I've lived in NYC, Chicago, and have tried pizza all over the planet.  If anyone wants to challenge my declaration that Little Star is the best pizza in the world I will kick their ass.

Zachary's in the Yeast Bay was disgusting, doughy, yeasty, and bland.
There is no comparison to Little Star.  

The deep dish cornmeal crust here is the best pizza crust.  I've actually gotten pissed off when I have to eat other pizza because it's not Little Star. This place rocks and all other pizza places suck as far as I'm concerned.  The beer, salad, cheesecake and indie rock are all good too.
author: Davidian A.

description: I've been a fan since they opened because of their good thin crust/deep dish/music/Racer5/laid back atmosphere.  My usual used to be the veggie deep dish or a make your own thin crust pie + a mixed salad & these always did me right.  Most recently I went w/ friends forcing a change up in ordering.  We had the roasted garlic bread (big roasted bulb o' garlic goodness to spread on sourdough+olive oil butter blend) as well as the thin white pie & spinach deep dish.  Maybe I just like what I like, but these didn't make me swoon like my usuals.  Still good though. The pizza sauces are seasoned well w/ lotsa herbs & toppings are quality.  My favorite thin crust pizza in SF & I prefer their deep dish to Zachary's. Service is a-ok & the space is chill.  Keep on shining on Little Star.
author: Kimberly C.

description: An amazing deep-dish pizza. Just amazing. We order 3-4 pies, each was equally tasty. Theres a wonderful finish, crunch and flavor to the crust. However, like most classic places, theres a long wait.
author: Jaymes H.

description:
this place reminds me of a lesson i learned when backpacking around europe for 4 months.  you're in Madrid, or, say, Berlin or Rome or where ever.  you read a review or hear something about a great place (which happens to be across town); you step outside your hostel and look on your map and get on a bus or a metro (if madrid) or a tube (if london) and you spend a good portion of the day traveling to the recommended restaurant/cafe to find that it is.... well, a pretty okay place.  solidly above average.  Solidly!  but it dawns on you that you could have probably thrown a rock from the doorstep of your hostel and hit 3 places just as good and saved yourself a heck of a trip across a busy metropolis.  remember this lesson and you'll be happier in life and save yourself a lot of time.

i do not understand why people get so bent out of shape about decent pizza.  i mean, are people really so starved for good pizza that they all have to go to the same pizza place?  is pizza rare these days?  or it is GroupThink?  mob mentality.  we must ALL GO to the same places all the time. if they are going, i must go.  we must all go.  pizza is basically pizza.  the salad was pretty much a salad. don't get me wrong.  it was good and all.  the sangiovese wasn't bad either.  the mixed salad was fresh and the dressing was tastey, but rare?  ah no.  i'll give it a four, i suppose but when you're talking about the basics (and i include pizza in that) the line between 3 and 4 starts to get blurry.  our group shared two deep dishes.  one veggie and one sausage.  i think that and the salad was good for a group of four.  
 
the spot was slick and clean and the decor was well put-together for a pizza place. i expected a lot more sloppy and hap-hazard but this was clearly a pizza place that thought it was a sit-down restaurant.  :)  which it is.  but most pizza places think of themselves not as restaurants but as "places that make pizza" and simultaneous, it just so happens that they have places to SIT while you all can eat the purchased pizza.... 
 
little star definitely puts itself in the "restaurant" category.  not a bad deal.  again, i can't see the super-special need that required us to drive half-way across town to go here at 8pm on a friday and wait like an hour for a seat with a room crowded with 60 or so people also waiting for tables.  by the time i sat down i was both really, really hungry and my expectations had soared so high from seeing the lines of people that i was pretty disappointed to find out that they poured regular ol' sangiovese for wine and when making their pizza, they used regular old dough and veggies and sausage like every other pizza joint i've ever been to.
author: dan h.

description:
Newish Location. Fresh and Hip. Deep Dish, but crunchy crust.. Usually packed out. Beer in bottles, comes in a glass. Nice staff, not pushy. 

WARNING: Try not to get distracted by the sound of the knife cutting on the plate. For some reason this got me good.
author: James B.

description:
this was my favorite restaurant on my trip to SF. I usually hate cold mozzarella - I had a traumatic experience. But, their caprese salad is simply mouth watering goodness!!!!! The service was great too! Our waitress checked up on us every few minutes or so. ;} 

I'm accustomed to Pizza Hut's deep dish because that's all I see in LA. I never order it because I know how much oil goes into the pan ( '_' ) 
But Little Star's deep dish is nothing like commercial deep dish's. It actually has flavor!!!! The Vegetarian deep dish is just awesome. It was zucchini, red onion, red bell pepper, and all these other yummy vegetables! 

The Cherry Soda was a nice compliment to my dinner. 
OH!!! and the cheesecake is a MUST try! 
So make sure there's room for a lil' piece of heaven. 
:drool:

:)
author: Ana M.

description:
my most Favorite pizza in the world.
Hands down.
their caprese and mixed greens salads are drool-worthy too.
if i could marry a slice of pizza, i'd marry a slice from here.
i'd have a hard time not eating our babies though.

the kids running that place are phenomenal too. big ups!
little star,
BIG SMILE.
author: jess c.

description: I want to go one more time before I give it the full five.  I went with a friend and had something that might have been more her speed.  Needless to say it was delicious -- and the wine is quite good too! -- but I'd like to go back and be able to get something I'm truly craving.  Only THEN can I be a good judge.  For anyone reading this who's never been, I say definitely give it a go!
author: Beccie F.

description: Yum, the crust is just so delicious. I haven't had Little Star for awhile, but they lived up to what I remember. Tonight we ordered the special pizza, which had broccolini, yellow squash, tomatoes and lots of cheese. It was delizioso!! Yum yum yum! It's very filling and a small can definitely feed two people. We also ordered the caprese salad to start, which had about 7-8 pieces of mozzarella and tomatoes.  Apparently we made it for happy hour specials because the beer was only $2.74! $2.74!!!!!!
author: Natalie S.

description:
this food is aMAZING!!!   the deep dish is to die for, the thin crust as well.   and you for sure have to try the buffalo wings, oh my god!   
the staff is super friendly and nice and always good for a recommendation.   and...  they have pbr!
author: Briana R-k B.

description: I love deep dish pizzas and heard this was the place to go.  After many months of procrastinating, I finally got the opportunity.  By the way, they extended their open hours.  The pizza was o-k-a-y.  I think all the hype and anticipating got to me.   Also, I think the pizzas are on the pricey side.
author: Ricky M.

description: Mmmmm!!  The Little Star deep dish pizza is delicious as was the gem salad.  A small salad was definitely enough for 2 people to split.  I love getting their pizzas and heading to Dolores Park for some picnic time.  I think I could eat a Little Star pizza every day.
author: Kristin C.

description:
the three blocks on valencia between duboce and 16th have become the hottest spot for pizza in san francisco. it's almost as if you're really serious about making pizza, you have to go to the valencia pizza blocks.......and if you can make it there, you can make it anywhere.

first there was arinell. cheap, ny style and extremely delicious!
then came pauline's. thin, california style and spectacularly wonderful!
and now to complete the circle, here comes little star and its amazing deep dishes!

now i'm definitely a thin crust guy, but i believe little star is the best kid on the block. that's a huge statement from me because both arinell and pauline's have received 5 stars from yours truly, but little star is better.

my favorite is the little star classic. this is their signature deep dish with sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers and onions. it's phenomenal! it's absolutely zesty and ridiculously delicious! it's so good that it just explodes in my body and shakes me to the core, in a good way, of course. ok, i'm going to say it. holy moly mackeroly!

in my opinion, little star is the new standard for deep dish pizza in the bay area and i hope they can keep that honor for a very long time because frankly, i don't want to go all the way to berkeley for pizza.

at least for now, unlike the nopa location, this little star is a little quieter and slower. i suspect that not everyone knows about the new mission location. so get there before the rest of the city finds out.......and tell them you heard it on yelp.

* supposedly, little star does thin crust, too........but why?

.
also, little star only accepts cash.
author: frisco j.

description: Corn meal crust and pizza is a great thing and Little Star has a great cornmeal crust.  Lately the toppings can be inconsistent....sometimes they taste fresher than others.  So I've been going here less since its also a little expensive for pizza.
author: Rob P.

description: We are big fans of Little star pizza.  Their spicy chicken wings are delicious! Even though this place is very popular for their deep dish pizzas, I love their  thin crust "White Pie" pizza. It is definitely the best pizza I have tasted so far in the city.
author: Mekhala M.

description:
Little Star is Zachary's Pizza's more sophisticated older sister.

The deep dish pies are fantastic, with a very good balance of flavors and yummy cornmeal crusts. It's the best deep dish pizza I've had. My favorite is the Little Star with sausage. 

Don't get the garlic bread. Cuz it's not really garlic bread. Just bread with a giant side of garlic cloves. The wait to get seated is also hella long, so don't go during peak hours unless you want to sit in the waiting area for an hour or more.
author: Chanpory R.

description: I like Zachary's better, but if you can't always get to the East Bay, this deep dish pizza place is a good alternative. I like their crust on their deep dish pizza bc it is crunchy. If you ever get to the East Bay, try Zachary's!
author: Maria C.

description:
Sunday was a fatty-fatty-fat day. Bloated? Check! Jiggly in all the wrong places? Check! Wishing I was young and stupid enough to turn to anorexia? Check! So when PartyBot suggested we hit up Little Star, my first instinct was to yell something like, "You stupid stupid stupid man! Can't you see I'm superchunkalicious today?!?!?!", but that would have been downright hormonal. Instead, I decided that I would nibble a bit at Little Star and enjoy the leftovers later, in my kitchen, with the lights out, where no one could see my fat ass chowing down. 
I should have suspected that Plan A would be abandoned as soon as we got within a block of Little Star. The air in that whole neighborhood is infused with the smells of melting cheese, roasting tomatoes, and herby goodness. My heart started beating faster, I began to salivate...and I knew I was done for.
Opening the door to Little Star is like waking up in heaven. The smell is out of control. I know I gained a pound or two just breathing the air in there. We got a large Little Star pie and I swear we spent the first 5 minutes photographing it...ok, PB did because he's the photographer and when I see food, all that's going through my head is, "FEED ME". The pies are like art. And delicious to boot. Just the right ammount of tomatoes, a crust so perfect it's beyond description, and delicious ingredients made me forget about my weight problems and body issues just long enough to eat a huge slice. 
We both agreed that it was a tiny bit cheesy for our taste, so next time we'll get something with more veggies. Either way, we're intent on becoming regulars and looking forward to trying out the Western Addition branch as it's closer to us, making the whole driving-home-in-a-food-coma thing a little easier. In the meantime, I'll be saving up my Weight Watchers points, because next time I'm not stopping at one slice. 

**ps- our soda was served in icy, icy pint glasses fresh from the freezer. That's worth a whole star right there. These guys aren't fooling around. Once again, PartyBot was right. One more point for him :)
author: Autumn K.

description: Little star pizza.. Yumm there goddess salad is  so good, n there chicken wings so spicy yet oh so tender n good!! Pizza one of a kind! delicious!
author: Shirl C.

description: Pizza doesn't get better than this.  Only ever had the deep dish there but why would you order anything else??  The wait time can be long sometimes, but its worth it.
author: Maureen K.

description: Yes, yes, yes!  I got the deep dish little star w/o mushrooms (allergic)  Delicious cornmeal accented crust, ricotta, mozzarella and fresh spinach and onions.  All topped off with chunky tomato sauce.  Best pizza I have had in SF and I will definitely go back.  Friendly staff...only complaint is I wish they delivered.  Usually when I want pizza, I want in it my PJ's in front  of the TV and I was a little grumpy that I had to get dressed and drive somewhere.
author: Stacy R.

description: For a neighborhood pizza joint the place manages to be chic with  a secretive, low-lit  atmosphere behind a frosted glass front door that makes you think they're out of business.  Quite the contrary.  They're busy.  The pizza--omg--I am still surprised to say the crust and sauce leave no room for improvement, one slightly buttery and flakey, the other rich and dense with tomatos.  I've been twice:  the service is good too.  Five stars for the genre!
author: Patrick B.

description: Yummy yum yum yum. This place really does live up to it's oh so popular reputation. Their pizza is outstanding with the cornmeal crust and the deep deelish sea of ingredients. We got the Little Star which is loaded with spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic and even as a meat lovin mo fo, I can honestly say that even with the strictly veggie toppings, this was one hell of a kickass pizza!
author: Stephy S.

description:
I am very proud of myself.  I am also very proud of Little Star Pizza for being fucking unbelievable.

The reason for my pride goes as follows:
I had left 111 Minna after a Friday Night happy hour during which I had put away more drinks that a lady should mention.  Nick H and I went to his buddy's place on the panhandle where we decided a pizza or two was definitely in order.  So we tracked across GodKnowsWhere until we got to Little Star, where Phel M had called in an order prior to our departure.  The place was hopping.  It was not your typical dirty or Italian-themed pizza place, but looked rather like a hip Asian-fusion style restaurant.  We sat on a bench while we waited for our take out.  We remained on this bench as we wolfed down about three pounds of pizza.  Each.  A waiter was good enough to bring us plates and napkins rather than tell us to scram.  Good man.  So we finally walked home, where we devoured another pound of pizza and I routinely declared my undying love and devotion to this new pizza mecca.

Why am I proud?  Because I ate way more pizza than I can normally handle.  Furthermore, my drunken mind was so impressed with the mind-blowing quality of the pizza (deep dish with cornmeal crust... SO TASTY!!!) that I actually remembered the name of the joint AND where it's located.  Usually I don't sweat these details, but clearly it left such a strong impression that I would happily trek over from East Bay just to chew on crumbs from other people's leftovers.  If anyone is so foolish as to leave a speck behind.  

Maybe I ought to just order my own.  
NEW FAVORITE PIZZA JOINT!!!!
author: Mari C.

description: UMMM I feel silly even leaving a review-cause everyone should already know how amazing this place is. The waiters are quite patient and helpful-though they keep extremely busy, so it's nothing over the top. BUT, the Classic deep-dish will keep me coming back here FORever...it's unreal actually how good it is..and, I can always count on over eating.
author: SLH H.

description:
My hubby and I went here for Valenitine's Day dinner, and I have to say that it was absolute Heaven.
The hostess was so helpful and polite, after we got on the list we had a beer from the bar.  Which is located in the lobby - Why doesn't every restaurant do this?
We were seated after 10 minutes in a busy warm, just right sized atmosphere. Seriously, the whole experience was like Baby Bear's everything from Goldilocks perspective for me.
We ordered Garlic bread-Amazing, it is served with the whole roasted garlic clove and light butter. So Delicious!
Caprese Salad.  great tomatoes even in Feb. I would have liked more Basil, but it was excellent none the less. Balsamic yummy.
Brass Monkey Deep Dish Pizza. Now, I haven't had a deep dish pizza since I left the mid-west, and wow!  This is probably the best one I have ever had.  Fresh Ingredients, well balanced chop and blend within the 'za and a tasty sturdy crust.  An amazing fresh tomato sauce finished the top. 
We left the restaurant stuffed, but never feeling overwhelmed.  On the hostess's recommendation we ordered the cheesecake to go, and it was thick, creamy and light. with the crust only on the bottom. It is perfection.
I can't even say enough how great the food was, how comfortable and inviting the atmosphere is, and how well the staff worked as a team overall.  There is a good jukebox, and a decent selection of beer and wine.
Thank you Little Star Pizza.
I can't wait until next time.
author: Deb B.

description: Delicious. We had the Mixed salad and the LittleStar (deep dish with spinach, mushrooms & onions) Pizza. Everything was really tasty good and the service was quick and friendly. I'll be back!
author: Kandy P.

description: Good deep dish pizza in the city, mmhmm. You don't have to drive to Zachary's any more. Why didn't someone think of this sooner? I'll be back. And again, and again.
author: Ken L.

description: I'm a thin-crust lover but after the hubby convinced me to go deep dish Little Star last week I'm a believer. Their deep dish is not thick, it's just deep... and stuffed with the MOST mouth-watering toppings a pie can have - the classic is amazing. Truly one of the best around, it's no wonder they have so many fans.
author: margot b.

description:
The four days prior to going out to Little Star,  we had an average of four hours of sleep a night due to a sick baby, lack of marital bliss due to a MIA husband, pour conversation topic choices on my part, and just general exhaustion because of the stresses of  everyday family life. We try once a week to go on a date. We usually look forward to it and sometimes we are even excited about it. In this particular  case I think we  wanted so bad to want to be excited when in reality all we really wanted to do was go home and sleep for five days strait waking up for snacks, bathes, and sex and then returning to sleep for another five days. Ah life before responsibilities. So the general mood of the evening was really working against us and our ability to thoroughly enjoy the pizza experience and basically made for the worst date ever!

Despite all the drama that surrounded that night I must say that the dining endeavor was lovely. The dining room was smaller than we pictured and the decor was a little higher end looking than most pizzerias. It made for an intimate environment. I enjoyed the fact that they stuck with the traditional parm and pepper shakers at the tables and the thick red glass votive candle holders that looked like they belonged in a stereotypical mafioso Italian restaurant set in a really bad movie. It was just a hint of kitch and I liked it. It was a bit dark though, which on another night may have been romantic but came across as a setting for  a covert operation instead. In fact I do believe that I saw a man in a long trench coat, dark glasses and a hat sitting  in the corner passing a mid-sized manila envelope to a man in shorts, a safari hat, and a Hawaiian shirt. Secret agents? Or was it just an example of the diverse fashion senses that many San Franciscans sport? We will never know. It would also be a great spot for those over forty woman dating an under thirty man to come and look her most marvelous. Fine lines don't really show in dark atmospheres. The bathroom was the crowning glory though. Very modern for a place that has a one room unisex bathroom. Everything was automated! You could have managed to go in and out of there without ever touching anything if they had put the trash can closer to the door and had a pop lock instead of the twisty kind. I really have trouble enjoying sharing public restrooms with men, no matter what the floor of the bathroom is always wet and you always have to touch the toilet seat in order to pee. Ick, that was the only unautomated thing in there, the toilet seat. There should be a requirement that all unisex bathrooms have an automated seat that lowers when the toilet is flushed and has a floor button for the men to press with their foot to lift it, then no one would have to touch the seat ever. Genius.

Now to the food. We perused the menu and then had a brief conversation about how guilty we would feel if we passed up a salad for garlic bread. Lets face it, who can really pass up good garlic bread? There was a ramekin of softened butter, warm bread, and a roasted head of garlic. The only thing that was missing was a hint of salt. If there was some chunky salt on the plate or table or if they had salted the garlic a little heavier it would have been perfect. Although I have to say I do enjoy the crisp outer and soft greasy inner of a traditional piece of really good garlic bread. You know the kind, where your lips are shinny for the rest of the evening, but it was delicious and unique, which I always appreciate. 

We then ordered the deep dish little star pizza. I have to say that my favorite part about it was the crust. It was crisp on the edges as well as on the bottom. No one likes a soggy bottom, but it was soft enough to eat with ease. It had spinach, feta, ricotta, tomato sauce and provolone I believe. The sauce was delightful and the cheese melty. Delicious! I had a glass of wine and the hubby had a beer, what a luxury. 

Don't worry kids, nothing swells the heart, extracts the tears and warms the belly like a full stomach, making up, a kiss on the nape of your neck goodnight, and falling asleep being hugged tight by the one you love and  want to be loved by. Peace has been restored, maybe the pizza is magic or maybe sleep cures all?!
author: Esa Y.

description: Little Star defied the laws of constant terrible businesses that opened and failed at this location on Valencia for years.  They can't go wrong with their no fuss service, great tasting deep dish pizzas (No soggy, oily crust!)  They did a great job turning out this former Thai restaurant.  The thin crust pizzas aren't bad, but you go to Pauline's for the flat stuff.  Both the classic and chicken med thick crust are excellent.  Don't be a food waster and throw away the crust because it's the best part, it's slightly sweet, crispy and covered in cornmeal.  Appeitizers to get include the do it yourself garlic bread and the spicy chicken wings.  By the way, this location seemed a lot less crowded than Divisadero.
author: Jason A.

description:
I love Little Star's food. It's amazing. So-so-so good. Garlic bread is awesome -- but I've never ordered it and actually gotten it. For some reason my server forgets it -- and I've had multiple servers! I finally had it for the first time yesterday and this is why:

We walked in yesterday and were told it was a 30 minute wait. No problem. An hour later we were seated. Minus a star for the doubled wait time. 

Our pizza came but, of course, the garlic bread did not. I reminded our server about the garlic bread, said "forget it", and bit into a pizza that was not the one we ordered. Minus a star for botching our order. 

Our server was apologetic and brought us free garlic bread to make up for it. I finally got to try the garlic bread. Yay!

Overall the food is amazing. The staff is cool and endearing even if they are a bit "checked out" at times.
author: shaun o.

description: You know that feeling you get when you climb a rope in gym class?  that is how I felt after eating one of these pies.  Safe to say one of the best pizzas I have had in the bay area.
author: Kevin C.

description: I know you all don't need me to tell you about the pizza at Little Star, because it pretty much speaks for itself. What I am going to tell you about, however, is the ATM they have on-site. Service fee? $0.25. Yup, TWENTY FIVE CENTS. The cheapest ATM in the city. If you are a painfully modern city dweller like me and conduct most, if not all, of your banking online, then you will appreciate this little nugget of information. Dine at LSP before a night out and load up on cheddar before you leave, if you know what I mean.
author: Tom H.

description:
two little review stars for, well, little star pizza and that's only because the food is good. Great deep dish pizza with a crunchy cornmeal crust. Horrible service that practically ruined our whole experience here. 

We had a pretty snippy waittress, but we didn't mind the curt service during the meal. It's a pretty busy place and we were there on a Saturday evening with a party of 6. We were dining at the same pace as everyone around us (i.e. we weren't hogging a table or taking our sweet time ordering, etc). We had just ordered our last round of beers and were finishing up our pizza when the server brought the bill. She handed it to us while saying in a very rude tone that if we wanted to finish our drinks, we'd have to do it at the bar because there were people at the bar who had been waiting a long time to eat  at our table. 

I've never been kicked out of a table before. This sort of behavior would possibly be understandable if we had been there for an hour or were just ordering rounds of drinks without ordering food or had finished our meal a while ago, but the pizza had just been cleared and we hadn't even paid the bill yet. Four of the six of us have worked in the food/restaurant service industry and know well enough not to hog a table after paying a bill. And of course if we were going to turn into a drinks-only party we would have moved on. But there was no need to tell us in a bitchy tone to hit the road. This is also an especially bad move if the bill hasn't been taken care of yet.  i mean, i know this is the mission but that doesn't mean you can kick me out of table before i've finished my beer or my meal. geez. 

So we left a smaller tip than we would have if the service had been pleasant (we are usually 20 percent tippers) and had we been allowed to finish consuming the meal we were paying for. But upon leaving, we discovered that my friend left a shopping bag at the table. And when she sent her boyfriend inside to get it, the waittress was holding it hostage while demanding to know why our tip was less than generous. He explained that he has worked in restaurants throughout the Bay area for years and had never been asked to leave a table before, especially before the bill had been paid. And he was pretty insulted, especially as we were celebrating a birthday! He practically had to claw the shopping bag out of her hand, even when a second member of our party joined him to see what was taking so long. She (the birthday girl!) explained that we were not happy with our service and that while we left a tip, it would have been bigger had the service been polite or at least humane. 
 
I know that table space is a precious commodity in the Mission. So next time, mean waittress lady, let me finish my beer and then just say in a POLITE tone, "we'd love you guys to stay and keep the party going, but if you're moving on to drinks only, can i help you find some seats at the bar so we can help our other customers get their grub on?" (We would have politely moved too!).
author: Mindy S.

description:
two words:

holy crap!

a few more words:

this place is unbelievable. anyone who can make deep dish taste soooo delicious and yet not make you feel like you are going to die eating it is worth a visit. we got the 'little star' deep dish, and while tasty, it wasn't dripping in cheese and oil (as many deep dish are). and the bbq wings were actually bbq'ed. not slathered in some red-colored pasty sauce. soooo good. with a bottle of wine, the perfect place to go with friends to relax after a long week.

two more words:

holy crap!
author: monkey l.

description:
i have only had take out here at the mission location. never been to the other. i usually like thin crust pizza but had to try the deep dish. well deep dish doesn't necessarily mean it is thick crust as i used to wrongly believe. this corn meal crust is still kinda thin and crispy. i loved it and will have no problem ordering a deep dish here again. i had the classic - sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers and onions and it was excellent. being one of my vices i really liked the sausage very much. and the sauce was good too.

one might think the place isn't where it says it is or maybe closed for the day. i drove by this place a few times before i was stopped at the traffic light and was barely able to read it's tiny sign. guess they only want people who are in the know about it's pizza and location. anyway it is worth a visit.

they deserve 1 star for the stupid ass cash only policy. fucking lame when the bill can be a bit high for cash on hand.
author: roger b.

description:
Mmmmmmmmm.

Wow. I'd had Little Star to-go before, but had never had the privilege of dining in. Although the takeout was delicious, the pizza is simply designed to eat in.

Our entire experience was fabulous from start to finish. First, the hostess quoted us about a 15-20 minute wait, but we were seated at a spacious 4-top within about 5 minutes. Our ebullient waiter, Ian, kept is satisfied and entertained. He had some great recommendations - doing two small pizzas of different halves for the four of us - so we could try as much as possible of the different pizzas.

We started with some garlic bread. This is not your typical garlic bread, though, folks. We're talking warm, soft, crusty sourdough with a crock of softened butter, accompanied by a whole head of roasted garlic. Oh yeah, baby. In case you were wondering, insanely delicious. We also split a mixed green salad which was good, yet basic.

Next, the pizzas arrived. The deliciousness of the pizzas impairs my ability to form sentences. Cornmeal. Cheese. Sauce. Mmmmmmmmmmm. Absolutely delicious. I consider myself somewhat of a deep dish connoisseur, as I spent my college years devouring Zachary's in Berkeley, and have had many a trip to Chicago where I dined at Pizzeria Uno (the ORIGINAL - far superior to the chains), Gino's East, and Lou Malnatti's in Lincolnwood (a suburb of Chicago). I've also had Paxti's several times, which, honestly, has never quite done it for me. It's decent, but doesn't hold a candle to the cornmeal-y goodness of Little Star. Yum yum yum.

At the beginning of our meal, Ian told us we had to save room for the cheesecake. I was thinking, yeah sure, sounds good but I'm gonna invest my calories on this here pizza. However, my boyfriend being the cheesecake lover that he is, we ended up ordering a slice. And let me just say, holy cow (literally). The cheesecake was perfect. A substantial graham crust and beautifully light and tangy. Not too dense, not too sweet. Ian also brought us a complimentary generous bowl of Cookies and Cream gelato. He said it was their newest dessert and he wanted to know what we thought. One of our dining companions said, "Oooh, Jill. He must know you're a yelper." I joked with Ian, "Ahhh... are you just giving us the royal treatment because of my yelper status?" He says, "okay... remember... my name is Ian. That's I-A-N" Loved it. :) FYI, the gelato was super delicious, but the cheesecake is where it's at.

I think my meal at Little Star was potentially the most fattening meal of my entire life. But, damn, it was worth every single calorie.
author: Jill M.

description: Hot damn, just as cool as the original. The little bar up front is fantastic for sliding me over a beer while I wait with a pretty unique selection on tap. And the atmosphere is great, at first you feel like it's going to be cramped and loud, but it's not at all. And they have quite the playlist going on a Friday night, I have to say. And I should be mad that waitress totally up sold us on two pizzas, but then I never would have had the chance to try (for the first time) their thin crust, which I almost like better. And I had Little Star in my fridge for the next couple of days. Woot!
author: Michael E.

description: Any Cal grad worth their weight in Blue and Gold probably already believes that Zachary's is the be-all end-all of deep dish pizza.  But then came Little Star.  And I am officially a convert.  Seriously, I am salivating as I write this. What sets Little Star apart from that other pizza parlour across the Bay is their crust.  It's thin, it's crisp, it's corn meal.  How can you go wrong?  No more puffy doughy-ness to get in the way of all that melty, cheesy goodness.
author: Becca V.

description: I was excited to try this pizza, maybe too excited.  They are known for their deep dish right? So that's what I ordered, even though everyone else in the restaurant seemed to only be ordering the thin crust.  So I asked the waitress "Deep dish right? I hear that's the way to go."  She nodded her head like a Bobblehead.  So of course I went with the deep dish.  Now, I grew up on the east coast, so I'm use to thin crust pizza.  But I still have taste buds ya know.  Little Stars pizza reminded me of Pizzeria Uno's pizza.  I just don't understand the hype at all over Little Star.  However, I will go back to at least try the thin crust.  Plus, I found the restaurant to have a nice ambiance for a pizza joint.  And just to let you all know I found the service perfectly adequate.
author: Amanda P.

description: Little Star Pizza. Simply the best pie in town.....  there's a girl in the bathroom right now, she's telling me I've got to yelp about this place. It's their second location, yes I hear you yell that from that room in the corner... am I going to put in that steak comment she says next... What?? Oh that one.. If you can't have a steak, you might as well have this pizza?? Yeah that one.. sounded better when we were there....but the pizza's still the best. Seriously. Bombdiggity... did I spell that right?
author: David R.

description: I wasn't too happy about circling around for parking for 20 minutes.  Apparently, it could have been worse.  I was thrilled to get a table as soon as we walked in.  I'm sure that could have been worse because the place is smaller than I imagined it would be.  My husband and I each ordered a 9 inch.  The waiter was concerned and warned us that was a lot of food for 2 people.  My husband said he knew what he is getting himself into as he'd been there before.  First bite and I think I've had the best pizza ever.  It's big, it's deep dish, the crust is excellent but even more so was the sauce.  It was bold, but the depth of flavor it had was remarkable.  I didn't even care about the toppings.  Couldn't even remember what I ordered.   Wound up with 2 slices to bring home.  My husband kept his word and polished off his pizza, plus a slice of mine.
author: Charmaine B.

description:
I went to Little Star on a first date the other night and it was pretty darn good. I give it 4 stars instead of 5 because it is pretty cramped and noisy. They really cram a lot of tables into a small space - if you are sitting against the brick wall you even have to move the table to get out which did provide an opportunity to meet our neighbors to the right when their table was suddenly right next to ours. It would be cool if all the tables were on wheels and every few minutes we got all switched around.
We spied a sweet looking giant salad on a nearby table and ordered it along with a small thin crust pie. I know they are known for their pan style pizzas but I'm not crazy about that style - a bit too heavy for me. The salad featured some tasty tomatoes but overall it was a bit underwhelming - good but not as great as it looked. The pie was quite good - not at all greasy and the small size was perfect for 2. On the way out my date asked for a card so she could remember the place and possibly review it here but they didn't have any cards so the super cool bartender lady took a postcard and decorated it with a picture of a slice of pie (could be savory - could be sweet) and stamped it along with our hands with a little red star. I would go in there just to sit at the bar and hang out with her - good times.
author: Colin S.

description: I've always been satisfied....gets my tastes buds going, it's hard to find with pizza, since so many in the city are not so good
author: Alex W.

description: I'm not what you'd call a pizza lover.  It does the trick when it's 2 am and you haven't eaten since noon or if you need to feed a bunch of folks cheap and easy, but I don't go looking for the stuff.  At least until I had Little Stars Deep Dish pizza.  Holy fucking Mary mother of Joseph!  That shit is GOOD.  I now have a deep and unwavering love of the pizza, as long as it comes from Little Star.
author: Kyla B.

description: I think I died and went to Brooklyn! Zachary's-style pizza w/out the schleppe to the EBay, cozy brick-walled ambience, and tunes that i have on my own I-pod. The antidote for that foggy, cool SF evening.
author: Suzanne R.

description: Freakin' dee-lish. I think the previous reviews get the point across. Loved the ambience of the place and both the deep dish and New York style pizzas. What a great deal too...went with a group of 6 friends and had 2 appetizers, 1 deep dish pizza, 1 think slice pizza, and 2 bottles of wine for a grand total of $20/ person, including tax and tip! Whaaaatt....I'll be back.
author: I C.

description:
Hello.

Yet another great pizza place in the Bay Area. Who knew that living in Berkeley, I'd develop a tongue for pizza???

Came here with the b.f. and his friend. Cash only, and pretty crowded. Bad service policy. Not sure how many tables she was covering, but I came here a couple weeks ago and I still remember how crappy the waiters and waitresses are.

It's a pretty small restaurant and lots of people want to eat here. After waiting longer than the estimated 20 minute wait time, we finally got a seat and ordered two deep dishes. After being told the pizza would take about 40 minutes to prepare (holy cow, are you familiar with how Zachary's operates? Wouldn't mind learning considering 1. small size of restaurant, 2. wait time for seats 3. time it takes to cook pizza), we decided to order an appetizer: the garlic bread. Little did we know that the garlic bread would take 35 minutes. i.e. appetizer for snacking while waiting for pizza, was actually appetizer to hurry up and finish before pizza came. It was delicious though, roasted garlic, creamed butter and toasty bread. Guy from our party complained, 'why did the garlic bread take so long?' Waitress replies, 'that's how long it tastes." me: '...' Anyway... the pizza came. Yes, lots of corn starch in the crust. But i like it. However, the sauce was very bland, like lots of tomatoes and not enough spice. For this reason, zachary's also wins on the flavor category of pizza. Anyway we finish and eat and the waitress takes forever to process our check. We catch another waiter and he tells us to wait five minutes and if our waitress hadn't come by by then, he'd process it for us. right. the service is lacking. so is the pizza. but not the crust. again cash only! for pricy pizza. BAH!

ok that's all.
author: Melody L.

description: What could I possibly say that hasn't already been yelped?  And when has that stopped me yet?   The hour and a half I spent at Little Star last weekend was the best pizza time I've spent since I don't know when.  Sure, the company, the service, the price - all great, but the FOOD!  I was in a very happy place for that hour and a half.  Don't miss out on the tasty, fresh salad either, a great mix of "stuff".  I recommend the deep dish crust (we ordered ours with anchovies, artichokes and sun-dried toms) but the thin crust looked like it would make "the other" type of pizza lovers happy, too, as it looks very thin and unassuming, leaving more space for yum-yum toppings.  Finally, although they are a cash-only place, you will be happy as a clam when you see their ATM only charges  a .25 service fee!  That's nice.  Real nice.
author: Rina A.

description: This place is great! Their deep dish pizza is to die for! I've dined here about a million times and the food is consistent and delicious. The staff are very friendly, and take out is ready in a flash! A great addition to the Mission.
author: Benjamin C.

description: Not sure why they are scared of having a restaurant sign but the folks at Little Star sure know how to bake a pizza. I am usually not a fan of the deep dish but the  Mediterranean deep dish was most excellent. The crust was not too thick and just the right consistency. We ordered with light cheese and there was still plenty to enjoy without feeling like Jabba. I'll be back here.
author: Akhil K.

description:
after trying to go once but fleeing because of the anticipated one-hour wait for a table, i finally went at a good time--ironically, 10pm on a saturday night was a good time. you'd think any time on a saturday evening would be hopeless in terms of not having to wait, but 10pm somehow was ideal. we were seated immediately, and it was definitely busy in there but not too packed, and weirdly no one at the bar. 

this is a classy, cozy spot, the exposed brick wall giving it the kind of elegance you don't really demand of pizzerias. but in other ways, this is just your typical neighborhood pizzeria -- example: the jukebox delivering steady doses of hipster indie rock that, yes, i'll admit, had me bopping my head and saying, "i love this song!" more than once. 

the service was attentive and kind, and that means a lot to me when i go to restaurants. we started with a mixed greens salad, which was sizable enough for 2 to split. the tomatoes in the salad were delicious and fresh. we then split a thin-crust pizza with artichoke hearts and mushrooms--this wasn't on the menu, but they do offer the choose-your-own-toppings route. the pizza was good--the thin crust was crispy. i was curious about the deep dish, wishing i could try it, until i saw it on another table--it was deep as fuck, dude. just looking at it made me bloated. so, glad we went with thin-crust, as i think the deep dish would have made for a night of uncomfortable flatulence, and who wants that on a saturday night? 

the small 9" pizza was enough for 2 people, with some leftover. the server kindly informed us of this when we tried to order large, and he steered us toward the small instead. 

this isn't life-changing pizza, but i like a restaurant that is friendly, cute, and committed to using fresh ingredients. i will go back to little star again for sure. it's cash only there, but they do have an ATM in the restaurant so that's helpful. 

downsides: it's sceney, but it's the mission, what do you expect? also, the music was so loud that me and my date had to shout to hear each other. and i tend to like loud music--but i also tend to dislike a dinner date that involves shouting.
author: Marla W.

description: Remarkably similar to Zachary's across the bay but Zachary's edges out Little Star in my opinion. Still, Little Star makes a fine deep-dish pizza. I had The Classic and it rocked. What more can you really say? This place has great pizza.
author: Aaron V.

description: Warning: this little star is actually not associated with the little star in Nopa. I am a huge fan of little star in nopa across town. Where as that place is easily five-star this place barely gets 3 stars. So I live all the way in the richmond much nearer the nopa location, so how did I end up here? I came all the way out to the mission initially to get some Palestinian food. But, that never happened because they never allowed me entrance, as they claimed that they had a large private party coming in, I suspect other reasons such as closing soon, and the  fact that I am blind and this place wasn't all that keen to help me last time I was at the middle east in place. But anyway, this review is not about old Jerusalem, so let's move on. It was probably nine for tea at night, and I had to figure out what to do, I certainly couldn't return to the Richmond and still find food so after a whole lot of searching and a phone call and a long bus ride and somewhat walk with some help of this very kind gentleman and I ended up here true, I got there around 10:25 and I finally got my pizza at 10:45 this does not dismiss or allow the less than minimally attentive service. I understand this was very near to closing, but I still expect as long as they're open a level of professionalism. It wasn't there, they literally dropped off my food after they toookmy order and dropped off my check the server came by once or twice, but when I told them something he was very dismissive, I was going to give them my card so they can charge me for the meal but I couldn't even do that because the server had rushed off, and I had to stand up for a couple minutes and try to get attention before he came back he charged me for the right amount and came back with my card and my receipt and just dropped it off without giving me enough time to tell him I was blind and did not know exactly where to sign on the receipt another girl finally  came by and helped me out to sign, but I almost had to beg her to help me out to the entrance the food was...... well...... not that good, the garlic bread was exactly what it sounded like garlic and bread, separately so that garlic was not made already on the bread. The bread was sliced up but the pieces were by no means separated, it was still in the shape of a loaf of bread, I am sure if I wanted to buy these same ingredients from the supermarket near me and make this dish I could do just the same as it was just cooked garlic and bread it was not that appealing at the other little star the garlic is nice and spread already with some very nice cheese on top so it's a sort of home-made kind of garlic cheese bread stick like thing except it's on something like slices of bread this is very delicious, what I had last night was not very delicious at all!!!! The pizza, at the other little star the crust is somewhat crisp but also somewhat softer at least not baked to a crisp I like cookies almost burnt to a crisp I like bacon almost burned to a crisp but pizza crust maybe not so much yes, the pizza crust was a little hard but most of all way to Krispy so it was almost like eating some sort of pizza on some sort of thick crackers also the toppings were kind of soggy and less good than at the other little star, you can tell they did not prepare it with as much care.and the slices are pretty dam small, where as at the other little star even if you order a small they just give you less slicers not miniature pieces I am not sure if the large pizza pieces are any bigger, but those slices at the other little star is easily one third bigger than the slices are here so, will I come back, sure maybe, but only if I really need food to last me a meal     But if I am craving for some little star pizza I'll goto the nopa location
author: Rachel N.

description:
I've been to chicago many times and have tried nearly every deep dish pizza with a claim to fame: uno's, due's, gino's east, giordano's, etc., and I'm proud to say that they all pale in comparison to san francisco's own little star pizza, the best deep dish in the known universe.  
seriously. 
go there.
author: Tessa O.

description: I would highly recommend visiting the Divisadero location instead of this one.
author: Ben S.

description:
hadn't been to the one on divis but went to this one right when it first opened.  we ordered the buffalo wings, a large salad and a small thin crust and a small deep dish.  the buffalo wings weren't anything special, but the salad was really really good - fresh, with sweet tomatoes and goat cheese.  could prolly use slightly less dressing but that's a minor quib.  i think i didn't like it the first go around cos i don't really like deep dish and i don't really know why i ordered it other than that i thought that's what little star was known for.

we went there last night for dinner and this time only ordered a large thin crust.  mmmmmmm thin crust.  THAT'S WHERE IT'S AT!!!!!  it's not necessarily a chewy crust if that's what you're in to, but it's got this great corn meal crispiness to it. i'm a big fan of pizza dough being rolled out in corn meal.  the toppings are varied and fresh etc, as is to be expected w/most really good pizza joints in the bay area so there's nothing really new there. i just wish that they had a little more to offer on the app/salad side of things and that they took credit cards (i want my miles!!!!!!).

we had the same server last night we had the first time we were there and she comes off as a little ditzy or something but i find her rather cute and amusing.  the servers and the hostess all seem to help each other with running food and settling tabs so service is not only friendly but usually pretty quick.  they've got an affordable wine list that matches pretty well with pizza.

sometimes it's the simple pleasures like sharing a bottle of red and a yummy pie with the man you love that makes you think life is sooooo good.
author: Bird B.

description: Tragically cute, but not suitable for vegans.  Get with the program - you're in the Mission! Where is our vegan pie???
author: Kelly C.

description:
J and I have been wanting to eat at Little Star before the Mission branch opened up...so, tonight, FINALLY after practicing Bikram yoga in North Beach, I met J in Union Square and we walked to 15th and Valencia. 

We walked right by the restaurant (since we were on the other side of the street) and didn't notice it...luckily, J remembered the street number. We walk in...bar is crowded. I spy one empty chair on the end. I grab it and immediately the bartender (Todd) gives me a menu. I ask him so questions. He gets me a Malbec. I asked him about the Rhone. He gives me a sample of Rhone. J gets the Italian wine. I hear Tod talking about the Zinfandel. I didn't know Dry Creek Valley winery was in Sonoma, I say...I love California Zin's... so Tod pours me a generous sample of the Zin. I listened Tod talk to the customers...he is very knowledgeable, mellow, affable and attentive. 
Note: he only works on Friday nights. Little Star Pizza is not a wine bar...I went to Nua the other week in North Beach...they claim to have a wine bar...however, Nua only had California whites, no reds and the bartender was not even half as informative as Todd. 

Our wait for a table was 30 min and I wanted something to eat while drinking wine...J suggested the garlic bread...I was thinking, I don't like garlic bread and I don't like sourdough...but J really likes garlic bread and sourdough so I held my tongue...the appetizer arrived. Oh my Goddess...the garlic clove was so creamy and light...the butter, mixed with olive oil, was soft enough for dipping. The sourdough...let's just say that it tasted perfect with the garlic and butter. 

Our server, Savannah, was AWESOME. She wore her hair in braids (very cute) and despite her name...has never visited Savannah, Georgia (I'm from the South and I love Savannah.) We were going to order a large salad but she declared that a small was enough for both of us. I looked her in the eye and said, "We're hearty eaters." She responded, "I stand by my declaration." I wondered if we should order thin crust or deep dish but J had his heart set on the tomato/sausage/onion/pepper deep dish...we got a large so we could have leftovers.  The salad came---very fresh--perfect size (Savannah was SO righ!). The pizza...the crust was cornmeal? The crust was delicious....tomatoes so fresh...sausage flavorful... we were very happy. 

So, the food was wonderful, service incredible...it was time for the bathroom... I mentioned to Savannah how irritating it was to go to the bathroom and find it sans T.P. (see my other reviews)...so, Savannah (restaurant was packed)...goes to the unisex bathroom and then comes back and reports that there is plenty of T.P. J and I were both flabbergasted. What amazing service. 

For dessert, there are two choices listed on the menu:
Cheesecake
Gelato

That's it...no fancy descriptions after the items. The food menu is one page. The drinks menu is one page. I like brevity and simplicity.  We thought long and hard about the gelato...but then decided we were too full and asked for the check. 

Note: the check took FIVE minutes to arrive. Again, we were pleasantly shocked. 

For such good food and cool ambience...we didn't expect such gracious, attentive, friendly service. 

Service gets FIVE stars. Food FIVE stars. Todd and Savannah...thank you for making our first experience so wonderful!

P.S. J and I recently tried pizza at Pizziaolo (Oakland) and Cheeseboard (Berkeley) and Arinell (Mission, close to LSP)...however, it is difficult to compare as these places all have their unique flavors and crusts...I would say, though..for the best service, atmosphere, food in addition to pizza...Go to Little Star!
author: Grace C.

description:
I'd heard so much about Little Star, a friend of ours said that it's better than Zachary's, so of course, I wanted to do my own comparison. 

We arrived on a Friday evening, 6pm, to no line, a few full tables, and rock star parking right out front. I had heard that Little Star tended to get kinda crowded. But upon reading other yelpers reviews, I guess this Little Star location is less crowded than the one on Divis, and they were right! So refreshing to not have to search for parking and wait in line for 30 minutes. Also, we arrived at the tail end of their happy hour, $1 off wine and beer. So, keep the wine coming(i'm a closet lush).

After looking over the simple, straight forward menu, we decided to  order the garlic bread as an appetizer. Warmed bread, a little bowl of butter and roasted garlic. Make your own garlic bread, yummy! We ordered wine: I had the cote du rhone, and my husband had the pinot grigio. Decent wine, decent prices.  And we decided to order, as our entree, the Little Star deep dish cornmeal crust pizza, which had feta, ricotta, spinach, mushrooms. My husband wanted to order a large. And I thought he was crazy. "You're crazy!" I said. I told him to trust me. He finally caved in and we ordered the small. Which, of course, I was once again vindicated, I was right. It was the perfect size for two people. I think we ate about 3 1/2 pieces each. Just to further prove my rightness, the table next to us, a table of 2 guys, with body mass indexes in the "overweight" to "obese" category, had ordered a large deep dish pizza. They couldn't even finish half the pie. 

Ok, so the comparison, Little Star vs. Zachary's. I vote for Little Star. The crust is light and crispy, probably because of the cornmeal. The pizza itself tasted less greasier than Zachary's. I ate 3 pieces and didn't feel like I was going to burst. My husband, though, is an enjoyer of the grease, and thought that Little Star was good, but that Zachary's was better. 

Oh, and I wanted to comment on the music. There's a juke box here, and the music they were playing was great...The Smiths, the Cure, Clap Your Hands Say Yeah, Pixies, Postal Service...

Oh and the wait staff...very attentive and prompt. Good service. (I think the prereq to work here is that you have to be a cute hipster with at least 3 tattoos and some kind of piercing somewhere....well, that's  probably the prereq to work at any place in the Mission...)

Total $57.00= app, entree, 4 glasses of wine and tip

We'll definitely be back.
author: Caroline C.

description: Just adding my 5 stars!  I should've fought more for the leftovers so that I could be eating a slice right now...
author: Mimi L.

description:
i'd heard stories. i knew this was supposed to be a great place to go for pizza, specifically deep-dish, within the city limits (i.e. crossing the bay for zachary's disqualifies you in this competition). and, seeing it both in my neighborhood and up on divis, i've been wanting to check it out for some time now. i was nervous, though. walking past it on valencia, the windows are so blacked out, i wasn't sure what shady operations were going on behind that darkened glass.

after eating here last night, i am glad i never pressed my face against the glass attempting to see inside. from the comfort of my table i laughed at passersby, reveling in my superiority of being on the inside. they had no idea. so, in retrospect, the best part of this restaurant is the $2 PBRs. they have two happy hours per day, which is ingenious. we ordered a bread appetizer which was served with warm butter and a huge roasted garlic. for dinner we had two pizzas: a thin crust and a deep dish. now, i am very biased on deep dish after having dined multiple times at zachary's, so little star's crust on their deep dish tasted a bit odd to me. it was heavy with cornmeal and more soft than flaky.

six PBRs later, it was time to move on to other watering holes, but my time at little star will not be forgotten. maybe we can do it again soon, but don't call me. the important thing is that we can still be friends.
author: Jeremiah W.

description: Awesome deep dish pizza.. and it's literally 100 yards away from my front door! Dare I say that the "Little Star" (the deep dish pizza special with spinach, ricotta, feta and other tasty tidbits) puts Zachary's to shame? Am I sacrilegeous? I think NOT!
author: Sunny Y.

description:
im no deep dish pizza expert - or aficionado for that matter, but i grew up minutes away from zachary's on solano.  that was the only deep dish i've ever had, and while i liked it, i never loooooved it.  its good, but a bit too rich and heavy.  one slice and i am completely done-zo.  

not to mention, i am a thin crust (ala pizzetta 121) kinda gal.

well, last night i got a chance to try little star.

one word: 

CONVERTED!

one bite of the little star pizza and all i could think was... if zachary's is the par, then little star must be alba-fuckin-tross.  or maybe even a condor or a vulture.  (and sorry for the golf terms, we were golfers for halloween and i cant seem to get the lingo out of my head.  yes i realize its been a week.)

the garlicky tomatoes were chunky and juicy and lightly sauced with a bit of onions and mushrooms, over a mixture of spinach and ricotta, and then all over some very stringy, chewy, melty mozzarella goodness.  the cornmeal dusted crust was light and crisp with just the right amount of bounce.  

gaaaahhhhhhh.  drooooooool.  i cant seem to put my thoughts into words.  yaaaabadeebadoooo.  i have never felt this way about deep dish pizza before.
  
other vitals: happy hour ($1 off drinks) until 6:30pm, they serve racer 5 bottles, they have a great tempranillo, and their yummy champagne cocktails come in a fuckin pint glass.  whats not to love??
author: Helen L.

description: I actually like this location better than the one in Western Addition - more tables, more parking and yet still the same great food. Gotta love $1 PBRs during happy hour....makes the deep dish pizza taste that much better!
author: Beth T.

description: Great Chicago-style pizza!  It's all about the crust and they seem to have it down.  Their thin crust pizza is good too.  Zachary's in Oakland/Berkeley is still my favorite but this place is a very close second.  I only wish they took reservations.
author: Julie D.

description: Yum!  Love the Little Star Deep Dish Pizza!
author: Steve D.

description: Only the best little deep dish pizza on the planet! Beats Zachary's across the bay hands down. I'm so lucky to live close by. Try their garlic bread -- you spread it yourself! Yum.
author: Bryan K.

description:
my first venture to LS was on a date with the hottest tattooed boy ever. we hit up the divis spot, which gets five stars for date ambiance and a great jukebox. hot boy and i dined on the caprese salad and mediterranean chicken deep dish..super yummy, plus the date ruled..too bad the relationship didn't really make much farther past that point.

second time there: mission spot with my most recent boyfriend now turned ex bf...another deep dish and two pbrs in a can. again super yummy!

since, i have been at least three times and have had a variety of pizzas. four stars for the deep dish, two for their thin crust (sorry i am loyal to arinells), and come to think of it...zero stars for their contribution to the longevity of my relationships. at least i got a good dinner and you will too.
author: Zoe s.

description: Good pizza, delicious salad, awesome spicy wings. Don't waste your time with the thin crust, the deep dish is where it's at.
author: Rob T.

description: Good vibe, food; vibe exceeds the food, but that does not mean the food is bad!
author: Glenn S.

description:
I've been a fan of Little Start for awhile now, but haven't gotten around to yelping it just yet. After my last visit, I figured it was about time, because it was definitely memorable. We had plans to meet up with friends (9 of us in all) at Little Star this past weekend. Donna A. and I got there a bit early so we sat at the bar and took advantage of happy hour (to our surprise). Happy hour on a Sunday? Yes!! We sat at the bar with the friendly bar staff, and knocked back a few beers in frosty pint glasses while we waited for our friends to arrive. Once all 9 of us were there, the hostess sat us within about 15 minutes which was a pretty impressive feat, even with us being on the early side. We ordered two salads and 3 large pies (one thin pepperoni, one classic and one Little Star), which amazingly worked out to be just right; everyone left satisfied and happy. And to top it off...it worked out to be about $15 a person, including tip, which for a big group dinner out, is hard to beat.

I could go on about how great the pizza was, but you've all already heard that. I'm just really impressed by the whole Little Star experience. It's pretty epic, and they're definitely doing something right. Nice job guys!
author: Chris R.

description:
so whoever says that the pizza in new york is the best, or maybe the pizza in chicago is better....
both are good...but little star surpasses them both!
ohhh i said it.

best pizza ever!!!
author: keleigh l.

description: Little Star Pizza is one of our special treats. Its pricey - $25 for a deep dish pizza to feed 2 adults and a kid but its totally worth it.
author: Anuj A.

description:
ha

ha ha ha.  ha ha.  

oh wait - i actually didn't get the joke.  

so we ordered the caprese salad, garlic bread, and little star pizza.  (note to dipshits - always order the dish with the same name as the restaurant.)  the salad was good, the garlic bread was simply bread next to a clove of garlic (how original!), and the pizza was just ok.  i really don't get all of the hype.  i'd much rather eat at zachary's.  as an sf boy, would i rather GO TO zachary's?  probably not.  but little star has inferior pizza in my book.  

more thoughts:

1) great jukebox.  

2) it may be comparing apples to horseshit, but i'd MUCH rather have pizza at tomasso's.  to me, it's the difference between a zuni burger and a bistro burger burger, if that analogy means anything to you.  

3) our waitress "thought we were kidding" when we said hold the mushrooms.  i joke around about many things, but never about fungus.  

4) apparently sunday night is "judas priest hat night."  i swear every woman in that place, patron and server alike, had the rob halford hat on, though there were no leather examples and "beyond the realm of death" was not in earshot.
author: schnarf-a-larf a.

description: I never knew pizza could taste this good.  I don't think they actually had a "meat lovers" pizza (I never actually saw the menu) but we accommodated by ordering a deep dish sausage, pepperoni and onion pizza.  I wasn't paying too much attention to the service but I do remember our lady server being particularly sweet and refilling our beers quickly with a smile.  Worth noting is the fact that they make pizzas with the cheese under the sauce.  It was the first time I've had pizza like that but color me impressed: I'm a Little Star Pizza fan now.
author: Joshua K.

description:
I took my wife for a Yelp foodie road trip to SF, as her Mothers Day gift.  Little Star was listed as one of the top 5 places for pizza and it was an accurate rating. 
My wife loves a thin crust, while I need gluten enriched dough and despise cracker crust pizza.  I tell my wife, pizza needs to look like a WHD (a Weapon of Health Destruction) piled with thick cheese, spiced tomato sauce and meat products that soak the cardboard box with fatty greasy goodness that only a cheap beer can wash away. When it comes to pizza a "healthy food" attitude is not a part of my equation.
Little Star's thin crust pizza was none of this, but it was damn good.  The thin crust was still a cracker, but a good cracker baked with corn meal.  The flavor was an artistic combination of sauce, meat and veggies that did not fight for taste bud space on my tongue.
....And now for the con.  We ordered the Italian Special to go and I twice asked to have it without pepperocinis, guess what?  When we got to the car I opened the box it was loaded with pickled peppers.  The peppers were picked off, but it would have been nice to get a pizza with the requested items left off.
We plan on returning to Little Star and if I get to choose the pizza (come on Fathers Day) I will be ordering the Chicago style pizza.
author: Pio E.

description: Got seated quickly. ATM fee is only 25 cents. Pizza was a little pricey at $23 but I felt like it was worth it.
author: Milton Y.

description: Its been a minute since my last review. So here we go!  There was a long wait for seats here but It's all good.  We ended up getting some al al al al alcohol from the corner store and did some pre-game drinking.  lol... Deep dish was so bomb, the crust part was "the" best I had by far.  This place is getting repeat business from me.
author: Abraham E.

description: Little Star is pretty awesome. We went on a Saturday at about 6:30 PM and despite warnings of a very long wait, we were seated within 15 minutes. We got the Little Star - Spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions,&  garlic. For a deep-dish pizza it was nothing less than amazing. The ingredients were fresh and tasty. Next time I think I will try a thin crust pizza because the deep-dish crust leaves me feeling kinda gross and too full.
author: Emily S.

description: This place does pizza very well - both Chicago-style deep-dish and a thin crust pizza.  If you love one, you will be surprised that you also love the other!  But, say for some reason you don't like their pizza, the real tour de force of the place goes beyond pizza.  Their baked spicy chicken wings are awesome and go great with their house or capreses salads.  The final thing that impresses me about this place (at least their Valencia location) is that the people who work there are very kind and professional.  The place must have good management.  We feel lucky to live within walking distance of Little Star.
author: Alice G.

description: This was some good, but not great pizza.  I don't know if I'd go really far out of my way for a slice of this deep dish, but I will say that for a quick bite before a show at the Independent, Little Star is well worth the visit.  Two qualities about this pie that hit you right away are the deep dish crust dusted in corn meal with a crunch, which surprisingly isn't oily, and the tomato sauce, that while chunky, seems to drown out the cheese and its accompanying toppings.  I was hoping for more cheesy.  A large pie, a small pie, and a large salad was enough to satisfy five healthy appetites.
author: Tony L.

description:
On a typical foggy summer Tuesday around 8 pm, our growling stomachs are not the least bit pleased when we are informed that  it will be at least a 30 minute wait to score a table at super trendy, super crowded-with-more-hipsters-than-you-can fit-on-a-pinhead- Little Star Pizza. Yes, this deafening enclave on the corner of 15th and Valencia is in full scale automated pizza production mode, each pie emerging from the kitchen looking more mouthwateringly delicious than the last. We decide to pass the time by drinking at the bar. A conversation is difficult to be had here, as the noise level would be on par with what the SF Chronicle deems "explosion/ bomb level". A good 45 minutes later we are finally seated at a large booth table, and as we had been pouring over the menu during our wait, we ordered immediately (thin crust white pizza with zucchini and tomato as well as the signature "little star" without mushrooms). First to arrive was the thin crust which was composed of a buttery crust topped with feta, mozzarella, garlic, and the aforementioned vegetables. This pizza was our appetizer, and we thoroughly enjoyed it in it's crispy, buttery, creamy, savory glory. A bit later to arrive was the famous deep dish, "chicago style" pie, a buttery shell sprinkled with corn meal and stuffed with chunky tomato sauce, ricotta, mozzarella, and spinach. I'll admit, this one is very similar to Zachary's but this is only a compliment as Zachary's is obviously a tried and true favorite of most anyone growing up in Berkeley. In fact, even the decor  ie brick walls reminds me of Zachary's (minus the kid's framed pizza paintings). In any event, Little Star does an excellent deep dish pizza and you can't go wrong with this rich  and cheesy heavenly pastry-like delicacy. Just be prepared for a long wait, although the lively ambiance and friendly staff make the wait all the more bearable.
PS. One super-helpful tidbit of advice: do not come here on Mondays, for they are closed...and do not come here for lunch, as they are also closed...and don't even think about asking for delivery, especially on a Monday for lunch-ain't gonna happen.
author: Kate A.

description:
After loving up the pizza on Divis, we finally made it to the new-ish Mission local.  We arrived just after opening on a Saturday night at 5:15PM thinking we would be one of the first.  No.  How silly of us!  We were a bit dismayed that they did not have any beers on tap.  They made up for this however by pouring our wonderful IPA and Stout into frosted pint glasses all the way to the brim.  We never even saw the bottles.  I wonder if they open multiple beers to fill the 14 oz. pint glass all the way or how they manage to do that.  Perhaps they carry the 20 oz. Racer 5 IPA and do it that way.  Hummm...  This might require another visit seated at the bar to figure this out.  Also a warning.
