If you are looking forward to those champaign cocktails, don't get your hopes up because this location has none of them.  They do have more beers and more wines though to make up for it.  That was fine by me.

Anyway, we started with the garlic bread.  It is not like typical garlic bread.  It is more of a do-it-yourself kind.  You get a trough of butter, a full oven roasted clove of garlic, and warm sourdough bread to smear it all on.  YUM!

Then we ordered our typical deep dish cheese with mushrooms.  If I was dining sans husband, I would have had some meat added but the cheese does the trick on this deep dish dream.

I have to say that it was not the best Little Star pizza I have had but it was still damn good.  And being able to have a leftover slice for Sunday breakfast was also divine!  Hubby took the rest for lunch with my blessing of course.  I am that kind of giver...
author: Tracy A.

description: OK so there's like 275 reviews of the other one on Divis so I'll just say it's just like that one only better!
author: church B.

description:
not bad....not bad at all...

growing up eating napoletano style all my life I have always looked at the chicago style deep dish with some disdain and distrust. I thought maybe it was just some mistake created by some fat Italian kid in Chicago that turned out okay. In Little Star's case, it turned out damn funkin' good.

I got the Classic - sausage, mushrooms, and bell peppers...It was hella tasty...
author: Tony R.

description: Pizza is just okay.  Lacks a certain punch in the flavors.  The service at this location absolutely sucks.  It is unacceptable and it all starts wt the front door.  The host is the Nazi of all hosts in SF.  The wait is always longer than indicated.  The system of taking your order before youa re seated is BS.  They wait until you are seated to put the order in.........so now they aren;t even turnign the tabls any quicker and you have been standing there anticipating that your order will come out quickly and it doesn't.  I cannot emphasize enough how horrible the host and his attitude is.  The pizza is just not good enough to justify poor treatment of customers.
author: K A.

description: I think this is one of the best pizza joints in the city.  I think the cornmeal does magic and pairing any pizza with boont amber ale is just way too good.    The deep dish little star is my favorite.  Thanks for existing.
author: ray s.

description:
little star is superb. really i like so many things about this spot. 

got their namesake "little star" pizza last time i was there and LOVED it. the little star pizza is one of their deep dishes (they also offer thin crust), has generous cheese and spinach and then is topped with a serious amount of sauce. even with all the sauce the crust still had a nice crisp to it. i think the crust is dusted with cornmeal giving it a hearty taste. 

the waitstaff were extremly gracious. one of the servers spilled a teeny tiny bit of my white wine when setting it down, profusely apologized and comp'd my next glass- RAD! 

i prefer the mission location, its a bit bigger and the lighting is better. good place to go with a group. another plus- colossal chicken wings! although they have a black peppery sauce instead of the traditional wing sauce (louisiana spicy sauce with oil and cayenne) but they are yummy and come with uber chunky bleu cheese sauce!
author: Adrienne P.

description: I cannot lie. I'm addicted to Little Star. One bite and all is well with the world. I'd have to say the Mission location beats the Western Addition location for three reasons: First off, there's more space for tables, plus more of a bar/waiting area. And yes there is usually a wait. Secondly, they take credit cards along with cash (although please be aware they strangely do not allow more than two payment options). And finally, the parking situation is oh-so-much better than in the Western Addition. Despite the differences among locations, one thing is constant. The deep dish cornmeal crusted "Little Star" is out of this world good!
author: a p.

description: A walk into this restaurant is like walking into a whole other city.  They have exposed brick walls with some funky decor.  The beer and pizza go together like perfect harmony.  Definitely going back the next time I'm craving pizza.  Good pizza.
author: Jenny L.

description:
though your name is little star, you put  BIG on  taste, ambience , service, cleanliness and friendliness! you awe me with your stellar  deep dish little star pizza topped with your fresh spinach, risotta, feta, garlic, onions and  your heavenly delicious tomato sauce. i love your dough mix with corn meal, too!!!!! you made my dinner so spectacular that i'll  be coming back for you BIG star!...see you in a week.

their  chicken wings were good & garlicky served with baby carrots and  bleu ranch for dipping.
author: Nelle A.

description:
I went to Zachary's last weekend and I came back to SF knowing that I will never again have to take Bart to get the best deep dish pizza in the Bay area. It's Little Star, baby!

Don't get me wrong--Zachary's is fantastic. Zachary's sauce is a little zestier but Little Star's is still delicious. What puts Little Star over the edge is the cornmeal crust. My two dining companions agreed.

(I also went to Ici and confirmed that Bi-Rite ice cream is better but that's for another review.)
author: Heather W.

description: We eat at Little Star Pizza at least once a week ... I take that back ... We get take-out from Little Star Pizza at least once a week. We always get the thin crust (we are "thin crust" people). We always get a large and say we'll save the leftovers for tomorrow (yeah, right). We always get our pie "his n' hers" style (my husband likes classic, while I'm a more mushrooms-and-olives fan ... however, we are often tempted -- and never disappointed by -- the special pizza of the day). I always tell myself, after the second slice, that I deserve a third and then rationalize my decision by reminding myself that pizza has vegetables in it and is, from that standpoint, good for me. Afterwards, I always feel a little full and a little bit guilty, promising myself that next time I'll show more restraint ... Because, Lord knows, there'll be a next time.
author: Katie B.

description: My coworker raved about this place and kept on pushing me to check this place out.  Knowing that I'm a pizza whore, he had high hopes that Little Star would rank up there.  I ordered the deep dish to go, picked it up, and went home.  I have to say, the pizza was pretty damn good.  It doesn't rank as high as Patxi's, but it is definitely a great place to get pizza.  My friend told me that it makes a difference if you order the pizza to go versus eating it inside the restaurant.  I really don't know what he's talking about, but from what I remember, the crowd inside seemed like they were having a great time.  I will definitely take his advice and eat [inside] there again.
author: Mark P.

description: Meghan B. says this place looks like a strip joint from the outside.  True.  It's the drawn red curtains.  Anyway, came here last night with vitAMYn C. and Meghan B.  and LOVED the pizza.  We had the Little Star deep dish -- spinach, ricotta, feta, mushrooms, garlic, onion served on a cornmeal crust. MMMMMMMMMM.....The crust was crispy and savory; the veggies and spices fresh.  MMMMMMMM....Also had a really tasty "hoppy" beer recommended by our delightful server, which went nicely with the pizza, the beer that is.... MMMMMMMM...My tummy's still full.  Pizza + beer + 2 beautiful wonderful friends = MMMMMMMMM.
author: Natasha S.

description:
okay, so i finally got my chance to weigh in on the zachary's versus little star debate.  after hearing sooooo much about little star and seeing nish on check, please... i made it, FINALLY.  it was perfect timing too because by chance the night before i had zachary's.  

my verdict: zachary's still WINS!!!

okay, so little star was really good.  i mean, it's really like 4 and a half.  totally worthwhile.  i still like zachary's crust better (it seems less greasy to me?) and i really like that chunky really fresh tasting tomato sauce they put on top.  the last thing is their system of preordering while you're waiting to be seated.  i mean, i think we waited like 40 minutes to be seated at little star and then another 35 or more for our pizza.  i was starving by the time it showed up!  little star does get a couple pluses though:  their green salad was really good, as was the garlic bread.  love how they give you the roasted garlic to smear on your bread.  we also tried their thin crust.  it wasn't anything special (same story as zachary's).  

glad i got to try-- still can't believe over 500 people have reviewed the little star franchise.  that's insane!!!!
author: Yvette H.

description: Yum, yum, yummy!  There is really no reason not to choose this place above all others for your pizza cravings (oh, except for the fact that you have to get up off your butt and go the to restaurant - no delivery).  The chunky tomatoes in that zingy sauce - come on, you could dream about them.  The crust doesn't get soggy, the flavors of the toppings meld together but have their own identify, and I feel like I'm reviewing a sonata.  Play on!
author: Julie L.

description: I love their wings and deep dish pizza.  The Belgian beer they offer goes well with the wings.  it gets ridiculously crowded in the weekends (about an hour wait), so I prefer to go during the week when it's only regularly full and it's only a ten minute wait.  It's amazing how bland it is outside in contrast to its designed interior.  However, it gets very noisy inside.
author: rosalyn m.

description:
i don't think i can add anything in a review that hasn't been said already.  

we got the mixed salad and deep dish vegetarian pizza. washed it down with 2 pints of blue star wheat beer.  and went home very, very happy.
author: cynthia q.

description: Have both dined here and picked up to go from here. The thick crust seems to be the favorite but for me  thin crust edges it out just a bit.. Both are so good.
author: Cindy B.

description: Most delicious! I am a thin crust gal myself,  but I did find my little eyeballs fixated on the deep dish beast that was on the table next to me. Everything was amazing. The Caprese Salad...the thin crust crust pizza with pepperoni, zucchini, and mushrooms. Wash it down with a glass of $7 Pinot Blanc and you've got a great meal!
author: Stacy T.

description:
Ok...I'd love to give this place 4 or 5 stars but I can't.  I make my living in the service industry and I don't care if you ARE in the best city in the country AND are in one of the best neighborhood in it, you HAVE to pay attention to your customers.  Without customer service your have nothing, however cute/stylish/young/hip they may or may not be...

Tonight, a couple of friends and I wanted some deep dish yummy pizza (to combat the rain) and we found it.  The pizza was fantastic; I will not take away from that.  Ingredients perfectly handled, salad divinely dressed.

Our server was wonderful as well.  This issue was that it was a TUESDAY night, and, mind you, my 4-top waited 15+ minutes for a table, we had a buzzard of a host watching our every moment.  It was as if we had De Niro's table and were holding him up.  I was sitting on the banquette so I was aware that she watched everything we did.  Now, a good host does this without the guests being aware of it.  I've done it; you have to know your room.   This was more of a countdown to our departure.  Luckily, my fellow diners were preoccupied with the pizza so they did not notice.  As one in the industry, I wish I could have done the same.

Our glasses were picked up off the table nanoseconds after they were placed empty.  Pacing happened behind our table in a frenzied fashion appropriate of a Saturday Valentine's night.  Not to mention the lack of eye contact and absence of friendliness.  Needless to say, after tipping generously, I wish I had not....

because...

it was bad enough that we were not given even a 'thank you smile' let alone a "thanks for  coming"...but one of my guests was glared at upon saying thank you.  

At this point, I was going to say something...

So, I stopped at the 'bar' to ask if I might leave a comment .  The woman behind the bar seemed more interested in looking me up and down for my sense-of-style (or whatever!)  than that I had felt rushed in my dining experience.  She said, "yeah...I'll tell the manager"...

Really.  

I live in the Mission and the attitude is not needed nor appreciated.    I'll take my business to Pauline's or Paxti's next time.

In this economy, don't we need to lift all boats by understanding that without customers, we have NO business.
author: J.C. H.

description: AWFUL SERVICE!   Ordered at  ~550pm on 12/31/13 via their web site - a large pie and salad for pickup.  Said 30 minutes and it will be ready (at Divis location).   Showed up 30 mins later at 629pm and was told it was not ready.  No follow up.  Asked again at 640, told 20 more mins.!  Had to ask bartender Benny for a beer, which he too thought was a fair thing to do.  702pm still nothing!  Asked for manager.  She had no idea where my order was. Talked to peeps who said they think they gave the pie to another person with the same name - even though they also ask for last initials too.  What?  And, salad was still not ready.  Told 20 or so more minutes.  Bummer.  Asked if they would deliver.  No.  Asked if they would consider comp'ing meal and manager laughed and said she had already said that.  Maybe I did not hear her... surprised she was laughing..... Just an awful over experience.  From 550 order to leaving my house at 620 to waiting to 729 for the order, to getting home at 740....hope the owners read this.   Just cannot have separate visibility into internet vs. phone orders at the pickup station.  Can't let orders out the door go to the wrong person.  Many people pissed at the bar trying to pick up orders.  Happy new year.
author: Henry F.

description: By far one of my favorite pizza places in the city. But then again I am a fan of any type of deep dish. What is great about this place however is the ambiance really cool, the dark walls and small bar.
author: Erin R.

description: I've been disappointed in San Francisco's pizza offering so many times that I don't get excited when someone recommends a new pizza place. Invariably, pizza that locals think is great would get you laughed at in Chicago or Brooklyn. However, I never give up hope and finally it seems justified. A friend told me about Little Star. At first I was skeptical when I saw that the menu included artichoke hearts and zucchini as a topping option. Surprise! The pizza's are actually authentic Chicago-style, with the cornmeal crust and crushed tomatoes on top of the cheese. I can't go 5 stars as I feel a pizza place should not be quite as upscale-looking as Little Star and the pies could use just a touch more cheese. Still, the pizza is outstanding and completely ends San Francisco's embarrasing lack of acceptable pies.
author: Joe H.

description: First impression when i picked up the pizza was whoa, its heavy, at least heavier than i thought for a large!  The cornmeal crust and sauce on top is definitely different than any pizza i've ever had, its great!  as soon as i got inside the car, i cracked open the box and devoured three slices.  i immediately taste the fresh roma tomatoes, mozzarella cheese, sausage, bell peppers, and onions.  now if i had a beer to wash it all down, it would have topped it off.  great pizza joint, i'd recommend it!  i'll wait a while before i come back...a large was a lot for myself.  i think i'm all pizza'ed out.
author: Michael Y.

description: Having lived in Chicago, I know that stuffed pizza can get tired and becomes the dish you serve visiting family and friends.  I had it when people visited because my preference is regular pizza.  However, if you happen to be craving the heartier version of pizza, and you live in San Francisco, Little Star is where you need to go.  The Med Chicken (no onions) is da shitz.  How can green olives, chicken, cheese and amazing crust taste bad?  I have not tried anything else here and don't plan to.  Store all your calories for the day though, this good stuff is heavy!
author: Amy N.

description: I had the classic deep dish pizza and the corn meal crust is heavenly. However, I thought the pie itself was not so great. The cheese topping is not that cheesy. You can tell when you have a great cheese pizza, when you try to lift a slice of pizza up and the string of cheese gets gooey and stringy and acts like a tug of war between your slice of pizza and the pie itself. That's why I prefer Zachery's. Zachery's diced tomatoes on their pizza top is a slice above the rest.
author: Andrenaline R.

description: I had heard people talk and talk about Little Star on Divisadero and could never get in because its always so packed. Then I visited the Mission location. Their pizza definitely does not disappoint - get the deep dish, because you're loser if you don't because that's what they're known for. The restaurant has a great atmosphere - modern, but very cozy. It was four of us, and we were able to engage in undisturbed, intimate conversation throughout dinner.  Aside from the pizza I ordered a caprese salad apetizer which was the best I have had at  a restaurant in the U.S. This is a simple salad, but it often ends up tasting bland. I personally like it when waitors treat you with respect and take your evening out seriously. 'Our guy' did, and it made the experience so much more enjoyable... or perhaps it was the second bottle of wine?
author: Katie H.

description: Ok I've heard it said many times by many different people: this is the best pizza out there. And I thought "How good can pizza really be? How different can it be? Pizza is pizza." So not true. Little Star is definitely the best pizza. Their crust is unspeakably delicious. But that being said, the pricing here is insanely expensive, so it has to be really worth it to you. And sometimes the service kind of sucks, but usually only the people seating have an attitude, I've never had a problem with the actual servers.
author: Kristin S.

description: Great, but not as good as the real thing in Chicago. The thin crust pizza is also good but I prefer Tony's or Paulines thin crusts better.
author: Brian J.

description:
came here with a vegetarian friend and i tend to be a fan of meat pizzas, so that may have affected my rating. 

we got the little star pizza, which had a whole lot of veggies on it, including mushrooms; however, i wish that they used different mushrooms than normal white mushrooms on this gourmet pizza.

prices weren't too bad, and the garlic bread was yummy -- they give you sourdough and a whole roasted garlic bulb
author: justin t.

description: Excellent Pizza.  Their garlic bread is good also.
author: X X.

description:
went for a second time today. the meatball deep dish was tasty! 
i like their deep dish better than zachary's. the crust is crispy with a bit of cornmeal.

the small was plenty for two ppl. 6 slices.

however, this time we waited for 25 minutes for a table of two. we watched as parties of 4 or more, who arrived after us, were seated before us. boo.
last time we had a party of 4 and only waited for 5 minutes. 

don't forget, cash only. there is an atm inhouse, which only charges 25 cents...but don't forget your bank will still prob charge $2.
author: Katy D.

description: I loved the White Pie when I tried it back in August for the first time... in Western Addition location. I think it's one of the all-time greatest recipes! Zucchini and Feta and garlic olive oil and tomatoes, yumMY! But I went to the new location in the Mission cuz it's right in my hood, and I think they have some kinks to work out. Totally different pie. Crust was much thinner and had less chewiness to it... toppings looked and tasted quite a bit greasier, and our House Salad was limp and lifeless; the vinaigrette was not tangy and fresh like I remember it. The bar area and general atmosphere is fun, but beware it is a CASH only restaurant. Also watch out because the windows are black and the sign is a bit cryptic so you might pass it up the first time.
author: Rebecca A.

description: We got there right when it opened and were the only ones in there, which was nice because I hear there can be quite a wait. We got a caprese salad, garlic bread (which you put on your own butter and roasted garlic cloves), and a white pie. It was a little oily, but really thin and crispy. It was quite good. I hear the deep dish is insane, too!
author: Tim M.

description: I'm not sure what it is exactly about this place, but this is the first time in a very long time that pizza has gotten me excited.  I like pizza (and the sheer amount of it I had during my college days probably put me off  of it a little) but I usually don't crave or look forward to having it again. This place did something to me to go against my usual conventions. I'm very loyal to NY style pizza, and prefer it to all other types. I'm a meat lover and usually need pepperoni or sausage on my pizza. But i came here, and not only do I love their crust, but I actually prefer the veggie pizza (the "Little Star" on the menu). And $2 PBR's!!! I can't wait to go back.
author: Jeffrey J.

description: A pizza place that doesn't deliver?  You've got to be kidding.  Automatically disqualified.
author: Tod G.

description:
i know i'm a bad midwesterner, but i like to think that my preference for thin crust pizza is acceptable since i left the midwest so long ago and was an east coaster for quite awhile.  

point is:  i'm gonna have to go back and try the thin crust at little star to truly see how i feel.  but for chicago-style pizza, they were pretty good and my dining-mates loved it.  as for me, well, the salads were delicious, the service great, and the garlic bread to die for.  

also appreciated the friendliness of the very harried host on a busy busy saturday night.  he actually managed to get us some garlic bread while we waited (maybe he liked us because we were patient and not grumpy).

maybe try it on a weeknight?  the crowd was a bit maddening on a saturday.  also, the noise level was pretty high - had to sort of yell to be heard across the small table.
author: Sharon M.

description: Went last Friday night during Passover, it was the first time I had bread in the past 5 days. (I know I am not supposed to have bread for the whole 8 days of Passover..but what can I say I am not that religious)...Anyway I digress...Only had to wait about 30 minutes and my group and I just bought a bottle of wine at the bar and chilled. The deep dish pizza was really great with perfect crispy crust.  I liked the simple decor as well as the cheap but good wine list. I would go here all the time if it was not so crowded. (But then again I would be 300lbs; so it is probably a good  thing that I have to wait).
author: Courtney R.

description: I don't know why I am bothering to write a review for a place with 390 reviews...but I might forget I ate there if I don't...We went for the deep dish since that is their specialty. It is very crispy and somewhat grainy from all that cornmeal. It holds up to the deep dish fillings well. The sauce was very flavorful and our salad fresh. With just 2 people on the early side, it was easy to get a table although several large groups were waiting. It was fairly dark and loud, somewhat barlike in atmosphere.
author: Amy E.

description: Holy sheepsh*t! This is some good stuff!
author: Ivan F.

description: YUMMMM! Little Star pizza is YUMMMM!! From the first time I went here and took a bite of their HUGE ARSE PIZZA PIE, I was hooked! And now I've got some of my friends and family hooked since we had my birthday here. Not only is this a friggin' great spot to hang at nite, but  it shines nicely during the day if you're lookin' for a private venue for a group event. Everyone here is super friendly which gives the place a great vibe and adds to the overall EXCEPTIONAL experience. Delfina, Gialina, Paxti's all good... just not Little Star!!
author: JB B.

description: would have given it two stars if the pizza was good, as the service was not there. i ordered take out and sat there for 50 minutes til they noticed me only as they were drinking and closing the restaurant and asked me if i needed anything. then, they handed me my pizza which had been done for over 30 minutes. then the pizza looked like crap, but tasted mediocre. next time, i will go to zachary's in the east bay.
author: Sean C.

description: my friend wanted pizza, I was on the fence..needed some guidance on the menu (unusual) which wasn't forthcoming, I defaulted to coffee, (they dont serve it) we walked out without ordering, hipster nonchalant service without the coffee..in the Mission.
author: Neil A.

description: Yummy! Thats really all I need to say. The pizza is great, have had both thin and deep dish and they were both good. They would be that much better if they took credit card but still good and will go back again.
author: Carli M.

description: Oh. My. God....this pizza is fabulous.  My mom and fiance who both grew up in Chicago also agreed this pizza is superior. (And it happens to have a higher Zagat rating than ANY pizza place in Chicago.)  The magic is that the pizza is not overtly heavy, but nonetheless retains it's decadance via deliciously fresh and high quality ingredients...the signature little star pizza is our favorite.  And the staff are just plain nice and down home.  (They even cheered on mom for ordering a PBR.)
author: Eva W.

description: First time there, will definitely return. We ordered the classic, the white pie and the chicken pesto pie. Hard to choose which was the best. And the leftovers tasted great the next day. Look forward to trying their deep dish next time. So nice to find a good pizza on the left coast!
author: chris m.

description: I like this place.  The other night I was craving deep dish pizza and I finally made the trip over to Little Star.  I'm glad I did.  I ordered a deep dish pepperoni pizza.  While waiting, I sat at the bar and enjoyed a beer before taking my pizza home.  I'm glad I stopped in.
author: Denny L.

description: The classic deep dish pizza with mozzarella, tomatoes, sausage, olives and ricotta was excellent! Prices are very fair given the quality of the food.
author: Thomas K.

description: The service is good and so is the pizza.  The waiter was very attentive without being suffocating anyone.  The buffalo wings are pretty tasty and come with blue cheese dressing.  The Little Star deep dish pizza is really satisfying and flavorful.  The Sangiovese isn't very good nor is the wheat beer.
author: Erik M.

description:
top service, quality pizza, great operation overall.

FOOD:~we ordered a thin crust, 1/2 chicken pesto, 1/2 classic (sausage & mushroom). it was delicious, but unfortunately made me & my bf feel ill. we can't be 100% sure that it was the pizza, but i hadn't eaten anything much all day, & this was the only thing we both ate together. i told the manager, she called the owner & they offered a $20 credit but refused to give a cash refund. after i expressed my discontent on yelp, the owner contacted me directly, & we had a lovely chat at the restaurant, he gave me a cash refund, & we drank wine together. i TOTALLY appreciated his top-notch service & attention, & i truly believe that they're running as tight an operation as possible. he reiterated several times that they wash their greens multiple times, have 100s on their inspection score cards, use the finest ingredients they can find, & keep an immaculate kitchen. i've really never heard of anyone else getting sick there, & i believe this was an aberration. my doctor said it was probably all the grease, especially on my empty stomach, but i don't think the food was tainted or infected whatsoever.

SERVICE: good, kinda airheaded.

DECOR: fancier than i expected! for a pizza joint?

BATHROOM: fine, just a single unisex stall tho.

OVERALL: i think they could be the next cpk, but a million times better!
author: Chris C.

description: Best pizza ever, the signature "Little Star" is to die for. Place is typically a zoo rightfully so, and service can sometimes be a little sluggish. It's frustrating bringing a group together here because it's cash only, but they have a ATM inside. But! my biggest complaint with the Valencia location and the demotion from 4 star to 3 stars is.. no beer on tap. For a pizza place of this caliber and this price, draft beer is a must, or at least make the bottle beer damn cheap. My advice, get your drink on at Zeitgeist first and walk over.
author: Stefan J.

description:
This place is damn good.  The most common comparison I noticed when reading the reviews prior to going to this place was that with Zachary's pizza in the East Bay.  I'd say they're a bit different but definitely in the same league (I'd also recommend Zachary's to those who have never been).  The pizza crust might over do the corn meal thing a little, but (in my experience) only after your stomach is majorly stuffed and starts telling your taste buds to step it down a notch.  

The spicy chicken wings (not to be confused with buffalo wings) were also pretty damn good in terms of flavor and texture (though my company thought it to be a bit over spicy/seasoned).

I'd recommend this place to anyone into pizza.
author: Anx R.

description: No joke, this was my first deep dish experience. Yeah, I know. I've never seen Pulp Fiction either, it just goes to show what kind of a life I have lead up until now. I'm really making an effort to try new things. It may not be fair to give this place 5 stars since it was my first time, but if it's good it's good right? This is what I have imagined deep dish to be like in my dreams, a nice crispy not too doughy crust and layers of perfectly browned cheesy goodness. Since I've walked in on people watching Pulp Fiction 521234476352 times and had to shield my eyes like it was the burning sun, I'll probably try watching it soon. If it is as good as Little Star, I can probably die happy.
author: Carly S.

description: Oh so good!  We had both the deep dish and the thin crust - both were tasty.  I'm usually not a big fan of deep dish since I find it kinda greasy...but I really loved it here.  The crust has a nice texture and not at all oily.  The tomato sauce is very full bodied, spicy,  and flavorful; it added a nice contrast to the crust.  The thin crust was also yummy - again, loved the crust's taste and texture.  I can't believe it's taken me this long to try Little Star.  I figured it was just another one of those over-hyped places...but this place lives up to the hype!
author: Eric C.

description:
twinkle, twinkle, baby. 

It's one of those places that you may need to wait forever in the crowded bar area or out on the corner where there is an unfortunate cross-wind. But it's worth the wait. I love the exposed brick and the everything on the menu. And if you are on some freakish carb-free diet, well, they have a generous and delicious green salad. I would like to recreate that dressing. I can't said I've had a bad item on the menu. The pizzas are outstanding - not oily and the crust is nice an chewy like fresh baked bread. Although I will say, skip dessert. You don't need it. Look, you've already had 10 slices of pizza. I think it's time to go home now.
author: Janet C.

description:
My friends and I were craving deep dish pizza.. Too lazy to go to the East Bay to eat Zachary's, so we did some research and came here.. 
I would like to say, they are ranking very high in my book.. The atmosphere is not what you expect.. dim lighting, kind of romantic, not a typical pizza joint.. and I would have to say, very yummy stuff.. we had the tomato sauce with chicken one and a big salad. 
I would say for the ambiance, about 2 stars better than Zachary's and for the food, Zachary's wins by a star. good stuff nontheless..
author: Mari K.

description:
I thought we had a hit as we had previous L.S. meals that were successful; yours truly loved Little Star in Divisadero. So I presumed this trip would be another home run. Unfortunately, it was a case where great food could not overshadow the service.

Food:  FOUR STARS- Garlic bread was once again a great hit. Great bulb of garlic to spread over the butter and warm bread . The Mediterranean chicken and vegetarian pies were really good. Loved the zucchini in the veggie pie, really stood out. They were able to sub the feta cheese with mozzarella for the mediterranean, which was nice.

Service: TWO STARS. This is where even the most immaculate pizza pie couldn't make up for it. We waited a very long time for our garlic bread to arrive, maybe close to 10 minutes, which just seemed like a lot for us. But we ordered a veggie and a non-veggie pizza for the 4 of us. The server specifically placed the pizzas on the table and noted which one was veggie and which one had chicken. Only problem: she mixed it up. So let's just say one wondered why chicken tasted light like zucchini and another was shocked that artichokes were really chicken.
No hives, breakouts, or "refunding of the meal" was required, but just a big no-no especially with hardcore vegetarians in the party.  We briefly mentioned it to the server and she seemed apologetic. The mgr actually stopped by and gave us a discount on the meal and apologized as well. They explained the lighting sometimes causes confusion. Well...then fix the lighting! 
It was cool that the mgr stopped by and rectified it, but it was one of those "too little too late" moments that would make Donald Trump say, "You're Fired."

Atmosphere:  THREE STARS. Very packed on a friday nite. Duh, but then again it was packed on a Saturday nite in Divisadero and it there was at least more breathing room or places to sit down. Wait time was around an hour & 15 for a table. On the plus, the restrooms were very clean, but the dining tables were really scrunched together and there were very little room for conversation. The Divisadero spot was much more open and actually made the most of its tables to make it more personal. Parking-wise, go to 16th or 17th for street parking. 

So overall, it averaged out to 3 stars. I was going to give it 2 stars, but since the mgr did apologize, it gets a third star. And that was very cool of her to do that, I can't stress that enuff. Would I come back here? Here, maybe only for takeout, but for now I'm probably gonna stick with the Divisadero location.
author: Neil N.

description: In case you still aren't convinced, the pizza is great.  The service was friendly and glasses for the cold drinks are nicely chilled.
author: Amy D.

description: Just as good as the original NOPA location! The best Chicago inspired deep dish pizza in the bay area (better than Zacharys, and well Paxti's is not even on my map). The valencia version of this place has a similar dark and hip atmosphere as the other location, as well as the great juke box. I know deep dish pizza isn't for everyone, but, if you haven't made the pilgrimage yet, you should make it part of your 2007 New Year's resolutions.
author: Neil K.

description:
I love your pizza, i love your staff.  i've never had a bad experience here.  anytime a friend from out of town visits, this is the place that i suggest for dinner.  

as for tips, i always suggest asking for a little pesto on top of the pizza - trust me, it's fantastic.  besides that, be ready to hang out at the bar for a minute if you're planning on dinner friday or saturday night.
author: nick e.

description: SO glad that the new location is open -- same pizza, just 10 minutes closer to my side of town!  I melt over the spinach with ricotta and feta.  Love the sauce and crust.  I am so looking forward to reheating my leftovers tomorrow!
author: Nat K.

description: The pizza option in SF suck.  Little Star is the best in the city and it's deep dish!!!  Sadly it is "fancy pizza," so you will pay an arm and a leg for it.  They accordingly do not deliver but you can do pick up.  Honestly with the prices you pay go in and enjoy the restaurant.  Its not a pizza joint, its a clean, slightly sophisticated eatery (for Mission standards-i.e. red wine instead of PBR).  Wine and anti-pasta options are very good.  Prepare yourself for long waits on the weekends.
author: BeeryMcGymrat X.

description: Damn, delicious deep dish.  If you like it thick, this is the spot.  Their salads are pretty good too.  But, I do not recommend their thin crust.... dry and burnt.  Their crusts are made for deep dish, so aren't right for thin crust.  If you're there, you shouldn't be ordering thin crust anyway.  They have great unique beers on tap too.  Yum.
author: Joe S.

description: Yummy deep dish pizza with corn meal crust.  Wait is a bit long, but worth it.
author: B C.

description:
the other little star doesn't take reservations, but supposedly this one does.  that is if you want a reservation between 5-7p or 9-10p.  lame-O.  

but that didn't effect the food.  the pizza was still tastey and the garlic bread still deadly.  the beer was cold!  big plus.  

the prices aren't as bad as i thought.  went there for a b-day dinner.  it was me and 6 guys.  we made it out of there for $20 each, including tip.  now granted we did most of our drinking before and after the pizza, with only a beer or two each during dinner (and two of the guys were drink $2PBR).  but still!
author: jen b.

description:
It was good!  It was really good!  I followed my fellow yelper's advice and made my way over to Valencia Street for pizza.  I tried to go to Pauline's, but they had run out of dough!  So I walked two blocks down the street to Little Star Pizza.  I'm sure Pauline's would have been good, but I am glad I ended up where I did because the signature Little Star deep dish was amazing.  Paired with a couple $2 PBRs and a large salad, my meal with a friend came to only $42.  We had a large salad, large deep dish, and 2 beers each, and  we walked out the door for $25 per person.  $2 for beer at a restaurant makes me so happy!  The interior is classic San Francisco - small, crowded, hip, unique with exposed brick wall.  Classic San Francisco is usually a good thing as in this case.

Two important notes:
1.) CASH ONLY (but they do have an ATM on site).  Again, classic San Francisco - establishments seem to hate paying the card companies(An instance where typical San Francisco can be improved upon).
2.)Be prepared to wait.  I waited for an hour starting at 8:30 on a Saturday night.
author: t l.

description: Bring your appetite, the deep dish just keeps on giving.
author: Angela K.

description:
We had the Classic deep dish, large salad and spicy chicken wings. The wings were a bit of a surprise for two reasons -- first, they had a huge kick and had my typically-spice-loving korean tongue enjoying a slow burn and second, it was a peppery dry rub (as opposed to those radioactive red mass produced sauces).  they were rather enjoyable despite my husband's prolific perspiration. 

The salad was typical fare but fresh with lots of nuts and goat cheese. As for the pizza, it was delicious and filling. The corn meal crust was unique and took a slice to get used to but my kids found it addictive. There was ample cheese in the middle, topped by a tangy red sauce with big chunks of tomato. I liked the pizza about a half star better than Patxi's though the latter has better service, a killer caesar salad and flat screens with sports. They are equally lacking in parking accommodations.
author: C K.

description:
Is Little Star better than Zachary's?  No, but it is till very good - 4 stars for the food, but minus 1 star due to our surly waitress.  

We were off to a good start - fun champagne drinks and excellent wings (spicy but not greasy).  Then came the head-to-head comparison of the deep dish Mediterranean pizza.  LS's has an airy corn meal crust that I like more than Zachary's, but the flavor/mix of ingredients didn't have the same pop as Zachary's version.  Zachary's wins hands down on the thin crust both in flavor, crust texture, and visual appeal.  Do they have dessert at LS?  Can't tell you, since our waitress threw our check in the middle of the table before we finished our pizza, so I guess not?!

Overall, if you are in the City and can't make it to Berkeley for Zachary's then Little Star is an adequate substitute.  And maybe the service is a little friendlier at their Divisadero location.
author: Lori G.

description:
I hate dropping the name of "the competition" in a review for a place, but in this instance, it'll be a compliment to compare Little Star to Zachary's in Berkeley.  

The landmark pizza joint in Berkeley is "the" undisputed hero of tomato-pie eaters flung the world over.  My favorite cousin comes from London every year just to recall his first PhD in the OB department at UC Berkeley by gorging himself on an entire "deep dish" - yes, the whole thing, all by himself.  Seriously, don't get too close when the feeding frenzy is on, you could lose an arm, or at least your favorite pinky-toe. 

I am pleased to say that I have a destination a little closer to my own home, and to my own fond life-education within the Mission. I had heard about Little Star from friends, and always took their advice with a grain of salt, after all - I had been to Zachary's, so there was no looking back.  Now, having been invited to a birthday gathering for a certain tomato-hater I know, I too have discovered a close second to the benchmark. By second I mean 99.5% or the original.  And by tomato-hater, I mean a hot blond schoolteacher I find myself enamored of lately. When a pie is so good that a person who claims to hate tomato's gobbles down 20 slices in 7 minutes, its saying something about the quality of the food, and the ability to pleasantly and gastronomically disguise an otherwise disdained vegetable or fruit. I speak of course of Mediterranean Deep Dish, which was a crowd favorite, and the reason for my own tears of joy on this particular Saturday night.

I will remember Saturday the 14th of April, 2007 for a number of reasons.  Not the least of which involves a charming educator who turned 32 on that day.  But also because of the satisfaction I found in broadening my pizza horizons, filling my fat belly, and ultimately delighting in the knowledge that I have a special treat to share with family and friends whenever they feel the need to feed. I also have a place for my own special events that doesn't involve any form of despised public transport. Just a quick walk from the heart of the Mission on Valencia and 15th, Little Star is a destination all it's own, and one I will be making often, well into the future.
author: Jeffrey T.

description: I honestly only been here once but I love it! The caprese salad and deep dish pizza was sooo good! My friend took me to this place and I fell in love. =) I tried to come back but they were only open for dinner on that very day I came to get more.. =( Well, I'll be back!
author: Kissy F.

description: Love this place!  Very hip, dark atmosphere.  Servers are cool, attentive and make good recommendations when you ask.  The pizza is fantastic!  I've only had the deep dish (you can get thin crust anywhere).  The Little Star deep dish is my fave and the Vegetarian is a close second.  Beer in bottles and variety of wine.  The caprese salad is yummy and a nice light way to start.  Oh and they play GREAT music!!
author: Amy S.

description: It takes forever to get a table and they don't do reservations. The pizza takes a long time to cook. The bar area is super small. There's no TV to watch the game, why is it so dark?. Did I mention the ridiculously long wait. And it is THE BEST (CHICAGO STYLE) PIZZA IN THE BAY AREA. You have to try it! This isn't your regular pizza shack. It is "fancy-smancy" pizza and it is darn GOOD. The corn meal crust is incredible. It is hard to compare a pizza restaurant that pairs Kermit Lynch (awesome place) imported wines from France to a Blondies or even Zachareys where soda and beer are the beverages of choice.
author: Big B. W.

description:
we used to go and eat inside.  but we always had to wait about 1 hour and we decided to pick-up and eat in our place.
we were told our pizza would be ready in 30min when we ordered, but it was over an hour until our order was ready.  we had to wait for more than 30min at the restaurant.   i with they just tell us an hour.  this is insane.
we wont go back again.

Update:  I tried out this place again a couple of times.  I went weekend, but no wait:)
author: Suki K.

description: Went here just this past weekend for a birthday bite with friends and fam, and let me tell you...for 15 bucks per person, you CANT go wrong. Despite waiting for about an hour to be seated (no reservations & friday night) we started with drinks and and some bread while some stood and some sat at the bar. The appetizer we had was the garlic bread, which was an inexpensive and a deliciously innovative twist on what we were expecting. A small loaf of slightly toasted ciabatta style bread, warm creamy butter and a whole head of roasted spreadable garlic (Similar taste to the "bathtub of garlic" from The Stinking Rose). 5 bucks and so damn tasty! After we were seated, needless to say the 12 of us were starving and decided to order immediatly. 4 pizza's, 3 breads, 2 chicken wings and a few bottles of wine. Everything from the crust to the warm deep dish tomatoe spread tasted fresh and delicious. I personally would recommend the thin crust pesto chicken pizza. Not overwhelmingly garlic'y but just the perfect amount of ingredients to satisfy my entire palette. The meal ended with a "happy birthday" and some delicious caramel cheesecake. Needless to say..it was a wonderful dinner and would like to give an extra special thanks to our servers (I wish i knew your names cuz you both kicked ass!) food was quick & service was top notch. I cant blame them so much for the wait, but I would think reservations would have been appropriate given the party size and date..otherwise it wouldve been a 5 star review! Thanks Little Star, we'll be back!
author: Kai N.

description: We always get a deep dish pizza with various toppings. My fav is a black olive/green olive pizza: saltily and cheesily delicious. There's usually a short wait, but you can take a seat at the bar and get a glass of wine until your party is called. Good atmosphere, good waitstaff, good pizza. Win all around! Little Star on Mission is my favorite pizza parlor in the city.
author: Heather T.

description:
my first impression of little star (Divis) was:
overcrowded hipster pizza joint . yawn.
 i figured the only reason people were going there was the lack of other options for convenient pre- independent affordable beers and food.

BUT 

my second visit  (Valencia) I made the pivotal choice to order the wings and now praise the lord, hallelujah  I have seen the light. 
The pizza is still fine, whatever, but the wings, the wings alone are worth giving the restaurant 4 stars and returning for regular visits to get my fix.  
One should note these are not buffalo wings, insipid pre packaged junk whose age and dryness are masked by a grotesquely artificial messy orange sauce heavenly spiced only to further distract one from the taste. No, these are perfectly crisp, tender fresh chicken wings which require no sauce at all but are appropriately accompanied by a seemingly home made bleu cheese dressing which only further enhances the flavor profile.
yum
author: rachel k.

description: This is a good place, but can be a little noisy and hard to get in. The Mixed salad is very good. Definitely recommend. I am not a pizza fan in general, but it is not bad.
author: Sophie N.

description: If you are a pizza lover...I mean, as in EVERYWHERE you go you look for the best pizza, then this is the place for you. After asking San Francisco locals, and reading countless internet reviews, my hubby and I (huge fans of pizza) decided to try Little Star. We went in as skeptics (we have, after all, been to Chicago and New York) and left as believers. We ordered the deep dish vegetarian and the deep dish artichoke and pepperoni. It was perfect! The atmosphere: dark, candle lit, young crowd, bar, crowed, loud (music and conversation), busy. The service: friendly, fast, accurate. The pizza: try and see for yourself!
author: Rachel J.

description: Yum.  Thanks for moving into the mission.  I don't care for the sometimes lengthy wait, the food and wine selection has always been well worth it.  And the staff?  Thank you for always making me feel like I'm coming home for dinner.
author: Jessie'sGirl m.

description:
Little Star Pizza was a bit boring for an American thin crust pizza. There was too much tomato sauce on it - belch! I ordered a second thin crust pizza minus the tomato sauce; it was better without the tomato sauce, but still bland.

Pizza is one of my least favorite foods, but I've been in search of a thin crust pizza like the one I had in a small town outside of Venice, Italy a number of years ago - that one was fantastic! Alas, it's been a struggle to find anything close to that. A few have come close, but the best thin crust pizza, really, is in Italy.
author: Apollo T.

description:
When I think Chicago-style pizza... I think a lot of dough, way too much cheese, and just an overall, over the top unhappy experience. Having stuck to thin crust pizza all my life, it took some convincing that deep dish could have positive gastronomic qualities but was swayed by the several happy reviews of foodie friends who hailed Little Star's pies as "amazing", "so good", "had four slices!" and "you have to try".
I'm now a believer. I had just moved into the area and stopped by Little Star for dinner with the same foodie friends who had coaxed my curiousity; I would say, it's definitely a California spin (given the kitschy Mission decor, and California wine list plus the pies themselves... you'll just have to see) on what I remember Chicago deep dish being, but it is oh-so-good that way. The sauce is so tasty, fresh, and generous in portion. There is not an excessive amount of dough, and its nice and crisp... kinda like a tougher pastry dough. So good, be assured that all crusts will be eaten!
The ingredients? Fresh, yum, and oh I want a piece right now! We ordered the Classic and the Little Star, and while I love both I think I my heart truly belongs with the Little Star. A vegetarian type pizza, this is sure to please both carnivores and veggie-only kin alike! The cheese selection, the mounds of spinach... so good, really I'm starting to salivate as I write.
We split the pies among 7 people,  most of us having moderate sized appetites, and it was about $10 a person including tax and tip (tip is included for parties over 6). Drinks were separate, and about $4 to $7 a person without tax or tip, and I would recommend the usual beer or wine, but maybe stay away from the Champagne cocktails, which are interesting but I don't think really go with the meal.
Be warned, I did wait a good half hour, but that was time well spent sipping drinks we'd ordered at the bar and catching up with friends. :) I'll definitely be back!
author: Jessica L.

description: I gave it a good review...but I'm a little biased on this one because I'm from Chicago.  BUT they have fresh ingredients and a crunchy crust.  It's a little thin for Chicago style and not really and DEEP PIE, but none-the-less it is delish.  The crowd was cool and the atmosphere was pizza-nice.  Also the thin crust, specifically the pesto chicken was great.  Separately, there was a waitress wearing Indian moccasins that was hella cute.
author: Jake H.

description: My husband is a man with discriminating pizza tastes and has long lamented that he hasn't been able to find a decent pie in the Bay Area.  That is, until we went to Little Star.  Our first time there, we found ourselves in heaven, particularly over their thin crust pies.  The crust is on par with many east coast establishments (crispy, flaky, no hint of cardboard flavor or texture), their base tomato sauce (if used) is fresh-tasting, and they don't overwhelm their pies with mountains of cheese and toppings.  We pretty much only do takeout since, although the inside is cozy, it tends to get very crowded and loud.  They are very reasonably priced given the quality of food you are getting.
author: Kaman C.

description: I swear this crust has crack in it cause its sooooooo good. Service rawked as well (Drunk Girl says order the Zin not the Pinot!). Awesome vibe, great pizza!
author: Inome C.

description: Pretentious pizza with worse service. The pizza was ok, like just pizza, some bread with some cheese and some toppings. Caprice salad was good, but I don't know how to mess that one up either. Our waiter was a Jerk with a capital J. I happen to enjoy my pizza with a side of ranch, or a side of BBQ. Normal requests right? Not to Little Star. Our waiter made me feel like a total dumb-ass just asking for simple condiments, it was like he was so weirded out with my request that he could no longer serve us. Totally disappeared. Maybe I wanted to order another pizza, or a glass of wine... oh well.
author: Lisa M.

description: I thought I was sick of pizza...until I met Little Star. It's pretty hard to find good deep dish pizzas, but I this little gem has GREAT deep dish pizzas! They were hearty but still crispy, and the girls I was with couldn't stop themselves from finishing every last slice. I especially liked the pesto chicken one. The thin-crust pizzas are great too, but not as great as the deep-dishes. I recommend any of the pizzas with mushrooms. Great for groups or a date, since it's low key trendy. Just expect a wait...and bad parking. But I can't wait to go again! We need one in SOCAL!!!
author: yeana j.

description: I love Little Star Pizza!  Although this was only my second visit, it definitely won't be my last!  Their deep dish pizzas are to die for!  My favorite is the "Little Star" which has spinach, mushrooms, and ricotta cheese - their pizza sauce is absolutely the BEST I've ever had - not too salty, kind of chunky, and very fresh!   We also shared a house salad, which is plenty for two people.  Get here early, though - we arrived about 5:30 on a Friday evening, and were seated right away.  When we left an hour later, the lobby/bar area was filled with people waiting.  Go early, or get the pizza to go!
author: Debbie B.

description:
The only thing redeeming I got out of dating one previous douche nozzle was the introduction of Little Star. Ah, Little Star. I'm glad I met you. It was fate that brought me to you. Let me count how many ways I love you. 

You're always there for me when I need you. Well except when you're closed on Mondays. All is forgiven though, when I order my deep dish Little Star Pizza. It is seriously a slice of heaven. It contains so many ingredients that I don't like, but they're blended together so perfectly that it works. The spinach, ricotta, tomato, mushroom, and onion..so yummy. The cornmeal crust is the SHIZNIT. If ever, I want to stray to another place, I always remind myself it will not compare to you. It also tastes so great the next day cold, which I can not say about many pizza places at all. I have tried pretty much everything on the menu, my faves are the deep dish Little Star (duh!) sacrelige to order anything else. My thin crust fave is the White Pie with salami (as introduced to by the WC). I love the blue star wheat beer and did I mention the buffalo wings and the blue cheese dressing. Make sure to order extra blue cheese, it is divine! 

Added bonus, their jukebox is amazing. It basically has every album I have ever loved circa 1999-2003. I love walking in and hearing all my fave tunes and then sharing a meal with the WC. It is the best. Their acoustics in here are terrible though, may want to rethink the brick walls as it just bounces sound across the room. The long wait can be a pain, but it's well worth it. I wish they delivered, but that would probably take away from the experience of what is Little Star.
author: Kristy H.

description: I've been here twice and both times the pizza was delicious. If you are a fan of Chicago style deep dish pizza then Little Star delivers.
author: Nate D.

description: I would petition Yelp to allow me to give six stars if Little Star would add the BBQ chicken deep dish pizza to its regular menu, and that's coming from a girl who doesn't even like deep dish pizza. It's THAT good.
author: Heather F.

description: Yes, I love the Little Star Pizza food.  What I can't stand is the marginal wait staff.  Went there this past week for pizza, and when you are getting a $53 pizza dinner, (one pizza, two salads, no alcholhol) I think I can do without the snooty abrupt behavior.  By the way, the noise level is really loud too!
author: Cheryl J.

description:
finally had the opportunity to try the mission dist. location last night and it was great!
i love deep dish and little star satisfies me every time.  lovely crust and toppings... i indulged in the classic deep dish and also got to taste one of the thin crust pizzas since sister in-law wasn't into deep dish... the thin crust is amazingly tasty too... and that's something coming from a person who loves... really loves thick crusts and deep dish and would only eat thin crust if there was absolutely nothing else to chose from... mmmmmm... 
the service was great as well even though it was packed and five of us :)
author: charlotte s.

description: For the deep dish pizza I give Little Star 5 full stars.  Their deep dish pizza is better than Zachary's or any other deep dish in the bay area.  For the service I have to give 3 stars. If you want to dine in be ready to wait your ass off, getting hungrier with each passing minute as you smell the pizza and see the slow eating bastards in front of you enjoying themselves.  I suggest ordering the pizza for pick up.  If you really want to dine in I suggest taking some medicinal marijuana (only if prescribed by a doctor) and spend the waiting time picking songs off the jukebox.
author: Jake A.

description: this place is so great, super friendly, amazingly good pizza(some of the best crust i've had) and a good selection of drinks. So many toppings to chose from with interesting weekly additions. a little on the pricey side, but  oh well. plus you can watch them have knife fights with pauline's down the street if you stay after closing.
author: Jared Z.

description: bigger and better than the Divis location!  I am SO excited to live within a block!
author: Kerry L.

description: I'm normally a thin-crust kind of girl, but every now and then I feel the need to get down and dirty with a little deep dish.  And when I do, I can always count on Little Star's Classic to rock my world.  The crisp cornmeal crust is fucking fantastic--it's ALMOST good enough to convince me to switch teams.  I may never leave the thin crust, but Little Star's deep dish will always be the one temptation I can't resist.
author: Sharyn F.

description: Actually this place should be a 4.5 but I gotta say service kinda rubbed me the wrong way. I got a large deep dish half original and half chicken mediterranean i think thats how u spell it..... I dont know im ESL... So I didnt really like the chicken but loved the meat w/veggies. I will be going back.  i like it.
author: Mark F.

description:
Run to Little Star for the best (only?) corn meal crust deep dish in SF.

Yumma bigga.

- Jon
author: Jon B.

description: Thanks Little Star for making our Valentine's dinner special. We will be back!  xo L
author: Leeshawn N.

description:
The cornmeal crust and marinara sauce are critical to this place's success.

and may it continue for years to come.
author: Daniel C.

description: Let's just say I live very, very close to Little Star and eat a small deep dish pizza there once a week.  Sausage, chicken and basil.  I have a ritual: I buy a bottle of red wine from Bi-Rite, stop in Little Star on the way home and put in an order, go home and drink a glass, pick up the pizza, eat 4 slices and refrigerate the other 2.  By the time the bottle is gone I am ready to re-heat the remaining 2 slices in the oven.  The trick is scooping the tomatoes onto a plate before you pop the slices in the oven.  The last step in the ritual is telling myself that the 6 block round trip to Bi-Rite negates the rest of it.  I realize this is false but that is the beauty of faith.
author: Kasey K.

description: My first Chicago style pizza experience.  It was good.  The crust was crispy cornmeal which I was told is signature Chicago style, so I guess I should have expected that.  It was good, but I'm saving the 4th and 5th star for when my socks are knocked off.
author: tamera t.

description:
i'ma total midwestern girl who lived in Chicago most of my life. then i moved to SF 4 years ago and was missing one of my favorite treats - deep dish pizza. i wouldn't call Little Star's deep dish "chicago style" per se, but definitely fulfills my craving. Dare I say I like it BETTER than my favorite deep dish in Chicago?! YES, I do! It's so freakin delicious. The cornmeal crust is nice and crisp, they are generous with their toppings, the sauce is tangy and sweet at the same time, and it's just the best pie i've ever had. ever. 

they get 4 stars because the service is not so good when you eat in. but then again, it is the mission, so what do you expect? i always get the classic deep dish with a mixed salad and it's the perfect amount for 2 people.

trust me, it's damn good.
author: Pumakat K.

description: Went there for dinner last night. food was excellent. waitress seemed clinically depressed or profoundly irritated and unhappy. not that there is anything wrong with that, but a waitress shouldn't necessarily convey that sentiment/attitude, right?
author: leyla m.

description: Awesome pizza. 'Nuf said. Deep and delicious. Tasty toppings. Even tastier crust (my favorite part of any pizza). Pleasant atmosphere. Enjoyed a beer at the bar before my dinner date appeared.
author: E C.

description:
i liked the garlicky spinach and tomato deep-dish but the starter greens salad was unremarkable, quarters were way too tight and place was far too noisy. 

although i didn't go to have a salad per se, i think it should be just as good as the main thing. 

anyhow, i'd like to try other kinds.
author: N J.

description: I go minimum 3x per month.  My absolute favorite.  I usually pick up my order because the dining room can be hectic, especially on the weekend.   I used to live in Berkeley and thought no pizza would ever compare to Zachary's,  so when i say Little Star gives them a run for their money, i'm speaking from experience.
author: jim a.

description:
being a die-hard thin crust pizza lover, i was curious about little star and it's deep dish fame. this place did not disappoint.

my girlfriend and i started off with the small mixed salad that was in itself filling, given the generous mounds of gorgonzola and walnuts. we were forewarned by our server that the pizza would take 40 minutes to prepare, to which i audibly gasped. it was torture to see the tables flanking us digging into their pies voraciously, as the sweet-salty aromas wafted over to taunt us. the wait was well worth it.

we split a small pie, half little star & half mediterranean chicken and i nearly inhaled my 3 slices. the little star was the more appetizing of the two. the smooth ricotta was a nice rich foil to the tangy chunks of tomato topping and tangy feta, and the mushrooms and onions balanced out the flavors. but my favorite was the rich olive-oily, buttery crust. almost tasted corn-mealy - YUM. definitely coming here again!!
author: Janet L.

description: Damn, this is good pizza. I'm eating it right now as I write this review. Recommended for anyone who loves Chicago-style pie.
author: Chase S. K.

description: Gooey crunchy orgasms in your mouth.  Little Star pizza is like really good sex.  Seriously.....REALLY good sex.
author: C. W.

description:
Delightful deep dish
With kick ass indie jukebox
Tasty thin crust too
author: HaikuReview X.

description: The classic Little Star Pizza is divine.  I personally like it better than Zachary's spinach and mushroom pie (I feel it is a little lighter and the tomato sauce on top is more mellowed and flavorful).  Plus their salads are excellent.
author: Vik K.

description: My experience may have been colored by a tearful post-break up date. Why do I torture myself in public? When does a post-break up date ever sound like a good idea, ever? Anyhow, perhaps I am just not a fan of deep-dish pizza--the tomatoes were too tomato-ey (is that possible? does that make any sense?), and overall our veggie pizza was just uninspiring, as was my salad. Though I welcome any future invitations for a date here that does not involve tears.
author: Melissa G.

description:
Good deep-dish pizza w/ sausage and mushrooms.
(this is a review covering many past visits)
author: Max D.

description: We finally tried this place and though the food is good we left a little disappointed. Neither one of us are into the hipster scene and this place definitely has that kind of vibe. The deep dish pizza is OK and will do in a pinch but really not comparable to Zachary's. So we probably won't go back. It might be a good choice for pick up if you are really craving deep dish and don't feel like making the trek to east bay.
author: Reza E.

description: The deep dish with meat is great. Good sized portion's and the crust is crispy. Mamma mia am I in heaven? No, just in a slice of Mission heaven. Long waits to get the delectable dish's but once the 30-60 minute wait is over the servers are fast and courteous. Take someone special and you won't be disappointed.
author: Roman L.

description:
there are only two problems with little star - the wait can be excruciating and the bill can been overwhelming. 

thats it. there is nothing else wrong. everthing else is perfect. perfect deep dish, perfect variety, perfect wine, perfect ambiance, perfect vibe, perfect staff. seriously, it is a lovely lovely dark glowing cave of yum.
author: Lily S.

description: How corny would it be if I broke out into a certain popular children's song in praise of a certain restaurant's deep dish pizza? If I happen to be that corny, I'm sure the lyrics would go something like this: twinkle twinkle little star, i'm so glad i found you b/c you not only satiated my craving for deep dish, but took it to another level of yum! okay, so that isn't really how the song goes but after you take a bite out of this pie, who really cares? we had the garlic bread (their bread & garlic are the TRUTH) and their classic deep dish and we had it all take-out. I don't think the quality would be anything less if we dined in. Loved that it wasn't greasy and that the toppings weren't engorged in tomato sauce. Now if I could only trick my body to having a deep dish craving so I can relive it all over again.
author: Cecile Q.

description:
The pizza is just as good as the original location, but, somehow, the design of the restaurant itself is more annoying than the Divisadero location.

I would love to purchase pizza from them if I was going to a nearby get-together, but I don't think I will ever eat there again. The Mission Little Star is attempting to be the opposite of the original. Instead of emo art-school black curtains and a bar in the back, the bar confronts you upon entry, where too few stools are arranged. There is a huge void on the floor where the tables are situated rather far away, and a plethora of lights showcase patrons.

The pizza is still a great alternative to Patxi's, but the design of the restaurant is bizarre and dischordant.
author: Mike K.

description:
over 1,500 reviews between this and their divisidero location. amazing. awesome.  

can't go wrong so it comes down to personal taste.  i much rather prefer the crust at Patxi's.  its saltier and more flaky.  this one is more dense. 

didn't like any of the photo's so added my own. enjoy
author: Alex C.

description: The garlic bread comes with a giant roasted whole garlic clove, the pesto chicken and deep dish veggizza came fresh and hot, the salad was a nice mix greens with a perfect amount of dressing.  This place is quaint, has wonderful food and the service was great even if you're with a big group of loud lesbians. If you want some gourmet pizza this is the place to go.  Also the price is just right!
author: Christina C.

description: My partner and I have been eating here since it opened (we live around the corner). We have always had consistently great food and service! We are both  also in the service industry and like to read yelp's on our work places and our favorite haunts. Ha, to the last people that ordered a "pineapple pizza". Unless I am crazy, have never seen that on the menu and we go there at least 3 times a month, at least! Love love love little star! Thank you for consistently putting us in food coma.
author: bartholomew k.

description: Yum yum!  Finally made it to this spot tonight and had the chicken pesto thin crust with my friend Kira who's been visiting.  The garlic bread is DIY and super tasty too.  Prices are reasonable and it feels New York-ish in the sense that the tables are a bit tight  but hey as long as you don't have someone with an annoyingly loud talking voice you should be fine.
author: Gene X.

description: I have to agree with the previous posts-their deep dish meat pizza with thick cornmeal crust is truly orgasmic, wanting to take my clothes off kind of good.  Want to go back,....esp. With a hot date!  Seriously, where are the men in this city?  Like the decent ones that buy you flowers before spending the night. :p
author: Patty J.

description: Ive been here twice and not been let down... good beverage choices and the pizza is good. Love the crust. I alsi like their idea of serving garlic bread with an entire roasted clove or garlic, haha.
author: Denny C.

description: Deep dish or thin crust- both are very yummy! A nice selection of brews as well. Only problem is too many people wanna get their Little Star fix, and you may have to wait your turn. It takes half an hour to prepare the deep dish, but well worth the wait.
author: Sandi E.

description: I loved the vegetarian pizza, though honestly, the caprese salad was better.  Excellent, thick slices of fresh cheese, super tasty heirloom tomatoes, and thick slices of toasted bread all drizzled with a phenomenal dressing.  My only complaint was the closeness of the tables.  I consider myself a pretty gregarious person, but when the tables are so close that you can see the pores on the face of the diner next to you, even the most gregarious person shouts for a bit of privacy.
author: D H.

description: I gotta say... it's pizza & beer done right.  The new Star is a little posher than most joints with hardwood floors, dim lighting, and a lot of brick, but when it comes down to it it's still about the pizza and beer.  Loved the local brews they offer and drank them outta the bottle all night long, just like you should.  We ordered 2 smalls: the deep-dish Mediterranean Chicken, which had potential but was pretty "ehh" because it was drenched in tomato sauce, and the thin-crust White, which was fantastic.  Perfect amount for 3 peeps.  There weren't the expected oooh's and aaaah's but it's just downright good pizza & beer.
author: Tara G.

description:
i use to love the thai place that little star pizza is currently in..  i totally forgot what the place was called.. haha.. 

anywayz, again crust wins at Little Star.. me and the wife were debating whether they add some cornbread mixture in the crust.. but nonetheless its just makes the pizza that much better.. the toppings never overwhelmed the pizza.. perfect...

the caprese salad was dope.. perfect balance between the sweet tomatoes and the slightly tart balsamic vinegar.. and the mozzarella was really fresh..
author: Carlo M.

description: YUMMY! I love that the Valencia St. location takes reservations. We had the thin crust special of the day - white cheddar, bacon and spinach - and a classic deep dish. Very tasty! The cornbread crust was simply addictive - I loved the texture and the fact that it was not soaking in grease.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
you can only get a deep dish in san francisco at little star or patxis.  i would definitely say little star pizza's better tasting than patxis.  so, since i crave myself a deep dish often, i turn to little star.  this little star, i feel, is better than the divis one.  it's larger with more seating.  it's easier to find parking.  if you dine in, prepare for a wait -- unless you have a reservation, but the reservations aren't helpful when a craving suddenly hits you at 3:05PM because they only accept reservations for that night before 3PM.

the service staff is sometimes a hit or miss.  mostly they are pretentious hipsters that serve you a plate of attitude.  if you think you're too good to serve me, then umm... get out of the waiting business?

their take-out is pretty decent.  you tell them when you want to pick your pizza up and they'll have it ready for you by then.  and for just a pick-up, you can just park in the bus zone for the five minutes right outside.  no fuss.
author: H. L.

description: Dave and I have an ongoing conversation bout the 2 little stars. After last nite's deep dish classic at Valencia, I am voting this establishment has the better pizza, though Divisadero has the better salad dressing. A meal after yoga, and after a series of downpours - I needed comforting. The corn meal pizza crust is reminiscent of Viccolo's in its hey day. Kudos to V for introducing many of us to corn meal crust. The staff that nite was primarily women, hostess, wait staff, bartender. I've noticed staff at the Divis is predominantly male, with the occasional gal host. I'll add to this observation later on.
author: One P.

description: We ordered a small vegetarian pizza with pepperoni added for pickup. They said half an hour. So I  was there salivating after reading all the reviews from my fellow fantastic yelpers. I waited a few minutes after the girl at the bar said and i quote, "it will be just a few more minutes" so a few minutes go by and i am watching the employees put all the booze away, i then asked her, "is the pizza ready", at which point she looks under the register and magically my pizza appears. She then goes to make some excuse that someone probably brought it over when she wasn't looking. I was mildly irritated because i watched them the entire time and no one came over with a pizza. It was sitting there the entire time I was. but overall the pizza is awesome- the staff or really the one gal behind the bar that is a pizza magician is ok.
author: Zannie S.

description: By far the worst restaurant experience ever in San Francisco. We went there with our two little girls and were expecting for one more person to join us. The waitress said she could not seat us as they do not seat incomplete parties. This restaurant probably has at least 50 seats, number of people seated at the time we walked in 4 (makes you wonder which big party was going to show up as she could not seat our incomplete party!!!! Upon telling them we have kids who are hungry and we would like to order right away, she seated us with a truckload of attitude! It gets better, my older daughter needed to use the restroom which was "Out of Order". Restaurant rule number one, have operational restrooms. Not only it is totally unhygienic, it is a SFDPH violation to have patrons and employees who cannot access a restroom!!! Upon expressing our dissatisfaction, waitress politely explains this is out of her control as she is not a plumber!! Pizza took a total of 45 minutes to arrive, was so lacking in flavor that my kids said "it is the worst pizza ever and waitress is so mean", I have to fully agree with their opinion.
author: P O.

description: The zachery's of the west bay.  Though not as tasty as zach's, the vibe is really cool.  There is a jukebox stacked with great rock tunes and the bar gives it a lively feel.  Great place to bring a first or second date.  So, though not as good as Zachs, if you want to stay in the city for deep dish, this is your place.
author: Tim X.

description: Growing up in Chicago, we shyed away from deep dish on a regular basis and treated it as a tourist food (like Clam chowder) since it was too heavy for a normal pizza night, but Little Star has changed that for me.  This is a place to have pizza as a more than casual outing, or take it to go to have at home watching a movie.   Their crust/cheese/sauce/inggredients combination are tasty, but not too heavy, which is perfect. Pauline's has some serious competition!
author: Mazi S.

description: For all the hype this place was getting, I figured I'd give it a shot, but honestly I wasn't impressed - and I know NOTHING about chicago style pizza. I've just had better at places like BJs or UNOs, but this was nothing special to me. It was just really bland.
author: Mark G.

description: Good pizza at the Divisadero location, but somehow the Valencia Street shop was sub-par.  It seemed overdone and dry.  But perhaps I've been spoiled by Patxi's which offers a much better pizza and experience.
author: Tommy O.

description: Excellent stuff, every bit as good as the one on Divisadero.  Got a table after a short wait at 8:30 on a Wednesday night.  Decorated well, nicely lit, friendly staff, all around good times.
author: Paul B.

description:
i love this place! this is the kind of pizza that makes me happy. well... most pizzas make me happy... but the deep dish pizzas at little star are especially excellent. as far as deep dish goes, these pizzas are not quite as stuffed and heavy as say Lou Malnati's in Chicago, but they're also less tomato-ey than Zachary's or Paxti's here in the bay. (note: i love all these aforementioned pizzeria's also!) there's a good blend of spicy tomato sauce, toppings, and cheese baked into a really tasty, buttery, crisp crust.   

in addition, they have one of my current favorite beers on tap - Racer5 IPA. the restaurant is loud, but has a great comfy feel to it. and the service is great and very friendly - i was chatting with my server and he was telling me how he had once finished a whole large deep dish pizza in one sitting, by himself!!

yummm... writing this review just made me crave more pizza...
author: Steven L.

description: Just want it for the record that I love this place.  I had never heard of Little Star Pizza until about two months ago.  Now I can't stop thinking about my next visit.  Before Little Star, I had deep dish pizza at Uno's in San Francisco, Zachary's, and some no-name place in Chicago.  Never could figure out the big deal.  Then I had Little Star.  Leftovers of the deep dish hold up very well the next day.  Just pop them in a toaster oven at 400 degrees for about 15 minutes.  Plan on ordering the chicken wings the next time I'm there.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description: The food is excellent, but unless you're in a party of two, you're better off ordering for takeout, as the wait for a table is always pretty insane.
