Also, for a place that costs so much, you'd think they could spring for a credit card machine, but instead, they take their chances at expecting that you won't mind the $0.25 ATM fee they're skimming off the top when you see their tiny "cash only" sign.
author: Erin P.

description: Little Star can do no wrong.  Except for the cash only part - that I could do without, because sometimes me and my people are trying to consume mass quantities of deep-dish goodness!  The one thing we were really sad about leaving in the East Bay was Zachary's - but once Little Star hit my radar, there was no turning back.  We're talking crispy, doughy, melty, juicy-chunky-tomatoey, spicey-sausagey, stringey-cheesy, little bit of garlic punch, all around delicious.  Once you have some Little Star in your mouth, you start getting this crazy idea that maybe your stomach is bottomless.  But if you exercise some self-restraint and end up with leftovers, it's even more delicious the next day.
author: Natalie S.

description: I think this place has very tastey pizza, however I do prefer Zachary's Pizza for deep dish.  The ambiance is way better at Little Star though.  It's more of a "real" restaurant.  It's like a fancy pizza place.  I like how the lighting is dim too because it makes pizza-eating somewhat romantic...hehehe :)
author: Neety P.

description: When my friend said he had a deep dish pizza I would like, I didn't believe him, and I still don't but Little Star really does make a great deep dish.  Most deep dishes are overpowering with dough, but Little Star's on the cornmeal dough really was balanced and original.  Would recommend.
author: Dan D.

description: There are certainly enough reviews here saying this place is great.  Being from the east coast and having lived in Chicago for 7 years, I can tell you this place is definitely worth going to.  Chicago has great deep dish, but you can only eat a slice of it.  The deep dish here is not overwhelming and the crust, well its to die for.  Its a mix of butter and cornmeal which makes it out of this world.  If you love carbs as much as me, you wont be disappointed.  As for the wings, they are nothing like you would expect.  I loved them, but if you are going in there hoping for traditional hot wings these aren't them.  They are just salt and pepper and some ovo I think, they were very tasty in my book.  The blue cheese added zero to them, but all in all this place was great.  Waiting an hour isn't the most fun, but they definitely do not hide the fact that you will indeed wait an hour.
author: Jaime C.

description: I am late bloomer and am only becoming a foodie in my 30's.  I used to wonder and moan what all of the fuss was about at this place.  A line this long for pizza: "Come on.," But, then I went a few more times and realized that this place is indeed good enough to wait in line for.  I am still embarrassed to be one of those people waiting in line but I realize the reason for all of it now. Even took my mom there who has eaten out around the world and back and she was raving about this place.  In fact, she wanted me to figure out how to bring her pizza in Canada!
author: susan c.

description: Can you ask for more?  I'm hooked on the corn crust deep dish pizza.  The thin crust is delicious too.  Make sure your entire party is at the restaurant or they will not seat you.  BTW, you can't complain about the $2.50 Pacifico's during Happy Hour.
author: Koa K.

description: I come from Chicago where deep-dish pizza is taken very seriously and this place serves up some excellent pies. They get very busy so be prepared to wait but I think it's well worth it. Not sure I would take a "date" here as it has a "high throughput" and busy atmosphere but it's perfect for a small group of friends. My only complaint is that they use a bit too much oil in their preparation. It ends up being tad too greasy. In Chicago, this place would probably get 3 stars but in SF it's 4-5.
author: Carter F.

description: This place has super delicious deep dish pizza and a good selection of beers. My buffalo wing aficionado friends will protest, but this place seriously has the best chicken wings ever--they are not really buffalo-y but they are warm and baked and just slightly crispy, with a light and refreshing dipping sauce. I could eat them all day.
author: Teo W.

description: Best Chicago style in sf
author: Keith L.

description: The deep dish pizza is very good.  Patxi's is better though.
author: Chris T.

description: Excellent pizza. Great crust. Somewhere between high end and by-the-slice. Please open another chain so the wait isn't so long.
author: Zoe W.

description: Pizza was AWESOME!!!!!  The cornmeal crust was just perfect.  We also orderd a thin crust pizza which was just as good.  Came in right when the place opened on a Sunday evening so it was pretty easy to get  a table.  Staff was really down to earth and friendly.  Happy hour was from 5-630 so we were able to get a buck of our beers.  This may be better than Zachary's...
author: Adrian D.

description:
Add me to the list of people that say Little Star is good, but does not manage to eclipse the perfection of Zachary's.

I have only had the deep-dish pizza here (why get thin crust at a Chicago style place?), but it was damn good.  To me, the crust was a little bland, but the texture was great.  I guess I just prefer the traditional crust (a-la Zachary's) over the cornmeal type.  I also felt that the the tomato topping/sauce was a little thick, and there was not enough of it.  If you go, I reccomend the Dry Creek Zin (I forget the name), it was delicious with the pizza.  

The garlic bread is booty.  If I order garlic bread, I expect there to be garlic on the bread.  Look, if I wanted to put butter and garlic on the bread myself, I'd get a job there. 

I'll take Little Star over most other pizza places in the city (except Amicis), even if it is a hipster magnet.  If I could rate this 4.5 stars I would, but I cant give it the same rating I gave to Zacharys.
author: Matt R.

description: At first I was really upset when my favorite Thai food resturant that was in the location at 15th and Valencia went out, thier food was beyond amazing, but when I heard that Little Star was going in, I think I shed a single tear of happiness.  Little Star makes Giordonno's look like Little Cesears (To the Chi-Town faithful that are going to hate me for saying that, go to Little Star, you'll understand).  My favorite is the Red Bell Pepper, Artichoke Heart, Zuchinni, and extra cheese... no meat necessary.  Great beer on tap, great appetizers, and a large is pleanty to feed 4...   The only downside to Little Star is that they won't let you order in advance, and they are always super crowded, but that's not such a bad thing for that corner, it needs a stable resturant to keep the area alive.
author: Darren R.

description: This was the first time I've had true deep dish and it pretty good. It was a little sauce heavy for me, but the crust was fantastic. I didn't know this place was cash only, but yes, they have an ATM with a $0.25 charge which is really unheard of. Parking is terrible, try to take BART or Muni.
author: Emily A.

description: While the little star deep dish was good everything else was not. The chicken wings were down right bad, the "garlic bread" was a lazy attempt to sell something other than pizza. stick to the pizza. Service was good, they only take cash...hmmm that also bothers me. They are too cheap to pay credit card fees but will gladly charge you to use their atm machine conveniently located in the lobby. Also this place is expensive as hell. We spent $60 on 2 small pizzas, bad wings, bad garlic bread, a coke and a beer. Thats 60 bucks for pizza. Never again....Delfina Pizzaria is 10 times better.
author: James S.

description: For years I've been a Zachary's customer. Two friends and i went at 5pm on a week day to the Divisadero location and had no problem sitting. We got a deep dish half sausage, garlic, and mushroom and half broccoli, sausage and fresh tomato. The crunchy crust amazed us and the ingredients were totally flavorful, fresh and well prepared. It was all worth the hype. Nice service too. We brought our own wine for a $10 corkage.
author: Susie W.

description:
we ordered take out pizza from little star last nite - the "little star" deep dish and a small green salad.

the salad was great, walnuts, gorgonzola, greens and ripe tomatoes.

the pizza was so-so... crust was kinda oily and dense.  the pizza had the tomato sauce ON TOP of the ricotta and spinach which caused the sauce to kinda be separate from the rest of the pizza. i wonder if the thin crust is more interesting....? i wonder if all the pizzas are sloppy and sorta bland?

i will try again, only because i live two blocks away. i gotta say, even if delfina pizza isn't the best, it's better. as is paulines.
author: Erika Y.

description: Omg, this pizza is crazy good. If you are all about the quality and flavor of the ingredients -- especially the tomatoes -- you will love it. The thin crust is stellar and the deep dish is a treat. It is the first deep dish I've liked (and I've tried the famous Chicago place, Zachary's, etc.). I heart the buffalo wings and my hubby likes the caprese appetizer. Everything else -- service, decor, whatever - is unimportant as long as it doesn't keep me from eating the yummy food here. Prepare to wait for a table! They also do carry-out.
author: Marina N.

description: I don't think it needs another review at 400+ but still... I had the white pizza last night as my last meal before a 2 week cleanse and it was deeee-licious! I can't wait to eat it again!
author: A W.

description: I only had to-go of the white pie, caprese salad, and the cheese cake. I must say that delfino offers fresher fresh mozarella. I can't rate the dine-in experience but the pizza we brought home was just ok. They do have a full-bar there. Maybe I'll try it next time.
author: Cathy Y.

description: This was my first visit to this location and I hadn't been to the other one in a while. It all came back to me as soon as I walked in, this one is very similar to the other. I like that they stuck with champagne cocktails and still have PBR in a can. Stick with what you're known for! This of course includes their delicious pizza, deep dish or thin crust... it's all good.
author: Melissa W.

description: I got really good service here :) I love when people serve you with a warm smile on. I had the chicken pesto pizza and it was yummy :) Very different from my usual pizza with tomato sauce, though. It is very loud in here but the atmosphere is very relaxed. It does get crowded in the evening. We had a slice left over and our server wrapped it in foil and made a swan out of the foil! It was really cool :) Great place.
author: M J.

description: Wow. Being roughly the 513th(?) review on here with a 4 star average, my review won't mean much. I basically echo the other positive reviews. Excellent pizza, sauce above the cheese; recommend the classic and Mediterranean. Wings a little too salty, though. Be sure to check the sign in the bathroom about graffiti...
author: Maximillian M.

description: Yep, me too! I will keep it short, the pizza, its its, so damn good. I love the reviews from the New York / Chicago locs that  hate on the West Coast (ONLY COAST) and claim their pizza turf, but I guess they dont realize California produce is some of the best in the world, Happy cows come from California, I respect a great pie and Little Star has got it going on. I concede to Chicago for the Midwest Beef, but Pizza, I think its easily duplicated and after all, this is San Francisco, culinary mecca of the world, we got it all. Just name the cuisine and I will give the name of the restaurant in San Francisco doing any bit as good as the homeland. I like to dine here once a week and if you dont like it, stop coming and free up a table.
author: Michael G.

description:
UPDATE: I tried the thin crust. It doesn't do it for me. I miss NY for thin slice pizza and go to Arinell for a fix. I go to Little Star for Chicago style pizza.
---------------------------------------------
I've been a pizza lover all my life. I even worked in a pizza joint during high school for a year. I particularly love a good sauce. This place makes the best. The toppings are mmmouth watering good. For my money, thin crust NYC pizza is the best pizza ever. At Little Star they have both thin & thick crust. Ironically, I have never been able to get away from the thick crust here, because it's so freaking orgasmically good. Which makes me really have to say it's not really pizza to me. It's more like a pizza-like casserole pie. It's all the things I love about lasagna, but it's pizza. It's the best Chicago-style and better than Zachary's (which I never imagined). It's so good, I'm going to have to try their thin slice this weekend, just to compare!
author: G Z.

description: Little Star is sooo much better than Patxi's.  I'm not a fan of Chicago style pizza, but Little Star made it more delicious for my discriminating palate.  The decor and ambiance was pleasant and slightly sheek.  The service was average.  Now I know why everyone is raving about this place.  Not sure I'll come back to this restaurant since I'm not a deep dish pizza gurl, but if the stars are aligned, possibly fate will lead me to Little Star again.  Will fate lead you to Little Star?
author: Walter C.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of pizza. I don't hate it, but I don't seek it either. That said, this is the best pizza I've had in the area. I'm usually suspicious of deep dish pizza because there is usually more dough than anything else, but this place got it right. 

This is also the nicest pizza place I've ever been to. 

I suffered abuse on the N (The N is pretty bad as it is, but I also went with a roommate who kept trying to push me off the seat) and it was worth it.
author: Aileen P.

description: I was really impressed by the service here and the food was quality too. Would definitely come back.
author: Shooter M.

description: Informed that Little Star was better than Zach's and Paxti's -- it's pretty darn good.  I love thin crust pizza and they make it just right, pastry-stylie but with a little more umph!  Their location on Valencia and 15th looks urban undercover on the exterior and feels more like a 'grown up pizza joint' vibe.  Happy hour beer and cocktails.
author: D L.

description: Leave the Gun...take the deep dish classic pizza!  The salad was awesome also.
author: Prescott T.

description: This is by far one of the best pizzas I have ever had in my life.  The "Mediterranean" deep dish pizza is NOT soggy, and even after I took the left overs home, the crust remained crisp and delicious.  This must be the ambrosia the Greek gods were raving about.
author: Kenneth L.

description: Love the restaurant.  Love the pizza.  Love the wait staff.  Everything about this place is awesome except for the wait time (but it's worth it!!)  I'm not a huge thick crust fan but I make an exception for Little Star.  Their thick crust is like heaven!  I'm getting hungry just thinking of it...
author: Jen C.

description: So delicious.  Such a great, intimate setting.  I would totally to go here for a romantic date.
author: Alex C.

description: All I can say is "Wow" about this place. Really great pizza whether you decide to go thin or thick. I got a kick out of their deconstructed version of garlic bread which was artisan bread served with roasted garlic. Their garlic wings are a must try. Tossed with garlic, black pepper, and salt. They are incredibly simple, yet really good.
author: Clodel G.

description: Far and away the best pizza in the world. I practically never eat in since I don't like to wait for anything but the takeout is just as del-icio-us. I will never eat another pizza ever ever ever ever ever.... unless Extreme brings back their Swiss Chick of course (that's a pizza not a girl).
author: Nathaniel R.

description: Delicious Chicago style pizza!  Pretty damn close to the real thing, too.  Not as good but still quite tasty.  The crust is what really makes it.  We got the spinach Little Star special pizza despite my complaining that I don't like fancy pants pizza.  Next time I will get the regular sausage pizza and I think it may be even better.  Maybe I'll up it a star if it is.  Save room for the near-perfect cheesecake, too!
author: Erick Z.

description: Pretty good stuff.  Like traditional Chicago deep dish with a twist.  The places to get deep dish in the Bay Area are few and far between.  I like the cornmeal crust, the chunky fresh tomatoes and the salads are great.  The atmosphere is cool too- I like that it's updated and laid back. Solid place.
author: M B.

description:
Our deep dish pizza was blend, and completely overfilled with tomato sauce and barely anything else. We order pretty much every ingredient on the menu and still, it was blend. The crust wasn't fantastic either, average at best. The service was borderline rude and the fact they we are 7 seven years down to the new Millennium and Little Star pizza still doesn't accept credit cards or ATM, that's the one drop too many.

I may be spoiled Old Chicago's Pizza in Petaluma and Palo Alto but Little Star didn't make the cut.
author: S. M.

description: I am not much of a pizza girl, ...but when I am in the mood Little Star is where it's at. Half Classic Half Little Star Deep Dish makes me happy.
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Mm mm mmmm! Pizza like my momma used to make, had she been Italian and not the white Scotch-Irish gal she is! I've been hearing the hype about Little Star for a while now and finally tonight I had a hankerin' for some take out pizza...while we watched last night's episode of LOST on line...we had a hammered drunk over last night that wouldn't let us watch it...but that my friends is a story for another day!
Back to the pizza. We ordered the Italian Combo, thin crust with pepperoni AND salami...I ask you, how can a pizza with two meats not be good!? So we were off to a good start I can tell you that! I love the thin crust and that they didn't overdo the base layer of sauce! I hate over sauced pizza's!  The way they layered the meat was perfection...it wasn't just a few tired pieces of meat thrown on there...this thing was covered edge to edge with meaty yumminess. And to complement the meat was a nice thin spread of bell peppers, olives and pepperoncini! I'm not sure that I've ever had pepperoncini's on a pizza before but I can tell you that I'll be having that again! 
Of course we had a salad, but I've said it before...it's tough to review a salad...it's green...really good tomatoes that were not mushy and Gorgonzola. Like the meat twins...tough to go wrong with the Gorgonzola! 
It was darn good pizza in a neighborhood that has Pauline's, one of the best darn pizza joints just a block away...bold location for the Little Star...but they are bold competition! So good...
author: Simms B.

description:
OH MY SWEET JESUS!! Why the hell did it take me so long to actually step in to this place and dine?? I mean I walk buy it all the time on the way to take the Prince to Dolores Park or am going to the only liquor store that sells hard alcohol 24/7...sorry cant tell you the location under the grounds that they may get fined or god forbid closed down...THIS PLACE IS HEAVEN. The thick,deep dish,Chicago style pizza with tons of toppings,sauce and sun dried tomatoes was just ummm SCRUMPTIOUS!! Me and my person ordered a customized pie with all the toppings I wanted on one half and all the toppings he wanted on the other...schmrrr schmrrrr that's why I'm once again single (COMPROMISE IS THE ANSWER PEOPLE)...Anyway...the pie was amazing...fresh and so filling I only ate 2 slices and those who know me know that me and pizza go hand in hand. You can BYOB and the corkage fee is ONLY 10 BUCKS...cant beat it with a stick when your drinking a 70 dollar bottle of wine and the ambiance is nice and ummm...dark. Okay maybe there is one negative but overall great service...yummy pizza oh AND...The mint chip ice cream I had for dessert was DELICIOUS!!

PS.They only take cash and are only open during the dinner hours...5pm until...and and and its kinda dark from the outside..window shades to prevent walker byes from staring in your mouth...literally. So be on the look out or you just might miss it.
author: Kokoa L.

description: I don't know what the hype is about this place. Seriously.
author: maggie m.

description: One word - YUM!!!!  The deep dish pizza is fantastic here.  The staff was very friendly and helpful in our decision-making.  We had the wings (app) and the 'Little Star' pizza with sausage added.  It was so good!  I can't wait to go back and try more!
author: Rise G.

description: This place is like Zachary's without all the hype!  Delicious, parking is a b***h though.
author: Jonathan T.

description: the first couple times the pies were amazing, but something was lacking this time around.  the wait was 1.5 hours on a saturday night, so we ordered take away and ate it back at a friends house.  it took less than 10 minutes to get the pies back to the house, so it's not as if it was cold, but the flavors just weren't as tasty as i had remembered.  it was not bad by far, but they were not food orgasm worthy as the previous times.  on the other hand the dry spiced wings were out of this world.  i loved the kick off of them, and they were fine without the blue cheese.
author: Sheri N.

description: Most unique deep dish crust I've ever had. The pizza and salad are delish, the service is great, and Kristin (at the bar) rocks!
author: Ed K.

description:
Simply the best pizza west of the Mississippi...

After living for 6 years in Chicago and 9 years in New York, I wasn't sure I would find good authentic Pizza like I learned to love in two of the best Pizza cities in the U.S.  .....  That is until I found Little Star....

My wife and I crave their pizza...great sauce, quality toppings and we love their thin crust pizza.  Compared this to others such as Pizzeria Delfina, Paulines  I have to say that Little Star is the best of the best.
author: David S.

description: This place is awesome!  I highly recommend the pizza at Little Star.  The cornmeal crust is ultra delicious. the toppings are fresh and they all blend together well.  I've never set foot inside since we always get our food to go.
author: Landy G.

description: Little Star's Chicago-style deep dish is reminiscent of Chicago's favorite Lou Malnati's, with its crispy crumbly crust, but I prefer doughy crust. And pizza will always just be pizza.
author: Andy K.

description:
oh joy, oh rapture. having moved away from the "NOPA" neighborhood I went into a sort of mourning over all the restaurants that were now a trek, not a quick "let's see what the line's like tonight" jaunt. imagine my JOY to see the discreet Little Star sign on a corner of Valencia. then imagine my astonishment to find that I could get seated immediately and start chowing as soon as I liked. the cornmeal crust is simply the best pizza crust I've ever had. the menu is quite simple: pizza. and appetizers. go for the deep dish pizza. if you don't like deep dish, don't go -- it's as simple as that (try Pauline's up the street). you can design your own or try their signature pizzas. I'm stuck on the Classic -- sausage, pepper, onion, mushroom -- and really need to branch out but it is soooo yummy.

and if you go, like, RIGHT NOW, you won't have to wait in line because everyone who doesn't read yelp doesn't quite get that they are open yet. so go NOW. now that I think on it, I'm going to follow my own advice and go NOW. ciao ...
author: Phoebe H.

description: My favorite pizza ever in the world (if you love deep dish like I do) or, just if you love pizza the way I do.  I probably don't love it as much as some, but this is some tasty pizza.  In my opinion, even better than Zachary's in Berkeley.  Thank you pizza gods for giving me something even better than that AND only 2 blocks away from my front door.  I love you.
author: Tiffany P.

description: I would give Little Star 5 stars, but have to remove one star because it's so damn dark in there.  However, I love the deep dish pizza, the wines are good but a limited list. Salad's good, and the garlic bread is great. I've recreated this at home- bake a loaf of bread, roast a head of garlic, and serve with butter on the side, then spread the roasted garlic on the bread. mmm....Anyway, minor tangent, but I like Little Star. It can get crowded, but there's a great juke-box to browse through while you're waiting. Cash only- closed Mondays (as we recently and disappointingly found out.)
author: Dana K.

description: Since it's so difficult to feed my urge for Zachary's, I'm glad that there's pizza of comparable quality in my neck of the woods.  Like the vibe inside, service is ok, proximity to The Indy is killer.
author: Dan H.

description: Best Friday night date ever: Little Star take-out, good red wine and a movie on the couch. Sometimes when we don't feel like compromising we get 2 small pizzas knowing that we'll have leftovers for breakfast. I'm a vegetarian, he's not and he LOVES the sausage special. When we get 1 small pizza, there's none left over and he has to have one without meat. Hardly a compromise, because no matter what you get there you'll be happy. Full disclosure: I've never had the thin crust. Why bother?
author: Ann F.

description: Wow, this deep dish pizza is GREAT. Not too cheesy (I don't like too cheesy), great sauce, fantastic crust, not at all greasy. This place rocks!!
author: Mama C.

description: Very, very good deep-dish pizza. And I used to live in Chicago. The crust has a little bit of.."je ne se qua"...cornmeal and good cheese,  maybe?  It is a good effect.  Good sauce, good cheese, decent sausage.  The service is fast and friendly, even on a very busy friday night.  What can I say, this fulfills my need for cheese (and carbs!)
author: Gabriela C.

description: The pizza here is so good. Be prepared to wait for a table, especially on a weekend, but that's typical in the Mission anyway. The location is great and close to the BART and other Mission spots so it's easy to get to. They have a really nice, laid back, not overly hip staff here which is a rare in the Mission. The atmosphere is also nice and it's not too loud for being such a busy restaurant. Cash only which can be troublesome but in this world, if going into a restaurant where cash only is your biggest issue (Emmons) than you're doing just fine and don't have any reason to complain. The food will be worth the wait if you ask for the special, trust me.
author: Benji T.

description: Definitely good pizza here, esp the deep dish, which I'll have to side with vs Zachary's, due to a tastier crust. It's definitely more of a hip space than you might expect for a pizza place, and noise level when crowded is high, but conversation can still be had.
author: Bruce C.

description:
little stars thin crust pizzas rule!

perfect crust, great tasting sauce and their home-made sausage rocks.
author: jon w.

description: Easily the best deep dish pizza I've had in San Francisco.  We started with some garlic bread and chicken wings and some beer on a frosted glass.    Both the garlic bread and chicken wings were very good, two items I suggest on getting for appetizers.  Then on with the main course, their signature deep dish pizza.  Crusted was perfect, good amount of sauce, and good combo of toppings.  Deep dish pizza cant get any better than this.  Parking maybe a hasle around the area but keep looking until you find one because its worth the time for Little Star.
author: Kris A.

description: I know this place gets compared to Zacharys.  All I have to say is the pizza here was memorable....the pizza at Zacharys?....not so much.  There is something about their crust, that makes you want to forget you ever heard the words "South Beach" or "No carb diet."  I'll definitely recommend this place to my East Coast peeps that say they can't find good pizza here in SF.
author: Cindy L.

description:
it's more a 3.5 than a 4 but i didn't want to round down - that's just mean.  

i'm not even a real pizza lover and i really liked the pizza here - nice thin crust pizza.  and they have decent wines at a reasonable price and salads if you want to add veegies to your meal.  i would give it a 4 on the food along but i had to knock half a star off because it was way too noisy.  i was there on a saturday night at peak time but i couldn't hear the person across from or next to me which made it a little awkward.  maybe if you go on another night or maybe once it's dies down a little in popularity, it will be better.
author: michelle k.

description: Yummy pizza. It was hard for me to find a good deep dish pizza when I first moved to San Francisco from Minneapolis. It seemed like all the pizza places I found were silly California style pizza. This place has silly pizzas too, but they have a serious pizza that rocks.
author: doug d.

description:
I have a vice - it's pizza. Whenever I eat pizza, I can not stop eating it. Even when I'm full, I will grab that last piece.

I especially like deep dish pizza. Little Star makes a very good deep dish pizza. Dare I say it may be better than that place over in Berkeley? It just might be. If I did not have this vice, I would eat it more often. But alas, I must leave it for those special occasions. twinkle twinkle
author: Luke F.

description: One of the best pizza places in the city, and much cheaper than most if you are with a group. Their Little Star, White Pie, and Medditerranean Chicken pizzas are incredible. Their roasted garlic bread is phenomenal, their drinks are cheap, and their cheescake is rich (share!!!) but very very good. The only thing thing that holds this place back is that it is often packed, and they don't seat you until your group is there, so timing is everything. Also, I did get very bad service once, but it seems that was a fluke. Probably my favorite under $18 joint in the city!
author: Micah R.

description: Best Chicago style pizza in the bay, hands down.
author: Jed L.

description: It is as outstanding as everyone says.  I'm so glad I live close-by.  Nothing more needs to be said.  It's that good.
author: Christy T.

description: I love their deep dish chicago-style pizza.  The crust is so crunchy.  And there're so many toppings to choose from.  I had one with chicken and it was so out of this world.  Chicken wings here are good as well.  And i like the decors of this place... with a little candle on each table.  Who would've thought a pizza restaurant can look so romantic?
author: Jessica N.

description: We came here on a Friday night at around 730 and this place was packed.  We waited around an hour for a table but after eating their pizza I can honestly say that it is so worth the wait.  We ordered 2 large deep dish (classic and mediterranean) and a large thin crust (pesto chicken) and it was enough for the 7 of us. The ingredients tasted fresh and the sauce was not too tart. Now, I don't normally eat the crust but this time I did and wow, was it good...nice crunchy cornmeal crust...delicious! Despite how busy it was, our server and the other staff members were very attentive and checked on us frequently.  Great pizza and great service!
author: Justin Y.

description: Great pizza, friendly-enough service, nice vibe.  The pizza isn't as good as Zachary's, but this place is still excellent enough to get 5 stars.
author: Michael M.

description: I dont think i have had pizza as good as this in a very very very long time...if not ever. I dream of coming back here, and if my cravings ever get too much to handle, i think i would make the drive from Sacramento to SF just to taste this mouthwatering pizza. their thin crust is also really good, but if you come here for the first time you have to go with their classic deep dish with their cornmeal crust hmmmm. i have to stop otherwise i might make myself come down there right now.
author: Bala H.

description: Yum Yum Yum.... I had given up on finding delicious pizza in SF. Then discovered this place, it is awesome! Seats are limited but you can always order to go.
author: Alicia L.

description:
i stumble into a lot of places. i didnt even know this place was open. open those curtains so people can actually see you're in business. but aside from that..the thin crust is the best i've had in years. i loved the salad too! and a nice glass of wine. i love the fact that this mission joint looks classy inside. white napkins...niiiiiice. i'll be back...often.
oh...and GREAT service!
author: City G.

description: Deep dish pizza done correct! The best shy town pie west of shy town!
author: James K.

description:
i know they're supposed to be known for their deep dish, but personally i like their regular ol' pies - particularly the white pie, it's something like cheese with zucchini, tomatoes and feta (no tomato sauce), in short, heaven on a pizza pan thing.

it's so good that my cheese hating ex-boyfriend couldn't get enough.

and the wings are good too.
author: Brittany E.

description:
hah, the outside of this place is so deceiving.  don't let the dark exterior  trick you into thinking you're about to enter some sleazy bar.  
good food, good people....good casual atmosphere.

good deep dish, and this is coming from a thin crust gal......come to think of it, i enjoyed the deep dish more than the thin crust.
author: Jackie C.

description: I love the pizza.  It's not as good as the other Little Star, but it's still better than any other pizza I've had in the city.
author: Heidi P.

description:
really good deep dish pizza. 

we walked in, were told there would be a 30 minute wait. there were 2 empty tables but when i pressed the hostess about them, she seated us right away, minus one star for having to ask.

the server was very nice and attentive. the garlic bread was great, piping hot sour dough with a vat of butter and a head of roasted garlic, YUMMY. The pizza was super, I am usually not a deep dish girl but this was nice for a change. We had sausage and mushroom and were quite pleased with the pie. The crust was cooked just right, the cornmeal made it interesting, the tomato sauce was very flavorful as was the sausage. I think the sauce on this pizza is much more interesting than zachary's. 

When I want deep dish, it is little star for me, it was in fact super.
author: Ashley T.

description:
Best deep dish pizza I've eaten. It's the kind with the tomato sauce on top of the cheese and toppings. I don't like the staining sloppiness of that style of pizza, unless it's damn good. And Little Star is damn good.

It can be very crowded and noisy with super-long waits, particularly on weekend nights. But they do a roaring take-away business. Be sure to call ahead, of course, because it takes at least 40 minutes for them to make a deep dish pizza.
author: Jared B.

description: Awesome.  Aside from craving some thin oven baked italian style pizzas from Delfina, Little Star Pizza is definitely one of the better places to get some Chicago STyle deep dish pizzas.  A group of us tried both their deep dish and thin crust pizzas, both were just outstanding.  Aside from the pizzas, very affordable alcohol prices on beers, trust me.  Finally, service here is awesome.  Cannot have asked for service at a pizza rest.  Even better, Valencia one now takes reservations
author: Charles C.

description:
Finally, got there....

Great pizza, yes takes a while but it's a dining destination...Very good service, wine by the glass should be upgraded.

We ordered both thin and deep..very good...

Will go back....
author: Liz D.

description: This is some unbelievably good pizza... a hard thing to find in this city.
author: Cliff M.

description: Little star pizza is one of my favorite places in the city.  The cornmeal crust is amazing.  Really cute date spot as long as you don't mind waiting a bit for a table.
author: Katie S.

description: ok...i am scaling back my raving review of little star. they def. nail the hipster vibe, jukebox, great beer and wine selection, excellent wait staff, and dueling divis vs. valencia locations. that scores them a solid 80% right there. the little star salad is still great. but i have to say the thin crust has been letting me down. i know they cook this stuff in a conveyor oven in their secret kitchen. it's still tasty just makes me feel a bit funny after eating it. maybe it's really all about the deep dish. just not a big fan of the genre. apparently they sold their recipes to a place in chicago which Obama claims as his favorite.
author: casey c.

description: excellent little pizza place with awesome wings and thin crust the way i like it! Its hard to tell there is even a restaurant inside the tinted glass windows, but once inside the causal and cozy space is warm and inviting. The bar is small but perfect for dining in without having to wait for a table. I enjoyed the  garlic bread with beer while a friend and I chatted with the friendly bartender. I would recommend the place to anyone who wants to go grab some grub without having to make an event out of it.
author: allen s.

description: Not usually a fan of the thick crust, but this place rocks!
author: Kenny H.

description:
As a Berkeley native and Zachary's worshipper for years, I use them as the standard for Chicago Style Pizza.  Now that I live in the City I'm happy to report that I don't have to cross the bridge for the best stuffed pizza in the Bay Area.  We started as huge fans of the Divis location and then as if through divine intervention a Little Star opens a couple of blocks from our place. THANK YOU {hands clasped} THANK YOU {on my knees} THANK YOU {bowing down before the pizza gods}
I still like Zachary's a ton as both places have great crust (different but both great), fresh ingredients and great cheese, but the thing that separates them is the sauce.  The sauce at Little Star is a few notches above any pizza sauce I have ever had and it's what brings me back over and over again.  Bravo Little Star people for making an amazing stuffed pie.
author: Jaime A.

description: This spot get four stars, but it was a close one... Sonya and I waited for an hour and in the end the hostess just asked us if we wanted to sit at the bar and order from them because it was going to be ANOTHER 20 min. wait.  I guess I don't eat at popular/yuppie spots these days because I really am not used to that kind of wait.   We got there about 7:30, I'd say?  A ton of pizza at 9pm is not really my cup of tea, but that said, the pizza was DIVINE.  Mmmm.  Fair prices, too.  We got the veggie deep dish and I was quite pleased, all the while trying to forget how long I'd been sitting there waiting.  I recommend it, but go early!
author: Katie M.

description:
We'd heard about Little Star after we told friends about Paxti's pizza and they said to check this place out. 

So we did a comparison of deep dish pizzas. 

I think it's a tie. Little Star is definitely good, the crust and sauce are amazing, but Paxti gives you more pizza for your dollar I feel. 

Not to take anything away from Little Star, you can't go wrong here. It's not cheap, but it is good. Maybe ask for extra sauce to ensure your visit is perfect. 

The neighborhood in the evening is a little gritty, but it's fine. Not as upscale as Paxti's neighborhood. The building doesn't look like a pizza joint, more like a design studio or an architect's office. 

Either way, SF has two great pizza choices for deep dish, just remember to order extra sauce.
author: John W.

description: My cousin took me to Little Star Pizza when I was visiting and it was great!  The chicken wings are awesome.  They have a great spicy rub on them that is addictive.  We had the deep dish 'little star', Mediterranean chicken, and a sausage and onion pizza.  I really enjoyed the little star pizza with the Mediterranean coming in a close second.  I didn't try the sausage and onion because I had filled up on the other two and the wings.   The atmosphere was very fun and friendly and the waitress was very attentive.  I will definitely go back to this place the next time I am in San Fransisco.
author: Mike C.

description:
Their deep dish pizza is delicious!  It has a crispy crust that I'd eat plain.   Be prepared to wait about 45 minutes during busy times.

I'd give them 5 stars, but their thin crust is just OK.  Pizzeria Delfina is much better for that style.
author: Matthew A.

description:
After seeing Little Star in Zagat's and hearing my hubby overly excited to try this place, I was expecting some good pizza.  We waited 30 minutes or so for a table - Tuesday night around 7ish.  Ordered the Caprese salad - good, but not anything great - and did a deep dish half Greek and half classic.  The crust was delicious - not oily or overly flaky.  My dissatisfaction came from the ratio of sauce to pizza.  The sauce was so thick you could not tell which half of the pizza was which and it really overwhelmed the toppings.  My husband even asked if there was feta on the Greek as he could not taste it through the sauce.  I know he does not have a great palate, but really, if you can't taste a strong cheese like feta because of the sauce, you might have a little too much sauce.  Overall the pizza was ok.  Nothing that great I thought.  I might come back, but I would never crave it.

Wait staff and service was good.
Very small restaurant with only one unisex toilet.  Not always a problem, but I noticed there was always a wait of at least one person.
author: Allison S.

description: Great pizza, love the do-it-yourself style garlic bread. Service was friendly and quick. I like the crust better at Zachary's but I was really delighted by the sausage here, I usually do not like sausage on pizza! Space is more cramped than it looked from the outside and I would imagine as word gets around that the wait will get extreme. I think the bar area is too small to comfortably hang out and have a drink while waiting, which is too bad!
author: Liboo K.

description: What can I say, I love pizza and this place is the best! i am so happy that they have open one in the mission, I used to trek over to Divisidero, but now it is oh so easy to get home when i am stuffed. Stuffed is the right word, their deep dish pizza is FILLING and amazing. like nothing i have ever has before. they also have a wonderful wine selection, good service and a nice selection of salads etc. But the deep dish pizza is really what I go for. i have never found anything like it in the city. A thick cornmeal crust covered in toppings (my choice is the veggie)  and then cheese and a chunky sweet tomato sauce. Kinda hard to describe, just go try it. you'll like it.
author: P-nut K.

description: The Deep Dish deeply satisfies, and the wait staff is so good = friendly + attentive.  I like going on off-nights, though I'm not sure those are frequent as yet.
author: Shimmalicious S.

description:
Great little joint.
 
The thin crust was yummy and while I am not a deep dish person, my friends seem to enjoy theirs and I finished up the toppings.

The salad was also great and I could really be content with a salad next time.
 
Beer selection was good.

One thing that I found pretty crappy was that they would not seat you until the entire party was present.  There were 5 of us there already, but until our 6th came they made us wait, even though there were PLENTY of tables free.  And the hostesses were not the most friendly, but the waiter was great.
author: Lara F.

description:
Get the Chicken Wings, Deep Dish Classico, & Cheesecake! Don't worry about over ordering--the left over pizza is even better the next day. 

This place is worth the long wait--but be careful about bring parties with more than 4 people.  I've seen large parties come in late and get turned away.

The food here is simple, fresh, & delicious!
author: Carolyn D.

description:
Have been there several times and have always enjoyed the food and have received great service.

The wine list is good.  They wait is usually an issue, but we know about it ahead of time, so we always go with a backup plan.

Their variety of pizzas is very good.  If there has to be a complaint, they sometimes have too much cheese, resulting in an overly-gooey pizza.  But I am sure some people prefer that.
author: Deoskar M.

description:
We stumbled upon this place after a couple of cocktails at a local mission bar. It was about 9:30 and it was very easy to get a table for four people. This place is great. We had two apps including the chicken wings , which were delicious but I agree with Mitzi C. that they could be a little spicier. We also had the garlic bread (yummy) and the veggie deep dish pizza. All this and a lovely bottle of Chianti for $64.00.

Service was ok...couldn't tell if our waitress was snotty or just bored!
author: Jen L.

description: Great, great deep dish pizzas, cool atmosphere, food is a little pricey but worth it. It's packed on weekend nights though, don't even think about just showing up and hoping to find a table.
author: Jim K.

description:
Oh, Little Star. Love of my life. 

If you're into pizza, especially deep dish, then look no further. Yes, it's better than Zachary's. More than a pizza, and more like a pie, what really sets Little Star apart is the cornmeal crust.  It just melts in your mouth. It's my personal goal to introduce the glory of Little Star to as many people as I can; whenever friends visit from out of town, this is the first place I take them to eat, and it never ceases to amaze. The Little Star pie is my fave: packed with ricotta, onions, mozzarella, garlic, spinach and mushrooms, topped with the most delicious tomato sauce ever.  Really. The best. Ever.

Though I've been to both locations, the Valencia spot is more cozy and closer to where I live, so I mostly go there. It also recently started accepting reservations and taking cards (Divis location does not, as far as I know). Parking is always awful, so I recommend walking/public-transiting it if you can.

Definitely make a reservation for weekend nights, or any night really if you don't want to wait (and you will) and before 5 pm (they don't accept reservations same-night after that). Otherwise you'll have a wait of 20 minutes to an hour. They have a good beer selection, so that helps the time pass, but the waiting area is super tiny, so you may have to wait outside.

Yum. Little Star = love.
author: Frances Q.

description:
This is the best pizza I've had. It's a lovely deep dish with cornmeal in the crust. Chicago style, though I've never been to chicago.

It's similar to zachery's only better.

I'm so sad I live in the south bay where there is no good pizza places.
author: Violetta X.

description: Little Star is my first experience of deep dish pizza as i walk in to little star it was busy plus waited about 25 mins for a table. Worth the wait.  GOOD deep dish. wonderful customer service.
author: R A.

description: Best Chicago style pizza in San Francisco - and this is coming from a Chicago native who is very familiar with Gino's East, Lou Malnati's, Giordano's, and Uno's.  Their thick, buttery crust is awesome, and their sauce has a nice sweet taste, with diced tomatoes.  Highly recommend it, and it deserves 5 stars because it's in San Francisco (as opposed to Chicago).
author: Alan C.

description: Deep Dish Classic - yummy good deliciousness.  Ready for pickup when promised.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Glenn R.

description: four big stars for little star! (i'm sure i'm not the first to say that) after all the hype i was prepared to be dissapointed but little star wasn't having it. they made sure my pizza was ultra delcious. not too much crust and it's not greasy. the caprese salad is good too. the mozerella tastes extra fresh. and the leftovers are equally as good the next day.
author: Regina C.

description: Love it.  Thick, chicago style pizza with a light corn meal crust.  It's amazing.
author: S S.

description: the only good pizza place in sf. i'd still rather have zachary's.
author: krys s.

description:
Can't fault the pizza or the service. Both were good. I can't really compare them to anyone else, as their crust is unique and tasty.

The only downer was having to eat at the bar after we decided to eat our take-out order there. Not sure why they refused us a table (the place was empty). But it cost them a star.
author: The M.

description: Enjoyed the pizza, beer and wine.  The staff was accomodating to our large-ish party, although definitely were in a hurry for us to leave after our meal...Saturday night rush.   The bar staff was a little less friendly, and sort of pretended we were not there at first.  But whatever.  The pizza was really good, although I liked the thin crust better.  I would go back.
author: Brandi H.

description: They have the best deep dish pizza ever - it goes very well with their wheat beer (they brew the beer themselves).  It's a classy place with a very romantic setting.
author: Anna P.

description: Best Pizza in town!!! Their deep dish pies are simply magnificent. i lived around the corner from these guys for years a loved this place!!! Now, if only they would open on Mondays.
author: John C.

description: The cornmeal crust is amazing.  My favorite was the thin crust pesto and chicken pizza.  I thought the chicken was a little dry but it was still delicious.  I also thought the classic deep dish was good and wasn't runny (like some other deep dish pizzas I've had). The pizza was also good as leftovers.
author: Emilee S.

description: if you've never had deep dish pizza in chgo, than this should be fine for you.  for those of us who've tried chgo deep dish, well... this is not the same.  i guess it's a california-ized version of deep dish.  why else would you need cornmeal on the crust?  and the cheese is not gooey stringy.  and it's packed on sat night.  i like patxi's better.
author: Zoe L.

description: This review is specific to the Valencia location --the Divis one is golden, in my eyes. So yes, the pizza here is good. But the service is crappy. As in it is staffed by a bunch of dumber-than-dirt fashion victim hipsters who are unskilled at managing customer flow in their restaurant. So, instead of being aware of the problems caused by their management or in the least bit apologetic for their mistakes, they give you defensive attitude. Also, I was totally not in love with the bartender who was so concerned about getting her tips that she hounded people eating and drinking at the bar while waiting for their table to settle with her instead of in their seat. Believe me, I understand that bartenders get the short end when it comes to this, and I always make sure I pay and tip at the bar before being seated, but I don't appreciate being pointedly asked to do as much. I watched her do it with everyone who sat down at the bar --even going so far as to strongly suggest that people order their pizzas and eat at the bar instead of getting a table-- and I thought it was in really poor taste. I doubt I'll go back because fuck dumb mission hipsters holding you responsible for their stupidity. I suggest eating there only if you can't get to the better-run and less hipster infested Divisidero location.
author: L W.

description:
a friend decided eight of us, all many sheets to the wind, should head to little star. we expected a cheap place with vinyl booths, and when we walked in and sensed - gasp - ambiance - we all worried.
they sat our eight wasted selves promptly, though, and the host flirted very nicely with the argentinian lads we had in tow. we had the garlic bread - which is sort of a deconstructed garlic bread - bread, butter, and a head of roasted garlic - and more work but very yummy. and the caprese salad, which was perfect. the buffalo wings weren't all that, but i shouldn't have ordered buffalo wings here, anyway.
for pizza we got two deep dish - italian and the little star (spinach, cheese, mmmmm) and a small thin crust, which i missed before it was devoured at the other side of the table. next time i would order a deep dish with sausage and peppers or artichokes, but for vegetarians the little star is divine, too. nice wine selection.
when we left at 7:30 or so the place was full - with people packed in for tables and take-out. the bill was higher than i had guessed, but it turned out our group had better taste in wine than i do, so it was still reasonable for pizza. like any valencia street establishment, the hipster vibe can be tiring, but the people who compain about hipsters tend to be the hippest of them all. i am not so hip, generally, so i won't complain.
author: Casey W.

description: pretty much the best deep dish pizza i've had since i last visited chicago.  the pizza dough is brushed with that wonderful crumbly cornmeal and it's the perfect consistency.  i totally recommend the vegetarian deep dish -- the toppings included zucchini, onions, mushrooms, and tomatoes.  at $20 for a large, it's a steal.
author: Sid D.

description: Um.. heck yeah dude, you can treat me to a pie here anyday of the week, except M-Sa since I only come out to the city on Sundays.  Minus one star for some of the worst gastro-intestinal pains i've felt in a long time... and of course the aftermath of it all (lemme tell you, that toilet bowl has seen better days.)  Me thinks 'twas the salad!  Despite that minor detail, i still honestly love this place... i love you Little Star Sexy Mama!
author: Dizzle T.

description:
this place is dimly lit, with a quiet table seating area and a cozy bar.  a small pizza is $15.  they do not serve pizza by the slice.  two people could easily spend $50+ here.  and when i handed them my card, they said "cash only".

wait, what?  am i at arinell?  did i stumble into a burrito joint?  i'm sorry, that's just dumb.  i don't want to walk around this area with a lot of cash.  and i want to use it when i need to grab a cab or something, not for a $20 take-out from an upscale restaurant (relatively speaking).  when a business like this one adopts a cash-only policy, they're basically saying "we don't care about you".

the pizza was fine.  but not good enough for them to think they can take that attitude.
author: ryan b.

description: 4-Stars cause it's hard to find good deep-dish outside of Chicago. And I'm happy to see a place like this in the city. If you want GREAT deep-dish and are willing to make the drive - go to Zachary's in Berkeley. If you're looking for good deep-dish in the city? Go to Little Star! The crust? Not bad. Pretty darn good! We had a large spinach and mushroom "Little Star" signature pizza. As far as deep-dish goes - I've had better, but not in San Francisco. It's likely among the best in the city. The menu isn't huge - which could be good - could be bad. I was a bit disappointed they didn't have a Caesar Salad. I ALWAYS have a Caesar with my deep-dish! We got the Caprese Salad instead. Seeing as how I don't like chunky tomato's - I can't speak for the entire dish. But the Mozzarella and Basil? Awesome. The prices were fair, and the "cash only" policy could definitely be an inconvenience (and is surprising for a place like this - the atmosphere was a step above casual, but could easily go either way). Luckily, I'd "Yelped" it before going and ran by the bank. They had a nice beer selection too. All in all? Yeah - I'll go back...
author: Eli S.

description: So you put yourself on the wait list and wait for 30-40 minutes.  Then, the host passes you up because it looks like his friends have arrived and they now have 3 instead of 2.  Your entire party stand there in front of him, making note that you are all there, have been waiting, and obviously next on the list.  Hey, the list in right in front of us.  But the host only mocks you, takes the list away, and pretend you don't even exist while his co-hostess stand there in a bit of shock, not knowing what's happening or what to do.  I only wish that I had grabbed that list and ripped it up since he already said, "Let's just ignore this list," and laughs.  Hmmm...I have never experienced such audacity at a restaurant before.  But hey, maybe all these great reviews have gotten to their heads and made them forget about principles.
author: Diane N.

description: When I first moved to SF from Chicago (the land of glorious GLORIOUS deep dish pizza) I went on a quest to find a deep dish pizza in SF along with a good Jewish deli (that's another post!). And I was disappointed enough to weep copious tears. There were bits and parts of the pizza's that worked individually, but did not come together as whole.While the sauce was passable on one pizza, the layering was better in another, or the crust was close to how it should be on a third. Little star was closest to being passable. And then I had a eureka moment about deep dish pizza  in SF. It wasn't the pizza, it was me. While I don't compare it back to Uno's/Gino's east/Lou Malnati's and think of the pizza here as a version of Chicago's deep dish healthier/lighter(if that's even possible in the world of pizza) cousin, I actually really liked it - the lighter cheese, the cornmeal crust and the freshness of the whole pizza. So order yourself a nice malbec and enjoy your pizza just for good pizza with no preconceived expectations and you won't be disappointed.
author: Sushma Y.

description: i lived in chicago, i know chicago-style deep dish pizza... and little star is better than all the known names in chicago.  crust, cheese, sauce, and all.  bam.
author: Victory V.

description:
If you're a Zachary's fan like myself - and if you went to LIttle Star because there's not a Zachary's in San Francisco and you bought into the idea that this pizza might in any way shape or form be even slightly similar to the deliciousness that is Zachary's...well sorry. No. Not even close. I'm stunned by the number of reviews on this site that even compare the two. The only resemblance was the way the pizza looks. It looks like Zacharys, but that's as far as it goes. So as for the debate about which place is better - it's not worthy of a debate. If you want Zachary's caliber pizza and you live in San Francisco like myself, you'll just have to trek over the bridge and head into Zachary's. Little Star Pizza is no comparison. 
Now - aside from the fact that it doesn't compare to Zachary's, it's just not that great. I hate when I consume HUGE amounts of calories without the reward of tasting and eating some Bomb A** food! Yuck. Who wants to feel like a cow after sub-par pizza? Not me. I should've made the trek to Zachary's and consumed the calories for a reason. 
We ordered the Little Star Pizza (their specialty). Way too busy and the crust was gross. The crust was nearly dripping with butter but not in the good Unos Pizza crust kind of way but just in a doing way too much kind of way. The Garlic bread was essentially a loaf of bread and a roasted clove of garlic on the side...for $5 or $6. The one thing that was really good was the salad...although we ordered takeout and the restaurant forgot to add my dressing to my bag...so i ended up eating it with some salad dressing I had at home..annoying - especially after sub-par pizza. 
All I can say folks is that if you want good regular pizza in the city, try Goat Hill (and make sure you try their ranch dressing! sooooo delic!)...and if you want really good deep dish pizza, make a trip to the East Bay and go to Zachs! You'll thank yourself after you do!
author: K R.

description:
i grew up in chicago eating giordano's and edwardo's and lou malnati's and going to good delis. then i came to california and missed two major things: good pizza and good bagels. 
i still have not managed to find a decent bagel in the bay area, but i can happily say that i have found pizza that not just lives up to, but even rivals the deep dish pizza i know and love.
the other two true chicago-style pizza places around here, patxi's and zachary's, are great. i was really impressed with zachary's when i had it for the first time (after being pizza-deprived out here for at least four years). and then when patxi's came to palo alto, i was overjoyed. but then i tried little star. 
little star raises chicago deep dish up to san francisco foodie levels. 
first, the DIY garlic bread was surprising and tasty. when you're waiting the 35-40 minutes for your pizza, you definitely have time to dig your own roasted garlic clove out of the bulb and smear it on buttery sourdough. 
i also had a delicious, very fresh salad. 
but as soon as the pizza arrives, you forget about everything else. i've been twice and have gotten the "little star" with spinach, feta, ricotta, mushrooms, onions and garlic. as a rule, i get spinach-only on my chicago pizza, but the extras really blew me away. the feta and ricotta added a saltiness and a lightness that you don't expect to find when you're downing what is usually an inch-thick wad of melted mozzarella. the tomato sauce on top tasted fresh and perfectly seasoned, and the crust, oh the crust. my chicago-grown friend kept saying "it's the butter, it's the butter." it's way different from crusts i'm used to. it's thick and crunchy and more like dense cornbread than a flaky, crispy edwardo's crust. 
the crust is what truly sets it apart from all the other places. but it also makes you feel so full that you can only bear to eat little star once a month, tops. 
i would have given this place five stars except that it's inconveniently cash-only, and it takes foreeeeeeever to get a table, even on a sunday night. boo. they have a good drink selection, though, and if you're bored and waiting for a table, flip through the jukebox. it's indierock heaven.
author: Molly T.

description: i didn't think i was a fan of deep dish pizza until i ate at little star. i had the little star deep dish (spinach, ricotta, feta, onions, mushrooms, garlic) and it was delicious. the crust has some cornmeal in it which gave it a nice texture.
author: Leuwam T.

description:
I had a really, really strange experience at Little Star tonight. I went in with a friend for dinner and we were enjoying ourselves immensely. I had a glass of wine and a bunch of water and needed to use the facilities. I walked up to the "ladies room" and it was closed. Out of order. End of story. I went up to the front to ask what they would suggest as an alternative and was told to go out into the (cold) San Francisco night to find somewhere to relieve myself. Mind you, this is after the food hit the table and it is just sitting there getting cold. 
I walk out onto Valencia street, head down the block to store after store until FINALLY a neighboring pizza joint let me do my thing. I wander back to Little star, worried that my dear friend is getting bored and worried. I tell the  guy at the front that I feel inconvenienced by the entire situation and that I don't feel like my meal should be interrupted to forage for myself in the night. 
He tells me he will take 50% off the bill to make my experience better.
Great. Fine. 
I go back to my seat and the waitress we had is now trying to rush us out. She comes by every three minutes trying to clear our COLD pizza and acting annoyed that we are now FINALLY having our COLD meal. 
She then tells us she is leaving. 
A new server takes over for her. 
We finish our cold pizza and sip our wine. 
He tries to sell us cheesecake. 
We decline and ask for the bill.
He then comes out, sits down at our table (I fricken HATE that) and tells us that WINK WINK WINK, he arranged with the manager for a discount for us. 
This guy was full of baloney. I ARRANGED WITH THE MANAGER for the discount. He tried to pull it off like he had done some "negotiating" on our part but all he did was bring the bill. 
We paid and gave a tip on the FULL amount. 
We left. 
Great food. Bad vibe. 
I don't know. The whole episode seemed strange to me.
author: Meghan R.

description: Probably the most memorable pizza I have ever had. I was expecting a very doughy crust, but it wasn't! To my pleasant surprise it was like a grainy thin PIE crust that was under tasty tomato sauce, garlic, meat, and cheese! Yum!
author: Suzie V.

description: so bummed.  i was in town visiting my old haunts and so excited for another trip to little star.  the wait was a pain and i was starving so we ordered immediately when we sat down.  the special sounded delicious - cheddar, green onion, bacon and potato. YUM.  the waitress was kinda bitchy  but we let that slide.  we got our salad and garlic bread and waited for our delicious pizza to arrive.  it arrived and the waitress says "i forgot to tell you that we ran out of cheddar so we subbed gorgonzola."  ummm, WTF?  that's a huge taste difference.  i mentioned that i hate gorgonzola and she said "well it was on your salad."  fair enough, except i gave it all to my friend.  so she offered us a thin crust or half off on our pie.  we took the half off b/c i didn't go to little star for thin crust but it was a serious bummer b/c i didn't like it.
author: sarah K.

description: Great deep-dish, delightful service, accurate estimate of the wait time on a busy night.  I would recommend this as a Chicago substitute, but higher-class.
author: Dwight B.

description: this isn't pizza, it's an event.  a small is more than enough for 2 people.  even if you devide it in half and eat your whole half you will be super stuffed afterwards.  we got a small combo to go and ate it with a nice bottle of wine we'd been saving, enjoyed ourselves thoroughly.
author: e w.

description: i came to this location for the first time yesterday and ordered a pizza for takeout.  they do half/half's here, so i got half classic and half veg.  i called at 530 pm, and they said it would be ready in 1/2 an hour, but i wanted to pick it up at 630.  when i arrived at 630, it was ready on the dot, which is a plus.  cash only!
author: Helen T.

description: If it's deep-dish you want, skip this place and head over to Patxi's. Everything--from the sauce to the cheese to the crust--is much better at Patxi's, and you get more of it. They make a mean and dense pizza! The name Little Star is apropos because they give you little, and the crust tastes like scone. Drive over the bridge to Zachary's or head to Patxi's. When it comes to deep-dish, Little Star doesn't even compare to either of those places.
author: Brian W.

description: Our pizza was placed on a rack which was situated on the crack between two small tables.  One small movement of the table sent the pizza spilling on the floor.  We were told that we would have to pay half the price of a pizza for a replacement.  The manager told us that it was our fault.  I have never felt so bad going out to dinner.  What a waste.  I will never go here again.
author: stephen m.

description: pizza tastes good, in my opinion it tastes better than zachary's, i knows that rude to say, but it sort of is.  it does happen to seem to be pizza for (1) apple users (2) graphic designers (3) product designers (4) retards (5) zipcar customers.  i like the fact that its basically next to VG so i hope some people who come here eventually get robbed.
author: christopher a.

description: I went to the Little Star in the Mission on Wednesday night after reading all the great reviews. I have to admit that I am a thin crust fan which might have been my first mistake but the thin crust pizza I ordered was beyond crispy. It was like eating a cracker; think burnt. The pizza was so oily I could barely eat more than one piece. On top of the oil it was over seasoned and as it cooled off the cheese turned rubbery. It was pretty gross. Salad was BORING. The space is crowded and way too LOUD. I could barely talk to my boyfriend. The staff is totally nice but all over the place. Overall I think it was pretty lame.
author: Erin L.

description:
i am a fan of zachory's deep dish pizza in berkeley.  so when i tried little star's deep dish i wasn't expecting too much, i guess thats the secret...

...because their deep dish pizza is damn good.  if you eat it with no expectations you're bound to like it.  i've also tried the thin crsut pizza which is not bad but i won't go to little star without getting a deep dish.

i've always order take out from this place because the ambiance never catches me right.  we're talking about pizza here and it looks like a nightclubb from the outside.  

[insert inside joke here]
if you've never been there...look for a small sign on a place with tinted windows.  the one on the corner! :)
author: Vinyl J.

description: The pizza here was fantastic.  The deep dish barbecue chicken (special of the night) was out of this world.  I cannot highly recommend the food enough.  The service however was hovering.  Like we were asked for our order 8 times in 10 minutes and the restaurant was empty.  The food made it all worthwhile though.  But, this is a commitment restaurant ($$$ or $30/person).  So, it's good - very very good - food, but it's a place for a date.
author: Patrick K.

description: my little star pizza is always delicious. the crowds are annoying so i suggest coming here with only a party of 4 at most. the wait is worth it and i don't mind sitting all cramped up in the corner. the waiter with the sleeve is easy on the eyes, but the gals showing alot of cleavage just didn't go well with my deep dish eating experience. i'm sure my old man would say otherwise.
author: Linda T.

description: this is an ideal place to get a good pizza.  the inside is great for a small group of people, it tends to get a little loud, but after a couple drinks and good food it is easy to overlook that.  they do have a decent wine list and their caprese salad is awesome!  service isn't bad either.
author: Steven K.

description: The cornmeal crust is a nice touch. But otherwise, it's not really that special. And really, really, really, really salty.
author: A. T.

description: little star makes great pizza.  i'm eating a piece of their deep dish classic right now for breakfast, left over from last night, and its delicious.  although i normally like thin crust pizza better, i truly can't decide which is better at little star - their deep dish or thin crust - i particularly like their thin crust white pie.  the pizza is best when you eat at the restaurant (as opposed to take out), and they have a pretty good juke box, which makes the wait more fun.  we ate at the bar last night for the first time which was just as nice as a table.  they also have a quality wine list, which is much appreciated!
author: Erin C.

description: Hands down the best pizza experience I've ever had.  I particularly loved the little nuances, such as chilled glasses for the sodas we had and the  garlic bread, where the garlic was cooked separately and we applied it ourselves onto the bread (yummy!).  And the pizza was delicious, even better than Zachary's - the tomatoes in particular had a real bright flavor to them.  I savored every moment, and I can't wait to go there again.
author: Sean C.

description: So much better than Zachary's! It's not that crowded and service is good. The deep dish pizzas are more tasty than Zachary's because they are perfectly baked (not soggy) and have the right balance of ingredients.
author: Retired B.

description: deep. very deep. and tasty. my roomie and i decided to forgo our usual zante's take out and called in an order to little star one lazy evening. i am sure glad we did ('cause one can only have so much zante's you know!). the delectable pizza sauce and beautifully baked thick and juicy pizza was  a delight to bite into. again and again. so much so that i didn't mind sinking my teeth into a leftover slice for breakfast the next day- a mere hours after my late night dinner. AND the dark windows at little star gives it an air of mystery and mischief... ooh la laaa
author: ray e.

description: i dont know how it could be better than zachary's. i really don't
author: Seiji C.

description: I always enjoy walking into a crowded restaurant to pick up take-away.  I guess I like seeing hungry people jealous of my tasty food.
author: Susie O.

description: First institution to win my just made up 5 slice award of excellence.
author: Travis C.

description: little star rocks so do all the people. deep dish is killer...this crust is killer...its all good. salads,  pizza, all of it. awesometown.
author: kelly M.

description: five stars.  absolutely wonderful.  can't get enough.  personal fav has been the thin crust pesto chicken.  blasphemous i know, since everybody raves about "chicago style".  i have tried both.  i am from california.  i find myself with intense cravings for a single slice often.  the misses love the "do it yourself" garlic bread too.  all love for little star.
author: Ryan H.

description: yum!  i'm not usually a fan of deep dish because it tends to be over-sauced, but little star created a pie with the perfect ratio of crust to sauce to ingredients.  even loaded down with cheese, sauce, and more veggies than you can shake a farmhand at, the crust remained crispy and chewy.  mmm-mmm!  eats like a meal!
author: Aimee C.

description: You might miss this place since the sign is so small. And you might as well miss it because it wasn't special at all. The crust was way too rich, the toppings and salad were plain boring, but and this one but, the cheese was delicous. As a final note, my ears were ringing more after dinner than after a metallica concert. Bring your ear plugs.
author: Sean B.

description:
good delicious chicago style pizza.  never got to try the wine there.  wait is long, but can always do take out. 

yum yum
author: Alex K.

description:
good
- best deep dish pizza in SF, hands down
- good selection of beer
- the wings are awesome, too

bad
- there can be a wait - call ahead and take out instead!
author: Anthony W.

description: thank GOD there's finally a place in SF to get an authentic chicago-style deep dish pizza. thin crust pizza is great too...but i'm ALL about the deep dish pepperoni. other recommendations include their house salad...oh and the cheesecake is DIVINE. props too for serving pretty much the coldest beer in the city. jukebox rules too.
author: dusty d.

description: looking for parking was worth the wait... the classic deep dish is a must try. you know it's good when you look forward to the crust! :)
author: Joyce G.

description: hmmm i always find it so hard to review deep-dish chicago-style pizza places because i was raised on zachary's and am therefore extremely biased and unimpressed with anything else.  (seriously, it gets awkward when i go to chicago and all my relatives try to share with me the best! pizza! ever! ... )  anyway, that being said, i liked this place a lot, i thought the look of it was cool, i like that you can't see in from the outside (makes it seem exciting), the caprese salad was yummy, and the pizza was good!  i split the deep dish little star with a friend (i always like to try things with the name of the restaurant in it if it's there) and they were happy to do half with mushrooms (for me) and half without (for him) and we were both happy campers.  extra points for being so close to me too.
author: ali l.

description: had a very mediocre experience here. took me a few minutes to find the place because they have a tiny sign on the street and their windows are papered up or frosted, whatever. they've got blue ribbon winning beer in a can, in a paperbag; thats pretty sweet. pizza is just okay. i think zachary's deep dish is a lot better. you're kind of squished into a tiny space when you eat in, if you wait about an hour.
author: Al I.

description: My favorite pizza place ever. Don't like the wait but its worth it...great place to spend a few hours with friends to hang out.
author: Catherine H.

description: Man, I was all jazzed about going to this place for so long that I was really disappointment after having dined there. I've been on the quest for the best pizza in all of S.F. for sometime now and everyone kept saying go to Little Star. So its my b-day and my family was in town and we dicide to head to Little Star. When it was determined to head to the Star I was so excited, but after the experience I wished we had went to a better pizza place. Now I knew going in that it was Chicago style and this was my reason for going, I love Chi-town style pizza. But the pizza just lacked the robust taste everyone said it would have. I expected to be in pizza nirvana. Now Little Star isn't all bad, the service was great and my waitress never kept me waiting. I would never go back there unless I was close by and wanted Chicago style pizza. If you want good Chi-town pizza in the city head over to Patxi's in Hayes Valley, you won't be disappointed. Now if you really want the best Chicago style in the Bay Area, there is only one place to go and thats Zachary's in Oakland or Berkeley (Its an EB chain).
author: Paul C.

description: this place is da bomb! the cornmeal crust is new and intriguing for me. the tomatoes taste yummy-licious. if we ask nice, our server said the chefs would make a margherita pizza even though it's not on the menu. wow. that's cool. you gotta be prepared to wait at the bar for your seat, but no big deal right? this place is POPULAR. the food is great, i mean i could take or leave the night-clubby-hip-dinner-joint atmosphere which was kinda loud, because i like conversation during dinner and i'm not trying to be seen at dinner. i'd put this on my regular rotation.
author: Tony L.

description: oh wow did they move to the mission too?i loved this on divis, and i dont even really like pizza. get the homemade garlic bread its off the chain
author: Lauren V.

description: Better than Patxi's, simply YUM-O!  The sauce is flavorful and the whole pie is delish.  Expect a wait for a table on the weekend but worth it!
author: K V.

description: We went here on a Friday nite at 8PM. The hostess told us it would be a 30 min wait. The place is small and cozy and the waiting area is a bit small. After an hour, we finally got our table. So, here's the review. The pros: we ordered a classic and some other pizza, a salad, and garlic bread. The deep dished pizzas were pretty good (gormet compared to all the other deep dish pizzas I've experienced), the salad was just right, and the garlic is different. I am not a fan of their garlic bread (the garlic is roasted and serve separately with the sourdough bread). Overall, the food is decent and the price was reasonable. Now the cons: I don't appreciate being mislead by more than 30 minutes of waiting to get a meal. Let's be real, these people have been doing this for awhile and they have a pretty decent idea how long a wait is and I feel most of the time, they drasitcally underestimate the wait on purpose. Second, the place is not well managed. They need more staff. The hostess doubles as a busboy, clearing and setting tables while the waiting staff is busy running around taking orders, but not really paying any attention to their guests. To be fair, the staff is friendly and try their best, but they need to run this place better and more efficiently. I would come back again.
author: nik t.
