description: The best deep dish pizza I've ever had.  The cornmeal crust is crispy and the filling tastes fresh.  Great for take-out, tastes even better if you eat it there.  I find their salads a little over-dressed and heavy, but not bad.  Nice atmosphere, good wines, and attentive service.
author: Laura L.

description: now i'm not a deep dish lover.  i lived in chicago for a year and only really like uno's and maybe lou malnati's.  but little star is so damn good.  that cornmeal crust.  oh yeah.  the thin crust is ok too but def. not as good as the deep dish.  they have yummy beer too.  this mission location is only better because you don't have to wait as long for a table.  don't even talk to me about zachary's.  gross.
author: a g.

description: This place rocks!  I'm not usually a big fan of deep dish pizza because the crust is usually so doughy and thick but Little Star serves a deep dish pizza with a thin, cornmeal crust that's really tasty (I especially like the spinach, garlic, ricotta pizza with added anchovies).  They also have a good tomato, mozarella salad.   I don't know if they take reservations but if they do, I'd definitely call ahead.  We went on a thursday at 8:30pm and it was an hour wait for 2 people - luckily, there's a really cool bar nearby called Fly Bar that you can hang out at while you wait.  Be aware that Little Star only takes cash.
author: Amanda L.

description: I really really like Little Star deep dish pizza. Tonight, my husband and I went quite early in order to beat the crowds and eat lots of carbs and fat. We arrived at about 6:20, sat down, looked and the menu, and then realized that happy hour would be over in 2 minutes or so. At which point my husband went up to the bar, tried to order a drink, and was told by a super unfriendly bartender that in fact it was 6:31 and so he could no longer order drinks at happy hour prices. WTF? So, on principle, we didn't order drinks and we thought this was really lame. This same bartender was totally bitchy later on when we tried to leave the check and our cash with her-- she pretty much refused to take it.  So, I don't know that we will be going back here due to this experience. There are plenty of other friendlier places to get pizza in the mission....
author: Michele F.

description: I'm from Chicago and lived on deep dish pizza.  This isn't quite as good as what you will find in Chicago, but it's pretty damn good, especially if you haven't been to Chicago in a while.  It's more "Chicago-style" than Zachary's.
author: Tom Z.

description:
Maybe my 3 stars aren't fair because I'm truly a thin crust girl. Either way, this place is overrated.
First of all, my pizza got soggy really fast. I don't know if that's necessarily their fault. I thought the cornmeal is meant to prevent that, but it definitely does not make good leftovers. Some parts of my pizza had just way too much sauce. The sausage that they use is really good, though. Overall, the pizza was good and I would eat there again if someone was taking me there and paying.
I can't believe they don't take card. To me, that is seriously unacceptable. It's a pizza place, an expensive one! Non-acceptance of cards is only (almost) okay for places that sell small things, like candy stores, coffee shops, places that will lose a somewhat substantial amount to card fees. It's not okay for Little Star Pizza to not take cards, where the average tab must be at least $20-25.
Okay, so that's a general rant against places that don't take plastic, but the pizza is also pretty expensive and probably just not worth it.
author: R D.

description: We are devoted neighborhood regulars and I cannot possibly add much to the fantastic reviews below (fab food, service, etc.), but I have an itty-bitty gripe. Little Star used to have these great coasters; they were thick and heavy with great images under a plastic coating - they're gone!! They've been replaced with too-light glass ones that stick to the bottom of frosty pint glasses and embarrass uncool folks like me in front of the all the hipsters when they drop off my drink into my pizza plate - clash!!. Apparently the old coasters were worn out, but couldn't there be a more artful, heavy, less embarrassment-inducing replacement?
author: Old D.

description: pizza is good hard to park bring your mace the neighborhood is not nice at night
author: james b.

description: i went here on a date in spring of 2007.  it was a bad date, but the pizza was so good i kept going back.  i'm not a fan of deep dish, but i enjoy the deep dish at little star (zachary's in berkeley is better, i usually make my own thin crust.  so yummy :)
author: Jennifer K.

description: If you are a true pizza lover this may not be the place for you. There is no wood oven and the dough/sauce is good, but not great. If you are looking for a fun place to eat decent pizza without spending too much money then this is an excellent choice. Creative toppings, good appetizers, hip look, and you can actually find tasty wines for less than $30 which is rare. It is difficult to find deep dish pizzas in the Bay Area  and Little Star's is delicious. It is 100% comparable to Zachary's in the East Bay.
author: Sean R.

description: Can you get any better than this joint?  Pauline's Pizza definitely gives it a run for it's money, but either way, pizza lovers are in heaven along a one block stretch that separates the two.  What's the deal here?  Deep dish..all deep dish.  Plus, if you decide to hang out and eat there, it is dimly lit and oozing with vibe.  And the juke box is primed with excellent tunes that represents the next best thing to a 70's freeform radio dude. Last thing, not the best place to bring young kids; definitely better if you up for gazing into one another's eyes.  Holla!
author: Kevin C.

description: I ordered Vegetarian and the pizza was very tasty. But I am not a fan of the cornbread crust. I still think zachary's in berkeley/oakland for the best deep dish. Granted we have to cross the bridge and pay $4 toll.
author: Venkat N.

description:
absolutely delicious.  cornmeal crust deep dish is amazing.  bonus that "the little star" pizza is vegetarian.

they also hit all of the details that make for an excellent experience.  

frosty beer glass:  Check!
great music: check! (bonus that it is a juke box)
fresh grated cheese in the shakers: check!
water on the table: check!

i will definately go back.
author: Andy P.

description: Lots of hipsters, but great pizza.  Crispy, cornmeal crust on deep dish...
author: Gary W.

description: Great food, but our server was the rudest ! She rushed us through the entire meal, and took my plate away before I was finished! I would rather stick a fork in my eyeball then go back there again.
author: christina r.

description: this place has some of the best pizza i have ever had. went there with some friends last night. five people shared two large pizzas and it was plenty of food, and cheap too. we tried one thin crust and one deep dish and both were fantastic. cool setting, good music, and excellent service.
author: Lauren D.

description: Two of us had a large deep dish pizza and it was awesome.  The deep dish is nothing like the greasy Chicago style.  Hands down one of the best pizzas.
author: Katie W.

description: One of the best deep dish pizzas in SF. The Little Star Special is amazing.   If you like Spinach, Tomatoes and a thick crispy crust, it doesn't get any better than this. The "No Seating Until the Entire Party is Here" policy is annoying and getting a seat after 7 on a weekend is a task but the excellent food and friendly service makes up for it. Go early and try the Little Star Special.
author: F K.

description: Yum, Yum, Yum. Great food, great service, great wine. What a fantastic place! Oh great decor too! :)
author: D H.

description: MMMM. Sausage Mush deep dish....perfect as always....some kind of magic...probably illegal in the remaining contiguous 48...
author: betty r.

description: It's been said before, but the pizza here is fresh and delicious. You have a choice of deep dish or thin crust. The service is friendly, and the wine and beer selection is very good.
author: Marlene S.

description: I went here for my birthday and I thought the pizza was excellent, the garlic bread was tasty. The only thing i thought that marked it down to 4 stars was the service. I thought it was rude of them to tell us to leave so they can seat the other people. That was the only down fall.
author: L G.

description: I absolutely LOVE little star pizza and would highly recommend to anyone!  HOWEVER, the last time I was there, we had the worst service I have ever had...  Our waitress was extremely unhelpful while we were trying to decide on a pizza and how much to order.  She also tried rushing us along with the bill at the end before we were even done eating!  She placed the bill on our table while we all still had food on our plates and when she came back and saw that it was empty threw it back on the table.  I told her we would pay when we were finished Eating!  It was a Saturday, so it was busy, but not as busy as a typical Saturday.  She also told us that once we ordered one deep dish we couldnt order another...yet we saw other tables sit down long after we did who were still ordering deep dish.  I'm not sure what her problem was, but this will prevent me from going to this Little Star ever again!  The hostess was great as was the bartender.  And of course the pizza was delish, but she tainted all of our experiences...  So you might want to steer clear of the Little Star in the Mission if youre looking for great service.
author: Emily T.

description: oh my god, heaven on earth.  it is so yummy here!!! i normally dont even like tomato chunks but i love this pizza.   it is so good!  a little loud and crowded so dont go if your in a hurry or want an intimate spot.  but if you can wait the lines it is worth every minute.  i reccomend the little srar.  im a vegi, but even my meat eater friend love this pizza.
author: Laura K.

description: My friend and I came here on a weeknight, so the crowd was minimal. First off, the service: it was swell. The guy who tended to us was very down to earth in his style and conversation, and I liked that. For some reason, it was very appealing to be served by a real guy's guy. As for the pizza, the two of us handily split a small deep dish vegetarian pizza, which was more than enough for the both of us. What really impressed me was the Caprese salad. I tried a Caprese at another restaurant (in North Beach, no less!) but it was runny and didn't compare to here. I haven't been to the other Little Star, but I like the ambience at this one. Dim and intimate, good for a date but also as an outing with a friend or a handful of friends. I was thrown by the cash only payment, and although there was an ATM on premises, I don't like paying the extra fees for non-bank transactions, and I found it odd that such an evidently-established restaurant like this couldn't honor even my debit card. Otherwise, you should definitely give Little Star at Valencia a shot.
author: Joseph R.

description: nopa was packed as usual so we decided to head to little star. convinced the bf to get the thin crust (my preference) and decided on the Classic - Sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bell peppers. very yummy it really hit the spot. also had their "movie star" which is champagne with ginger beer and a ginger candy at the bottom. very yummy. a little too yummy. i was chuggin it like soda.  between the two of us we got the small and we had half the pizza left over and was stuffed. plus we started with the caprese salad which wasn't bad as well.
author: B H.

description: wow, this place is great! had the meat version and also the veggie deep dish... the pizza was just stuffed! the crust crumbles in your mouth.. the place is kinda small.. and very loud...be prepared to shout when talking., the wait surprising was fast..then again, we went early on Sunday night.. go and check out the place!
author: Linda Y.

description: i heart Little Star!  this is the best deep-dish pizza in town.  we rave about this place to everyone; they said we had to try Zachary's...we did...it wasn't even close!  that cornmeal crust makes a huge difference!  we always get take-out from there as their location is a bit small and its always packed.  im hoping they will expand their hours to accommodate lunch cravings (they open at 5pm) our favorite it the deep-dish classic, but event the regular crust white pie (vegetarian) is just as good!
author: Rene V.

description: i think this place is better than zachary's. their pizza's pretty tasty with good ingredients and the crust is great and flaky. i don't know how to critique pizza but i know their pizza is very good.
author: Kan L.

description: excellent deep dish chicago style pizza; perfect flaky crust (a little oily which I LOVE); sublime tomatoe sauce; if you call in your order, they are always on schedule, and the staff who answers the phone will put you in a fabulous mood---even if there is a fine line between hunger and anger! phenomenal homemade cheesecake. (as if i need more calories after indulging in a big, yummy pizza!)
author: Michelle P.

description: i like the dark elusive quality to it and the sleek romantic atmosphere not so common for a pizza place. and i like the comfortable blue couch in the bar waiting area where one can enjoy a prosecco among friends- but i'm just not in to the "sauce on top" idea, mostly because it's in such ridiculous abundance, and thus overwhelmingly tomatoey.  i like to be able to see my carefully chosen and aesthetically pleasing additions. how do i know if i'm about to bite into a garlic cross-section slab or a diced garlic chunk? i need to know these things in advance. and, it just seems oddly unneccesary. its like putting your socks on outside of your shoes. textures in chaotic disarray.  the crust IS good however. that buttery crisp edge is like a quiche crust but olive oilier. The fresh mozzarella appetizer was amazing, much better than the pizza.and i hear they make their own cheese  which gives it more points. and since the service was excellent, and i have a hunch the thin crust option is better,  i may give them another try- the location is just too optimal.
author: little gem z.

description: pizza was decent, the atmosphere was bright an lively the customer service was lacking.
author: joe j.

description: The Valencia Street location is much quieter than the original locale, but something makes me think the pizza is a bit different too.  While the Divisadero spot is just phenomenally delicious, the new venue's pizza is just slightly under a five star rating.  Whether this locale's cooks who are not yet versed in the particulars of "little star pizza making" the crust is still as buttery good as its parent but the sauce can vary from day to day.   The chicken wings are great at both spots and the beer and wine lists are relatively above average for a pizza shop.  I tend to only order the deep dish pizza as the thin sliced just doesn't do it for me like Pizzetta 211, Pizzeria Delfina or Pizzaiolo.   And one wish, "Littlestar take a darn ATM or charge card please!  Whatever happened to a chashless society??!!"  That's a really small quibble and don't you let this stop you from exploring this great pizza joint.  Just bring your cash.
author: scott m.
